headline: ­Recreation and Commerce Collide on New York’s Crowded Waterways

headline: Brazil’s Ousted President
abstract: The new president faces the tough task of restoring Brazilians’ faith in their scandal-plagued political class.
lead_paragraph: Brazil has had four elected presidents since democracy was restored in 1985. Two served out their terms. On Wednesday, Dilma Rousseff was the second to be ousted while in office amid political upheaval and allegations of wrongdoing.

headline: Spokesman’s Death Will Have Islamic State Turning to Its ‘Deep Bench’
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Targeted Killings', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Though a lethal drone strike demonstrates progress against the militant group, ISIS has proved to be remarkably resilient and well prepared for the succession of key figures.

keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'Global Warming']

headline: Caroline Wozniacki Rallies From Early Deficit to Win
abstract: Wozniacki, down by 0-4, love-30 in the first set, defeated ninth-seeded Svetlana Kuznetsova, 6-4, 6-4.
lead_paragraph: From the player’s box at Arthur Ashe Stadium, Piotr Wozniacki was desperately trying to calm his daughter down below. His signals were nothing fancy or too intricate. Just palms down: Take it easy. Hands pushing forward: Move up toward the baseline during rallies.

headline: Dr. Joy Browne, Long-Running Psychologist of the Airwaves, Dies at 71

headline: Anthony Weiner, Who Always Had Something to Say, Goes Silent

headline: Having a Variable Identity
abstract: A very modern theme by Ben Tausig.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — It’s very hard to be an objective judge of a puzzle when the theme affects you personally, so I’ll just admit that Ben Tausig’s puzzle struck me right in the heart. And it’s not just because it manages to pull off a really neat constructing trick called a Schrödinger theme (described below), but also because I have a young adult child who happens to be GENDER FLUID. And this concept of gender existing on a continuum instead of a binary (male or female only) is the theme of our crossword puzzle today.

headline: French Group Suspends Three Players for Unprofessional Behavior
abstract: Three young French players seeded at the United States Open — Benoit Paire, Kristina Mladenovic and Caroline Garcia — have all been provisionally suspended by the French tennis federation.
lead_paragraph: Tennis is said to have taken its name from the French word “tenez,” and the sport’s vocabulary has been built around the French language since its origins. But right now, the most appropriate term to describe the rising generation of French tennis players may be “enfants terribles.”

headline: All Impeachments Are Political. But Was Brazil’s Something More Sinister?

headline: Brooklyn Man Recalls 2013 Beating and His Pleas for Help

lead_paragraph: A few days after Thanksgiving 2013, a woman was driving down Flushing Avenue in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, when suddenly, lurching from the street, a man ran toward her car, banging on her window and hollering for help. It was nearly 4:30 a.m. The man was young, black, terrified. The woman kept driving but quickly placed a call to 911.

headline: ‘Mr. Robot’ Season 2, Episode 9: A Bad Dream
abstract: This week’s episode carried over its predecessor’s horror-movie vibe.
lead_paragraph: Sure, the “Full House” meets “ALF” mash-up sequence from two episodes ago got the most ink. (Understandably!) But when it comes to painstaking recreations of outmoded aesthetics, the show’s slasher parody “The Careful Massacre of the Bourgeoisie” is clearly the retro Rosetta stone for “Mr. Robot.” While no one was murdered onscreen, this week’s episode carried over its predecessor’s horror-movie vibe, and then some. Flickering lights, dark hallways, doppelgängers, menacing knocks at the door, a generalized sense of impending doom: “eps2.7_init_5.fve” was about as creepy as you can get without a serial killer or supernatural entity stalking the cast.

headline: Can Trump Win on Native Soil?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Speeches and Statements', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: His campaign sees a path to victory that runs through Mexico, but a look at New Hampshire tells us more about his chances on Election Day.
lead_paragraph: Before setting off on Wednesday to visit Enrique Peña Nieto, the president of Mexico, Donald Trump appeared to be making a feint toward equivocation on immigration and trade. But with less than 10 weeks to go before Election Day, a blustering Trump told an expectant audience in Arizona that he wasn’t reneging on his signature promise. After failing to address the issue with Peña Nieto in a serious way — bringing back nothing concrete and providing no further details — he blithely told a rally in Phoenix:

headline: Explaining What Donald Trump Wants to Do Now on Immigration
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Immigration Detention', 'Deportation']
abstract: His proposals include ending so-called sanctuary cities, assembling a deportation task force, maintaining “zero tolerance for criminal aliens” and putting up a wall.
lead_paragraph: With calls to end so-called sanctuary cities, create a deportation task force and maintain “zero tolerance for criminal aliens,” Donald J. Trump laid out a 10-point immigration plan on Wednesday in Phoenix that reverted to the tough, uncompromising talk on the issue that has powered his appeal to his strongest supporters. While he is no longer talking about immediately deporting the estimated 11 million people in the United States illegally, he also distanced himself from any notion that they could gain legal status anytime soon.

headline: Traveling Alone, With Help
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Automobile Renting and Leasing', 'Roads and Traffic']
abstract: From Las Vegas to Los Angeles, thanks to several strangers.
lead_paragraph: I was driving through the Nevada desert on a hot morning in late July, going from Las Vegas to Los Angeles in a brand-new silver Nissan Versa. This was my first time driving in the United States and my first time driving an automatic car. I had asked for a manual transmission, but the rental agency didn’t have one. In my country, Argentina, everyone drives a manual.

headline: How to Tickle Someone
abstract: Be unpredictable. Keep things consensual.
lead_paragraph: “Stop, start again, be surprising,” says Marina Davila-Ross, a professor at Britain’s University of Portsmouth who studies laughter and play. Unpredictability is the key element of tickling, which is why you cannot tickle yourself. Brains are prediction machines; if your own hand reaches in for a tickle, your brain will foresee and cancel out the results. (Research shows that some schizophrenics are able to tickle themselves because they don’t make the same distinctions between self and other.) Davila-Ross has tickled humans, chimpanzees, bonobos, orangutans and gorillas, and she says sometimes just the pretouch anticipation evokes laughter. Only the great apes regularly tickle one another, although many animals, including rats, cats and dogs, enjoy it. (In one study, rats kept in social isolation and exposed to regular electrical shocks exhibited less fear and lower catecholamine stress hormones when tickled daily by a researcher.)

headline: A Midtown Apartment, the Opposite of Nice and Quiet

headline: The Crispy Decadence of the Patty Melt

headline: What to Consider Before Renting a Vacation Home
abstract: Want to rent a home for your next vacation? Make sure you have a gathering space, service contacts and smoke and carbon monoxide detectors.
lead_paragraph: Renting a home on your next vacation could make for a dream trip or, depending on the home you rent, turn out to be one that’s full of headaches, according to Cathy Ross, the chief executive of Exclusive Resorts, a Denver-based membership vacation company that offers home rentals. “You’re most likely choosing by looking at pictures and a description online,” she said, “but there’s so much more to be aware of that you can’t necessarily see or read about.”

headline: Waiting for Cancer
abstract: Taking a DNA test for fun, then finding yourself on permanent standby, just waiting for cancer.
lead_paragraph: With cancer, there are generally two scenarios – you either have it or you don’t. But I am somewhere in the middle, stuck inside a vortex. I don’t have cancer, but as a notable breast surgeon told me, “For you, it’s not a matter of if you’ll get it, but when.” And so I find myself on permanent standby… just waiting.

headline: Have Three Weeks for a Vacation? There Are Trips for You
keywords: ['Paid Time Off', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: Travel companies are offering trips that span three weeks or more, with destinations including New Zealand, Alaska and Greece.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, a week of vacation just isn’t enough, and travelers who can spare the time for a longer getaway have plenty of choices: Travel companies are increasingly offering itineraries that span three weeks or more. Here are a few of them.

headline: TV Takes a Prime-Time Chance: Kooky Comedy
abstract: NBC, Fox and ABC, dogged by cable, are gambling this season on outside-the-box comedies and quirky niche shows.
lead_paragraph: BURBANK, Calif. — It was early afternoon on the set of “The Good Place” here, and the cast had scattered — Ted Danson to his trailer for a costume change, Kristen Bell to hers for hair extensions — leaving the creator of this new comedy, Mike Schur, to enlighten me on its embrace of wild and just plain weird visual effects.

headline: New York Today: Wonders on Our Walls
abstract: Thursday: Must-see murals, a unicycle festival and cicadas in the city.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:56 a.m.

headline: DealBook Morning Agenda: Challenging Gender Bias, Potential for Bank Mergers and Dashed Tech Dreams
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Legal Profession', 'Start-ups', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Female lawyers are increasingly pushing back when they think their employers are favoring men and penalizing women.
lead_paragraph: “Women are no longer going to be cowed into believing that they have to stay silent or suffer the label that says ‘undesirable colleague.’ ” — Michele Coleman Mayes, chairwoman of the American Bar Association’s commission on women in the profession.

headline: Chicago Has Its Deadliest Month in About Two Decades
abstract: By midnight on Wednesday, 90 murders had occurred in August, as the city has experienced more homicides this year than Los Angeles and New York combined.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — In a city wrestling with a rise in gun violence and turmoil in its police department, August seemed like the longest month. By midnight on Wednesday, 90 murders had occurred in August alone, making it the deadliest month in Chicago in about 20 years.

headline: Reopening of Miami Beach’s Bass Museum Is Delayed
abstract: The museum is now scheduled to reopen in 2017 after a $12 million renovation project.
lead_paragraph: Because of construction delays, the Bass contemporary art museum in Miami will reopen in the spring of 2017 rather than on Dec. 1, the museum announced on Thursday.

headline: Daniel Silva: By the Book
abstract: The author of the Gabriel Allon thrillers, including the latest, “The Black Widow,” loves F. Scott Fitzgerald and named his son Nicholas after Nick Carraway from “The Great Gatsby.” But his daughter is Lily — “not Daisy or Jordan or Myrtle.”
lead_paragraph: The author of the Gabriel Allon thrillers, including the latest, “The Black Widow,” loves F. Scott Fitzgerald and named his son Nicholas after Nick Carraway from “The Great Gatsby.” But his daughter is Lily — “not Daisy or Jordan or Myrtle.”

headline: A ‘Better Trump’ and the Future of the Republican Party
abstract: A weekly politics chat looks at what Donald Trump could be doing now to cut into his polling deficit, and what he could have done from the very start.
lead_paragraph: Each week, Nate Cohn, The Upshot’s elections analyst, based in Washington, and Toni Monkovic, an Upshot editor in New York, discuss the 2016 race and post a lightly edited transcript of their written exchange.

headline: Hundreds of Pounds Lighter, and Now Shedding Another Burden of the Past
abstract: Paul Mason, once known by the dismaying title of the world’s fattest man, had the second of two surgeries to eliminate the excess skin enveloping his body.
lead_paragraph: Losing 650 pounds is a remarkable achievement, but it does not mean the end of your troubles.

headline: Cosmic Correspondent for a Day — and What a Day!
keywords: ['Planets', 'Solar System', 'Stars and Galaxies', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Kepler Space Telescope']
abstract: “Truthfully, I hadn’t been following the galactic planet chase all that closely. But Dennis Overbye was on vacation, so Proxima b was MY story.”
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares insights into how we work at The New York Times. In this piece, Kenneth Chang, a Science reporter for The Times, describes what it was like to venture beyond the edge of our solar system (where his beat usually ends).

headline: Why Is Turkey Accusing Me of Plotting a Coup?
keywords: ['United States International Relations', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat"]
abstract: Turkish anti-Americanism is out of control. President Obama must try to put a stop to it before it’s too late.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On the night of July 15, elements of the Turkish military attempted a coup. It was a poorly organized effort that was defeated by a combination of people power, loyal units and serendipity. What made this failed effort remarkable was the putschists’ extreme brutality against civilians who resisted or happened to be in their way. Some 240 people were killed.

headline: Does Germany Understand Its Own Strength?
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: A year ago, the country opened its door to refugees. It still doesn’t know what to do next.
lead_paragraph: HAMBURG, Germany — Sometime during the night of Sept. 4, 2015 — a year ago this weekend — Chancellor Angela Merkel made a simple, historic decision. Because she didn’t want to become responsible for violence and possibly death at her country’s border, she ordered the German government — and by extension, German society — to take in thousands of refugees who had been sent westward by Hungary’s prime minister, Viktor Orban.

headline: Bags of Cocaine Worth $56 Million Are Found at Coca-Cola Factory in France
abstract: The cocaine amounted to 370 kilograms and was stowed in a shipment of orange juice concentrate to the plant in the town of Signes.
lead_paragraph: Uncovering a drug-smuggling operation with a French connection, workers at a Coca-Cola factory in southern France this week found a huge cache of cocaine worth approximately $56 million in a shipment of orange juice concentrate, according to news reports.

headline: Georgetown University Plans Steps to Atone for Slave Past
abstract: The school, which in 1838 profited from the sale of 272 slaves, plans to award preferential status in the admissions process to descendants of slaves.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nearly two centuries after Georgetown University profited from the sale of 272 slaves, it will embark on a series of steps to atone for the past, including awarding preferential status in the admissions process to descendants of the enslaved, university officials said Thursday.

headline: Hong Kong Independence Movement Contests Beijing at the Polls
abstract: A new, youthful force, supporting some degree of greater self-determination for Hong Kong, may acquire a small measure of actual power in the election on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Sixtus Leung sees no hope for Hong Kong if it sticks with its current political system, which has governed it since the former British colony reverted to Chinese rule in 1997.

headline: Reader Idea | Thinking Critically About How We Engage With News Events Online and in Social Media
abstract: This Reader Idea centers on teaching students how to generate — and foster — thoughtful inquiry in responding to events in our world.
lead_paragraph: Our week of Reader Ideas continues with this submission from Kate Harris.

headline: With Mother Teresa Set to Be Canonized, Her Work Lives On in the Streets
abstract: Her Missionaries of Charity religious congregation has continued to grow, serving the poor around the world, and just outside the seat of the Roman Catholic Church.
lead_paragraph: ROME — With their blue-trimmed white saris, the sisters are a discreet but distinctive presence on the streets at night, offering solace to the destitute and, when possible, a place to stay.

headline: China’s ‘Core Socialist Values,’ the Song-and-Dance Version
abstract: In Hunan Province, the authorities have come up with 20 “square dance” routines to extol qualities like patriotism, dedication and equality.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The 12 “core socialist values” are memorized by schoolchildren, featured in college entrance exams, printed on stamps and lanterns, and splashed on walls across China. Now they have made their way into 20 song-and-dance routines that the authorities in Hunan Province plan to promote to the country’s millions of “square dancers,” the mostly middle-aged and older women who gather in public squares to perform in unison.

headline: Refugees’ Lives ‘Stripped of Meaning’ by Detention, Australian Author Says
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Immigration Detention', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Richard Flanagan described the suffering by refugees and asylum seekers held on the islands of Nauru and Manus as so extreme that it has been compared to torture.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — One of Australia’s leading authors used a speech on Thursday at a prominent literary gathering to rebuke the government for its policies on refugees and asylum seekers held offshore, describing their suffering as so extreme it has been compared to torture.

headline: Want a Job in British Banking? You May Have to Ditch the Brown Shoes
abstract: A report said that some managers placed as much importance on whether a potential hire fit the polished image of an investment banker as on their skills and qualifications.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The right pair of oxfords can make or break a potential job candidate in staid investment banking circles in Britain, according to a report released on Thursday.

headline: ‘Moulin Rouge’ Is Headed for the Stage
abstract: Alex Timbers is attached to direct an adaptation of Baz Luhrmann’s movie musical.
lead_paragraph: If the production company Global Creatures has its way, Baz Luhrmann’s cancan will dance-dance to the stage.

headline: Hurricane Hermine, Landing in Florida, Batters Tiny Towns
abstract: The hurricane hit land in the northwestern part of the state. The storm, which has weakened, is expected to soak Georgia and the Carolinas.
lead_paragraph: SUWANNEE, Fla. — The first hurricane to hit Florida in 11 years, Hermine, made landfall early Friday, touching down as a Category 1 Gulf Coast storm in the northwestern part of the state before weakening and heading to Georgia.

headline: SpaceX Rocket Explodes at Launchpad in Cape Canaveral
abstract: The fiery blast also destroyed a satellite that Facebook had planned to use to expand internet services in Africa.
lead_paragraph: A spectacular explosion of a SpaceX rocket on Thursday destroyed a $200 million communications satellite that would have extended Facebook’s reach across Africa, dealing a serious setback to Elon Musk, the billionaire who runs the rocket company.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: The Sick Traveler
abstract: A 50-year-old woman has fevers and vomiting after visiting her family in Kenya. Can you figure out why?
lead_paragraph: The Challenge: A 50-year-old woman feels tired and feverish after a trip to her home in Kenya. Can you figure out why?

headline: Pamela Adlon Is Starring in Her Very Own Zen Riddle
abstract: With help from Louis C.K., Ms. Adlon has her own show on FX, “Better Things,” loosely based on her real life as a divorced mother of three working in Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: Somewhere on the 101 Freeway in Los Angeles, as Pamela Adlon shuttled herself among a voice-recording session for one TV show she works on, an editing session for another and school registration for her middle daughter, she decided it was an opportune moment to call me and talk about her new FX comedy, “Better Things.”

headline: Coed Duets Return Female Voices to Country Playlists
abstract: Male-female duets are making a comeback in country music, though the woman’s side of the equation is now often sung by a pop singer.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this summer, Dierks Bentley introduced his duet partner, Elle King, to a football stadium full of country fans who had traveled to Nashville for the C.M.A. Music Festival. George Jones and Tammy Wynette they were not: Mr. Bentley epitomized coltish, clean-cut country stardom, spending much of his set bounding around the stage in a T-shirt and jeans, while Ms. King, who had a Hot 100 hit last year with the retro rocker “Ex’s & Oh’s,” wore blue hair and had heavily inked arms. They performed the broody ballad “Different for Girls,” about how men and women deal with the pain of a breakup, side by side.

headline: Fatal Beating of Polish Man Fuels Debate Over Xenophobia in Britain
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Discrimination', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Hate Crimes']
abstract: As the police investigate whether the killing of Arkadiusz Jozwik, 40, was motivated by hate, Poland’s ambassador expressed alarm.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Two Polish immigrants were eating takeout pizza against a brick wall on a muggy night in Harlow, a working-class town about 20 miles northeast of central London.

headline: What an Undocumented Immigrant Wanted to Tell Donald Trump
abstract: A groundskeeper who came to the U.S. two decades ago stood outside the Phoenix hall where the candidate spoke and shared some thoughts of his own.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — He had heard about Donald J. Trump’s trip here on the news the night before and wondered: What if I could meet him? José Enrique Camacho had so much to tell Mr. Trump, but, “if I could say only one thing,” he said, “I’d tell him about how proud I am that my children, my family, are part of this country.”

headline: A Summer Music School for Stars, Amateurs and Students
abstract: A mix of classical-music lovers gathered for concerts and classes at the Dartington International Summer School and Festival in Devon, England.
lead_paragraph: DEVON, England — Medieval manor houses often come with ghosts, and Dartington — a 14th-century estate in rural Devon — no doubt has its share. But they don’t rest in peace during the summer.

headline: Move Over, Marble: Plaster Gets Pride of Place
abstract: Dozens of plaster casts, many among the finest examples of their kind, have found a home at the Institute of Classical Architecture & Art in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: THE discus thrower was missing his head and hands. The horse was blackened with grime and had a chipped ear. And poor St. Francis of Assisi — he was little more than a pile of rubble.

headline: Review: In ‘Narcos’ Season 2, Pablo Escobar’s Time Is Running Out
abstract: This Netflix series picks up the story of the Colombian drug lord where Season 1 left off, with the kingpin trying to keep his empire intact.
lead_paragraph: The least interesting man in the world — stay with me; that’s actually a compliment — is back. Yes, it’s time for more “Narcos,” with Wagner Moura again portraying Pablo Escobar as the doughiest, least expressive kingpin you’ll ever meet — he’s the visual opposite of the old Dos Equis pitchman, and he’s peddling something far more potent. (“Saturday Night Live” should order up a parody that ends with Escobar at a cocaine-covered table urging, “Stay jacked, my friends.”)

lead_paragraph: By the end of Thursday’s matches at the U.S. Open, the roof at Arthur Ashe Stadium was no longer a novelty. It was a necessity.

headline: Retiree Awarded $15.6 Million in Reported Ponzi Scheme Tied to MetLife
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Ponzi and Pyramid Schemes', 'Life Insurance']
abstract: After an eight-week trial, a Los Angeles jury awarded the retiree, Christine Ramirez, punitive and compensatory damages.
lead_paragraph: A Los Angeles jury on Wednesday said MetLife and two of its affiliates should pay $15.6 million to a woman who said she was swindled in a reported Ponzi scheme  that had links to a MetLife insurance agent.

headline: Video Review: The Nissan Titan Takes on the Big Boys
abstract: American automakers dominate the pickup truck market, but Nissan hopes to chip away at that by introducing the first new Titan since 2003.
lead_paragraph: UNLIKE in the car market, American brands rule the full-size pickup market in the United States; the Detroit Three sold more than two million vehicles combined in 2015. On average, Ford sells more F-150s in a week than Nissan Titan sold all year.

headline: 1941: Japan Seeks Peace With U.S.
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: Japan seeks peace with the U.S. in September 1941.
lead_paragraph: TOKIO — As the European war enters its third year, Japan has abandoned hope of an early termination of the conflict. A feeling of having been let down by German promises of a quick conclusion was noticeable here today. The Japanese have become aware of the necessity of adopting ‘‘realistic’’ diplomacy instead of ‘‘idealistic.’’ The announcement that Japan is negotiating with the United States for a settlement of Far Eastern issues has created a problem for the government from the point of view of public peace and order. — New York Herald Tribune, Sept. 2, 1941

headline: 1966: Desegregation in Trouble
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: The U.S. Office of Education struggles with desegregation guidelines enforcement in September 1966.
lead_paragraph: MONTGOMERY — As public schools prepare to reopen, it is increasingly clear that the U.S. Office of Education has serious enforcement problems with desegregation guidelines throughout the Deep South. Resistance to the guidelines has been so strong in hard-core segregationist areas that in a great majority of cases the Education Office has accepted token compliance rather than invoke Title 6 of the 1964 Civil Rights Act and withdraw federal assistance. As a result, more than 96 percent of some 1,500,000 Negro pupils in Alabama, Georgia, Mississippi, Louisiana and South Carolina will be attending all-Negro schools as they return to classes. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 2, 1966

headline: Violence After Gabon Elections Leaves One Dead
abstract: Security forces in the West African nation clashed with opposition supporters after the declaration of a second term for President Ali Bongo Ondimba.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Postelection violence in Gabon left one person dead on Thursday after officials declared the incumbent president, Ali Bongo Ondimba, the winner in a race that the opposition said had been marked by fraud.

headline: A Call From Outer Space, or a Cosmic Wrong Number?
keywords: ['Extraterrestrial Life', 'Stars and Galaxies', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Telescopes and Observatories']
abstract: Everybody plans to keep looking, but for now the radio signal from the constellation Hercules seems destined to join the other false alarms.
lead_paragraph: It’s probably just a piece of cosmic spam, the astrophysical equivalent of butt dialing. But nobody really knows for sure.

keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Dolls', 'Education (K-12)', 'Parenting', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Teenage Pregnancy', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: A teen pregnancy prevention program has unintended results.
lead_paragraph: For more than two decades, educators with high hopes of preventing teen pregnancy have assigned their students computerized baby dolls, programmed to cry, coo, and make life complicated, just like a real baby.

headline: African Elephant Population Dropped 30 Percent in 7 Years
abstract: The decline is accelerating: Largely because of poaching, the African elephant population is dropping 8 percent a year.
lead_paragraph: The African elephant population is in drastic decline, having shrunk about 30 percent from 2007 to 2014, according to a survey published this week.

headline: Depression Is Poorly Diagnosed and Often Goes Untreated
keywords: ['Depression (Mental)', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'ANTIDEPRESSANTS', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation']
abstract: About 8.4 percent of Americans interviewed in a study had depression, but of those, only 28.7 percent had received any treatment.
lead_paragraph: Using data from a survey that screened more than 46,000 Americans for depression, researchers found evidence that the condition is not properly diagnosed in many people. And even when diagnosed correctly, depression often goes untreated.

headline: Tunneling Under the Border With Mexico
abstract: On the U.S.-Mexico border, a large fence has done little to deter enterprising drug smugglers. In Nogales, Ariz., they’ve been digging out tunnels for years in order to cross the border undetected.
lead_paragraph: On the U.S.-Mexico border, a large fence has done little to deter enterprising drug smugglers. In Nogales, Ariz., they’ve been digging out tunnels for years in order to cross the border undetected.

headline: Do Those Travel Search Results Look Fishy? Here’s Why
abstract: Searches on sites like Google Maps, Yelp and TripAdvisor are often wildly different. Blame it on visibility, algorithms and, yes, commerce.
lead_paragraph: Famished after a two-leg cross-country flight rife with delays and scarce on nutrition, I tapped open Google Maps on my phone and scanned the area around my LAX airport hotel for someplace interesting to eat.

lead_paragraph: Ethiopian with a nod to the Jewish diaspora at a former after-hours jazz haunt in Harlem.

headline: At Tsion Cafe in Harlem, Food From Ethiopia via Israel
abstract: Vegetable stews share the menu with less traditional dishes, like eggs and lox on injera, a crepe-like flatbread.
lead_paragraph: On one side lie eggs scrambled with lox over a drape of injera, the sour, springy Ethiopian flatbread as thin and pliant as a crepe and perforated like coral. On the other side, challah French toast, its egg coating spiked with awaze, a meld of earthy-hot berbere and tej, or Ethiopian honey wine, a drink of millenniums past.

headline: Daily Report: When Things Go Very Wrong at a Start-Up
abstract: A recent Medium post by a disappointed ex-employee of a start-up is a reminder that not every little tech company is destined to succeed.
lead_paragraph: For many young engineers and business people, Silicon Valley is their version of Hollywood. If you want to make it big, go there, create your own company or sign on with a start-up on the way up, and get ready to make a fortune. Maybe you will even become famous.

headline: Contraceptives Drive Teenage Pregnancy Down
abstract: The sharp decline in American teenage pregnancy rates in recent years was a result of the increased use of contraceptives, a new study concludes.
lead_paragraph: The sharp decline in American teenage pregnancy and birthrates in recent years was driven exclusively by the increased use of contraceptives, a new study concludes.

headline: Derek Cianfrance Narrates a Scene From ‘The Light Between Oceans’
abstract: The director discusses his film featuring Michael Fassbender and Alicia Vikander.
lead_paragraph: In “The Light Between Oceans,” a married couple, Tom and Isabel (Michael Fassbender and Alicia Vikander) live on a remote island off the coast of Australia. They long to be parents but Isabel has suffered two miscarriages. In this scene, the two find a boat that washes ashore and are surprised to see what’s inside.

headline: Review: A Baby in a Boat Changes Everything in ‘The Light Between Oceans’
abstract: Michael Fassbender and Alicia Vikander play an Australian couple who long for a child — and happen to find one — in this post-World War I romance.
lead_paragraph: In “The Light Between Oceans,” Michael Fassbender exudes the war-weary stoicism of a man who has grown numb from witnessing too much senseless carnage. Tom Sherbourne, his character in this sweeping period romance adapted from M. L. Stedman’s 2012 novel, is an embittered World War I veteran who takes a job as a lighthouse keeper on Janus Rock, a remote, uninhabited island on the edge of Western Australia. His hope is to get as far as possible from civilization and its savagery.

abstract: Protesters marched through Caracas, Venezuela, on Thursday, demanding a recall referendum this year against President Nicolás Maduro.
lead_paragraph: Protesters marched through Caracas, Venezuela, on Thursday, demanding a recall referendum this year against President Nicolás Maduro.

headline: As Donald Trump Calls for Wall on Mexican Border, Smugglers Dig Tunnels
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Border Barriers', 'Smuggling', 'Bridges and Tunnels', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Drug Cartels', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Fences along the frontier have only helped push smugglers underground, and experts say it may be years before the technology exists to reliably detect the tunnels.
lead_paragraph: NOGALES, Ariz. — On an embankment that runs along a towering steel fence separating this border town from its Mexican sister city, a patch of new concrete with a date carved into it stands out, marking the exit of a tunnel Border Patrol agents sealed in May.

headline: Getting Burned by a Hot Story
abstract: The Times jumped right onto the Anthony Weiner-Huma Abedin separation story. Then it stumbled.
lead_paragraph: Everything is running right about on cue. A sex scandal broke out on Sunday, with a Clinton campaign aide, Huma Abedin, facing more public embarrassment after a confessional call from her sexting husband. By Monday she was announcing plans to separate from him. And by the next morning the spotlight had turned to where it usually does in such matters: the media. The crime was producing coverage considered tawdry, overblown and blameful of the victim. I was out of town, but I came back to an inbox full of emails to the public editor taking aim at The New York Times.

headline: Passionate Reactions to Impeachment
abstract: Both supporters and opponents of Dilma Rousseff, the former Brazilian president, took to the streets after she was removed and was replaced by Michel Temer.

headline: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History

headline: ‘Private Hell’: Prep School Sex Abuse Inquiry Paints Grim Picture
abstract: An investigation commissioned by St. George’s School in Rhode Island found that at least 51 students were abused by staff members in the 1970s and ’80s.
lead_paragraph: Sexual abuse was so rampant that it created a “private hell” for some students at an elite prep school in Rhode Island in the 1970s and ’80s, investigators reported on Thursday, describing an atmosphere of terror in which at least 61 students were victimized and some staff members committed assaults for years before being forced out.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Graciousness
abstract: A former law student of Hillary Clinton recalls ways in which she went out of her way to help him.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Defending Obama’s Record on National Monuments
abstract: A presidential adviser describes the president’s efforts to protect land and waters using the Antiquities Act.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Report on St. George's School With Exhibits
abstract: The following is the report of investigators about sexual abuse accusations at St. George's School in Rhode Island.
lead_paragraph: The following is the report of investigators about sexual abuse accusations at St. George's School in Rhode Island.

headline: As Trump vs. Clinton Captivates World, Netanyahu Is Unusually Silent
abstract: Four years after he was accused of meddling in the American election, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is being careful not to take sides.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — For three hours, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel held forth on all sorts of topics — on Israel and the Middle East, on his record and on his plans. One subject that Mr. Netanyahu studiously avoided in his expansive conversation with American visitors last weekend, though, was the United States election.

headline: EpiPen Price Rises Could Mean More Riches for Mylan Executives
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Executive Compensation', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'ALLERGIES']
abstract: Filings show that under a one-time stock grant created in 2014, top executives stand to reap riches at least partly on the back of price increases on the EpiPen.
lead_paragraph: Heather Bresch, chief executive at Mylan, the pharmaceutical giant that has been vilified for price increases on its EpiPen allergy treatment, maintains that her company has attained a sort of capitalist nirvana — it does good for others while doing well for itself.

headline: Timeless Pieces for Your Home — With a Graphic Punch
keywords: ['Pop-Up Stores and Restaurants', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Kelly Behun’s new capsule collection for Barneys will be unveiled at a gallery-like pop-up shop beginning Sept. 8.
lead_paragraph: In an age when stores look increasingly like  homes — cozy and well-appointed spaces to hang, relax, stay awhile — it comes as little surprise that the interior designer Kelly Behun’s newest pop-up shop at Barneys New York would be outfitted with one-of-a-kind furniture, custom wallpaper and art. The focal point of the shop was once installed in the late gallerist Holly Solomon’s own dining room: a bespoke, floor-to-ceiling neoprene panel, painted for Solomon by the artist Izhar Patkin. “It was this very traditional theme of pastoral picnic and yet it was on this crazy very subversive material, and the fact that she would have that in her Park Avenue apartment — I was so intrigued by,” Behun says, adding that the space itself is a homage to Solomon, who blurred the lines between art, craft and design in the ’70s and ’80s. “It comes back to this idea of living with art and how you incorporate art and design in your world. And you create these sort of tableaus in your home that hopefully enrich you in some way.”

headline: A Morning in Chelsea with the Skate Kitchen
abstract: The stars of Crystal Moselle’s new short film for Miu Miu are six female skaters (and best friends), who took T along for a ride.
lead_paragraph: The stars of Crystal Moselle’s new short film for Miu Miu are six female skaters (and best friends), who took T along for a ride.

headline: American Teenager’s Tennis Game Shaped by Argentina’s Clay
abstract: Jared Donaldson, 19, who spent over two years in Buenos Aires learning the fine art of topspin, pulled off another U.S. Open upset on Thursday, against No. 32 Viktor Troicki.
lead_paragraph: When Courtney Donaldson arrived at the airport in Buenos Aires for the first time, in January 2012, he was unfamiliar with the language and the customs of Argentina and did not know a soul there.

headline: A Day at the Park With Fashion’s Favorite Girl Skateboarders
abstract: T spent a morning with the real-life all-female crew that stars in — and inspired — Miu Miu’s latest dreamy “Women’s Tales” short film.
lead_paragraph: Crystal Moselle, the director most recently of the feature “The Wolfpack,” first spotted Nina Moran and Rachelle Vinberg on the G train, skateboards in tow. They swapped information on the platform. “I was talking mad loud, and I noticed she was peeping us, but everybody peeps when you’re a girl with a board on the train,” Moran says. “We gave her our email because we’re real. We waited to see if she was.” To the girls’ surprise, Moselle reached out — and spent the next few months getting to know their all- female skateboard crew that also includes Ardelia Lovelace, Jules Lorenzo, Kabrina Adams and Ajani Russell.

headline: Sergei Polunin, Ballet’s Bad Boy, Has a Change of Heart
abstract: “Dancer,” a documentary by Steven Cantor, depicts the contradictions and anomalies that have made Mr. Polunin a controversial figure in the ballet world.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The first image is of a man kneeling in a misty white light, his head bowed, his tattoo-covered, muscular torso swaying rhythmically, side to side. Then we see an opera house, the audience arriving, musicians warming up. Backstage, the dancer — Sergei Polunin — in makeup and costume, is in his dressing room, taking various pills and potions. “Soon I am going to be so high,” he says gleefully, doing quick jumps to warm up, in front of a mirror.

headline: The Best TV Shows and Movies New to Netflix, Hulu and More In September
abstract: From the Watching team, expert TV and movie recommendations for September.
lead_paragraph: At the beginning of every month, subscription streaming services like Netflix, Amazon Prime, Hulu and HBO Now add a new batch of movies and TV shows to their libraries. Some of those movies and TV shows are bad. Some are good. Below is a list of the good, broken down by service. Everything mentioned is available to stream starting today, Sept. 1, unless otherwise indicated.

headline: She Didn’t Get a Promotion. Should She Stay or Quit?
abstract: Also, how to deal with a fiancé’s bad behavior at a wedding and more.
lead_paragraph: I applied for a promotion to replace my boss, who is retiring. I was the obvious choice and the only applicant with the degree and experience for the position. I also had the longest tenure. But the search team chose someone else. Since then, my new boss has hired many consultants because she doesn’t know how to do the job herself. (I suspect she never will.) Worse, I never received a rejection letter after my interview. The disrespect is very discouraging. Should I take the bull by the horns and offer to resign or (fake) smile and go along with the company in perpetuity?

headline: Donald Trump’s Brexit Moment
keywords: ['Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Private and Sectarian Schools']
abstract: Mr. Trump is not the first to promise that an isolationist approach would result in a big payout.
lead_paragraph: Early in his long, loud and frightening immigration speech on Wednesday, Donald Trump claimed that “illegal immigration costs our country more than $113 billion a year.”

headline: Yayoi Kusama’s “Dots Obsession — Alive, Seeking for Eternal Hope”
abstract: Inside (and outside) the 87-year-old artist’s installation at Philip Johnson’s Glass House in New Canaan, Conn.
lead_paragraph: Inside (and outside) the 87-year-old artist’s installation at Philip Johnson’s Glass House in New Canaan, Conn.

headline: An Icon of Modernist Architecture — Covered in Polka Dots
abstract: A new site-specific work wraps Philip Johnson’s Glass House in Connecticut in Yayoi Kusama’s signature bright spots.
lead_paragraph: The Glass House, Philip Johnson’s New Canaan, Conn. modernist paean to voyeurism (well, sort of), has played host to a number of site-specific projects over the last few years, ever since its exhibition series began with a show of Frank Stella sculptures in situ back in 2012. In almost every case, though, “site-specific work” at the Glass House has entailed inhabiting the unique exhibition space, often with contemporary dance or ambient music — not interfering with the house itself. (The closest anyone had come to date was Fujiko Nakaya’s “Veil,” which enveloped the house in a mist of fog once an hour in 2014.)

headline: An Airport Survival Guide
abstract: Delayed because of weather? What to do (and where to eat, do yoga, or charge your phone) at 10 major American airports.
lead_paragraph: Weather delays mean plenty of free time on our hands, but chances are, you fill it by checking flight information. How to make the most of your wait? You can settle in with a neck pillow and the latest Stephen King tome, of course, from the airport bookshop. Or check into a micro-hotel, listen to a string quartet, visit a museum or explore the quick service efforts of a rash of celebrity chefs at many of the following domestic terminals in 10 major airports across the country.

headline: Cracking a Glass Ceiling With the Maestro’s Baton
abstract: Women are increasingly taking over a stubbornly male preserve in front of orchestras.
lead_paragraph: LUCERNE, Switzerland — There were practical tips on wielding the baton, on using the left hand to inspire the orchestra, on when to go for clarity and when to go for passion. Then the conductor Marin Alsop offered a word of warning after one of the women she was coaching at a master class here made a delicate flourish while leading the orchestra.

headline: ‘He Used Us as Props’: Conservative Hispanics Deplore Donald Trump’s Speech
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Deportation']
abstract: Some of Mr. Trump’s top Hispanic Republican supporters denounced his reversal after signaling a more conciliatory approach to illegal immigrants less than two weeks ago.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump faced a backlash on Thursday from some of his top conservative Hispanic supporters, who said their hopes that he was softening his immigration policy had been dashed by his fiery speech Wednesday night, which they said was anti-immigrant.

headline: Did Donald Trump’s Mexico Gamble Pay Off?
abstract: Readers discuss whether Mr. Trump’s visit made him seem more presidential or made Mexico’s president seem less so.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Latino Protesters Say ‘No’ to Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Foreign Workers', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Mexican-Americans', 'Citizenship and Naturalization']
abstract: Activists in Los Angeles and demonstrators in Phoeniz, Ariz., protested against Donald J. Trump’s bid for the White House and denounced his recent visit to Mexico City.
lead_paragraph: Activists in Los Angeles and demonstrators in Phoeniz, Ariz., protested against Donald J. Trump’s bid for the White House and denounced his recent visit to Mexico City.

headline: When I’m Mistakenly Put on an Email Chain, Should I Hit ‘Reply All’ Asking to Be Removed?
abstract: I did not ask to be put on this list.
lead_paragraph: No.

headline: Kurds Fear the U.S. Will Again Betray Them, in Syria
keywords: ['Kurds', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Throughout history, Washington and other Western powers have used the Kurds for their ends, then abandoned them when it became expedient.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — For almost two years, Syrian Kurds, with American weapons, air cover and training, have fought and died in battle against the Islamic State. They have taken pride in their status as the United States’ most faithful proxy in the fight against the militant group, and they have hoped their effectiveness as warriors would lead to American support for Kurdish political gains inside Syria.

headline: Swiss Open Criminal Investigation of Franz Beckenbauer
abstract: Beckenbauer is one of four top German soccer officials under investigation for fraud and other criminal offenses related to Germany’s bid to host the 2006 World Cup.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Franz Beckenbauer, one of German soccer’s most famed players and managers, is one of four top officials under investigation for fraud and other offenses related to Germany’s bid to host the 2006 World Cup, the Switzerland attorney general’s office said Thursday.

headline: Five Interesting New Stores (and Retail Happenings) in New York
abstract: From Bergdorf Goodman's new ground-floor renovation to Balenciaga at Dover Street Market, the retail news to know.
lead_paragraph: From Bergdorf Goodman's new ground-floor renovation to Balenciaga at Dover Street Market, the retail news to know.

headline: Map of Tropical Storm Hermine’s Path
abstract: Live map of Hermine's forecasted path.
lead_paragraph: Live map of Hermine's forecasted path.

headline: Review: Le Carré, the Con Man’s Son: Writer, Liar, Survivor, Spy
abstract: This collection of reminiscences from John le Carré — a pseudonym for David Cornwell — offers glimpses of the author, and former spy, over the years.
lead_paragraph: Years ago, when he was thinking about writing an autobiography, John le Carré recounts, he hired two detectives to research him and his family. As the son of a flamboyant con man, as a spy for Her Majesty’s Secret Service, and as a novelist who spent his days making up things, truth and memory tended to blur together: “I’m a liar, I explained. Born to lying, bred to it, trained to it by an industry that lies for a living, practiced in it as a novelist.” He was interested in learning the facts of his life, he told the detectives — since, “as a maker of fictions, I invent versions of myself, never the real thing, if it exists.”

headline: Under New Policy for Homeless Families, Children Can Miss Less School
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Homeless Persons', 'Families and Family Life', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: New York is changing a rule that requires an entire family to be present at the city’s intake center when reapplying to get a spot in a shelter.
lead_paragraph: Homeless families in New York City have long been forced into a difficult choice: In order to apply for housing, they must have their children skip school.

headline: Rising Drug Prices Put Big Pharma’s Lobbying to the Test
abstract: Drug makers have spent $2.3 billion lobbying Congress over the last decade, which may explain why lawmakers have done little to curb drug prices.
lead_paragraph: Drug makers have been getting their $2.3 billion worth in Washington. That is how much they have spent lobbying Congress over the last decade. It may help explain why no legislative proposal to rein in rising prescription prices has gone anywhere. The latest outcry involving Mylan will put that hefty investment in influence to its biggest test.

headline: For the Sake of Art: Risk and Reward at 2,000 Degrees
abstract: UrbanGlass in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, gives glass blowers access to the space and expensive equipment they need to practice their craft.
lead_paragraph: Even when temperatures reach 90 degrees, a certain type of New Yorker will choose to stand next to a 2,000-degree furnace. This is a glass blower. Since few of them are able to set up shop in their apartments, many head to UrbanGlass, which started in 1977 as an artists’ co-op in SoHo called the New York Experimental Glass Workshop. Under its current name and at its current location in Fort Greene, UrbanGlass gives glass artists, and those who try to be, access to the expensive and enormous equipment they need.

headline: Israel Courts Foreign Money in Effort to Become Gas Exporter
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Natural Gas', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The campaign is a major shift for a country whose government wrestled with how to regulate the energy industry.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Israel’s energy minister laid on the charm as he spoke to a few dozen oil executives, contractors and analysts in a crowded hotel conference room about the country’s natural gas prospects.

headline: Aimed at Zika Mosquitoes, Spray Kills Millions of Honeybees
abstract: Officials in Dorchester County, S.C., neglected to warn all beekeepers of a plan to spray pesticide from the air. The results were devastating.
lead_paragraph: The Monday morning scene at Juanita Stanley’s apiary in Summerville, S.C., was ghastly and stunningly quiet: Everywhere one looked were clumps of honeybees, dead after a dousing on Sunday with the potent pesticide with which the local authorities had intended to kill mosquitoes.

headline: Jackie Chan Is Among Winners of Honorary Oscars
abstract: Mr. Chan will join the film editor Anne V. Coates, the documentarian Frederick Wiseman and the casting director Lynn Stalmaster in being honored at the Governors Awards.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A legend of martial arts cinema, a film editor with 60 years of experience, a celebrated documentarian and the casting director for films like “Tootsie” and “Fiddler on the Roof” will receive honorary Oscars from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences at the organization’s Governors Awards on Nov. 12.

headline: Popcorn, Booing and Cheering: This Is Summer Mummers
abstract: Thousands of people pack the Yucca Theater in Midland, Tex., every summer on Fridays and Saturdays for a rowdy evening filled with popcorn throwing. The 67-year-old tradition is called Summer Mummers.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of people pack the Yucca Theater in Midland, Tex., every summer on Fridays and Saturdays for a rowdy evening filled with popcorn throwing. The 67-year-old tradition is called Summer Mummers.

headline: Producer Scott Sanders to Direct Westfield Entertainment
keywords: ['Theater', 'Shopping Centers and Malls', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Culture (Arts)', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The Tony-winning Broadway producer will oversee theater, food and fashion projects at the Westfield malls.
lead_paragraph: The Westfield Corporation, which recently opened a new mall in the World Trade Center Oculus, has tapped the Tony-winning producer Scott Sanders to direct its entertainment offerings.

headline: Photo of F.S.U. Football Star Sitting With Boy Eating Alone at School Charms Internet
abstract: Travis Rudolph, the college football star, saw Bo Paske, who has autism, having lunch alone and joined him. The small act of kindness went big.
lead_paragraph: Travis Rudolph, a star football player at Florida State University in Tallahassee, is no stranger to the spotlight. He is famous for his award-winning athleticism, catching high and running far as a wide receiver.

headline: The Bride and Groom Are Kittens. At Death They Did Not Part.
abstract: The show “Taxidermy: Art, Science & Immortality” at the Morbid Anatomy Museum in Brooklyn offers a cat tableau by the Victorian Walter Potter.
lead_paragraph: WHAT does it take to herd about 15 dead cats in Victorian dress to a wedding in Brooklyn?

headline: Thousands March in Venezuela to Demand President’s Ouster
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Referendums', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Food', 'Shortages']
abstract: Opponents of President Nicolás Maduro took to the streets of Caracas to protest the nation’s economic collapse and its government.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Thousands took to the streets here on Thursday to demand the ouster of President Nicolás Maduro in what appeared to be the year’s largest display of frustration with Venezuela’s economic collapse and leadership.

headline: Birthday Wishes at a Homeless Shelter
abstract: A birthday party for children at a Manhattan homeless shelter.
lead_paragraph: A birthday party for children at a Manhattan homeless shelter.

headline: Getty Images Announces Grant Winners for 2016
abstract: Photographers doing personal projects on social issues received $10,000 each on Thursday from the 2016 Getty Images Grants for Editorial Photography.
lead_paragraph: Photographers doing personal projects on social issues received $10,000 each on Thursday from the 2016 Getty Images Grants for Editorial Photography.

headline: Getty Images Announces Grant Winners for 2016
keywords: ['Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Photography', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Photographers doing personal projects on social issues received $10,000 each on Thursday from the 2016 Getty Images Grants for Editorial Photography.
lead_paragraph: PERPIGNAN, France — Photographers working on personal projects that focus on social issues received $10,000 each on Thursday from the 2016 Getty Images Grants for Editorial Photography. The awards were announced here at the Visa pour l’Image festival.

headline: Crying Wolf, Then Confronting Trump
abstract: Did Democrats exhaust their alarm before they needed it most?
lead_paragraph: Conservative commentators and die-hard Republicans often brush off denunciations of Donald Trump as an unprincipled hatemonger by saying: Yeah, yeah, that’s what Democrats wail about every Republican they’re trying to take down. Sing me a song I haven’t heard so many times before.

headline: Tests Confirm Mosquitoes in Miami Beach Are Carrying Zika Virus
abstract: Florida announced on Thursday that for the first time mosquitoes in Miami Beach had tested positive for the virus, showing the virus was still active in the area.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Florida announced on Thursday that, for the first time, mosquitoes in Miami Beach had tested positive for the Zika virus, a disappointing confirmation that the virus is still active in the area.

headline: Here’s Hollywood’s Newest Foreign Legion
abstract: A handful of summer genre films, including “Don’t Breathe,” “Hands of Stone” and “Blood Father,” were directed in English by young, foreign-born directors.
lead_paragraph: From Fritz Lang to Alejandro G. Iñárritu, Hollywood has a long tradition of nabbing talent from abroad. This summer, the custom has found new life in a crop of genre pictures by foreign-born filmmakers directing in English.

headline: From Toys to Art Treasures: ‘The Teddy Bear Project’
abstract: At the New Museum, children can learn about collecting, decorate bears and pose with them, creating photos like those in the exhibition “The Keeper.”
lead_paragraph: Children consider them beloved companions. Parents think of them as cuddly toys. Psychiatrists call them transitional objects, comforting possessions that help the young navigate their way from helplessness to independence. But right now at the New Museum, they’re playing an unexpected role: elements of art.

headline: Presto! Pulp and Poetry: ‘Chandu the Magician’ and ‘Stranger on the Third Floor’
abstract: “Chandu” (1932), adapted from a nightly radio broadcast, anticipated the superhero Dr. Strange; “Stranger” (1940) stars Peter Lorre in an atmospheric B-movie.
lead_paragraph: Long ago, in a distant galaxy, Hollywood’s superhero movies were as modest as the comic books or radio shows that spawned them, using special effects that now feel homespun to conjure fantasies with the artless quality of folk tales.

headline: Which Power Conference Won’t Vie for National Title? Sorry, Pac-12
abstract: The depth of the conference, paradoxically, means a greater chance for a two-loss champion that would be snubbed when the final four is chosen.
lead_paragraph: There is a simple math problem at the heart of the college football season: five power conferences, four playoff spots.

headline: Experimental Arts on Fire Island, and Music in the Hamptons
abstract: The Boffo Fire Island Performance Festival returns to the Pines; VH1 Save the Music hosts its “Hamptons Live” benefit.
lead_paragraph: The Boffo Fire Island Performance Festival returns to the Pines; VH1 Save the Music hosts its “Hamptons Live” benefit.

headline: Hillary Clinton Raised $143 Million in August for Democrats and Her Campaign
abstract: August was Mrs. Clinton’s most successful fund-raising month so far, and the haul lays the groundwork for a substantial investment in swing states before the election.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton is raising huge amounts of cash for the Democratic National Committee and state parties, according to figures released by her campaign on Wednesday, laying the groundwork for a substantial investment in swing states during the fall.

headline: David Brown, Dallas Police Chief, Announces Retirement
keywords: ['Dallas, Tex, Shooting of Police Officers (2016)', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: Chief Brown did not give a reason for his decision but discussed his department’s response to the fatal shooting of five officers in an ambush this summer.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Eight weeks after five officers were killed in an ambush in downtown Dallas, David O. Brown, the Dallas police chief, announced his retirement from the department on Thursday.

headline: Experimental Arts on Fire Island, and Music in the Hamptons
abstract: The Boffo Fire Island Performance Festival returns to the Pines, and VH1 Save the Music hosts a benefit.
lead_paragraph: Savor the final weekends of summer. The Boffo Fire Island Performance Festival, which showcases experimental dance, performance and music, took place Aug. 26 to 28 on the L.G.B.T.-friendly beaches of the Pines. The festival featured a pop-up shop, estate tour, beachside performances and a V.I.P. dinner with Casey Spooner. On Aug. 27, VH1 Save the Music held a benefit in Sagaponack, N.Y., featuring a performance by Fifth Harmony. The event raised $1 million to promote instrumental music education in public schools.

headline: Factory Activity Dips, but Economic Growth Seems Promising
abstract: Though a strong dollar and lower oil prices constrained August manufacturing, labor market strength could push the Fed closer to raising interest rates.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON (Reuters) — Factory activity contracted in August for the first time in six months as new orders and production tumbled, the Institute for Supply Management said on Thursday, but a low level of layoffs continued to point to a pickup in economic growth in the third quarter.

headline: Review: In ‘Morgan,’ a Snow White With Lips Stained Red
abstract: This film, directed by Luke Scott (whose father is Ridley Scott), focuses on a girl who is pale and fast, strong and hungry.
lead_paragraph: That “Morgan” is a movie about genetics is somehow appropriate, given that the origins of its director, Luke Scott, will be an inescapable component of any discussion of its merits. Unveiling a first feature seems stressful enough; but when your father is peeking over your shoulder as one of the producers, and he’s none other than Ridley Scott — who, with “Alien” and “Blade Runner,” gave us two of the most memorable science-fiction films of the past 40 years — then the weight of expectation must be especially daunting.

headline: Gun Battle Between Ethnic Factions Roils Afghanistan’s Capital
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Tajiks (Ethnic Group)', 'Hazaras (Ethnic Group)', 'Uzbeks (Ethnic Group)']
abstract: At least one fighter was killed when Uzbek militiamen loyal to the vice president clashed with Tajik demonstrators.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Militia forces loyal to the Afghan vice president, the former warlord Gen. Abdul Rashid Dostum, fought a gun battle with a group of northern Tajik demonstrators in the heart of Kabul on Thursday, leaving at least one person dead and several wounded in a chaotic scene that shook the country’s civil-war fault lines from a generation ago.

headline: Review: In ‘Zoom,’ Everyone Feels Certain Body Parts Are Too Small
abstract: Alison Pill, Jason Priestley, Gael García Bernal and Mariana Ximenes star in Pedro Morelli’s amusing mix of animation and live action.
lead_paragraph: “Zoom,” a brainteaser of a film with a breast-and-penis fetish, bets everything on cleverness and a few appealing performances, and it wins. Its conceit nicely fills up its 96 minutes; 97 would have been too long.

headline: Review: In ‘Kickboxer: Vengeance,’ Duty Calls for an Unpracticed Fighter
abstract: In John Stockwell’s film, a man seeking to avenge his slain brother trains under a martial-arts master. Guess who: Jean-Claude Van Damme.
lead_paragraph: Sure, the new action workout “Kickboxer: Vengeance” — a reboot of a foot-fighting franchise from the 1980s and ’90s — follows a tiresome martial-arts movie formula. But amid the hoary conventions are agreeable inklings of an alternate sensibility.

headline: Dismal Days for Brazilian Democracy
abstract: Unpopular as Dilma Rousseff’s presidency was, the irony of her ouster is that she was one of the few politicians untainted by corruption.
lead_paragraph: Rio de Janeiro For an event that marked the end of an era, the final act of the impeachment of Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff was a staid affair, punctuated by procedure and civil speeches.

headline: Big Carmakers Merge, Cautiously, Into the Self-Driving Lane
abstract: As G.M., Audi and Mercedes match the capabilities of Tesla’s Autopilot, they are taking steps to make sure drivers use it responsibly.
lead_paragraph: When General Motors starts selling a new Cadillac sedan next year, it plans to equip the car with G.M.’s answer to Tesla Motors’ Autopilot.

headline: Review: ‘White Girl,’ a Tale of Cocaine, Sex and Privilege
abstract: Elizabeth Wood’s film stars Morgan Saylor as a wild college ingenue who winds up struggling when her new drug-dealing boyfriend is arrested.
lead_paragraph: “White Girl” poses a troubling but unspoken question: To what degree has hard partying with sex and drugs become entrenched as a hazardous rite of passage for bored millennials? Leah (Morgan Saylor), the doll-faced blond protagonist of this movie, written and directed by Elizabeth Wood, is an ebullient New York City college student with an appetite for marijuana, cocaine and casual sex.

headline: Can’t Get Broadway Tickets? Rock Out to Musicals at the Gym
abstract: Don’t stop the beat. Show tunes are setting the tempo for classes at Crunch, Soul Cycle and Broadway Bodies.
lead_paragraph: Amid the pounding pop and hip-hop beats that fill area gyms, a small subset of fitness fanatics has, for years, chosen to work out to “Les Misérables,” “Cats” and “West Side Story.”

headline: Can You Name These Broadway Theaters?
abstract: The play may be the thing, but it’s not the only part of the theater worth your attention. Look up!
lead_paragraph: The play may be the thing, but it’s not the only part of the theater worth your attention. Look up!

headline: Review: Jokes, Not Punches, Land With a Thud in ‘Skiptrace’
abstract: In “Skiptrace,” Jackie Chan tries the unlikely-buddy conceit again, this time with Johnny Knoxville.
lead_paragraph: “We’ve signed Jackie Chan and Johnny Knoxville to star; our work is done,” said apparently everyone involved in the unintelligible action comedy “Skiptrace.” The trouble is, pairing two guys who have been amusing individually in the past doesn’t guarantee that they’ll be amusing together.

headline: A Hans Memling Show Is More Than the Sum of Its Divine Parts
abstract: Humane exuberance and spiritual drama are on display at the Morgan Library & Museum, a showcase of Memling’s paintings, drawings by his successors and books.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to jewels, there are Taylor-Burton rocks and discreet heirloom stones. With museum shows, it’s the same. “Hans Memling: Portraiture, Piety and a Reunited Altarpiece,” at the Morgan Library & Museum, is a minute but invaluable gem of some two dozen small paintings, drawings and books set in the Morgan’s Clare Eddy Thaw gallery, known as the Cube for its intimate size.

headline: Why Roz Chast Makes Fun of White Middle-Class New Yorkers
abstract: “Cartoon Memoirs,” at the Museum of the City of New York, exhibits the mind-to-hand connection in about 200 of Ms. Chast’s wacky creations.
lead_paragraph: A cartoon by the brilliant, widely beloved visual humorist Roz Chast has the title “Einsteins on the Beach” drawn above a family of three camped out on the shore: Dad, listening to the gurgling coming from his wristwatch, remarks, “Guess I shouldn’t have worn my Rolex.” Mom, sitting in a beach chair and observing a large, transparent bag of food on the blanket at her feet, reflects, “Maybe it’s time to move the sandwiches out of the sun.” Their young daughter, emptying a bag of snacks onto the sand, says, “I wonder if sea gulls like Cheez Doodles.”

headline: In ‘Artek and the Aaltos,’ Caution — Sleek, Modernist Curves Ahead
abstract: “Artek and the Aaltos: Creating a Modern World,” at the Bard Graduate Center Gallery, focuses on a married team of groundbreaking Finnish designers.
lead_paragraph: “Artek and the Aaltos: Creating a Modern World,” a landmark exhibition at the Bard Graduate Center Gallery, is a dizzying, sometimes slightly daunting array of objects, furnishings, drawings, photographs and archival material. Laid out in finely wrought displays, it is one of the most comprehensive exhibitions about the artistry and making of design you are likely to see.

headline: Review: ‘The 9th Life of Louis Drax.’ So, Little Boys Get Nine Lives, Too?
abstract: “The 9th Life of Louis Drax” starts with a disastrous ninth birthday and some unanswered questions.
lead_paragraph: It’s not clear whether “The 9th Life of Louis Drax” is deliberately inconsistent or merely an example of confused filmmaking. One thing is certain, however: It sure leaves an unpleasant aftertaste.

headline: An Artist’s Maine Menagerie, as Enduring (and Elusive) as Wildlife
abstract: After a long restoration, Bernard Langlais’s wooden sculptures are set to go on view at his former property in Cushing, Me. And institutions have acquired many.
lead_paragraph: CUSHING, Me. — As historians, art restorers and land conservationists transform the artist Bernard Langlais’s property in this coastal hamlet into a museum and sculpture park, they keep finding wooden carvings in the overgrowth.

headline: 9 Books for Back-to-School That Times Editors Think You Should Read
abstract: New books recommended by the editors of The New York Times Book Review this week.
lead_paragraph: Even those of us who’ve left school far behind can’t help recognize that pencils-at-the-ready feeling that comes at the end of summer. Fall just feels like the time to get serious, whether you have to go back to class or not. Some of our favorite new back-to-school books tackle difficult issues — voter fraud, ADHD and education. So while the books below don’t offer light reading, they do offer plenty to chew on.

headline: Theater Listings for Sept. 2-8
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.

headline: No Subway. No Buses. No Uber. No Problem.
abstract: Six destinations that can be reached by ferry and foot.
lead_paragraph: WE were trapped beneath the heat dome — the air like soup, the sun relentless — with no escape. But as my son, Spencer, and I set off by ferry toward Randalls Island in late July, something like relief swept over us. A faint breeze squeezed through an open window and then stiffened as the boat motored north on the East River. And if I closed my eyes and succumbed to the water’s rhythm, I was almost transported out of this urban toaster oven and onto a Caribbean island or maybe a Pacific atoll.

headline: Comedy Listings for Sept. 2-8

lead_paragraph: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.

headline: Leaked Script Shows What Advisers Want Donald Trump to Say at Black Church
abstract: A document obtained by The Times shows the wording suggested by advisers for Mr. Trump’s replies to questions about race, religion and racism.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Donald J. Trump’s visit to a black church here on Saturday will be a major moment for a candidate with a history of offending the sensibilities of black Americans.

headline: Review: In Kevin Smith’s ‘Yoga Hosers,’ Enlightenment Is Elusive
abstract: This film, the second in a comedy-horror trilogy, features a quirky Johnny Depp and two heroines named Colleen.
lead_paragraph: Since the ignominious critical and commercial failure of his 2010 comedy, “Cop Out,” Kevin Smith has been allowing his filmmaking inspiration to take him in directions that are fanciful even by his own gonzo standards. For reasons best known to himself and perhaps his producers (his explanations in interviews notwithstanding), he is in the middle of a “True North” trilogy of films combining comedic and horror elements, all set in Canada.

headline: The News From Trump Changed. The Main Story Was Slow to Catch Up.
abstract: The Times’s lead story Wednesday on the G.O.P. candidate’s Mexico and Arizona immigration remarks didn’t keep up with his changing tone.
lead_paragraph: It was a fast-paced day for the team covering politics at The New York Times on Wednesday.

headline: A Chinese Mystery: Who Owns a Firm on a Global Shopping Spree?
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: Owners of Anbang, a Chinese insurer behind a wave of multibillion-dollar deals, include relatives and friends of its politically connected chairman.
lead_paragraph: Pingyang County’s verdant hills still hint at a long-lost China. Rice paddies and villages surround its bustling towns, and in the fields, farmers wade into the mud to plant seedlings as they have for thousands of years.

headline: Behind China’s Anbang: Empty Offices and Obscure Names
abstract: The Chinese insurer has made a global splash with its deals, but its ownership lacks the marquee investors that a major company typically boasts.
lead_paragraph: In the center of Beijing’s booming commercial district, with soaring office towers, gleaming shopping malls and luxury apartment complexes, sits a shabby, four-story building with an office that houses stupendous wealth.

headline: Review: ‘Max Rose’ Has Jerry Lewis Tearful Over a Hint of Infidelity
abstract: Mr. Lewis, for all his outsize comic credentials, can be a formidable dramatic actor, but this film provides no space for the story’s darker corners.
lead_paragraph: “Max Rose,” a soggy, fragile feature about love, death, marriage and memories, might never have made it to theaters were it not for its star, Jerry Lewis. More than 20 years have passed since he appeared in the delightfully weird “Funny Bones,” and, whether from curiosity or admiration (most likely, both), moviegoers of a certain age will be unable to resist this unexpected glimpse of a true-blue legend.

headline: Review: Look, Yes, but Listening Is the Key to ‘The Academy of Muses’
abstract: Intellectual discourse predominates in this cerebral film whose pleasures are more of the mind than the heart.
lead_paragraph: From the first minute of “The Academy of Muses” to the last scene, there are discussions of fiery love, of deep desire, of intense longing. Classical poetry is cited, ancient myths are recounted and romantic affairs are described. Just don’t expect to see a kiss or a caress onscreen.

headline: Some Rikers Island Guards Will Get Stun Guns, de Blasio Says
abstract: The move was among new security measures unveiled by Mayor Bill de Blasio for New York City’s jail complex after a series of attacks on correction officers.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio on Thursday announced new security measures for Rikers Island that include arming some correction officers at the jail complex with electric stun guns after a series of violent attacks on guards there.

headline: Review: ‘Antibirth’ Invites the Question, Is This Your Adult-Size Infant?
abstract: Danny Perez, the director of this exercise in grotesquerie, may have aimed for a Lynchian or Cronenbergian vibe, but created something all its own.
lead_paragraph: One day, perhaps at a party, I’ll come across another luckless soul who’s seen “Antibirth.” I suspect that we’ll move away from the crowd like two battle-scarred veterans of some 95-minute war, commiserating over a shared trauma that only people who have experienced it can truly comprehend.

headline: Why Did Peña Nieto Invite Trump to Mexico?
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The president made his terrible summer worse by inviting the Republican candidate to his palace.
lead_paragraph: Mexico City — Mexico’s president, Enrique Peña Nieto, had already had a terrible summer. July was the most murderous month in Mexico since he took office in 2012. Second-quarter results showed negative economic growth for the first time in three years. A survey found his approval rating slipping to 23 percent. And a news report even alleged that he plagiarized nearly a third of his law degree thesis. How could he make it any worse? Only by inviting Donald J. Trump, one of the most hated men in Mexico — so hated that piñatas with his visage are brisk sellers across the country — to his presidential palace.

keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', "Women's Rights", 'Women and Girls', 'Constitutional Amendments', 'Law and Legislation', 'Movies']
