headline: Secrets and Suspicion in Uzbekistan
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: Uzbeks have never known their country without their longtime dictator, Islam Karimov.
lead_paragraph: Sept. 1 marked Uzbekistan’s 25th year of independence and the first national celebration of it without the president, Islam Karimov, in attendance. A few days earlier, the Uzbek government announced that Mr. Karimov, 78, had suffered a serious brain hemorrhage — an unusual proclamation considering pronouncements about his health were often as glowing as those made by Donald Trump’s doctor.

headline: T.P.P. Faces Rough Road in Congress
keywords: ['Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Democrats and Republicans are finding the politics of the far-reaching Trans-Pacific Partnership trade accord so risky that its prospects are uncertain.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, reaching Asia on Friday, will reassure allies of his determination to win congressional approval of the far-reaching Trans-Pacific Partnership trade accord, but back home in congressional races, his party is on the air and online slamming it as a bad deal — and hitting Republicans for supporting it.

headline: Anthony Weiner Confirms Child Welfare Agency Is Investigating Him
abstract: Mr. Weiner, facing another scandal over lewd online messages, originally said he had not yet been contacted by the New York City Administration for Children’s Services.
lead_paragraph: Anthony D. Weiner confirmed on Thursday that the New York City Administration for Children’s Services has opened an investigation into his treatment of his 4-year-old son, Jordan.

headline: As Deutsche Bank Looms, Rickie Fowler Recalls Good Old Days of Last Year
abstract: Fowler’s once-promising season has become a nightmare, capped by a disappointing finish at the Barclays on Sunday, but as the defending Deutsche Bank champion, he is confident.
lead_paragraph: NORTON, Mass. — There is an unmistakable air of confidence in Rickie Fowler’s voice as he talks about T.P.C. Boston, the site of this weekend’s Deutsche Bank Championship. It is a confidence born not of any recent success but of his last visit here, in 2015, when he outdueled Henrik Stenson down the stretch to win the championship in the second leg of the FedEx Cup playoffs.

headline: After Roster Moves, Yankees Find Freedom in Low Expectations
abstract: On the morning of Aug. 1, the Yankees were 52-52. Since then, they are 17-11 and have climbed within two and a half games of Detroit and Baltimore for the second American League wild-card spot.
lead_paragraph: Tyler Clippard took the call in his hotel room in Los Angeles, where he was on the road with the Arizona Diamondbacks. It was Brian Cashman, the general manager of the Yankees, the team that had first promoted Clippard to the majors nine years ago. Clippard was pitching for a bad team but did not expect to be traded, and certainly not to the Yankees.

headline: Man Charged in Killing of Queens Imam and Aide Pleads Not Guilty
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Imams']
abstract: During the arraignment, a prosecutor said there was ample evidence against the defendant, Oscar Morel, but Mr. Morel’s lawyer raised concerns about how the investigation had been handled.
lead_paragraph: The man accused of the execution-style shooting of an imam and his assistant pleaded not guilty on Thursday to charges including first-degree murder in the attack on a sidewalk in Queens that alarmed many of the city’s Muslims.

abstract: Recalling an episode that began in a sinister way but ended in comical fashion.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Friday, September 2, 2016.

headline: Joe Sutter, Who Led an Army in Building Boeing’s Jumbo 747, Dies at 95
abstract: Mr. Sutter headed a team of 4,500 engineers that in only 29 months designed and built the 747, a 20th-century answer to the luxury ocean liner.
lead_paragraph: Joe Sutter, whose team of 4,500 engineers took just 29 months to design and build the first jumbo Boeing 747 jetliner, creating a gleaming late-20th-century airborne answer to the luxury ocean liner, died on Tuesday in Bremerton, Wash. He was 95.

headline: Committed to Rebuilding the World Trade Center, for 15 Years and Counting
keywords: ['World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Building (Construction)', 'September 11 (2001)', '1 World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)']
abstract: Frank Hussey, a superintendent for Tishman Construction, has worked on four towers in the complex since the attacks on Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: Obama Visits Midway, Highlighting Monument and Commitment to Environment
keywords: ['Coral', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Global Warming', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores']
abstract: The president, an eye on his legacy, recognized the expansion of the Papahanaumokuakea Marine National Monument in the remote reaches of the Pacific.
lead_paragraph: MIDWAY ATOLL — President Obama, taking his campaign to confront climate change to a pristine spit of land in the remote Pacific Ocean, said on Thursday that it was critical to examine the effects of the planet’s warming on the seas and to protect wild areas from degradation caused by human activity.

headline: Georgetown Confronts Its Ugly Past
keywords: ['ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Scholarships and Fellowships', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Slavery (Historical)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Editorials', 'Reparations']
abstract: The university’s efforts to acknowledge its role in enslaving African-American men, women and children are a good start, but more should be done.
lead_paragraph: Georgetown University is taking a series of historically important steps to atone for the acts of 19th-century Jesuits who held African-American men, women and children in slavery and sold 272 of them to Southern sugar plantations to keep the college that became Georgetown operating.

headline: In Debate Over ‘Sanctuary Cities,’ a Divide on the Role of the Local Police
abstract: Where Donald J. Trump sees oases for criminals, some local law enforcers see policies that make their jurisdictions safer by encouraging undocumented immigrants to report crimes.
lead_paragraph: In Donald Trump’s telling, there are places across America that have become dangerous oases for criminals, where foreign lawbreakers roam the streets without fear of the authorities.

headline: Just What an Emotional Andy Murray May Need: A Coach Who Isn’t
abstract: When a match isn’t going his way, a tortured-looking Murray may seek sympathy. He won’t find any from Ivan Lendl, his coach, a model of stoicism.
lead_paragraph: A first set that Andy Murray believed was in the old tennis bag was suddenly in the balance. His body language and facial expressions were taking on his trademark mode of transparently tortured.

headline: Rafael Nadal Regains His Form by Virtue of Impatience
abstract: Nadal, a two-time United States Open champion, has looked strong since pushing himself to come back from a wrist injury to play at the Rio Olympics.
lead_paragraph: Rafael Nadal has forged his career by imposing his bruising physicality on opponents and, at times, himself. Few of his body parts have escaped unscathed.

headline: At U.S. Open, Winning Isn’t Easy Under a Deafening Roar of Rain
abstract: Andy Murray and the Williams sisters were among the players who advanced at a sealed stadium, despite the loud sound of pelting rain.
lead_paragraph: Tennis players, Andy Murray said, do not rely solely on their eyes.

headline: Bill Etra, Inventor Who Helped Make Video an Art Form, Dies at 69
abstract: Mr. Etra and a colleague created the Rutt/Etra synthesizer, which let a user manipulate video more easily to make it a more expressive art form.
lead_paragraph: Bill Etra, an artist and inventor who, with a partner, created a video animation system in the early 1970s that helped make videotape a more protean and accessible medium for many avant-garde artists, died on Aug. 26 near his home in the Bronx. He was 69.

headline: Melania Trump Charges That She Was Libeled by The Daily Mail
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Libel and Slander', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The candidate’s wife, seeking $150 million in damages, said the tabloid published false statements, including one that she was an escort before she met her husband.
lead_paragraph: Melania Trump filed a libel lawsuit Thursday against the publisher of The Daily Mail, contending that it published an article that contained “false and defamatory statements,” including that she was once an escort.

headline: Order That’s Rarely Followed
abstract: David Liben-Nowell gets inspiration for his puzzle from an interesting place.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Creative inspiration can come from just about anywhere, and today’s crossword by David Liben-Nowell is a good example of that. If you pay attention, good ideas can sprout up everywhere.

headline: Review: ‘The Trojan Women’ Laments War and Bloodshed, From a Distance
abstract: Ellen McLaughlin’s adaptation of Euripides’ tale has its New York premiere at the Flea; the impetus for her work was the Bosnian War.
lead_paragraph: The men of Troy have been slaughtered. The women, who watched their sons and husbands die as fighting raged through the city, are left to endure the aftermath. Prime plunder of a 10-year war they never asked for, they will be slaves to the Greeks, assigned one by one to masters and ripped from the land they love.

headline: Attack Ad Among First Salvos Against Mayor de Blasio in 2017 Race
abstract: The first contours of the negative campaign against the mayor are emerging, including a critical ad and a “Stop de Blasio” ballot line, even if no challengers have yet done so.
lead_paragraph: The video, posted on Thursday morning, includes perhaps the most annoying music ever featured in a political attack ad: a cloying trickle of sound to accompany a bobble-headed Mayor Bill de Blasio bouncing through a jaundiced summary of his week.

headline: This Time, Colin Kaepernick Takes a Stand by Kneeling
keywords: ['Football', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'National Anthems', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: The San Francisco 49ers quarterback refused to stand for the national anthem before an exhibition game as he continued to draw attention to his views on racial oppression.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — As he was walking off the field at Qualcomm Stadium, Colin Kaepernick’s ears perked up and his head swiveled just before he reached the tunnel leading to the visitor’s locker room. He planted like he was trying to avoid a linebacker, made a hard right turn and raced to the edge of the stands.

headline: Nathan Lyons, Influential Photographer and Advocate of the Art, Dies at 86
abstract: Not only was Mr. Lyons known for his photographic work, he was an organizer who helped lay the foundations of contemporary photography as an art form.
lead_paragraph: Nathan Lyons, a photographer who helped elevate contemporary photography to its current status as a major branch of the fine arts and an important field of study through his work as curator, teacher, writer and editor, died on Aug. 31 in Rochester. He was 86.

headline: Lambeau Field Gives Football the Old College Try
abstract: Saturday’s game in Green Bay between Wisconsin and Louisiana State will end a drought dating to 1983.
lead_paragraph: Jerry Lang was a safety for the St. Norbert Green Knights in 1983 when they defeated Fordham, 18-9, in what turned out to be the last college football game played at Lambeau Field in Green Bay, Wis.

headline: Emails Raise New Questions About Clinton Foundation Ties to State Dept.
abstract: A top aide to Hillary Clinton agreed to try to obtain a diplomatic passport for an adviser to Bill Clinton in 2009, according to newly released emails.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A top aide to Hillary Clinton at the State Department agreed to try to obtain a special diplomatic passport for an adviser to former President Bill Clinton in 2009, according to emails released Thursday, raising new questions about whether people tied to the Clinton Foundation received special access at the department.

headline: The Mets Lose, and the Injury Bug Flares Again
abstract: Neil Walker confirmed that he would soon have season-ending surgery, and Jacob deGrom labored through five innings before signaling for the trainer.
lead_paragraph: The nearly unfathomable spate of injuries the Mets have incurred this season have often ballooned from minor nicks into season-ending ailments.

headline: The Real Science of Abortion Drugs
abstract: Laws in many states actually work against women’s health, by making safe drugs less accessible.
lead_paragraph: Since 2000, over a million American women have been able to terminate pregnancies safely using drugs instead of surgery. Over the years, doctors have found ways to make these sorts of abortions even safer and more convenient, but anti-choice politicians in many states have pushed restrictions that make the process more onerous and that could even harm women’s health.

headline: Identity Politics Run Amok
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: Politics is no longer about argument or discussion; it’s about trying to put your opponents into the box of the untouchables.

headline: Donald Trump, Deporter in Waiting
abstract: His speech described a system that works as hard to catch hotel maids and landscapers as gang members and terrorists.
lead_paragraph: Don’t be confused by the days of mixed messaging from Donald Trump’s campaign, or the head-feint trip to Mexico, where he was polite to the president. Speaking on Wednesday in Phoenix, Mr. Trump did not retreat from, or in any way soften, his promise to make 11 million unauthorized immigrants targets for deportation. His speech — in 10 points, embellished with statistics, ad-libbed asides and audience hollering and chanting — was as clear a statement of hard-core restrictionism as any he has given.

abstract: Poisoning kids is a partisan issue.

headline: A Bali Restaurant With Laid-Back Appeal
abstract: Spice has an affordable menu of locally inspired dishes, accented with sauces, like basa gede, a mixture of 14 to 17 ingredients.
lead_paragraph: From the outside, Spice by Chris Salans seems out of place in the moss-covered jungle town of Ubud, the cultural heart of Bali, Indonesia’s most tourist-trod island. This restaurant, unlike many of its culinary neighbors, has no outdoor seating, thatched bamboo roof or fresh frangipani flowers strewn about. Its glass-walled exterior, with Southwestern-like tiles and a somewhat ostentatious sign, feels a little too polished and proper. But once you are inside, Spice exudes a decidedly relaxed atmosphere and has an affordable menu of locally inspired dishes.

headline: 1891: Fraud at the Bank of England
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: The Bank of England suffers fraud in September 1891.
lead_paragraph: For some days persistent rumors have been in the air of a colossal fraud said to have been perpetrated on the Bank of England. On Monday the amount alleged to have been stolen was currently given as £250,000, and since then the sum has advanced by leaps and bounds, until today it was confidently asserted in the City that it amounted to half a million. These rumors have obtained a degree of credence in banking circles which calls for authoritative treatment. There is no truth whatever in the report, which, if well founded, would have startled the commercial world, and must have produced results disastrous to the largest interests. The Governor of the Bank of England states that there is absolutely no foundation for the rumors. The story, it appears, arose as follows: It will be remembered that in February last a counter robbery was effected at the Bank of Scotland. Certain of the securities then stolen have been within the last few days presented for payment in Paris, and in one of the Paris papers an announcement appeared confusing the Bank of Scotland with the Bank of England, and stating the amount of the frauds to have been £250,000. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 3, 1891

headline: 1966: Sukarno Likens Self to Christ
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: President Sukarno compares himself to Jesus Christ and Mohammed in September 1966.
lead_paragraph: DJAKARTA — Comparing himself to Mohammed and Christ, President Sukarno said today [Sept. 2] that he would go on speaking his mind. The president, who has been stripped of most of his powers, was replying to the criticism which has been leveled at him for his speeches contradicting stated government policy. ‘‘Mohammed also made speeches all the time,’’ he declared. Challenging those who criticized hero worship and the personality cult in Indonesia, Mr. Sukarno said it was necessary to worship something. He asked what would happen to Islam and Christianity without worship of Mohammed and Christ, then added; ‘‘I want Indonesia to have a hero the Indonesians can be proud of.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 3, 1966

headline: Reading Toward Recovery
abstract: “Out of the Wreck I Rise” is an anthology of literary excerpts about addiction and recovery.
lead_paragraph: “Alcoholics Anonymous,” commonly referred to as the Big Book, helped to establish the 12-step program. It’s been an indispensable guide for millions since it was published in 1939. A new, very different kind of book, “Out of the Wreck I Rise: A Literary Companion to Recovery,” by Neil Steinberg and Sara Bader, aims to be a complementary comfort.

headline: The Latest and Best in Crime Fiction
abstract: New novels by Louise Penny, Alex Marwood, Ken Bruen and Anne Perry.
lead_paragraph: A huge weight of grief bears down like a marble tombstone on A GREAT RECKONING (Minotaur, $28.99), Louise Penny’s disquieting mystery featuring Armand Gamache, the retired homicide chief of the Sûreté du Québec. Gamache and his wife, Reine-­Marie, are wintering among their eccentric neighbors in the remote village of Three Pines when the first snowfall sends everyone scrambling for the warmth of the fireplace at the local bistro. As the village turns into a scene in a snow globe, the friends take to sorting through the desiccated newspapers, magazines and catalogs stuffed behind the bistro walls as insulation a century earlier (“as though words could keep winter at bay”) and salvaged during a renovation.

headline: How Growth-Focused Politics Helped Build Vulnerability in Louisiana’s Flood Zones

lead_paragraph: As coastal communities from the Carolinas through New England track Tropical Storm Hermine, which struck Florida yesterday as that state’s first hurricane since 2005 before weakening, it’s worth looking back at the disastrous deluge in Louisiana for wider lessons. A good starting point is two photographs.

lead_paragraph: No Zika infections were reported in Brazil during the Olympics, either among athletes or visitors, the World Health Organization said Friday.

headline: Five Things T Editors Are Really Into Right Now
abstract: A by-no-means-exhaustive list of items we like.
lead_paragraph: I am not, nor have I ever been, a Serum Person. Serums just always seemed to be a thing people liked to say they use in order to appear fancy and well groomed. That was until I tried Dr. Gross’s “Radiance Booster” — housed in a little orange bottle that, I was sure when I purchased it, would not make me more radiant. But as I’ve used the serum in my morning routine (either applying it before moisturizer or mixing it into my makeup), it has surprisingly delivered on its promise. I’ve been told how radiant I look — even though, no, I didn’t just come back from summer vacation. $68, drdennisgross.com. — ISABEL WILKINSON

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Elizabeth Letts’s “The Perfect Horse,” No.17 on the extended hardcover nonfiction list, is about a breed of horses abducted by the Nazis.
lead_paragraph: Saddle Up: As any observer of the best-seller lists can tell you, World War II exerts a deep hold on the popular imagination. Lately, though, readers seem less interested in the Nazis’ human victims than in the quirky corners of the war. A couple of years ago, Robert M. Edsel (and his co-writer, Bret Witter) spent 21 weeks on the paperback nonfiction list with “The Monuments Men,” about Allied efforts to retrieve looted art from the Germans; now Elizabeth Letts’s “The Perfect Horse” — No. 17 on the extended hardcover nonfiction list — tells a similar story about the mission to save a breed of horses, the noble Lipizzaner stallions, that the Nazis abducted to create a “master race” of war animals. General Patton himself approved the rescue: “Get them. Make it fast,” the book quotes him saying. But why divert military resources to protect horses, however mighty? According to an essay Letts wrote for the ­Amazon blog Omnivoracious, the answer lies with the Army’s legacy of training cavalry officers. “Turns out, the interwar years are called the cavalry’s golden age,” she says. “Army-bred horses won Olympic medals and Army-trained riders shone in international competitions. To belong to the U.S. Cavalry was to be a skilled rider. It was also to be trained in a code of honor known to cavalries around the world: Always take care of your horse first. In the last days of World War II, the world’s most priceless purebreds were in danger of being slaughtered for food. Their only hope was a group of American soldiers who by chance were camped out nearby. As it happened, these were the soldiers of the Second Cavalry — one of America’s most storied mounted units, and one of the last to be mechanized. . . . As Patton liked to remind people, many of the most celebrated leaders in World War II got their start as cavalry officers, and in the last days of the war, when the priceless purebreds were in danger, these men remembered the lesson to put the horses first.” Letts is, no surprise, a horse lover herself: Her previous best seller, “The Eighty-Dollar Champion,” was about the show jumper Snowman, and in her Twitter biography she admits she “never got over Black Beauty.”

headline: I Do, Part Two: Why Couples Decide to Renew Their Vows
abstract: It’s a way for some couples to show everyone that their marriage still works.
lead_paragraph: After a decade or two of marriage, what could possess someone to hire a party planner, caterer, florist and officiant, and then surprise a spouse with a ceremony and reception in which they renew their vows in front of several dozen of their closest friends?

headline: Atlantic Silversides Know the Wisdom of Crowds
keywords: ['Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Fishing, Sport', 'Coastal Areas']
abstract: Silversides, rife all along the Atlantic Coast, are like popcorn to larger fish, and even the smallest bits flung into the waters are eagerly devoured.
lead_paragraph: Those who fish the piers and shorelines of New York City probably know the skinny Atlantic silverside by its bait-shop alias: “spearing.” Dozens of the small fish are frozen and vacuum-packed into blocks of ice, which can be purchased for a few dollars at local bait and tackle shops. Decades ago, my brother and I learned about patience from these impenetrable chunks of frozen fish, waiting for what seemed like hours until the block thawed sufficiently to pry out a full length fish or two, which we immediately impaled whole, on a hook.

But Parisians, being Parisian, tend to tell time by landmark exhibitions: “Paris-Moscow 1900-1930” at the Pompidou Center in 1979, the Cézanne retrospective at the Grand Palais in 1995, Dada at the Pompidou in 2005.

lead_paragraph: In 2007, Koshin Paley Ellison and Robert Chodo Campbell founded the New York Zen Center for Contemplative Care, a nonprofit in Chelsea that offers meditation training and study programs for medical professionals and caregivers. Dr. Paley Ellison, co-editor of the new book “Awake at the Bedside: Contemplative Teachings on Palliative and End-of-Life Care,” lives on the Upper West Side with Mr. Campbell, who is also his husband, and two Maine coon cats.

headline: A Popular Vacation Stop? This New Hampshire Liquor Store Beckons
abstract: The top grossing liquor outlet in New Hampshire attracts weekenders, foodies and people returning to ancestral cottages, in what has become a familiar pre-vacation ritual.
lead_paragraph: HAMPTON, N.H. — Over Independence Day weekend, a million vehicles cruised the Maine Turnpike, as Interstate 95 is known north of the Piscataqua River. It is impossible to say exactly how many of those cars first stopped at New Hampshire Liquor & Wine Outlet No. 76, but a bit of regional vernacular — “hella wicked many” — will suffice for an estimate.

headline: Donald Trump’s Tax-Cut Plan: A Boon for the Wealthy
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Income Inequality', 'Inheritance and Estate Taxes']
abstract: The Roosevelt Institute’s president calls Mr. Trump’s plan “the same old failed ‘trickle-down’ economics”; another reader discusses repeal of the estate tax.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: My Family’s Story in Georgetown’s Slave Past
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Slavery (Historical)', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: How an institution that profited from slavery can make it up to me and other descendants.
lead_paragraph: New Orleans — One fall day in 1838, Jesuit priests from Georgetown University assembled enslaved people and walked them to a ship at a wharf south of Washington. The boat was not filled with silver or wood or cotton, but with 56 people, some of the 272 enslaved humans kept by the university.

headline: Lawyers Burnish Tesla’s Deal for SolarCity
abstract: A securities filing tries to smooth over the conflict of interest stemming from Elon Musk’s ownership interest in both companies.
lead_paragraph: The lawyers have grabbed control of the merger between Tesla Motors and SolarCity. They are blanketing the deal with legal process to try to smooth over the conflict of interest stemming from Elon Musk’s ownership interest in both companies. But will it be enough?

headline: The F.B.I.’s Summary of Its Investigation of Hillary Clinton’s Email
abstract: The F.B.I. on Friday released its interview with Hillary Clinton, the Democratic presidential candidate, and a lengthy memorandum summarizing the bureau's investigation into her use of private email server while she was secretary of state.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. on Friday released its interview with Hillary Clinton, the Democratic presidential candidate, and a lengthy memorandum summarizing the bureau's investigation into her use of private email server while she was secretary of state.

headline: Christiania, a Commune in Denmark, Dismantles Drug Market After Shootings
abstract: The decision to demolish the market in the Christiania neighborhood of Copenhagen came after a suspected drug dealer shot and wounded two police officers and a bystander.
lead_paragraph: With its open-air marijuana stalls festooned in psychedelic colors and its freewheeling, self-governing structure, the Christiania neighborhood in Copenhagen has been for decades emblematic of Danish liberalism and tolerance.

headline: In NYC This Weekend? Here Are 2 Art Shows, 2 Operas and 5 Plays
abstract: Catch these summer season highlights before they close.
lead_paragraph: Catch these summer season highlights before they close.

headline: More Bad News for Africa’s Elephants: A Super-Slow Reproduction Rate
abstract: Even if all poaching ceased immediately, researchers calculate that it would take 90 years for forest elephant populations to return to pre-2002 levels.
lead_paragraph: Africa’s elephants are widely loved — and widely endangered. Poachers killed off nearly 30 percent of the continent’s savanna elephants from 2007 to 2014, according to a survey published this week. Their populations are now declining at a rate of nearly 8 percent a year.

headline: Coming Back Home to Oscar de la Renta
abstract: Passed over at Oscar de la Renta two years ago, Laura Kim and Fernando Garcia left to create Monse, fashion’s hottest new label. Now, they are getting the prize they wanted all along.
lead_paragraph: When Oscar de la Renta died, in October 2014, the fashion world was shaken, nowhere more strongly than at Mr. de la Renta’s West 42nd Street atelier. His was a family company — his son-in-law, Alex Bolen, is its chief executive — and many long-serving employees felt like family, too.

headline: Indonesia Is Pushed to Ban Alcohol for Health of Bodies, if Not Souls
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES', 'Law and Legislation', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Islamist parties long opposed to drinking have taken a new line: that alcohol should be banned for health reasons, rather than religious ones.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — I.B. Agung Partha foresees an apocalypse, as he put it, on the Indonesian resort island of Bali.

headline: What I Love | Nancy Zeckendorf
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The widow of the developer William Zeckendorf Jr., lives in Museum Tower in Midtown Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: The widow of the developer William Zeckendorf Jr., lives in Museum Tower in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Life With the Legendary Zeckendorfs
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: The widow of the developer William Zeckendorf Jr. reflects on the family that shaped the Manhattan skyline.
lead_paragraph: As the wife, daughter-in-law and stepmother of New York real estate titans, Nancy Zeckendorf has spent a lifetime studying blueprints and refining her common-sense approach to home design. When she renovated her two-bedroom pied-à-terre at Museum Tower on West 53rd Street, decorated with contemporary and antique furnishings, she had a dedicated broom closet built in the hall by the living room.

headline: A Short History of The Times’s Shortest Story
abstract: Daniel Victor’s story clocked in at one word (two letters) — which will be “pretty hard to beat.”
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Daniel Victor, a reporter on the Express Team, discusses his one-word story.

headline: F.D.A. Bans Sale of Many Antibacterial Soaps, Saying Risks Outweigh Benefits
keywords: ['Cleansers, Detergents and Soaps', 'Triclocarban', 'Triclosan', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Chemicals', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances']
abstract: The agency said manufacturers had failed to prove the products were safe to use over the long term or more effective than using ordinary soap and water.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration banned the sale of soaps containing certain antibacterial chemicals on Friday, saying industry had failed to prove they were safe to use over the long term or more effective than using ordinary soap and water.

headline: Why Facts Don’t Unify Us
abstract: Even accurate information can increase political polarization.
lead_paragraph: According to the Pew Research Center, the nation is more polarized than at any time in recent history. While some of the issues dividing us boil down to ideology and preference, there is at least one on which hard science should have a strong say — climate change. But do numbers and figures change people’s opinions?

headline: Think Like a Doctor: The Sick Traveler Solved!
abstract: Readers solve the case of a 50-year-old woman back from Kenya who develops a fever and vomiting.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to take on the complicated case of a 50-year-old woman who felt feverish and couldn’t stop vomiting and who ended up losing a lot of weight. Like the doctors who saw her as she searched for a diagnosis, many of you focused on her recent journey to Kenya as the source of her symptoms. It was a completely reasonable approach, and one that was extensively explored by the doctors who cared for her. But ultimately it was incorrect.

headline: After 0-12 Season, Kansas Starts With Romp and Hopes for Best
abstract: Coach David Beaty said he learned a few things from the Jayhawks’ first winless football season since 1954.
lead_paragraph: LAWRENCE, Kan. — By the yardstick that matters most, the 2015 Kansas football season was a disaster: The Jayhawks lost all 12 of their games. Look deeper, and the numbers are worse. Eight of the losses were by at least 25 points. Home attendance dipped by 20 percent, to an average of 27,282. Crowds that size make up barely half the capacity at Memorial Stadium.

headline: Donald Trump, Changing His Mind
abstract: Presidential candidates have a long history of reversing their positions, but Mr. Trump takes it to a new level.
lead_paragraph: Presidential candidates have a long history of reversing their positions, but Mr. Trump takes it to a new level.

headline: Yum Brands in China Adds Owners With Skill and Connections
abstract: Alibaba’s mobile-payment affiliate and a private-equity firm will buy part of Yum’s China unit for a good price, but the deal may also pay off for Yum.
lead_paragraph: Yum Brands has added some spice at a price. The company, which owns KFC and Pizza Hut, is selling part of its China business to Alibaba’s mobile-payments affiliate and a private-equity firm run by Fred Hu, the former chairman of Goldman Sachs China. They bring valuable technology skill and connections. It is a better deal than usual for so-called cornerstone investors, but may pay off for Yum’s coming spinoff.

headline: Dean Baquet in Conversation With Media Columnist Jim Rutenberg
abstract: Mr. Baquet, The Times’s executive editor, will talk with Mr. Rutenberg about how The Times covers “all the news that’s fit to print,” on Sept. 12.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Times Insider Events — live programming for Times Insiders and their guests.

headline: 6 Things We Learned in the F.B.I. Clinton Email Investigation
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'E-Mail', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: Highlights from the report released by the F.B.I. detailing its investigation into Mrs. Clinton’s use of a private email server.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Documents released by the F.B.I. on Friday revealed new details about the Justice Department’s yearlong investigation into Hillary Clinton’s use of a private email server and whether she and her aides mishandled classified information. Among the documents was an 11-page summary of an interview F.B.I. agents conducted with Mrs. Clinton on July 2. Two days later, the F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, said the bureau had recommended to the Justice Department that neither Mrs. Clinton nor her aides should be charged with a crime. Here are six highlights from those documents:

headline: The Man and Spirit Behind GucciGhost, Gucci’s Renegade Line
abstract: Trevor Andrew, a former Olympic snowboarder, is a Brooklyn artist and musician — and unlikely fashion collaborator. He’s also married to Santigold.
lead_paragraph: NAME Trevor Andrew

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Jonathan Martin, Sandra Stevenson and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week.

headline: Juno Offers New Look at Jupiter’s North Pole
abstract: NASA released new pictures taken by the spacecraft’s camera as it finished its first of 36 orbits around our solar system’s biggest planet.
lead_paragraph: Behold, the very first close-up of Jupiter’s big blue north pole.

headline: Prince’s Old Band Resurrects Him Through His Songs
abstract: The Revolution reunited at First Avenue, the Minneapolis club seen in “Purple Rain,” to grieve for, and remember, its fallen leader.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — On April 21, as news spread that Prince had been found dead at his Paisley Park compound in Chanhassen, Minn., a crowd began to gather 21 miles away at First Avenue, the Minneapolis club where he had filmed the concert scenes for the 1984 film “Purple Rain.” Thousands of fans flocked to what became a giant all-night block party memorial, and local acts took the stage to play covers of Prince’s songs.

headline: At New Museum, a Pop-Up Support System for Black Lives Matter
abstract: At a time when the country is confronting questions about racial bias and the police, Black Women Artists for Black Lives Matter serves as a response.
lead_paragraph: In the New Museum’s lobby on Thursday night, a circle of women, all dressed in red, swayed from side to side, clapping as they chanted a simple call and response: “End the war on black people,” followed by “It’s time.”

headline: Blast Rips Through Market in Philippines
abstract: On Friday night, an explosion killed and injured patrons of a night market in the Philippine city of Davao.
lead_paragraph: On Friday night, an explosion killed and injured patrons of a night market in the Philippine city of Davao.

headline: Is the National Anthem Racist? Beyond the Debate Over Colin Kaepernick
abstract: The quarterback’s refusal to stand during the playing of “The Star-Spangled Banner” raises the issue. A musicologist says no.
lead_paragraph: The continuing refusal by the San Francisco 49ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick to stand during the playing of “The Star-Spangled Banner” before games has set off a debate about patriotism, protest and professional sports. But it has also raised another fraught question: Is our national anthem itself racist?

headline: U.S. Open Quieted Those Calling for a Roof. Now It Faces a Louder Problem.
abstract: After years of deflecting pressure to build a roof that would prevent the almost inevitable rain delays, the tournament is dealing with unforeseen noise issues at Arthur Ashe Stadium.
lead_paragraph: The United States Open added a new $150 million retractable roof before this year’s tournament, so fans inside Arthur Ashe Stadium no longer need umbrellas. They might, however, need earplugs.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Jared Fogle Blames Parents of One of His Victims for Her Distress
abstract: The former Subway pitchman, who pleaded guilty to sex acts with minors and distribution of child pornography, made the claim in a response to the parents’ lawsuit against him.
lead_paragraph: Jared Fogle, the former Subway pitchman who pleaded guilty last year to sex acts with minors and distribution of child pornography, is blaming the parents of one of his victims, arguing that their divorce and lack of supervision led to the girl’s emotional distress that they attributed to him.

headline: This Robot Is Greeting Tourists in Japan
abstract: Chihira Junco is one of four such androids that have been created so far. The company that developed the technology plans to make 1,000 more in 2017.
lead_paragraph: Chihira Junco is one of four such androids that have been created so far. The company that developed the technology plans to make 1,000 more in 2017.

headline: An Unlikely Fangirl Discovers Charles Merz
abstract: At first blush, the editor of The Times’s editorial page from 1938 to 1961 is an improbable object of adoration. Until you get to know him.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares historic insights from The New York Times. In this piece, David Dunlap, a Metro reporter, connects the dots between eBay and an unsung Times defender of freedom of the press.

headline: Friday Night Music: New From Pavo Pavo
abstract: Some moody, beautiful stuff.
lead_paragraph: I encountered this very young band opening for Lucius a year ago. Now they have a record about to come out, and a first single here:

headline: Save Gabon From Election Fraud
abstract: When the results finally were announced, a curious set of returns from one province — the incumbent’s — gave him the slimmest of victories over me.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday, Aug. 27, presidential elections were held in my country, Gabon, in West Africa, and I was the candidate who won by a substantial vote margin. Nearly a week later, I would have expected to be addressing the world as Gabon’s president-elect, ready and willing to work with the United States and all our international partners to fight terrorism, build our economies and improve the lives of our citizens through increased development and cooperation.

headline: Looking Back at Alan Kurdi and Other Faces of Syrian Crisis
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Drownings', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: On the anniversary of the death of the 2-year-old, whose drowned body was discovered in Turkey, The Times reviews coverage of Syrian children in peril.
lead_paragraph: Friday is the first anniversary of the death of Alan Kurdi, a 2-year-old Syrian refugee whose drowned body was discovered on a beach in Turkey. Photos of the boy shocked the world and put a human face on the refugee crisis.

headline: Tensions Deepen Between Donald Trump and R.N.C.
abstract: The fiery tone of Mr. Trump’s speech on immigration tore a painful new wound in his relationship with the Republican National Committee.
lead_paragraph: The Republican National Committee had high hopes that Donald J. Trump would deliver a compassionate and measured speech about immigration on Wednesday, and prepared to lavish praise on the candidate on the party’s Twitter account.

headline: Reinhard Selten, Whose Strides in Game Theory Led to a Nobel, Dies at 85
abstract: Professor Selten shared the Nobel Prize with John C. Harsanyi and John F. Nash Jr. for their pioneering advances in strategic decision-making.
lead_paragraph: Reinhard Selten, who was expelled from school in Germany when he was 14 because he was half Jewish, but returned after World War II to study mathematics and become the country’s first and only Nobel winner for economics, died on Aug. 23 in Poznan, Poland. He was 85.

headline: Spain Remains Deadlocked as Vote to Form New Government Fails
abstract: Mariano Rajoy, Spain’s caretaker prime minister, failed to win parliamentary backing to form a new government, making another national election likely.
lead_paragraph: For the second time this week, Spanish lawmakers on Friday rejected a bid by Mariano Rajoy, the caretaker prime minister, to form a government, increasing the likelihood that Spain will have to hold its third national election in a year to break its political stalemate.

headline: The Hidden Scars All Refugees Carry
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Vietnamese-Americans']
abstract: Like the Syrians today, my family wasn’t fully welcome when we arrived here. Like us, they will wear their wounds for a long time.
lead_paragraph: Many people have characterized my novel, “The Sympathizer,” as an immigrant story, and me as an immigrant. No. My novel is a war story and I am not an immigrant. I am a refugee who, like many others, has never ceased being a refugee in some corner of my mind.

headline: Assembling the Front Page: A Time Lapse
abstract: The front page of The New York Times begins as a pencil drawing (on green paper).
lead_paragraph: The front page of The New York Times begins as a pencil drawing (on green paper).

headline: Is EpiPen a Brand-Name or a Generic Drug? Mylan Casts It Both Ways
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Medicaid', 'Epinephrine (Drug)', 'Generic Brands and Products']
abstract: The drug company has listed the device as a generic to the government, possibly leading state Medicaid programs to overpay for it by millions of dollars.
lead_paragraph: The drug company Mylan has profited richly from its exclusive right to sell EpiPen, the severe allergy treatment. Recent price increases on the product have rendered it unaffordable for many, leading to a public outcry.

headline: 22 Migrant Women Held in Pennsylvania Start a Hunger Strike to Protest Detention
keywords: ['Immigration Detention', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Hunger Strikes', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Women and Girls', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: A group at an immigration detention center is hoping to draw attention to policies for families seeking asylum from violence in Central America.
lead_paragraph: Margarita Alberto cannot forget the tantrum her 6-year-old son threw several months ago. One afternoon he started shouting that he wanted to leave the Pennsylvania immigration detention center for families, where they have been held since Oct. 28, 2015, “He said, ‘It’s your fault that we’re here, your fault!’” Ms. Alberto said.

headline: Focused on Singles, Jack Sock Delivers a U.S. Open Upset
abstract: Sock has two Grand Slam titles in doubles, but by beating ninth-ranked Marin Cilic, 6-4, 6-3, 6-3, he has matched his longest singles run in a Grand Slam event.
lead_paragraph: Jack Sock was not going to be satisfied anymore with just making the third round of a Grand Slam tournament.

headline: Microsoft’s Challenge to Government Secrecy Wins Dozens of Supporters
abstract: Tech companies, civil liberties groups and media organizations are planning to back Microsoft’s resistance to government attempts to snoop on customers.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Dozens of allies threw their weight behind Microsoft on Friday in a case that challenges law enforcement’s use of secrecy orders to cloak its pursuit of digital communications in investigations.

headline: Madison Keys Arises from a Second Set Slumber
abstract: Keys said her goal has been to reach the second week of Grand Slam tournaments. She overcame a listless spell to achieve that on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Inside a sleepy Arthur Ashe Stadium, Madison Keys needed some noise.

headline: In Britain, Soul-Searching on ‘Brexit’
abstract: Months after the vote to leave the European Union, Britons have yet to work out the details and consider all of the consequences.
lead_paragraph: It has been more than two months since the British voted to leave the European Union, yet it often appears from the continuing debate in Britain that the June 23 referendum served only to intensify the questions about “Brexit.” That is healthy. A move as complex and consequential as this can only benefit from more discussion and soul-searching. After all, this is new territory, with Britain headed where no other E.U. member has gone before.

headline: Economic Resilience, Political Paralysis
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Recession and Depression', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Minimum Wage', 'Editorials', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Education (K-12)', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: Economists are calling for more fiscal stimulus and higher wages, but officials must act on those recommendations.
lead_paragraph: In the more than seven years since the Great Recession ended, the economy has never soared, but it would be fair to say it has been remarkably resilient.

headline: Endorsements in New York Primary Races
abstract: The Legislature is broken and needs members who will put public interests ahead of their own.
lead_paragraph: The New York Legislature is still broken, even though its two leading bad actors — Sheldon Silver, the former Assembly speaker, and Dean Skelos, the former Senate majority leader — have been convicted of corruption and sentenced to prison. Besides prosecuting the criminals, changing Albany’s culture requires sending in people who will put public interests ahead of their own. Here are recommendations for some races in the Democratic primary on Sept. 13.

headline: Yankees’ Run Down the September Stretch Gets Off on the Wrong Foot
abstract: A crucial three-game series against Baltimore, currently the holder of the second American League wild-card spot, opened with a shutout loss.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — The month of August provided a dose of optimism for the Yankees. The team found that, even though it had traded away several key parts, its new cast of players was capable of success.

headline: New York City Will Change Lead Testing Methods at Its Schools
abstract: A spokeswoman for the mayor said that starting in October, the city would retest every building that had at least one water sample that exceeded 15 parts per billion of lead.
lead_paragraph: New York City said on Friday that it would adjust its procedure of testing for lead in the water supply of schools, after experts said the city’s methods could lower the levels found.

headline: For Russell Knox, $4.8 Million in Earnings but a Ryder Cup Snub
abstract: Knox has struggled with an illness at the Deutsche Bank Championship, after a disappointing Barclays finish and the news he would not be a member of Team Europe for the Ryder Cup.
lead_paragraph: NORTON, Mass. — Two holes before he finished his opening round Friday at the Deutsche Bank Championship, Russell Knox sought out his wife, Andrea, in the gallery. He told her that he needed to see a doctor. His wife was not surprised.

headline: Donald Trump Meets With Black Leaders Ahead of Detroit Church Visit
abstract: Mr. Trump met business and community leaders and had an emotional meeting with the mother of a young woman who was killed by undocumented immigrants.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Amid confusion over whether he would speak at a black church this weekend, Donald J. Trump’s halting attempts to win over African-American voters took him to Philadelphia on Friday, where he spoke with a small group of business owners and community leaders and had an emotional meeting with the mother of a young woman who was killed by undocumented immigrants.

headline: A Met Who’s Become the Met-Killer
abstract: In his first year with the Washington Nationals, Daniel Murphy has churned out homers as he did in his last two months as a Met, hitting .341 while slugging .598.
lead_paragraph: When the Washington Nationals signed Daniel Murphy last December, for three years and $37.5 million, Max Scherzer thought he knew what they had gotten.

headline: Avoiding Foreclosure for Now, Harlem Church Celebrates With Anti-Gay Vitriol
abstract: After the Atlah Worldwide Church won a court ruling in a long-running legal dispute, a sign outside said it would celebrate by burning a rainbow flag in the building’s courtyard.
lead_paragraph: The Atlah Worldwide Church in Harlem has grown infamous for the incendiary and often anti-gay views expressed by its pastor, which are trumpeted in bold letters on a large sign outside the church.

headline: Buddy From the Block
abstract: Damon Gulczynski introduces a few new words to the New York Times crossword.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I predict that the response to today’s puzzle by Damon Gulczynski will be as divided as his entries, which can be boiled down to Things Most People Over the Age of 40 Are Bound to Know and Things Most People Over the Age of 40 Might Not Know But Are About to Learn.

headline: Fred Hellerman, Last of the Weavers Folk Group, Dies at 89
abstract: Mr. Hellerman, a pillar of the quartet that helped build a folk music revival, also played on the debut albums of Joan Baez and Judy Collins and produced Arlo Guthrie’s first two albums.
lead_paragraph: Fred Hellerman, a singer, guitarist and songwriter and the last surviving member of the Weavers, the quartet that in the 1950s helped usher in the folk music revival, died on Thursday at his home in Weston, Conn. He was 89.

headline: Mets Fall to Nationals; Ailing Jacob deGrom May Miss His Next Start
abstract: DeGrom has experienced soreness in his right forearm, meaning the Mets’ starting rotation is down to two: the 43-year-old Bartolo Colon, and Noah Syndergaard.
lead_paragraph: At this point, should Mets fans shake their heads in disbelief or applaud that their team is still in the playoff hunt despite a seemingly endless stream of injuries? Perhaps they should do both, and pray.

headline: Jon Polito, a Favorite in Coen Brothers Films, Dies at 65
abstract: Mr. Polito had more than 200 roles in film and television and appeared on Broadway as well.
lead_paragraph: Jon Polito, a character actor who often played law enforcement figures and gangsters and had memorable turns in many films by Joel and Ethan Coen, died on Thursday in Los Angeles. He was 65.

headline: CiCi Bellis’s Charming Run Through the U.S. Open Ends Swiftly
abstract: Bellis, a 17-year-old American amateur, was eliminated in the third round by second-seeded Angelique Kerber, 6-1, 6-1.
lead_paragraph: CiCi Bellis was the youngest player left in the women’s draw when she arrived Friday night for her third-round match at Arthur Ashe Stadium. The lights dimmed when Bellis, a 17-year-old Californian, made her entrance. She got a warm reception. She unpacked her tennis bag and got ready for the biggest stage of her life.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, September 3, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “I feel degraded.”

headline: Alexandra Willkie and Zachary Pasanen: A Romantic, and Risky, Dance Move
abstract: A suitor tries a risky dance move, and ends up winning the hand of Wendell Willkie’s great-granddaughter.
lead_paragraph: Alexandra Elizabeth Willkie, a daughter of Carlotta Fendig Willkie and Wendell Lewis Willkie II of Darien, Conn., is to be married Sept. 4 to Zachary Anton Pasanen, the son of Susan Anton Pasanen and Dr. Wayne Edward Pasanen of North Andover, Mass. The Rev. Richard Pike, an Episcopal priest, is to officiate at Blue Hill at Stone Barns in Pocantico Hills, N.Y.

headline: Corrections: September 3, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, September 3, 2016.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: For Art Dealers, the Place to Be Is Still London
abstract: ‘Brexit’ hasn’t deterred high-end art dealers from opening new spaces.
lead_paragraph: These are early days, but the Hieronymus Bosch vision of a socioeconomic apocalypse that many feared would follow Britain’s June 23 vote to leave the European Union has yet to materialize.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘The Talented Mr. Ripley’ and ‘Building Star Trek’
abstract: Seeking a thrill? Choose “The Talented Mr. Ripley” or “Carol,” both adapted from Patricia Highsmith novels. Or venture into deep space with “Building Star Trek.”
lead_paragraph: Seeking a thrill? Choose among “The Talented Mr. Ripley”; its French precursor, “Purple Noon”; and “Carol,” all adapted from Patricia Highsmith novels. Ride the roller coaster at Walley World in “Vacation.” Or venture into deep space with “Building Star Trek,” a 50th-anniversary special.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘The Intervention’ and ‘Shame’
abstract: Clea DuVall reunites with Natasha Lyonne in “The Intervention,” about friends who think they know best. And Michael Fassbender reveals all — and nothing — in “Shame.”
lead_paragraph: Clea DuVall couples with her bestie, Natasha Lyonne, in “The Intervention,” about friends who think they know better where marriage is concerned. And Michael Fassbender reveals all — and nothing — in “Shame.”

headline: Want a National Title? Hire a Coach, Wait Three Years
abstract: A coach’s third year at a top football program seems particularly magical for winning a title, based on recent examples.
lead_paragraph: If college football’s national championship were awarded purely on the basis of preseason hype, the Washington Huskies would be top contenders. A frequent Pacific-12 also-ran, Washington returns more than a dozen starters from last year’s team, which was widely acknowledged as better than its 7-6 record. The team’s No. 14 ranking in the current Associated Press poll is the team’s highest since 2002.

headline: Onstage With Putin, Shinzo Abe of Japan Calls for Resolution of Island Dispute
abstract: During a panel discussion Saturday in Russia, the Japanese leader made an impassioned plea to end a seven-decade-old territorial conflict.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan made an impassioned plea on Saturday to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia for their two countries to resolve a dispute over a group of islands that has been a sore point in their relations since the end of World War II.

headline: ‘Don’t Try to Use It or You Will Be Called Un-American’
abstract: Our top 10 comments of the week: Readers debate Donald Trump’s trip to Mexico, protests during the national anthem, voting laws in North Carolina and more.
lead_paragraph: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

headline: Goodbye, Ivory Tower. Hello, Silicon Valley Candy Store.
keywords: ['Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Consumer Behavior']
abstract: The promise of big data and big paychecks is drawing some of academia’s top economists to study consumer behavior for tech companies like Airbnb, Amazon and Uber.
lead_paragraph: For eight years, Peter Coles had an economist’s dream job at Harvard Business School.

headline: Venture Communism: How China Is Building a Start-Up Boom
abstract: The Chinese government is lavishing benefits like free rent and cash handouts on homegrown start-ups in an effort to move beyond the factory floor.
lead_paragraph: HANGZHOU, China — In Dream Town, a collection of boxy office buildings on the gritty edge of this historic city, one tiny company is developing a portable 3-D printer. Another takes orders for traditional Chinese massages by smartphone. They are just two of the 710 start-ups being nurtured here.

headline: Renovation Restores the Luster to Cartier Flagship
keywords: ['Restoration and Renovation', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Jewels and Jewelry']
abstract: The landmark store on Fifth Avenue reopens this week after a restoration of more than two years.
lead_paragraph: Enlightened urbanism is not the first thing that comes to mind when a prestigious jeweler owned by a multinational luxury goods conglomerate throws open its doors. Yet with the reopening this week of the Cartier flagship on Fifth Avenue, after a renovation of more than two years, it is the city itself that reclaims a gem.

headline: Serving Stylish Looks at the U.S. Open
abstract: Tennis devotees brought their fashion game courtside.
lead_paragraph: Tennis devotees brought their fashion game courtside.

headline: Cher’s Latest Road Show? The Campaign Trail
abstract: The singer is going all out for the election of Hillary Clinton and is bringing her 3.1 million Twitter followers along for the ride.
lead_paragraph: Cher’s first brush with politics was an act of teenage civil disobedience. It was right before the election of 1960. And she came home one day horrified to discover that her mother and stepfather had festooned their house in Hollywood with Richard Nixon paraphernalia.

headline: The Week on Instagram
abstract: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took Instagram followers from Bamian Province in Afghanistan to the Silver Gull Beach Club in Queens.
lead_paragraph: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took Instagram followers from Bamian Province in Afghanistan to the Silver Gull Beach Club in Queens.

headline: Rare Harmony as China and U.S. Commit to Climate Deal
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United States International Relations', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership']
abstract: President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China formally committed to the Paris climate agreement at a time of increasingly discordant relations between their nations.
lead_paragraph: HANGZHOU, China — President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China formally committed the world’s two largest economies to the Paris climate agreement here on Saturday, cementing their partnership on climate change and offering a rare display of harmony in a relationship that has become increasingly discordant.

headline: ‘Narcos’ Season 2, Episode 2: The Legend vs. the Monster
abstract: This episode nods to the baptism scene in “The Godfather,” but only shows Pablo Escobar in one dimension: as a ruthless gangster.
lead_paragraph: The baptism sequence in “The Godfather” is one of the most celebrated montages in cinema, a breathtaking assertion of power from Michael Corleone as he gains control over the Corleone crime family and puts down threats from the other four New York mob syndicates. Everyone remembers the sequence for its sharp juxtaposition of serene religious ritual and startling violence, as Michael, the once-reluctant successor to his father’s business, handles the job with efficient, cold-blooded aplomb. What tends to be forgotten is the thematic significance of the baptism itself, the sick association between Catholic rites and a child’s passage into a family of unrepentant sinners. Divorced from any larger meaning, it can be chalked up as a tribute to gangland ruthlessness.

headline: A Little Variety
abstract: A place to discuss the “A Little Variety” suite of puzzles.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLES — This week’s puzzles include:

headline: What Do You Know About Mother Teresa and Other Saints?
abstract: Mother Teresa, one of the 20th century’s most visible religious figures, was canonized on Sunday. Test your knowledge of Mother Teresa and the lives of other saints.
lead_paragraph: Mother Teresa, one of the 20th century’s most visible religious figures, was canonized on Sunday. Test your knowledge of Mother Teresa and the lives of other saints.

headline: Farhad’s and Mike’s Week in Tech: What? No More iPhone Headphone Jack?
abstract: Our duo thinks hard about the SpaceX fireworks in Cape Canaveral, Andreessen Horowitz’s returns and Apple’s $14.5 billion trip to European tax purgatory. A new, surly reporter joins the proceedings.
lead_paragraph: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. This week, they needed extra help and roped in new tech reporter Daisuke Wakabayashi.

headline: Discord Over Lobby Remodeling
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Boards of Directors', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Cooperatives']
abstract: Costly renovations, serving on a co-op board and ownership of house plans.
lead_paragraph: Last year, our co-op board selected a design firm to renovate the two lobbies in our building. Shareholders were shown two conceptual renderings with a cost estimate of $500,000 to $750,000. Ten months later, the managing agent sent shareholders a letter telling us that the project would now cost $1.2 million and we could view the updated renderings on request. Many shareholders think  the process has been autocratic and opaque, and are upset about the skyrocketing costs. What are our rights, and what can we do to find out what happened — and to start a conversation about lowering the costs?

headline: A Sharp Increase In ‘Sunny Day’ Flooding
abstract: Global warming and rising seas are increasing the amount of tidal flooding on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts.
lead_paragraph: Global warming and rising seas are increasing the amount of tidal flooding on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts.

headline: Flooding of Coast, Caused by Global Warming, Has Already Begun
abstract: Scientists’ warnings that the rise of the sea would eventually imperil the United States’ coastline are no longer theoretical.
lead_paragraph: NORFOLK, Va. — Huge vertical rulers are sprouting beside low spots in the streets here, so people can judge if the tidal floods that increasingly inundate their roads are too deep to drive through.

headline: Which Tennis Ball is in Use? It Makes a Difference

headline: The Baseball Hall of Fame’s New Era: Digital

lead_paragraph: Cal Ripken Jr. has been a Hall of Famer since 2007, when he was 46 years old. At first, when he would visit the exhibits and tour the archives, Ripken was more interested in the equipment, the tools of the trade he had mastered as an ironman infielder for the Baltimore Orioles. That has changed with time.

headline: Premier League’s Wealth Often Subsidizes Clubs Across the Channel
abstract: The insatiable appetite for talent, along with the league’s deep pockets, has European clubs determined to extract the highest possible price in any deal.
lead_paragraph: Suddenly, Le Havre A.C. has choices. As is the case with most teams in France’s second division, money is usually tight for Arnaud Tanguy, Le Havre’s chief executive. There are salaries to be paid and bills to be settled. Tanguy’s job, more often than not, is to make ends meet.

headline: A ‘Nightmare’ Presidential Campaign Ad That Stayed in the Vault
keywords: ['Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Political Advertising', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: A 1976 commercial referencing the assassination of John F. Kennedy proved to be so unsettling that Gerald R. Ford’s handlers made sure it never aired.
lead_paragraph: Forty years ago next month, the two major-party nominees, President Gerald R. Ford and Jimmy Carter, the former governor of Georgia, were almost tied in the polls. Mr. Ford’s media team, Doug Bailey and John Deardourff, argued for taking a chance on a television commercial that would infuse the Ford campaign with the vote-getting power of emotion and history.

headline: A Warrior Against Junk Mail at Yahoo Looks Out for Mom, Too

headline: Libya: Unified Against ISIS, Fragmented After
abstract: With the Islamic State down to three neighborhoods in the coastal city of Surt, the question becomes: How will this nation of many factions be governed?
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Martin Kobler, the United Nations envoy to Libya, used to regularly joke that the only functioning government in Libya was the Islamic State. Unlike the country’s other three governments, it not only held territory but ran the courts, provided services to the public and ensured security — however harsh its rule.

Trump in the general election campaign, his message and style have closely followed his stump speech: a dark, ominous and fearful portrait of the future under Hillary Clinton, and proclamations of all that the country has to gain by supporting him. His first ad focused on immigration, and his new ad, titled “Two Americas: Economy,” is about jobs.

headline: A Bold Attempt to Redefine ‘Dissidence’ in Cuba
keywords: ['Censorship', 'Museums', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Editorials']
abstract: Through a digital “museum of dissidence,” a Havana couple sets out to remind Cubans that Fidel and Raúl Castro were once dissidents.
lead_paragraph: “Dissident” is a loaded word in Cuba, a label used to discredit and punish. Those who have embraced the term can be shut out of public jobs and are often subjected to arbitrary detentions and beatings.

abstract: It’s time to revise police contracts that make it almost impossible to bring officers to justice.

headline: The Czars Return to Crimea
abstract: My ancestors have been adopted as political mascots by Crimean politicians seeking to celebrate their ties to Russia.
lead_paragraph: YALTA, Crimea — My quest to unearth my Russian roots brings me regularly to Crimea, where my ancestors cultivated a vineyard along the spectacular southern coast for generations until the 1917 Revolution.

headline: You’re How Old? We’ll Be in Touch

abstract: Ageism in the workplace is toxic, and it hurts everyone.
lead_paragraph: It might not seem that Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump have much in common. But they share something important with each other and with a whole lot of their fellow citizens. Both are job seekers. And at ages 68 and 70, respectively, they’re part of a large group of Americans who are radically upending the concept of retirement.

headline: For a Long Life, Retire to Manhattan
abstract: Like urban life, aging makes you feel a nobody. Paradoxically, it also makes you feel alive.
lead_paragraph: In his famous essay about New York, E. B. White distinguished among three cities and three types of New Yorkers. The first two — the city belonging to people born here, and that of commuters who work here by day and leave by night — were, he said, less compelling than the third, “the city of final destination” for those who come here in hope and nervousness.

headline: Political Correctness and Its Real Enemies
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Philanthropy', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: Conservative donors have seized on campus debates to push their belief in free markets, not in free speech.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — Last November, Scott C. Johnston, a 1982 Yale graduate, was attending a conference organized by the William F. Buckley Jr. Program at his alma mater when student protesters disrupted it. Soon after, he watched an online video of a black Yale student hurling imprecations at a professor who headed her residential college for failing “to create a place of comfort and home.”

headline: How to Tell a Mother Her Child Is Dead
abstract: Do not ever say he was lucky that he did not feel pain.
lead_paragraph: Philadelphia — First you get your coat. I don’t care if you don’t remember where you left it, you find it. If there was a lot of blood you ask someone to go quickly to the basement to get you a new set of scrubs. You put on your coat and you go into the bathroom. You look in the mirror and you say it. You use the mother’s name and you use her child’s name. You may not adjust this part in any way.

headline: America’s Shocking Maternal Deaths
keywords: ['Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Editorials']
abstract: In many countries, the number of deaths during pregnancy or after childbirth has fallen sharply. The United States is a glaring exception.
lead_paragraph: The rate at which women die during pregnancy or shortly after childbirth has fallen sharply in many nations as maternal care has improved. The United States — and particularly Texas — is a glaring exception.

headline: The Big Gay Sway
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Elections', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: L.G.B.T. rights are playing a fascinating, pivotal role in 2016 elections.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — On a sweltering afternoon in late August, Stephanie Murphy, a Democrat running for Congress against a longtime Republican incumbent, stole a half-hour from a crammed schedule for something that grieving residents of this metropolitan area still routinely do: She visited Pulse nightclub, where a gunman ended 49 lives in June.

headline: Take Back the House, Democrats. Please.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Global Warming']
abstract: The candidacy of Donald Trump offers a unique opportunity the party would be foolish to miss.
lead_paragraph: Ithaca, N.Y. — RECENT polls put Hillary Clinton slightly ahead of Donald Trump in traditionally Republican states like Georgia and close even in South Carolina. Should she make the serious investment necessary to put those states in play for real? Or should she ignore them and invest the same money in traditional battleground states? If the only concern were to minimize Mr. Trump’s chances of winning, it would be an easy call: Caution would dictate focusing exclusively on swing states.

headline: Deliveryman Sues Ex-Mayor David Dinkins Over Collision

headline: BBC Soap ‘The Archers,’ Pushing 70, Generates New Buzz With Abuse Thread

lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the rural village of Ambridge on the British radio show “The Archers,” nothing much changes, and listeners like it that way.

headline: Venezuelan President Is Chased by Angry Protesters

headline: Tennis as Far as the Eye Can See
abstract: New raised walkways and terraces at the U.S. Open site let fans view the action on several courts at once.

Here was Jake Snorsky, for instance, standing atop his seat far above a cluster of courts at the United States Open the other day, able to watch seven potentially interesting things at once.

keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Civilian Casualties']
abstract: The Obama administration is engaged in an increasingly desperate effort to broker a deal with Russia for a cease-fire that would halt bombing on Aleppo.

lead_paragraph: A particular wave of crime has yet to crest, a pattern of theft in Manhattan that has penetrated the safest of neighborhoods.

headline: 1941: Submarine Attacks U.S. Destroyer in Atlantic
keywords: ['Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'Submarines and Submersibles']
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: The U.S.S. Greer is attacked by torpedoes and replies by firing depth charges in September 1941.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An unsuccessful submarine attack on an American destroyer, the U.S.S. Greer, somewhere in the Atlantic en route to Iceland, was reported tonight by the Navy Department. Several torpedoes missed their mark, according to the commander of the destroyer, who immediately ordered the firing of depth charges. The result of the dropping of the TNT-filled “ashcans” is not known. The Greer was on her way to Iceland, most distant outpost in the United States’ hemisphere defense zone, with mail for the American forces which are relieving British troops there. Nothing could be learned from the Navy Department as to the nationality of the submarine making the attack. — New York Herald Tribune, Sept. 5, 1941

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Get prepared for Labor Day cooking, then make a plan for the days to follow.

headline: Letter From a Bahraini Jail
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Political Prisoners', 'Torture', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The United States decision to lift an arms embargo has empowered the regime to intensify its political repressions.
lead_paragraph: RIFFA, Bahrain — I write this from a Bahraini jail cell where I have been detained, largely in isolation, since the beginning of summer. This is not new to me: I have been here before, from 2012 to 2014, in 2015, and now again, all because of my work as a human rights defender.

headline: Hermine Swirls Off East Coast, but Threat Eases
abstract: The storm prompted emergency declarations and disruptions of the holiday weekend, but appeared to be less of a threat than had been forecast.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The powerful post-tropical cyclone Hermine lurked off the Eastern Seaboard on Sunday, and its evolving path made the storm more likely to be a bother than a threat.

headline: 1916: Tristan Da Cunha to Receive Mail
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: The British inhabitants of a remote island in the South Atlantic were looking forward to their first shipment of messages and supplies from their homeland for a decade in September 1916.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — One hundred and three British subjects, self-exiled on a lonely isle in the South Atlantic, are eagerly awaiting their “Treasure Ship,” which will steam from London in a few days, says the ‘‘Weekly Dispatch.’’ They are the inhabitants of Tristan da Cunha, and it is so far off the beaten track that they have not heard officially from the Motherland for ten years, but now a ship has been chartered to visit the island and take mails. The Colonial Office and other friends of the islanders are sending them comforts and stores, and at the offices of the Crown Agents for the Colonies (who are packing and dispatching the goods free) there have been busy scenes the past few days. The gifts are chiefly of a practical value, and include soap, which is greatly in demand in Tristan da Cunha, rope, dungaree for making clothes, boots, rice, oars, medical supplies and sails.The women exiles are not forgotten, and a good supply of hairpins and other necessities will bring joy to the belles of Tristan. The only flag the islanders are said to have to prove their allegiance to the Empire is a red ensign, and the Colonial Office is sending out a brand new Union Jack. There are sure to be hearty cheers in the lonely settlement when the new flag arrives and is unfurled. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 1, 1916

headline: Tim Kaine Compares Donald Trump’s Comments on Russian Hacking to Watergate Scandal

headline: Nicolas Sarkozy Mounts What He Hopes Is a Comeback in France
abstract: In most other political systems he would be a has-been. Yet in a France under terrorist threat, Mr. Sarkozy may be the man of the moment in a presidential race.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — He was beaten in the last presidential election, his presidential term was considered a failure, and he has been the subject of numerous judicial inquiries. In most other political systems, he would be a has-been. Yet in a France under terrorist threat, Nicolas Sarkozy may be the man of the moment in a presidential race picking up steam.

headline: A George Carlin Special Too Raw After Sept. 11 Resurfaces Now
