lead_paragraph: On Sept. 10, 2001, George Carlin, the greatest political comic in history if measured only by stand-up specials, recorded a bracing hour of social commentary for his new HBO special. The next day, he shelved it.

headline: Jose Reyes Raises the Mets’ Spirits and Hopes
abstract: After a slow start to his return to the team that started his career, Reyes has helped the Mets both at the plate and in the clubhouse.
lead_paragraph: A black sign hangs above the exit of the Mets’ clubhouse. In white lettering, it reads, “Do Your Thing.” Mets players wear blue and black T-shirts with the slogan “Has Tu Diligencia,” which carries a similar message in Spanish.

headline: Labour Party Is Poised to Back Jeremy Corbyn Again, Even if Britain Isn’t
abstract: The party is expected to re-elect Mr. Corbyn this month despite opposition from its legislators and polls suggesting it will lose badly to the governing Conservatives.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A recent semi-scandal over seats on a train illuminates the deep problems of Britain’s Labour Party. Its left-wing leader, Jeremy Corbyn, made a video sitting on the floor of a train, calling for the renationalization of the railways while claiming that there were no empty seats and that travelers were “ram-packed.”

headline: Vin Scully’s Farewell Should Be Heard Far and Wide
abstract: TBS will have the option of giving Scully, the Dodgers’ broadcasting great, a national audience for his final game. If it doesn’t, another network should get the chance.
lead_paragraph: Vin Scully will conclude his 67-season run as the voice of the Dodgers on Oct. 2 in a game against the Giants at AT&T Park in San Francisco. But it should be more than a local event for Scully’s fans in the Los Angeles area. When baseball’s greatest announcer retires, it is a national occasion.

headline: Rolling Coal at the Fair
abstract: Spewing black smoke is part of the allure of pulling events at county fairs, where drivers in modified vehicles compete to see how far they can pull a heavy sled.
lead_paragraph: Spewing black smoke is part of the allure of pulling events at county fairs, where drivers in modified vehicles compete to see how far they can pull a heavy sled.

headline: The Trucks That Intentionally Spew Smoke
abstract: Coal rollers alter their diesel trucks so they put out thick black smoke, sometimes in the direction of joggers, cyclists and hybrid cars.
lead_paragraph: Coal rollers alter their diesel trucks so they put out thick black smoke, sometimes in the direction of joggers, cyclists and hybrid cars.

headline: Hollywood’s Summer of Extremes: Megahits, Superflops and Little Else
abstract: As the industry searches for answers, some point to the loss of an underappreciated figure: the ticket buyer who treks to the theater more for the experience than for the movie itself.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Sequel fatigue does not fully explain it. Nor does an overload of mega-budget event movies. A spate of terrible films? Yes, but that’s not entirely the explanation, either.

headline: Political Intrigue in Israel Leaves Commuters Without Trains for a Day
abstract: An uproar followed a shutdown that appeared to be related to unholy bickering and muscle flexing inside the fractious government.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — In an abrupt resurrection of Israel’s “Sabbath wars,” a key train line was disabled for repairs on Sunday, snarling tens of thousands of Israeli commuters and soldiers returning to base in traffic jams at the start of the workweek — all because of a political spat involving Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, his transportation minister and their ultra-Orthodox coalition partners.

headline: Review: ‘Viktor’ Is Vintage Pina Bausch, Complete With Gravedigger
abstract: Structure and narrative are not frameworks for works by this choreographer, which consist of vignettes that build by accretion.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Death is omnipresent. The stage is an enormous grave, with 20-foot-high mud walls forming cliffs around its perimeters. At the top of the walls, a man slowly and steadily shovels earth into the huge chasm below. The gravedigger shovels for all three hours of Pina Bausch’s “Viktor,” a rarely seen 1986 work, which the Tanztheater Wuppertal is performing at the Théâtre du Châtelet here through Sept. 12.

headline: Review: ‘Twelfth Night,’ Anything Goes in Love and Shakespeare
abstract: Professional and amateur actors and civic and cultural groups join in this contemporary musical adaptation from the Public Works program by the Public Theater.
lead_paragraph: Everybody’s pretty much crazy in love in Shakespeare’s “Twelfth Night,” so it seems natural to include a shout-out to the Beyoncé song of that name in the contemporary musical adaptation of the play that finishes a brief Labor Day weekend run on Monday night at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park.

headline: ‘Razor Girl,’ a Tale of Kidnappers, Reality TV Stars and Dodgy Seafood
abstract: Carl Hiaasen’s latest novel weaves together a demoted detective, a reality-TV star and Florida skulduggery in the writer’s trademark comic style.
lead_paragraph: Carl Hiaasen’s irresistible “Razor Girl” meets his usual sky-high standards for elegance, craziness and mike-drop humor. But this election-year novel is exceptionally timely, too. It illustrates the dog-whistle effects of bigotry that take the form of entertainment, with a plot that revolves around a “Duck Dynasty”-type reality show, the sermons delivered by one of its stars and a crazed fan who decides to follow what he thinks are the star’s teachings. Mr. Hiaasen — and probably only Mr. Hiaasen — could weave this into a book that’s still so funny.

headline: Review: In ‘800 Words,’ a Widowed Father of Teenagers Uproots the Family
abstract: This light, heart-warming drama series is about an Australian dad and his two teenagers decamping to New Zealand to start afresh.
lead_paragraph: The Australian drama series “800 Words” will remind you in one way of “Sex and the City.” Its hero, George Turner (Erik Thomson), writes a column for a Sydney newspaper — it’s exactly 800 words long — and like Carrie Bradshaw, he reads snippets of it aloud as narration. Unlike her, he actually reads them onscreen, sitting at his laptop and occasionally looking into the camera, as if to make sure we’re listening.

headline: ‘Rolling Coal’ in Diesel Trucks, to Rebel and Provoke
keywords: ['Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Diesel Power', 'Automobiles', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Trucks and Trucking', 'Environment']
abstract: “Coal rollers” alter their diesel trucks so they spew thick black smoke, sometimes in the direction of joggers, cyclists and hybrid cars.
lead_paragraph: MONTROSE, Colo. — There is a new menace on America’s roads: diesel truck drivers who soup up their engines and remove their emissions controls to “roll coal,” or belch black smoke, at pedestrians, cyclists and unsuspecting Prius drivers.

headline: Clash of Titans? Opponents of Pier 55 Have Secret Backer, Media Mogul Says
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: Barry Diller says the real estate tycoon Douglas Durst is behind the fight against his effort to build a park on a Hudson River pier.
lead_paragraph: In their quest to build a huge new cultural pier on the West Side of Manhattan, the Hudson River Park Trust and Barry Diller, the media mogul who is paying for it, have faced one seemingly intractable opponent: the City Club of New York, a little-known civic group founded in 1892 that was all but dead a few years ago. But it has gone back to court repeatedly in the last year to stop the project.

headline: Gun Control Groups Divide Their Loyalties in Senate Races
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Elections, Senate', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)']
abstract: The split illustrates a new dimension in the gun control debate, with party politics at times taking a rare back seat.
lead_paragraph: GLENOLDEN, Pa. — Senator Patrick J. Toomey hears a lot of things he would rather not these days, like the taunts of protesters outside a body shop here about his (actually nonexistent) relationship with Donald J. Trump.

headline: Lucrative Book Deals Might Finance the Obamas’ Post-White House Life
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Writing and Writers', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'First Ladies (US)']
abstract: Though the president has only hinted at what his next step might be, major publishers say the Obamas could earn millions from book contracts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After he is out of the White House, President Obama has said that he wants to become a venture capitalist, own part of an N.B.A. franchise and avoid taking off his shoes during security screenings at commercial airports.

headline: Rafael Nadal Upset by Lucas Pouille in Fourth Round of U.S. Open
abstract: Nadal, a two-time champion of the event, had been rolling through the tournament field. Later, Novak Djokovic easily defeated Kyle Edmund of Britain.
lead_paragraph: After four grueling hours spent fending off a relentless adversary who refused to submit, Rafael Nadal saw the ball exactly where he wanted it, practically on a platter and ready to be plucked.

headline: Egypt’s Christians Say They Are at a ‘Breaking Point’
keywords: ['Christians and Christianity', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: While Imam Mahmoud Gomaa, appointed to keep the peace between two faiths, blames journalists for exaggerating the problem, a local bishop says, “We are at a breaking point.”
lead_paragraph: MINYA, Egypt — The Egyptian government has appointed Imam Mahmoud Gomaa, a Muslim cleric, to keep the peace between Christians and Muslims in this corner of upper Egypt. “Everything is good,” he insisted in an interview, citing Christian participation in his official peace-building initiative.

headline: This Street Is the Whole World
abstract: A woman tallies up the features of a familiar place.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Team Canada Offers Lessons for the Future, From 1972
abstract: Members of Team Canada refuse to let the legacy of their win over the Soviet Union — and the lessons it can provide — slip away.
lead_paragraph: The members of Team Canada 1972 are among the few hockey squads in the history of the country to have both a deep, emotional connection to their citizens and a legacy that stretches beyond their borders. But until recently, the surviving players had lacked a platform to share their story.

headline: Libertarian Gary Johnson Polls at 10 Percent. Who Are His Supporters?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Third-Party Politics (US)']

lead_paragraph: Gary Johnson, the Libertarian candidate for president, may be on track to win more votes than any third-party candidate in 20 years, if current polling holds up.

headline: Jerry Heller, Music Manager Who Promoted N.W.A and Gangsta Rap, Dies at 75
abstract: Mr. Heller was a founder of Ruthless Records, which released N.W.A’s album “Straight Outta Compton” in 1988.
lead_paragraph: Jerry Heller, a veteran music manager who helped introduce N.W.A to the masses and promoted gangsta rap to a mainstream audience, died on Friday in Thousand Oaks, Calif. He was 75.

headline: PGA Tour Rookie Smylie Kaufman Strives to Aid Louisiana Flood Victims

headline: Results of Obama Voter Focus Groups on Hillary Clinton
abstract: Hillary Clinton’s difficulties with young African-Americans were laid bare in four damning focus groups conducted for a handful of progressive organizations. The results were outlined in a presentation by a Democratic pollster, and shared with The Times by another party strategist who wanted to draw attention to Mrs. Clinton’s difficulties in hopes that the campaign would move more aggressively to address the matter.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton’s difficulties with young African-Americans were laid bare in four damning focus groups conducted for a handful of progressive organizations. The results were outlined in a presentation by a Democratic pollster, and shared with The Times by another party strategist who wanted to draw attention to Mrs. Clinton’s difficulties in hopes that the campaign would move more aggressively to address the matter.

headline: Young Blacks Voice Skepticism on Hillary Clinton, Worrying Democrats
abstract: The lack of enthusiasm, and in some cases outright resistance, is rooted in a deep discomfort with the establishment that they believe Mrs. Clinton represents.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When a handful of liberal advocacy organizations convened a series of focus groups with young black voters last month, the assessments of Donald J. Trump were predictably unsparing.

headline: Jack Sock, the Last American Man at the U.S. Open, Heads Home
abstract: Sock lost to Jo-Wilfried Tsonga, 6-3, 6-3, 6-7 (7), 6-2, in the fourth round. No man from the U.S. has reached the tournament’s quarterfinals since 2011.
lead_paragraph: After one final, wildly wayward forehand return by Jack Sock, the American male population in the United States Open singles bracket was reduced to an all-too-familiar zero. Zilch, once again.

headline: F.B.I. Arrests Florida Man Accused of Threatening to Kill Gays
keywords: ['Hate Crimes', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Threats and Threatening Messages', 'Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)']
abstract: A man said on Facebook that he was planning a Labor Day attack, comparing it to the Orlando nightclub massacre and killings of African-Americans by the police, the F.B.I. said.
lead_paragraph: A Florida man who posted a Facebook rant threatening to kill gay people on Labor Day in a style he compared to the massacre at an Orlando nightclub and the killing of African-Americans by police officers has been arrested and charged with a federal crime, the F.B.I. said in a statement.

headline: Look Up: In the Digital Age, Billboards Are Far From Dead
abstract: Billboards, long used by big brands to promote their products, and more recently by tech companies, are flourishing compared with other traditional media.
lead_paragraph: When Axl Rose ended a 23-year feud with his former Guns N’ Roses bandmates, Duff McKagan and Slash, and agreed to reunite with them onstage in 2016, the band unveiled its North American tour in an unusual way. There were no news conferences, talk-show chats or photo ops. Instead, flashy electronic billboards featuring the band’s logo and famous song titles began popping up in major cities across the country.

headline: Caroline Wozniacki Advances to Quarterfinals With Win Over Madison Keys
abstract: Wozniacki, a former world No. 1, has fallen to No. 74, but she handled eighth-seeded Keys in straight sets at the United States Open.
lead_paragraph: After a season of struggles, Caroline Wozniacki said it was “crazy” to be back in the United States Open quarterfinals, given that she had reached that stage only twice this year, at much smaller tournaments.

headline: White House Pushes for Export-Import Bank Deal as Apple Readies iPhone Update
abstract: As the administration seeks a way to get an Obama nominee confirmed to the Export-Import Bank’s board, Apple plans to unveil new versions of the Apple Watch and the iPhone.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what to expect in the week ahead:

headline: Yes, the News Can Survive the Newspaper
abstract: As newspapers fade from the scene, there has been no certainty that the best services that newspapers provide would live on.
lead_paragraph: One day many decades hence, when your grandchildren ask you, “Grandma, what was a newspaper?” you can direct them back to Wednesday, Sept. 7, 2016. Because it may well go down as the day the American newspaper as we’ve known it moved out of intensive care and into the palliative wing on its way to the Great Beyond.

headline: He Denied Blacks Citizenship. Now a City Is Deciding His Statue’s Fate.
abstract: Frederick, Md., is debating how to remove a bronze bust of Roger Brooke Taney, the Supreme Court chief justice who wrote the 1857 Dred Scott decision.
lead_paragraph: FREDERICK, Md. — In 1801, Roger Brooke Taney, the politically minded son of a Maryland tobacco planter, settled here to practice law. He married the sister of Francis Scott Key, won election to the State Senate and worked his way to Washington, where he landed a dream job: Chief Justice of the Supreme Court.

headline: An Art Exhibit Based on a Migrant Tragedy in Austria Stirs Unease
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Festivals', 'Art']
abstract: A video piece about the white truck in which 71 migrants suffocated last year has divided a border town with a long history of embracing refugees.
lead_paragraph: NICKELSDORF, Austria — When darkness descends on this farming village on the border with Hungary, the only lights left shining are often at the Jazzgalerie Nickelsdorf.

headline: No Sailors Needed: Robot Sailboats Scour the Oceans for Data
keywords: ['Sailboats and Sailing', 'Robots and Robotics', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Research', 'Fish and Other Marine Life']
abstract: Richard Jenkins created Saildrone’s autonomous boats to assess fish populations, study the oceans and more, but his grander vision concerns climate change.
lead_paragraph: ALAMEDA, Calif. — Two robotic sailboats trace lawn-mower-style paths across the violent surface of the Bering Sea, off the coast of Alaska. The boats are counting fish — pollock, to be specific — with a fancy version of the fish finder sonar you’d find on a bass fishing boat.

headline: Kolkata Testifies to the Grace of Mother Teresa, Its New Saint
abstract: In an Indian city that has expressed ambivalence about the work of a missionary who made it her home, praise carried the day of her canonization by Pope Francis.
lead_paragraph: KOLKATA, India — When Mother Teresa’s canonization took place on Sunday, a battered-looking audience gathered in front of a screen some 4,500 miles east of St. Peter’s Square: men with caved-in chests, weeping sores wrapped in gauze, extremities missing entirely, legs so thin you could encircle them with a finger and thumb.

headline: How Uber Drivers Decide How Long to Work
keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Research']
abstract: Many new drivers quit early on days when their hourly wage is high but work longer when it is low, the opposite of what economic rationality would seem to dictate.
lead_paragraph: The ride-hailing company Uber is best known for upending the taxi industry. Now it may be making waves in the economics profession as well.

headline: A Publisher Joins an Industry It Covers, Blurring Lines
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Online Advertising', 'Small Business']
abstract: Entrepreneur Media has entered new territory by starting a lending business — a topic it reports on — and using its editorial coverage to promote its venture.
lead_paragraph: When Judy Balint, the chief marketing officer at SmartBiz Loans, read a freelance article that her company’s president contributed to Entrepreneur.com last month, she was startled to see that  a promotion for a rival lender had been added to the beginning — a lender with a partnership with Entrepreneur.

headline: Ivo Karlovic’s Net Game is Rising to Match His Serve, and His Wit
abstract: Recent improvements may help explain why Karlovic, the career leader in aces, finally made it to the fourth round of the U.S. Open on his 13th try.
lead_paragraph: Few things in tennis move faster and land harder than Ivo Karlovic’s serves. The veteran Karlovic, who stands 6 feet 11 inches, has fired off at least one at 156 miles per hour, and no one has recorded more aces. He has delivered more than 11,200 of them and counting.

headline: Oysters Are Nearly Extinct in New York Waters. This Team Is Trying to Coax Them Back.
abstract: The city’s Environmental Protection Department and the Billion Oyster Project are placing tens thousands of oysters in Jamaica Bay to renew their population.
lead_paragraph: Torrential rain poured down on the team of scientists and conservationists on Jamaica Bay as their small boat slowly towed about 85 cages packed with 36,000 oysters, a species that once blanketed New York Harbor but is now nearly extinct there.

headline: Heavy Metal Magazine, Long a Provocateur, Returns to Its Roots
keywords: ['Magazines', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Art', 'Comic Books and Strips']
abstract: The science-fiction and fantasy publication, known for its mature content, aims to recapture its role as a showcase for avant-garde art.
lead_paragraph: Heavy Metal magazine, which will celebrate its 40th anniversary next year, is harking back to its past.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Sept. 5
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes regular weekly auctions of new three- and six-month bills, rescheduled to Tuesday this week because of the Labor Day holiday, and an auction of four-week bills, also on Tuesday.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Monday, September 5, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “I think, perhaps, we may have some difficulty in calling her St. Teresa: Her holiness is so near to us, so tender and so fruitful, that we continue to spontaneously call her Mother Teresa.”

headline: SpaceX’s Explosion Reverberates Across Space, Satellite and Telecom Industries
abstract: Last week’s setback is raising new questions about the private space launch company that has risen rapidly by offering lower costs and promising accelerated schedules.
lead_paragraph: The explosion of a SpaceX rocket last Thursday will have an impact across the space industry, far beyond the losses on the launchpad at Cape Canaveral, Fla.

headline: Roger Y. Tsien, Nobel Winner for Use of Glowing Proteins, Dies at 64
abstract: The biochemist at the University of California, San Diego, transformed a green fluorescent protein from jellyfish into a ubiquitous biological tool.
lead_paragraph: Roger Y. Tsien, who won a Nobel Prize in Chemistry for creating a rainbow of fluorescent proteins that could light up the dance of molecules within cells, died on Aug. 24 in Eugene, Ore. He was 64.

headline: Michel Butor, French Novelist Who Shattered Conventions, Dies at 89
abstract: His experiments with narrative and structure in the late 1950s and early ’60s put him at the forefront of the literary trend known as le nouveau roman.
lead_paragraph: Michel Butor, a French novelist whose experiments with narrative and structure in the late 1950s and early ’60s put him at the forefront of the literary trend known as le nouveau roman (“the new novel”), died on Aug. 24 in Contamine-sur-Arve, in the Rhône-Alpes region of southeastern France. He was 89.

headline: Adriano Espaillat Tests the Role of Kingmaker After His Historic Primary Win
abstract: Mr. Espaillat, a Democrat who is favored to win a congressional seat in November, is trying to help two fellow Dominicans win state primaries.

headline: ‘Fear the Walking Dead’ Season 2, Episode 10: We’ve Done Worse
abstract: Everyone is trying to convince themselves that help is coming.
lead_paragraph: What if you took the zombies out of the “Dead” universe?

headline: Labor Unions, Waning Nationwide, Stay Robust in New York
abstract: New York City and New York State, where the Fight for $15 movement began, have higher rates of union membership than any other city or state.
lead_paragraph: Despite all the attention that has been paid to the union-backed campaign for a $15 minimum wage, the national decline in organized labor has persisted. Still, for three straight years, New York City, the birthplace of the Fight for $15 movement, has bucked that trend, according to a report that was to be released on Monday.

headline: In Hong Kong, Young Protest Leaders Win Seats in Local Elections
abstract: Some of the protesters who took part in the large 2014 pro-democracy demonstrations will now wield a small measure of real political power for the first time.

headline: Nicholas Monroe Takes a Bad Tumble at U.S. Open

headline: New Yorker Festival to Feature David Letterman, Louis C.K.
abstract: Writers, politicians and comedians will give interviews at the 17th Annual New Yorker Festival.
lead_paragraph: David Letterman, the basketball player Jeremy Lin and Sarah Silverman are among the guest stars to be interviewed at the 17th annual New Yorker Festival. The festival will consist of talks, panels, performances and screenings with writers for The New Yorker and prominent cultural figures, and will run Oct. 7-9 in Manhattan.

headline: Mets Get a Solid Start After Dispiriting News on Jacob deGrom
abstract: The Mets again made do with a replacement starter, defeating the Nationals, 5-1. Manager Terry Collins said deGrom would probably miss his next two starts with a sore right forearm.

headline: Obama Plays Down Confrontation With China Over His Plane’s Stairs

headline: New Chinese Vessels Seen Near Disputed Reef in South China Sea

lead_paragraph: In career twilight and in the competitive shadow of her younger sister, Venus Williams nonetheless stepped into the sunlight of a practice court Sunday morning, 12 hours removed from her previous match.

headline: Hillary Clinton Gets Gored
abstract: Will innuendo in the presidential race bring on apocalypse?
lead_paragraph: Americans of a certain age who follow politics and policy closely still have vivid memories of the 2000 election — bad memories, and not just because the man who lost the popular vote somehow ended up in office. For the campaign leading up to that end game was nightmarish too.

headline: A Life of Meaning (Reason Not Required)
abstract: If philosophy is to stay relevant, it must bridge the gap between feeling and thought.
lead_paragraph: Few would disagree with two age-old truisms: We should strive to shape our lives with reason, and a central prerequisite for the good life is a personal sense of meaning. Ideally, the two should go hand in hand. We study the lessons of history, read philosophy, and seek out wise men with the hope of learning what matters. But this acquired knowledge is not the same as the felt sense that one’s life is meaningful.

headline: Looking Down on Black America
abstract: What Donald Trump is missing in his pitch for our votes.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump officially lost me early on the morning of Aug. 25.

headline: Prisons Aren’t the Answer on Immigration
abstract: There are ways to enforce the law without mistreating a population that fits no definition of a criminal threat.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Homeland Security announced late last month that it is considering ending its use of private prisons, as the Justice Department has decided to do. The Homeland Security secretary, Jeh Johnson, told his department’s advisory council to study the issue and report back to him by the end of November.

headline: Donald Trump Does Detroit
abstract: His so-called outreach to black voters is as phony as everything else about him.
lead_paragraph: So, after weeks of preaching his sinister sermon of black pathology to mostly white audiences as part of his utterly fake “black outreach” — which is in fact the effort of a bigot to disguise his bigotry — Donald Trump finally brought his message before a few mostly black audiences.

headline: The Injustice of Making Kids Pay
abstract: Charging court fees to poor juveniles is counterproductive and only increases the likelihood of more crime.
lead_paragraph: It takes a lot these days to surprise anyone with the irrationalities of the American criminal justice system, rife as it is with harsh and counterproductive practices that do little or nothing to improve lives or keep the public safe.

headline: Hope for Americans With Mental Illness
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Editorials']
abstract: Hillary Clinton’s plan would pave the way for improved diagnosis and treatment.
lead_paragraph: More than 40 million American adults — almost 20 percent of the adult American population — will deal with mental illness this year. Yet mental health (of the citizens, not the candidates) has not been an issue in the presidential campaign. Hillary Clinton tried to change that last week, announcing a plan that offers hope for improving mental health research, diagnosis and treatment.

headline: Keep Bikes Off Our Wilderness Trails
abstract: There are plenty of other places to go cycling.
lead_paragraph: Palm Springs, Calif. — Some new threat is always trying to nose its way into America’s wilderness areas. Fierce battles have been fought over logging, mining and damming these last vestiges of our wild heritage. Now proposed legislation in Congress would allow bikes in wilderness.

headline: Shanghai Violin Competition Celebrates Isaac Stern’s Legacy in China
abstract: Mr. Stern’s visit to China, in 1979, is credited with having influenced a generation of young Chinese musicians.
lead_paragraph: More than 35 years after the violinist Isaac Stern made a groundbreaking visit to China, his legacy there lives on.

headline: Australian Teenager Sentenced to 10 Years in Jail for Anzac Day Terror Plot
abstract: Sevdet Ramadan Besim, 19, planned to run over and behead a police officer during a parade in Melbourne for the national holiday in 2015.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — A teenager who plotted to run over and behead a police officer during a holiday parade in Melbourne last year was sentenced on Monday to 10 years in jail.

headline: North Korea Test-Fires 3 Missiles Toward Japan, Seoul Says
abstract: The missiles landed in the sea 125 to 155 miles west of Hokkaido, the northernmost of Japan’s main islands, the Japanese Ministry of Defense said.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea fired three ballistic missiles from the western town of Hwangju toward Japan shortly after noon on Monday, according to South Korea’s Joint Chiefs of Staff. The launches came on the final day of the Group of 20 summit meeting, where the president of South Korea urged the North’s traditional allies, China and Russia, to help persuade it to end such provocations.

headline: A Shopping Mall at Ground Zero, Uninformed by Its Sacred Land
keywords: ['September 11 (2001)', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Shopping Centers and Malls']
abstract: Apart from its snow-white marble floors and soaring features, the new Westfield World Trade Center looks like a mall that could be just about anywhere.
lead_paragraph: “The advice that I would give to people today, if they’re home from work, is to — is to go about a normal day,” Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said on Sept. 12, 2001. “Take the day as an opportunity to go shopping, be with your children. Do things. Get out. Don’t feel — don’t feel locked in.”

headline: Will the New Apple iPhone Have a Headphone Jack? Rumormongers Say It Won’t
abstract: Apple is expected to unveil the latest model on Wednesday, but if it is indeed missing this basic feature, devotees may be left disenchanted.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — If Apple had its way, this week would play out like Christmas for 5-year-olds. First, unbelievable anticipation. Then, great surprise. At the end, immense satisfaction.

headline: Sonia Sotomayor and Elena Kagan Muse Over a Cookie-Cutter Supreme Court
abstract: The justices discussed diversity on a Supreme Court drawn solely from Ivy League law schools and almost entirely from the East and West Coasts.
lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — As the Supreme Court prepares to return to the bench next month, its two newest members have been reflecting on the absence of Justice Antonin Scalia, who died in February, and on the striking lack of diversity among the remaining justices.

headline: Drug Linked to Ohio Overdoses Can Kill in Doses Smaller than a Snowflake
abstract: Carfentanil, an animal tranquilizer, was believed responsible for many of more than 200 overdoses in the Cincinnati area over the past two weeks.
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — On the day he almost died, John Hatmaker bought a packet of Oreos and some ruby-red Swedish Fish at the corner store for his 5-year-old son. He was walking home when he spotted a man who used to sell him heroin.

headline: Mark Thompson’s New Book on the Use and Misuse of Rhetoric
abstract: The Times Company’s chief executive, Mark Thompson, reflects on the changing use of language by politicians, the public and the media in “Enough Said.”

lead_paragraph: One generation’s smartest talk show host meets another’s to discuss the rules of comedy, and how to break them.

headline: ScienceTake: Bees Buzz for Their Supper
abstract: Researchers from the University of Arizona experimented to find out whether a bee’s technique to cull pollen from flowers was learned, or instinctual.
lead_paragraph: Researchers from the University of Arizona experimented to find out whether a bee’s technique to cull pollen from flowers was learned, or instinctual.

headline: Bees Buzz for Their Supper
abstract: The insects innately use vibration to cause the release of pollen from some flowers.
lead_paragraph: The familiar buzz of a bumble bee is one of those summer sounds that is easy to take for granted. But for the bees, buzzing has a purpose. They may buzz during courtship, or out of alarm if they are caught or trapped.

headline: London Burns, for the Sake of Art
abstract: A replica of the city’s skyline was set ablaze as part of a festival marking the 350th anniversary of the Great Fire.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The skyline of the British capital burst into flames Sunday night. Unlike when London burned in 1666, this was only an art project.

headline: Politics Are Tricky but Science Is Clear: Needle Exchanges Work
keywords: ['Medicine and Health', 'Hypodermic Needles and Syringes', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Hepatitis', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: Not only do the exchange programs reduce the spread of damaging viral infections, but they also have been shown to save money.
lead_paragraph: For decades, public health experts have known that syringe exchange programs reduce the spread of certain viral infections — like H.I.V., hepatitis B and hepatitis C — by removing contaminated syringes from circulation.

headline: South Sudan to Allow More U.N. Peacekeepers, but Force Will Be No ‘Panacea’

lead_paragraph: UKUNDA, Kenya — Under intense pressure, South Sudan’s beleaguered government has relented and will allow more United Nations peacekeepers into the country.

headline: Gentler Chicken Slaughter? Chinese Province Thinks It’s Worth a Try
keywords: ['Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Slaughterhouses', 'Chickens', 'Factory Farming', 'Poultry', 'Agriculture and Farming']
abstract: New voluntary guidelines in Shandong Province are motivated at least as much by commercial considerations as by concerns for animal welfare.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In its final hours before being butchered, a chicken deserves to be reasonably comfortable and relatively stress-free. This is the message from China’s first official recommendations to the poultry industry, recently issued by Shandong Province, on how to slaughter the animals.

headline: 1966: Philippine Sect Battles Police
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: A sect in the Philippines fights with the police in September 1966.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — A band of religious fanatics led by a white-robed man who calls himself ‘‘God’’ battled on today [Sept. 5] against pursuing armed police after a weekend clash in which 1,000 of his followers surrendered. Victorino Siagan, the 27-year old leader, and about 40 armed followers escaped after a skirmish with troopers on Mindanao island in which six followers and one policeman were killed.

headline: Vote in Hong Kong Deepens a Thorn in China’s Side
abstract: The election of six freethinking young legislators means that Beijing must deal with an indigenous movement elevated to positions of political power.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — In Canada, it is the Québécois. In Spain, the Catalans. In Britain, the Scots.

headline: On Labor Day, Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton Begin a Final Sprint
abstract: Mrs. Clinton returned to the trail on Monday after a summer of fund-raising, while Mr. Trump went to Ohio to begin a week of swing-state campaigning.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump ran virtually parallel campaigns on Monday as they geared up for the final stretch of the presidential race. She made nice with the news media by opening up her campaign plane and chatting with reporters. He followed suit, inviting a smaller group of reporters onto his plane and answering questions during the 30-minute flight.

headline: 2 Killed at J’ouvert Celebration in Brooklyn Despite Security Steps
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'West Indian-American Day', 'Parades']
abstract: The early morning festivities that precede the West Indian American Day Parade left a 17-year-old and a 22-year-old dead from gunshot wounds.
lead_paragraph: This year, J’ouvert was supposed to be different.

headline: ‘Gaps of Trust’ With Russia Bar a Syrian Truce, Obama Says
abstract: After a meeting with Russia’s president at the Group of 20 summit meeting failed, President Obama said he had told Secretary of State John Kerry to continue negotiating.
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos — The Obama administration’s latest effort to broker a cease-fire in Syria’s civil war fell short on Monday, after a 90-minute meeting between President Obama and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia failed to resolve problems between them.

headline: Barclays Hires JPMorgan Executive to Head Investment Bank
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Tim Throsby will join Barclays in January as president of its corporate and international business and as chief executive of its corporate and investment bank.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — James E. Staley, the Barclays chief executive, has turned to another executive from his former employer, JPMorgan Chase, to fill out his new bank’s executive ranks.

headline: At World Scrabble Championship, ‘Braconid’ Carries the Day
abstract: Good for 176 points, the word for a type of parasitic wasp helped a London recruitment consultant take the top prize of 7,000 euros.
lead_paragraph: In the end, victory came down to a parasitic wasp.

headline: I Was a Hotline Psychic for Miss Cleo
abstract: Lonely hearts hoped to talk with the woman famous from those late night TV commercials. They got me instead.
lead_paragraph: The summer I became a phone psychic, you could still wear shoes through airport security, Britney Spears had not yet shaved her head and no one knew I was flunking out of college.

headline: A Budding Beauty Baron Gets an Assist From Nas
abstract: The entrepreneur Tristan Walker has introduced an electric trimmer designed especially for black men. Now a famous fellow Queens native is on board.
lead_paragraph: For nearly four years, hip-hop fans have been waiting for Nas to release his long-gestating 12th studio album. Over the summer the Queens-born rapper offered more than a hint that it was ready to go when he appeared as the featured rapper on a track from DJ Khaled’s latest album, “Nas Album Done.”

headline: How New York Times Stories Are Like Footballs
abstract: Backfield to copy desk to slot. Pass, run, score!
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this article, Steven Rocker, a news assistant, explains how Times stories move through the editing process, not unlike a football through a play.

headline: The Mystery of Sweating Buckets
abstract: The overlapping factors that affect an individual’s heat tolerance are many, ranging from age and body mass to circulatory efficiency and hydration.
lead_paragraph: Q. A 90-degree day means I sweat buckets just walking the dog and lose every bit of energy. Why do some people tolerate the heat less well than others?

headline: U.S. Open Today: Breakthrough Wins for Karolina Pliskova and Ana Konjuh
abstract: Here’s what happened Monday at the United States Open, including upsets of Venus Williams and Agnieszka Radwanska.
lead_paragraph: In the past year, Karolina Pliskova, 24, has been in the top 10 and became the highest-ranked player from the Czech Republic.

headline: Merkel Vows to Stay on Course Despite Party Setback
abstract: The German leader’s party placed third in state elections, beaten on the right over her refugee policy and defeated on the left as well.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A day after voters in Chancellor Angela Merkel’s political home state delivered what amounted to a strong rejection of her refugee policy, the German leader acknowledged on Monday that she was “very dissatisfied” with the result but insisted that she would stick with her chosen course.

headline: 1891: Wusueh Outrages in China
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: China’s foreign population is outraged over the country’s tardiness to punish the Wusueh murders perpetrators in September 1891.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — A Wuchang correspondent, writing on August 3 to the North China News, which has just been received here by mail, says the patience of the foreign population is well nigh exhausted by the tardiness of the Chinese officials in punishing the perpetrators of the Wusueh outrages. On the second batch of offenders, eight in number, who were convicted of murder, assault and pillage, sentences of penal servitude for life, banishment for life, or branding on the face or back were imposed. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 6, 1891

headline: Coordinated Bombs in Kabul Kill Senior Afghan Officials at Defense Ministry
abstract: An army general and police security chief were among the dead in a Taliban assault at rush hour. Just before midnight, another blast shook central Kabul.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A pair of coordinated Taliban bombings targeted the Afghan Defense Ministry in a crowded neighborhood of Kabul on Monday, officials said, killing at least 24 people and wounding dozens, among them senior security officials.

headline: Where Is Safe? Travelers Seek Havens in Wake of Europe Attacks
abstract: Tour operators say Americans are going to places like Canada, Iceland, United States national parks and, yes, some spots in Europe.
lead_paragraph: In the months since the November terrorist attack in Paris and the March bombing of the Brussels airport, Americans did something that may seem counterintuitive. They went to Europe more, with travelers up 5 percent in April, according to the Department of Commerce’s National Travel & Tourism Office.

headline: A Monster Watch Mashup
abstract: The Swiss watchmaker HYT salutes Frankenstein’s famous monster.
lead_paragraph: This year the Swiss watchmaker HYT is saluting the 200th birthday of another well-known creation of Swiss provenance: Frankenstein’s famous monster, which Mary Shelley dreamed up while visiting Lord Byron at Lake Geneva.

headline: Happy Labor Day!
abstract: Patty melts, ice cream cake and more for a day of celebration.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: ‘A Mechanical Bestiary’, With Time
abstract: Galerie J. Kugel is organizing a display of rare Renaissance-era automaton clocks.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — “Who is ticking?” Alexis Kugel playfully asked a group of ornate animal figures in his palatial antiques gallery at the historic Hôtel Collot.

headline: A.N.C.’s Combative Response to Election Losses Startles South Africa
abstract: The country’s governing party has brushed aside calls to replace President Jacob Zuma, raising doubts about another African liberation movement.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — When South African voters last month handed the African National Congress its worst-ever losses, seemingly chastened party leaders said they would engage in “introspection.”

headline: ‘I’ve Become a Racist’: Migrant Wave Unleashes Danish Tensions Over Identity
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Discrimination', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: The thousands of Muslim asylum seekers pouring into Denmark have spawned a backlash, and questions over whether the country has a latent racial hostility at its core.
lead_paragraph: TAARNBY, Denmark — Johnny Christensen, a stout and silver-whiskered retired bank employee, always thought of himself as sympathetic to people fleeing war and welcoming to immigrants. But after more than 36,000 mostly Muslim asylum seekers poured into Denmark over the past two years, Mr. Christensen, 65, said, “I’ve become a racist.”

headline: A Land Eager to Look Rich: Luxury Brands Edge Into Myanmar
abstract: Overseas luxury brands are beginning to sell watches and other goods in Myanmar, which has grown swiftly since 2012.
lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — “Every man has a crazy hobby,” said U Thiri Thein Than, an automotive engineer from Yangon who also has a home in Tokyo. “For me, it’s cars and watches.”

headline: Obama Says Colin Kaepernick Is ‘Exercising His Constitutional Right’
abstract: The president spoke for the first time on the decision by the San Francisco 49ers quarterback not to stand during the national anthem.
lead_paragraph: President Obama said Monday that Colin Kaepernick, the San Francisco 49ers quarterback, was “exercising his constitutional right” by refusing to stand during the national anthem, a decision that has fostered considerable controversy since he first took the action on Aug. 26.

headline: Crossing the Pool
abstract: You’re on one side of the pool, and your martini is on the other. What’s the fastest way to reach your beverage?
lead_paragraph: This week’s puzzle was suggested by Steve Humble (@drmaths), an author and mathematics educator from Newcastle University. Steve was relaxing by the pool in Murcia, Spain recently and thought of this athletic challenge. Here’s Steve with —

headline: What You Should Watch: ‘Queen Sugar’ and ‘Atlanta’
abstract: From the Watching team, expert TV and movie recommendations for the next few days.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Watching, The New York Times’s what-to-watch guide. We comb through releases big and small to email readers twice a week with our timely recommendations. You can browse previous guides here, and to receive recommendations straight to your inbox, sign up here. Stay tuned for our coming website.

headline: Female Scientists Turn to Data to Fight Lack of Representation on Panels
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Brain', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Discrimination', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: Noticing the skewed lineups at conferences, a Princeton neuroscientist and colleagues have started a website to compare the gender ratios at conferences to those in a particular field over all.
lead_paragraph: One day in August 2015, the Princeton University neuroscientist Yael Niv saw an email notice of a conference on deep brain stimulation, a hot topic in treatment for depression and other mental disorders. Dr. Niv noticed that none of the 21 scientists scheduled to speak were women.

headline: Q. and A.: Andy Murray Puts On His Politician’s Hat
abstract: Murray was recently elected to his first term on the ATP Player Council and attended his first meeting, which lasted four and a half hours.
lead_paragraph: For a fifth year, The New York Times is speaking to Andy Murray after his matches at the United States Open, where he broke through for his first Grand Slam title in 2012. Murray, who plays Grigor Dimitrov in the fourth round Monday night, was recently elected to his first term on the ATP Player Council (Novak Djokovic was elected president). After a strenuous first meeting, Murray discussed the issues most important to the tour and to him, as well as his inclination toward politics.

headline: Doctors on Lookout for Crimean-Congo Hemorrhagic Fever in Spain
abstract: A hospital patient in Madrid died of the illness, the first finding of the fever in Western Europe in someone who had not traveled to an endemic area.
lead_paragraph: Doctors are closely watching about 200 people in Spain after a patient at a hospital in Madrid died of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever, the first time the disease has been found in Western Europe in someone who had not traveled to an endemic area.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers react to articles in Science Times.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: 11 Books Worth Reading About the World Trade Center’s Redevelopment
keywords: ['September 11 (2001)', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'ARCHITECTURE', '1 World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)']
abstract: David W. Dunlap, who has covered the rebuilding of ground zero for the past 13 years, offers his go-to list of books on the topic.
lead_paragraph: Lynne B. Sagalyn’s “Power at Ground Zero: Politics, Money and the Remaking of Lower Manhattan” and Judith Dupré’s “One World Trade Center: Biography of the Building” are two of the most consequential new books about the redevelopment of the World Trade Center.

headline: Does the Messaging Service Telegram Take Privacy Too Far?
abstract: Telegram, favored by the Islamic State because of its formidable privacy controls, is a source of consternation for antiterrorism investigators.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The encryption of digital information is considered the best protection against hackers, snoops or potential enemies looking to poke around into private exchanges of all sorts.

headline: No Longer Missing: Rosetta’s Philae Spacecraft Located on Comet
abstract: Scientists have found the space lander, which disappeared in 2014 after a rough landing on the surface of a comet.
lead_paragraph: With its legs poking out of a dark crevice on a speeding comet many millions of miles away, the Philae spacecraft, missing since 2014 after a 10-year trip, has finally been found.

headline: On Being a Black Female Math Whiz During the Space Race
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Books and Literature', 'Rocket Science and Propulsion', 'Movies']
abstract: Former NASA mathematicians discuss the matter-of-fact way they approached their work and the new history about their careers in “Hidden Figures,” which is being made into a film.
lead_paragraph: HAMPTON, Va. — Growing up here in the 1970s, in the shadow of Langley Research Center, where workers helped revolutionize air flight and put Americans on the moon, Margot Lee Shetterly had a pretty fixed idea of what scientists looked like: They were middle class, African-American and worked at NASA, like her dad.

headline: In Philippine Drug War, Little Help for Those Who Surrender
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: An estimated 687,000 drug users have turned themselves in since President Rodrigo Duterte took office, but the government is proving unprepared to assist them.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — Rayzabell Bongol, an 18-year-old mother and methamphetamine user, was afraid to die in President Rodrigo Duterte’s war on drugs in the Philippines. So she turned herself in to the police. They made her sign a pledge that she would never take illegal drugs again, then sent her home.

headline: Kabul Bombing Witnesses Describe Attack
abstract: An attack by Taliban suicide bombers in a busy area near the defense ministry in Kabul killed at least 20 people, the deadliest toll in the Afghan capital in weeks.
lead_paragraph: An attack by Taliban suicide bombers in a busy area near the defense ministry in Kabul killed at least 20 people, the deadliest toll in the Afghan capital in weeks.

headline: Researchers Confront an Epidemic of Loneliness
abstract: Social isolation is linked to physical illness and to functional and cognitive decline. Programs to reach out to the elderly are growing, particularly in Britain.
lead_paragraph: BLACKPOOL, England — The woman on the other end of the phone spoke lightheartedly of spring and of her 81st birthday the previous week.

headline: ‘Narcos’ Season 2 Episode 4: No One Escapes
abstract: If Season 1 of “Narcos” was about the drug empire Escobar created, this season is about the moral and mortal toll it exacts on everyone, even Escobar.
lead_paragraph: The character of Colonel Horacio Carrillo in “Narcos” was thought to be based loosely on Col. Hugo Martínez, the leader of the Search Bloc police unit tasked by President Gaviria with hunting Pablo Escobar. In a Daily Beast column from last year titled “The Man Who Brought Down Pablo Escobar,” the then-74-year-old Martínez told the author Kim MacQuarrie about Escobar’s many attempts to bribe, intimidate and murder him before Search Bloc finally captured him on Dec. 2, 1993. MacQuarrie also noted the “Narcos” inspiration, writing:

headline: Sorry About That: Wells Fargo to End Ads Suggesting Science Over Arts
abstract: The financial services giant apologizes after an uproar on Twitter in response to “teen financial education day” ads.
lead_paragraph: Wells Fargo, the financial services giant immortalized in lyrics to “The Music Man,” has apologized for advertisements that seemed to suggest that teenagers should set aside their artistic dreams and choose careers in science.

headline: Overlooked Influences on Donald Trump: A Famous Minister and His Church
abstract: For all that has been written about Mr. Trump, relatively little attention has been paid to the time he spent at Marble Collegiate Church and his relationship with the Rev. Norman Vincent Peale.
lead_paragraph: Just before a Sunday morning service in the early 1990s, two women walked into one of Manhattan’s most venerable sanctuaries, Marble Collegiate Church, on Fifth Avenue. The usher who seated them, sizing them up as first-time worshipers, asked what had brought them to Marble, as the church is known.

headline: The California Voter Ordeal: 17 Decisions on the Ballot
abstract: It may be hard for Californians to fully take in all the ballot initiatives in November, though close to $100 million in advertisements will try to persuade them.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Pity the California voter.

headline: Keeping Your Old Phone Alive and Working
abstract: Even if your trusty smartphone is no longer supported or updated by its maker, you can keep it going with replacement parts and tender loving care.
lead_paragraph: Q. Some of us like our older phones and want to keep them. I know for many just getting a new battery will be enough, so what resources are available for those of us who want to keep our older iPhones, Android phones and other gear going for as long as possible?

headline: Air Force, Running Low on Drone Pilots, Turns to Contractors in Terror Fight
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Defense Contracts', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Aircraft']
abstract: The Pentagon is increasingly relying on private contractors to operate drones for reconnaissance missions in Afghanistan and Iraq.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The American military’s extensive use of drones against the Islamic State and other terrorist groups has resulted in a shortage of Air Force pilots and other personnel to operate the aircraft, leading the Pentagon to rely more on private contractors for reconnaissance missions in Afghanistan and Iraq.

headline: Syrian Forces Make Gains Near Aleppo With Russian Help
abstract: Russian airstrikes aided the advance, as officials from Russia and the United States reportedly tried to negotiate access for humanitarian aid to the city.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Russian airstrikes helped the Syrian government and allied forces seize critical territory on the outskirts of the divided northern city of Aleppo on Monday, tightening a siege of rebel-held territory there as Russian and American officials joined meetings said to be aimed at hashing out access for humanitarian aid to the city.

headline: With Occupancy High, Hotels Seek to Avoid Online Booking Services
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Customer Loyalty Programs', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: To attract guests from services like Expedia and Travelocity, hotels offer discounts if travelers book through the hotel’s site.
lead_paragraph: Hotels and online travel booking companies tend to have a marriage of convenience — one that savvy travelers can exploit.

headline: Director of the Victoria and Albert Museum to Step Down
abstract: The museum announced the move, slated for this fall, on Monday, after British media reports of the departure of Martin Roth.
lead_paragraph: London — Martin Roth, the director of the Victoria and Albert Museum, will step down from his position in the fall, the museum announced on Monday. The announcement came after the British media had published rumors of his imminent resignation over the weekend, based on an interview that Mr. Roth gave in late June to the German broadcaster DW. In that interview, the German-born Mr. Roth voiced his unhappiness at Britain’s Brexit vote, describing it as “horrible.”

headline: Brazil’s ‘Better Than Goldman’ Bank Slowly Rebounds From Scandal
abstract: Since the arrest of its former chief, André Esteves, in connection with the Petrobras investigation, BTG Pactual has reined in its highflying ambitions.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — BTG Pactual, a once highflying Brazilian investment bank that stumbled badly during a brush with scandal last year, is reinventing itself with more modest aspirations.

headline: After Obama Cancels Talk, Rodrigo Duterte of Philippines Says He Regrets Slur
keywords: ['Elections, Mayors', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Philippine leader had used coarse language in warning President Obama not to ask about extrajudicial killings at their scheduled meeting in Laos this week.
lead_paragraph: President Obama canceled a meeting with President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines scheduled for Tuesday in Laos, after the Philippine president directed an expletive at Mr. Obama on Monday.

headline: Streisand’s ‘Encore’ Tops the Billboard Album Chart
abstract: Ms. Streisand’s latest record didn’t do well on streaming services. But strong sales gave her yet another No. 1 album, 52 years after her first.
lead_paragraph: Show business rule No. 1: Never doubt Barbra Streisand, as this week’s music charts affirm once again. (Rule No. 2 might be: Never doubt Beyoncé.)

headline: Tyler Austin Aids in a Yankees Victory, and Makes a Statement
abstract: Hoping to become the team’s regular first baseman when Mark Teixeira retires after this season, Austin doubled twice and helped the Yankees defeat Toronto.
lead_paragraph: With Mark Teixeira set to retire after this season, there will be a rare vacancy at first base at Yankee Stadium next year.

headline: Review: In FX’s ‘Atlanta,’ a Princeton Dropout Works the Angles Back Home
abstract: Donald Glover stars in this dry, offbeat comedy about the expansive territory between rags and riches.
lead_paragraph: In “Atlanta,” Donald Glover plays a character whose name — Earn — is also his aspiration. He’s not earning much right now. A Princeton dropout, he’s “technically homeless,” crashing with the mother of his baby daughter and pushing credit-card sign-ups at the airport for $5.15 an hour.

headline: Review: ‘Queen Sugar,’ on OWN, Yields Family Drama
abstract: This series, the latest on Oprah Winfrey’s cable channel, brings three feuding siblings back together, a sugar operation hanging in the balance.
lead_paragraph: More than five years after it went on the air, OWN, Oprah Winfrey’s cable channel, still seems as if it’s trying to define itself. So perhaps it’s no surprise that its latest series, “Queen Sugar,” feels that way too. The show, which begins on Tuesday, is definitely a drama, but it sure is a hodgepodge of tones and topics.

headline: Review: ‘Nutshell,’ a Tale Told by a Baby-to-Be (or Not-to-Be)
abstract: Ian McEwan’s newest novel combines elements of “Hamlet,” “Look Who’s Talking” and maybe even “Family Guy.”
lead_paragraph: With “Nutshell,” Ian McEwan has performed an incongruous magic trick, mashing up the premises of Shakespeare’s “Hamlet” and Amy Heckerling’s 1989 movie, “Look Who’s Talking,” to create a smart, funny and utterly captivating novel.

headline: Theresa May Rules Out Immigration Plan That ‘Brexit’ Backers Espoused
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The British prime minister rejected a points-based system in giving her first, tentative details on plans for Britain’s withdrawal, but remained fuzzy on much else.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Outlining the first, tentative details of how she intends to leave the European Union without damaging Britain’s economy, Prime Minister Theresa May on Monday ruled out the type of immigration curbs championed by prominent supporters of withdrawal before June’s referendum on quitting the bloc.

headline: Review: Inventing a Better Bitcoin in ‘StartUp,’ New on Crackle
abstract: This drama brings together an unlikely threesome in Miami in an effort to get a new digital currency off the ground.
lead_paragraph: Jerry Seinfeld is going to run out of cars someday. “StartUp” is the latest manifestation of that inevitability.

headline: Cinema Is Dead? Telluride Says Not Yet
abstract: It was a dreary summer at the box office, but this festival provides proof of life for the art of moviemaking.
lead_paragraph: TELLURIDE, Colo. — Can we please kill the talk about the death of movies?

headline: Review: In ‘The Jamb,’ 2 Gay Middle-Age Friends Face a Reckoning
abstract: J. Stephen Brantley’s new play is set in 2008 as same-sex marriage is becoming legal one state at a time.
lead_paragraph: At 40, Roderick is fit and muscular, and leads a healthy life. He is also angry at just about everything, especially gay men who waste their lives getting wasted — chief among them his best friend, Tuffer, a trust-fund wastrel with a weakness for crystal meth and go-go boys. What makes things worse for Roderick is that before adopting the monastic precepts of straightedge hardcore music — no drugs, no booze, no fun — he used to be just like Tuffer. Now, he’s the one on call when his buddy cries for help at 4 a.m.

headline: Lacking Sleep and Several Starters, the Mets Power Through
abstract: The Mets were under-slept and resting Asdrubal Cabrera, Yoenis Cespedes, Jose Reyes and Curtis Granderson when they arrived in Cincinnati but went on to shut out the Reds.
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — The Mets arrived here just before 3 a.m. Monday, and many players did not get to sleep until an hour later, all because of a late game Sunday night at Citi Field. Mets Manager Terry Collins swore at his alarm clock when it sounded, yet he was still at Great American Ball Park at 8 a.m.

headline: Hugh O’Brian Dies; Dashing TV Star of ‘Wyatt Earp’ Was 91
abstract: Mr. O’Brian played the title role in the western “The Life and Legend of Wyatt Earp” from 1955 to 1961.
lead_paragraph: Hugh O’Brian, who rose to fame on television as the quick-drawing lawman Wyatt Earp in the 1950s and who later devoted extensive time to a foundation he created that trains young people to be leaders, died on Monday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 91.

headline: Osiris-Rex: Chasing Asteroid Bennu
abstract: NASA’s Osiris-Rex spacecraft will hunt down an asteroid and return a sample to Earth.
lead_paragraph: NASA’s Osiris-Rex spacecraft will hunt down an asteroid and return a sample to Earth.

headline: NASA Aims at an Asteroid Holding Clues to the Solar System’s Roots
abstract: The robotic spacecraft Osiris-Rex, to be launched Thursday, will chase down Bennu and then, hopefully, return with a sample from its surface.
lead_paragraph: For the next two years, NASA’s latest robotic spacecraft will be chasing down an asteroid near Earth in the hopes of scooping up some of the most primordial bits of the solar system.

headline: BuzzFeed Regroups as Media Turns Video-Centric
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: A reorganization emphasizes video and entertainment to generate revenue, but executives say the company remains committed to its news operations.
lead_paragraph: Staff meetings at BuzzFeed are not uncommon. Jonah H. Peretti, the site’s founder and chief executive, who is based in Los Angeles, travels to the New York offices regularly and often meets with employees to answer questions or outline strategy.

headline: Namon Hoggle, 81, Accused in a Civil Rights Killing, Is Dead
abstract: Mr. Hoggle was the last surviving defendant in the fatal beating of James J. Reeb, a white minister who had marched with civil rights advocates, in Selma, Ala., in 1965.
lead_paragraph: Namon O’Neal Hoggle, the last surviving defendant accused of bludgeoning a minister to death in Selma, Ala., in 1965 — a killing that galvanized the civil rights movement in the South and helped embolden Congress to ban racial discrimination in voting — died on Aug. 30 in Selma. He was 81.

headline: Q. and A.: Eric Korita Shares the Keys to a Power Serve
abstract: In the 1980s, Korita regularly served over 140 miles per hour in an era when that was unheard of. And power, he says, is about more than size and strength.
lead_paragraph: In the 1980s, the most powerful serve in tennis belonged to Eric Korita. He never achieved the overall success of his big-serving predecessor Roscoe Tanner or successors like Mark Philippoussis or Ivo Karlovic. Korita’s highest world ranking was 30th in doubles and 46th in singles, but he regularly served faster than 140 miles per hour in an era when that was unheard of. Korita will be at the United States Open, giving a clinic on serving, for The New York Times on Facebook Live on Tuesday at 1 p.m. First, he shared some thoughts on his biggest weapon.

headline: The Bridge Scandal: You Ask, We Answer
abstract: New York Times reporters answered readers’ questions about the George Washington Bridge scandal in a live online discussion on Wednesday, Sept. 7, 2016.
lead_paragraph: New York Times reporters answered readers’ questions about the George Washington Bridge scandal in a live online discussion on Wednesday, Sept. 7, 2016.

headline: Rory McIlroy Wins a Windy Deutsche Bank Championship
abstract: Amid conditions one golfer described as “heavy, heavy, really gusty,” McIlroy earned his first PGA win since May 2015 and vaulted to fourth in the FedEx Cup standings.
lead_paragraph: NORTON, Mass. — For most of the field — even golf’s elite — a relentless, swirling wind turned the final round of the Deutsche Bank Championship into a survival test.

headline: Why Airgas Was Finally Sold, for $10 Billion Instead of $5 Billion
abstract: After a bitter battle with a rival intent on taking over the company he founded, Peter McCausland grew tired of fighting big shareholders.
lead_paragraph: Big shareholders do not always play nice.

headline: No ‘For Sale’ Sign? Silicon Valley Buyers Aren’t Deterred
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: So few homes are on the market that buyers are getting more aggressive and innovative in approaching owners who haven’t officially decided to sell.
lead_paragraph: REDWOOD CITY, Calif. — Swell-looking home you’ve got here. Ever think about selling it? How about to me, right now?

headline: Donald Trump’s Alt-Right Brain
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Editorials']
abstract: Mr. Trump has given white supremacists the megaphone they have craved for years.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has devoted most of the past two weeks to discussing immigration, even though only 8 percent of Americans rank it as “the most important problem facing this country today,” according to a recent Gallup poll.

headline: Despite Bernie Sanders’s Urging, Die-Hards Still Resist Hillary Clinton
abstract: The Democratic runner-up urged attendees at a Labor Day rally to vote for Mrs. Clinton as a bulwark against Donald Trump. But many weren’t convinced.
lead_paragraph: LEBANON, N.H. — Outside Senator Bernie Sanders’s first general-election rally for Hillary Clinton on Monday, a small group of Clinton supporters and former Sanders backers glared at one another.

headline: Roger Ailes Hints at Suit Against New York Magazine
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Libel and Slander', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Gabriel Sherman, a reporter for the magazine, has been at the forefront in covering the former Fox News chairman’s ignominious removal.
lead_paragraph: A lawyer for Roger Ailes, the former chairman of Fox News, has sent a letter to New York magazine suggesting he might take legal action over its reporting about Mr. Ailes.

headline: Phyllis Schlafly, ‘First Lady’ of a Political March to the Right, Dies at 92
abstract: Angered by the cultural transformations of the 1960s, Mrs. Schlafly led grass-roots campaigns against Communism, abortion and the Equal Rights Amendment.
lead_paragraph: Phyllis Schlafly, whose grass-roots campaigns against Communism, abortion and the Equal Rights Amendment galvanized conservatives for almost two generations and helped reshape American politics, died on Monday. She was 92.

headline: Russian Polling Center Is Declared a ‘Foreign Agent’ Before Elections
abstract: The independent Levada Center, which has conducted surveys since the late 1980s, recently reported declining support for the governing United Russia party.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russian officials declared the Levada Center, the country’s only major independent pollster, a “foreign agent” on Monday, two weeks before nationwide parliamentary elections and days after a poll showed sliding support for the governing party, United Russia.

headline: Save the Republican Party: Vote for Clinton
abstract: For Republicans opposed to Trump, sitting out the election or supporting a third-party candidate are a coward’s game.

Vote for Hillary Clinton, who has trouble with the truth, wants to raise taxes and opposes free trade with Asia? Vote for the Libertarian candidate, Gary Johnson, an outlier who once ran a marijuana business and embraces isolationism? Or not vote at all, maintaining a certain purity but allowing others to decide the next president?

headline: False Hope and a Needless Death Behind Bars
keywords: ['Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Probation and Parole', 'Editorials']
abstract: John MacKenzie was a model prisoner for more than 40 years, but after 10 denials of parole he realized the only way out was to kill himself.
lead_paragraph: On July 26, John MacKenzie went before the parole board at the Fishkill Correctional Facility in Beacon, N.Y., and made the case, once again, for his freedom. He had been locked up since 1975 for shooting and killing a Long Island police officer, Matthew Giglio, during a bungled robbery attempt. His sentence was 25 years to life — the maximum under state law.

headline: The Incredible Shrinking Obamacare
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Considering how it’s turned out, what was all the fuss about?

The supporters argued that the system would help Americans purchase health insurance through carefully regulated state exchanges. President Obama envisioned a day when consumers could shop for health coverage “the same way you’d shop for a plane ticket on Kayak or a TV on Amazon.”

headline: Surfing in Nixonland
keywords: ['Surfing', 'Vietnam War', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: I learned that history, too, happens in waves.
lead_paragraph: I first moved to San Clemente, Calif., in 2007, my last year of graduate school, renting a house in town about a mile up the coast from the so-called Western White House, the beachfront estate Richard Nixon bought in 1969 shortly after winning the presidency. The Nixons called it La Casa Pacifica and lived there through most of the 1970s. I surfed in front of it a lot that first summer, at a spot the locals called Cotton’s, after the original owner of the property, Hamilton H. Cotton, an F.D.R. man as it happened.

headline: Shariah With Chinese Characteristics: A Scholar Looks at the Muslim Hui
abstract: Matthew S. Erie’s findings about the Hui ethnic group confound many preconceptions about Shariah, Chinese law and the rigidity of the Communist state.
lead_paragraph: Matthew S. Erie, a trained lawyer and ethnographer who teaches at Oxford University, lived for two years in Linxia, a small city in the northwestern Chinese province of Gansu. Known as China’s Mecca, it is a center of religious life for the Hui, an ethnic minority numbering 10 million who practice Islam. Along with the Turkic Uighurs, they are one of 10 officially recognized ethnic groups that practice Islam, making the total population of Muslims in China around 23 million, according to the 2010 government census.

headline: How Much ‘Disclosure’ Do We Really Expect From Candidates?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'English Language', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: And what exactly are we looking for?
lead_paragraph: It’s a safe bet that advisers to Hillary Clinton spend more time than they would like batting away the suggestion that their candidate must be hiding something. This is what Joel Benenson, Clinton’s chief campaign strategist, had to do on CNN one morning in late August, when the anchor Chris Cuomo confronted him with questions about Clinton’s meetings with donors to the Clinton Foundation, in the years when she was secretary of state. The subtext was whether Clinton had been forthcoming enough about the influence of her private connections on her exercise of official power. Benenson, like any good surrogate, tried to change the subject. “Let’s talk about Donald Trump,” he said. “The man who said, ‘I will release my tax returns if I run for president.’ Who knows what we’ll find if he releases those tax returns? I think if you want to be hammering somebody in this race day in and day out about disclosure,” he added, it should be Trump.

headline: How Much Do We Really Know About Global Trade’s Impacts?
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment', 'Poverty']
abstract: On the surprisingly murky economics of globalization.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s campaign has at times resembled a whistle-stop tour of broken-down manufacturing towns. Places like Monessen, Pa., and Hickory, N.C., have come to be seen as central to his rise — and that of Bernie Sanders, before he bowed out — as well as symbols of a national preoccupation during this election season: the downsides of globalization. Earlier this year, research that led to an academic paper from several economists titled “The China Shock” found that between 1999 and 2011, the growth in imports from China killed about 2.4 million American jobs, one million or so of them in manufacturing. That’s a much greater impact than most economists had been assuming, and the 2.4 million figure has come up again and again in debates over global trade.
