headline: A Hero’s Burial for a Long-Dead Dictator
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Funerals and Memorials']
abstract: The Philippines’ new president wants to move Ferdinand Marcos’s body to a cemetery for heroes. It’s an affront to our history.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — Mornings in the Philippines reveal bodies dumped outside slums. Averaging 13 a day, nearly 2,000 in the last two months, the bodies are hung with cardboard labels: purse snatcher, drug pusher, addict. The authorities decline to investigate. These are the casualties of a controversial crusade against crime that was the subject of the recent spat between the country’s new president, Rodrigo Duterte, and Barack Obama, which devolved into crude insults (by Mr. Duterte) and canceled meetings (by Mr. Obama).

headline: Nicolas Sarkozy Is Back, but France Has Changed
abstract: Does his country really want a divisive arsonist fighting its fires?
lead_paragraph: PARIS — One of the most popular items on the social networks as Nicolas Sarkozy opened his new presidential bid last month was a video of an interview he gave to the French news channel BFM-TV on March 8, 2012. Still president then, Mr. Sarkozy was seeking a second five-year term, with François Hollande running against him. Asked whether he would quit politics if he lost, he firmly answered, “Yes.” The journalist was taken aback. “Will you quit politics?” he asked again, incredulous. “You can ask me a third time,” the president shot back. “I’m telling you: yes.”

headline: Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump Head Into Crucial Last 2 Months
abstract: The final stretch of the grueling presidential race started with the candidates emerging from Ohio to fan out across the country.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump, with Labor Day behind them, enter the final stretch of the grueling 2016 presidential campaign on Tuesday as they emerge from Ohio and fan out across the country.

headline: Renée Zellweger Is Back and Standing Up for Herself
abstract: Off the big screen for six years, she returns in “Bridget Jones’s Baby.” Here, she discusses her break from Hollywood and scrutiny of her appearance.
lead_paragraph: It has been six years since Renée Zellweger appeared on a big screen, and twice as long since she has channeled Bridget Jones, the British heroine who made charming sport of cataloging her romantic foibles. The gap was by design: Ms. Zellweger, 47, an Oscar nominee for the first “Bridget” movie and a winner in 2004 for “Cold Mountain,” stepped away from the Hollywood “cycle,” as she called it, to take stock of her life. “I had a lot of promises that I made to myself, years ago, about things that I wanted to learn and try,” she said.

headline: Is the World Becoming Safer?
abstract: Does a peace process to end the civil war in Colombia signal a trend toward less violence within and among other countries?

headline: On the Menu When Congress Returns From Recess
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Zika Virus', 'Law and Legislation', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: The first major issue is how to deal with the Zika virus. Military spending, the future of the I.R.S. commissioner, and a Sept. 11 bill are also on the table.
lead_paragraph: Members of Congress returned from a seven-week recess on Tuesday in a rush to get out the door yet again to campaign for re-election. Still, they have a few items they must address and some optional items. Think of it as a dinner menu at a party voters were not invited to attend:

headline: Chappatte on Mother Teresa’s Canonization
abstract: Younger generations assess Mother Teresa’s sainthood 19 years after her death.
lead_paragraph: Younger generations assess Mother Teresa’s sainthood 19 years after her death.

headline: Release the Records on Dag Hammarskjold’s Death
abstract: The N.S.A. may have crucial evidence that could solve the mystery of the United Nations leader’s 1961 death.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Last month, the outgoing secretary general of the United Nations, Ban Ki-moon, published a memo following up the inquiry he instigated last year into the death, nearly 55 years ago, of one of his predecessors in the role, the Swedish diplomat Dag Hammarskjold. Hammarskjold perished, along with his entourage, just after midnight on Sept. 18, 1961, when his chartered airliner crashed near Ndola, in what was then Northern Rhodesia, now Zambia.

headline: Chinese Company’s Payment to Lawmaker Sets Off Furor in Australia
abstract: Senator Sam Dastyari apologized for accepting the $1,270 donation, which has provoked charges that foreign donors are buying political influence.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — An Australian senator who accepted a donation from a Chinese company and used it to cover travel expenses has provoked charges in the country that foreign donors are buying political influence.

headline: Announcing Our 2016-17 Student Contest Calendar
abstract: A list of all the student contests we will be running on The Learning Network this school year.
lead_paragraph: Update: We have created a new version of this post on our new site. You can find all our updates there.

headline: Welcome to School Year 2016-17
abstract: The Learning Network marks its 18th birthday this month. To celebrate, we’re refreshing the site, with a new look and feel we hope will make it even easier for you to teach and learn with Times content.
lead_paragraph: The Learning Network, which began as a New York Times subsite in September 1998 and became a blog in 2009, marks its 18th birthday this month.

headline: Madrid for Kids? Try D.I.Y. Spanish Immersion
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Spanish Language', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: I went to Spain to dive into the language, and to pass Latino culture along to my American daughter.
lead_paragraph: Like many first-generation Americans my age, I learned Spanish on the fly. My Panamanian mother spoke to my brother and me in Spanish. We answered in English. Back then, in New York City in the late 1970s and ’80s, being able to speak flawless English was a prize. When people complimented me on how well I spoke, my family members beamed.

headline: In Europe, Three Cities, Three Fashion Weeks
keywords: ['Milan Fashion Week', 'Paris Fashion Week', 'London Fashion Week', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Cocktails and Mixed Drinks', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: In London, Milan and Paris, hotels and restaurants will observe fashion weeks with special packages, menus and cocktails like the Better in Red.
lead_paragraph: Even the cocktails will be stylish. Following New York Fashion Week: the shows, being held from Sept. 8 to 15, London, Milan and Paris celebrate spring 2017 fashion with their own events. The runway aside, there’s plenty going on in hotels in each city where travelers and locals alike can get a taste of the scene without attending an actual, invitation-only show. It’s a nice way to feel, well, fashionable.

headline: Neon Makes a Point at the U.S. Open
abstract: A fashion cautionary tale courtesy of the yellow! and pink! and green! on Center Court.
lead_paragraph: Blame it on its proximity to New York Fashion Week, which officially starts on Thursday (unofficially, it starts on Wednesday), but the United States Open (which started last week) has always attracted a disproportionate amount of style scrutiny. It tends to focus on ways in which tennis imitates fashion, with players calling center court their “runway,” discussing their “evening dress” and acknowledging their awareness of trends. But for anyone who spent the holiday weekend watching the tournament at Arthur Ashe Stadium, there’s been a lesson in fashion to take away from the tennis — especially when it comes to the athleisure end.

headline: Cassia
abstract: Balanced flavors at the chef Bryant Ng’s latest restaurant in Santa Monica, Calif.
lead_paragraph: Balanced flavors at the chef Bryant Ng’s latest restaurant in Santa Monica, Calif.

headline: Our Restaurant Critic Goes National. First Stop: California.
abstract: Cassia in Santa Monica, Calif., serves up large flavors with delicacy and a pointed lack of interest in being confrontational.
lead_paragraph: Editors’ Note: The Times has published starred reviews of restaurants in the New York metropolitan area since 1963. Starting today, we will occasionally offer such reviews of restaurants in other cities as well, applying the same standards that govern our reviews in New York: a minimum of three anonymous visits to the restaurant.

headline: California Today: Your Voices
abstract: Introducing California Today, a morning update on the stories that matter to Californians (and anyone else interested in the state).
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: 2 Pipeline Companies, Enbridge and Spectra Energy, to Merge
abstract: If approved by shareholders and regulators, the stock-for-stock deal would create the largest energy infrastructure company in North America.
lead_paragraph: Two pipeline companies agreed on Tuesday to merge in a deal that could create the largest energy-infrastructure company in North America.

headline: Keith Vaz, British Lawmaker, Quits Senior Post Amid Sex and Drug Scandal
keywords: ['Prostitution', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: The high-profile Labour politician resigned as head of a Home Office oversight committee after a tabloid reported he had met two men working as prostitutes.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Caught in what appeared to be a classic British newspaper exposé, an opposition lawmaker on Tuesday relinquished leadership of an influential parliamentary committee over allegations that he paid for the services of prostitutes and offered to buy drugs for them.

headline: The Giant Panda Is No Longer Endangered. It’s ‘Vulnerable.’
abstract: But the danger has increased for other species, including the eastern gorilla and the plains zebra.
lead_paragraph: The giant panda has long languished on the endangered species list, but an international monitoring group finally had some good news for it over the weekend.

headline: Volkswagen Takes Minority Stake in Truck Maker Navistar
abstract: The German automaker’s truck and bus business will enter a strategic alliance with Navistar, giving it greater access to the North American market.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Volkswagen said on Tuesday that its truck and bus business had agreed to acquire a 16.6 percent stake in the Navistar International Corporation, an American commercial truck maker, giving it a greater access to the North American commercial vehicle market.

headline: New National Poll Shows Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton Essentially Tied
abstract: While Mr. Trump has closed the gap and may be slightly ahead among likely voters, the CNN/ORC survey still has Mrs. Clinton leading in crucial swing states that may decide the election.
lead_paragraph: A national poll released Tuesday shows that Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton are entering the final stretch of the presidential race essentially tied, and the survey revealed a country deeply divided on a racial and gender lines ahead of the November election.

headline: Dan Kluger Steps Out on His Own
abstract: The chef makes a play for autonomy after years working for Jean-Georges Vongerichten at the ABC restaurants.
lead_paragraph: On a muggy summer afternoon at his home in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., Dan Kluger stood watch as stalks of broccoli soaked up smoke on a backyard grill. Stout of frame and sweaty of brow, he looked more like a workaday suburban dad, which he is, than a celebrity chef, which he has never exactly pretended to be.

headline: Geologist Sees Clues, and Further Dangers, in Puzzle of Oklahoma’s Earthquakes
keywords: ['Earthquakes', 'Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The state has had “thousands of years of earthquake activity in a short period of time,” a geologist says.
lead_paragraph: Scientists and regulators agree that earthquakes like the 5.6-magnitude tremor that struck Oklahoma on Saturday, and thousands of smaller ones in recent years, have been spurred by the disposal of millions of tons of wastewater that is pumped to the surface, and then injected back into the ground, during oil and gas production. The  shock last week tied a record set in 2011 in Prague, Okla., for the strongest such tremor in the state’s history.

headline: 1966: Verwoerd Assassinated
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Prime Minister Hendrik Verwoerd of South Africa is assassinated in parliament in September 1966.
lead_paragraph: The funeral in 1966 of Prime Minister Hendrik Verwoerd of South Africa. British Pathé.

headline: Guerrilla Art Exhibit Unmasks the Face of Terrorism
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Art', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Above Dizengoff Square, a killer’s face and hateful words are on display as part of an Israeli philanthropist’s mission to get his country to confront terrorism.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — Eight months after the attack, the killer’s face hovered over Dizengoff Street again, full of menace and malevolence.

headline: In the Land of the Robot, Androids Are on the March
abstract: A handful of androids now greet visitors at a shopping mall and entertain on television. The company that made them plans to add them by the thousands.
lead_paragraph: Meet Chihira Junco, a tourist greeter at a shopping mall in Tokyo. In her crisp blue button-down shirt, white blazer and pinstripe skirt, she stands in sensible pumps behind a counter in Aqua City Odaiba on Tokyo Bay, dispensing directions to local sites and shops in Japanese, Chinese and English.

headline: Freddie Mercury Now Races Around the Sun
abstract: An asteroid has been named for the Queen lead singer, who died in 1991.
lead_paragraph: Freddie Mercury, the lead singer of the 1970s rock group Queen, already shared his name with one celestial body, but another has been added to the list.

headline: Fox Settles With Gretchen Carlson Over Roger Ailes Sex Harassment Claims
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Sexual Harassment', 'News and News Media']
abstract: In a separate development, Fox News announced that Greta Van Susteren was leaving the network, effective immediately.
lead_paragraph: Fox News’s parent company spent $20 million on Tuesday to settle a lawsuit brought by a former anchor, Gretchen Carlson, whose allegations of sexual harassment toppled the network’s powerful chairman, Roger Ailes, and engulfed the company in crisis.

headline: La Newyorkina to Open Its First Shop for Mexican Sweets
abstract: Fany Gerson, known for her dessert stands, gets a full-service store.
lead_paragraph: Fany Gerson is waiting on a delivery of garrafas from Mexico. Once they arrive, she’ll use the wooden barrels lined with metal cylinders to make the ice cream called nieve de garrafa.

headline: Valls critique un article du New York Times donnant la parole aux musulmanes
abstract: Le premier ministre décrit le recueil de témoignages, dans lequel des femmes se disent victimes de discrimination, comme donnant une image insupportable, car fausse, de la France.
lead_paragraph: Le premier ministre français, Manuel Valls, a vivement critiqué ce lundi un article du New York Times dans lequel des femmes musulmanes françaises décrivent être ostracisées par des non-musulmans, victimes de discrimination à l’emploi et se sentir persécutées.

headline: Police Officer Is Fired a Year After Fatal Shooting of South Carolina Teenager
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Lt. Mark Tiller had opened fire during a drug sting in Seneca, killing Zachary Hammond, an unarmed white teenager, in 2015.
lead_paragraph: A South Carolina police lieutenant who fatally shot a 19-year-old man during an attempted drug arrest in a Hardee’s parking lot last year has been fired from his job, the police chief said. The officer contended that he was acting in self-defense when the suspect drove a car toward him.

headline: U.N. Chief Presses to Unlock Mystery of Dag Hammarskjold’s Death
abstract: Britain and the United States have stonewalled requests by Ban Ki-moon to divulge information on the plane crash that killed his predecessor in 1961.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A few days from now, the anniversary of one of the most enduring international mysteries will slide by, hardly likely to be marked by those in Britain and the United States accused of withholding the secret clues to its resolution.

headline: ‘Narcos’ Season 2, Episode 5: No Turning Back
abstract: Peña and Murphy are willing to do whatever is necessary to get Escobar, no matter the damage to their integrity or their souls.
lead_paragraph: There’s an absurd sequence in “The Enemies of My Enemy” that can at least be salvaged as metaphor. With Col. Horacio Carrillo, the leader of Search Bloc, out of the picture, the official operation to capture or kill Pablo Escobar has not only lost the tip of its spear, but it also barely has a stick left for poking. The D.E.A. agents continue to gather information and surveillance, but protocol keeps them chained to their desks, compiling folders of classified information without anyone to act on the intelligence. And yet, remarkably, there’s a shot of Peña entering Carrillo’s office and delivering the documents anyway, like an old habit he hasn’t thought to break. Enter Murphy’s voice-over narration, lamenting that the hunt for Escobar had been reduced to “a growing stack of unread files on a dead man’s desk.”

headline: The New Union Square Cafe
abstract: The restaurateur Danny Meyer rebuilds his signature restaurant in a new location on Park Avenue South.
lead_paragraph: The restaurateur Danny Meyer rebuilds his signature restaurant in a new location on Park Avenue South.

headline: The Same, Only Different: Designing a New Union Square Cafe
abstract: The designer David Rockwell and the restaurateur Danny Meyer have set out, carefully and at times exhaustively, to re-create a classic.
lead_paragraph: On a clear February morning, executives from Union Square Hospitality Group and several architects sipped hot coffee and milled around a table in the partly demolished remains of a shuttered restaurant, waiting for Danny Meyer.

headline: New Karachi Mayor Gets Daytrip From Prison to Be Sworn In
abstract: The election of Waseem Akhtar to lead the city of 22 million comes as his Muttahida Qaumi Movement and its exiled leader are under fire from Pakistan’s military.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — The yellow-walled, colonial-era central prison in Karachi houses some of the city’s hardened criminals, but one of its inmates, Waseem Akhtar, still has a day job: He’s the mayor of Pakistan’s biggest and most tumultuous city.

headline: 1941: Frenchmen Are Executed
keywords: ['GERMANY', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: The three were shot at dawn for an attack on a German sergeant in Paris in September 1941.
lead_paragraph: VICHY — Three French men were shot at dawn today [Sept. 6] by the German military authorities of Paris in reprisal for the shooting and slight wounding of a German sergeant near the East railroad station in Paris Wednesday night. Notice of this grim deed was communicated to the Paris population by a two-column announcement appearing on the front pages of all the Paris newspapers this morning [Sept. 6]. The act was said to be the fulfillment of the threat, made by the Germans after the killing of a Nazi ensign in a Paris subway, that they would regard all French civilians held in detention by them as hostages liable to be shot without notice if any further attempts were made on the lives of German soldiers. — New York Herald Tribune, Sept. 7, 1941

headline: Living in Two Time Zones With Google Calendar
abstract: If you have to manage meetings in different parts of the world, you can make Google Calendar show two or more time zones at once in your browser.
lead_paragraph: Q. Is it possible to show more than one time zone in Google Calendar to help find workable meeting times with two distant offices?

headline: Sullivan & Cromwell Hires Online Security Specialist
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Legal Profession', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']

headline: Whistle-Blowing Insiders: ‘Game Changer’ for the S.E.C.
abstract: More than 14,000 tips on company wrongdoing have been received in the last five years, and rewards to informants reach into the millions.
lead_paragraph: Although there have been many complaints about the Dodd-Frank Act, one area generally hailed as a success is the whistle-blowing program at the Securities and Exchange Commission. Since the program’s creation in 2011, the S.E.C. has received more than 14,000 tips, including almost 4,000 last year.

headline: Too Much ‘Lemonade’? Beyoncé Postpones Concert to Rest Voice
abstract: Beyoncé reschedules her MetLife Stadium concert for Oct. 7; and Zayn Malik cancels his solo show in October, saying he has “extreme anxiety.”
lead_paragraph: Beyoncé’s big voice needs a break.

headline: U.S. Open Today: Another Short Match for Novak Djokovic
abstract: Here’s what’s happened at the United States Open on Tuesday, when four players earn spots in the semifinals.
lead_paragraph: With a 6-4, 6-3, 6-3 victory over his French countryman Lucas Pouille on Tuesday, Gaël Monfils rolled into his first United States Open semifinal, having not lost a set in the tournament.

headline: #1000BlackGirlBooks Campaign Expands
abstract: An 11-year-old dreams big.
lead_paragraph: Eleven-year-old Marley Dias has gotten a lot of attention for being the girl who got sick of reading about white boys and their dogs and did something about it.

headline: Campuses Cautiously Train Freshmen Against Subtle Insults
abstract: Many orientation programs now cover “microaggressions” in addition to addressing issues of diversity and sexual consent.
lead_paragraph: WORCESTER, Mass. — A freshman tentatively raises her hand and takes the microphone. “I’m really scared to ask this,” she begins. “When I, as a white female, listen to music that uses the N word, and I’m in the car, or, especially when I’m with all white friends, is it O.K. to sing along?”

headline: Nearly a Century On, Chumley’s Has a New Idea: Serious Food
abstract: The speakeasy will reopen, after a renovation, with an ambitious menu and waiters in white jackets.
lead_paragraph: I was never a beer-drinking regular at Chumley’s. But back when I was in college (and New York’s drinking age was a tender 18), I would occasionally visit that hallowed West Village tavern with a date, sipping a martini or two before dinner somewhere else downtown (Blue Mill? Monte’s?).

headline: Joanna Coles, Cosmopolitan Editor, Named to New Job at Hearst
abstract: Hearst said Ms. Coles would become its first chief content officer. Michele Promaulayko will become editor in chief at Cosmopolitan.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, Joanna Coles was having lunch with David Carey, the president of Hearst magazines, when he suggested she should take on a bigger role at the company.

headline: ‘Marvin’s Room,’ a Wise Comedy About Dying, Is Bound for Broadway
abstract: Roundabout Theater Company said it would bring the play to the American Airlines Theater in June; Anne Kauffman will direct.
lead_paragraph: “Marvin’s Room,” a comic play about a dying woman caring for a dying man, will be staged on Broadway for the first time next summer, more than a quarter-century after it was written.

headline: Series of Attacks Ends in Afghanistan
abstract: The Afghan capital, Kabul, was rattled by a series of attacks, which came to an end early Tuesday after an 11-hour standoff with gunmen at the offices of a humanitarian group. Earlier, two blasts targeted the Defense Ministry and left more than 35 people dead.
lead_paragraph: The Afghan capital, Kabul, was rattled by a series of attacks, which came to an end early Tuesday after an 11-hour standoff with gunmen at the offices of a humanitarian group. Earlier, two blasts targeted the Defense Ministry and left more than 35 people dead.

headline: The Clock That Time Cannot Improve
abstract: The Cifra 3, one of the first electromechanical flip clocks, was a revelation of industrial design in the ’60s. Today, it’s coveted by collectors.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who travels is familiar with the large flip-board displays indicating the gate of your plane, train or bus. Their distinctive shuffling sound, which sends travelers scurrying like a well-orchestrated flash mob, is so synonymous with departure that when Boston’s North Station upgraded its boards to LED displays, they were programmed to emit the familiar clicketyclack, as much for nostalgia as for necessity: How else to get passengers to look up from their phones?

headline: The Bomber Jacket is the Most Versatile Fall Staple for Men
abstract: With all its masculine connotations, the style is cut for strong, unambiguous posturing this season.
lead_paragraph: With all its masculine connotations, the style is cut for strong, unambiguous posturing this season.

lead_paragraph: Time to put away the cargo shorts and flip-flops, guys.

headline: The Hard-Cider Craze Will Get a Hard-Core Pub

lead_paragraph: This fall’s Big Idea award may go to Peter Yi, the city’s first tree-to-table maker of hard cider, who will operate a restaurant, bar, tasting room and cidery in a formerly decrepit 15,000-square-foot warehouse in Bushwick, Brooklyn.

headline: New Wave of American Soccer Players in Europe Bucks a Trend
abstract: The dwindling number of Americans playing abroad has been a source of fret, but some have taken solid first steps up the European ladder.
lead_paragraph: A dominant discussion around the United States men’s national soccer team in the past three years has concerned the dwindling number of Americans playing abroad. Since 2013, partly because of aggressive recruiting by M.L.S., a core group of national team players who had established a toehold in Europe — players like Michael Bradley and Clint Dempsey, and later Jozy Altidore and Alejandro Bedoya — has migrated home.

headline: All of Africa, Served at Serengeti Kitchen
abstract: Coming to Harlem, a restaurant that plans to cover the continent, one region at a time.
lead_paragraph: “Africa has been totally misunderstood,” said Doughba Caranda-Martin III, the owner of a tea shop in Harlem. “We have so many complex flavors and delicacies, and I want to investigate all of them.”

headline: The Crumbling Case for a Mexican Border Wall
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Foreign Workers', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Even looking at a best-case scenario, Donald Trump’s immigration proposals aren’t worth the economic cost.

headline: The Tuck Room Will Serve a Little History With Your Highball
abstract: Lower Manhattan is about to get another cocktail bar that pays homage to the past.
lead_paragraph: Lower Manhattan has become the place where historically minded cocktail bars go to live. Following in the footsteps of the Dead Rabbit Grocery and Grog (which asks, “What would a 19th-century New Yorker drink?”) and BlackTail (“What would a Prohibition-era American tourist in Havana drink?”) comes the Tuck Room, to open in October in the newly revamped Fulton Market building in the South Street Seaport area.

abstract: New sources for meat, chocolate, pastries and more prepared foods and ingredients will arrive in New York this fall.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For much of the time that Hillary Clinton has run for president, her chief adversary on Capitol Hill has been Representative Trey Gowdy, Republican of South Carolina and chairman of the special committee that investigated the 2012 attacks in Benghazi, Libya.

headline: ITT Educational Services Closes Campuses

headline: Taking Amtrak’s California Zephyr Across Country
abstract: See what a writer saw as she recreated an eye-opening rail adventure that took her family to the Summer of Love.
lead_paragraph: See what a writer saw as she recreated an eye-opening rail adventure that took her family to the Summer of Love.

headline: Riding the Rails to the Summer of Love
abstract: Nina Burleigh retraces her family’s rail adventure across half the continent to Haight-Ashbury, the epicenter of the counterculture movement in 1967.
lead_paragraph: A few days after first grade ended, in June 1967, I boarded a train pulling out of Union Station in Chicago with my parents, younger brother and baby sister. My father, a University of Chicago Ph.D. candidate, had decided to bail out of academia and move to San Francisco, where he planned to devote himself to writing poetry and where, coincidentally, the Summer of Love was about to commence.

headline: A Wave of Japanese Restaurants With a Twist
abstract: New York’s latest crop will have a narrow focus: on solitude, speed and special noodles.
lead_paragraph: Every year brings a fresh crop of Japanese restaurants, but this fall, three popular Japanese chains will open New York satellites, each with an unusually narrow specialty.

headline: Long-Lost 9/11 Flag, an Enduring Mystery, Will Go on View at Museum
keywords: ['September 11 (2001)', 'Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)']
abstract: The flag, which was featured in a famous photograph of ground zero and disappeared soon after the attack, will again become a prominent part of Lower Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: The moment was captured in a photograph, an unforgettable image that was seared in the world’s collective memory as a symbol of resilience: three firefighters raising an American flag amid the ruins of the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: Science Fiction Meets Music (Fanatically) at Jupiter Disco

headline: L.B.J. and Mexican Immigrants

headline: Times Insider Photo Challenge: Caption This!
abstract: We asked readers — without any context — to caption a photo that ran in The New York Times. Here’s how they responded.

headline: Iran and Saudi Arabia Squabble as Millions of Muslims Begin Pilgrimage

headline: Chains Will Bring a Taste of the West Coast to New York
abstract: Arriving this fall, restaurants from Sugarfish, Wolfgang Puck and Eatsa.
lead_paragraph: In his heyday, Kazunori Nozawa, a star of the Los Angeles sushi scene, developed a reputation for scolding diners who ate sushi incorrectly, sometimes even kicking them out. That’s how he earned a New York-inspired nickname: the “sushi Nazi.”

headline: Opening Their Own Restaurants, for the First Time
abstract: Adam Leonti, Jared Sippel, Anne Burrell and Jeanne Mélanie Delcourt will get kitchens this fall.

headline: Carl Icahn to Take Federal-Mogul Private
abstract: Mr. Icahn’s investment firm will buy the remaining 18 percent of Federal-Mogul, an auto parts supplier, it does not already own for $9.25 a share in cash.
lead_paragraph: Carl C. Icahn’s investment firm has agreed to take the Federal-Mogul Holdings Corporation private, continuing his quest to buy suppliers to the auto industry.

headline: Fantasy Football 2016 | Week 17 Rankings
abstract: These player rankings from the Sablich brothers are for standard scoring formats and will be updated each week.
lead_paragraph: These player rankings from the Sablich brothers are for standard scoring formats and will be updated each week.

headline: Rouge Tomate: Smaller Restaurant, Bigger Wine List
abstract: After a two-year wait, a New York wine destination will reopen in Chelsea in a new guise.
lead_paragraph: For two years now, New York wine lovers have been restlessly tapping their feet, checking their watches and sighing heavily as they waited for word that Rouge Tomate would reappear.

headline: Manhattan’s Hottest New Dining Spot: The 20s
abstract: The Flatiron and NoMad areas will get a crop of new restaurants.
lead_paragraph: Manhattan has become so densely cluttered with restaurants that it’s hard to imagine a new dining neighborhood emerging. But one well-fed area is showing signs of even more activity: the area around the 20s, East and West, especially through the Flatiron district and NoMad.

headline: From Patricia Arquette: Equal Rights for Women
abstract: The actress writes that “discrimination against women continues.”

headline: Hillary Clinton Treats Theories About Coughing Attack With Dose of Humor
abstract: Mrs. Clinton said she had seasonal allergies — though she joked that she was allergic to Donald J. Trump — as conspiracy theories abounded in conservative media.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Hillary Clinton addressed conspiracy theories about an allergy attack she had on Monday with humor — and an extra dose of antihistamines.

headline: The City? It’s a Dance Floor
abstract: Plenty of dance takes place on stages. But here’s a look at what happens when it heads to beaches, piers and pavement.
lead_paragraph: Plenty of dance takes place on stages. But here’s a look at what happens when it heads to beaches, piers and pavement.

headline: Coming From the Estela Chef: Flora, in the Met Breuer
abstract: Ignacio Mattos and his partner, Thomas Carter, plan to add ‘downtown spirit’ to the uptown museum.
lead_paragraph: The  innovations of the chef Ignacio Mattos and his business partner, Thomas Carter, have defied expectations at their downtown restaurants, Estela and Café Altro Paradiso. But even they are somewhat flustered by their next collaboration, the restaurant in the Met Breuer, the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s new museum in the former uptown home of the Whitney Museum of American Art.

headline: Israel and Its Neighbors: Complex Ties
abstract: Readers discuss regional alliances and the prospects for Israeli-Palestinian peace.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Timeless Cocktails on the Lower East Side
keywords: ['Bars and Nightclubs', 'Cocktails and Mixed Drinks', 'ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES']
abstract: Giuseppe González runs his bar his way.
lead_paragraph: The menu at Suffolk Arms, a cocktail lounge that recently opened on the Lower East Side, has a section called “Intractable and Unapologetic.” The phrase may also be used to describe the bartender Giuseppe González, a co-owner.

headline: New York’s Latest Craving, Poke, by the Pound at Sweetcatch
abstract: A small group of restaurants says it will serve the dish in a more authentic Hawaiian way.
lead_paragraph: Poke (poh-kay) has become the next veggie burger, a suddenly popular dish that compels New Yorkers to put up with long lines. My explanation for why Hawaiian poke — diced raw tuna with seasonings and an Asian-accented dressing — has become such a crowd-pleaser here is that it amounts to a cheaper, simpler version of tuna tartare, a popular starter on a thousand menus. But for a bowl of poke, you don’t need a reservation, deep pockets or more courses.

headline: ‘Here I Am,’ Jonathan Safran Foer’s Tale of a Fracturing Family
abstract: Mr. Foer’s story of loss, pain and regret is his best and most caustic novel, but is undercut by a cloying winsomeness.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Safran Foer has a gift for describing what a teenage boy calls in “Here I Am,” the author’s third novel, “the disgusting, smelly, smoked and gelatinous foods Jews suddenly need in times of reflection.”

headline: Nancy Pelosi Urges Paul Ryan to Ban Republicans From Using Hacked Documents
abstract: Ms. Pelosi, the House minority leader, argued to Mr. Ryan, the speaker, that “defending our democracy is more important than any advantage or disadvantage in this election.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nancy Pelosi, the House minority leader, sent a letter on Tuesday to Speaker Paul D. Ryan urging him to bar Republicans from using hacked documents in the campaign, arguing that “defending our democracy is more important than any advantage or disadvantage in this election.”

headline: J’ouvert Will Continue, de Blasio Says, but Its Hours May Change
keywords: ['Police', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Parades', 'West Indian-American Day']
abstract: The mayor made the announcement after the police said they had arrested Reginald Moise, 20, in the death of Tiarah Poyau, 22, who was shot on Monday.
lead_paragraph: A day after deadly violence struck the J’ouvert parade in Brooklyn for the third straight year, Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Tuesday that the annual celebration of Caribbean culture would continue but that the city would consider changing the hours of the overnight event, which precedes the much bigger West Indian American Day Parade.

headline: Malaysian Rivals’ Reunion Highlights Shifting Political Alliances
abstract: The court reunion of Anwar Ibrahim, who is imprisoned, and Mahathir Mohamad, the former prime minister who put him away, highlighted Malaysia’s fractious politics.
lead_paragraph: An improbable reunion took place at the High Court in Kuala Lumpur this week, offering a snapshot of Malaysia’s fractious yet incestuous politics.

headline: At 21st Century Fox, the Price of Poor Governance Adds Up
abstract: The settlement with the former Fox News anchor Gretchen Carlson is another example of the perils of letting one shareholder control the operation.
lead_paragraph: Investors in 21st Century Fox, the media company controlled by Rupert Murdoch, are once again paying a price for poor governance.

headline: With Koch Brothers Academy, Conservatives Settle In for Long War
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: Whatever the setbacks for Republicans this year, the billionaire brothers want their Grassroots Leadership Academy to ready combatants for the future.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Va. — The rise of Donald J. Trump, with his hostility toward free trade and vow to protect entitlements, is a sharp rebuke to the free-market principles long championed by the billionaire brothers Charles G. and David H. Koch.

headline: New York Gets a New Helping of Barbecue
abstract: The Southern invasion continues this fall, mostly in Brooklyn and Queens.
lead_paragraph: The barrage of kitchens that have turned New York from barbecue desert to rib heaven continues, most prominently in Brooklyn and Queens.

lead_paragraph: An airport parking lot in Los Angeles has become an improvised village of airline workers.

headline: You Are Going to Want to Bake Those Pork Chops, My Friend
abstract: Pan confusion, tomato-peeling and the secret to good brisket. Our readers have questions. Our resident Food editor has the answers.
lead_paragraph: Have questions about recipes, cooking and food? My job is to answer them. Ask me anything: foodeditor@nytimes.com.

headline: Home Is Where the Parking Lot Is
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'AIRPORTS', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Parking Garages and Lots', 'Pilots', 'Flight Attendants', 'Recreational Vehicles']
abstract: An airport parking lot in Los Angeles has become an improvised village of airline workers.
lead_paragraph: Taking a back-road shortcut to catch a flight from Los Angeles two years ago, I passed an obscure airline employee parking lot — and was surprised to see over 70 motor homes. It looked like there was an entire community planted right there in the parking lot of the airport. I wondered, who lived there — and why?

headline: Research Suggests Women Are Asking for Raises, but Men Get Them More
abstract: A study of Australian women points to discrimination as a cause of a pay gap, with men getting raises 20 percent of the time they asked, compared with 16 percent for women.
lead_paragraph: One common theory to explain the pay gap between men and women assigns blame to women themselves: Maybe they just aren’t asking for raises.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York City.
lead_paragraph: $11.57 MILLION

headline: How Does a Hurricane Get a Name Like Hermine?
abstract: Believe it or not, this moniker was chosen 37 years ago, during the Carter administration.
lead_paragraph: Ask The Times, a Times Insider feature, draws on New York Times expertise to answer questions about current events, science, sports, culture and whatever else is making headlines.

headline: Zimbabwe Follows Robert Mugabe’s Health by Following His Plane
abstract: Government officials reveal little about the 92-year-old president’s condition or his travels, so Zimbabweans use apps to scour his flight path for clues.
lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe — It is an indirect clue at best, but it is often all they can get: Many Zimbabweans have taken to divining the state of their increasingly frail 92-year-old leader’s health from the movements of his presidential plane.

headline: Nostalgia Tops the Menu of Fall’s Big Restaurant Openings
abstract: Florence Fabricant looks forward to old-style luxury, new Nordic cooking and reinvented Asian dishes.
lead_paragraph: Alessandro Borgognone, who is about to reopen the venerable West Village speakeasy Chumley’s, calls it a “throwback” in its style, food and drink. It’s not the only revival on New York’s restaurant horizon. The nostalgia card is being played all over town, and it looms large in the dining experiences I’m most anticipating this fall.

headline: Donald Trump Says Hillary Clinton Doesn’t Have ‘a Presidential Look’
abstract: Mr. Trump demurred on whether he was making an aesthetic judgment, but the remarks joined a long line of provocative comments about women and drew criticism as being sexist.
lead_paragraph: VIRGINIA BEACH — Donald J. Trump — the master showman turned presidential candidate — has added yet another critique to his list of reasons he believes Hillary Clinton should not be president: She simply does not look the part.

headline: A Bohemian Surf Town in Bali, Where Serenity Rules
abstract: Escape the province’s bedlam with a quick pilgrimage to the artsy coastal town of Canggu. Here’s where to eat, pray and chill there.
lead_paragraph: For first-time visitors, modern Bali — especially in established tourist spots such as Seminyak, Kuta and Ubud — can be disheartening. In recent years, the fantasy of spiritual enlightenment has been replaced by the reality, where throngs of travelers are constantly dodging motorbikes on streets so clogged they make Times Square look like, well, Bali.

headline: Law Enforcement ‘Not Winning’ War on White-Collar Crime
abstract: Delegates at symposium on economic crime in Cambridge, Mass., sought solutions for fighting crimes like money laundering, fraud and insider trading.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, England — The record of combating economic crime is so woeful that governments need a new approach. That was the view of many at a gathering of about 1,600 delegates from academia and the legal and compliance profession here on Monday.

headline: How Black Voters View Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump
abstract: Readers discuss articles about young blacks’ qualms about Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump’s lack of understanding of the black community.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How to Buy a Vintage Watch (and Not Get Fleeced)
abstract: A watch expert from Christie’s offers tips on secondhand timepieces, including what’s hot and how to avoid fakes.
lead_paragraph: These days, vintage watches are hot enough that some aficionados treat their collections like 401(k) accounts: a great way to build for retirement. But with prices spiking, the level of risk is shooting up, too. Even experts can get stuck with bad merchandise if they are not careful. Eric Wind, a vice president and the senior watch specialist at Christie’s New York and a longtime contributor to Hodinkee, the watch blog, discussed the new rules of buying vintage.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Mike Isaac, Sam Sifton and others.

headline: Elon Musk’s Solar Vision, Up for a Dicey Vote
keywords: ['Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Solar Energy']
abstract: Shareholders can be finicky and opaque, but the Tesla-SolarCity deal shows the importance of having all buyers of significant assets hold a vote.
lead_paragraph: Tesla Motors’ proposed acquisition of SolarCity is most likely to come down to whether shareholders support Elon Musk in his vision of creating a solar power juggernaut. Yet the deal also raises broader issues of how and when shareholders should vote to approve acquisitions.

headline: The 2016 Fall Restaurant Preview
abstract: A look at the new restaurants, bars and markets opening in New York this season.
lead_paragraph: A look at the new restaurants, bars and markets opening in New York this season.

headline: Nitehawk to Open a Second Cinema in Brooklyn
abstract: The owner of the popular boutique movie house in Williamsburg will convert the Pavilion theater in Park Slope to Nitehawk Prospect Park.
lead_paragraph: Park Slope, Brooklyn, hang on to your strollers. The Pavilion, the neighborhood’s lone remaining movie house — one frequently criticized for varying degrees of neglect — is to be transformed into a Nitehawk theater, set to open early fall 2017. Plans to add condominiums to the site, made before the Nitehawk entered negotiations with the building’s owners, have been scrapped.

headline: This Fall, Stripes Are In (at New York Galleries, at Least)
abstract: The pattern is on trend in several new exhibitions, which just happen to open during New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Beginning Sept. 8, the Paula Cooper Gallery will exhibit work by Sol LeWitt at all three of its Chelsea locations — placing the gallery among a handful in the city opening shows that prominently feature striped motifs, just in time for New York Fashion Week. (Incidentally, LeWitt himself also dabbled in fashion, designing scarves for Louis Vuitton and a T-shirt for the São Paulo Biennale in 1996.)

headline: Barry Jenkins on ‘Moonlight,’ a Tale of Black America and Personal Adversity
abstract: At the Telluride festival, Mr. Jenkins talks about his well-received film, which ruminates on desire, identity and friendship.
lead_paragraph: TELLURIDE, Colo. — In recent years, Barry Jenkins has been a familiar presence at the Telluride Film Festival. He has programmed short films, moderated panels with filmmakers and actors and served as a “ringmaster,” standing up before screenings to thank sponsors and ask that cellphones be silenced. This year he took on a different role. His second feature, “Moonlight,” had its premiere here, and to say that it received a warm welcome would be a drastic understatement. There were tears and standing ovations, a reception that is likely to continue as the film makes its way into theaters. (It opens in October.)

headline: Projects Not to Miss at the London Design Biennale
abstract: The inaugural event's theme, Utopia By Design, celebrates the 500th anniversary of the publication of Thomas More’s novel "Utopia."
lead_paragraph: The inaugural event's theme, Utopia By Design, celebrates the 500th anniversary of the publication of Thomas More’s novel "Utopia."

headline: Former Chief at El Museo del Barrio to Lead Museum of Arts and Design
abstract: Jorge Daniel Veneciano considers the new job a “special opportunity,” but to some extent, he’s leaving one bumpy road for another.
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 12, Jorge Daniel Veneciano announced that he was stepping down as executive director of El Museo del Barrio — just two years after starting the job — “to pursue new opportunities.”

headline: After Her Son’s Death, Sally Mann Stages a Haunting Show
abstract: This photographer reflected on her relationship with Cy Twombly and the death of her son ahead of her “Remembered Light” show at Gagosian Gallery.
lead_paragraph: LEXINGTON, Va. — “It’s just indescribable,” Sally Mann, the photographer and writer, was saying. She stood in the kitchen of the home she built on her family’s farm with Larry Mann, her husband of 46 years, and erupted in tears.

headline: Fall Beauty’s Rosy Outlook
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Perfumes and Fragrances']

headline: Q. and A.: Andy Murray on Tennis With a Young Family
abstract: Murray discussed the surprising sturdiness of babies and the surprising amount of sleep he is able to get as a new father.
lead_paragraph: For a fifth year, The New York Times is speaking to Andy Murray after his matches at the United States Open, where he broke through for his first Grand Slam title in 2012. Murray and his wife, Kim, welcomed their first child, Sophia Olivia, in February, just after Murray reached the Australian Open final. After defeating Grigor Dimitrov on Monday night to reach the quarterfinals, Murray discussed learning their daughter was arriving and the unexpected sturdiness of babies.

headline: Campaign Ads, Then and Now
abstract: Whose ads are breaking through this year, and why? We dissect this season’s campaign ads with Wesley Morris, the chief culture critic for The New York Times, and Russ Schriefer, a longtime Republican ad maker who has created some of the most memorable campaign commercials of the past decade.

lead_paragraph: A series of young children sit cross-legged on the floor, transfixed by glowing television screens featuring Donald J. Trump cursing, heckling and mocking. The commercial, made by Hillary Clinton’s campaign, struck Wesley Morris, our chief culture critic, as “a hall-of-fame, effective ad.”

headline: Anjem Choudary Is Sentenced to Prison for Promoting ISIS
abstract: Mr. Choudary, one of Britain’s best known Islamist activists, and an associate, Mohammed Mizanur Rahman, were both sentenced on Tuesday to five and a half years in prison.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Anjem Choudary, one of Britain’s best known Islamist activists, was sentenced on Tuesday to five years and six months in prison after having been convicted in July of encouraging support for the Islamic State.

headline: ‘Jersey Boys’ Will Close in January
abstract: The jukebox musical about Frankie Valli and the Four Seasons opened in 2005 and won four Tony Awards in 2006. It is the 12th-longest-running show in Broadway history.
lead_paragraph: Bye bye baby: “Jersey Boys” is closing on Jan. 15.

headline: L.I.U.-Brooklyn Locks Out Professors Amid Contract Dispute
abstract: Administrators at the university, which canceled the faculty members’ health insurance over the weekend, said pre-emptive measures were necessary to prevent a possible strike.
lead_paragraph: Classes will start on Wednesday at Long Island University-Brooklyn without key participants: The professors.

headline: Turkish Official Says U.S. Was Not Complicit in Coup Plot
abstract: In an interview on Tuesday with The New York Times Editorial Board, Turkey’s deputy prime minister said “we don’t see any evidence” of American involvement.
lead_paragraph: Despite dark conspiracy theories in Turkey linking the United States government to the military coup attempt on July 15, Turkish leaders see no signs of American complicity with the plotters, Deputy Prime Minister Numan Kurtulmus said on Tuesday.

headline: William Ackman’s Pershing Square Takes a Stake in Chipotle
abstract: Pershing Square takes a 9.9 percent stake, making it the second-largest holder after Fidelity. Shares rose in after-hours trading.
lead_paragraph: William A. Ackman has a craving for fast food.

headline: Withholding Evidence From a Defendant, on ‘The Night Of’ and in Real Life
abstract: The prosecutor in the HBO series does not tell the defendant’s lawyers about exculpatory evidence, an egregious violation, and one similar to a real case in Queens.
lead_paragraph: In the HBO series “The Night Of,” the police think they have solved a murder by arresting a young man from Queens who had a bloody knife in his pocket and was found near the victim’s house after a night of debauchery with her. But a relentless detective named Box cannot resist digging deeper. In the middle of the murder trial, Box tells the prosecutor that he has discovered circumstantial evidence that points to an entirely different suspect.

headline: Hillary Clinton Says Donald Trump Doesn’t Measure Up on Foreign Policy
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Her emphasis on her experience in global stagecraft comes a week after Mr. Trump tried to bolster his foreign policy credentials with a trip to Mexico.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Leaning heavily on her tenure as secretary of state, Hillary Clinton assailed Donald J. Trump’s national security credentials on Tuesday, portraying him as a bungling businessman unequipped to serve as commander in chief.

headline: Record of Officer in Eric Garner Case Should Be Public, Officials Argue
abstract: Daniel Pantaleo’s disciplinary history should remain confidential, Mayor Bill de Blasio said, disagreeing with many members of the City Council and a judge’s ruling.
lead_paragraph: A group of elected officials and activists in New York stood on the steps of City Hall on Tuesday to renew their call for officials to release basic findings of misconduct against the police officer who held Eric Garner in a chokehold.

headline: Bill Cosby to Stand Trial in Sexual Assault Case in June
abstract: A Pennsylvania judge set June 5, 2017, for the start of the criminal trial against Mr. Cosby on charges that he drugged and molested Andrea Constand at his home more than a decade ago.
lead_paragraph: NORRISTOWN, Pa. — Bill Cosby, the comedian and television star who faces charges that he drugged and molested a woman he once mentored at his suburban Philadelphia home more than a decade ago, will be tried starting June 5, 2017, a Pennsylvania judge ruled on Tuesday.

abstract: A driver at a red light is distracted when a doorman pulls a joint out of a planter and lights up.

headline: Conflict and Poverty Have Uprooted Nearly 50 Million Children, U.N. Says
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Children and Childhood', 'Global Warming', 'Poverty']
abstract: According to the agency, children make up a third of the world’s population but about half of all refugees.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 50 million children worldwide have migrated across borders or been forcibly displaced by conflicts, the United Nations said on Tuesday in a new report meant to emphasize the trauma children face from war, climate change and poverty.

headline: Angelique Kerber and Caroline Wozniacki Advance to the Semifinals
abstract: Kerber, seeded second, survived a nerve-racking first set against No. 7 Roberta Vinci before cruising through the second to advance to the semifinals, where she will face Wozniacki.
lead_paragraph: When many might have panicked — including, perhaps, a younger version of herself — Angelique Kerber remained calm.

headline: Five Things to Know About Congress’s Fight Over Zika
keywords: ['Zika Virus', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Mosquitoes', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: Politics — specifically a fight involving Planned Parenthood — has hindered passage of funding to combat the virus, and solutions may yet be weeks away.
lead_paragraph: Congress has had difficulty accomplishing much in this session, even where a potential health crisis like the Zika virus is concerned. Here are five questions that help explain the debate.

headline: Senate Democrats Block Zika Bill Over Planned Parenthood Provisions
keywords: ['Zika Virus', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: As Congress returned from recess, a stalemate resumed over a $1.1 billion plan to fight the virus even as public health experts warned that funding was desperately needed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Congress returned from a seven-week recess on Tuesday, Senate Democrats again stymied a $1.1 billion plan to fight the Zika virus, demanding that Republicans drop an effort to block Planned Parenthood from receiving money to combat the mosquito-borne disease.

headline: A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Yankees’ Rebuild
abstract: Trading proven veterans for high-profile prospects actually aided the team’s playoff push this season by giving players already in its system a chance to take the field.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees spent four months proving they were not true contenders — and, really, four months is being generous. After playing in one playoff game in the previous three seasons, the Yankees have needed a change for a while.

headline: Roger Ailes Stands Defiant as Fox Settles Lawsuits
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Sexual Harassment']
abstract: Lawyers for the ousted Fox News chairman say he paid no money in a $20 million sexual harassment settlement with Gretchen Carlson.
lead_paragraph: In the nearly seven weeks since Roger Ailes left Fox News in the aftermath of a sexual harassment lawsuit, the drama has barely subsided.

headline: Swin Cash Leaving Her Mark on Liberty in Her Last W.N.B.A. Season
abstract: Cash, a 15-year league veteran planning to retire, has started most of the team’s games while mentoring younger players and putting her strong voice to use in other ways.
lead_paragraph: When the W.N.B.A. introduced a new logo before the 2013 season, there was no indication of the identity of the player represented in silhouette. While the image remains up for interpretation, Liberty forward Swin Cash would have been a fitting inspiration.

headline: Bad Luck and Worse Manners Tarnish Obama’s Asia Trip
abstract: The trip brought progress, but it was marred by a chaotic arrival ceremony in China and an ugly personal outburst from the Philippine president.
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos — President Obama has grown accustomed to having his foreign travels overshadowed by terrorist attacks or police shootings. This might be the first time one of his trips has been marred by bad manners.

headline: Parents Sue After New York State Denies Money to ‘Failing’ Schools
abstract: In a lawsuit against two agencies, the plaintiffs say a promise was broken when nine schools labeled “persistently failing” showed improvement but were removed from a program that offers grants.
lead_paragraph: A group of public school parents has gone to court in hopes of prying from New York State money that they say they were promised for improving their schools.

headline: Mauricio Funes, Ex-Leader of El Salvador Under Inquiry, Gains Asylum
abstract: Nicaragua granted asylum to Mr. Funes, who has been under investigation by the Salvadoran authorities for suspicion of corruption.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The Nicaraguan government said Tuesday that it had granted political asylum to Mauricio Funes, the former president of El Salvador, who has been under investigation by the Salvadoran authorities for suspicion of corruption.

headline: Tennis Players Go Back and Forth on No-Ad Scoring
abstract: No-ad scoring took a long time to find acceptance on the pro tour, and the super tiebreaker remains a sore point.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to scoring, tennis has no doubles standard.

headline: Leslie H. Martinson, Director of Prime-Time TV for Four Decades, Dies at 101
abstract: Mr. Martinson’s long list of credits is a veritable capsule history of prime-time television through the postwar decades and beyond.
lead_paragraph: Leslie H. Martinson, a ubiquitous director whose long list of credits is a veritable capsule history of prime-time television through the postwar decades and beyond, died on Saturday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 101.

headline: Evangelicals Ignore G.O.P. by Embracing Syrian Refugees
keywords: ['Christians and Christianity', 'Evangelical Movement', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Governors (US)', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)']
abstract: Republican governors resisted the resettling of Syrians, but it was their supporters, Christian conservatives, who rushed to welcome the newcomers.
lead_paragraph: MARIETTA, Ga. — William Stocks, a white, Alabama-born, Republican-leaning member of Johnson Ferry Baptist Church, arrived at the tiny apartment of a Syrian refugee family on a Wednesday night after work. He was wearing a green-striped golf shirt and a gentle smile, and he was eager to teach yet another improvised session of English 101.

headline: Novak Djokovic to Face Gaël Monfils in U.S. Open Semifinal
abstract: Djokovic advanced after Jo-Wilfried Tsonga retired with an injury during their quarterfinal, and Monfils won in straight sets over fellow Frenchman Lucas Pouille.
lead_paragraph: As Novak Djokovic pursues a third United States Open title, he finds himself in the odd position of issuing get-well messages to a chorus line of incapacitated opponents.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Wednesday, September 7, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “Yes, it’s true. I was dead, and I resurrected, as I always do.”

headline: Pay to Play, Mr. Trump?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Campaign Finance', 'Editorials', 'Attorneys General', 'Elections, Attorneys General']
abstract: He gave Florida’s attorney general a campaign donation days after her office said it was reviewing allegations against Trump University.
lead_paragraph: In light of the suspicions hanging over Donald Trump and Pam Bondi, the Florida attorney general, this opening quote from her Republican National Convention speech is particularly rich. “Nov. 8 is a day of reckoning for all those who have abused their power,” she said. “Winning this election means reclaiming something to which I’ve dedicated my entire career: the rule of law.”

headline: Richard Neville, 74, a Founder of ’60s Counterculture Magazine Oz, Dies
abstract: The Australian iconoclast, who stood trial for obscenity, challenged mores and societal taboos with magazines in his country and in Britain.
lead_paragraph: Richard Neville, who challenged societal taboos and obscenity standards as a founder of the satirical countercultural magazine Oz in the 1960s, died on Sunday in Byron Bay, Australia. He was 74.

headline: Donald Trump’s Donation Is His Latest Brush With Campaign Fund Rules
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Campaign Finance', 'Attorneys General', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Elections, Attorneys General']

Trump, who has repeatedly denounced pay-to-play politics during his insurgent campaign, is now defending himself against claims that he donated $25,000 to a group supporting the Florida attorney general, Pam Bondi, to sway her office’s review of fraud allegations at Trump University.

headline: W.H.O. Clarifies Advice on Sex and Pregnancy in Zika Regions
abstract: A spokeswoman said, “We want it to be unmistakable that we are not counseling anybody toward delay.”
lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization on Tuesday clarified — once again — its advice on sexual transmission of the Zika virus, saying that couples living in areas where it is circulating should be offered contraception and counseling to help decide whether to become pregnant.

headline: Read Me On Twitter!
abstract: This blog isn’t all there is.
lead_paragraph: It has come to my attention that some long-time blog followers aren’t aware that I am now Tweeting directly, and that this has to some extent displaced my blogging — especially when it comes to political commentary. If you don’t know about this, you should check it out. You don’t need to be on Twitter yourself, although if you are I’m @paulkrugman. As long as you are online, just go here — twitter dot com slash paulkrugman.

headline: Follow the Directions
abstract: A newcomer, Kary Haddad, needs our help.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Making your New York Times Crossword debut in front of the entire world is a nerve-racking experience. It’s the sort of thing that takes the fortitude that comes only with a full stomach, and the newcomer Kary Haddad is at a disadvantage: He’s wandering around his puzzle, desperately trying to feed himself on prepackaged and leftover foods.

headline: Vertamae Smart-Grosvenor Dies at 79; Celebrated Gullah Food and Culture
abstract: A South Carolina native, who liked to call herself a “culinary griot,” she was heard on NPR for three decades. She also was an author, an actress and a singer.
lead_paragraph: Vertamae Smart-Grosvenor, who in a life of varied artistic careers, most notably as a commentator on NPR, was best known for extolling the virtues of the Gullah food and culture of her native South Carolina, died on Saturday in the Bronx. She was 79.

headline: A Boogie Wit Da Hoodie Modernizes New York Hip-Hop
abstract: The most promising young rapper the city has produced in some time, A Boogie may have cracked the code at creating a new New York style.

In the song, after meeting a girl, he tries talking her up. “I’m from New York,” he tells her. “She like my accent.”

lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — The final wave of Mets reinforcements arrived at Great American Ball Park at the same time on Tuesday afternoon. In street clothes and his blue Mets duffle bag in hand, Eric Campbell was welcomed with hugs.

headline: Final-Out Catch by Brett Gardner Secures Yankees’ Win Over Blue Jays
abstract: The Yankees had a three-run lead going into the ninth inning but needed a grab at the left-field wall by Gardner to escape a bases-loaded jam and seal a one-run victory.
lead_paragraph: As Brett Gardner retreated unsteadily toward the left-field wall, tracking the baseball all the way, he leapt and felt it hit his glove. But the ball jiggled around in his mitt, and hitting the wall had jostled Gardner. The crowd noise only fed his uncertainty.

headline: We Are All Noah Now
keywords: ['Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Biodiversity', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Environment', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: We and our kids are rapidly becoming charged with saving each species’ last pairs.
lead_paragraph: HONOLULU — Robert Macfarlane, in his book “Landmarks,” about the connection between words and landscapes, tells a revealing but stunning story about how recent editions of the Oxford Junior Dictionary (aimed at 7-year-olds) dropped certain “nature words” that its editors deemed less relevant to the lives of modern children. These included “acorn,” “dandelion,” “fern,” “nectar,” “otter,” “pasture” and “willow.” The terms introduced in their place, he noted, included “broadband,” “blog,” “cut-and-paste,” “MP3 player” and “voice-mail.”

The latest charges illustrate how far the gulf nation’s leaders are willing to go to crush dissent.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Glass Bricks
abstract: Hidden everywhere in plain sight, they can quickly transport you to the distant past.
lead_paragraph: Like so many seemingly innocuous things, glass bricks were created to make the world a better place. They were invented at the turn of the 20th century to provide factory workers with more natural light. Soon they moved beyond the world of industry, as Art Deco architects took to their sleek modernism, using them to adorn building exteriors and divide interiors. A 1930 issue of Popular Science speculated about a future in which skyscrapers would be made almost entirely of glass bricks.

headline: An Effective but Exhausting Alternative to High-School Suspensions
abstract: When kids get into trouble at school, traditional forms of discipline often lead to more trouble. Is there a more productive way to change behavior?
lead_paragraph: In December 2013, Colleen Walsh, a social-studies teacher at Leadership and Public Service High School in Manhattan’s Financial District, called one of the school’s four deans in charge of discipline. She had just had a short, heated dispute in the hallway with a 17-year-old student who had his cellphone out, a violation of school rules. Walsh, then 27, was an energetic teacher, entertaining and assertive, but something about the way she spoke to the young man, who was not her student, infuriated him. A junior who could be exceptionally charming but also combative, he started yelling at Walsh, at which point she contacted a dean in the hope that he could calm him so they could all discuss what had happened.

headline: What Should I Do With My Dead Husband’s Journals?
keywords: ['Ethics (Personal)', 'Lying', 'Dementia', 'Death and Dying', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Diaries', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on when private papers should remain private, whether prospective tenants should be told of a violent death in their apartment and whether a loved one with dementia must be told truths she can’t remember.
lead_paragraph: For 15 years I was happily married to a man who, sadly, died several years ago. It was a second marriage for both of us. He was survived by his former wife and two adult children, and I maintain a cordial relationship with all of them. I know that my husband loved his children, but also that he had difficulties with them.

headline: Lisa Lucas Wants to Make Reading Fun Again
abstract: The executive director of the National Book Foundation on inclusivity in publishing, genre fiction as literature and getting her Uber drivers to read more.
lead_paragraph: In February, you were named the director of the National Book Foundation. What does that mean on a day-to-day level? Our mission is to enhance the cultural value of good writing in America. That’s a big job! But I can’t just think of it in terms of, say, a 10-year plan. It’s getting to work, and saying it out loud, and reminding every person I meet on a bus and every Uber driver and every girlfriend who isn’t “a reader” that they, too, will like these things that I work every day in support of.

headline: Fortress of Tedium: What I Learned as a Substitute Teacher.
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'School Discipline (Students)', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: A novelist’s education in the classroom.
lead_paragraph: One wintry mix of a morning, while I was in training to be a substitute teacher, I saw a textbook that was being used in an 11th-grade English class. The class was studying transcendentalism, and the students were required to read excerpts from an essay called “Nature,” by Ralph Waldo Emerson. Emerson was an unmethodical writer with low, puffy sideburns who liked to work himself up into paragraphs of rapture. When it came time for him to write an essay or give an oration — about nature, say, or self-­reliance — he combed through his voluminous journals and pulled out choice bits that were more or less on topic, and he glued them together with some connective prose. For instance, in “Nature,” Emerson writes: “Standing on the bare ground, — my head bathed by the blithe air, and uplifted into infinite space, — all mean egotism vanishes. I become a transparent eye-ball.”

headline: New Self-Help Books for Pet Parents
abstract: Can cats be trained? What do you do if your poodle is afraid of puddles? Pet experts offer advice and consider problems common and otherwise.
lead_paragraph: In a 2013 study by the market research firm Kelton Global, 81 percent of respondents considered their dogs to be equal in status to human family members. That seems a lowball figure to me. Judging by the number of people in my dog run whom I know only as Walter’s dad or Puffy’s mom, I’d say the number is closer to 100 billion percent. But let’s not quibble about numbers. This much is clear: Treating our pets like children means we might indulge them a little. O.K., a lot. My point is, people who love their pets too much sometimes encounter problems, and for that, several recent books come to the rescue.

headline: New to Airbnb? How to Make It Work for You
abstract: First-time users of Airbnb should contact hosts before their stays, know the cancellation policies, and leave honest feedback.
lead_paragraph: I have a confession: before writing this column, I had never used Airbnb. My first experience with this San Francisco-based rental-home marketplace, which was founded in 2008 and dropped a proverbial bomb on the hotel industry, came when I visited Milwaukee in April. Before then, I had been hesitant to use the service: What if something went wrong? What if the place was grossly misrepresented? What if the owner tried to unfairly pin a broken dish or a rip in the sofa on me? The possibilities for something going wrong, it seemed, were endless.

The bill includes $280 million to address the crisis over contaminated drinking water in Flint, Mich., as well as funding to combat the pollution runoff that has fed the vast bloom of algae in the waterways of southeastern Florida.

headline: Writing a ‘Last Letter’ When You’re Healthy
abstract: A Stanford University project guides people — healthy or not — to write a letter to their loved ones so they won’t have regrets at the end of life.
lead_paragraph: Over the last 15 years, as a geriatrics and palliative care doctor, I have had candid conversations with countless patients near the end of their lives. The most common emotion they express is regret: regret that they never took the time to mend broken friendships and relationships; regret that they never told their friends and family how much they care; regret that they are going to be remembered by their children as hypercritical mothers or exacting, authoritarian fathers.

headline: That Voice Inside Your Head? It May Be His
abstract: Simon McBurney prepares a one-man show, “The Encounter,” for Broadway.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Simon McBurney was chatting about his children as a technician adjusted his microphone. How many photographs he had of them on his phone — more than had ever been taken of him in his lifetime. How memories are preserved and created around images and sound. “Put on your headphones,” he urged, going on to explain how binaural technology — sound transmitted separately into each ear — works, fooling the brain into imagining a person is just inches away.

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — “I’m very polite. One must be polite,” the artist Tsang Kin-wah said in an interview last month at his spare, one-room studio in an industrial area of Hong Kong. “I used to never swear in real life, so I did so in my art.”

headline: China’s Tech-Savvy, Burned-Out and Spiritually Adrift, Turn to Buddhism
keywords: ['Buddhism', 'Meditation', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Monasteries and Monks', 'Work-Life Balance']
abstract: The Longquan Monastery in northwest Beijing has become a haven for those seeking connectivity instead of seclusion, and practical advice rather than deep philosophy.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — For centuries, Buddhists seeking enlightenment made the journey to Longquan Monastery, a lonesome temple on a hilltop in the hinterlands of northwest Beijing. Under the ginkgo and cypress trees, they meditated, chanted and pored over ancient texts.

headline: Obama Takes a Detour to Reconnect With Southeast Asia
keywords: ['Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'United States International Relations', 'Mines, Explosive', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The president spent time at a monastery and went shopping, but he also used a visit to a university to press for passage of the Trans-Pacific Partnership.
lead_paragraph: LUANG PRABANG, Laos — President Obama has always liked to move to the languid rhythms of Southeast Asia. On Wednesday, he interrupted a hectic tour of China and Laos to reconnect with his inner Southeast Asian in this beguiling city of Buddhist temples and French colonial villas.

headline: The U.N.’s Responsibility in Haiti’s Cholera Crisis
abstract: The spread of cholera in Haiti was a preventable disaster. The United Nations must continue to open up about its role in the outbreak.
lead_paragraph: Marseille, France In late 2010, the Haitian government asked me to investigate a cholera outbreak that struck that autumn following the arrival of a United Nations peacekeeping unit. It quickly became evident that some of the peacekeepers, who had been rotating through Haiti as part of a mission started in 2004 to provide security and stability, had introduced cholera from Nepal, where the disease had been flourishing.
