lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Federal investigators in India brought murder charges on Wednesday against a right-wing activist they say conspired in the killing of a veteran campaigner against religious gurus, faith healers, godmen and other mystical entrepreneurs.

headline: Creepy Clown Reports Continue, and Clowns Are Not Happy
abstract: In a two-week period, communities in North and South Carolina have been calling the police about people dressed as clowns, some trying to lure children.
lead_paragraph: First there were the reports in Greenville County, S.C., of creepy clowns offering children money to come into the woods. There was also the mysterious late-night sighting of a clown waving under a streetlight.

headline: Recalling Butoh Pioneers, at Japan Society
abstract: Work inspired by Kazuo Ohno and Tatsumi Hijikata will be presented on Sept. 16 and 17.
lead_paragraph: One day, the Japanese dancer Takao Kawaguchi had a vision. “It suddenly popped into my head: I want to become Kazuo Ohno,” he recalled. Ohno, who died in 2010 at 103, was internationally celebrated as a founder of the emotionally intense dance form known as Butoh. Mr. Kawaguchi never saw Ohno perform, although Ohno danced past the age of 100, presenting solos in which he played both female and male roles. Mr. Kawaguchi eventually took vintage films of two of Ohno’s most famous solos, “My Mother” and “Admiring La Argentina,” which honors a great Spanish dancer, and duplicated them phrase by phrase with his own body.

headline: Lucy Dacus, Hopscotching From Wounded to Wounding
abstract: With her fragile yet commanding voice and barbed lyrics, this singer-songwriter from Richmond, Va., will hold forth at the Bowery Ballroom.
lead_paragraph: Lucy Dacus, a 21-year-old singer and songwriter based in Richmond, Va., makes indie rock sound urgent again by never rushing toward catharsis. On her precocious debut album, “No Burden” (recently reissued by Matador after a smaller independent release earlier this year), even the fuzzy, full-band stomps build like the ballads: Release comes only when Ms. Dacus has laid the foundation for emotional wreckage. With a fragile yet commanding voice and barbed lyrics that move between wounded and wounding, Ms. Dacus shares a skeptical wit with Will Toledo, her fellow Matador signee and current tour mate, who performs as Car Seat Headrest. Ms. Dacus, though, has teeth sharpened by the realities of being a woman. “Daddy told you to stay indoors,” she sings on “Troublemaker Doppelgänger.” “And I can understand how a girl gets bored/too old to play and too young to mess around.” (Thursday, Sept. 15, and Friday at the Bowery Ballroom; boweryballroom.com.)

headline: Brad Pitt Reads Marlon James
abstract: The actor, who was interviewed by James for T’s Men’s Style issue, shares a passage from James’s novel “A Brief History of Seven Killings.”
lead_paragraph: The actor, who was interviewed by James for T’s Men’s Style issue, shares a passage from James’s novel “A Brief History of Seven Killings.”

headline: A Carmen Herrera Solo Exhibition at the Whitney
abstract: “Carmen Herrera: Lines of Sight” focuses on her work from 1948 to 1978, when she was finding her signature style.
lead_paragraph: “Don’t do it,” the painter Carmen Herrera recently counseled an interviewer, about turning a century old, which she did last year. “It’s horrible.”

headline: Five or Six Things I Didn’t Know About Brad Pitt, by Marlon James
abstract: Musings from the Man Booker-winning author after his first meeting with one of the biggest — and nicest — stars on the planet.
lead_paragraph: The worst kind, too. The kind who lets a plant starve to death. The evidence, at two opposing corners of his office in Beverly Hills; skeletal remnants that long gave up hope of ever being watered. He’s been away for 10 months, he says. An explanation, if not exactly an excuse. Regardless, I vow to expose his plant-murdering ways because the American public deserves to know, and besides, at 52 one should take whatever notoriety one can get.

headline: Phoebe Waller-Bridge’s Rage and Sex, in ‘Fleabag’
abstract: Ms. Waller-Bridge is bringing her sexually rapacious, anger-riddled, flailing London cafe owner to a TV series on Amazon.
lead_paragraph: In her 20s, Phoebe Waller-Bridge found herself confused about what makes a good feminist and how much sex women should have. She wove her deliriously smutty preoccupations, along with a wallop of rage, into “Fleabag,” a show at the 2013 Edinburgh Festival Fringe that scooped up an Olivier nomination and the Stage award for solo performer.

headline: A Sept. 11 Memorial at Bargemusic and a Juilliard Faculty Show
abstract: A free concert will be held in a venue that used to look out on the twin towers, and a faculty recital kicks off a season.
lead_paragraph: Bargemusic, the popular floating concert hall docked near the Brooklyn Bridge, is an especially poignant place for a Sept. 11 memorial. The twin towers used to be visible through the picture windows behind the small stage in this intimate space. This year’s free memorial program presents the violinist Mark Peskanov; the pianist and composer David Bottoms; the String Orchestra of Brooklyn; and others in works by Bach, Barber, Beethoven and more. (Sunday, Sept. 11, at 4 p.m., Fulton Ferry Landing, Brooklyn, 800-838-3006; bargemusic.org.)

headline: Where Were Women in Movies? Anthology Film Archives Gives an Early History
abstract: “Woman With a Movie Camera: Female Film Directors Before 1950” starts with works by Ida May Park, Gene Gauntier and others.
lead_paragraph: Any historical discussion of female directors is likely to name-check Leni Riefenstahl, the German documentary filmmaker whose biggest fan was Adolf Hitler, and Ida Lupino, the actress who directed a handful of features in the late 1940s and ’50s before expanding into television.

headline: U.S. Open Today: Andy Murray Falls; Serena Williams Survives
abstract: Here’s what’s happened at the United States Open on Wednesday, including an upset and farewell to the fan favorite.
lead_paragraph: The collapse started with some rain, then accelerated with a bang. And after nearly four hours, Andy Murray was out of the United States Open, losing to Kei Nishikori, 1-6, 6-4, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5.

headline: 12 Recipes for Midweek
abstract: For the no-recipe fans, try polenta and fresh crab meat.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Cocktails and Mixed Drinks', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: For Fashion Week in New York, makeup classes, hotel packages and designer cocktails.
lead_paragraph: It’s that time of year again in New York City: New York Fashion Week, where more than 60 international designers showcase their spring 2017 collections, is held from Sept. 8 to 15 and kicks off a fall season of global fashion weeks in cities like London, Milan and Paris.

headline: Bryans Might Want to Switch Sides on Service Returns

lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — One of President Enrique Peña Nieto’s top ministers and closest allies resigned on Wednesday, an apparent casualty of Mr. Peña Nieto’s wildly unpopular meeting last week with Donald J. Trump.

headline: Scientists See Push From Climate Change in Louisiana Flooding
abstract: Warming makes intense storms like those that hit southern Louisiana last month at least 40 percent more likely, researchers said.
lead_paragraph: Climate change has increased the likelihood of torrential downpours along the Gulf Coast like those that led to deadly floods in southern Louisiana last month, scientists said Wednesday.

headline: 1916: Hundreds of Slackers Roped In
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Hundreds are roped in during a boxing event in London in September 1916.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The boxing entertainment at the Ring, Blackfriars road, on Tuesday afternoon [Sept. 5] came to an abrupt conclusion. Three thousand persons were present, and the well-ordered and scientific pummelling was in full swing when a force of military and police, acting under the orders of the recruiting authorities, took possession of the building. Of the thousands who thronged the hall the majority were young men, sturdy, athletic and well trained. They tried to bolt, but all the exits were strongly guarded. A number gained the roof and tried to escape through the skylights. A few jumped into the street — in every case into the arms of a policeman. About 300 men were escorted to Southwark Police Station to give a satisfactory account of themselves, and wounded soldiers in the street cheered loudly. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 8, 1916

headline: Five Places to Go in D.C.’s North Shaw Area
abstract: Once a 15-acre swath of gritty streets, parking lots and vacant buildings, North Shaw is the latest residential, retail and creative hub in the district.
lead_paragraph: North Shaw is popping as a vibrant urban landscape with new shops and restaurants and more in mid-construction. Formerly a 15-acre swath known for gritty streets, parking lots, vacant buildings and chain-link fences, it’s the latest residential, retail and creative hub in the nation’s capital. On warm nights now, crowds pack the outdoor tables of tasteful restaurants on the wide sidewalks near the intersection of Florida Avenue and Eighth Street Northwest; street murals by local artists brighten building facades; and posters promote sumo wrestling and free henna tattoos.

headline: The Historic Building That Presented an Intriguing Architectural Problem
abstract: The small, design-forward firm WORKac created a new penthouse on the roof of 93 Reade Street, that can’t be seen from the street.
lead_paragraph: The small, design-forward firm WORKac created a new penthouse on the roof of 93 Reade Street, that can’t be seen from the street.

headline: The Glass Apartment Hidden in Plain Sight
abstract: The architects at WORKac were tasked with designing a penthouse that couldn’t be seen from the street. They succeeded, which is a shame: It’s pretty cool.
lead_paragraph: When the Jones brothers, Joshua and John Q., built 93 Reade Street in 1857, it was one of the first cast-iron buildings in downtown New York. The brothers decided to show off a little — after all, they came from the very same family whose uptown house had inspired the phrase “keeping up with the Joneses.” The facade was a veritable wedding cake, incorporating just about every molding, capital and dentilled cornice they could get out of the D.D. Badger ironworks catalog, and when it was all bolted together, the brothers capped it off with a big arched pediment.

headline: Five New Designers Debuting This Season
abstract: A crop of new names are showing their spring/summer 2017 collections this New York Fashion Week — and beyond. Here, a handful to know.
lead_paragraph: A crop of new names are showing their spring/summer 2017 collections this New York Fashion Week — and beyond. Here, a handful to know.

headline: Veterans Back on Patrol, This Time to Protect Marijuana
abstract: In Colorado, a marriage of sorts has formed between the marijuana industry and war veterans, with more than 200 of them now employed as cannabis security guards.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — It’s nighttime at the Herbal Cure, a south Denver marijuana shop and grow house tucked into a parking lot beside the highway. Inside is a marijuana bounty: thousands of dollars’ worth of cannabis plants, boxes of marijuana-infused chocolate, jars of $360-an-ounce weed with names like Frankenberry, Lemon Skunk and Purple Cheddar.

headline: Win or Lose, Donald Trump Is Coming to Pennsylvania Avenue (With His New Hotel)
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']

lead_paragraph: The Presidential Suite is 4,000 square feet of pure opulence, with three bedrooms, a fitness center, a butler’s pantry and a bathroom tiled with Calacatta Gold marble from an Italian quarry.

headline: ‘Leave the Editorializing to Our Colleagues on the Opinion Side’
abstract: As the election nears, Times staffers have gotten another warning to play it safe on social media.
lead_paragraph: For the second time in three months, The Times’s associate managing editor for standards sent a note out to the newsroom Wednesday morning warning journalists to avoid offering up their own political opinions through Twitter, Facebook or other social media. The standards editor, Phil Corbett, says no particular incident prompted the note.

headline: How a Man Falls in Love
abstract: No, it’s not “The Notebook.” It’s real life. And it’s terrifying and wonderful all at once.
lead_paragraph: In those miserable, wonderful days when love is new, when your heart pounds and your breath comes short and sharp, the only thing that matters is your beloved. News of the outside world comes as a rumor. Daily life is a melodrama, a musical, a rom-com, an epic.

lead_paragraph: LUCERNE, Switzerland — On the surface here, things seemed as tranquil as the swan-dotted waters of Lake Lucerne, which flow right into the lobby of the KKL Luzern concert hall.

lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Donald J. Trump on Wednesday called for a vast expansion of the military, including 90,000 new soldiers for the Army and nearly 75 new ships for the Navy, requiring up to $90 billion a year in additional spending.

headline: The First Shows
abstract: Designers recall their debuts and other pivotal moments in their runway careers.
lead_paragraph: As New York Fashion Week approaches its 75th year (the first official shows, massed under the heading of Press Week, were held in 1943), with 151 shows spread over nine days, many designers are questioning the future of this semiannual gathering. “We are facing the end of an era,” the designer Diane von Furstenberg said in a recent interview. “But there is nothing nostalgic about that. The future will be more exciting.”

headline: Relatively Few Americans Live in Partisan Media Bubble, but They’re Influential
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: New research finds that the great majority of people learn about political news from mainstream media sources.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who has followed this election carefully would be forgiven for thinking that voters have diverged into two separate realities. But it’s too soon to declare that we have entered a “post-fact” apocalypse, especially when we consider where people get information about politics.

headline: Another Side of Bob Dylan: Iron Sculptor
abstract: Mr. Dylan’s new public-art archway, titled “Portal,” will be at the MGM National Harbor, which opens later this year in Prince George’s County, Md.
lead_paragraph: Bob Dylan’s latest side project is even more perplexing than usual: He built an elaborate, 26-by-15-foot iron archway for a $1.3 billion resort casino in Maryland.

headline: In Ann Patchett’s ‘Commonwealth,’ Knotting and Unknotting the Ties That Bind
abstract: This time, Ms. Patchett explores the awkwardness, pain and grace of involuntary companionship by drawing on her own experience.
lead_paragraph: “Commonwealth,” Ann Patchett’s exquisite new novel, opens with one man handing a bottle of gin to another. Its contents will dissolve an entire family.

headline: Doug Aitken Plans Underwater Art Installation
abstract: Three mirrored pavilions, open to swimmers and fish, will be submerged off the coast of Catalina Island.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In planning his hometown survey, which opens on Saturday at the Museum of Contemporary Art here, Doug Aitken decided early on that he also wanted to develop a separate site-specific art project to reach beyond museum walls. But instead of going into the desert to find a site, as so many West Coast artists have done, he went the other direction: entering the Pacific Ocean for his first underwater art installation.

headline: No Clear Logic in Verizon’s Digital Media Venture
abstract: Verizon’s acquisitions of Yahoo and AOL raise legitimate questions about the judgment of Verizon’s management.
lead_paragraph: Maybe I am a Luddite. I just don’t get the industrial logic behind Verizon Communications’ recent $9.2 billion foray into the digital media “space,” especially because the way it has chosen to compete in it is by buying Yahoo and AOL, two companies that have seen much better days.

keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense']
abstract: Ashton B. Carter harshly rebuked the Russian government, saying it wanted to “erode the international order.”
lead_paragraph: OXFORD, England — Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter lashed out at Russia on Wednesday, accusing the government of President Vladimir V. Putin of demonstrating a “clear ambition to erode” international order and warning Russia to stay out of the American elections.

headline: Denmark Will Buy Leaked Panamanian Documents in Fight Against Tax Evasion
abstract: It was unclear if the files were from the so-called Panama Papers, but they originated with the same law firm at the center of an offshore finance scandal.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Denmark will buy documents leaked from the Panamanian law firm at the heart of an offshore finance scandal, part of a growing global effort to clamp down on tax evasion by wealthy individuals, Denmark’s tax minister said on Wednesday.

headline: One-Thing Shop: Tinned Fish, Lisbon
keywords: ['Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores']
abstract: The 86-year-old Conserveira de Lisboa sells over 130 types — including squid in ink, smoked octopus and a variety of fish eggs.
lead_paragraph: With World War II looming, the owners of a little grocery store in Lisbon made two big decisions. First, they decided to specialize in tinned fish, which would be easier to stock and export than a wider range of groceries — and, in a move that was rather rare at the time, they began to register their own brands. “A bet they made 86 years ago really paid off,” says Tiago Cabral Ferreira, whose grandfather was one of the initial owners of Conserveira de Lisboa, which still, to this day, sells only tinned fish. Without such forward thinking, the shop would likely be long gone.

headline: Naomi Campbell on Diversity in the Fashion Industry, Beauty and More
abstract: The legendary model, who is a mentor at this season’s VFiles show, spoke to T about how things have changed since she started out.
lead_paragraph: On the eve of VFiles’s fashion-week show, Naomi Campbell — who has been cast as one of the program’s mentors along with the stylist Mel Ottenberg, the makeup artist Pat McGrath, the Fear of God designer Jerry Lorenzo and the rapper Young Thug — was crouching down in a vintage dress and corset to look at designer mood boards and talk to each of the five designers who will present their collections at the group show on Wednesday night. “It’s an honor to see what’s new and young in fashion,” she told T. Below, Campbell talks about whether she feels models on the runway have become more diverse — and how being a model has changed since she began working in the 1980s.

headline: Shakiness of Giant Deals Poses No Threat to 2015 Record
abstract: More than $750 billion worth of acquisitions proposed last year have been abandoned, and more hang in the balance, but $4.4 trillion in deals were made.
lead_paragraph: Two notable mergers and acquisitions achievements hang in the balance for 2015, but even with a couple of giant deals on the rocks, 2015 is set to retain the global crown. A year will come someday, though, that surpasses its $4.4 trillion of action. The volume and scale of withdrawn deals in 1999, however, are more likely to stand the test of time.

headline: Lawsuits Over ITT Shutdown Are Just Starting
abstract: ITT has already been sued for violations of the federal WARN Act, and it has telegraphed its intent to sue the Department of Education.
lead_paragraph: As a boy growing up in Southern California, sick days meant staying home from school and watching reruns of “Mission Impossible” while my parents went to work. Each episode started with Peter Graves as Mr. Phelps accepting his mission and was punctuated with plenty of advertisements for the ITT Technical Institute.

headline: Shakespeare Didn’t Actually Write That
abstract: The scholar David McInnis delves into which phrases attributed to Shakespeare were used by him first — or not.
lead_paragraph: This year marks the 400th anniversary of Shakespeare’s death, and the worldwide commemorations and plaudits abound. But not everybody’s using the occasion to puff up the playwright.

headline: Oregon Police Look for People Who Wrecked Popular ‘Duckbill’ Formation
keywords: ['Vandalism', 'Rock and Stone', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores']
abstract: Park officials first thought the sandstone had fallen naturally. But a video shows people toppling it.
lead_paragraph: For years, the sandstone pedestal on Oregon’s northwest coast stood out like a fist jutting skyward. Now it lies in a crumbled pile, the target, apparently, of vandals.

headline: U.S. Open Match Draws Scrutiny by Betting Investigators
abstract: A tennis anticorruption body is investigating one of the women’s singles matches after irregular betting patterns were detected.
lead_paragraph: The Tennis Integrity Unit, the sport’s primary anticorruption body, is investigating a first-round women’s singles match at the United States Open after irregular betting patterns were detected.

abstract: Scenes from fashion shows in New York City through the decades.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from fashion shows in New York City through the decades.

headline: Days After Slur, Obama and Rodrigo Duterte of Philippines Meet Briefly
abstract: The short exchange at a summit meeting in Laos came after Mr. Obama canceled a previous meeting because Mr. Duterte used a slur against him.

headline: An Iconic Graphic Designer on His Process
abstract: Karel Martens, a legend in his native Netherlands, annotates a handful of his signature prints on the occasion of his first stateside show.
lead_paragraph: The influential Dutch graphic designer Karel Martens is most strongly associated with typography: He even developed his home country’s gold-standard master’s degree program focusing on the discipline. But Martens isn’t just a serifs-and-kerning guy: He works across video, installation and sculpture, too, having spent nearly 60 years developing a practice that reflects his persistent inquisitiveness. Starting this Sunday, Martens shares pieces — including an interactive video installation, a modular wall-covering system and a kinetic clock sculpture — at his first North American solo exhibition, hosted by P!, a project space on Broome Street. (The Martens show kicks off P!’s final season of programming at the Chinatown location, where it’s been based for five years; it’s planned to reopen in 2018 in a new space.) But there are plenty of Martens’s trademark letterpress monoprints on view, too; and before Martens touched down in New York, the artist gave T a preview. Above, some of his colorful prints explained in his own words.

headline: ‘Mr. Robot’ Season 2, Episode 10: Anatomy of a Murder
abstract: The ugliest scene in this week’s episode is also its most elegantly constructed.
lead_paragraph: The ugliest scene in this week’s “Mr. Robot” is also its most elegantly constructed. It serves as the climax and endpoint of the episode, which, like the previous few weeks’ installments, had been a steadily mounting drumbeat of dread. Acting on equal parts intuition and plain good detective work — both of which are ignored by her superiors, as usual — the F.B.I. agent Dom DiPierro realizes that the two major fsociety suspects who’d dropped off a wounded associate at a local E.R. had not fled the scene fearing discovery at all. They’d simply stepped out for a bite to eat before returning to check on their comrade’s condition, and if she wants to catch them before they return to the hospital, find it swarming with law enforcement, and fly the coop for real, she has to step out, too.

headline: For Gay and Transgender Teens, Will It Get Better?
keywords: ['Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Social Media', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: School life can be hell for teenagers who don’t identify as straight. One refuge? The internet.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy to assume that now must be a better time than ever to be a lesbian, gay or bisexual teenager. We recently celebrated the one-year anniversary of the Supreme Court’s ruling in favor of same-sex marriage. Our culture has grown more accepting, too; one of the most anticipated albums of the year, Frank Ocean’s, embraces his desire for men. These factors work together to create the illusion that as a society we are barreling toward a world of complete liberation, where everyone is truly free to be whoever they are.

My friend Sam feels that I am being cold and unfeeling, and we no longer run errands together because of this dispute. Who’s right?

headline: When a Food Craving Won’t Let Go
abstract: Cochinita Pibil — pork made aromatic with citrus, cumin and allspice — will be a dish you want to eat on repeat.
lead_paragraph: When I cooked at a restaurant 30 miles south of San Francisco, I drove home after plating the last dessert order and scrubbing down the counters with soapy water. It was after midnight by then, and my neighborhood pizza place was closed, and everything else was, too. I showered in the time it took a pot of rice to cook on the stove, mixed in some butter, salted peanuts, whatever herbs I had and brown sugar. It was a sad little dinner, but for a long time it was mine.

So the artist Bruce Nauman had few distractions, which is the way he has liked it for more than 30 years, since moving to rural New Mexico from Los Angeles, away from an art world that has coveted him with an ardor he seems to need to hold at arm’s length.

It’s all about choosing the right travel partners and going in with some ground rules, said Melissa Biggs Bradley, the founder of Indagare, an online travel company that specializes in private custom group trips. “Vacationing with friends sounds like a good idea, but, in reality, that’s not always the case, and these trips can lead to broken friendships,” she said.

lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — When Amazon introduced its first tablet, it seemed like just another me-too entrant in a hot category pioneered by Apple. The company did nothing to diminish this view when it later came out with a smartphone that bombed so badly it stopped selling the phone a year later.

headline: ‘What Is Aleppo?’ Gary Johnson Asks, in an Interview Stumble
abstract: On “Morning Joe,” Mr. Johnson, the Libertarian Party candidate, indicated that he really was not aware of the Syrian city engulfed in civil war.
lead_paragraph: Gary Johnson, the former New Mexico governor and Libertarian Party presidential nominee, revealed a surprising lack of foreign policy knowledge on Thursday that could rock his insurgent candidacy when he could not answer a basic question about the crisis in Aleppo, Syria.

headline: 1966: Cairo Sentences Communists
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: The Egyptian Supreme Court sentences communists in Cairo in September 1966.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The Supreme State Security Court today sentenced eight pro-Peking communists to prison terms ranging from life to five years at hard labor on charges of plotting to overthrow the government and establish an ‘‘Egyptian People’s Republic.’’ The court sentenced the general secretary of the Egyptian Communist Party, Mustafa Agha, to life imprisonment with hard labor and also ordered the dissolution of the party and confiscation of its funds. Three defendants were acquitted, including army Col. Hamed Mustafa Daoud. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 9, 1966

headline: This Show Was Garbage. No, We’re Not Mean. It Literally Was.
abstract: Heron Preston makes his New York Fashion Week debut with a collection reworked from sanitation department uniforms.
lead_paragraph: One person’s used uniform is another person’s fashion find. Or so was the thinking of Heron Preston, a founding member of the art/disc jockey/design collective Been Trill and designer, who presented a collection in collaboration with the Department of Sanitation New York on Wednesday evening. (The venue was in and around the Spring Street Salt Shed, an award-winning structure that houses 5,000 tons of salt for city winters.)

headline: Top Palestinian Court Postpones Oct. 8 Municipal Elections
abstract: The ruling follows a challenge to a decision to exclude balloting in East Jerusalem, but the Fatah-Hamas rivalry is also a factor.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Palestinian politics are constantly in disarray. This time, the chaos is by court order.

headline: A Subversive Take on Men’s Formal Wear
abstract: As streetwear continues its advance on men’s fashion, fancier dress has become the most unexpected way to present oneself right now.
lead_paragraph: As streetwear continues its advance on men’s fashion, fancier dress has become the most unexpected way to present oneself right now.

headline: ‘Narcos’ Season 2, Episode 7: Collateral Damage
abstract: Both Escobar and the president of Colombia are focused on a fight that has entangled innocents.
lead_paragraph: “Deutschland 93” opens with a domestic scene we’ve witnessed countless times before in TV shows and movies: A family hustles through the morning routine before zipping off to school, work and other destinations. It’s visual shorthand for normalcy, in other words, a way to establish that the family dynamic we’re watching is no different than our own. The big difference in “Narcos” is that we’ve never seen this beautiful family before, which is a primer for tragedy on a show about Pablo Escobar. And so this generic scene becomes an agonizing wait for the inevitable bomb that will rip it apart.

headline: ‘Don’t Erase Us’: French Catalans Fear Losing More Than a Region’s Name
abstract: Combining the Languedoc-Roussillon and Midi-Pyrénées regions under a new name, Occitanie, is regarded by some as a threat to their cultural identity.
lead_paragraph: PERPIGNAN, France — What’s in a name? A lot apparently, at least if you ask French Catalans who live in the country’s southwest corner, here around Perpignan.

headline: The Hunger in Our Heads
abstract: How physical activity might quell the eating binges that follow intense mental activity.
lead_paragraph: A busy brain can mean a hungry body. We often seek food after focused mental activity, like preparing for an exam or poring over spreadsheets. Researchers speculate that heavy bouts of thinking drain energy from the brain, whose capacity to store fuel is very limited. So the brain, sensing that it may soon require more calories to keep going, apparently stimulates bodily hunger, and even though there has been little in the way of physical movement or caloric expenditure, we eat. This process may partly account for the weight gain so commonly seen in college students.

headline: Highlights of Hillary Clinton’s News Conference
abstract: Hillary Clinton took questions at a news conference on Thursday on an airport tarmac in New York, one night after a presidential forum on national security issues.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton took questions at a news conference on an airport tarmac in New York on Thursday, one night after a presidential forum on national security issues.

headline: How Do You Get to Be a Governor in Vladimir Putin’s Russia?
abstract: Putin won’t trust anyone — except the people whose literal job is keeping him safe.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW According to Aleksei Diumin, it happened late one night, far from Moscow. He was standing guard at a presidential palace where Vladimir V. Putin was sleeping. A bear approached. “He and I looked each other in the eyes,” Mr. Diumin told a Russian newspaper. Then the bear backed away slightly. “I opened the door and emptied my gun’s entire clip at his feet.” The bear retreated. Russia’s president was safe.

headline: Tim Tebow Signs Minor League Deal With Mets
abstract: Tebow, 29, a former Heisman Trophy winner and N.F.L. quarterback, is now listed as an outfielder and expected to report to the Mets’ instructional league on Sept. 19.
lead_paragraph: When word trickled out last month that Tim Tebow hoped to embark on a professional baseball career, Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson wanted in on the joke.

headline: Lewis Black Flaunts His (Really, Really) Angry Side on Broadway
abstract: Mr. Black will bring his red-hot temper to the Marquis Theater in a new show, “Black to the Future.”
lead_paragraph: Lewis Black is probably best known for his comedic rants on “The Daily Show,” which he has done during the tenure of all three of its hosts, dating back to Craig Kilborn. But Mr. Black also has a long history in the theater, both writing (including a short work produced at Ensemble Studio Theater) and performing (in New York as well as at the Williamstown Theater Festival, where he has appeared many times). While his trademark fury is the same, he presents a richer and more varied performance live, one that shows off his many shades of red-hot anger. His new show, “Black to the Future,” arrives on Broadway on Monday, Sept. 12, and considering the impending election, he should have plenty to vent about. (Marquis Theater; 877-250-2929, marquistheatre.com.)

headline: Airbnb Adopts Rules to Fight Discrimination by Its Hosts
abstract: The short-term rental company has been facing criticism that some hosts reject renters based on race, religion, gender, ethnicity, age or disability.

headline: Daveed Diggs Jets From ‘Hamilton’ Into the Future

headline: 1891: A Sacrilegious Fox
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: A fox enters the Sacre-Coeur in September 1891.
lead_paragraph: While the caretakers in the Church of the Sacre-Coeur were going on their rounds late on Monday night [Sept. 7], they were startled by a strange noise which seemed to come from behind the high altar. Suddenly something leaped on the altar, overturned the candles, and disappeared. By the light of the lanterns appeared the shadow, not of a Socialist, but of a fantastic-looking animal with a tail. Yesterday morning the curé of Montmartre found fifteen of his chickens strangled, and in a corner of the fowl house a fox was crouching. The animal was of course taken before the Commissary of Police, who condemned it to death. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 9, 1891

headline: In Siberia, a ‘Blood River’ in a Dead Zone Twice the Size of Rhode Island
abstract: The Norilsk Nickel plant is one of the world’s biggest polluters, so it was no surprise when the nearby Daldykan River began to run red.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A river in the far north of Siberia turned bright red this week, residents said, leading Russians to nickname the tributary the “blood river.”

headline: Frick Collection to Offer Free Admission on First Fridays
abstract: Starting in October, admission and gallery programs will be free from 6 to 9 p.m. on the first Friday of the month.
lead_paragraph: The Frick Collection, which began staying open late on Friday nights starting in 2002, has been making some of those nights free on an occasional basis for the last five years — and noticing that the crowds tend to be younger and filled with first-time visitors. Now the collection — home to three of eight Vermeers in Manhattan, along with enough van Dycks, Rembrandts, El Grecos and Turners to stock several nice museums — plans to make its free nights a regular institution, on the first Friday of every month beginning in October.

headline: She Was No Bird: ‘Jane Eyre’ Manuscript on First Trip to America
abstract: “Charlotte Brontë: An Independent Will,’’ at the Morgan Library & Museum, delves into the enchanted childhood of the author of “Jane Eyre.”
lead_paragraph: THE dress — a floor-length blue-on-white petal print with little round buttons up the bodice and a tight collar — is tiny, tailored for a woman 4 feet 9 inches tall. The wearer was Charlotte Brontë, and her demure day dress, just about big enough for a 12-year-old girl, was the plain wrapping that encased an enormous talent, a bubbling blend of ambition, passion and literary genius.

That is, unless you count the black eyes incurred by U.S.A. Swimming and the United States Olympic Committee, the governing bodies for which Lochte proved an indecorous ambassador.

headline: Whether Shaved by Hand or Machine, This Roman Treat Is Just as Frosty
abstract: Purveyors of grattachecca, the traditional homegrown version of a snow cone, have spirited debates about the proper way to prepare the ice.
lead_paragraph: The simple ingredients haven’t changed much since the first grattachecca appeared in Rome more than a century ago: ice and fruity, colored syrups, seemingly not so different from an American snow cone. But today’s grattacheccari, makers of the treat, are divided into two adversarial groups: the purists and the hygienicals.

headline: ‘I Want to Win Someday’: Tribes Make Stand Against Pipeline
keywords: ['Native Americans', 'Pipelines', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: Some of the Native Americans protesting in North Dakota speak of lost lands and broken treaties. They hope this fight will have a happier outcome.
lead_paragraph: NEAR CANNON BALL, N.D. — Verna Bailey stared into the silvery ripples of a man-made lake, looking for the spot where she had been born. “Out there,” she said, pointing to the water. “I lived down there with my grandmother and grandfather. We had a community there. Now it’s all gone.”

Putin, signaling a preference for the leadership of an authoritarian adversary over that of America’s own president, despite a cascade of criticism from Democrats and expressions of discomfort among Republicans.

headline: The Woolly Wisdom in the ‘Llama Llama’ Books
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Books and Literature', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)']
abstract: In her series of children’s books about llamas, Anna Dewdney wrote with a deceptive brilliance that spoke to parents and children alike.
lead_paragraph: When I walked into the pediatric clinic yesterday morning, I went to the shelves where the volunteer readers keep their books, and pulled out a battered — in the sense of well-read and well-loved — copy of “Llama Llama Mad at Mama.” Like Anna Dewdney’s other stories, this one is funny and recognizable, as the young llama is dragged off, much against his will, for an expedition to the (yes!) Shop-O-Rama. Sure enough, things turn boring: “Look at knees and stand in line, Llama Llama starts to whine.”

headline: Snacks of Nepal Are a High Point at Woodside Cafe in Queens
abstract: A family started out with Italian food, then turned to the dishes of its Himalayan homeland.
lead_paragraph: The momos are giants, fat round dumplings with furrowed peaks, rising from a pink-orange sauce the color of penne alla vodka. It tastes a little like penne alla vodka, too, oddly, inexactly and wonderfully — marinara meets tikka masala, with momos as tortelloni writ large.

headline: ‘Queen of Katwe’ Makes Moves on a Ugandan Chessboard
abstract: Lupita Nyong’o, David Oyelowo and nonactors from Kampala star in Mira Nair’s movie, based on a true story about a girl whose life was changed by chess.
lead_paragraph: ATTERIGEVILLE, South Africa — On a sunny winter day in May 2015 in this run-down suburb, a 45-minute drive from the shiny office buildings and shopping centers of central Johannesburg, 30 tables were symmetrically arrayed in a large, shabby hall. At each one sat two tense-looking children, a chessboard between them, with spectators clustered in stands on either side of the hall. The actress Lupita Nyong’o, dressed in a bright yellow robe, clutched a small child at her side, as the director Mira Nair yelled directions at officials walking up and down the aisles.

headline: An Artist’s Haunting Fantasy of the Paris Opera Ballet
abstract: Alex Prager’s “La Grande Sortie” comprises both film and her trademark eerie crowd photographs.
lead_paragraph: Last year, the Paris Opera Ballet’s new online platform, 3e Scène, approached the photographer Alex Prager and asked her to make a film. She was given creative carte blanche, and allowed full access to the company’s facilities and dancers. What resulted is “La Grande Sortie,” a ten-minute movie that makes its stateside debut at Lehmann Maupin in New York this week alongside Prager’s distinctive, haunting photographs.

headline: Video Review: The F-Pace Crossover Keeps Its Jaguar DNA
abstract: It would have made sense for Jaguar Land Rover to borrow the architecture from the Evoque or Range Rover Sport, but the F-Pace is all Jag.
lead_paragraph: Jaguar has produced beautiful sedans, coupes and convertibles over the years. The F-Pace is the first crossover from the formidable team of Jaguar’s design director, Ian Callum. Its largely aluminum skin is a fetching compilation of curves that somehow manages to evoke the F-Type coupe, a machine with no prayer of carrying a family.

headline: The Indie Rocker Behind Creatures of the Wind’s Fiery Red Lip
abstract: Shane Gabier said PJ Harvey “is the closest thing I have to an idol or hero.” Here’s how to get the look she inspired for the brand’s spring 2017 show.
lead_paragraph: “I love a really hard, drawn-on lip,” the makeup artist Mark Carrasquillo said this morning, backstage at Creatures of the Wind. For the brand’s spring/summer 2017 show, he created a fiery red shade that paid tribute to the rebellious ’90s spirit of the indie-rock musician PJ Harvey — his technique mirroring what you might actually do if you only had five minutes to prep in a van before a show. He quickly defined the mouth with the Nars Velvet Lip Pencil in Dragon Girl — a bright red that, he says, “every girl I know wears” — then tapped on Nars Coeur Battante fuchsia blush (a limited-edition shade that’s in tight circulation; try blush in Exhibit A for a close match), creating a matte effect that’s “a little sicker and more rock and roll.” Of the two-step application, Carrasquillo said, “It’s an old-school trick that I learned back in the ’80s when they didn’t have matte lipstick. You had to powder the lip to get that texture.”

headline: ‘Narcos’ Season 2, Episode 8: A Grieving Kingpin
abstract: Pablo Escobar is lashing out where he can over his fallen empire, but his resources are dwindling by the day.
lead_paragraph: In my previous recap, I suggested a shift in Pablo Escobar’s behavior from strategic acts of violence to reckless displays of retribution and nihilism. Whatever his savagery, this was a man smart enough to turn a modest smuggling operation into a billion-dollar cocaine business, based heavily on his ability to leverage power and insulate himself from both the authorities and his adversaries. And so it stands to reason that Escobar, in the early months of 1993, the year of his death, would have a clear understanding of just how much power he has left.

headline: Donald Trump and Allies Raised $90 Million in August, Trailing Hillary Clinton
abstract: The fund-raising matched Mr. Trump’s pace from earlier in the summer but left Mrs. Clinton with a commanding advantage in cash on hand.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump raised $90 million in conjunction with his party in August, according to totals released by his campaign on Thursday, keeping pace with his efforts earlier in the summer but lagging far behind Hillary Clinton.

headline: Those Who Defended Roger Ailes, and Those Who Now Regret It (Geraldo Rivera, Greta Van Susteren)
keywords: ['Sexual Harassment', 'News and News Media', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: In a long Facebook post, Mr. Rivera recanted his defense of Roger Ailes. Here is a guide to those who rushed to defend Mr. Ailes before Fox settled the claims against him.
lead_paragraph: In a long Facebook post, Mr. Rivera recanted his defense of Roger Ailes. Here is a guide to those who rushed to defend Mr. Ailes before Fox settled the claims against him.

headline: Wells Fargo Fined $185 Million for Fraudulently Opening Accounts
abstract: Federal banking regulators say that the bank issued unauthorized credit cards and charged late fees on accounts created by bank employees but not authorized by customers.
lead_paragraph: For years, Wells Fargo employees secretly issued credit cards without a customer’s consent. They created fake email accounts to sign up customers for online banking services. They set up sham accounts that customers learned about only after they started accumulating fees.

headline: Creatures of the Wind: Spring 2017
abstract: Spring looks from Shane Gabier and Christopher Peters.
lead_paragraph: Spring looks from Shane Gabier and Christopher Peters.

headline: Man Arrested in Holland Tunnel Guns Case Is Freed on Bail
abstract: John Cramsey, who said he was on an antidrug mission when he was pulled over by the police in June, is facing felony weapons charges.
lead_paragraph: The Pennsylvania man who was arrested at the  Holland Tunnel in June after the police said they found a cache of weapons in his truck was released on bail from a New Jersey jail on Thursday.

headline: Developers of Pier 55 in Manhattan Win a Round in Court
keywords: ['Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The New York State Appellate Division rejected arguments against the project, handing a victory to the media mogul Barry Diller and the Hudson River Park Trust.
lead_paragraph: Barry Diller and the Hudson River Park Trust won another legal battle in their quest to build a cultural park on a new undulating pier on the Hudson River when the state’s Appellate Division on Thursday rejected arguments against the $200 million project.

headline: Veterans as Props on NBC’s Commander-in-Chief Forum
abstract: A veteran who attended the forum left feeling that veterans were not given their voice as promised.
lead_paragraph: Veterans are familiar with being used as props. Parades, V.I.P. tours and various public functions often require service members to line up, fill seats and keep our mouths shut. Unfortunately, the NBC/MSNBC commander-in-chief forum hosted by Matt Lauer on Wednesday evening felt the same way. It was a well-intended gesture that failed to give veterans their voice as promised.

headline: Review: ‘The Apostate’ Chronicles a Rebellious Catholic
abstract: Federico Veiroj’s wry comedy-drama portrays a frustrated young man who sets out on a quixotic mission to have his baptism records expunged.
lead_paragraph: The Uruguayan director Federico Veiroj’s leisurely comedy-drama “The Apostate” has its charms, though the story (and its hero) could benefit from a tarter approach. The title character is Gonzalo (Álvaro Ogalla), a disheveled 30-something perennial student and layabout in Madrid, who — believing that the Roman Catholic Church has imposed values on him that have sabotaged his life — is determined to have his baptism expunged from church records. Though his mother is mortified, Gonzalo meets priests (including one seemingly incapable of removing his arm from Gonzalo’s) to press his demands, only to encounter a wall of obfuscation.

headline: Review: ‘Come What May,’ an Ode to French Villagers Displaced by War
abstract: Christian Carion’s event-packed World War II film lines up an impressive cast but leans toward the sentimental and schematic.
lead_paragraph: The French film director Christian Carion, whose Oscar-nominated audience pleaser, “Joyeux Noël,” depicted a heartwarming temporary détente between World War I combatants, opens his latest film with a few words of historical context. He follows those with a dedication to his mother, who was among many citizens in northern France who were displaced by the German invasion of May 1940. “Come What May” grafts a suspense narrative involving multinational characters to a story of genial rural folk compelled to flee their homes before they’re overrun by bloodthirsty trespassers.

headline: ‘Rolling Coal’ Is a Crime
abstract: A reader asks, “Who would be so senseless as to treat polluting as a sport?”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Lady Chablis, Sassy Eccentric in ‘Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil,’ Dies at 59
abstract: Ms. Chablis was a standout character in the book and movie that introduced the world to Savannah, Ga., and the sometimes unconventional people who live there.
lead_paragraph: The Lady Chablis, the transgender performer featured in the 1994 best seller “Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil” and in the film version, died on Thursday in Savannah, Ga. She was 59 and had been working until about a month ago.

headline: What Muslims Do on Hajj, and Why
abstract: Our correspondent, who is in Saudi Arabia for the annual pilgrimage, explains why Muslims, dressed in white, throw stones, kiss a large black rock and have a goat sacrificed.
lead_paragraph: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia — It is incumbent upon every able-bodied Muslim who can afford to do so to travel to Mecca, Saudi Arabia, Islam’s holiest site, at least once in his or her lifetime. The annual pilgrimage is known as the hajj, and it is one of the five pillars of Islam, prescribed in the Quran:

headline: My Hajj Reading List: Preparing for Mecca
abstract: Our correspondent shares her reading list before embarking on the annual Muslim pilgrimage to Saudi Arabia.
lead_paragraph: Starting Saturday, about two million Muslims will participate in the hajj, an annual pilgrimage to holy sites in Saudi Arabia. I’ll be participating for the first time, and to prepare, I assembled an eclectic reading list including Islamic history, firsthand accounts of the hajj and spiritual meditations.

headline: Farewell to Armstrong
abstract: Our city’s nod to tennis as big business came in a noisy, charmless mingling of steel and concrete. But we still loved the place.
lead_paragraph: While broadcasting the final United States Open match in Louis Armstrong Stadium on Tuesday afternoon, the ever cool and chatty Pam Shriver took an emotional timeout. In that moment, it occurred to her that, more than most, she could appreciate what had once been America’s grand — albeit gritty — tennis palace.
