headline: Review: In ‘Landfill Harmonic,’ One Person’s Trash Is a Child’s Violin
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Music', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Movies']
abstract: This documentary focuses on a Paraguayan landfill that became the wellspring for a children’s orchestra, which uses instruments assembled from discards.
lead_paragraph: The story behind “Landfill Harmonic” is so good that even some imperfect filmmaking can’t hold it back.

headline: Glenn Beck’s Empathy
abstract: A reader praises Mr. Beck’s call for understanding and reconciliation to heal social and racial divides.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Packed Restaurant. Screaming Kid. Oblivious Mommy. What Now?
abstract: The Urban Avenger tries to bring peace and quiet to dinner in New York, but it’s no easy task.
lead_paragraph: My friend Herb and I were having dinner the other night at our hangout, the Knickerbocker, when we were cruelly reminded of the overpopulation problem.

headline: Review: In ‘Other People,’ a Son’s Anxieties Mount as Tragedy Looms
abstract: A deeply personal tale from the writer-director Chris Kelly, the movie follows a gay comedy writer in New York who returns home to care for his mother.
lead_paragraph: In “Other People,” David (Jesse Plemons), a gay comedy writer in New York scrambling for a big break, returns to Sacramento to help care for his mother, Joanne (Molly Shannon), who has cancer. That means moving back into a conservative, religious home, and living again with a family from whom he’s been estranged. His two younger sisters are supportive, but his father, Norman (Bradley Whitford), has never accepted David’s sexuality — though Norman says he’s always ready to “have that debate.” Joanne at least acknowledges that she behaved badly when David first came out 10 years earlier.

headline: Hillary Clinton, Donald Trump and the Military
abstract: Readers discuss a forum on national security, endorsements from military figures and Donald Trump’s plan to increase defense spending.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: ‘Starving the Beast’ Traces the Burdens of Higher Education Defunding
abstract: This documentary by Steve Mims describes an ideological war over public higher education that is being conducted state by state.
lead_paragraph: Academics used to joke that campus politics were so vicious because the stakes were so small. That’s no longer the case, at least where the stakes are concerned, as “Starving the Beast” makes clear.

headline: Review: Sully Landed the Plane. Then He Had to Endure the Spotlight.
abstract: “Sully,” Clint Eastwood’s film about US Airways Flight 1549, largely involves what happens after he, his crew and his passengers are plucked from the Hudson.
lead_paragraph: Clint Eastwood’s latest movie, “Sully,” is about a man who is excellent at his job. Specifically, it tells the story of Capt. Chesley Sullenberger and how, on a frigid January afternoon in 2009, he came to land a plane on the Hudson River. The movie is economical and solid, and generally low-key when it’s not freaking you out. That it unnerves you as much as it does may seem surprising, given that going in, we know how this story ends. But Mr. Eastwood is also very good at his job, a talent that gives the movie its tension along with an autobiographical sheen.

headline: With No Edge on the Economy, Clinton and Trump Focus Elsewhere
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Economy', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: While voters tell pollsters that the economy is their most important concern, the candidates are focusing on other issues, like changing demographics.
lead_paragraph: This year, it’s not the economy. And actually, there’s nothing stupid about that.

headline: Isabelle Dinoire, Recipient of First Partial Facial Transplant, Dies at 49
abstract: Her 2005 operation paved the way for dozens of other patients to receive this complicated surgery.
lead_paragraph: Isabelle Dinoire, the Frenchwoman who in 2005 received the world’s first partial facial transplant, paving the way for dozens of other patients to receive this complicated surgery, has died. She was 49.

headline: Your Car’s New Software Is Ready. Update Now?
abstract: Automakers are taking advantage of connected cars by beaming improved features right into their vehicles via software upgrades.
lead_paragraph: TIRED of your vehicle and its aging, limited features? Don’t trade it in just yet. Download new software instead.

headline: My Son Seems Happy at College. But Is He?
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Children and Childhood', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Social Q’s: The “Back to School” edition. On homesickness, bare feet and a dating quandary.
lead_paragraph: My husband and I have one son, who started college last month. We’re both surprised that he has come home every weekend since school began. He takes a two-hour train ride home on Friday, and we drive him back on Sunday night. He seems to be pretty happy at school, if a little withholding on the details. But as Sunday progresses, and especially during the drive back to campus, he seems really down. My husband thinks this is a routine case of homesickness, and we should let it play out. But I want to talk with our son on the next Sunday drive. Any thoughts?

headline: Review: ‘Transpecos’: At a Dusty Border, a Trek Along a Moral Tightrope
abstract: Greg Kwedar’s first feature focuses on three United States Border Patrol agents at a desolate desert outpost.
lead_paragraph: Accomplishing a lot with very little, Greg Kwedar compresses his first feature, “Transpecos,” into a single day and night at a remote outpost in the Chihuahuan Desert, where three United States Border Patrol agents will face tough choices.

headline: Rashid Johnson’s “Fly Away”
abstract: Inside the artist’s new show at Hauser & Wirth, including paintings, sculptures and a plant-based installation with a live pianist embedded in it.
lead_paragraph: Inside the artist’s new show at Hauser & Wirth, including paintings, sculptures and a plant-based installation with a live pianist embedded in it.

headline: A Giant Art Installation With 250 Plants — and Live Jazz
abstract: Rashid Johnson’s much-anticipated new show incorporates a giant sculpture created with greenery, lights, video — and a pianist performing inside.
lead_paragraph: On the Friday before Labor Day, the New York-based artist Rashid Johnson was shooting hoops outside the city and talking about his new show at Hauser & Wirth that comprises 14 new pieces, including a monumental sculpture installation that integrates a live piano performance. Music has always been an inspiration for Johnson, who first made art-world waves when three of his large-scale photographic portraits were included in Thelma Golden’s landmark 2001 “Freestyle” exhibition at the Studio Museum in Harlem. And it’s often been physically represented in his practice: Album covers have prominently figured into his installations in the past. But the live audio element of the upcoming Hauser & Wirth show — one of the New York art season’s most anticipated, named “Fly Away” after the gospel hymn — is a first for the artist.

headline: Black Lives Matter Benefit Is Canceled Over Stand on Israel
abstract: The owners of the club have canceled a concert, citing a platform of groups affiliated with Black Lives Matter that calls Israel “an apartheid state.”
lead_paragraph: A popular Broadway cabaret club has canceled a concert benefiting Black Lives Matter, citing the movement’s criticism of Israel.

headline: Gary Perweiler’s Commercial Photos, Reimagined as Fine Art
abstract: The photographer spent the ’70s, ’80s and ’90s creating crisp, vivid images for commercial clients. For a new show, his son has recontextualized them.
lead_paragraph: The photographer spent the ’70s, ’80s and ’90s creating crisp, vivid images for commercial clients. For a new show, his son has recontextualized them.

headline: The Second Life of One Photographer’s Ad Images
abstract: In a new show, Alex Perweiler resurrects — and newly contextualizes — images his father took for advertising clients in the ’70s, ’80s and ’90s.
lead_paragraph: All of the photos in Gary Perweiler’s upcoming show, “Commercial Archive (Transparencies),” were originally shot for commercial clients in the ’70s, ’80s and ’90s. Today, the images have been resurrected by the photographer’s son, Alex Perweiler, who designed and directed the exhibition with his father. “For several years,” Alex explains, “I’d been thinking a lot about what would happen if these images were rerouted outside the space they were created for, advertising. I have always felt that his images were so artfully designed, produced and in many cases made statements that went far beyond anything he was thinking about in the short period of time he had to get an image done for a client.” Displayed for the first time in a gallery setting, the large archive has been beautifully brought back to life after many decades in the dark. The crispness and tonality of Gary’s work in the exhibition marks it as belonging to another, much simpler era of photography — but there’s a freshness and nostalgia to the images that register as current and purposeful.

headline: Review: In ‘The Wild Life,’ Island Critters School a Castaway
abstract: This animated film, long on amiability if not complexity, features amusing animal characters learning to collaborate with a shipwrecked Crusoe.
lead_paragraph: Long after our screening of the animated feature “The Wild Life,” my almost-10-year-old companion was still chatting about the film’s amusing animal characters. And judging from the sounds emitted during that screening, I suspect that younger children in the audience liked it even more.

headline: Missouri Woman Is Miss America Pageant’s First Openly Lesbian Contestant
abstract: “It took many years of struggle to figure out who I was,” Erin O’Flaherty, Miss Missouri, has said.
lead_paragraph: Erin O’Flaherty, one of the contestants in this weekend’s Miss America pageant, wants fans to know a few things about her: She was raised on a farm; she is a trained livestock judge; and she supports suicide-prevention programs.

headline: ‘Super PAC’ Backing Hillary Clinton Pulls In Largest Fund-Raising Haul Yet
abstract: Priorities USA Action raised $21.6 million in August, in the wake of the parties’ nominating conventions, leaving it with $41.4 million in cash on hand.
lead_paragraph: The main “super PAC” supporting Hillary Clinton raised $21.6 million in August, a sum that officials for the group said was its largest monthly haul in its history.

headline: Donald Trump’s Remarks Show He’s Mistaken on Sexual Assault in Military
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Sex Crimes', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Women and Girls', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: In defending his suggestion that the integration of women led to assaults, Mr. Trump exposed a faulty understanding of a complex issue and of the military justice system.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Sexual assault in the military has plagued the Pentagon in recent years as a series of high-profile cases, and new data, revealed the extent of the problem. In response, President Obama and members of Congress demanded that military officials more aggressively address the threat and its causes.

headline: Between ‘Transparent’ Seasons, Judith Light Isn’t Playing Nice
abstract: The actress will return to the stage in Neil LaBute’s “All the Ways to Say I Love You.”
lead_paragraph: Judith Light is enjoying the kind of career she deserves. In other words, at 67, she gets to work as much as she likes, she gets an early crack at quality roles, she is nominated for awards (and wins some) in each medium she tackles, and she is “beloved wherever she goes.” (That last remark comes from Jill Soloway, the creator of the breakthrough Amazon series “Transparent,” for which Ms. Light is up for an Emmy.)

headline: Danny DeVito Will Make Broadway Debut in ‘The Price’
abstract: Roundabout Theater Company will present this revival of an Arthur Miller play, co-starring John Turturro, Tony Shalhoub and Jessica Hecht.
lead_paragraph: For Danny DeVito, “The Price” is right.

headline: New Push for Taiwan’s Representation at the United Nations
abstract: Michael Tsai of the Taiwan United Nations Alliance discusses efforts to win the island’s full membership in the world body, a notion anathema to Beijing.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The 71st session of the United Nations General Assembly opens on Tuesday, and 45 members of the Taiwan United Nations Alliance are heading to New York and other cities in the United States, including Washington, Boston and Philadelphia, to make the case for Taiwan’s representation in the world body.

headline: G.E. Spent Years Cleaning Up the Hudson. Was It Enough?
keywords: ['PCB (Polychlorinated Biphenyls)', 'Water Pollution', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances']
abstract: The New York State Department of Environmental Conservation is pushing to reopen the issue of whether General Electric’s efforts to remove PCBs from the water have succeeded.
lead_paragraph: FORT EDWARD, N.Y. — Ask Matthew Traver, the mayor of this village north of Albany, his opinion of General Electric and its two closed factories that spilled PCBs into the Hudson River for decades, and his words could not be clearer.

headline: Private Equity Tries to Chip Away at Dodd-Frank With House Bill
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Private Equity', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The House is expected to pass a bill that will loosen the information that the industry must report to regulators about the nature of its investments.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of the 2008 financial crisis, private equity suffered a rare setback on Capitol Hill.

headline: U.S. Rescue Attempt in Afghanistan Missed Western Hostages by Hours
abstract: Navy SEALs led the unsuccessful raid to free an American professor and his Australian colleague from the Taliban last month, engaging in a fierce gunfight.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Navy SEALs led an unsuccessful raid last month to free an American university professor and his Australian colleague who are being held by the Taliban, engaging in a fierce gun battle with dozens of insurgents at a remote compound in the mountains of eastern Afghanistan, American officials said Thursday.

headline: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
abstract: Art in review, from Times critics.
lead_paragraph: Ubu Gallery 416 East 59th Street, Manhattan Through Sept. 30

headline: Mystery Surrounds Car With Gas Containers Found in Paris Near Notre Dame
abstract: The car did not contain detonators, but the police have arrested four people — all suspected of being Islamist extremists — in connection with the case.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It was an ominous discovery, especially for a city so recently scarred by large-scale terrorism: A car full of gas cylinders, parked in the heart of Paris near Notre Dame Cathedral.

headline: Theater Listings for Sept. 9-15
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.

headline: Review: In This One-Man Opera, It’s All in His Head
abstract: With “The Loser,” David Lang has devised an unconventional staging for his opera adaptation of Thomas Bernhard’s 1983 novel.
lead_paragraph: Intriguing ambiguity permeates every element of David Lang’s “The Loser,” a mysterious 60-minute chamber opera. Or is it an austerely staged concert work? Or an in-your-face monologue for baritone?

headline: Art and Words Are Inseparable in the Sackner Collection
abstract: More than 400 pieces from the Sackner Archive will go to the Pérez Art Museum Miami.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Ruth and Marvin Sackner of Miami collected language-based artworks — typewriter art, artist books, micrography, sound and performance poetry, mail art and experimental calligraphy — amassing what now could be the largest private collection of its kind in the world, the Sackner Archive of Concrete and Visual Poetry.

headline: Review: 5 Murdered Prostitutes and an Anxious City in ‘London Road’
abstract: A spate of real-life murders in England in 2006 forms the basis of this film directed by Rufus Norris.
lead_paragraph: An ungainly yet strangely captivating oddity, “London Road” snags your attention from the get-go in the manner of any razor-edge experiment: By making you wonder, what on earth? As soon as that question is answered, however, you’re hooked, and this unconventional examination of the ripple effect of real-life killings on a quiet English town has worked its curious magic.

headline: Review: ‘For the Love of Spock,’ a Son’s Tribute to Leonard Nimoy
abstract: Adam Nimoy’s documentary about his father nimbly straddles biography and “Star Trek” valentine, but also recounts the fraught but devoted ties between father and son.
lead_paragraph: At the outset of his documentary “For the Love of Spock,” the director Adam Nimoy (son of Leonard Nimoy) imparts its origins. He intended to examine his father’s “Star Trek” character, Mr. Spock, and his place in culture for that franchise’s 50th anniversary. But in February 2015, Leonard Nimoy died, and the project became more of a tribute to his life. This film nimbly straddles biography and “Trek” valentine (Adam is a longtime television director), but also recounts the fraught if ultimately devoted ties between Adam and Leonard.

headline: Review: In ‘Ithaca,’ Meg Ryan and Tom Hanks Reunite for a War Story
abstract: In this adaptation of William Saroyan’s “The Human Comedy,” a young bicycle messenger delivers telegrams to families during the tumultuous World War II years.
lead_paragraph: “Ithaca,” Meg Ryan’s directorial debut, is a quiet, bittersweet adaptation of the William Saroyan novel “The Human Comedy,” a story about a 14-year-old named Homer who delivers telegrams in the small town of the film’s title. It’s 1942, so many of those telegrams contain the worst possible news for the families of soldiers.

headline: Digital Troves, Providing Insights and Reuniting Antiquities
abstract: Databases are shedding light on the ancient rulers as well as the Europeans and Americans who dug at historic sites.
lead_paragraph: While documenting material looted in recent decades, databases of Middle Eastern archaeological artifacts are also shedding light on the lives of ancient rulers and poets as well as the Europeans and Americans who dug at historic sites nearly a century ago.

headline: Metal Gates Unfurl as Colorful Canvases on the Lower East Side
abstract: Artists have been adding splashes of color to the neighborhood, painting security barriers through the 100 Gates Project. (Katz’s Delicatessen is the lucky 100th.)
lead_paragraph: A small crowd amassed recently at the corner of East Houston and Ludlow Streets, with people squinting in the evening sun, snapping photographs and maneuvering for the best angle. The center of attention was the street artist L’Amour Supreme, who was complementing the brick-and-red-neon exterior of Katz’s Delicatessen with shades of aqua, gleaming pink and gravel gray.

headline: Off the Runway: Day 1
abstract: Scenes from the first day of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the first day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: A Pâtisserie Gets Another Chance
abstract: Unlike many mom-and-pop shops in SoHo, Once Upon a Tart was resurrected and much of its beloved character (and even its recipes) remains.
lead_paragraph: Unlike many mom-and-pop shops in SoHo, Once Upon a Tart was resurrected and much of its beloved character (and even its recipes) remains.

headline: Once Upon a Tart, Reborn in SoHo
abstract: The French bakery reopened under different ownership in 2014, and though there were several changes, the recipes for the shop’s famous scones, muffins and tarts were not altered.
lead_paragraph: There’s a part of SoHo that’s still home to townhouses and small independent shops, apart from the glossy multinational chains for which the Manhattan neighborhood is known. But the sad story of the mom-and-pop store closing and being supplanted by a branch of some corporate retailer isn’t particular to SoHo.

headline: Always Something Unnerving in Paul Outerbridge Photographs
abstract: The peculiar career of this acclaimed avant-garde artist is well-served by a museum-caliber retrospective at Bruce Silverstein Gallery.
lead_paragraph: Paul Outerbridge (1896-1958) was a master of photographic desire, a shape-shifting orchestrator of Apollonian light and Dionysian shadow. His strange career is well served by a beautiful, museum-caliber retrospective at the Bruce Silverstein Gallery in Chelsea.

headline: You Remember John Aubrey. Chased by Debt Collectors, Chaser of Whores.
abstract: One of England’s best-loved 17th-century writers didn’t leave a diary. With “John Aubrey: My Own Life,” the historian Ruth Scurr has fixed that.
lead_paragraph: The English biographer, naturalist, philosopher and convivial wit John Aubrey (1626-97) did not leave a diary behind, to the dismay of those who admire his writing about other people. In an ingenious new book titled “John Aubrey: My Own Life,” the historian Ruth Scurr has made one for him, and it is a thoroughgoing delight.

headline: Review: ‘Brother Nature’: Fish Out of Water With the Future In-Laws
abstract: Taran Killam and Bobby Moynihan of “Saturday Night Live” are among the cast in an unfunny comedy set in the woods.
lead_paragraph: Every new generation has to learn the lesson: Comedy success on the small screen doesn’t guarantee the same on the big screen. If anything, it guarantees the opposite.

headline: 73 Syrian Aid Groups Suspend Cooperation with U.N.
abstract: The groups said the United Nations had been manipulated by the government so that civilians in opposition-held areas get little or no help.
lead_paragraph: Seventy-three Syrian aid groups suspended their cooperation with the United Nations on Thursday, accusing the world body of complacency in the face of what they called manipulation by the government to deny help to people in opposition-held areas.

headline: Suzanne Koller’s “Red Lips, Attitudes and Other Obsessions.”
abstract: The super-stylist has collected the fruits of 20 years of work in a new book.
lead_paragraph: The super-stylist has collected the fruits of 20 years of work in a new book.

headline: Classic Pictures From a Stylist’s 20 Years in Fashion
abstract: “Red Lips, Attitudes and Other Obsessions,” a collection of images from Suzanne Koller’s two-decade-long career, is out this week.
lead_paragraph: “Attitude: that’s the first thing I notice about a woman, more than something physical or the clothes,” says Suzanne Koller, the Austrian-born fashion director of French Vogue and the co-founder of the revered biannual fashion magazine Self Service. It’s a philosophy reflected in the title of her first monograph, out this week: “Red Lips, Attitudes and Other Obsessions.”

headline: Gary Johnson, Donald Trump, Wells Fargo: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Review: In ‘Cameraperson,’ a Found Poem Filtered Through an Intent Eye
abstract: Kirsten Johnson’s riveting documentary flits from Bosnia to Darfur to ground zero and zigzags across time, prompting reflection on the nature of her art.
lead_paragraph: “Cameraperson,” Kirsten Johnson’s transfixing documentary, defies easy summary. It’s unlike anything you’ve seen before, although if you remember films like Kirby Dick and Amy Ziering Kofman’s “Derrida”  or Whitney Dow and Marco Williams’s “Two Towns of Jasper,” some of the images may be familiar. Ms. Johnson worked as a cinematographer on those documentaries and dozens of others, but the footage she shares here doesn’t come from the finished films. It includes outtakes, offhand moments, snatches of time when the camera just happened to be running. “These are the images that marked me,” she says in an introductory note, and she has woven them together into a unique and affecting memoir.

headline: The Limits of Lauer
abstract: The “Today” co-anchor’s questioning of Hillary Clinton said more about him than about the candidate.
lead_paragraph: When Hillary Clinton took the seat for her interview with NBC’s Matt Lauer at the Commander-in-Chief Forum that was broadcast on the network Wednesday night, she smiled warmly at the “Today” show co-anchor. “I’m happy you’re doing this,” she said. Even before the first question of substance came up, she most likely felt otherwise. Certainly, by the end of the program, everyone else did.

headline: Zao Wou-Ki, an Abstract Fusion Master
abstract: “Zao Wou-Ki: No Limits” at Asia Society is the first comprehensive show of the artist’s work, which radiate energy and hypnotic power, in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The painter Zao Wou-Ki (1920-2013) is by now one of the best-known Chinese painters of the 20th century. It helped that he lived in Paris from 1948 on and that his gestural abstractions, which drew on Eastern and Western sources, enjoyed great success in Europe and the United States. By 1952 he had had solo shows in Paris and New York and went on to be collected by many museums on both continents. In New York he exhibited in the late 1950s and ’60s at Samuel Kootz’s gallery, an Abstract Expressionist stalwart.

headline: Review: ‘Author: The JT Leroy Story’ Renders a Literary Charlatan
abstract: Jeff Feuerzeig’s documentary charts the invention of an underage H.I.V.-positive hustler, and how the famous and nonfamous were taken in until the hoax was exposed.
lead_paragraph: It’s sometimes said that forgers of old-master paintings are accomplished artists in their own right. A successful fraud — even if it’s ultimately uncovered — requires discipline, hard work and talent, and it’s hard not to feel at least a grudging respect for charlatans who fool the public and especially the experts. We don’t call them con artists for nothing.

headline: Review: In ‘As I Open My Eyes,’ Feeling a Revolution Coming
abstract: A headstrong singer comes of age on the eve of Tunisia’s Jasmine Revolution.
lead_paragraph: “I see those deprived of work, of food, of life outside the neighborhood,” sings Farah (Baya Medhaffar), a fiery 18-year-old Tunisian singer who lights up Leyla Bouzid’s film “As I Open My Eyes.”

headline: Review: ‘Quarry’ Puts Death to Great Music. Very Slowly.
abstract: This eight-episode thriller coming to Cinemax sets a grim Vietnam-era tale in a soulful Memphis.
lead_paragraph: With “Quarry,” an eight-episode hard-boiled thriller beginning Friday night, Cinemax boards the mystery train once again. Following “Banshee” (crime in small-town Pennsylvania) and “Outcast” (horror in rural West Virginia), “Quarry” is another exercise in lurid pulp storytelling and sweaty regional flavor. It’s not as much fun as either of those earlier shows — it’s too slow and solemn, and its obligatory touches of baroque weirdness lack conviction. But the carefully maintained 1970s setting, a few good performances and a soundtrack full of Memphis soul at least partly redeem it.

headline: Comedy Listings for Sept. 9-15
abstract: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.

headline: Review: In ‘Demon,’ Wedding Jitters From the Uninvited Dead
abstract: A modern ghost story haunted by the Holocaust, this film by the Polish director Marcin Wrona reconceptualizes the Jewish mythology of the dybbuk.
lead_paragraph: “Demon,” a modern ghost story haunted by the Holocaust, opens with an arrival and closes with a departure. These scenes, each set on a raft gliding on a deceptively tranquil country river, bookend a movie that raises light shivers by tapping into historical memory and employing some satisfying, bluntly old-fashioned screen magic. The movie’s visual style, narrative ellipses and weighty subject make it ready-made for the art house even if its mystical flourishes — an otherworldly claw, an undead bride — are the sort of woo-woo pleasures more often scared up in genre stories.

headline: Review: In ‘Kicks,’ the Promise (and Perils) of Those Air Jordans
abstract: This debut feature depicts a 15-year-old in a tough neighborhood who buys the shoes of his dreams — and the desperation he feels when they are taken from him.
lead_paragraph: Teenage life in the East Bay neighborhood of Richmond, the setting of Justin Tipping’s promising debut feature film, “Kicks,” is so rough that it’s little wonder that the movie’s 15-year-old protagonist, Brandon (Jahking Guillory), fantasizes that he is watched over by an imaginary spaceman. Because Brandon is small for his age and has delicate features, he is a natural target for bullies. Lacking the macho swagger of his peers, he is not a romantic magnet for the girls who throw themselves at his friends. He dwells in an anxious limbo where the harsh realities of big-city life coincide with a childlike longing for a magical escape.

headline: 9 Great Books to Start Off September
abstract: New books recommended by the editors of The New York Times Book Review this week.
lead_paragraph: The fall book season is finally upon us, and I don’t know about you, but I couldn’t possibly escape the summer heat or election onslaught fast enough. And luckily, the books out now provide their own welcome respite. This week, we at the Book Review are particularly excited about three new works of fiction, five excellent new nonfiction books and . . . a play.

headline: Charlotte Moorman, Tradition Disrupter, Is the Focus of Two Shows
abstract: This artist, a foundational 20th-century art figure and embracer of the avant-garde, is re-revealed to the public in twin exhibitions at New York University.
lead_paragraph: “Think Crazy” is sound advice for today’s artists, faced with cookie cutter training and art fair sclerosis. And the phrase did once have some practical application. It was emblazoned, like a logo, across a banner at one of the New York Avant Garde Festivals that took place annually in the city between 1963 and 1980, rounding up feral fringe talent from around the world and letting it loose in places like Grand Central Terminal, Shea Stadium and the Staten Island Ferry.

headline: Review: ‘Defying the Nazis’: An American Couple on a Rescue Mission
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: Ken Burns and Artemis Joukowsky’s documentary tells of Waitstill and Martha Sharp, who traveled to Czechoslovakia in 1939 to help Jews and others flee persecution.
lead_paragraph: “Defying the Nazis: The Sharps’ War” is a generic documentary about two people who were anything but. Yet even when the film wanes, its subjects still come across as remarkable.

headline: Movie Listings for Sept. 9-15
abstract: A guide to movies playing at theaters in the New York City area, as well as select festivals and film series.
lead_paragraph: Read reviews of new releases and search our full database of thousands of films at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.

headline: Classical Music Listings for Sept. 9-15
abstract: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area.

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for Sept. 9-15
abstract: A selected guide to concerts in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to concerts in the New York City area.

headline: Review: Have You Heard the One About the Grieving Daughter?
abstract: The comedian Tig Notaro stars in Amazon’s tender-funny “One Mississippi,” in which a loss brings a troubled family together.
lead_paragraph: It’s been said that comedy is tragedy plus time. Lately, it’s been more like tragedy minus a half-hour.

headline: Go Fish! Festival Casts a Wide Net for Young New Yorkers
abstract: Children can drop a line in the Hudson River, look upward to learn about birds and make a musical instrument at the Go Fish! festival in Lower Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Even if you’ve never baited a hook or cast a line, you’re bound to catch something at the Go Fish! festival on Saturday in Battery Park City: rousing American roots music, glimpses of migrating songbirds and intriguing sculptures, a chance to make art.

headline: An Emerging Jewelry Designer Meets Her Match
abstract: Wing Yau of the young brand WWAKE will launch a sister collection, CLOSER, at tonight’s Phelan show.
lead_paragraph: The jewelry designer Wing Yau of WWAKE has been following the designer Amanda Phelan’s work for the past year, from the time that Phelan — a fellow RISD alum — launched her eponymous women’s wear brand. “Her clothing is about the texture, and creating something unexpected but with a sophisticated silhouette, which I can relate to,” Yau says. “It’s refreshing, after everyone has become so obsessed with basics.” Earlier this summer, she emailed Phelan about CLOSER by WWAKE, her line of sculptural accessories that she had sidelined after her finer, jewel-encrusted pieces took off in 2013.

headline: Millions of Blank Pennies Block Highway
abstract: A truck bound for the Philadelphia Mint overturned Thursday morning, spilling around eight million coins that were to become pennies onto the interstate in Delaware. The driver escaped with minor injuries.
lead_paragraph: A truck bound for the Philadelphia Mint overturned Thursday morning, spilling around eight million coins that were to become pennies onto the interstate in Delaware. The driver escaped with minor injuries.

headline: U.S. Ends Corruption Case Against Former Virginia Governor
keywords: ['Gifts to Public Officials', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: The Justice Department said Thursday that it would cease its prosecution of Bob McDonnell and his wife, Maureen.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department said Thursday that it would abandon its case against Robert McDonnell, a former governor of Virginia, whose career was upended by a corruption conviction that the United States Supreme Court overturned in June.

headline: Jazz Listings for Sept. 9-15
abstract: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.

headline: Dance Listings for Sept. 9-15
abstract: A selected guide to dance performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to dance performances in New York City.

headline: 45,000 Pounds of Would-Be Pennies Coat Highway After Delaware Crash
abstract: A tractor-trailer crashed on Interstate 95, spilling eight million blank pennies. It took 13 hours to reopen the highway.
lead_paragraph: It looked like free money all over the highway. But even the most opportunistic of motorists likely passed by without taking any.

headline: Museum & Gallery Listings for Sept. 9-15
abstract: A critical guide to exhibitions and installations in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: A critical guide to exhibitions and installations in the New York area.

headline: Around Town for Sept. 9-15
abstract: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.

headline: New York City to Help Fund Internships at Cultural Organizations
abstract: The Department of Cultural Affairs has launched an initiative to place CUNY students at paid internships at Carnegie Hall and other institutions.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Department of Cultural Affairs is beginning an initiative to improve diversity at major New York cultural institutions by financing paid internships at those organizations. The $1 million initiative, half financed by the city and the other half by the Rockefeller Foundation, will place City University of New York students as interns at places like Carnegie Hall, MoMA PS1 and the Museum of Natural History.

headline: Spare Times for Children Listings for Sept. 9-15
abstract: A select guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: A select guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families.

headline: Regulators Seek Tighter Curbs on Investments by Big Banks
keywords: ['Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Commodities', 'Private Equity', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The rules would prohibit banks from buying and selling commodities and would require them to close what’s left of their in-house private equity operations.
lead_paragraph: Regulators are seeking to impose further restrictions on the ability of Wall Street banks to make risky investments with their own money.

headline: New Hampshire - 2016 Election Forecast
abstract: Forecast for New Hampshire's 4 electoral votes in the presidential election and for its Senate seat.
lead_paragraph: Forecast for New Hampshire's 4 electoral votes in the presidential election and for its Senate seat.

headline: The Osiris-Rex Spacecraft Begins Chasing an Asteroid
abstract: The craft is set to return to Earth in seven years with bits of a nearby asteroid that would give scientists a window on some of the material that made up the early solar system.
lead_paragraph: NASA’s mission to grab pieces of an asteroid and bring them back to Earth took off on Thursday night.

headline: Clinton-Trump Presidential Forum Draws 15 Million Viewers, and Many Critics
abstract: While Matt Lauer, the NBC “Today” show host, drew pointed criticism for his performance, Nielsen said the event beat many of the primary debates.
lead_paragraph: NBC’s prime-time presidential forum on Wednesday with Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump drew nearly 15 million viewers, beating many of the debates held during the primary season, according to Nielsen statistics.

headline: North Carolina Men Arrested in Hacking Into C.I.A. Director’s Email
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'E-Mail', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense']
abstract: The two men are accused of working with a group that calls itself Crackas With Attitude and has targeted U.S. government and other law enforcement officials.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two North Carolina men were arrested on Thursday in the hacking of the personal email accounts of the director of the Central Intelligence Agency and other senior officials.

headline: Mont Blanc Cable Car Passengers Are Stranded Aloft Overnight in French Alps
abstract: Helicopters rescued dozens of people at 12,500 feet in the Mont Blanc massif near Chamonix after the cars came to a halt.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Thirty-three passengers were stranded overnight on Thursday in high-altitude cable cars in the French Alps after helicopters were used to rescue 65 others who had been trapped, officials said.

headline: Donald Trump Releases Education Proposal, Promoting School Choice
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Education', 'For-Profit Schools', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Education (K-12)', 'Minorities']
abstract: Mr. Trump on Thursday promised to direct $20 billion in federal grants for poor children to attend a school of their family’s choice.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Continuing his efforts to attract minority voters, Donald J. Trump visited an inner-city charter school on Thursday, where he promised to direct $20 billion in federal grants for poor children to attend a school of their family’s choice.

headline: Rehearsing With a Rockette
abstract: Signing on to perform a choral piece at Lincoln Center, an amateur singer learns she is a second alto and when it comes to choreography, there is a ringer in the group.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: House Republicans Who Favor Immigration Overhaul Face Potential Losses
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: Running in competitive districts and struggling to distance themselves from Donald J. Trump, several overhaul supporters could lose, leaving a party less willing to negotiate.
lead_paragraph: NORTHBROOK, Ill. — Representative Robert J. Dold, Republican of Illinois, is eager to work with Democrats to change the nation’s immigration laws, despite Donald J. Trump’s signature proposal to build a border wall and deport immigrants who are in the country illegally.

headline: Hedge Fund and Cybersecurity Firm Team Up to Short-Sell Device Maker
abstract: MedSec and the Muddy Waters hedge fund joined to expose a potential security vulnerability with St. Jude’s pacemakers.
lead_paragraph: The cybersecurity firm behind a short-seller’s campaign against St. Jude Medical, a major manufacturer of pacemakers, has a curious operating history.

headline: An Afghan Father-Son Tale Takes a Fatal Turn, but Does Not End
abstract: Abdul Basir and his son Said Muhammad were sworn enemies until they made peace last month, but the story of their fight against the Taliban has been called into question.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — When Abdul Basir, an Afghan government militia commander, and his son Said Muhammad, who had been a Taliban fighter, made peace last month after several attempts to kill each other, it was clear their story would not end there.

headline: Sam Iacobellis, Whose B-1 Bomber Recast the Cold War, Dies at 87
abstract: His development and lightning delivery of 100 stealth bombers to President Reagan in the 1980s was credited with speeding the Soviet Union’s collapse.
lead_paragraph: Sam Iacobellis, an engineer whose development and lightning delivery of 100 B-1 supersonic stealth bombers to President Ronald Reagan in the 1980s was credited with speeding the collapse of the Soviet Union, died on Saturday in San Luis Obispo, Calif. He was 87.

headline: John R. Coleman, Haverford President Who Explored Blue-Collar Life, Dies at 95
abstract: A labor economist, he was a strong voice at the Philadelphia-area college in the 1960s for the admission of women and against the Vietnam War.
lead_paragraph: John R. Coleman, a labor economist who as president of Haverford College in Pennsylvania became a national folk hero when, on sabbatical leave, he took a series of low-wage jobs and wrote about the experience in his book “Blue-Collar Journal,” died on Tuesday in Washington. He was 95.

headline: Serena Williams Loses Bid for 23rd Major and Her No. 1 Ranking
abstract: Williams lost to Karolina Pliskova and second-ranked Angelique Kerber will ascend to the top spot. Williams also remains tied with Steffi Graf with 22 major titles in the Open era.
lead_paragraph: The semifinal stage of the United States Open was the unexpected departure point for Serena Williams last year, a surprisingly early exit in her quest for the Grand Slam.

headline: Trump’s Love for Putin: a Presidential Role Model
abstract: Donald J. Trump emphasized in his NBC interview that he did not necessarily endorse the political system Mr. Putin has erected, but respected the way Mr. Putin is perceived.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — What is striking about Donald J. Trump’s latest effusion of admiration for Russia’s stony-faced leader, Vladimir V. Putin, is how similar it is to the way Mr. Putin is portrayed in Russia: as a necessary foil for an aggressive and flawed American leadership.

headline: Justice Dept. Granted Immunity to Specialist Who Deleted Hillary Clinton’s Emails
keywords: ['E-Mail', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Republicans have called for the department to investigate the deletions, but the deal with the specialist, Paul Combetta, makes it unlikely that the request will go far.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A computer specialist who deleted Hillary Clinton’s emails despite orders from Congress to preserve them was given immunity by the Justice Department during its investigation into her personal email account, according to a law enforcement official and others briefed on the investigation.

headline: A False Conviction Is Overturned, but the System That Allowed It Remains
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Prosecutorial Misconduct', 'Legal Profession']
abstract: Proof of Wayne Martin’s innocence was buried during his 2010 murder trial. On Wednesday, the Brooklyn district attorney moved to dismiss all charges.
lead_paragraph: Here is the case of a missing paragraph that turned into a trap door that dropped a man into prison.

headline: Adam Selman: Spring 2017
abstract: Rihanna’s longtime collaborator shows his spring 2017 collection.
lead_paragraph: Rihanna’s longtime collaborator shows his spring 2017 collection.

headline: More Pitchers and Fewer Innings as Teams Battle Injuries
abstract: Expanded rosters always bring a new batch of pitchers, but teams are finding it harder than ever to shepherd a staff through the grind of 162 games.
lead_paragraph: Nathan Eovaldi stood by his locker at Yankee Stadium the other day, all dressed up with nowhere to pitch. Eovaldi, the Yankees right-hander, was in full uniform for the official team photograph but will not pitch for the rest of this season, or next. He underwent his second Tommy John operation last month.

headline: Nora York, Singer Who Fused Forms, Dies at 60
abstract: A performance artist as well, Ms. York layered philosophy, poetry, politics and song when she appeared before an audience.
lead_paragraph: Nora York, a singer and performer who intrigued audiences with bold mashups of jazz, rock and other genres, died on Sept. 3 at her home in Manhattan. She was 60.

headline: North Korea Tests a Mightier Nuclear Bomb, Raising Tension
keywords: ['Nuclear Tests', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'International Relations']
abstract: The test, South Korean officials said, produced a more powerful explosive yield than the North’s previous detonations.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea conducted its fifth underground nuclear test on Friday, its government said, despite threats of more sanctions from the United States and the United Nations. The latest test, according to South Korean officials, produced a more powerful explosive yield than the North’s previous detonations, indicating that the country was making progress in its efforts to build a functional nuclear warhead.

lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Sully,” “Author: The JT Leroy Story” and “Kicks.”

lead_paragraph: Gaël Monfils, a fan of the N.B.A. and the United States, was talking about what LeBron James means to him.

headline: An F-Minus for America’s Schools From a Fed-Up Judge
abstract: A decision that threw out Connecticut’s education financing system as unconstitutional spoke to a larger nationwide truth.
lead_paragraph: When a Connecticut judge threw out the state’s school financing system as unconstitutional this week, his unsparing 90-page ruling read and resonated like a cry from the heart on the failings of American public education.

headline: A Debate Disaster Waiting to Happen
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans', 'Debates (Political)', 'United States International Relations', 'Editorials']
abstract: Moderators at future presidential debates must do a better job of holding the candidates accountable.
lead_paragraph: There was not much of a contest in Wednesday night’s forum with Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump. Mrs. Clinton answered the questions of the moderator, Matt Lauer, in coherent sentences, often with specific details. Mr. Trump alternated between rambling statements and grandiose boasts when he wasn’t lying.

headline: Late to the Fight Against Predator Schools
keywords: ['For-Profit Schools', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Student Loans', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Editorials']
abstract: Regulators need to act sooner in cases where students are victimized by for-profit colleges.
lead_paragraph: The federal government’s failure over decades to regulate for-profit colleges freed the schools to prey on veterans, minorities and the poor by saddling students with crushing debt and giving them worthless degrees in return. This is all the more outrageous because the schools rely on the federal student aid system for virtually all of their revenue.

headline: Searching for Oneself
abstract: Kristian House shows me what I don’t know.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — I believe it was just yesterday that I was telling you how much my solving skills had improved since I started writing Wordplay and, because the one of the secrets to an interesting life is balance, Kristian House offers a puzzle that solved for me like it should have been called “All the Things Deb Didn’t Know She Knew Until She Filled Them In.”

headline: Review: In ‘Spamilton,’ Broadway’s Savior Meets His Match. It’s Not Burr.
abstract: This spoof from Gerard Alessandrini, the creator of “Forbidden Broadway,” takes aim at “Hamilton” and its place in the battlefield of musicals.
lead_paragraph: Though the juggernaut musical “Hamilton” is bursting with facts and figures from the American Revolution, there’s a whole other, less obvious history that underlies its every performance. No, I am not hinting at the existence of coded conspiracy messages involving the Illuminati. (But apparently, if you play the song “The Reynolds Pamphlet” backward. …)

headline: F.A.A. ‘Strongly Advises’ Against Using Samsung Galaxy Note 7 Aboard Planes
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Defective Products', 'Batteries', 'Smartphones', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Lithium (Metal)']

lead_paragraph: The Federal Aviation Administration is “strongly” advising passengers onboard planes not to use Galaxy Note 7 cellphones by Samsung, which is recalling 2.5 million of the models after discovering a flaw in the battery cell that could result in fires.

headline: Hillary Clinton Emphasizes Importance of Faith to Black Audience
abstract: The Democratic nominee also portrayed Donald J. Trump, without mentioning him by name, as a nihilist who doesn’t understand African-Americans or their faith.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Hillary Clinton quoted biblical scripture. She talked about her youth minister who took her from the safe harbor of suburbia to the inner city of Chicago, and she shared the memory of seeing her gruff father bent on his knees in prayer each night.

headline: Broncos Rally Past Panthers in Season-Opening Rematch of Super Bowl 50
abstract: The young quarterback Trevor Siemian, who has taken over Denver’s reins from Peyton Manning, helped his team overcome a 17-7 second-half deficit.
lead_paragraph: In the first half of the N.F.L.’s season opener between the Carolina Panthers and the Denver Broncos on Thursday night, Cam Newton seemed to be a man on a mission to redeem himself for his failures in last season’s Super Bowl. But the second half was a reminder of just how good the reigning Super Bowl champion Broncos can be, as they charged back from a 17-7 deficit to beat the Panthers, 21-20, after a 50-yard field-goal attempt by Graham Gano sailed wide left in the closing seconds.

abstract: How did British Vogue beat its American counterpart to the Rihanna cover? And other revelations from a documentary about Britain’s glossiest magazine.

Cutler’s 2009 documentary about Anna Wintour and life at Vogue, and “Franca: Chaos and Creation,” Francesco Carrozzini’s new film about Franca Sozzani, the editor of Italian Vogue, increasingly it seems the answer is no.

headline: The Partisan Winds Aimed at Kansas’ Court
keywords: ['Supreme Courts (State)', 'Elections, Courts and the Judiciary', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Education (K-12)', 'Editorials']
abstract: A Republican campaign to vote out four state Supreme Court judges who have displeased party members threatens the independence of the judiciary.
lead_paragraph: Kansas Republicans have started a campaign to purge a majority of judges from the State Supreme Court. That move has rightly prompted opposition from four former governors — two Republicans and two Democrats — who say that a fair and independent judiciary is under threat on the November ballot.

headline: The Conscience of the Contrarian Voter
abstract: In a normal year, an independent or a Democrat could vote for Gary Johnson and feel O.K. about it. But not this year.
lead_paragraph: I met Gary Johnson, the somewhat-surging Libertarian Party candidate for president, years ago in one of those beautiful Western settings full of mostly awful people at the time — that is, lobbyists and various sycophants who attach themselves to any gathering of power.

headline: Time for a Realignment
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Voting and Voters', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: By 2031 you may well have switched political parties.
lead_paragraph: There’s a good chance many of you will be switching political parties over the next 15 years. You may be a corporate executive who’s voted rock-solid Republican for decades, but you may be a consistent Democrat by 2024. You may be an African-American community activist in Cleveland, but don’t be surprised if you someday call the Republican Party home.

headline: What Trump Doesn’t Understand About the Military
keywords: ['Veterans', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The Republican candidate has veterans’ support, but insults our service.
lead_paragraph: I doubt that many of us veterans had high expectations for the candidates’ forum on national security on Wednesday. Our country has essentially been at war now for 15 years, yet fewer of our would-be leaders have real ties to the military.

headline: Convincing My Cuban Mom to Vote for Hillary
abstract: Brave is the daughter who tries to persuade her Cuban mother to vote for a Clinton.
lead_paragraph: Lincoln, Neb. — The Cuban-American vote in Florida is a coveted demographic. I used to be part of this vote, but a recent out-of-state move means I’ve spent this week watching the campaigns work their way there from afar. I’m playing a different role this election. I’m an unofficial get-out-the-vote advocate for a dozen or so very disenchanted Cuban-American voters, the two of most immediate concern being my parents.

headline: Donald Trump’s ‘Big Liar’ Technique
abstract: He thinks he won’t get caught.
lead_paragraph: Long ago, you-know-who suggested that propagandists should apply the “big lie” technique: make their falsehoods so huge, so egregious, that they would be widely accepted because nobody would believe they were lying on that grand a scale. And the technique has worked well for despots and would-be despots ever since.

headline: Payback in Guadalajara
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Hoaxes and Pranks', 'Orphans and Orphanages', 'Children and Childhood', 'Down Syndrome']
abstract: Growing up in a Mexican orphanage, where nothing was fair and revenge was bittersweet.
lead_paragraph: When I was 8, my parents split up. My father took up with another woman and had a completely different family. Who wants the old family around when there is a new one? But it turned out that my little sister, Velia, and I couldn’t stay with our mother either, because she hit us. So a social worker sent us to El Instituto Cabañas, a home for children in Guadalajara.

headline: How to Track an Animal
abstract: Catching is not the point. Keep looking.
lead_paragraph: “Once you’re following a track, you don’t know where you’re going to end up, which is part of the fun of it,” says Paul Rezendes, who has written two books about animal tracking. One to two inches of new snow make for optimal conditions; in deeper snow, animal footprints may appear as indistinguishable holes. Sandy or muddy substrates like riverbanks hold prints, too, but don’t bother with forest floors blanketed in leaves or pine needles. “If you have a nice fresh snow, you can track an animal all day, come back the next day and pick up where you left off,” Rezendes says. Snow can help prevent your getting lost too, by allowing you to trace your own imprints back to your starting point.

headline: Hillary’s First 100 Days
abstract: A speculative political fiction by the showrunner of “Veep.”
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton took the oath of office as the 45th president of the United States on Friday, Jan. 20, 2017, after defeating the thousandaire Donald J. Trump in the previous November’s election. Since F.D.R., the first 100 days have come to be seen as the defining moment of each presidency and are used to measure each new president’s accomplishments. Below are the highlights of President Clinton’s first 100 days as recorded near the end of her second term, in 2024, by her official biographer, and recovered from a deleted email in 2025.

headline: Where to Live? Ask an App
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Mobile Applications', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: New apps and online tools use a combination of big data and smart algorithms to help buyers and renters find their ideal neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: Searching for an apartment online has long been limited to plugging in what you can afford and where you think you might want to live and then sifting through dozens of listings. But what if you don’t have a neighborhood in mind? In a city as large as New York, there are probably neighborhoods you’ve never heard of. And even a place you think you know can change character within just a few blocks.

headline: How to Read a Bar
abstract: There’s never a wrong drink, but there’s probably a better one.
lead_paragraph: Recently, a new customer asked me to make him a strong, gin-based cocktail. That sounded like a martini, but he demurred. I then suggested a highball; that didn’t cut it, either. “Take a look around,” I said. Most people were drinking beer and shots. I love making cocktails, I told him, but this was a pub, with certain constraints. For garnishes, we have lemons, limes, olives and cherries. We’ve got one kind of bitters. We infuse nothing.

Williams, 57, along with Dixon Long (her co-author on “Markets of Paris”), explores an often-overlooked reason to visit: the abundance of markets.

headline: A Berlin Bar That Embraces Natural Wines
abstract: At Wild Things, in Neukölln, the natural wine list is the focus, but the vibe and food are equally successful.
lead_paragraph: Just inside the entrance of Wild Things, a new wine bar in the Neukölln neighborhood of Berlin, looms a makeshift basketball hoop, into which customers can shoot discarded corks. Its bottom is sealed — so that customers don’t get bonked — making it more of a cork basket. Precaution aside, the boozy spin on the American sport is an example of the bar’s playful attitude, one also reflected in both its funky selection of wines and a menu that features fresh ingredients and some twists.

headline: At New York Fashion Week, Just Swipe Left
abstract: Thakoon and Creatures of the Wind are thinking small screen.

headline: What Should a Cubs Fan Pay to Realize a Lifelong Dream?
keywords: ['World Series', 'Ticket Scalping', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Personal Finances', 'Baseball']
abstract: For the chance to see their team in the World Series for the first time in 71 years, some fans are prepared to dig deep, and others may get creative.
lead_paragraph: Setting a budget for a ticket to see the Chicago Cubs play a World Series game in Wrigley Field is a complex and, arguably, dangerous exercise. But many fans would admit that they are running the numbers in their head a lot these days, and their calculations offer plenty of lessons for people who have no interest in baseball.

headline: We Need ‘Somebody Spectacular’: Views From Trump Country
keywords: ['Coal', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Unemployment', 'Mines and Mining', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Appalachian voters know perfectly well the candidate is dangerous. But they’re desperate for change.
lead_paragraph: Paris, Ky. — After Bill Bissett, the president of the Kentucky Coal Association, told me that “President Obama cares more about Paris, France, than he does about Paris, Kentucky” — a sentiment that seems broadly shared around here — I decided to check out this little town with a big name set amid the verdant undulations of picket-fenced Kentucky horse country. Soon enough I ran into Cindy Hedges, whose boot store stands on Main Street and whose hours, as described by a sign on the door, are: “If I’m here, I’m here. If I ain’t, I ain’t.”

headline: Gazing While Male
abstract: What once seemed shocking may now be seen as normal, and what seemed pernicious — the male gaze — can sometimes turn out to just be someone looking and trying to see.
lead_paragraph: In the ’60s, the artist Tom Wesselmann was as famous as his contemporaries Andy Warhol, Roy Lichtenstein, James Rosenquist and Robert Indiana. His work then fell from favor in part because some critics took umbrage at what they felt was his objectification of the female form. Indeed, Wesselmann’s work incorporates big, bright Pop iconography of lady parts, like breasts and lips and suntanned bikini lines.

headline: California Today: Is This the End for Movies?
abstract: Welcome to California Today, a morning update on the stories that matter to Californians (and anyone else interested in the state).
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: 1916: Doctor Loses Finger to X-rays
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Dr. Maxime Menard at Cochin hospital in Paris loses a finger due to X-rays in September 1916.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Maxime Menard, chief radiographer at the Cochin Hospital in Paris, is a victim of his devotion to the wounded, having just had the index finger of his left hand amputated as a result of the ravages caused by the X-rays. In 1914, several weeks before the war, he sacrificed the index finger of his right hand in the same way, but despite this he continued his splendid work, and has now again fallen a victim to the mysterious rays.

headline: ‘Blair Witch’: Shaky Cams That Left Audiences Shaking
abstract: As an updated version of “The Blair Witch Project” comes to theaters, the directors of the original film recall the impact it had on horror movies.
lead_paragraph: When “Blair Witch” opens in theaters on Friday, Sept. 16, it will probably play to a crowd of moviegoers who were barely walking when the first  film, “The Blair Witch Project,” now a found-footage classic, was released in 1999. That’s fine with the directors of the original film, Daniel Myrick and Eduardo Sánchez; they have given the update their blessing and are credited as executive producers. “Enough time has passed where the new one can be embraced on its own merits,” Mr. Myrick said. “A whole bunch of young horror fans want to see a new ‘Blair Witch’ they can call their own.”

lead_paragraph: It’s happening slowly, and there are still rough edges. But building by building, Hudson Yards is finally taking shape.

headline: ‘Narcos’ Season 2, Episode 9: Stumbling Toward the Finish Line
abstract: Here we are, in the second to last episode of Escobar’s story, almost literally stuck in the mud.
lead_paragraph: The trouble with adapting biographies or historical events into a fictional narrative is that real life doesn’t unfold in a neat three-act structure — it lurches and wheezes through bursts of activity and stretches where little of consequence happens and it doesn’t usually end how a dramatist would prefer to write it. Over two seasons of “Narcos,” the rise and fall of Pablo Escobar has been documented in a heady rush of information, so much that Murphy’s ubiquitous voice-over has been necessary to cram it all in there. And that’s been a primary strength of the show: The scope of Escobar’s empire and the multifront effort to dismantle it isn’t easy to encapsulate in any medium. If any story could be said to benefit from meat-and-potatoes artlessness, it’s Escobar’s.

headline: 3 Former Tesco Executives Charged With Fraud Over Accounting Scandal
abstract: The charges stem from a criminal investigation dating to 2014, when the British supermarket giant announced it had overstated profits.
lead_paragraph: Three former Tesco executives have been charged with fraud in connection with an accounting scandal that rocked the British supermarket giant two years ago, investigators said on Friday.

headline: Facebook Restores Iconic Vietnam War Photo It Censored for Nudity
abstract: The social network was criticized for removing the image of a naked girl fleeing napalm, renewing questions about the company’s role in what can be published online.
lead_paragraph: The image is iconic: A naked, 9-year-old girl fleeing napalm bombs during the Vietnam War, tears streaming down her face. The picture from 1972, which went on to win the Pulitzer Prize for spot news photography, has since been used countless times to illustrate the horrors of modern warfare.

headline: Magritte Jigsaw Puzzle: Another Piece Found
abstract: A third section of “La Pose Enchantée,” which until 2013 was thought to have been destroyed, has been found concealed under a painting in Norwich, in England.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Only one quarter to go. The third section of “La Pose Enchantée,” a missing painting by René Magritte, has been discovered under another painting by this surrealist artist in the Norwich Castle Museum collection in Britain. This comes three years after two sections were found in Stockholm and New York.

headline: Just Another Night at the Adam Selman Funhouse
abstract: The audience was a wild mix of pop and art-house types. The collection, unexpectedly, seemed more pulled together than the crowd might have suggested.
lead_paragraph: There’s a raucousness to Adam Selman’s shows that feels vital. The crowds are the types who go wild. In the house on Thursday night, the Cobrasnake (alias the photographer Mark Hunter) was snapping away as if 2006 had never left us. The art-house types (there’s Casey Spooner) mixed with the Top 40 types (there’s the sultry R&B popette Tinashe). Mr. Selman, with his Castro-clone mustache and Texas Baptist manners, brings them all to the party.

headline: 1966: Gemini-11 Leak Delays Flight
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: A fuel leak delays the liftoff of Gemini-11 in September 1966.
lead_paragraph: Cape Kennedy, Fla — Gemini-11’s space flight was postponed for 24 hours early today [Sept. 9] when a fuel tank in a launch rocket developed a pinhole leak a few hours before liftoff. Space officials said the leak in the Titan-2 rocket which was to have launched astronauts Charles Conrad and Richard Gordon on a three-day flight was small but necessitated the defueling of the rocket. Technicians later repaired the hole, which was in a spot-weld about halfway up the 109-foot rocket. After checks, officials rescheduled the flight for tomorrow [Sept. 10] morning.

headline: ‘It Finally Clicked That This Wasn’t an Exercise’: Report Recounts San Bernardino Shooting
abstract: A previously undisclosed report chronicles in vivid detail the shootout that killed Syed Rizwan Farook and Tashfeen Malik, the actions of the police and the massacre itself.
lead_paragraph: The two masked killers burst through a door and, without saying a word, swept the conference room with semiautomatic rifle fire, spraying more than 100 rounds before they fled, just two or three minutes later.

headline: The Story Behind This Week’s Best Sellers
abstract: Tom Wolfe, whose new book about the evolution of language is No. 14 on the hardcover nonfiction list, says picking fights is “a lot better than not being noticed at all.”
lead_paragraph: Everybody’s Talking: In some ways, it makes perfect sense that Tom Wolfe would write a book about the evolution of language. Over the past half-century, after all, Wolfe’s own work has contributed mightily to the evolution of a certain kind of language — or the evolution of a style, anyway: the neon-lit, whiz-bang exploding cigar of a sentence, bristling with exclamation points and packed tighter than a spring-loaded snake in a can of peanuts. As a founder of New Journalism in the 1960s and the author of sprawling social novels beginning with “The Bonfire of the Vanities,” in 1987, Wolfe has cast a big shadow on generations of American writers. But it turns out mere influence isn’t what he has in mind with “The Kingdom of Speech,” new on the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 14. Instead, Wolfe trains his sights on biological evolution — specifically, Darwin’s theory of natural selection — and what he sees as its inadequacy to account for the existence of human language. Along the way, he also attacks the neo-Darwinian linguist Noam Chomsky, who has advanced the idea of language as an innate evolutionary trait.

A prime-time series on a major network about “us”? It’s occasion for excitement, and for reflection. What, exactly, do we who live in the “Speechless” universe hope this series will accomplish?

headline: Images of Ground Zero, Transformed by Sandy’s Waters
abstract: Michael Redpath, a lieutenant in the Fire Department, spent six months documenting the cleanup at the World Trade Center site after the Sept. 11 attacks. Then a hurricane found his negatives.
lead_paragraph: Michael Redpath had just started surfing near his home in Breezy Point, on the Rockaway Peninsula, when he looked up and saw smoke billowing up from Lower Manhattan. That was the end of his surfing that day, 15 years ago. A lieutenant in the Fire Department now, he was a firefighter in Ladder Company 169 then. By the time he got to the World Trade Center, both towers were down, and the area looked “like a nuclear winter,” he said, with “totally empty streets, white dust covering everything.” The next day he learned how many of his compatriots died.

lead_paragraph: BILL PRICE was a founder of TPG, one of the world’s largest private equity firms, and was involved in large deals, including buying Continental Airlines and J. Crew. He also invested in Beringer Vineyards and Chateau St. Jean, two California wineries.

headline: The Depression Radically Changed the Way Americans Ate
abstract: “A Square Meal,” by Jane Ziegelman and Andrew Coe, is an engaging, moving history of how the Depression changed the way Americans thought about food.
lead_paragraph: A SQUARE MEALA Culinary History of the Great DepressionBy Jane Ziegelman and Andrew CoeIllustrated. 314 pp. Harper/HarperCollins Publishers. $26.99.

headline: Jon Ronson Reviews a New Book About Bad Digital Behavior
abstract: Why for many of us does our behavior change while in the digital world? Mary Aiken’s “The Cyber Effect” considers the possibilities.
lead_paragraph: THE CYBER EFFECTA Pioneering Cyberpsychologist Explains How Human Behavior Changes OnlineBy Mary Aiken387 pp. Spiegel & Grau. $28.

headline: Hepatitis A Outbreak Linked to Strawberries at Smoothie Chain
abstract: About 89 people have been sickened, many of them customers of Tropical Smoothie Cafe outlets in Maryland, North Carolina, Virginia or West Virginia.
lead_paragraph: An outbreak of hepatitis A linked to strawberries at a smoothie chain has sickened 89 people from seven states, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Thursday.

headline: With Wearable Tech Deals, New Player Data Is Up for Grabs
keywords: ['Wearable Computing', 'Athletics and Sports', 'Football (College)', 'Sporting Goods and Equipment', 'Privacy', 'College Athletics', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: A new, $170 million deal could allow Nike to harvest personal data from Michigan athletes through wearable tech, raising concerns over privacy and who should control such information.
lead_paragraph: The University of Michigan football team took the field for its season opener on Sept. 3 accompanied by Michael Jordan, the team’s honorary captain for the game, in uniforms bearing his signature Jumpman logo. Such pageantry is the fruit of a new apparel contract, worth about $170 million, between the university and Nike.

headline: Arm Wrestling’s Popularity Goes Over the Top
abstract: A New York firefighter’s success shows that the sport, once a barroom pastime, has turned into big business.
lead_paragraph: The arm regarded by many as the strongest in New York measures 39 inches from neck to wrist, with biceps the circumference of a football and skin spray-tanned to a similar leathery brown. Even in repose, its snaky veins swell to the surface, masked only by a tangle of tattoos. Six days a week, the arm spends two hours in the gym, sculpting itself to perfection. It can curl 100-pound dumbbells with ease. It requires specialized tailoring. It has saved lives.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to recent reviews of Marjorie Ingall’s “Mamaleh Knows Best,” Ben Lerner’s “The Hatred of Poetry” and more.
lead_paragraph: ‘Mamaleh Knows Best’

headline: Оружие Современного Террора: Как “Калашников” и AR-15 стали оружием выбора массовых убийц
abstract: Оружие, ставшее символом агрессии, позволяет кучке бандитов убивать многих а устрашать гораздо больше людей, и бороться на равных с современными военными и полицейскими силами.
lead_paragraph: Это повторяется снова и снова. Стрелок одиночка, или небольшая группа вооруженных людей, совершают чудовищные преступления, которые приковывают внимание всего мира.

abstract: Seven new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: Seven new paperbacks to check out this week.

headline: A Little Nagging Can Help Reduce Credit Card Debt
abstract: A study found that some simple rules about using credit led some consumers to carry less credit card debt.
lead_paragraph: While no one likes to be nagged, a bit of prodding — with periodic emails or online messages — can help consumers reduce their credit card debt, a new study has found.

headline: Norbert Schemansky, Who Won Weight-Lifting Gold but Little Applause Back Home, Dies at 92
abstract: In competition largely outside the sports world spotlight, he awed crowds and was the first to win medals in four Olympics but felt unappreciated in his hometown.
lead_paragraph: Norbert Schemansky, one of the world’s greatest weight lifters and the first to win medals in four Olympic Games, all while scraping to make a living in a hometown, Dearborn, Mich., that more than 60 years ago greeted his achievements with a shrug, died on Tuesday at his home there. He was 92.

headline: 2 New Faces for Staatsballett Berlin, When Nacho Duato Leaves in 2019
abstract: The choreographer Sasha Waltz and the Royal Swedish Ballet director, Johannes Ohman, will become joint artistic directors of the troupe in 2019.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer Sasha Waltz and the Royal Swedish Ballet director, Johannes Ohman, will become the joint artistic directors of the Staatsballett Berlin when its current director, Nacho Duato, comes to the end of his contract in 2019. The announcement, made on Wednesday by Michael Müller, the mayor of Berlin, comes just two years after Mr. Duato took over from Vladimir Malakhov.

lead_paragraph: Ten questions about the news of Sept. 6-12, 2016

lead_paragraph: New picture books include “Captain Jack and the Pirates” and “The Pirate Jamboree.”

headline: Mike Pence Has G.O.P. Candidates’ Respect. Just to Be Safe, They Keep Him at a Distance.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Elections, Senate', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']
abstract: The tentative reception given the Republican vice-presidential candidate is not because of Mr. Pence, strictly speaking, but instead the man on top of the ticket.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana has so far played the role of Donald J. Trump’s translator to conservatives, character witness to evangelical Christians, and clarifier in chief, issuing explanatory statements after Mr. Trump has committed a variety of unforced political errors.

headline: The Lure of the Fish Cake
abstract: Made with fresh cod, bread crumbs and green herbs, these fish cakes are lighter than the typical.
lead_paragraph: There are myriad types of fish cakes, and it’s hard not to love them all.

headline: Reliably Red Ohio County Finds Both Trump and Clinton Hard to Stomach
abstract: Many residents of Delaware County, which last voted for a Democratic president in 1916, simply cannot imagine voting for either candidate.
lead_paragraph: DELAWARE, Ohio — Donald J. Trump is not popular in this prospering county north of Columbus. The Republican nominee’s dystopian language does not resonate here. Signs that read “Now Hiring” outnumber “Trump” campaign placards.

headline: Downside of Bitcoin: A Ledger That Can’t Be Corrected
abstract: The financial services industry needs to face the question of how to balance the appeal of pristine accounting with the demands of the real world.
lead_paragraph: There has been much discussion about the potential of blockchain, the technology underlying virtual currencies like Bitcoin, to change the world. We have heard waves of inspired commentary on how the technology, with its ability to share information and record transactions, will be as revolutionary as the internet itself. At Accenture, we agree about these huge possibilities, but there is an elephant in the room that will need to be confronted.

headline: Privatizing Drones
abstract: A reader asks if this will mean less information disclosed to the public about the details of such operations.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Show Jumping and Celebrity Spotting in the Hamptons; Wall Streeters Host 9/11 Memorial Dinner
abstract: Last week’s top galas included the Hampton Classic Grand Prix, and the 9/11 Memorial Dinner at Cipriani Wall Street.
lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg hosted his annual 9/11 Memorial Dinner, a benefit for the National September 11 Memorial and Museum, on Sept. 7 at Cipriani Wall Street. The event honored Ronald O. Perelman and Michael L. Corbat of Citigroup, and raised $3 million. The Hampton Classic Grand Prix on Sept. 4 capped off the summer social calendar, featuring world-class show jumping and celebrity spotting on a gorgeous Sunday afternoon.

abstract: “The heart of this small, petty, virulent man lies not in what he has accomplished but what he has failed to accomplish,” a reader says.
