You can listen to this playlist on Spotify here. Like this format? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com.

headline: Molly Shannon Loves You, but Will Not Give You Her Number
abstract: The star of “Other People” visited some old New York haunts: Chelsea Market and 30 Rockefeller Plaza.
lead_paragraph: When Molly Shannon visits New York, one of the few places she goes to is Chelsea Market. She lived across the street from it in the early aughts and in the ’90s while she was a cast member of “Saturday Night Live,” turning out characters like Mary Katherine Gallagher, the awkward Catholic-school girl who wants to be a superstar.

headline: Donald Trump’s Admiration for Vladimir Putin
abstract: Three readers analyze the two men’s praise for each other. Mr. Putin, a former K.G.B. operative, “is playing Donald Trump with flattery,” one suggests.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Suspends Construction on Part of North Dakota Pipeline
keywords: ['Pipelines', 'Native Americans', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The order came after a federal judge’s ruling rejected efforts by the Standing Rock Sioux Tribe to halt construction of the Dakota Access pipeline.
lead_paragraph: BISMARCK, N.D. — The federal government on Friday temporarily blocked construction on part of a North Dakota oil pipeline, an unusual intervention in a prairie battle that has drawn thousands of Native Americans and activists to camp and demonstrate.

headline: Monsanto Whistle-Blower: $22 Million Richer, but Not Satisfied
abstract: The former employee at the agribusiness company said he was still bothered that management was not held accountable for years of accounting violations.
lead_paragraph: Winning isn’t everything.

headline: N.F.L. Says Officials Missed Head Hit on Panthers’ Cam Newton
abstract: The league continues to combat the perception that it is not doing enough to protect players from hits that can lead to head trauma.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. has determined that a penalty should have been called against a Denver Broncos linebacker after his helmet-to-helmet hit against Carolina Panthers quarterback Cam Newton in the third quarter of Thursday night’s game, which opened the football season.

headline: Conviction Thrown Out for Ex-Rutgers Student in Tyler Clementi Case
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Hate Crimes', 'Privacy', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Bullies']
abstract: A New Jersey court called for a new trial for Dharun Ravi, who was convicted in 2012 after spying on his roommate, Mr. Clementi, while he had sex with another man. Mr. Clementi later committed suicide.
lead_paragraph: An appeals court in New Jersey on Friday threw out the conviction of the former roommate of Tyler Clementi, the Rutgers University freshman who killed himself six years ago after he was spied on while having sex with another man.

headline: Hopes Dimming for a Woman to Lead the United Nations
abstract: More women than ever entered the race to be the next secretary general. But informal polls of the Security Council suggest members are leaning to men.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Britain has Theresa May. Chile has Michelle Bachelet. In the United States, Hillary Clinton this year became the first woman to clinch a major party nomination for president.

headline: What Should You Choose: Time or Money?
abstract: If you picked time, chances are, you’re a happier person for it.
lead_paragraph: Given the choice between more time or more money, which would you pick? For a beach vacation, you might pay more for a direct flight to gain a couple of extra hours getting sand between your toes. On the other hand, you might take a better-paying job that requires late nights at the office.

headline: 3 Questions: Designing the Magazine’s ‘High School, U.S.A.’ Issue
abstract: “I tried to set the type in the way I imagine someone who doesn’t set type professionally would.”
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. Below, Chloe Scheffe, the lead designer for Sunday’s special issue of The Times Magazine, reveals what she meant to convey by “manipulating” the section’s print typefaces: “High schoolers are all about ownership.”

headline: How the Novelist Megan Abbott Spends Her Sundays
abstract: “You Will Know Me,” the latest book by Ms. Abbott, is set in the cutthroat world of girls’ gymnastics. Her Sundays are more relaxed than her thriller novels.
lead_paragraph: Megan Abbott’s thrillers are explorations, she says, of “women, power and aggression.” Her latest, “You Will Know Me,” is set in the cutthroat world of girls’ gymnastics and was published this summer, just before the Olympics. A Times review in July said Ms. Abbott had resumed “her customary role of black cat, opaque and unblinking, filling her readers with queasy suspicion at every turn.” She recently completed a cross-country promotional tour for the book, and now Ms. Abbott is back in Forest Hills, Queens, where she lives. During her Sunday writing stints, the author, 45, takes a break from the shadowy side of human nature to step into the light of a neighborhood she loves.

headline: Seriously Committed, and Not Just to Each Other
keywords: ['Weddings and Engagements', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Widows and Widowers']
abstract: Allie Stickney and Dr. Jack Beecham, whose first marriages ended in divorce and whose second spouses died from cancer, connected when they needed each other most.
lead_paragraph: Allie Stickney and Dr. Jack Beecham, whose first marriages ended in divorce and whose second spouses died from cancer, connected when they needed each other most.

headline: A Widow and a Widower Embrace Love After Loss
keywords: ['Marriages', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'ABORTION', "Women's Rights", 'Widows and Widowers', 'Vows (Times Column)']
abstract: Parallel lives, lived in the cause of women’s reproductive rights, finally intersect several marriages and decades later.
lead_paragraph: Readers of this column have no doubt lost count of the many ways people meet and later marry, but few couples can claim the hard-fought battle over women’s reproductive issues as their backdrop.

headline: Jason Wu: Spring 2017
abstract: Mr. Wu, who also designs Hugo Boss women’s wear, presents a show focused on merino wool.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Wu, who also designs Hugo Boss women’s wear, presents a show focused on merino wool.

headline: Shopping Guide: Dining Chairs
abstract: Tips on choosing dining chairs
lead_paragraph: For Benjamin Vandiver, choosing a dining chair is about more than finding a comfortable place to sit during meals. “I approach it as an opportunity for a sculptural moment — probably before comfort,” he said. “Here’s a beautiful opportunity to add an art piece that you might sit in for 45 minutes.”

headline: Manchester Renowned, and Redrawn, by Its Soccer
abstract: Soccer, in the form of Saturday’s City-United match, has done more than consume Manchester, England, this week. It has revived the city itself.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — It is what Gary Neville sees from the roof terrace of his hotel that gives him a sense that something is happening. Not the immediate view to his right of the Sir Alex Ferguson Stand at Old Trafford, with the words “Manchester United” — the club Neville supported, represented and captained — emblazoned in neon red. Neville points, instead, to the view on his distant left.

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: Ev Williams
abstract: The Twitter co-founder shares the titles he would most want with him on a desert island.
lead_paragraph: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is Ev Williams, the co-founder of Twitter and the founder of Medium.com, who shares his list exclusively with T.

headline: Minority Youths Mistrust Police. A Brooklyn High School Has a Plan.
abstract: At a transfer school in Coney Island, an elective class aims to bridge the gap between officers and young people from a poor, minority community.
lead_paragraph: On a chilly morning in November, Lt. Donzel Cleare of the New York Police Department stood in front of a classroom at Liberation Diploma Plus High School in Coney Island and asked a simple question: “How many of you guys feel that I work for you?”

headline: In East Williamsburg, an Architect Updates the Streets of His Youth
abstract: Anthony Morena opts for designs like a zinc shingle facade that recalls the neighborhood’s vinyl exteriors.
lead_paragraph: Unlike the brownstones of Park Slope and Cobble Hill, the vinyl-sided rowhouses of North Brooklyn have never quite garnered the admiration of borough tastemakers. If anything, most new developments in North Brooklyn seem to make a point of distinguishing themselves from these structures.

headline: Prosecutors Appeal Overturned Conviction of ‘Making a Murderer’ Subject Brendan Dassey
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Television', 'Web-Original Programming', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: Mr. Dassey, whose case became the focus of a Netflix series, will remain in prison pending the outcome.
lead_paragraph: Brendan Dassey, the Wisconsin man whose murder conviction was questioned on the popular “Making a Murderer” documentary series on Netflix, will have to spend at least a little more time in prison.

headline: Review: Signs of Rebirth at New York City Opera
abstract: The company’s season opening, a double bill of the seldom-heard “Aleko” and enduringly popular “Pagliacci,” is a milestone in its comeback.
lead_paragraph: Is New York City Opera, which went under in 2013, finally back in business? Last January, the reorganized company, under its general director, Michael Capasso, made a tentative comeback with an uneven production of Puccini’s “Tosca.” June brought a colorful production of Daniel Catán’s maudlin “Florencia en el Amazonas.”

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Amanda Hess, Damon Darlin and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']

lead_paragraph: Sara Bareilles, the Grammy and Tony-nominated singer-songwriter, lives in a two-bedroom rental in Lower Manhattan.

headline: Sara Bareilles, of ‘Waitress,’ on Her Sanctuary in the City
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Music', 'Theater']
abstract: Sara Bareilles, the Grammy and Tony-nominated singer-songwriter, lives in a two-bedroom rental in Lower Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: When the singer-songwriter Sara Bareilles came to New York from her native California in 2013 and rented what she described as “a really sweet one-bedroom” in the West Village, who knew — certainly not Ms. Bareilles — that she’d soon be crooning a love song to the city?

headline: Review of the San Bernardino Terrorist Attack
abstract: The Police Foundation, with help from the Justice Department, examined the law enforcement and emergency response to the mass shooting in San Bernardino, Calif., on Dec. 2, 2015. The report shows how officers handled the crisis.
lead_paragraph: The Police Foundation, with help from the Justice Department, examined the law enforcement and emergency response to the mass shooting in San Bernardino, Calif., on Dec. 2, 2015. The report shows how officers handled the crisis.

headline: The Curious Case of Susan Estrich
abstract: The legal scholar puzzles feminists with her staunch defense of her onetime political opponent Roger Ailes.
lead_paragraph: Susan Estrich is known for being first.

headline: At Jason Wu, Bright Red Lips Fit for a Rave
abstract: For spring/summer 2017, the makeup artist Yadim created an energized beauty look to complement the designer’s athletic collection.
lead_paragraph: The Olympics might be over, but a certain athletic, body-in-motion mentality ruled backstage at Jason Wu’s spring/summer 2017 show this afternoon. The makeup artist Yadim, dressed in high-tops and a baseball cap, created an energized, high-performance red-orange lip color that channeled the graceful sportswear vibe of Wu’s collection. “In the past, we’ve done a blood red, but because of the sportiness and youth of the clothes this season, I wanted to make a rave red,” he said. “It’s a bit brighter, it’s a bit more shocking, almost like a neon red.”

headline: Kevin Amato Casts New York Fashion Week
abstract: The photographer documents his time casting several shows — and shares his images exclusively with T.
lead_paragraph: The photographer documents his time casting several shows — and shares his images exclusively with T.

headline: What It’s Like to Cast a Fashion Week Show
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Books and Literature', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: Kevin Amato, who releases a new book of his photography this week, takes T behind the scenes of his street casting for several runway shows.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Amato is something of a multihyphenate: He casts several fashion week shows — including, this season, VFiles, Band of Outsiders and Kith — and this week has released a new book of photography, “The Importants,” featuring over 200 images culled from his years spent taking pictures. Amato focuses on “street casting,” picking models he finds on the street — or, increasingly, on Instagram — who typically don’t conform to the traditional look of models in the industry. Amato also runs his own Instagram talent agency. This season, he held an open casting call for the VFiles show, which attracted hundreds of young hopefuls (including one who made the trip up from Florida). Amato captured his process of scouting for the show, as well as late-night pizza, exclusively for T.

headline: Giulio Regeni, Italian Student, Was Under Investigation in Egypt Before His Death
abstract: Prosecutors acknowledged for the first time on Friday that Mr. Regeni had been under investigation before he disappeared. Egypt has denied that security officials played a role in his killing.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO, Egypt — Egyptian security officers investigated an Italian graduate student for several days just two weeks before his brutalized body was discovered on the outskirts of Cairo in February, Egypt’s top prosecutor said on Friday, altering the official timeline of events leading up to the man’s disappearance.

headline: A Ballerina Steps Out — as a Choreographer
abstract: For Lauren Lovette, a New York City Ballet principal, "When you do something scary, you get stronger. Always.”
lead_paragraph: On a recent Saturday afternoon, Lauren Lovette surveyed her dancers before sliding into a split — one of her go-to positions when she’s contemplating a step — and rose suddenly to move through a dynamic passage in her new ballet. She calls this part “soft serve.” In it, dancers line up along a diagonal and pirouette away as their arms swirl above their heads like curlicues topping a dip of Dairy Queen. She made some tweaks; her dancers peeled away from the line with more refinement but no less verve.

headline: 9/11 Memorial Concerts, Mostly Low-Key
abstract: New York seems keenly attuned to the 15th anniversary of the terrorist attacks, yet the classical music world is scarcely taking notice.
lead_paragraph: In classical music, birthday celebrations and other anniversary observances sometimes seem strained, even ludicrous, marketing ploys. It is hard to argue with recognitions of round numbers in, say, multiples of 50. But something like Carnegie Hall’s 125th anniversary, which came in May? Borderline. And how does a 15th anniversary stack up against a 10th?

headline: Kerry James Marshall, Boldly Repainting Art History
abstract: Mr. Marshall has always painted only black figures: “If I didn’t do it, how else were they going to be seen?”
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Kerry James Marshall, whose highly anticipated retrospective, “Mastry,” opens Oct. 25 at the Met Breuer, is steeped in classical training more thoroughly than almost any painter of his generation. He’s spent hundreds of hours in figure-drawing classes and anatomical studies, honing techniques developed over centuries by idols like Veronese and Rembrandt, to “get up alongside them on the wall,” as he says.

headline: Turkey Uses Post-Coup Emergency Decree to Purge Mayors and Teachers
keywords: ['Kurds', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Mayors', 'Teachers and School Employees']
abstract: The government said it would take over the administrations of 28 municipalities using powers granted by a state of emergency after the failed military coup on July 15.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The Turkish government said on Friday that it was preparing to take over at least 28 municipal administrations nationwide, ousting elected mayors as part of an intensified crackdown against Kurdish insurgents.

headline: Jason Wu Brings it Home
abstract: Recreating the salon shows of the 1950s prompted the designer’s best work in seasons.
lead_paragraph: “It’s gotten so crazy out there, I just really wanted to bring it home.”

headline: Kelly Osbourne, Suffering for Fashion
abstract: At the Milly show on Friday afternoon, the 90-degree temperature didn’t seem to faze the fashion-obsessed TV star.
lead_paragraph: The temperature in New York reached an uncomfortable 90 degrees on Friday afternoon as guests arrived at Michelle Smith’s Milly show in Chelsea. With her Pomeranian, Polly, in tow, Kelly Osbourne took her seat among a front row that included Candace Cameron Bure, best known for her role as D.J. Tanner on “Full House,” and Johanna Braddy, who stars alongside Priyanka Chopra in the television show “Quantico.”

headline: Critics Are Lining Up to Oppose Changes to Dodd-Frank Law
keywords: ['Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Private Equity', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Opponents said loosening of regulations would exploit investors and threaten retirement savings.
lead_paragraph: Buyout firms are at the forefront of Capitol Hill. They have successfully promoted legislation to roll back regulatory disclosures required under the postcrisis Dodd-Frank legislation, even as they settle cases over misleading investors. If the bill is enacted, however, there is a risk of repercussions.

headline: Review: In ‘Son of Zorn,’ the Dad’s Dense, and Drawn That Way
abstract: The defining gag of this Fox comedy is that the divorced father, Zorn, is an animated He-Man-style warrior, while everyone else in the show is real.
lead_paragraph: There are plenty of jokes in “Son of Zorn.” There’s the one when Zorn’s ex-wife asks if he owns a shirt, and he says, “Does a Gryffian herdsman have nine anuses?” There’s the one when his son tries to convince a predictably chauvinistic Zorn that his new boss is, in fact, a woman, and Zorn replies: “No, son, you’re not listening to me. He’s my superior.”

headline: U.S. Presidential Race, North Dakota, NASA: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: An American Opera Company Adapts China’s ‘War and Peace’
abstract: A San Francisco Opera staging of the novel “Dream of the Red Chamber,” beloved in the Chinese-speaking world, hopes to succeed where similar efforts have struggled.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It was a week before the premiere, and Bright Sheng, the composer and co-librettist of the new opera “Dream of the Red Chamber,” was already bracing for the backlash.

headline: Friday Night Music: The Red Army Choir Sings “It’s A Long Way To Tipperary”
abstract: Because why not.

headline: Identity Crisis: Theater Productions That Refuse to Be Theater
abstract: What if Cirque du Soleil acrobats took over “Avatar” — and little Norwegian trains just ran across some tracks? Such are the shows “Toruk” and “Bridge Over Mud.”
lead_paragraph: We had landed on Pandora, a moon 4.4 light-years from Earth. Strange beasts roamed here; curious plants flourished. The air smelled of ketchup, and a mysterious, fluting voice encouraged us to visit the merchandise kiosk.

headline: Review: ‘When the Bough Breaks,’ Blame a Scary Pregnancy Surrogate
abstract: This movie, about a well-off couple and the woman they hire to carry their embryo, looks for suspense in a genre that has little left.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps you were wondering if it were still possible to wring any suspense out of an unbalanced-third-wheel plot. “When the Bough Breaks,” about a surrogate pregnancy gone horribly wrong, has a definitive answer: No, it isn’t.

headline: Galaxy Note 7 Owners Are Urged to Stop Using Their Phones
abstract: The warning came from Samsung and safety regulators. Dozens of the smartphones have caught fire or exploded in recent days, and a recall is underway.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The fallout over the potential for Samsung Galaxy Note 7 smartphones to catch fire is intensifying.

headline: Canada Today: A Surge in Interest, and Prices, for Toronto’s Film Scene
abstract: Our weekly roundup for Canadian readers and anyone else interested in the True North features hot tickets in Toronto and a Stompin’ Tom Connors tribute.
lead_paragraph: We’re trying something new: Canada Today, a weekly roundup for Canadian readers and anyone else interested in the True North. Tell us what you think and what you’d like to see, at CanadaToday@nytimes.com.

headline: Novak Djokovic Survives Gaël Monfils and the Humidity
abstract: The No. 1 seed at the United States Open reached the final by defeating his exasperating opponent and the difficult weather conditions.
lead_paragraph: Novak Djokovic has had more fluid days on the tennis court. But on a suffocating day when his body became desperate for fluids, he was grateful to take a victory any way he could get it.

abstract: His firm helped develop the specialty of handling communications about corporate mergers and acquisitions.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Rinehart, who is credited with helping to pioneer the field of deal-making communications, died on Aug. 30. He was 86 and lived in New York.

headline: On This Runway, Non-Models and Cool Kids
abstract: How the Eckhaus Latta designers select fashion week’s coolest cast.
lead_paragraph: Over Labor Day weekend, a steady stream of hopefuls arrived at Eckhaus Latta’s basement studio in Chinatown for the chance to take an audition strut down a makeshift runway.

headline: Hillary Clinton Takes Aim at North Korea, Then at Donald Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Nuclear Tests']
abstract: The candidate called for a “rethinking” of U.S. strategy in dealing with the nuclear threat posed by North Korea, including enlisting more help from China.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton called Friday for rethinking President Obama’s strategy to combat North Korea’s nuclear program, saying the country’s latest nuclear test gave the White House “an opening” to expand sanctions and broaden a missile-defense program in neighboring countries.

headline: Mike Pence Releases 10 Years of Tax Returns
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s running mate provided what the Republican nominee has not: details on income, charitable contributions and federal taxes paid.
lead_paragraph: While Donald J. Trump resists making his tax returns public, his running mate, Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana, released a decade of his own filings on Friday.

headline: Russia and the United States Reach New Agreement on Syria Conflict
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: If successful, the agreement would reduce the violence and lead to joint military operations to target Islamic militants in Syria.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Russia and the United States agreed early Saturday on a new plan to reduce violence in the Syrian conflict that, if successful, could lead for the first time to joint military targeting by the two powers against Islamic jihadists in Syria.

headline: North Carolina Elections Board Settles Fight Over Voting Guidelines
keywords: ['Elections', 'Voting and Voters', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: The county-by-county decisions in a battleground state could influence the course of voting in close races for president, governor and a United States Senate seat.
lead_paragraph: North Carolina’s state elections board settled a deeply partisan battle over this fall’s election rules on Thursday, largely rejecting a Republican-led effort to write local voting guidelines that would limit Democratic turnout in a political battleground state.

headline: Akris: Spring 2017
abstract: Albert Kriemler shows his spring 2017 women’s collection in New York for the first time.
lead_paragraph: Albert Kriemler shows his spring 2017 women’s collection in New York for the first time.

headline: 7 Police Officers to Be Charged in Bay Area Sex Scandal
keywords: ['Police', 'Prostitution', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: A California prosecutor said criminal charges would be filed after a monthslong investigation into allegations of officers having sex with a teenage prostitute.
lead_paragraph: A prosecutor in California said on Friday that criminal charges would be filed against seven current or former police officers in the San Francisco Bay Area, capping a monthslong investigation into allegations of officers having sex with a teenage prostitute.

headline: Apple Is Said to Be Rethinking Strategy on Self-Driving Cars
keywords: ['Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions']
abstract: The company has closed parts of its self-driving car project and laid off dozens of employees, according to three people briefed on the subject.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple is rethinking what it plans to do about self-driving cars, just as other big tech companies appear ready to plow ahead with competing efforts.

headline: Gov. Mike Pence’s Personal Financial Disclosure
abstract: Mr. Pence, the governor of Indiana and the Republican vice-presidential nominee, released his own personal financial disclosure, which showed his state pension, a few investments and a series of loans totaling more than $80,000 for his children’s education.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Pence, the governor of Indiana and the Republican vice-presidential nominee, released his own personal financial disclosure, which showed his state pension, a few investments and a series of loans totaling more than $80,000 for his children’s education.

headline: The 2015 Income Tax Return for Gov. Mike Pence and Karen Pence
abstract: In 2015, Mr. Pence, the governor of Indiana and the Republican vice-presidential nominee, and his wife, Karen, reported an adjusted gross income of $113,026, paid $8,956 in federal taxes and contributed $8,923 to charities.
lead_paragraph: In 2015, Mr. Pence, the governor of Indiana and the Republican vice-presidential nominee, and his wife, Karen, reported an adjusted gross income of $113,026, paid $8,956 in federal taxes and contributed $8,923 to charities.

headline: Dustin Moskovitz, Facebook Co-Founder, Pledges $20 Million to Aid Democrats
abstract: Mr. Moskovitz said Donald J. Trump’s campaign had raised such fundamental questions that he and his wife, Cari Tuna, felt compelled to intervene.
lead_paragraph: A billionaire co-founder of Facebook is committing $20 million to help elect Democrats this fall, saying the campaign of Donald J. Trump has raised such fundamental questions that he and his wife felt compelled to intervene.

headline: Judge in 9/11 Suits Feels No Regret That None Ever Went to Trial
abstract: Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein acknowledged that by not holding a trial for any of the cases, there was a “loss of information” to the public.
lead_paragraph: After the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, scores of victims’ family members decided to pursue lawsuits in federal court, bypassing a dedicated compensation fund in order to seek not only millions of dollars in damages, but also answers and accountability.

headline: Wells Fargo Offers Regrets, but Doesn’t Admit Misconduct
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The case reflects a trend in which regulators fine financial institutions and require changes, but not an admission of wrongdoing.
lead_paragraph: Wells Fargo was flowing with regrets on Friday, taking out ads in nearly a dozen newspapers saying the bank took “full responsibility” for creating sham bank accounts without its customers’ permission.

headline: G.M. Spots an Airbag Problem and Moves Quickly to Respond
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The carmaker, this time getting out in front of a safety problem, will recall 4.3 million vehicles worldwide to fix airbags that may not deploy in a crash.
lead_paragraph: Concerns about automobile airbags lately have focused on ones that deploy too explosively or even spontaneously.

headline: Fact Check: Trump and Clinton on Security
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The New York Times checks statements by Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton about national security and foreign affairs.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times checks statements by Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton about national security and foreign affairs.

headline: Keeping Ahead in Arms Race for the Perfect Wheelchair
abstract: The wheelchair, like a shoe, must fit an athlete perfectly. But customization of the latest tech is out of reach for many athletes at the Paralympics.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The Paralympic wheelchair basketball competition had not even begun, and Mike Frogley was already thinking about the next one. And the one after that.

headline: Rapper Bobby Shmurda Takes 7-Year Plea Deal in Gang Case
keywords: ['Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Music', 'Gangs', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Firearms']
abstract: The performer, arrested in 2014 and accused of being a leader in a Brooklyn street gang, pleaded guilty to conspiracy and weapons possession.
lead_paragraph: After spending over a year and a half in jail awaiting trial, the Brooklyn rapper Bobby Shmurda pleaded guilty on Friday to conspiracy and weapons possession in a deal with prosecutors three days before jury selection was to start.

headline: Health Care Providers Scramble to Meet New Disaster Readiness Rule
keywords: ['Disasters and Emergencies', 'Medicaid', 'Medicare', 'Hospice Care', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hospitals', 'Nursing Homes', 'Retirement Communities and Assisted Living']
abstract: The new requirements seek to help medical facilities better provide care during emergencies, including severe weather, pandemics and terrorist attacks.
lead_paragraph: An estimated 72,315 American health care providers and suppliers — from hospitals and nursing homes to dialysis facilities and care homes for those with intellectual disabilities — will have a little over a year to meet federal disaster preparedness requirements  completed this week by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services.

headline: Call It a Growing Family: ‘High Maintenance’ Moves to HBO
abstract: The show, which originally appeared on the video-sharing website Vimeo, heads to premium cable.
lead_paragraph: Ben Sinclair and Katja Blichfeld were wedged into the bedroom belonging to their friend Russell Gregory on a cold and rainy February day, shooting a scene for the television series “High Maintenance.” Mr. Gregory’s railroad apartment was crawling with people — sound guys, assistant directors, camera operators — and the atmosphere was as tense as the working conditions (and schedule) were tight.

headline: Sexism: Let’s Deconstruct Donald
abstract: There are insults, and then there are insults.
lead_paragraph: Are Donald Trump’s attacks on Hillary Clinton sexist? To be fair, Trump is a guy who makes insulting personal remarks about everyone he disagrees with, regardless of gender. Let’s not jump to conclusions. This deserves a serious breakdown.

headline: Monse: Spring 2017
abstract: Laura Kim and Fernando Garcia, recently appointed creative directors of Oscar de la Renta, present their spring collection.
lead_paragraph: Laura Kim and Fernando Garcia, recently appointed creative directors of Oscar de la Renta, present their spring collection.

headline: For Rudy Giuliani, Embrace of Donald Trump Puts Legacy at Risk
abstract: A Trump victory could open the door for a return to public office for Mr. Giuliani. A loss, however, could be a last act for “America’s Mayor.”
lead_paragraph: Weeks after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, with bodies still being pulled from the smoldering rubble, New York’s mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, delivered an emotional address before a hushed United Nations.

headline: North Korea Will Have the Skills to Make a Nuclear Warhead by 2020, Experts Say
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'Nuclear Tests', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The Pentagon warned this year that Pyongyang’s new missiles, if perfected, “would be capable of reaching much of the continental United States.”
lead_paragraph: North Korea’s fifth nuclear test is ominous not only because the country is slowly mastering atomic weaponry, but because it is making headway in developing missiles that could hurl nuclear warheads halfway around the globe, threatening Washington and New York City.

headline: Young, Digitally Savvy and Just Fine With a Little Grime in Their Subway Cars
abstract: New York City’s subway system has ardent followers who study its maps and its tunnels, its history and its rail yards. The Super Subway Bros. is one of those fan groups.
lead_paragraph: When 23-year-old Patrick J. Stewart reviews a subway car for his subway-centric YouTube channel, he sometimes brings a white glove to stroke the poles, checking how besmirched his fingertips get. It is a good way to gauge how well a car is maintained, he says, and, by extension, how caring its overseers back at the rail depot are: The finger-swab is a health check on the entire system.

headline: Women in Terror Cell Were ‘Guided’ by ISIS, Paris Prosecutor Says
abstract: The use of a cell made up entirely of young women represents a chilling turn in the Islamic State’s tactics, the prosecutor said.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A “terrorist cell” made up mainly of radicalized young Frenchwomen has been dismantled by security forces, the Paris prosecutor said on Friday, after a car filled with gas canisters was found last week in the heart of Paris.

headline: North Korea’s Nuclear Enabler
abstract: China’s ambivalence has led to the current crisis.
lead_paragraph: No country has more influence over the rogue state of North Korea than China, which provides it with food, fuel and access to vital trade routes. Yet when North Korea conducted its fifth and most powerful nuclear weapons test on Friday — underscoring once again the failure of international efforts to halt the nuclear program — Beijing’s response amounted to pap.

headline: Virginia’s Republicans Turn Back the Clock
abstract: The state’s Senate majority leader wants to impose the strictest voting ban in the nation on people convicted of a violent felony.
lead_paragraph: In the last couple of decades, states have begun to recognize the particular viciousness of laws that prevent people with felony convictions from voting. Virginia Republicans, on the other hand, appear eager to return to the 19th century, when most of these laws were drafted explicitly to keep African-Americans away from the ballot box.

headline: A Way to Protect Planned Parenthood Services
keywords: ['States (US)', 'Editorials', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: The Department of Health and Human Services has proposed a rule that could stop states from stripping the organization of Title X funds.
lead_paragraph: Opponents of Planned Parenthood in recent years have cut funding to the organization that goes through the Title X Family Planning Program, which provides federal money for services like contraception, testing for sexually transmitted infections and cancer screenings. (Like all federal programs, it is largely barred from paying for abortions.) State and local governments distribute that money to health care providers, and at least 14 states took actions to cut the share they direct to Planned Parenthood.

headline: You’re Soaking in It
abstract: Peter Wentz offers a solid Saturday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — As a devotee of film and television pop culture, it did not surprise me in the least that my first two entries in Peter Wentz’s crunchy and challenging puzzle were ALEX ROCCO and PALMOLIVE.

headline: Bob Graham: Release More 9/11 Records
abstract: Many questions about the Sept. 11 hijackers remain unanswered. It is time for the government to declassify its many investigations into the attack.
lead_paragraph: In July, after approval from the Obama administration, Congress released a 28-page chapter of previously classified material from the final report of a joint congressional inquiry into the Sept. 11 attacks. Saudi Arabia’s foreign minister, Adel al-Jubeir, said that the document had ruled out any Saudi involvement in the attack. “The matter is now finished,” he declared.

headline: The Selling of Donald J. Trump
abstract: He’s pushing himself as a product, not a politician, to a country steeped in a market-driven reality.
lead_paragraph: In their struggle to understand the Trump phenomenon, establishment pundits, political scientists and millions of flabbergasted American voters have settled on a long list of sober-sounding socioeconomic explanations: Deindustrialization. Anomie. Racial animosity. The rising up of a dislocated America.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, September 10, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “Sully is worried about his reputation, but this movie isn’t helping mine.”

keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: They sat, like others will this weekend, in the darkness watching “Sully.” But for those who survived the landing of US Airways Flight 1549 in the Hudson River in 2009, this was not just a night at the movies.
lead_paragraph: They sat, like others will this weekend, in the darkness watching “Sully.” But for those who survived the landing of US Airways Flight 1549 in the Hudson River in 2009, this was not just a night at the movies.

headline: After a Rocky Start, Stan Wawrinka Storms Into His First U.S. Open Final
abstract: Wawrinka notched a semifinal victory over Kei Nishikori, 4-6, 7-5, 6-4, 6-2. He will face Novak Djokovic in the final on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: The United States Open took a hit in July when Roger Federer announced that his season was over because of a knee injury. Fans were disappointed that the veteran Swiss master with the graceful one-handed backhand would be unable to make another run to a final.

headline: De Blasio Faces Mounting Pressure on Matters of Transparency
keywords: ['Freedom of Information Act', 'Politics and Government', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']

lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s weekly radio appearance ought to have been a sleepy affair on a grindingly humid Friday morning at the tail end of summer.

headline: Protesters Respond to Pipeline Ruling
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Pipelines', 'Native Americans']
abstract: The U.S. government temporarily halted construction on the Dakota Access pipeline after a federal court denied a Native American tribe’s request for an injunction.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. government temporarily halted construction on the Dakota Access pipeline after a federal court denied a Native American tribe’s request for an injunction.

headline: Donald Trump Says Hillary Clinton Wouldn’t Be Prosecuted Even if She Shot Someone
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mr. Trump, at a rally on Friday, escalated his attacks against Mrs. Clinton, saying that “she is being so protected.”
lead_paragraph: PENSACOLA, Fla. — Donald J. Trump, in escalating attacks against Hillary Clinton, suggested on Friday that his opponent was so immune to prosecution that she could shoot someone in front of thousands of witnesses and not be prosecuted.

headline: Rally to Beat the Braves, and a Favorable Schedule, Buoy the Mets’ Hopes
abstract: In their final 21 regular-season games, the Mets play only three against a team with a winning record. So their postseason aspirations are very much in play.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The nadir of the Mets’ season may have been Aug. 19. They were two games under .500, and five and a half games out of the second National League wild-card spot. Playoff projections had the Mets’ percentage chances of reaching the postseason in the single digits.

headline: Nora Mendis and Samuel Ellison: From Platonic ‘Buddies’ to an Unexpected Love
abstract: The couple found a connection in their love of film, and then later on a summer road trip.
lead_paragraph: Nora Rose Mendis and Samuel Noah Lindsay Ellison were married Sept. 10 in Dummerston, Vt. Joshua Bauchner, a friend of the couple who received authorization from the State of Vermont, officiated at Full Plate Farm, a vegetable farm owned by Laura Hecht and Matthew Crowley, friends of the couple.

headline: Emma Tessler and Benjamin Jacoff: The 116th Time Was the Charm
abstract: The couple, who met through OkCupid in 2013, were married at Barberry Hill Farm in Madison, Conn.
lead_paragraph: Emma Eiber Tessler and Benjamin Samuel Jacoff were married Sept. 10 in Madison, Conn. Rabbi Jessica Minnen officiated at Barberry Hill Farm, a vegetable, fruit and wildflower farm.

headline: Kate Horowitz and Jake Klarberg: From Campers to Counselors to Spouses
abstract: The couple met as 14-year-olds on their first day of summer camp. Later that evening, they shared their first kiss.
lead_paragraph: Kate Margaret Horowitz, a daughter of Katherine C. Horowitz and the stepdaughter of Scott S. Glassman of Dix Hills, N.Y., was married Sept. 10 to Jake Tyler Klarberg, a son of Rindi N. Klarberg of Morristown, N.J., and Barry J. Klarberg of Greenwich, Conn. Rabbi Susie Moskowitz officiated at the summer home of the bride’s family in Kings Point, N.Y., with Cantor Sarene Applebaum taking part.

headline: Amy Margolis and David Wilson: Atop Yosemite’s Half Dome, a Banana-Bread Wedding
abstract: The couple, who met at a triathlon, were married at Half Dome in Yosemite National Park.
lead_paragraph: Amy Beth Margolis and David John Wilson were married Sept. 6 in Yosemite National Park in California. Hannah M. McHugh, a friend who became a Universal Life minister to preside, officiated on the summit of Half Dome, a popular hiking destination.

headline: 5-Year Prison Term in Iran Is Reported for Thomson Reuters Charity Official
abstract: The official, Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, a British national, was seized more than five months ago. The accusations against her were never made clear.
lead_paragraph: A British-Iranian employee of the Thomson Reuters Foundation, who was arrested more than five months ago while she and her daughter, a toddler, were visiting family in Iran, has been sentenced to a five-year prison term for unexplained charges, the foundation said Friday.

headline: Corrections: September 10, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, September 10, 2016.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Dustin Johnson, With 2 Eagles, Sets Course Record
abstract: Johnson shot a 63 to take a share of the lead at the BMW Championship.
lead_paragraph: Dustin Johnson made two eagles in a seven-hole run, shot 31 on the back nine and set the course record at Crooked Stick in Carmel, Ind., on Friday with a nine-under-par 63 that gave him a share of the lead with Roberto Castro in the BMW Championship.

headline: Yankees Ride Out Rain, With Their Future Suddenly Looking Bright
abstract: Mark Teixeira hit a grand slam home run to help the Yankees move within a game of the final wild-card spot.
lead_paragraph: At 11:17 p.m., with Yankee Stadium emptying and one out in the ninth inning, the rain again became too much to bear. The Yankees and Tampa Bay Rays had already withstood two delays, each just 21 minutes long — more nagging intrusions than debilitating storms — and this was the worst one yet. A game that was dragging into its fifth hour came to another halt.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Star Wars: The Force Awakens’ and ‘Sisters’
abstract: “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” blasts onto Starz channels. And Tina Fey and Amy Poehler play siblings hosting the party of a lifetime in “Sisters.”
lead_paragraph: “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” blasts onto all Starz channels. Tina Fey and Amy Poehler let loose as siblings hosting the party of a lifetime in “Sisters.” And you can watch “The Devil Wears Prada” and “The September Issue” in honor of New York Fashion Week.

headline: War Games Show Off Russia’s Tightening Grip on Crimea
abstract: A huge show of power, including 12,000 troops, simulated an invasion and counterattack on the Crimean peninsula, which Russia annexed from Ukraine in 2014.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Large landing ships approached the shores of Crimea on Friday, simulating an invasion of the peninsula that was annexed by Moscow from Ukraine in 2014. Tanks and armored vehicles lumbered out of the ships, only to be met by the superior forces of the defenders, equipped with heavy artillery.

headline: NYPD 9/11 Parade Honors Lost Officers
abstract: To mark the 15th anniversary of 9/11, the NYPD held its first memorial parade. The procession commemorated the 23 officers who died on 9/11 and the 99 who died as a result of related illnesses.
lead_paragraph: To mark the 15th anniversary of 9/11, the NYPD held its first memorial parade. The procession commemorated the 23 officers who died on 9/11 and the 99 who died as a result of related illnesses.

headline: ‘Wars Have Been Fought for Much Less’
abstract: Our top 10 comments of the week: Readers debate college diversity training, climate change, an epidemic of loneliness and more.
lead_paragraph: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

headline: In a Reverse Mentorship, Seeing Age Though a New Lens
abstract: A young Times editor gets an unexpected chance to take on a leadership role when a seasoned colleague asks for Snapchat lessons.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, Phyllis Korkki, an assignment editor at The New York Times who sits a few cubicles away, approached me with a question that gave me pause. “Will you mentor me?” she asked.

headline: What Could I Possibly Learn From a Mentor Half My Age? Plenty
abstract: How Snapchat lessons from a younger colleague, whose job didn’t exist five years ago, stretched a New York Times editor professionally and personally.
lead_paragraph: How on earth did I become an “older worker?”

headline: In the Bonobo World, Female Camaraderie Prevails
abstract: In the African forest, the critically endangered species demonstrates a gender split. The matriarchal group rules their social networks and punishes male aggressors.
lead_paragraph: The female bonobo apes of the Wamba forest in the Democratic Republic of Congo had just finished breakfast and were preparing for a brief nap in the treetops, bending and crisscrossing leafy branches into comfortable day beds.

headline: The Stars Come Out for Opening Ceremony’s Fashion Week Agitprop
abstract: Natasha Lyonne, Rashida Jones, Rosario Dawson and Rowan Blanchard back the designers in their promotion of “loud and proud“ American voices.
lead_paragraph: If anything is likely to pierce the seemingly impenetrable fashion week bubble, surely it has to be this wacko election season. Not even the most frivolous catwalk devotee remains untouched by a presidential race as unprecedentedly weird as this one.

headline: Gwyneth Paltrow and Goop Go Into the Fashion Business
abstract: Focused on a new clothing line, the actress steps further away from movies.
lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — “Can you help me clear something up?”

headline: The Trauma of Violent News on the Internet
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'Television', 'Violence (Media and Entertainment)', 'News and News Media']
abstract: How violent images and news on the internet may be more traumatic for some viewers than those in traditional media.
lead_paragraph: “The world has always been messy,” President Obama said in 2014 after a string of doom-and-gloom news events. “In part, we’re just noticing now because of social media and our capacity to see in intimate detail the hardships that people are going through.”

headline: Jerry Lewis At 90: His Mouth Runneth Over
abstract: On the occasion of a new movie, the actor talks about the trials of age, the perks of wealth and a sexy encounter with Marilyn Monroe.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — It wasn’t always easy to make out his words above the din of five Chihuahuas yipping at his feet. But when Jerry Lewis has something to say, damn if he isn’t going to be heard.

headline: New York Fashion Week, Day 4: Start Early, Party Late
abstract: Alexander Wang, DVF and Rebecca Minkoff bring New York fashion into the weekend.
lead_paragraph: Weekend? What weekend? New York Fashion Week knows no such thing. On Saturday, the shows soldier on — and so, in their thrall, do we.

headline: Postcards From the Hajj: The Wildlife
abstract: When I was preparing for the hajj, the holy Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca, Saudi Arabia, my brother warned me of a peril in the skies: the birds.
lead_paragraph: When I was preparing for the hajj, the holy Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca, Saudi Arabia, my brother warned me of a peril in the skies: the birds.

headline: Throwing Stones and Slaughtering Sheep at the Hajj
abstract: Diaa Hadid, a Times correspondent making the Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca, picked up tips on how to practice some of the rites and rituals of the hajj.
lead_paragraph: Usually, the post office is where you send mail or pay your bills. In Saudi Arabia during the hajj, it’s where you pay for your animal sacrifice.

headline: A Little Variety
abstract: A place to discuss the “A Little Variety” suite of puzzles.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLES — This week’s puzzles include:

headline: Tobin Was Right (Implicitly Wonkish)
abstract: The great man, imaginary and real.
lead_paragraph: Right now, when not trying to do something about the political horror unfolding, I’m revising macro chapters and also preparing for several European speeches, including this one on macroeconomic lessons from recent experience. And I found myself returning to a theme I’ve touched on a few times over the years: it seems to me, all too often, that both economists and economic policymakers might actually have done a better job responding to the crisis if they has been using an old-fashioned theoretical toolkit, say what smart Keynesians believed circa 1970.

headline: The Daily Bag: Jason Wu
abstract: T plucks the best bags right off the runway.
lead_paragraph: The classic saddle bag got a modern update at Jason Wu: chalk-white leather, silver hardware and a sleek shape.

headline: The Daily Jewel: Chris Gelinas
abstract: T plucks the best jewels right off the runway.
lead_paragraph: The sculptural, rose-gold earrings at Chris Gelinas were inspired by abstract florals.

headline: Farhad’s and Mike’s Week in Tech: The iPhone’s Super Mario Moment
abstract: Apple is killing the headphone jack but helping revive Nintendo’s great franchise with Super Mario Run, coming exclusively to iOS.
lead_paragraph: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: The Daily Shoe: Tanya Taylor
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.
lead_paragraph: Memories of summer lingered at Tanya Taylor, where the designer collaborated with Paul Andrew on playful, festive raffia slides.

headline: Monse Draws Attention, and Not Just for the Clothes
abstract: Amid much excitement over Monse’s designers being appointed to lead Oscar de la Renta, the label showed its new collection.
lead_paragraph: Amid much excitement over Monse’s designers being appointed to lead Oscar de la Renta, the label showed its new collection.

headline: Amid Much Buzz, Monse Shows Its Spring Collection
abstract: Laura Kim and Fernando Garcia, newly appointed as creative directors of Oscar de la Renta, showed their own label.
lead_paragraph: One week ago, the news broke that Laura Kim and Fernando Garcia, the designers of Monse, would be going back to Oscar de la Renta — where they had spent 12 and 6 years, respectively — as its next creative directors. The timing was not ideal. Ms. Kim and Mr. Garcia’s own label was barely a year old, and the preparations for its New York Fashion Week show, only its third, were well underway. But news will out.

headline: When Birds Nest in Bad Places
abstract: Nests near air vents, safety in low-rise buildings and accommodating disabilities.
lead_paragraph: I live in a condominium with beautiful landscaping, trees —  and lots of birds. The air-conditioning and heating units in the apartments are vented outdoors through louvers built into the building’s brick facade. Birds nest in the spaces between the louvers and the cooling-and-heating units, leaving behind droppings and nesting material. It is messy and a health hazard, but does not damage the appliances. The board says condo owners are responsible for cleaning and removing the nests. But shouldn’t this be the board’s responsibility, since the nests are in the facade and not in the appliances?

headline: The Secret History of Colombia’s Paramilitaries and the U.S. War on Drugs
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'United States International Relations', 'Cocaine and Crack Cocaine', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Drug Cartels', 'Extradition']
abstract: After decades of atrocities, the warlords were finally being held to account. Then the Americans stepped in.
lead_paragraph: CALABAZO, Colombia — Skinny but imposing with aviator glasses, a bushy mustache and a toothy smile, Julio Henríquez Santamaría was leading a community meeting in this sylvan hamlet when he was abducted by paramilitary thugs, thrown into the back of a Toyota pickup and disappeared forever on Feb. 4, 2001.

headline: Gawker’s New Owner Deletes Six Posts Involved in Lawsuits
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Libel and Slander', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Univision, which bought Gawker Media last month, believed that it was obligated to delete the posts because it did not assume Gawker’s liabilities, according to a memo.
lead_paragraph: Executives at Univision, which bought Gawker Media last month for $135 million, voted on Friday to remove six posts previously published by Gawker Media sites. The posts, which were taken down on Saturday, are involved in continuing legal action.

headline: Fashion Week Photo Diary: Jason Wu, Monse and Tommy Hilfiger
abstract: Scenes from the collections which were presented in New York on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the collections which were presented in New York on Friday.

headline: Greek Life
abstract: Recent graduate captures greek life on an HBCU campus.
lead_paragraph: Recent graduate captures greek life on an HBCU campus.

headline: Boise State Mounts a Paper Defense of Its Home Turf
abstract: The university holds a trademark that covers not just blue football fields, but fields of all stripes — including stripes.
lead_paragraph: BOISE, Idaho — If anyone in the world — a high school in Texas, a college in New England, a university in Japan — wants to install an artificial turf field of any color besides green, it must first receive permission from the occupant of a corner office in a brick building at the center of the campus of Boise State University.

headline: For Twins’ Dozier, One Big Swing Unlocks Another
abstract: Brian Dozier was swinging a golf club when his coach saw the power potential inside him.
lead_paragraph: It took a while for the most prolific power hitter of the summer to understand his potential. But doing so was essential to reaching the majors, said Brian Dozier, whose epiphany came on a golf course.

headline: Boiler Explosion at Bangladesh Factory Kills at Least 23
keywords: ['Fires and Firefighters', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Rana Plaza Building Collapse, Bangladesh (2013)', 'Explosions (Accidental)', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: At least 50 people were injured in the latest in a series of industrial disasters over the last several years in Bangladesh.
lead_paragraph: TONGI, Bangladesh — A boiler explosion in a cigarette packaging factory outside Dhaka enveloped the five-story building in flames early Saturday, killing at least 23 people, fire officials said.

headline: Rickie Fowler’s Killer Instinct Comes With a Smile
abstract: Fowler is being considered for the U.S. Ryder Cup team, but some golf observers think his friendliness hurts his chances in match play.
lead_paragraph: CARMEL, Ind. — As honorary observers, the two men were close enough to get splattered by the muddy spinout that was Rickie Fowler’s opening round at the BMW Championship at Crooked Stick Golf Club last week. Fowler’s three-over-par 75, six strokes higher than the scores carded by his playing partners, gave Ted Azar and Mike Bova pause.

headline: North Korea, Far From Crazy, Is All Too Rational
keywords: ['Nuclear Tests', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Propaganda', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: While the country does not want war, it cultivates a permanent risk of one — and prepares to stave off defeat, should war happen, potentially with nuclear weapons.
lead_paragraph: Is North Korea irrational? Or does it just pretend to be?

headline: Real-Time Election Day Projections May Upend News Tradition
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'News and News Media', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: VoteCastr, a Silicon Valley company, plans to report early election results in key states, raising concerns about an effect on how people vote.
lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — For decades, news organizations have refrained from releasing early results in presidential battleground states on Election Day, adhering to a strict, time-honored embargo until a majority of polls there have closed.

headline: On Ben McAdoo’s Journey to the Top, False Starts and Tenacity
abstract: McAdoo, the first-year Giants coach, had trouble finding a coaching job when he decided to change careers early in graduate school.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — In 2000, at 22 years old, Ben McAdoo had no plans to become a coach, not even in midget football, let alone in the N.F.L. His career game plan included law school. He had not been in a football uniform since high school.

headline: Ryan Clady’s Twisted Turns
abstract: The Jets’ Clady has twice been an All-Pro and twice sustained season-ending injuries. Now he must find a way to replace a player who never got hurt.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Upon being traded to the Jets in April, Ryan Clady wondered whether his new teammates would accept him.

headline: Variety: Urban Renewal
abstract: Mike Shenk takes us on a trip.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — This puzzle by Puzzability’s Mike Shenk is a lot of fun, particularly if you pay attention to the two-word combinations you have to make before you change the letters to get the United States or world cities.

headline: Review: ‘Fiorello!,’ the Mayor Who Fought for the Little Guy
abstract: This Tony-winning 1959 musical about New York’s colorful, corruption-fighting mayor gets an Off Broadway revival from the Berkshire Theater Group.
lead_paragraph: Imagine, if you can, a musical comedy called “La Guardia!” Picture a chorus angrily lamenting their canceled flights. A frustrated plaint from an overtaxed ticketing agent trying to calm them. A frenetic hip-hop dance number as arriving passengers dodge traffic to find their Uber drivers.

headline: An Overlooked Rivalry: Novak Djokovic and Stan Wawrinka
abstract: Djokovic is the world’s best player. Wawrinka has blossomed into the world’s best finalist.
lead_paragraph: With his sweatshirt hood up and the midnight hour approaching, Stan Wawrinka stifled a laugh.

headline: Yellow, Fuzzy and Flat: Where Do Recycled Tennis Balls Go?
abstract: Although most tennis balls end up in landfills, there is a growing effort to reuse them.
lead_paragraph: Pop open a can of tennis balls before a match. Open a new can for the next match, and the next.

headline: Why Aren’t They in Jail? Here’s One Company Head Who Is
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Customer Relations', "Workers' Compensation Insurance", 'Hats and Caps']
abstract: The Haggler finds out that an Alabama businessman actually is in jail — for defrauding the federal government. But customer complaints about his business sent him there early.
lead_paragraph: Consumers who write to the Haggler to describe particularly egregious behavior often end their letters with variations of this question: Why aren’t the people in charge behind bars?

headline: Bobby Chacon, Boxing Champion Hounded by Misfortune, Dies at 64
abstract: Chacon earned the first of two world titles less than two years into his career in 1974. As debilitating drug use and family tragedy took their toll, he refused to quit.
lead_paragraph: Bobby Chacon, a scrappy two-time world boxing champion who was haunted by tragedy outside the arena and memorialized in song by Warren Zevon, died on Wednesday at a hospice in Hemet, Calif. He was 64.

headline: No Driver? Bring It On. How Pittsburgh Became Uber’s Testing Ground
keywords: ['Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs']
abstract: Uber’s experiment with autonomous vehicles is proceeding with the blessing of city officials, who have pretty much just stayed out of the way.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — Any day now, Uber will introduce  a fleet of self-driving cars in Pittsburgh, making this former steel town the world’s first city to let any passenger hail an autonomous vehicle.

headline: Married Off by the Khmer Rouge, and ‘Nobody Could Help Me’
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Cambodians have testified about abuse and heartache after being paired with strangers, as a tribunal considers allegations of crimes against humanity under the 1970s regime.
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — In a vast courtroom on the outskirts of Phnom Penh, a middle-aged Cambodian woman soberly described a night nearly four decades ago that she said she had never talked about before.

headline: The Bull Is Still Running. So Why Are Investors Tiptoeing?
keywords: ['Interest Rates', 'United States Economy', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Many market strategists warn that caution, rather than greed-induced euphoria, is appropriate at this stage of the seven-year-old bull market.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street seems unable to make up its mind about risk-taking.

headline: A Robot May Be Training to Do Your Job. Don’t Panic.
abstract: Robots that can recognize emotions are in development, and they could someday move into roles reserved for humans. But it’s an opportunity, not a threat.
lead_paragraph: In my speaking engagements, when I mention the terms “the future of work” and “automation” in the same sentence, I often see the audience squirm. People’s worst fear is that their job will soon be taken over by the equivalent of Rosie the Robot from “The Jetsons.” But even though we’re only in the beginning stages of work force automation, I’m optimistic about the effect it will have on human workers.

headline: A Linguist Helping Apps Learn to Speak Millennial
abstract: Marsal Gavalda, director of machine intelligence at the social network Yik Yak, works on a system that analyzes users’ posts for patterns and emotions.
lead_paragraph: Q. What is Yik Yak and what is your job there?

headline: The Trump-Ailes Buddy Act
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Sexual Harassment', 'News and News Media', 'Editorials']
abstract: Donald Trump can’t possibly be betting on Roger Ailes to help him win the election. Could these two serial misogynists share a future in TV land?
lead_paragraph: Trump TV.

headline: Street Style: New York Fashion Week
abstract: Street style from the spring 2017 fashion season at New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Street style from the spring 2017 fashion season at New York Fashion Week.

headline: ‘Narcos’ Season 2 Finale: The Last Stand
abstract: Season 2 wraps up the Pablo Escobar story with a scrupulous recreation of the drug kingpin’ final moments.
lead_paragraph: The photograph of Colombian armed forces members standing over the body of Pablo Escobar on a Medellín rooftop shows the end of a costly mission captured in suitably unsavory fashion. Bloodied and splayed across the tile with no shoes, rolled-up jeans and a shirt hiked above his generous belly, Escobar became the subject of a ghoulish photo-op, with various operatives posing with wide smiles on their faces, like big-game hunters showing off a prize catch. They cannot be blamed for their exuberance, given the terror and violence Escobar perpetuated to his very last breath, but the photos are the punctuation mark at the end of an unsettling chapter for Colombian and United States law enforcement.

headline: Liu Wen, the Happy-Go-Lucky Model
abstract: With 2.1 million Instagram followers, she could be called China’s first supermodel.
lead_paragraph: On Friday evening, the fashion world turned out for a glitzy carnival on Pier 16 in the Financial District — or to be more accurate, a carnival/fashion show/shopping extravaganza hosted by Tommy Hilfiger and Gigi Hadid, who collaborated on a collection with the designer.

headline: Against a Backdrop of War, Ad Portrays Donald Trump as Reckless
abstract: The latest ad from the “super PAC” supporting Hillary Clinton presents her rival’s foreign policy positions as a danger to the country.
lead_paragraph: Priorities USA, the primary “super PAC” supporting Hillary Clinton, takes viewers through a visual tour of the horrors of warfare, from Vietnam to the Islamic State, in a new ad that seeks to paint her opponent, Donald J. Trump, as reckless and flippant on the use of military force.

headline: Dropout by Dartmouth Raises Questions on Health Law Cost-Savings Effort
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Dartmouth faced mounting financial losses in a federal program that is in the vanguard of efforts to move Medicare away from a fee-for-service system.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In its quest to remake the nation’s health care system, the Obama administration has urged doctors and hospitals to band together to improve care and cut costs, using a model devised by researchers at Dartmouth College.

headline: David Duke’s Senate Run in Louisiana Draws Attention but Not Support
abstract: There have been gritted teeth that the candidate who has gotten the most publicity is the one whom pollsters give virtually no chance.
lead_paragraph: MANDEVILLE, La. — It has so far been a mostly humdrum race for Louisiana’s open United States Senate seat, likely to end in a victory for some veteran officeholder: the Republican state treasurer, one of the congressmen, maybe even, in a surprise, a Democratic public service commissioner.

headline: Temperatures Rise, and We’re Cooked
abstract: Humans don’t function nearly as well when the heat goes up.
lead_paragraph: ONE of Donald Trump’s 100 wackiest ideas is that climate change is a hoax fabricated by China to harm America.

headline: The Strip
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: Seeking the Final Faces for a 9/11 Tapestry of Grief, Loss, Life and Joy
abstract: A gallery at the National September 11 Memorial Museum has photos of all but 10 of the 2,983 people killed in either the 2001 terrorist attacks or the 1993 World Trade Center bombing.
lead_paragraph: Albert Ogletree, a food handler with Forte Food Service, was working in the cafeteria at Cantor Fitzgerald in the north tower of the World Trade Center when a hijacked jetliner careered into the skyscraper. He is one of the 2,983 people killed in the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, and Feb. 26, 1993, when the trade center was bombed.

headline: How to Celebrate Eid al-Adha Like an American
abstract: Thanks to the moon, and the Saudis, it’s not on 9/11.
lead_paragraph: The Muslim festival of Eid al-Adha, which commemorates the end of the annual hajj pilgrimage, begins Monday, Sept. 12. For a few weeks, it looked as if the holiday was going to fall the day before: Sept. 11.

headline: Michigan Prosecutors Defy the Supreme Court
keywords: ['Juvenile Delinquency', 'Mandatory Sentencing', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Editorials', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The justices have said repeatedly that juveniles should almost never be locked up for life. In Michigan, the message isn’t getting through.
lead_paragraph: Why are Michigan’s prosecutors ignoring the Supreme Court?

headline: Our Russia Problem
abstract: Why both parties are so confused about the Kremlin.
lead_paragraph: RUSSIA’S place in American politics used to be (relatively) simple. The further right you stood, the more you feared Ivan and his Slavic wiles. The further left, the more you likely thought the Red Menace was mostly just a scare story.

headline: Why We Should Stop Grading Students on a Curve
keywords: ['Tests and Examinations', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Grading of Students', 'Executives and Management (Theory)', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: Turning college into a zero-sum game hurts their chances of succeeding after graduation.
lead_paragraph: Ask people what’s wrong in American higher education, and you’ll hear about grade inflation. At Harvard a few years ago, a professor complained that the most common grade was an A-. He was quickly corrected: The most common grade at Harvard was an A.

headline: Donald Trump’s Ideology of Applause
abstract: For the Republican nominee, there’s no difference between ratings and worth.
lead_paragraph: Americans are such sticklers. Such poops. Sure, some of Vladimir Putin’s political opponents wind up in jail, while some of the journalists he dislikes end up in the morgue. Yes, his government is apparently committing cybercrimes to meddle in our election. And there was that small matter of invading and annexing one of Russia’s neighbors.

headline: A Walk Around the Void of 9/11
abstract: Move slowly through the World Trade Center memorial plaza. Watch the names that flow by. Absorb the vast emptiness, the enormity of our loss, the passage of years.
lead_paragraph: Walk onto the plaza in Lower Manhattan and you hear the memorial before you see it — a whooshing through the oak trees. You soon realize it’s not the wind, but water. At the footprint of each tower, north and south, a vast square emptiness is bound by four walls of falling water, the pool below pouring into a smaller central void that flows out of sight. The memorial is black upon black, but the water casts reflections. Sunlight and mist make fragmentary rainbows that flicker as clouds go by.

headline: Before You Spend $26,000 on Weight-Loss Surgery, Do This
abstract: Why don’t the medical guidelines reflect the evidence, and suggest a low-carb diet?
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, the Food and Drug Administration approved a new weight-loss procedure in which a thin tube, implanted in the stomach, ejects food from the body before all the calories can be absorbed.

headline: The Bitch America Needs
abstract: The word is an epithet and an honorific, and will cling to the back of Hillary Clinton’s smart pantsuits forever.
lead_paragraph: There are so many ways to be a bitch when you’re Hillary Clinton. You can refuse to give up a thriving law career when your husband is elected governor of Arkansas. Later, when he becomes president of the United States, you can infuriate housewives across the nation with a dismissive reference to baking cookies.

headline: Even Amid Cease-Fire Countdown, Syria’s Conflicts Deepen
abstract: For all the talk of diplomacy, the five-year-old war has continued to surprise, with combatants finding new and brutal ways to shape the narrative.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — On the swirling battlefield in Syria in the past month alone, Turkey has sent in tanks, incendiary bombs have charred children and whole towns have been emptied in surrender deals that could change the country’s demographics.

headline: Marathon Swimmer Falls Short in Bid for a Record Off San Francisco
abstract: Kim Chambers had been in the water for 24 hours when conditions made it clear that she would not finish a 93-mile trip.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — Just before noon on Friday, Kim Chambers, 39, stood on a floating dock at the Sacramento Yacht Club as Kala Sherman-Presser, a member of her support team, rubbed lanolin under Chambers’s arms and the seams of her swimsuit.

headline: Trigger Warnings, Safe Spaces and Free Speech, Too
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: A little heads-up about uncomfortable and complex topics isn’t coddling. It helps students engage with one another.
lead_paragraph: I didn’t get the University of Chicago welcome letter that made the rounds on the internet earlier this summer. I’m a senior this year, and the message from Jay Ellison, the dean of undergraduate students, was for the incoming class: Don’t expect trigger warnings or safe spaces here. The university, he said, was committed to free expression and would not shield students from ideas they disagreed with or found offensive.

headline: With Pensions Like This ($315 a Month), Chileans Wonder How They’ll Ever Retire
abstract: In the wake of mass protests over the nation’s privatized system, once hailed by President George W. Bush, the government is looking for ways to change it.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — Discontent has been brewing for years in Chile over pensions so low that most people must keep working past retirement age. All the while, privately run companies have reaped enormous profits by investing Chileans’ social security savings.

headline: Megan Price
abstract: A human-rights executive on the Syrian conflict, bonding over “Star Trek” and finding humanity in board games.
lead_paragraph: Megan Price is executive director of the Human Rights Data Analysis Group, or Hrdag, a nonprofit, nonpartisan organization that collects and analyzes data to investigate and document human rights violations around the world.

headline: The Truth About ‘False Balance’
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'News and News Media', 'Public Editor (Times Column)']
abstract: When is a news article fair? For some critics, only when they think it serves their cause.
lead_paragraph: TO anyone who has avoided the debate over “false balance,” apologies for disturbing your bliss. But it’s necessary, because those who haven’t heard this phrase are missing out on one of the more consequential debates to engage the media in years.

headline: Hillary Clinton Calls Many Trump Backers ‘Deplorables,’ and G.O.P. Pounces
abstract: Mrs. Clinton later said she had spoken too broadly, then doubled down on what she called Mr. Trump’s appeal to prejudice.
lead_paragraph: Republicans from the presidential ticket on down pounced Saturday on Hillary Clinton’s remarks that half of Donald J. Trump’s supporters fit into a “basket of deplorables,” saying it showed she was out of touch with an economically hard-hit electorate.

headline: Under a Maestro, Manchester City Strikes the Perfect Note
abstract: For City’s new coach, Pep Guardiola, a 2-1 win over Manchester United was an elegant riposte to critics who have credited his successes to his players, not his coaching.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — Pep Guardiola, still basking in the delight of a victory in his first Manchester derby, was walking past the gleaming hospitality boxes that line Old Trafford’s Sir Bobby Charlton Stand when a familiar face emerged from one of the suites to greet him.

headline: Cast-Out Police Officers Are Often Hired in Other Cities
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: An Oregon officer was barred from taking another police job after a charge involving a child. Three months later, he was a police chief in Kansas. Experts say it’s a widespread problem.
lead_paragraph: As a police officer in a small Oregon town in 2004, Sean Sullivan was caught kissing a 10-year-old girl on the mouth.

headline: Putin, Admired by Donald Trump, Emphasizes Strength as Virtue

Putin, dressed in a somber suit and tie, sat for over an hour this past week sipping tea from a delicate porcelain cup and offering earnest advice on how to improve housing, medical care and other services in a provincial town south of here.

abstract: Ms. Friedman was one of several women who said they were photographed kissing a sailor in Times Square at the end of World War II.
lead_paragraph: Greta Friedman, who said she was grabbed and kissed by a sailor in a euphoric moment that made for one of the most defining American photos of the 20th century, died on Thursday in Richmond, Va. She was 92.
