headline: Stabbing Attack in Australia Is Linked to the Islamic State
abstract: The police said a 22-year-old man with “strong, extremist beliefs inspired by ISIS” had attacked another man at a park outside Sydney.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — A man who stabbed and critically wounded another man in a park in a Sydney suburb on Saturday was inspired by Islamic State extremists, the police here said on Sunday.

headline: Collision at Home Shakes Up Wilmer Flores and Leaves Mets Reeling
abstract: The Mets had a chance to take the lead against the Braves in the eighth, but a miscue by Manager Terry Collins ended with Flores facedown on the ground at the plate.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — After Saturday’s 4-3 loss to the Atlanta Braves in 10 innings, Mets Manager Terry Collins sat in his office waiting to speak with reporters as he normally does. This time, though, he had a confession to make.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Churchill’s Secret’ and ‘Son of Zorn’
abstract: In “Churchill’s Secret,” Michael Gambon plays Britain’s prime minister in 1953, determined to hide his stroke. And “Son of Zorn” blends animated and real characters.
lead_paragraph: In “Churchill’s Secret,” Michael Gambon plays Britain’s aging prime minister in 1953, determined to hide his debilitating stroke from the world. “Son of Zorn” blends animated and real characters in the tale of a He-Man-style warrior trying to win back his ex-wife and son. And a new season of “Masters of Sex” plays musical chairs in and out of the bedroom.

headline: Anti-Semitism and the British Left
abstract: Jeremy Corbyn’s leadership of the Labour Party has alienated Britain’s Jews.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Opponents of Jeremy Corbyn, the left-wing leader of Britain’s Labour Party, usually claim one of two things about him: that his politics are extreme and will lead the party to electoral oblivion, or that his values are admirable but he is too incompetent to put them into effect.

headline: Few Expect China to Punish North Korea for Latest Nuclear Test
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Nuclear Tests', 'International Relations', 'United States International Relations', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems']
abstract: Pyongyang’s aggression is an embarrassment for Beijing, but a collapsed North Korean regime worries Chinese leaders much more, analysts say.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — North Korea’s biggest nuclear test, conducted last week less than 50 miles from the Chinese border, sent tremors through homes and schools in China’s northeast. But hours later, there was no mention of the test on China’s state-run evening television news, watched by hundreds of millions of viewers.

abstract: Victoria Beckham and Opening Ceremony keep the theatrics coming.
lead_paragraph: Day of rest? Nah. New York Fashion Week continues; so does sweaty weather. Dress accordingly. Here’s what you’ll see today.

headline: Gems from the Deep
abstract: Synthetic rubies, recovered from a sunken ship, now feature in a commemorative jewelry collection.
lead_paragraph: BEAULIEU, England — When divers searched the wreckage of the S.S. Persia off the coast of Crete in 2003, they found some remarkable cargo: more than 200 gemstones, including rubies, amethysts, moonstones and what are believed to be some of the first mass-produced synthetic rubies.

headline: Daniele Gatti, Creative Risk-Taker, Picks Up Baton at Royal Concertgebouw
abstract: The 54-year-old Italian assumes the post of conductor with the hope of expanding its repertoire.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — The first time Daniele Gatti stepped inside the Concertgebouw concert hall in Amsterdam, he was 30 years old and wearing jeans and a T-shirt. The young Italian conductor had just come off a 10-day cycling tour through the Netherlands, and when he arrived in Amsterdam he saw that tickets were still available for that evening’s performance. He bought cheap seats and sat on the onstage podium behind the double basses.

headline: Tianjin Mayor Caught Up in Xi’s Antigraft Campaign
abstract: An announcement said the official was “suspected of severe disciplinary violations,” which usually means taking bribes or other kinds of corruption.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — President Xi Jinping’s grinding campaign against graft and disloyalty in the Chinese government claimed another powerful victim over the weekend, when the Communist Party’s disciplinary agency announced that the mayor of Tianjin, a northern port city, was under investigation.

lead_paragraph: ■ The Oakland Raiders defense may need some tightening up, but their offense can keep up with Drew Brees in the Superdome and their coach’s Twitter game is decidedly elite.

headline: Raised Hackles and Shears Over a Lottery Card Mix-Up
abstract: Jose Cardoso, 81, said he did not know a New York Millions ticket belonged to another man when he picked it up off a counter. And that led to a scene and his arrest.
lead_paragraph: The old man shuffled along West 10th Street on Thursday toward the police station in Manhattan. He has lived next door for decades. He had a question.

headline: Silence May Be Good News for Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Some believe that secret supporters will vent their anger and resentment only in the privacy of the voting booth, which could be skewing poll figures.
lead_paragraph: There is talk among Republicans, and some trepidation among Democrats, that Donald J. Trump could benefit from a silent vote. Although these voters aren’t captured by polls, the privacy of a voting booth or a mail-in ballot will allow them to vent their anger and resentments.

abstract: This film’s backers laid the groundwork for an Oscar campaign with appearances by Pharrell Williams and Taraji P. Henson at the Toronto film festival.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — With a free concert by Pharrell Williams and tearful appearances from the starry cast, the makers of “Hidden Figures,” the coming film about black female mathematicians working at NASA during Jim Crow, charmed public and private audiences at the Toronto International Film Festival here while laying the groundwork for an Oscar campaign.

headline: 1966: East Germans Bulldoze Way to Freedom
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: East Germans clash through the Berlin wall in a bulldozer in September 1966.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Two East German couples and a child crashed through Communist barbed wire in a steel-plated bulldozer today [Sept. 11] and escaped into West Berlin. East German border guards riddled the bulldozer with sub-machine-gun bullets but it got through a trench and three barbed-wire barriers into West Berlin’s Spandau district. Steel plates placed around the bulldozer’s cabin saved the five refugees – two pregnant women, their husbands and a four year-old boy. Two bullets grazed the heads of one man and woman. They were treated for flesh wounds at a West Berlin hospital and then released.

headline: Beauty Q. & A.: Taylor Hill on Her Alexander Wang Debut
abstract: The Victoria’s Secret supermodel chatted with T about the surf-punk bobs at the designer’s spring/summer 2017 show, and her own hair and skin routine.
lead_paragraph: Alexander Wang always casts a band of cool, of-the-moment models to appear in his runway shows, and his spring/summer 2017 lineup was no different — the mix of faces was both fresh and familiar, and included the doe-eyed, Colorado-bred Taylor Hill. While the 20-year-old has already landed campaigns for Miu Miu, earned her Victoria’s Secret wings and recently become the face for Lancôme, this marked her first time walking for Wang. As it turns out, last night’s runway was full of surprises; the designer announced his collaboration with Adidas at the finale. Backstage, T caught up with Hill to talk about athletic workouts, the surfer-punk-inspired hair at the show and her splash-on-skincare routine.

headline: Prince Buster, Trailblazer of Ska, Dies at 78
abstract: The performer and producer transformed Jamaican music in the 1960s, generating hundreds of songs with an emphasis on the backbeat.
lead_paragraph: Prince Buster, a performer and producer who transformed Jamaican music in the 1960s as a trailblazer of the ska beat, died on Thursday in Miami. He was 78.

headline: 1916: Lloyd George Visits Verdun
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Lloyd George visits Verdun in September 1916.
lead_paragraph: The eloquence of Mr. Lloyd George was framed in a dramatic setting when, while paying a visit to the French front, accompanied by M. Albert Thomas, French Under-Secretary for Artillery, he partook of a frugal meal last Friday with the officers in the underground defences of Verdun. In the casemates of the citadel of Verdun, under those vaulted roofs, fashioned in solid rock, at depths which render them impregnable, the officers of the defence were on September 8 filled with an intense emotion.

headline: The New DVF and the Incredible Lightness of Legacy
abstract: Jonathan Saunders reimagines Diane von Furstenberg.
lead_paragraph: There is a ritual that pretty much all designers who take on a legacy brand have to go through when they start their new jobs: a visit to the archives. There, surrounded by the past, they can be steeped in the history of the house, the better to channel its essence as they enter the atelier.

headline: Spate of Deadly Attacks in Syria Ahead of Cease-Fire
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Terrorism', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: At least 91 people have been killed in strikes on rebel-held areas in the two days since Russia and the United States declared that a cease-fire would begin on Monday.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Bags of body parts. Three young siblings killed along with their mother. A pregnant woman lying dead under a fallen roof.

headline: ‘Sully’ Flies High and Lands Smoothly at the Box Office
abstract: Clint Eastwood’s latest film, starring Tom Hanks, collected an estimated $35.5 million at North American cinemas over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: “Sully,” the kind of adult-oriented, midbudget drama that isn’t supposed to succeed in theaters anymore, at least if you listen to franchise-obsessed studio executives, soared at the box office over the weekend.

headline: Venice Film Festival Announces Winners
keywords: ['Movies', 'Venice International Film Festival', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors']
abstract: Films by Lav Diaz and Tom Ford took top prizes on the festival’s last day, as did Emma Stone for her performance in “La La Land.”
lead_paragraph: The Venice Film Festival announced its winners on Sunday, with Lav Diaz’s “The Woman Who Left” winning the top prize for best film and Emma Stone winning for best actress for “La La Land.”

headline: Tome: Spring 2017
abstract: Ryan Lobo and Ramon Martin show their latest collection.
lead_paragraph: Ryan Lobo and Ramon Martin show their latest collection.

headline: Photos: Tommy Hilfiger, Alexander Wang, Victoria Beckham and More

lead_paragraph: Backstage and on runway at some of New York Fashion Week’s most Instagrammed shows, including Tommy Hilfiger, Alexander Wang and Monse.

headline: Hashtag Fashion on the Rise
abstract: When social media meets style, who wins? Lessons from Alexander Wang, Tommy Hilfiger and Victoria Beckham.
lead_paragraph: We live in a time of bifurcation and oppositions: Trump vs. Clinton, the one percent vs. the 99 percent, globalism vs. isolationism. So it shouldn’t be a surprise to any of us, really, that fashion is right on trend. There’s a rift opening in New York Fashion Week, with big blowout extravaganzas facing off against quieter, more traditional collections; hashtag hoo-has against analogue outreach. It’s an either-or moment.

headline: Afghan Police Chief Is Killed as He Tries to Turn Tide Against Taliban
abstract: The police chief, Gen. Zarawar Zahid, was visiting an outpost when explosives detonated. The Taliban claimed responsibility for his death.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A hard-charging Afghan police chief with deep experience in Afghanistan’s long conflict with the Taliban was killed in a blast on Sunday in the country’s eastern Nangarhar Province, which has been under threat from the Taliban and affiliates of the Islamic State.

headline: Alexander Wang, Naomi Campbell and Karlie Kloss Party on Saturday Night of Fashion Week
abstract: Doutzen Kroes hosts #KnotOnMyPlanet benefit for the Elephant Crisis Fund; Madonna and Nicki Minaj at Alexander Wang; Blood Orange performs for Re/Done jeans.
lead_paragraph: Doutzen Kroes hosts #KnotOnMyPlanet benefit for the Elephant Crisis Fund; Madonna and Nicki Minaj at Alexander Wang; Blood Orange performs for Re/Done jeans.

headline: Christian Siriano, a Designer for all Body Types
abstract: After dressing Michelle Obama and “Saturday Night Live” star Leslie Jones, he attracted a celebrity-studded front row at New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday afternoon, seated in the front row of Christian Siriano’s sartorial sojourn to Capri were Kelly Osbourne, Coco Rocha, Christina Hendricks, Pamela Anderson, Neve Campbell and Jaimie Alexander.

headline: Ireland Doesn’t Want Apple’s Back Taxes, but the Irish Aren’t So Sure
keywords: ['Corporate Taxes', 'Tax Shelters', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: After six years of belt-tightening and tax increases, many Irish workers say their government’s reluctance to collect $14.5 billion from Apple is unfair.
lead_paragraph: CORK, Ireland — When European officials ordered Ireland to collect a record $14.5 billion in back taxes from Apple, Kieran O’Connell drew up a wish list for spending the money.

headline: After Centuries of Loss, Seeds of Hope for Argentina’s Indigenous People
keywords: ['Indigenous People', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Ranquel communities have emerged as patient champions of indigenous rights in a nation that is conflicted about the past and about the appropriate response now.
lead_paragraph: VICTORICA, Argentina — Each year on the night of June 23, they gather at the sacred outpost on the brown flatlands to celebrate New Year’s on a pre-Columbian calendar. Wearing ponchos and a type of jewelry called tupu, they make offerings of food, feast on barbecued ribs and tell stories. In the morning, they march around a ceremonial wooden stake and a fire fueled through the night to honor the land.

headline: Where to Stay for $39 a Night in New York City? In a Yellow Cab
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers']
abstract: A decommissioned taxi parked on a street in Long Island City is no one’s idea of a luxury vacation, but at less than $40 a night (and no bathroom), few can complain about the price.
lead_paragraph: It may have a great view of Manhattan, but this vacation rental sits in parking spaces in Long Island City, Queens, and has no bathroom. And it has a bit of that old car smell.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Sept. 12
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: As More Devices Board Planes, Travelers Are Playing With Fire
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Batteries', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Consumer Protection', 'Smartphones', 'Lithium (Metal)']
abstract: The batteries in phones and laptops pose fire hazards, and experts caution that the odds could catch up with the air-traveling public.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Aviation Administration, citing fire hazards, has warned against using Samsung Galaxy Note 7 smartphones on aircraft. Three Australian airlines and the German carrier Lufthansa have outright banned their use onboard.

headline: Why Business Class Poses a Unique Fire Hazard
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Smartphones', 'Batteries', 'Fires and Firefighters']
abstract: Electronically adjustable airline seats are comfy, but they can crush a cellphone — and the volatile battery inside it.
lead_paragraph: In mid-May and again in late June, business-class passengers on Qantas flights from Australia to the United States dropped their smartphones into the mechanism below their seats.

headline: Madonna, Zoë Kravitz and More Come Out for Alexander Wang
abstract: Pamela Anderson, Skrillex and Nicki Minaj were also in the front row of the designer’s fashionably late show.
lead_paragraph: Pamela Anderson may not be the first pulp icon to feature prominently in a designer’s ad campaign. (For that, thank Marc Jacobs, who once cast Victoria Beckham, better known in those days as Posh Spice, in a series of irreverent ads.) But Ms. Anderson was certainly among the first, alongside Kim Kardashian, to make a selling point of her famously pneumatic curves for a fancy, high-priced brand.

headline: How Countries Like the Philippines Fall Into Vigilante Violence
abstract: Social scientists who study extrajudicial killings say the real story is more complicated — and more tragic — than a simple story of good versus evil.
lead_paragraph: When campaigning for the Philippine presidency last spring, Rodrigo Duterte promised to kill so many criminals that “fish will grow fat” in Manila Bay from feasting on their corpses.

headline: Nate Parker Deflects Questions About His Past to Push ‘The Birth of a Nation’ in Toronto
abstract: At a news conference at the Toronto International Film Festival with his co-stars, the filmmaker refused to apologize about rape charges he faced in college.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — A Sunday news conference in Toronto for “The Birth of a Nation,” the controversy-mired film about Nat Turner’s slave revolt, seemed geared for one thing: It would give the film’s director and star, Nate Parker, the chance to fully address sexual assault allegations from his past that have largely overshadowed the film.

headline: Italian Grows Forgotten Fruit. What She Preserves Is a Culture.
keywords: ['Trees and Shrubs', 'Fruit', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Biodiversity', 'Endangered and Extinct Species']
abstract: Like her father before her, Isabella Dalla Ragione scours the countryside in search of varieties that no longer satisfy agricultural trends, market demands and modern tastes.
lead_paragraph: SAN LORENZO DI LERCHI, Italy — There are probably few places as tranquil as the languorous hills that surround Umbria’s Città di Castello. But on her farm, Isabella Dalla Ragione pursues a personal mission — saving ancient fruit trees from extinction — with a strong sense of urgency.

headline: Hood by Air: Spring 2017
abstract: Shayne Oliver, whose street-inspired aesthetic was recently worn by Rihanna at the VMAs, presents his spring 2017 collection.
lead_paragraph: Shayne Oliver, whose street-inspired aesthetic was recently worn by Rihanna at the VMAs, presents his spring 2017 collection.

headline: Elon Musk Says Pending Tesla Updates Could Have Prevented Fatal Crash
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: The upgrades to Tesla’s Autopilot system will require drivers to refrain from taking their hands off the wheel for long periods and will use radar to better identify potential obstacles in the road.
lead_paragraph: Tesla Motors is readying improvements to its Autopilot technology that might have prevented an accident in May that took the life of an Ohio man, Tesla’s chief executive said on Sunday. The man was killed when his Model S car driving in Autopilot crashed into a tractor-trailer.

headline: Sies Marjan: Spring 2017
abstract: Looks from Sander Lak’s second collection.
lead_paragraph: Looks from Sander Lak’s second collection.

headline: Angela Merkel’s Problems in Germany Could Challenge Europe, Too
keywords: ['Elections', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: The chancellor is under growing political pressure over her migration policy at a time when the Continent is looking for strong leadership.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Even Angela Merkel, the usually unruffled veteran of European crises after almost 11 years as chancellor of Germany, had to admit it last week: “The world finds itself in a critical condition,” she said, and there is no point “in painting anything rosier than it is.”

headline: Band of Outsiders Returns
abstract: The new Band is not the old. It is a slouchier take on what the label once was, still with a mix of tailoring and American sportswear.
lead_paragraph: The new Band is not the old. It is a slouchier take on what the label once was, still with a mix of tailoring and American sportswear.

headline: Opportunity, Like Bengals Receivers, Slips Past the Jets
abstract: The Jets got sterling play from their defensive line and ran and threw the ball effectively for stretches, but blunders in their secondary spelled doom in Week 1.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The scheduling doyens at N.F.L. headquarters did not do the Jets any early-season favors. Five of their first six opponents this season made the playoffs last season, a maze of danger that began Sunday afternoon when the Cincinnati Bengals visited MetLife Stadium.

headline: On 9/11 Anniversary, Somber Reflections on Lives, and a World, Changed
keywords: ['September 11 (2001)', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Terrorism', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Pentagon Building', '1 World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Funerals and Memorials']
abstract: Relatives of those who died in the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, gathered in Lower Manhattan, at the Pentagon and in Shanksville, Pa., to commemorate the 15th anniversary.
lead_paragraph: With the ringing of a bell, the thousands who gathered in Lower Manhattan fell silent on Sunday, and all that could be heard was the water cascading in the reflecting pools where the World Trade Center towers once stood.

headline: From 280 Tribes, a Protest on the Plains
abstract: Native American representatives have gathered in North Dakota, demonstrating against an oil pipeline in what activists are calling the largest, most diverse tribal action in at least a century.
lead_paragraph: Native American representatives have gathered in North Dakota, demonstrating against an oil pipeline in what activists are calling the largest, most diverse tribal action in at least a century.

headline: Amazon and Pandora to Gauge Music’s Value in the Internet Age
keywords: ['Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Music', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: The companies are planning to charge as little as $5 a month for new streaming music services, half the cost of the current pricing model.
lead_paragraph: How much are people willing to spend for streaming music?

headline: Rays Put a Dent in the Yankees’ Fragile Postseason Aspirations
abstract: With three homers off Yankees starter Luis Cessa, who had gone 2-0 since he moved into the rotation on Aug. 20, Tampa Bay prevented a four-game sweep.
lead_paragraph: During the past week, with a grab bag of wall-scaling catches and rookie game-ending home runs, the Yankees elevated themselves into the thick of the American League playoff race on multiple fronts, while also inflating their confidence to highs that were unimaginable for much of this season.

headline: Review: Resonant Bodies Festival Blends Freedom With Radiance
abstract: Even as it delved into the experimental, this year’s installment of a contemporary vocal music festival was infused with a holy solemnity.
lead_paragraph: There’s solemnity in the name of the Resonant Bodies Festival, an annual celebration of contemporary vocal music now in its fourth year. But this time, there was also solemnity in the concerts, which seemed at times like a series of small religious services.

headline: Review: ‘The Secret Agent’ Is Reimagined on AcornTV
abstract: This streamed BBC adaptation of Joseph Conrad’s 1907 novel centers on a London shop owner who is also a spy for Russia.
lead_paragraph: The BBC can’t seem to leave “The Secret Agent” alone — it’s commissioned four adaptations of Joseph Conrad’s 1907 novel about the social and psychological underpinnings of a bomb attack. That probably says less about Conrad than it does about the continuing relevance of terrorism as a subject for fictional examination.

headline: With Spain in Political Deadlock, Catalans Renew Calls for Independence
abstract: Hundreds of thousands took to the streets of Barcelona and four other cities to urge their leaders to push for separation from Spain.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — Hundreds of thousands of pro-independence Catalans took over downtown Barcelona and four other cities on Sunday to urge their politicians to push ahead with plans to break away from the rest of Spain.

headline: Trying to Make JonBenet Ramsey Must-See TV, Again
abstract: The approach of the 20th anniversary of this Colorado girl’s murder prompts a barrage of programming, but why?
lead_paragraph: Television can be a great unifier, and that can be a useful thing — in a time of national crisis or triumph, for instance. But not always. At the moment TV seems determined to have us all believe that we should be ghoulishly obsessed with the ugly murder of a 6-year-old girl 20 years ago.

abstract: Relatives of those who died in the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, gathered in Lower Manhattan, at the Pentagon and in Shanksville, Pa.
lead_paragraph: Relatives of those who died in the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, gathered in Lower Manhattan, at the Pentagon and in Shanksville, Pa.

headline: ‘Mischling,’ a Holocaust Tale of Twin Sisters in Mengele’s Grip
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The 12-year-old heroines in Affinity Konar’s affecting novel seem to have been partly inspired by Eva and Miriam Mozes, twins at Auschwitz.
lead_paragraph: “During the period of the past century that I call Night,” Elie Wiesel wrote in a 2005 essay, “medicine was practiced in certain places not to heal but to harm, not to fight off death but to serve it. In the conflict between Good and Evil during the Second World War, the infamous Nazi doctors played a crucial role. They preceded the torturers and assassins in the science of organized cruelty that we call the Holocaust.”

headline: Dos Equis Makes Its Case for Its New ‘Most Interesting Man’
abstract: The beer brand said its survey of about 1,000 men ages 21 to 35 found that what’s interesting now is different from a decade ago, when it hired its longtime spokesman.
lead_paragraph: FOR nearly a decade, Dos Equis has advertised its beer through a pitchman known as the “Most Interesting Man in the World.”

headline: A Consolation of Voices: At the Park Avenue Armory, Mourning the World Over
abstract: Mourning in many cultures calls for ceremonies with paid professionals. Now the art of mourning can be seen and heard at the Park Avenue Armory.
lead_paragraph: It might be easier to get a soul to heaven than to get a professional mourner to New York City.

abstract: A group of young people committed to rewriting the rules that govern Hong Kong’s relationship with China were swept into office in elections.
lead_paragraph: A group of young people committed to rewriting the rules that govern Hong Kong’s relationship with China were swept into office on Sunday in elections

headline: Asia Argento and Others Are Angry About Being in JT LeRoy Documentary
abstract: “Author: The JT LeRoy Story” has excerpts from phone calls a hoaxer secretly recorded while posing as JT LeRoy. Many on tape are now vexed.
lead_paragraph: When JT LeRoy, a young H.I.V.-positive novelist from West Virginia, whose fiction supposedly mirrored his tough life as a teenage hustler, was revealed in 2006 to be a literary hoax, many who had considered themselves friends or sought to help his career felt betrayed.

headline: Rhiannon Giddens Brings Diversity to Banjo Award
abstract: Ms. Giddens is the first woman and nonwhite musician to win the Steve Martin Prize for Excellence in Banjo and Bluegrass.
lead_paragraph: Reflecting on the last few months of her career, Rhiannon Giddens said recently, “It’s been a rather roller-coastery kind of year.” And she can reasonably make this claim: This musician, vocalist and co-founder of the Carolina Chocolate Drops, the Grammy Award-winning string band, has experienced peaks like being cast in the new season of the TV drama “Nashville,” and lows, like seeing her much anticipated Broadway debut unravel before it could happen.

headline: Seth Lugo’s Underdog Story Continues With Another Mets Win
abstract: Lugo, who allowed two runs against the Braves, wants to aid the Mets’ playoff run but has another incentive to pitch well: He is trying to pay off his student loans.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — When he was a little-known minor league pitcher, Seth Lugo made little money, netting $200 a month, he estimated. To save money while he was playing for Class AAA Las Vegas this season, Lugo even lived with his agent’s mother.

headline: Akin to a Semicolon
abstract: Victor Fleming and Andrea Carla Michaels start off our solving week.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — There is nothing quite like starting one’s solving week with an Andrea Carla Michaels byline. Easy and fun, her puzzles, solo and collaborative, are often like an amuse-bouche for the rest of the week, and they make me smile. Her collaborator, Victor Fleming, has hit for the cycle (had a puzzle published on each day of the week at least once) and inspired this entertaining Monday crossword.

headline: A New Phase for World of Warcraft’s Lead Designer: His Own Start-Up
abstract: Rob Pardo, a gaming idol, is taking his reputation, experience and some of his former colleagues to his newest venture, Bonfire Studios.
lead_paragraph: Big video games, like movies, are usually created by squadrons of people, including dozens or hundreds of artists and developers.

headline: Cary Blanchard, Journeyman Kicker Who Delivered in the Clutch, Dies at 47
abstract: Blanchard’s career was not particularly stable, taking him to several N.F.L. teams, but he often had a decisive impact on key games and made a Pro Bowl as a Colt.
lead_paragraph: Cary Blanchard, a clutch place-kicker who played for the Giants and the Jets and helped the Indianapolis Colts reach the American Football Conference championship game in January 1996, died on Sept. 6 in Gun Barrel City, Tex. He was 47.

lead_paragraph: Moments from the shows of Tome, Hood by Air, Victoria Beckham and more.

headline: Never Forget: Sept. 12
abstract: Fifteen years ago, America’s NATO allies proved their commitment to collective defense. That promise lives on.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Americans will always remember Sept. 11, 2001. Fifteen years later, the feelings of confusion, shock and loss from the deadly attack on our country are still vivid. But the next day, Sept. 12, 2001, was also historic. That was the day America’s staunchest allies stood with us in solidarity, ready to respond in America’s time of need. It was the day when our then 18 NATO allies invoked, for the first and only time in history, Article 5 of the Washington Treaty, the clause that declares that an attack on one nation is an attack on all.

lead_paragraph: It will not be the trial of the century. It may just feel as if it has taken that long to get underway.

abstract: Mrs. Schlafly, who died Sept. 5, mobilized forces to block passage of the Equal Rights Amendment, which had been ratified by all but three needed states before it was tabled.
lead_paragraph: The passage of time had in no way eroded life’s certitudes for Phyllis Schlafly. “It was a tremendous victory,” she said in May about her greatest triumph, stopping the Equal Rights Amendment in its tracks four decades ago.

headline: Michelle Obama Brings Voters’ Trust to Hillary Clinton’s Campaign
abstract: Mrs. Obama will this week put her broad popularity and reputation for authenticity to work for a candidate who has suffered from a lack of both.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Michelle Obama has bridled for years at the confines of life in the White House and has tried to steer clear of the partisan messiness that has consumed her husband and is fueling this year’s bare-knuckled presidential contest.

headline: Stan Wawrinka Solves Top-Seeded Novak Djokovic to Win Third Major Title
abstract: The Swiss Wawrinka overwhelmed the Serb Djokovic in four sets at Flushing Meadows, leaving Wimbledon as the only Grand Slam that Wawrinka has not yet claimed.
lead_paragraph: For the third time in the past three seasons, Stan Wawrinka has done the toughest thing in tennis: stop Novak Djokovic in the latter stages of a Grand Slam tournament.

headline: Marriage Falls in China, Transforming Finances and Families

abstract: The drop in marriage stems in part from China’s aging population, but also reflects that women who once were pushed to wed are exploring new options.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Liu Zhenfeng got married at 25. The usual trappings of family life followed — a daughter, a home, furniture, toys.

headline: Militia Seizes Libyan Oil Terminals in Challenge to Government
abstract: A militia attacked and seized as many as three major oil terminals, not long after the militia that had held them signed a deal with the unity government to resume oil exports.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Fighting erupted in Libya’s oil crescent on Sunday when forces loyal to the dominant militia commander in eastern Libya attacked and seized as many as three major oil terminals, military and civilian officials said.

headline: Alexander Wang, Naomi Campbell and Karlie Kloss Party on Saturday Night of Fashion Week
abstract: Fashion week doesn’t pause for the weekend — and neither do the parties.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday night, Doutzen Kroes hosted the #KnotOnMyPlanet benefit for the Elephant Crisis Fund; Madonna and Nicki Minaj were among the celebrity guests at Alexander Wang; and Blood Orange performed for Re/Done jeans.

headline: At Altuzarra, a Party-Ready Touch of Glitter
abstract: The makeup artist Tom Pecheux created a “sweaty, sexy, naughty” look — and at least one model didn’t want to take it off after the show.
lead_paragraph: Backstage at the Altuzarra spring/summer 2017 show this afternoon, the makeup artist Tom Pecheux was his usual chic, irreverent self. Smiling, he described the beautifully dewy look he created as “sweaty, sexy, naughty,” with a bit of a wink to reporters. The effect, he explained, picked up on the energetic, playful vibes of Joseph Altuzarra’s collection and channels the women who emerge from a pool or shower and “throw on their clothes and they just go.” For the high-shine look, he swept Butter Elixir botanical oil over the skin, patted on creamy foundation, and dusted MAC Mineralize SkinFinish in Perfectly Lit across the upper cheeks and nose in a wavelike formation for a natural glow. On the eyes, Pecheux applied black eyeliner smudged in with MAC Neon Studio Eye Gloss, a fleshy tone that warms up the black eyeliner so “it’s not so aggressive” and doesn’t look too pristine (“perfection is boring,” he said, with Parisian insouciance). But the glamorous twist? Pecheux lightly dappled MAC Glitter in Reflects Bronze over the models’ faces — the fine particles floating through the air before they gently landed on the skin to produce a subtle shimmer.

headline: In Connecticut, a Wealth Gap Divides Neighboring Schools
abstract: Fairfield and Bridgeport sit side by side and spend more per student than the national average, but the quality of the education they offer is worlds apart.
lead_paragraph: The two Connecticut school districts sit side by side along Long Island Sound. Both spend more than the national average on their students. They prepare their pupils for the same statewide tests. Their teachers, like virtually all the teachers in the state, earn the same high marks on evaluations.

headline: Visa Program Up for Renewal Amid Allegations of Fraud
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Visas', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Foreign Investments']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A contentious visa program that allows wealthy foreigners to obtain a green card by investing in economic development projects will expire at the end of this month unless Congress acts to extend it.

headline: Eddie Antar, Retailer and Felon Who Created Crazy Eddie, Dies at 68
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Racketeering and Racketeers', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: Mr. Antar expanded his business from a single Brooklyn store, founded in 1969, into the largest consumer electronics chain in the New York metropolitan area.
lead_paragraph: Eddie Antar, the Brooklyn-born man who created the chain of Crazy Eddie electronics stores only to watch it collapse when an underlying fraud was exposed, died on Saturday. He was 68.

headline: For Two Rising Prospects, a Day of Victory and Redemption
abstract: Félix Auger-Aliassime of Canada and Kayla Day breezed to junior titles at the U.S. Open.
lead_paragraph: The last time Félix Auger-Aliassime was in the final of a Grand Slam junior event was in Paris, where he was seen firing his rackets onto the ground after a brutal loss. It was a match he had had on his racket three times, but he had blown each match point to Geoffrey Blancaneaux.

headline: Atlanta’s BeltLine: An Ambitious Plan to Bring a City Together
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Transit Systems', 'Cable Cars and Trams']
abstract: Planners say the biking and pedestrian loop, when finished, will link 45 of the city’s neighborhoods, and has already proven to be a boon to civic pride.
lead_paragraph: Planners say the biking and pedestrian loop, when finished, will link 45 of the city’s neighborhoods, and has already proven to be a boon to civic pride.

headline: A Glorified Sidewalk, and the Path to Transform Atlanta
keywords: ['Cable Cars and Trams', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Transit Systems']
abstract: The Atlanta BeltLine project, which would circle the city’s urban core with a biking and pedestrian loop, aims to rejuvenate an area known for suburban sprawl.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Could this traffic-clogged Southern city, long derided as the epitome of suburban sprawl, really be discovering its walkable, bike-friendly, density-embracing, streetcar-riding, human-scale soul?

headline: Kanye West Performs at the Harper’s Bazaar Fashion Week Party
abstract: Kylie Jenner, Coco Rocha and other fashion elites celebrate the magazine’s “Icons by Carine Roitfled” at the Plaza Hotel; Julianne Moore and Keri Russell toast Gemfields at the Jane Hotel.
lead_paragraph: It was either the event of New York Fashion Week or Kanye overload. On Friday night, Kanye West performed at the Harper’s Bazaar Icons party at the Plaza Hotel, which was packed with a crowd from Hollywood and the fashion world.

headline: Just in Time for the Giants, a Star Turn From Victor Cruz

lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — The Giants began the 2016 season on Sunday inside the home of the Dallas Cowboys, returning to the humiliating scene of last year’s season opener. In that memorable game, a late, bungled sequence near the Dallas goal line led to a devastating Giants defeat that set the tone for a disastrous season.

headline: From Staten Island to a 9/11 Memorial, a Bus Ride Becomes a Ritual
keywords: ['September 11 (2001)', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Terrorism', 'Volunteers and Community Service']
abstract: As they have each year since 2002, a group of people who lost family members on Sept. 11 shared a ride from Staten Island to the memorial events.
lead_paragraph: They started arriving before dawn, pulling into the empty, lamp-lit parking lot of the Staten Island Mall, just as they had every year for the past 14 years. They had come on Sunday to board a bus to make the same short yet difficult trip to Manhattan, returning to the place where their loved ones had been killed.

keywords: ['Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Terrorism', 'United States Politics and Government']

abstract: At stadiums around the league, the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and their victims were recalled with flag displays, military tributes and predominantly traditional attention to the national anthem.

About the only people who seem to watch are fans waiting to buy food and drinks, if they bother to look at all.

headline: Review: ‘The Wolves’: A Pack of Female Warriors, Each Determined to Score

The scary, exhilarating brightness of raw adolescence emanates from every scene of this uncannily assured first play by Sarah DeLappe, and at times your instinct is to shade your eyes.

headline: Thugs and Kisses
abstract: Who admires Putin, and why?
lead_paragraph: First of all, let’s get this straight: The Russian Federation of 2016 is not the Soviet Union of 1986. True, it covers most of the same territory and is run by some of the same thugs. But the Marxist ideology is gone, and so is the superpower status. We’re talking about a more or less ordinary corrupt petrostate here, although admittedly a big one that happens to have nukes.

headline: Suing Journalists in Mexico
keywords: ['Corruption (Institutional)', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Censorship', 'News and News Media', 'Libel and Slander', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Editorials']
abstract: The impact of Mexico’s new anticorruption law depends on the ability of journalists to do critical work without facing specious lawsuits.
lead_paragraph: This summer, responding to public outrage over a spate of government corruption scandals, Mexican lawmakers passed a strong anticorruption law that requires public officials to be more transparent about their finances. Whether that will help end Mexico’s culture of cronyism and graft will depend largely on journalists being able to investigate and report about the ruling class.

keywords: ['Organized Labor', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Collective Bargaining', 'Graduate Schools and Students', 'Editorial Observer', 'Editorials']
abstract: Will private universities keep fighting despite the recent National Labor Relations Board ruling on graduate assistants?
lead_paragraph: Life for many graduate students is about to change for the better. For decades, universities treated graduate teaching and research assistants not as professionals in their own right, but as supplicants working long hours for low pay in return for the privilege of being considered for the academic club.

headline: Teaching Calvin in California
abstract: Some think theology has no place in a secular classroom. I’ve learned otherwise.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — We spend a great deal of time worrying about theology these days. From extremist violence to the American culture wars, the theological imagination can feel like an existential threat to liberal democracy. Or more simply, just to common decency. No surprise that many believe that theology has no place in the secular college classroom.

headline: The Rise of Presidential Extremists
abstract: Candidates take extreme stands because there is little electoral consequence to doing so.
lead_paragraph: Political scientists teach their students that to win elections, the parties in a competitive two-party system must take policy positions that appeal to centrist “swing voters.” If voters choose the candidate closest to them ideologically, moderates will hold the crucial balance of power necessary to win a majority.

headline: Turkey’s Suspicious Mind-Set Has Been a Century in the Making
keywords: ['Psychology and Psychologists', 'Ottoman Empire', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Treaties']

lead_paragraph: Conspiracy theories about Western plots to undermine Turkey run so deep in the nation’s collective psyche that only the language of psychology is suitable to understanding them.

headline: Colin Kaepernick and the Question of Who Gets to Be Called a ‘Patriot’
keywords: ['Football', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'English Language', 'National Anthems']
abstract: There are countless ways to show love for your country. So why does it feel as if you also need to be the right kind of person and show it in the right kind of way?
lead_paragraph: Citizenship is citizenship, until appearances get in the way. The world now knows, for instance, that Colin Kaepernick, a quarterback for the San Francisco 49ers, is protesting racial injustice — all because of a routine photo, taken during the singing of the national anthem before a preseason game. The photographer, Jennifer Lee Chan, tweeted the image last month, writing, “This team formation for the national anthem is not Jeff Fisher-approved.” Fisher is the head coach of the Los Angeles Rams, who, in an episode of the reality football show “Hard Knocks,” told his team that standing for the anthem was sacrosanct: “It’s an opportunity to realize how lucky you are.” Yet here was Kaepernick, sitting down.

headline: An Architect Who Built His Career on Resuscitating New York Landmarks

lead_paragraph: Grand Central Terminal, the main building on Ellis Island and the Enid A. Haupt Conservatory at the New York Botanical Garden — all among the greatest New York City landmarks — look better today than they have since their earliest years.

lead_paragraph: CARLISLE, England — After this ancient fortress city was hit by a crippling flood in 2005, its residents could take some comfort in the fact that it was the kind of deluge that was supposed to happen about once every 200 years.

headline: Ikea Forever
abstract: By upping its design but not its prices, the Swedish giant is making its ephemeral furnishings more pervasive than ever.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, during an interview with the BBC, Kanye West announced, in his trademark third-person idiom, that he hoped to design for Ikea: “Yo, Ikea, allow Kanye to create, allow him to make this thing because you know what? I want a bed that he makes, I want a chair that he makes.” This seemed strange at first; what did West care about budget-friendly particleboard furniture? But if your goal is a kind of worldwide saturation, then collaborating with Ikea, with its 387 stores in 48 countries, is an ingenious tack. Ikea is one of the world’s largest consumers of lumber. It sells a set of its Billy bookcases every 10 seconds, and it’s said that one in 10 Europeans is conceived in an Ikea bed. Last year, approximately 884 million people — more than twice the population of the U.S. — visited Ikea stores. There’s even a web series called “Hikea,” in which people take psychedelics and attempt to assemble, from a wordless instruction manual, the pile of planks and screws in front of them. Ikea, not unlike West himself, is part of the zeitgeist.

headline: Postcards From the Hajj: A Good Hair Day

headline: High Blood Pressure in Children
abstract: Once considered an adult disease, it has become more common in children, largely because of increased obesity.

headline: Fail Better, America, on this 9/11 Anniversary

headline: 1966: Church May Elect Cardinals
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: The Roman Catholic Church may start electing cardinals in September 1966.
lead_paragraph: TURIN, Italy — The Roman Catholic College of Cardinals may be turned into an election body, with the top bishop of each nation serving a limited term according to an authoritative report here today. The Turin archdiocesan weekly ‘‘Ti Nostro Tempo’’ (Our Times) hinted that a plan was under study at the Vatican. Such a change would throw out the centuries-old system in which popes alone choose cardinals and appoint them for life. Under the new system, the heads of the Church’s 53 national and regional bishop’s conferences would become cardinals. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 13, 1966

headline: Can Beijing Stop Hong Kong’s Separatists?
keywords: ['Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: China’s tone-deaf leaders appear to think that taking a hard line against Hong Kong’s youth political movement can contain it.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Two years after China’s leadership slammed the door on political reform for Hong Kong, six young candidates running on separatist platforms won seats in the Sept. 4 election for the territory’s legislature. The rapid rise of a youthful political movement intent on gaining more independence for Hong Kong is a direct result of Beijing’s tightening grip on this former British colony.

headline: How Mexico and the U.S. Can Fix Migration
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Migrant Labor (Agriculture)', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Since 1965, the two governments haven’t worked together to regulate the flow of labor migrants. No wonder there’s a huge black market.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States and Mexico have a rich, shared history. For more than a century, people have moved back and forth at the border to work. Their toil and industry could have taken place within a well-regulated and mutually beneficial labor market. But in recent years much of their labor has occurred in a vast black market — harming workers, families, security and public finances in both countries.

headline: Donald Trump Seizes Hillary Clinton’s Absence to Press His Case
abstract: Mr. Trump scrambled to put his rival on the defensive, showing unusual restraint over her illness but denouncing her charge that many of his supporters were bigoted.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump hurled himself into a new effort to reshape the presidential race on Monday, scrambling to allay voters’ concerns about his temperament and put Hillary Clinton on the defensive over her critical comments about many of Mr. Trump’s supporters.

headline: A Constellation of One-Room Cabins, Embedded in the Forest
abstract: In a radically conceptual family retreat in Northern California, the architect Douglas Burnham has made temporary buildings dramatically consequential.
lead_paragraph: THE BACK ROADS THAT SNAKE through Mendocino County, a few hours from San Francisco, seem open to the sky and closed to outsiders. Here, where high-tech pot farms thrive amid the weekend homes and backyard wineries of Silicon Valley entrepreneurs, people like their privacy; no small talk or pancake breakfasts at the Elks lodge. Once in a while there’s a path, wide as a pickup, spanned with a padlocked metal gate and a discount-store-bought “No Trespassing” sign.

headline: Jimmy Garoppolo Rises From the Ashes of Deflategate
abstract: Using what appeared to be properly inflated balls, Garoppolo guided the Patriots past the Cardinals.
lead_paragraph: Passionate partisans on both sides of the Deflategate debate — and there are still many out there — will tell you that it was a battle between right and wrong, truth and lies, even good and evil.

headline: Mexico City’s Fading Art: Organ Grinders
abstract: Organ grinders in Mexico City say they are losing popularity. They face more competition and a younger population that does not appreciate their music.
lead_paragraph: Organ grinders in Mexico City say they are losing popularity. They face more competition and a younger population that does not appreciate their music.

headline: Mexico City’s Organ Grinders, Once Beloved, Feel Shunned
abstract: While their numbers may be growing, organists worry that a younger generation does not share the desire to preserve their culture and fails to appreciate the craft.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Business was not going well for Moisés Rosas. A saxophonist was down the street, making decent money. A young woman was loudly hawking eyeglass repair services. And Super Mario, stationed at the entrance to the pedestrian path, was drawing a crowd.

headline: What’s Daring Now? Hood by Air and Altuzarra Make a Statement
abstract: Hint: It’s not about sex. It’s politics — the mere appearance of.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to fashion, what’s shocking now? Or even (let’s lower the bar a bit) discomfiting, challenging, daring? After a summer when the burkini became an international cause célèbre, it’s not an irrelevant question. And in New York, an answer of sorts is starting to appear on the catwalks.

headline: Arson Suspected at Mosque That Orlando Nightclub Gunman Attended
abstract: Investigators said video showed a person approaching the Islamic Center of Fort Pierce before the flames flared early Monday. No one was in the building.
lead_paragraph: The members of the Islamic Center of Fort Pierce had broken their fasts and left the mosque near Florida’s eastern shoreline. In the waning minutes of Sunday, less than an hour later, a surveillance camera recorded a man as he approached the mosque. Then came a flash as flames damaged the house of worship where the man who attacked an Orlando, Fla., nightclub often prayed.

headline: Home and Work: Lia Chavez
abstract: The artist converted a 4,500-square-foot house on Long Island into a clean space to quiet her mind — and get to work.
lead_paragraph: The artist converted a 4,500-square-foot house on Long Island into a clean space to quiet her mind — and get to work.

headline: One Artist’s Long Island Home: A Meditation in White
abstract: The artist Lia Chavez lives in a minimalist’s dream.
lead_paragraph: “The moment I experienced the light here, I just knew that this was going to be a place — a really important place,” said the artist Lia Chavez, as we stepped out onto the back deck of the Long Island home she shares with her husband — and has transformed into a minimalist’s nirvana.

headline: Netanyahu Criticized for ‘Ethnic Cleansing’ Remarks
abstract: In a video titled “No Jews,” Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu accuses the Palestinian leadership of demanding a Jew-free Palestinian state by opposing Israeli settlements in the West Bank. He adds, “There’s a phrase for that: It’s called ethnic cleansing.”
lead_paragraph: In a video titled “No Jews,” Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu accuses the Palestinian leadership of demanding a Jew-free Palestinian state by opposing Israeli settlements in the West Bank. He adds, “There’s a phrase for that: It’s called ethnic cleansing.”

headline: This Decanter Aerates Wine in a Flash
abstract: An attractive glass decanter from the maker of the Rabbit wine opener is now available.
lead_paragraph: A well-designed decanter is the star of a new high-end line of brass-trimmed barware from the maker of the Rabbit wine opener called the RBT Collection. The secret is the stopper, which has a removable stainless-steel filtering screen and a series of tiny holes around the edge that send the wine down the sides of the wide glass vessel for better aeration. It’s wrapped in rubber for a tight fit. The decanter is easy to handle and can hold a magnum’s worth of wine. It comes with a protective acacia wood coaster: $99.95 at Bloomingdale’s, bloomingdales.com.

headline: An Olive Oil Revolution in Tunisia
abstract: Tunisian olive oils are now worth savoring thanks to tighter restrictions on labeling and production.
lead_paragraph: Tunisia was the featured country at this summer’s Fancy Food Show in New York, and almost half of that country’s exhibits were promoting extra-virgin olive oil. The industry, which has existed since Roman times, has shifted to a higher-end product for export to Europe and America. Although Tunisia’s extra-virgin olive oil is still sent in bulk to Europe for anonymous blending, production rules and labeling certifications for extra virgin and organic have been tightened. Now 100 percent of what’s in a bottle labeled Tunisian is indeed from Tunisia. Some oils tend to be lighter, sweeter and less peppery than their European counterparts. For example, Terra Delyssa Extra Virgin Olive Oil is typically mild and fruity with a hint of bitterness in the aftertaste (try it in a salad dressing), and Olivi Chemlali de Djerba Extra Virgin Olive Oil is lighter and even more delicate. Les Moulins de Mahjoub, an organic extra-virgin oil, is deeper in color, more viscous and herbal, with a nice green olive bite. It would add a sleek finish to grilled fish and vegetables: Terra Delyssa, $8.99 for 34 ounces, worldmarket.com; Olivi, $14.90 for 8.45 ounces, from amazon.com; Les Moulins de Mahjoub, $19.99 for 12.5 ounces, from amazon.com.

headline: How the Sugar Industry Shifted Blame to Fat
keywords: ['Sugar', 'Obesity', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Heart', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Oils and Fats', 'Research']
abstract: Newly discovered documents show that the sugar industry paid scientists in the 1960s to shape the debate around heart disease, sugar and fat.
lead_paragraph: The sugar industry paid scientists in the 1960s to play down the link between sugar and heart disease and promote saturated fat as the culprit instead, newly released historical documents show.

abstract: The educational program is aimed at middle school students, but critics say the fact it requires a tablet makes it unavailable to lower-income families.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones,’ of Course, Rules as First Emmys Are Handed Out
abstract: The show received nine Creative Arts Emmys, which cover technical categories and others left out of the Primetime Emmy Awards, which will air Sunday.
lead_paragraph: “Game of Thrones” continued its TV award dominance over the weekend, leading the way with nine Creative Arts Emmys. The awards, which cover technical categories and others left out of the Primetime Emmy Awards, like guest acting and nonfiction honors, were handed out Saturday and Sunday in a two-night ceremony in Los Angeles.

headline: Opening Ceremony Sends a Message (Plenty, in Fact)
abstract: In a combination beauty pageant, pep rally and consciousness raising, the label served up the most political statement of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: As a concept, the opening ceremony is synonymous with pageantry. As a company, Opening Ceremony — the fashion retailer and label — is synonymous with pageantry. Was it only a matter of time before Humberto Leon and Carol Lim, Opening Ceremony’s founders and stewards, made the connection literally?

headline: The Daily Bag: Victoria Beckham
abstract: T plucks the best bags right off the runway.
lead_paragraph: Victoria Beckham’s floral shopper tote and matching printed dress are the perfect spring camouflage. — MALINA JOSEPH GILCHRIST

abstract: T plucks the best jewels right off the runway.
lead_paragraph: Twisted door-knocker earrings make an especially strong statement in cherry red lacquer. — MALINA JOSEPH GILCHRIST

headline: Italian Staples Straight From the Source
abstract: LaRina Pastificio & Vino, a restaurant in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, is now selling its fresh pasta to the public.
lead_paragraph: LaRina Pastificio & Vino, an inviting new Italian neighborhood restaurant in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, offers an extra perk: a retail counter well stocked with food made both in-house and imported from Italy. Silvia Barban is the chef and an owner. Her fresh pasta includes buckwheat shells, black bucatini and ruffled lemon-scented gigli that begs for a sauce of crab meat and cherry tomatoes. Calabrian chiles, fat jars of anchovies, taralli biscuits, fresh sausages, Corbara tomatoes from the Naples area, and tartly sweet pomegranate balsamic vinegar from Modena are some of the other items. The counter opens with the restaurant at 5 p.m. Monday to Friday, 11 a.m. Saturday and Sunday: LaRina Pastificio & Vino, 387 Myrtle Avenue (Vanderbilt Avenue), Fort Greene, Brooklyn, 718-852-0001, larinabk.com.

headline: Airbnb, a Silicon Valley Titan, Breaks Ranks in Admitting Its Power
abstract: A plan by the home-rental site to curb bias among users rejects the logic of networks like Uber and Facebook, which claim to be neutral platforms.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, the idea of privilege — for whites, for men, for straights, and for others — has moved to the fore of American discourse.

headline: Brand to Know: A Curated Line of Very Special Things
abstract: The designers Fanny Singer and Mariah Nielson unveil the selections in their new label, Permanent Collections.
lead_paragraph: In culling pieces for their new label, Permanent Collection, Fanny Singer and Mariah Nielson relied on principles of museum acquisition: They sought “what is most elemental and classic,” says Singer, and took care to avoid “even short-term obsolescence.” Inspired by their own possessions, the things “we’d had the longest, that felt most relevant no matter what,” their first collection includes porcelain teacups cast from originals by Nielson’s father, the sculptor J.B. Blunk (her mother is the organic textiles pioneer Christine Nielson), and a pair of Attal leather slides like the ones a family friend once gave Singer, whose mother is Alice Waters. Nielson and Singer, both Northern California natives, met in a London bakery while wearing matching navy blue jackets, both vintage of indeterminate origin, and hit on the idea for the project.

headline: Dessert for Dinner and Other Recipes
abstract: “Clafoutis” is the word, and recipe, of the day.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Kate DiCamillo Among Candidates for Young People’s Literature Award
abstract: Others on the National Book Award longlist include Kwame Alexander, Grace Lin, Jason Reynolds and Nicola Yoon.
lead_paragraph: The National Book Foundation announced the Longlist for the 2016 National Book Award for Young People’s Literature on Monday. The 10 nominated books represent a stylistic and thematically diverse range, with fiction, a graphic memoir and nonfiction that address subjects like domestic violence, sexual identity, race, social activism and how children cope during war. The remaining longlists, for the poetry, nonfiction and fiction categories, will be announced over the next three days. Finalists will be revealed on Oct. 13, and the winners will be announced at a gala in New York City on Nov. 16.

headline: A Taste of How Beer Is Made
abstract: Blues, Brews and Botany at the Botanical Garden in the Bronx celebrates the plants used to make cider and beer.
lead_paragraph: Beer begins with plants, including grains and hops. To reinforce that connection, the New York Botanical Garden will have displays and demonstrations this weekend to explain the botany behind the brewing process. There will be tastings of beers and ciders, and, to liven things up, blues and bluegrass music: Blues, Brews and Botany, Saturday and Sunday, noon to 5 p.m., $30 for tasting for adults 21 and older ($5 for members), New York Botanical Garden, Bronx, nybg.org.

headline: Eddie Redmayne’s Guide to ‘Fantastic Beasts’
abstract: The star of J.K. Rowling’s new movie gives an exclusive look at the wonders within.
lead_paragraph: Anticipation for “Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them” has been so high that fans began dressing up as its main character, Newt Scamander, based solely on the trailer. That surprised its star, Eddie Redmayne, when he attended Comic-Con International in July and looked out into the audience only to see several Newts staring back at him.

headline: Thoma Bravo Raises $7.6 Billion Fund to Pursue More Tech Deals
abstract: Along with Vista Equity Partners, Thoma Bravo is one of the few specialists who focus solely on taking over aging tech companies and then turning them around.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — At a busy time for technology takeovers, one of the main private equity specialists in the field is raising its biggest-ever fund to pursue more deals.

headline: A Book to Distill Wine to Its Essence
abstract: “The 24-Hour Wine Expert” by Jancis Robinson breaks down the basics of wine appreciation.
lead_paragraph: Jancis Robinson, a British wine writer renowned for her many big, glossy tomes, has come up with a compact, breezy, one-shot wine seminar for novices. In 112 no-nonsense pages, she covers all the basics for understanding, selecting, appreciating, serving and storing wine. She dismisses pretension in favor of the practical. If carignan or claret are still vinous mysteries to you, look here for answers: “The 24-Hour Wine Expert” by Jancis Robinson (Abrams Image, $12.95).

headline: Polishing Financial Results Looks Good, but Can Lead to Fraud
keywords: ['Company Reports', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'ACCOUNTING AND ACCOUNTANTS']
abstract: Cases involving American Realty Capital Partners and Fiat Chrysler show how manipulating reported results can end up misleading investors.
lead_paragraph: Like a child on a playground who wants everyone to watch a new maneuver, companies clamor for public attention by presenting their numbers in a way that makes them look as successful as possible. But when those measures involve manipulating the figures, then their efforts can end up as a fraud on investors.

headline: Syria Is Calmer but Cautious as Cease-Fire Begins
abstract: The truce, which has drawn skepticism, led to a reduction of violence in its early hours, but there were some reported violations by both sides.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A cease-fire in the Syrian civil war, negotiated by Russia and the United States, officially took effect at sundown on Monday after a weekend of intensified fighting and a vow by Syria’s president to retake the entire country.

headline: 1916: Fingerprints Prove Prisoner’s Guilt
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Fingerprints prove prisoner’s guilt in London court, September 1916.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — ‘‘Science has proved beyond any reasonable doubt that you are guilty,’’ said Judge Atherley Jones at the Old Bailey yesterday [Sept. 11], when sentencing Andrew Scarloli, aged 24, a newsvendor, to twelve months’ hard labor for breaking into Sadlers Wells Theatre and stealing Treasury notes and about £43.

headline: A Chocolate Slipper That’s the Perfect Fit
abstract: This chocolate shoe has red soles just like the real Christian Louboutin pump.
lead_paragraph: If you have ever longed for those Christian Louboutin pumps with the signature red soles, they can now be had for a modest price — in chocolate. Annie Rupani, a chocolatier in Houston who specializes in unusual formats and seasonings like garam masala, fennel and cardamom, has introduced a version of her chocolate high heel with a red sole. Select dark, milk or white chocolate: Louboutin-Inspired Chocolate High Heel, $55; other styles $35 and $45, from cacaoandcardamom.com.

headline: Edward Humes on How Transportation Overkill Is Killing Us
keywords: ['Roads and Traffic', 'Speed Limits and Speeding', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Automobiles', 'Books and Literature', 'Transit Systems']
abstract: The Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist and author examines the wastefulness, in more ways than one, of America’s door-to-door culture.
lead_paragraph: Edward Humes, 59, is a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist whose latest book, “Door to Door: The Magnificent, Maddening, Mysterious World of Transportation,” is a wide-ranging look at the planes, trains and cars that Americans have chosen to rely on. We spoke recently in Manhattan and later by phone. Here is an edited and condensed version of those conversations.

headline: Walk Signals
abstract: What’s the fastest way across town full of unsynchronized traffic signals? Try this navigation challenge by Seth Cohen.
lead_paragraph: Our puzzle this week was suggested by Seth Cohen, who teaches astronomy and physics at St. Paul’s School in New Hampshire. We last saw Seth a year ago, when he illuminated us with Bulbs and More Bulbs. Let’s now join him for a race through town. Here’s —

keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: The decision involved an inquiry into whether the Campaign for One New York, which supported the mayor’s political agenda, violated state regulations by failing to register in 2015 as a lobbyist.
lead_paragraph: A judge in Albany has ordered Mayor Bill de Blasio’s political nonprofit to comply with a subpoena from a state ethics panel, putting a damper on the mayor’s widening effort to prevent the disclosure of certain communications that he deems privileged.

headline: Donald Trump Releases ‘Deplorables,’ an Anti-Hillary Clinton Ad
abstract: The ad is running in Ohio, Pennsylvania, North Carolina and Florida, with the Trump campaign hoping to turn Mrs. Clinton’s words into a flash point.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump released a new ad Monday seizing on comments made by Hillary Clinton late last week in which she called some of his supporters a “basket of deplorables” during a fund-raiser.

headline: The New Ghost Snake in Madagascar
abstract: Scientists discovered Madagoscarophis lolo, a new species of snake, on a rocky plateau in northern Madagascar.
lead_paragraph: A new species of snake — pale gray, with white and black spots — was discovered on a rocky plateau in northern Madagascar. Researchers are calling it Madagoscarophis lolo, after the Malagasy word for “ghost.”

headline: Travis Scott Debuts at No. 1 and Apple Notches Another Win
abstract: Also on the chart, A Day to Remember opens at No. 2 with “Bad Vibrations,” Drake’s “Views” is No. 3, and the soundtrack to “Suicide Squad” is No. 4.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the strange release of Frank Ocean’s “Blonde” three weeks ago, the music business has been buzzing with the expectation that “exclusive” digital albums — in which the music is at first available only through one service — would disappear, a casualty of industry politics. But as this week’s Billboard chart shows, windowed releases are not gone quite yet.

headline: Daily Report: A Light Local Hand on Tech
abstract: Uber, along with other tech companies, are finding pliant governments as they build the future.
lead_paragraph: “If you want to see the future, head to Pittsburgh” is probably something unsaid for most of a century. That may be about to change, because of the way its local government is welcoming its robot overlords.

lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — The trial of Ammon Bundy, his brother Ryan and five of their followers, antigovernment protesters charged in the armed takeover of a national wildlife refuge this year, will begin here on Tuesday in a federal court.

headline: Fed Official Says She Favors ‘Prudence’ in Raising Interest Rates
abstract: The remarks by Lael Brainard, a proponent of continuing the Fed’s stimulus campaign, reinforce expectations that the Fed won’t raise rates this month.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lael Brainard, a Federal Reserve governor and a leading proponent of the Fed’s efforts to stimulate the economy, said in a speech on Monday that she still favored “prudence” in raising interest rates despite recent signs of economic progress.

headline: Oceans Are Absorbing Almost All of the Globe’s Excess Heat
abstract: This year is on track to be the third consecutive hottest year on record. Where does that heat go? The oceans, mostly.
lead_paragraph: This year is on track to be the third consecutive hottest year on record. Where does that heat go? The oceans, mostly.

headline: Failure to Improve Is Still Being Used, Wrongly, to Deny Medicare Coverage
abstract: A lawsuit settlement made clear that providers and Medicare adjudicators cannot apply the so-called improvement standard. Yet the practice continues.
lead_paragraph: Edwina Kirby was having a hard time. She had tripped over a rug in her home in Livonia, Mich., and the fall broke a femur. After she had surgery and rehabilitation, an infection sent her back into the hospital. Her kidneys failed, requiring dialysis; she was also contending with diabetes and heart disease.

headline: Did Degas Make This Plaster? An Expert Now Says Yes
abstract: Arthur Beale, one of the world’s leading authorities on Degas, now believes that a plaster of “Little Dancer,” discovered in 2004, was created during Degas’s lifetime.
lead_paragraph: In a twist to a longstanding debate that for years has riveted a corner of the art world, one of the leading experts on Degas has decided that a long-disputed plaster of that artist’s “Little Dancer,” which shows the ballerina in a slightly different pose, is indeed an earlier model of his famous 1881 sculpture “Petite Danseuse de Quatorze Ans.”

headline: Violence Erupts in Southern India Over Order to Share Water
abstract: Protesters in Bangalore threw rocks and set fire to vehicles after the Indian Supreme Court ordered Karnataka State to release river water to neighboring Tamil Nadu.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Violent protests broke out in the southern state of Karnataka on Monday after the Indian Supreme Court ordered the state to release water to the neighboring state of Tamil Nadu, the latest chapter in a longstanding dispute.

headline: Sies Marjan Spring 2017
abstract: Looks from Sander Lak’s latest colorful collection.
lead_paragraph: Looks from Sander Lak’s latest colorful collection.

headline: Sies Marjan Still Swears Off Black
abstract: In his second season, the designer Sander Lak sticks to his guns, and the colors fairly blare.
lead_paragraph: Last season, the new label Sies Marjan arrived on the New York Fashion Week schedule in a blaze of color. Sander Lak, its designer, declared — heretically, given that he had just taken up residence in New York — that very few women actually look good in black. He advocated fearlessly for neon yellow and orange, lilac and magenta.

headline: Mother’s Killing of Children in Rural China Spurs Debate About Inequality
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Poverty', 'Income Inequality', 'Rural Areas']
abstract: The case of a mother who killed herself and her four children has ignited concerns about the grim realities rural families face amid rampant inequality.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The young mother lived in obscurity in a wobbly house at the end of a dusty road. She did not speak much with strangers, spending her days tending to rows of wheat, peas and potatoes.

headline: Potash and Agrium Deal Is a Friendly, Balanced Merger
abstract: The straightforward, no-premium deal is a contrast to other recent attempts at industry mash-ups, which did not fare so well.
lead_paragraph: It is a rare corporate love-in. The Potash Corporation of Saskatchewan and Agrium, a fertilizer company, have agreed to a merger of equals worth $36 billion in enterprise value. Monday’s straightforward, no-premium deal is a contrast to other recent attempts at industry mash-ups, which gave off a whiff of exuberance before collapsing.

headline: Most Parents Give the Wrong Dose of Liquid Medication
keywords: ['Labeling and Labels (Product)', 'Medicine and Health', 'Children and Childhood', 'Parenting', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)']
abstract: More than 84 percent of parents made errors in measuring liquid pediatric medicines in a study.
lead_paragraph: Most parents unwittingly give their kids the wrong dose of liquid medication — in some cases more than twice as much as instructed, a new study shows.

abstract: Scenes from the collections that were presented in New York on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the collections that were presented in New York on Sunday.

headline: David Cameron Steps Down From His Seat in British Parliament
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Referendums', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: The former British prime minister said he is leaving the House of Commons because his continued presence would be a distraction to the new government.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The post is ancient, and the duties are light (nonexistent, actually). But in order to step down from his seat in the House of Commons, David Cameron, the former prime minister of Britain, had to take on another position on Monday: Crown Steward and Bailiff of the Manor of Northstead.

headline: Watching, and Wincing, as Clinton Stumbles
abstract: A fleeting moment that, like so much of her campaign, is impossible to separate from history.
lead_paragraph: For all of her famed competence, Hillary Clinton has also been, from the beginning, something of a stumbler. While she was still a prospective first lady, she famously insulted all those cookie-baking mothers of the world; there was a gap between her and everywoman, and she walked right into it with a misstep that colored her public persona going forward. She has stumbled in traps of her own making — those emails — and traps set by others.

headline: August Ties July for Hottest Month on Record
abstract: The newest record continues a trend that points to 2016 becoming the hottest year since modern record-keeping began.
lead_paragraph: It just keeps getting hotter.

headline: In the Studio With the Creative Director of Coach

headline: Arson at Orlando Gunman’s Mosque

headline: Can Teenage Defiance Be Manipulated for Good?
keywords: ['Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Addiction (Psychology)', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Research']
abstract: A study shows teenagers make wiser choices if they are encouraged to reimagine healthy behavior as an act of rebellion.
lead_paragraph: Since there have been teenagers, there have been adults trying to control them. The Massachusetts Bay Colony passed the Stubborn Child Law in 1646, allowing parents to have their defiant teenage sons put to death. The Bible suggests stoning them to death. But what if adolescent defiance is not a demon to be exorcised, but a power to be harnessed?

headline: Review: ‘A Truck Full of Money’ and a Thirst to Put It to Good Use
abstract: Tracy Kidder’s book chronicles the life of Paul English, a Kayak.com founder who got rich, battled bipolar disorder and found a gratifying outlet in altruism.
lead_paragraph: Before the sensibility of Tracy Kidder’s new book clearly emerges, and before its subject, Paul English, becomes endearingly familiar, you may be tempted to put it down. The first few chapters of “A Truck Full of Money: One Man’s Quest to Recover From Great Success” have the sound of a glossy business-magazine hagiography — so much so that readers may wonder why the book isn’t blushing.

headline: Review: Sept. 11’s Monumental Despair, Evoked by Solo Piano

lead_paragraph: “Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close” is Jonathan Safran Foer’s Sept. 11 novel, one of the best-known responses to those traumatic events. Its title works equally well as a description of Michael Hersch’s “The Vanishing Pavilions,” a monumental solo-piano work that he started the day after the attacks and composed over the next five years.
