headline: Highlights From the Food World’s Most Game-Changing Festival
abstract: At the annual MAD Symposium in Copenhagen, small causes continue to inspire big conversations — and change.
lead_paragraph: At the fifth MAD Symposium — Denmark’s annual culinary twist on the Butterfly Effect, where small acts lead to large outcomes — a young cook from India, Ashwami Manjrekar, landed a gig with Rosio Sanchez, the Mexican-American chef from Chicago who opened a now-famous taqueria in Torvehallerne. That two women from disparate cultures on opposite sides of the earth found common ground over tacos under a circus tent is just one example of how MAD Symposium is arguably the most impactful food movement around.

headline: El Salvador’s “Abortion Lawyer”
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Miscarriages', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Stillbirth', 'Women and Girls', "Women's Rights"]

lead_paragraph: The congested road to El Salvador’s Ilopango Women’s Prison is lined with rundown snack shops and pink dogwood trees. Dennis Muñoz describes the concrete complex, which operates at 900 percent capacity, as “living hell.”

headline: At 3.1 Phillip Lim, Eyeliner Meets Architecture
abstract: For the designer’s spring/summer 2017 show, the makeup artist Francelle Daly created a graphic look that played on the idea of negative space.
lead_paragraph: The designer Phillip Lim is a passionate collector of art (furniture made by cabinetmakers is a particular interest). So it made sense that the makeup look at his spring/summer 2017 show took an artist-driven approach. Backstage, the makeup artist Francelle Daly slicked on graphic eyeliner, then removed the edges for a conceptual play on negative space. “It’s about modernizing the way we wear eyeliner,” she explained of her technique — which stood out for not only its impactful quality, but also for its ease of application. Daly simply outlined the eyes, “saturating” the upper and lower lash lines in Nars Eyeliner Stylo in Carpates, then traced Nars Kohliner Minorque along the inner waterline. Then, for the fun part: Daly dipped her Q-tip in a water cleanser and “chopped” off the inner and outer corners of her lines, customizing the shape to each models’ eyes. “Maybe it’s a little smaller at the bottom, maybe it’s a little bigger on top, just to make sure you don’t overpower the eye, or look like a raccoon,” she noted. Daly also recommends stepping back and looking in the mirror to ensure your liner is somewhat symmetrical on both eyes. But don’t agonize over it: “It’s all about what works best for you when doing your makeup, and being your own artist.”

headline: Full Disclosure on Candidates’ Health
abstract: Presidential candidates’ willingness to release their health histories is as important a test of transparency as other forms of disclosure.
lead_paragraph: As President Obama’s graying hair suggests, the American presidency is perhaps the most grueling and stressful political job there is. This year, both major party candidates for that job are past the nation’s customary retirement age. And while submitting health records is not a requirement for the job, Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump would be doing American voters a great service by furnishing a much clearer picture of their physical health than the abbreviated and sunny reports provided so far.

headline: Bar Cars May Return to Metro-North Trains Serving Connecticut
abstract: Commuter advocates say the service on the New Haven line is intended to cushion the blow of approaching fare increases; the governor plans a news conference on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The last of the bar cars on commuter trains in the New York metropolitan area made their final runs more than two years ago. But rolling cocktail service may be returning to the rails in Connecticut.

headline: Pregnant Women Anxious as Florida’s Zika Test Results Take Weeks
abstract: The state offers free tests to pregnant women, but a lack of resources has contributed to a backlog that has left hundreds waiting a long time.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — So many pregnant women have taken advantage of Florida’s offer of free Zika testing that state laboratories have been unable to keep pace, doctors and patients say, leading to long delays for women anxious to know whether the virus has passed to their fetuses.

headline: Did You Hear the Latest About Hillary?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Pneumonia', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Social Media']
abstract: Why misinformation spreads so quickly in this conspiracy-theory election.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton has pneumonia. Did you know she has a body double? She was that blond woman waving at reporters in front of Chelsea Clinton’s apartment a few hours after Mrs. Clinton felt unwell and left the Sept. 11 commemoration at ground zero.

headline: G.O.P. Voters Urged to Select Dead Assemblyman in New York Race
abstract: Bill Nojay, a Republican from the Rochester area who fatally shot himself last week, seems likely to win the primary election for his seat.
lead_paragraph: Even in death, State Assemblyman Bill Nojay, a Republican from the Rochester area who fatally shot himself in a city cemetery last week, seems likely to win the primary election for his seat on Tuesday.

headline: Matt Kuchar, J. B. Holmes and Rickie Fowler Named to U.S. Ryder Cup Team
abstract: Kuchar, Holmes and Fowler, who each have Ryder Cup experience, were selected by the team captain Davis Love III to take on Europe this month.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Phil Mickelson had already played his way on to the United States Ryder Cup team before the BMW Championship when he said that the eight automatic qualifiers “know who is going to be playing with who, when they’re going to be playing, what matches.” Mickelson’s remarks suggested that the team captain Davis Love III’s four discretionary picks were a foregone conclusion, and the three selections that Love announced on Monday did nothing to disabuse anyone of that notion.

headline: There You Have It
abstract: Stan Newman brings his Tuesday game.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — When last we saw Stan Newman, the editor of the Newsday crossword puzzles, in the New York Times crossword, he was capitalizing on a national holiday to say “thank you.” Today he’s back to offer us a puzzle that happens to double up on a high-scoring Scrabble letter.

headline: Review: ‘Aubergine,’ a Stew of Regret and Impending Loss
abstract: Julia Cho’s drama about family, food and mortality, at Playwrights Horizons, focuses on the invisible barriers that spring up between people.
lead_paragraph: In the monologue that begins “Aubergine,” a drama by Julia Cho about family, food and mortality that opened on Monday at Playwrights Horizons, a woman named Diane (Jessica Love) speaks at length about her and her husband’s obsessive love of food.

headline: Review: Nice Music, but in ‘Maestro’ He Doesn’t Look a Thing Like Lenny
abstract: Hershey Felder plays that “telegenic ham” Leonard Bernstein in “Maestro,” a solo show with songs, at 59E59 Theaters.
lead_paragraph: The riskiest moments in “Maestro,” Hershey Felder’s tribute to the conductor-composer Leonard Bernstein, come as spectators settle in at 59E59 Theaters, waiting for the performance to start. Onstage, projected in black-and-white archival television footage, is the handsome, charismatic Mr. Bernstein.

headline: Wally Backman Will Not Return as Mets’ Class AAA Manager
abstract: Backman spent five seasons managing in Las Vegas and was a finalist for the Mets’ managing job that went to Terry Collins in 2010.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Wally Backman, who played second base for the 1986 World Series champion Mets, will not return as the manager of the team’s Class AAA affiliate in Las Vegas, Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson said Monday. Some reports said Backman had been fired, and others said that Backman had resigned.

headline: The Public Face of Crazy Eddie Recalls the Real One
abstract: Jerry Carroll, the high-energy pitchman for the electronics chain, was often confused for one of its founders. He wasn’t, but he knew the man who was.
lead_paragraph: There was the time that inspiration for a radio commercial struck as Jerry Carroll was walking down Third Avenue. He explained it to the advertising executive he was with, who said, “Sounds like a good idea.” They stopped for a moment, just long enough for Mr. Carroll to write out the commercial, using the top of a trash can as a desk.

headline: Mets Fall to N.L. East-Leading Nationals
abstract: Desperate for wins in a tight wild-card race, the Mets were trounced by Washington as Rafael Montero stumbled badly in his third start, allowing six runs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With each pitch, Rafael Montero looked more out of place. Montero, a once-promising prospect who has fallen on hard times, could not find the strike zone. And just as in his past starts, the walks were piling up. But this time, the Mets could not survive them.

lead_paragraph: Marcus Wainwright presents his first collection as sole C.E.O. after David Neville stepped down from his daily duties in June.

headline: Lasker Awards Given for Work in Physiology, Virology and Science Education
keywords: ['Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Lasker Awards', 'Medicine and Health', 'Hepatitis', 'Blood', 'Oxygen']
abstract: This year’s honors speak to the additive nature of scientific research, with prizes recognizing people who built on the findings of others.
lead_paragraph: The Lasker Awards, among the most respected prizes in medicine, will go to six researchers who made major discoveries in physiology and virology, and to a scientist who has tirelessly promoted science education, the Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation announced on Tuesday.

headline: Brazil’s Congress Expels Lawmaker Who Led Ouster of President
abstract: The lower house of Congress voted overwhelmingly Monday night to expel Eduardo Cunha, a conservative lawmaker who is facing graft charges.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s lower house of Congress voted overwhelmingly late Monday night to expel the conservative lawmaker who led the charge to oust Dilma Rousseff, Brazil’s former president, reflecting how on edge the country’s political class remains over colossal corruption scandals.

headline: Protesters Disturb Ryan Lochte’s Debut on ‘Dancing With the Stars’
abstract: Two men were detained after at least one tried to rush the stage during the ABC competition’s season premiere.
lead_paragraph: The Olympic swimmer Ryan Lochte, making his debut on Monday night on the season premiere of the ABC competition “Dancing With the Stars,” was rushed by at least one protester, causing a significant disturbance that sent the program to an abrupt commercial break.

headline: From Mowing to Mascots: Playing by the Champions League’s Rules
abstract: Leicester City, the surprise winner of the Premier League, received a grueling education on how the European tournament operates months before its start.
lead_paragraph: In the course of 155 pages, no detail is considered too fine, no issue deemed too trivial. From the level of glare given off by the stadium lights to the size of a club mascot — “only slightly larger than a normal person” — the manual issued by UEFA to every entrant in the Champions League, soccer’s most glamorous club competition, covers it.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday: ‘The Shallows’ and ‘Deadliest Catch: Dungeon Cove’

headline: The Avalanche of Distrust
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Taxation', 'Medicine and Health', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Hillary Clinton, Donald Trump and much of society isolate themselves.
lead_paragraph: I’m beginning to think this whole sordid campaign is being blown along by an acrid gust of distrust. The two main candidates, Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump, are remarkably distrustful. They have set the modern standards for withholding information — his not releasing tax and health records, her not holding regular news conferences or quickly disclosing her pneumonia diagnosis. Both have a problem with spontaneous, reciprocal communication with a hint of vulnerability.

headline: The Touch League That I Love
abstract: A New Yorker’s weekend football game is a health tonic that offers a rare chance for cross-cultural-religious-ethnic-socioeconomic interaction.
lead_paragraph: I remember the play as if it were yesterday — or this past February, when it actually happened. I was a storytelling consultant/defensive end trying to sack a terrorism expert/quarterback who was 12 years my junior and several steps quicker.

headline: Back to the Stone Age
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Minorities', 'Discrimination']
abstract: What Donald Trump’s rise looks like to black and Hispanic Republicans.
lead_paragraph: Jacob Monty is not a RINO — a Republican in Name Only — even though some of his hate mail says otherwise. Mr. Monty, an immigration lawyer in Houston, has been deeply involved in Republican politics in Texas and nationally for much of the past 20 years. He was a fund-raiser for both of George W. Bush’s campaigns, and estimates that he has personally contributed more than $250,000 to Republican candidates.

headline: Who Will Make It Through the Homestretch?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voting and Voters', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Age, Chronological', 'Medicine and Health', 'Third-Party Politics (US)']
abstract: We’re all a little weary. The presidential campaign feels like it’s been going on since 1066.
lead_paragraph: Arthur Brooks: Welcome back from the break, Gail. Two months until Election Day, and no doubt our readers have been at loose ends without being able to kick off every Tuesday with our conversation. So let’s jump back into the ring.

headline: Will Speaker Paul Ryan Stand Up to the Freedom Caucus?
abstract: A meritless and unprecedented attempt to impeach the I.R.S. commissioner poses a challenge for Paul Ryan.
lead_paragraph: The leadership of the House speaker, Paul Ryan, is about to be challenged by the latest partisan mischief from ultraconservative Republicans — a meritless and unprecedented attempt to impeach the commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, John Koskinen.

headline: Keep the Pressure on Myanmar
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Rohingya (Ethnic Group)', 'United States International Relations', 'Human Trafficking', 'Editorials']
abstract: It would be a mistake for the United States to lift all remaining sanctions on Myanmar now.
lead_paragraph: When Myanmar’s leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, meets with President Obama and members of Congress in Washington this week, one of the items for discussion will be easing the remaining American sanctions on Myanmar. That may be a tempting move, given recent efforts by Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi to end ethnic conflict and the persecution of the Rohingya, a Muslim minority group, but it would be a mistake to lift all remaining sanctions now.

headline: For Refugees in Lebanon, Cash Instead of Camps
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Food']
abstract: With debit cards rather than bagged food, refugees buy their produce, live in more dignity, and raise less resentment among their Lebanese neighbors.
lead_paragraph: The United States has pledged to accept 10,000 Syrian refugees, and apparently the sky is falling. Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey said the country shouldn’t  take even orphans under 5 years old.

headline: How the Next President Can Stop North Korea
abstract: The Obama administration’s policy has failed to halt Pyongyang’s nuclear program. But the next White House still has a chance.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It’s been a banner year for North Korea. The government in Pyongyang has already conducted 17 missile tests and two nuclear tests, including the most recent nuclear explosion on Friday. And there are still three and a half months left in 2016.

abstract: Is a "heads-up" about violent material in a college course what students who have experienced trauma or suffer from P.T.S.D. really need?

lead_paragraph: Chihira Junco, shown above, is a tourist greeter at a shopping mall in Tokyo. She gives directions to local sites and shops in Japanese, Chinese and English.

abstract: A new book by David Turnley has him returning to the University of Michigan, where he had been in love with football before he took up photography.
lead_paragraph: During his long career, David Turnley has dodged gunfire, shaken hands with world leaders, witnessed the toppling of regimes and won a Pulitzer Prize. But what has given him perspective, he said, are memories from an indelible part of his college years: a 1973 stint as a walk-on — along with his twin, Peter — on the University of Michigan’s storied football team.

keywords: ['Nuclear Tests', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: They vowed to push for a resolution at the United Nations Security Council that includes new sanctions and the removal of existing loopholes.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The United States and South Korea vowed on Tuesday to push for the “strongest possible” resolution at the United Nations Security Council, including new sanctions and the removal of existing loopholes, to punish North Korea for its latest nuclear test.

headline: Healthy Touch of Flair Helps Argentina Compete With Southern Rivals
abstract: Argentina’s Pumas are no longer the predictable team they once were, only noted for their scrum and maul and goal-kicking flyhalves.
lead_paragraph: “Organized chaos” was how New Zealand described Argentina’s style of rugby before last weekend’s test here in Hamilton.

headline: I.P.O. Could Value Nets, a Danish Payment Processor, at $4.8 Billion
abstract: The company was acquired by a consortium of private equity investors about two and a half years ago from a group of Nordic banks.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Nets, the Danish payment processor, said on Tuesday that it expected to be valued at up to 32 billion Danish kroner, or $4.8 billion, in its initial public offering this month.

headline: Margot Lee Shetterly Wants To Tell More Black Stories
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Books and Literature', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The author of “Hidden Figures” on black excellence, visibility in STEM fields and why imagination is paramount to social progress.
lead_paragraph: Your new book, “Hidden Figures,” is the story of the black female mathematicians at NASA who helped put Americans on the moon. Why haven’t we heard about this before? Where I grew up, in Hampton, Va., we knew the story, and we thought it was pretty normal. They were people who were doing this exceptional job when you look back on it, but at the time, they were just ordinary people who loved their work. It was kind of nice to grow up in a place where that achieved such a degree of normalcy that people weren’t talking about it all the time.

headline: John le Carré’s Memoir About His Journey From Spy to Novelist
abstract: In “The Pigeon Tunnel,” John le Carré traces his fascination with spycraft to his early life with his father, a con man.
lead_paragraph: THE PIGEON TUNNELStories From My LifeBy John le Carré310 pp. Viking. $28.

headline: Maureen Dowd’s Latest Book on Everything Hillary and Donald
abstract: Maureen Dowd’s “The Year of Voting Dangerously” presents the characters behind this election’s dramas.
lead_paragraph: THE YEAR OF VOTING DANGEROUSLYBy Maureen Dowd432 pp. Twelve. $30.

headline: What Playing Madden Teaches Us About Football — and What It Doesn’t
abstract: How a video game lets fans think they understand N.F.L. games, even as it keeps them at enough remove to still enjoy the sport.
lead_paragraph: Nearly everything I know about football I know from Madden. My first encounter with the game came in 1992 in David Rabinowitz’s basement. I was 12, living in a cable-free household, in a town where the Sunday CBS or NBC broadcasts were very limited. My main exposure to the N.F.L. was through my trading-card collection — I had fortuitously invested in football cards in 1989 and therefore had the rookie cards for Troy Aikman, Barry Sanders, Deion Sanders and the great Andre Rison. But because I did not see a lot of football, even those stars were mostly just names to me.

headline: For Every 10 U.S. Adults, Six Vote and Four Don’t. What Separates Them?
abstract: People are motivated to vote by a combination of individual priorities, group culture, candidate outreach, and how easy or hard it is to cast a ballot.
lead_paragraph: People are motivated to vote by a combination of individual priorities, group culture, candidate outreach, and how easy or hard it is to cast a ballot.

headline: How Two Producers of ‘Transparent’ Made Their Own Trans Lives More Visible
abstract: The photos Zackary Drucker and Rhys Ernst took of each other showed a young couple in love. They became an important public record of transgender life.
lead_paragraph: On a hot night in July at Skylight Books in Los Angeles, Zackary Drucker and Rhys Ernst perched on stools to discuss their new book of photographs, “Relationship.” It is by far the most personal of the many projects they have worked on together. The photographs chronicle their six-year romance, which ended soon after many of these images were shown at the Whitney Biennial in 2014.

headline: Sitcom Men, Grappling With a New Reality on TV
abstract: Male protagonists are adjusting to new roles in society or reduced circumstances. In new broadcast sitcoms, not just in politics.
lead_paragraph: This fall, broadcast television will turn its attention to the battle of the straight white man to assert his masculinity in an increasingly alien world. And you won’t need to wait until the first presidential debate to see it.

headline: An Unplanned Absence for Hillary Clinton at an Inopportune Time
abstract: After a relatively quiet summer, Mrs. Clinton was returning to the campaign trail and trying to connect with voters in more personal terms. Then she got sick.
lead_paragraph: For much of the summer, Hillary Clinton deliberately kept a low public profile, fund-raising in private and pursuing a hands-off campaign strategy: If Donald J. Trump wanted to seize center stage by picking unpopular fights — with a Gold Star father, a federal judge, the leaders of his own party — she would not stand in his way.

headline: Candidate Gaffes Are Overrated; Health Concerns Could Influence Voters More
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Age, Chronological']

lead_paragraph: The website features photographs and short biographies of children, some with special needs. Choices can be narrowed by gender, age, race and ethnicity.

headline: The Medieval Monasteries of Kosovo
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Monasteries and Monks', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: In the heart of Kosovo, where religion and politics can be a volatile mix, lie centuries-old masterpieces of ecclesiastical architecture.
lead_paragraph: The main street in Gracanica, a village on the outskirts of Pristina, the capital of Kosovo, is lined with bakeries and markets strung together in a jumble until the shop fronts give way to a high stone wall. Step to the other side, and the hum of Volkswagens and Skodas falls away almost entirely. At the center of a wide lawn sits Gracanica Monastery, a masterpiece of late-Byzantine ecclesiastical architecture, its rosy domes like steppingstones that draw the eye and the spirit toward the sky.

headline: IPhone 7 Review: Though Not Perfect, New iPhones Keep Apple’s Promises
abstract: Although they lack a headphone jack, the iPhone 7 and 7 Plus are fast, their cameras take superb photos and the batteries last longer.
lead_paragraph: Apple’s iPhone, just short of 10 years old, has hit puberty.

headline: 1966: Tortured Pilot Escapes
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: A Navy pilot escapes the torture of Laotian Communists in September 1966.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — A young Navy pilot today [Sept. 13] calmly described his incredible escape from Laotian Communists and the barbaric tortures he experienced after being shot down early this year during a bombing raid over North Vietnam. Lt. Dieter Danglers’s adventures began when his propeller-driven Skyraider was downed Feb. 2 and ended with his dramatic July 20 rescue by helicopter after U.S reconnaissance planes spotted signal fires he had set in the jungle. He also told how a fellow escapee Air Force Lt. Duane Martin, of Denver, died when a villager virtually beheaded him with a machete. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 14, 1966

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Sept. 6-12, 2016
abstract: Have you been following the news? Our weekly 10-question quiz is back!

headline: Theater’s Evolving Role in China and Taiwan
abstract: Stan Lai, a celebrated Chinese-language playwright and director, discusses changes in the theater industry and how his Buddhist beliefs influence his writing.
lead_paragraph: Over the past few decades, Stan Lai has established a reputation as one of the most celebrated Chinese-language playwrights and directors. His works include more than 30 original plays, two feature films and four operas. Mr. Lai, who was born in the United States and is based in Taiwan, has written classics like “Secret Love in Peach Blossom Land” (1986), now an iconic play in contemporary Chinese theater, while still continuing to experiment with new forms, as seen in his eight-hour epic “A Dream Like a Dream” (2000), which has audiences sitting on swivel chairs in the center of the stage.

headline: Italy’s ‘Fertility Day’ Call to Make Babies Arouses Anger, Not Ardor
abstract: A government ad campaign aimed at tackling Italy’s low birthrate was swiftly abandoned after it was widely deemed offensive.
lead_paragraph: ROME — One ad pictured a woman holding an hourglass next to the words: “Beauty has no age limit. Fertility does.” Another portrayed a pair of baby shoes wrapped in a ribbon of the Italian flag. Yet another showed a man holding a half-burned cigarette: “Don’t let your sperm go up in smoke,” it read.

headline: Israel Denies Claims That Syria Shot Down Warplane and Drone

headline: California Today: Fighting Fire With Fire
abstract: Welcome to California Today, a morning update on the stories that matter to Californians (and anyone else interested in the state).
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Stockholm as Strindberg’s Muse
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Theater', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Stripping Strindberg down to his writing, his frequent inspiration — in addition to his three wives — was his hometown, Stockholm. And it is remarkably well-preserved.
lead_paragraph: Rare is the writer who can still rile his countrymen more than a century after his death. But in Sweden, August Strindberg remains lodged under the country’s proverbial skin. The author and playwright, known as much for his gossip-column lifestyle and controversial political views as for his prodigious literary output, died in 1912.

headline: Trix and Robert Haussmann
abstract: Meet the eightysomething Swiss architects responsible for some of the most subversive design in the world.
lead_paragraph: Meet the eightysomething Swiss architects responsible for some of the most subversive design in the world.

headline: These Architects, Working Into Their 80s, Should Be Famous
abstract: How is it that the brilliantly subversive work of Trix and Robert Haussmann is virtually unknown in the U.S.?
lead_paragraph: How is it that the brilliantly subversive work of Trix and Robert Haussmann is virtually unknown in the U.S.?

headline: Contemporary Design That Upsets Our Perception of the Home
abstract: The Polish-born designer Matylda Krzykowski will soon bring her knack for sniffing out talent to Chelsea.
lead_paragraph: Matylda Krzykowski, the Polish-born designer, curator and co-founder of the contemporary-design space Depot Basel, in Switzerland, will lend her knack for sniffing out talent to Chamber, the Chelsea gallery and boutique, next month. Inspired by the artist Richard Hamilton’s iconic collage “Just what is it that makes today’s homes so different, so appealing?” — a comment on postwar consumer culture — she’s selected objects that are “between sculpture and your living environment,” including a surrealist lamp from the Austrian duo Mischer’traxler and a pair of trompe l’oeil wooden boxes by the Swiss designers Trix and Robert Haussmann. “It’s about shifting our perception of things that we know,” Krzykowski says. ­

headline: Colin Kaepernick Finds His Voice
keywords: ['Football', 'National Anthems', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The quarterback’s protest against police brutality divides fans.
lead_paragraph: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — A postgame professional football locker room is a primal cave. Massive and bruised men dress and move slowly, their bodies lost to ache. I noticed a curiously ebullient man, San Francisco 49ers linebacker Eli Harold, and wandered over to hear what he had to say.

headline: Time Inc. Shakes Up Management, Replacing Chief Executive
abstract: Rich Battista was named president and chief executive, and the current chief executive, Joseph A. Ripp, will continue to lead the board.
lead_paragraph: For the second time in two months, Time Inc., the publisher of Time, People and Sports Illustrated, has shuffled its top leadership as it tries to reinvent itself as a digital organization and turn its well-known magazine titles into successful online properties.

headline: Wukan, a Chinese Village, Erupts in Unrest Over Activists’ Arrests
abstract: The police responded with rubber bullets and tear gas, bloodying several people, according to interviews with villagers and images posted online.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A riot broke out in the southern Chinese village of Wukan on Tuesday as dozens of people, many of them waving flags and hurling stones, protested early morning raids that led to the arrests of activists who had criticized the government.

headline: ‘Great British Bake Off’ Will Leave BBC, and Two Hosts Quit

abstract: The political world is quick to declare a turning point. Too quick? We explore, with six Times reporters, moments that have mattered in this presidential race.
lead_paragraph: In presidential politics, everyone is on the lookout for them and an army of analysts is eager to declare them: turning points. It’s the moment when a single image or phrase or blunder could change the trajectory of the campaign.

headline: 1916: Circus Raided for Shirkers
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: A circus in England is raided for military absentees in September 1916.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A raid for military absentees was made on a travelling circus on Monday [Sept. 11] night by the military authorities, assisted by the police and special constables and a large detachment from a volunteer training corps. The latter surrounded the circus tent while the military and police entered. The names and addresses of seventy men without necessary papers had been taken when all the lights went out, and the audience of between three and four thousand was left in darkness. The proceedings of the military and the remainder of the performance had to be abandoned. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 14, 1916

Trump, have made public about their medical histories thrust questions of transparency about health to the center of the presidential campaign this week, with both candidates promising to release more detailed records in the coming days.

headline: The Best Pairing for Indian Food? It’s Not Beer
abstract: More good Indian restaurants are offering excellent wine lists. The trick is in knowing how to pair it with the food.

Papadum and other crisp wafers arrived with an assortment of sweet and spicy chutneys, though, in an elegant expression worthy of high-end aspirations, the wafers were presented vertically, their edges anchored in a bed of dry lentils.

headline: Why Are The Media Objectively Pro-Trump?
abstract: The cool kids gang up on the smart nerd.
lead_paragraph: Because they are, at this point. It’s not even false equivalence: compare the amount of attention given to the Clinton Foundation despite absence of any evidence of wrongdoing, and attention given to Trump Foundation, which engaged in more or less open bribery — but barely made a dent in news coverage. Clinton was harassed endlessly over failure to give press conferences, even though she was doing lots of interviews; Trump violated decades of tradition by refusing to release his taxes, amid strong suspicion that he is hiding something; the press simply dropped the subject.

headline: Can You Guess the Models by Their Walk?
abstract: A look back at a few legends of the catwalk, and what made their stride so special.
lead_paragraph: In times like the 1980s, when fashion itself was brash and theatrical, designers were unafraid of models who brought their outsized personalities to the catwalk. People like Vivienne Westwood or Gianni Versace encouraged the beauties they hired — exceptional types like Naomi Campbell, Christy Turlington, Carla Bruni — to translate on the catwalk not only their professional chops but their love of the moment, the camera’s lens, the rapt attention of the claques they attracted and even, occasionally, the clothes.

headline: The Economic Expansion Is Helping the Middle Class, Finally
abstract: However you measure it (and there are lots of ways), the news on wages is good, though it could still be better.
lead_paragraph: For years, the standard knock on this economic expansion has been twofold: Growth has been slow, and big businesses and wealthy investors have been its major beneficiaries, rather than middle-class wage earners.

headline: Rodarte Brings Back Youthful, D.I.Y. Headbands and Barettes
abstract: Models donned handmade hair accessories crafted with silk, chiffon, crystals and sequins — leftover from making the label’s spring 2017 collection.
lead_paragraph: The Rodarte designers Kate and Laura Mulleavy often spin a dreamy, youthful quality into their ethereal collections. At today’s spring/summer 2017 show, that vibe also came across in delicate floral hair accessories — headbands and barrettes the French hairstylist Odile Gilbert crafted from bits and pieces of silk, chiffon, crystals and sequins left over from making the garments in the collection. “It’s like being a kid in school, where you’re given materials and you have to create something,” she said, adding that the process took “a full day”: “We started at nine o’clock and finished at six.” Each piece was a one-off, in that no two were exactly alike — and Gilbert placed them into the hair with a similarly spontaneous attitude: She rubbed Wella Enrich moisturizing conditioner between her palms, and worked it through strands to add softness and texture, and misted on  Stay Essential light crafting spray for grip and hold. Then she slipped headbands on the back of the models’ heads, like half-crowns, and attached barrettes in a cascading, organic pattern.

headline: Britain’s New 5-Pound Note Is Chewable, Washable and Harder to Fake
abstract: The bill, printed for more than a century on cotton paper, now comes in polymer, a thin, flexible plastic film that makes it more resistant to criminals.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It can withstand a spin cycle in a washing machine filled with extremely hot water. It can be eaten by mischievous toddlers or pet hamsters without causing lethal indigestion. It can fend off wily criminals with tiny lettering visible only under a microscope.

headline: The Spicy Spoils of China’s Boom, at Hao Noodle and Tea
abstract: In Greenwich Village, skillfully updating classic dishes.
lead_paragraph: In the hedonist’s view of American immigration patterns, bad times for chefs in China are good times for dumpling chasers and noodle hunters in New York. When experienced cooks couldn’t make a living there for political or economic reasons, they came here. Conversely, over the last decade or so, the hypertrophic Chinese economy has left the kitchens of our Chinatowns somewhat flattened, with fewer high peaks of talent standing out in the landscape.

abstract: Robert Gottlieb’s memoir is an indispensable publishing history, thick with instruction and useful gossip about his dealings with famous writers.
lead_paragraph: Robert Gottlieb, the celebrated editor at Simon & Schuster, Alfred A. Knopf and The New Yorker, was a pale, bookish, sensitive, rumpled and vaguely mousy young man. His first father-in-law, a roofing contractor, took a look at him and said, “If I had a son like that, I’d take him out and drown him like a sick kitten.”

headline: New York Gets a New Ratings Service for Restaurants
abstract: Eleven Madison Park tops the first rankings from Renzell, which surveys over 2,000 members.
lead_paragraph: A new service for rating restaurants has released its first results for New York City, and the winners are: Eleven Madison Park, Atera and a host of similar restaurants that often end up on such lists.

headline: Review: Comedy Central’s New Basketball Show Racks Up Raunchy Points
abstract: In the animated series “Legends of Chamberlain Heights,” three foulmouthed freshmen players try to fit in at high school.
lead_paragraph: Move over, all you basketball wives. Three animated high school basketball players have arrived, and they’re more outrageous in any given five minutes than you are in an entire episode.

headline: How a Dutch Businessman Fulfilled His Dream to Open a ‘World-Class’ Museum
abstract: The former chemical company executive Joop van Caldenborgh has created the Voorlinden, a museum in the Netherlands founded on several thousand works of art.
lead_paragraph: WASSENAAR, the Netherlands — The Dutch chemical company executive and art collector Joop van Caldenborgh was attending a dinner in London in the 1990s when the American abstract artist Ellsworth Kelly approached him.

headline: U.S. Finalizes Deal to Give Israel $38 Billion in Military Aid
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Foreign Aid', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The agreement, which the allies plan to sign on Wednesday, represents a major American commitment to Israel’s security after years of fractious relations.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The United States has finalized a $38 billion package of military aid for Israel over the next 10 years, the largest of its kind ever, and the two allies plan to sign the agreement on Wednesday, American and Israeli officials said.

headline: Harvey Weinstein Gets Oscar Boost After ‘Lion’ Screening
abstract: Although reviews were mixed, some see an opening for Mr. Weinstein’s company after a screening generated a euphoric buzz at the Toronto International Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — A week ago, most Oscar prognosticators and strategists had effectively written off Harvey Weinstein as a player in this year’s awards race.

headline: Donald Trump Unveils Plan for Families in Bid for Women’s Votes
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Child Care', 'Family Leaves', 'Women and Girls', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: Mr. Trump’s call for six weeks of mandatory paid maternity leave and expanded tax credits for child care is another attempt to court elusive support from women.
lead_paragraph: ASTON, Pa. — Donald J. Trump unveiled a menu of proposals on Tuesday to help working parents, calling for six weeks of mandatory paid maternity leave and expanded tax credits for child care.

headline: I’m Not From Here
abstract: Day after day, an elderly woman recalls the Spanish Basque country of her youth — while forgetting she is consigned to a retirement home in Chile.
lead_paragraph: Day after day, an elderly woman recalls the Spanish Basque country of her youth — while forgetting she is consigned to a retirement home in Chile.

headline: I’m Not From Here
abstract: Day after day, an elderly woman recalls the Spanish Basque country of her youth — while forgetting she is consigned to a retirement home in Chile.
lead_paragraph: As so much of our world’s population ages and faces the attendant burden of Alzheimer’s and other forms of dementia, the rest of us are left to consider the collective mysteries of memory. When just about all is forgotten, how do we process what remains?

headline: Broadway-Bound ‘Groundhog Day’ Will Cast Shadow on Tonys
abstract: A musical version of the hit film will open on Broadway in April, just before the deadline to qualify for the Tony Awards. It’s now playing in London.
lead_paragraph: Make way for “Groundhog Day.” A musical version of the hit film is coming to Broadway, and it immediately assumes front-runner status in this season’s Tony derby.

headline: Emily Blunt Rides the Unnerving Rails of Addiction in ‘The Girl on the Train’
abstract: The actress had to conceal a pregnancy and portray a shattered alcoholic in the coming screen adaptation of Paula Hawkins’s best seller.
lead_paragraph: Emily Blunt’s metamorphosis into Rachel Watson, the physically ravaged, emotionally shattered alcoholic in “The Girl on the Train” (out Oct. 7) burrowed deeper than a mere Hollywood make-under.

headline: Thai Seafood Finds a Downtown Home at Fish Cheeks
abstract: Parm takes on Williamsburg, Printers Alley brings Nashville to Times Square, and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: FISH CHEEKS Ohm Suansilphong, a chef who worked at the highly rated Nahm in Bangkok, has joined his brother, Chat Suansilphong, a chef who worked for Tom Colicchio, to help bolster New York’s somewhat scant offering of reasonably authentic Thai food. The room, decorated with Thai motifs, is a glowing, golden affair. And their concise, creative menu of mostly family-style dishes is heavy on seafood (coconut crab curry with betel leaves, crispy garlic branzino) and frequently fueled by tiny, potent bird’s-eye chiles. “We’re not dumbing down the dishes or the spice levels,” said Chat, adding that they are grinding their spice mixtures: 55 Bond Street (Bowery), 212-677-2223, fishcheeksnyc.com.

headline: Review: ‘Documentary Now!’ Skewers Politicians and Food Fetishists
abstract: A new season of the mini-mockumentaries from “Saturday Night Live” alumni begins.
lead_paragraph: In an age of niche television, few shows are more niche than “Documentary Now!” How much of an audience could there be for half-hour parodies of famous documentaries (including “Grey Gardens” and “The Thin Blue Line” in Season 1) contained in a loving re-creation of a weekly public television showcase?

headline: Ibrahim Maalouf Gives His Trumpet a Human Voice
abstract: The musician and composer discusses his work, his evocation of strong women and the influence of contemporary politics on how his art is seen.
lead_paragraph: Bridging musical cultures comes naturally to the trumpeter and composer Ibrahim Maalouf. Born in Beirut and reared in Paris, he has earned wide acclaim for his work in the Western classical tradition, as well as in Arabic music, film music, jazz and rock. Throughout the Francophone world, and in parts of the Middle East, he operates on the scale of a global pop star.

headline: A Politician’s Health: What Do We Need to Know?
abstract: Readers discuss how Hillary Clinton handled her pneumonia diagnosis, and the afflictions of several of our most notable presidents.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

lead_paragraph: Let’s assume, just for the sake of argument, that Donald Trump and his supporters on the deplorable right actually mean what they say and are not just spewing sound bites for fun or attention.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A House committee on Tuesday approved a bill to roll back significant portions of the financial-crisis-era overhaul known as the Dodd-Frank Act in a vote that was largely down party lines.

headline: Obama Derides Trump’s Veracity

lead_paragraph: At a campaign event for Hillary Clinton, President Obama criticized Donald J. Trump, the Republican nominee — saying he made repeated false statements — and disparaged his past as a reality television star.

headline: Review: ‘Command and Control’: Common Errors, Nuclear Arms and Consequences
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The film documents a 1980 accident in a missile silo in Arkansas that showed just how vulnerable the nation’s most fearsome weapons can be.
lead_paragraph: American military history is full of misguided wars, botched battles and scandals of all sorts, so it’s no secret that there is fallibility all through the ranks. But the events chronicled in “Command and Control,” a documentary by Robert Kenner based on the book by Eric Schlosser, are terrifying nonetheless. Our most destructive weapons are somehow immune to our own clumsiness and inexactitude, aren’t they? No, they’re not.

lead_paragraph: In their recent single “Drop,” the R&B sister duo Chloe x Halle are all attitude, telling a boy: “Baby, I get sick of you. You’re that same old tune I don’t ever want to hear again.”

headline: Fast Response to ‘Brexit’ News: A Pop-Up Paper Finds Success in Britain
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Newspapers', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The New European was conceived as a short-term weekly offering in the wake of Britain’s vote to leave the European Union, but it has been a surprise success.
lead_paragraph: The morning after Britain voted to leave the European Union, Matt Kelly ducked into a coffee shop on a graffiti-lined street in the trendy East London neighborhood of Shoreditch.

headline: Kelly Beeman and Susan Cianciolo Sketch the Maryam Nassir Zadeh Fitting
abstract: Behind the scenes with the artists — and the designer.
lead_paragraph: Behind the scenes with the artists — and the designer.

headline: One Designer’s Fashion Week Fittings, Illustrated
abstract: Ahead of her first fashion week presentation, Maryam Nassirzadeh asked Susan Cianciolo and Kelly Beeman to sketch the hubbub.
lead_paragraph: Since the opening of her Lower East Side boutique in 2008, and the launch of her namesake line in 2013, Maryam Nassirzadeh has (in one way or another) infiltrated countless New Yorkers’ closets. But she hasn’t held a fashion week presentation — until now. (“I always felt fulfilled doing my own thing,” she says.) Tonight, a cast consisting of Nassirzadeh’s nearest and dearest friends will model the designer’s spring/summer 2017 collection. “They’re part of the reason why I wanted to do a show,” she says. “It’s organic to ask the people who I’m comfortable seeing in the clothes to participate, and it’s truly a collaborative process. It’s not that I want to impose my vision, it’s that I’m inspired by them.”

headline: Young Women Get Buzzed, on Their Own Terms
abstract: In buzz cuts, women see a shortcut to style and empowerment.
lead_paragraph: A generation of young women is discovering a new way to get buzzed — no illicit substances required. Instead, all that’s needed is a good pair of clippers and some nerve.

headline: In Expanding Russian Influence, Faith Combines With Firepower
abstract: The Russian Orthodox Church helps spread President Vladimir V. Putin’s gospel of illiberal democracy and traditional values, pushing into resolutely secular members of Europe like France.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The golden main dome of a new Russian Orthodox cathedral now under construction on the banks of the Seine shimmers in the sun, towering over a Paris neighborhood studded with government buildings and foreign embassies. Most sensitive of all, it is being built beside a 19th-century palace that has been used to conceal some of the French presidency’s most closely guarded secrets.

headline: Fed Proposes Ban on Merchant Banking, a Practice With Little Risk
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Despite merchant banking’s storied past as a way to invest in companies, the Federal Reserve is calling for a ban under the guise of tamping down risk.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve has taken dead aim on merchant banking, proposing to ban the practice as part of a “take no risk” regulation strategy.

headline: Lucerne Festival Theater Project Killed by Vote
abstract: Despite a $137 million donation pledged in 2007 to build a flexible theater for experimental productions, Swiss officials rejected the plan.
lead_paragraph: An unusual episode in classical music philanthropy — the effort to build a theater for the Lucerne Festival in Switzerland to produce operatic and experimental works — came to an apparent end on Monday when Swiss officials voted it down.

headline: U.S. Agency Faults Pilot of Delta Jet That Slid Off La Guardia Runway
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Pilots', 'AIRPORTS', 'Snow and Snowstorms', 'Transportation', 'Evacuations and Evacuees']
abstract: The National Transportation Safety Board’s inquiry into the March 2015 crash also found problems with the evacuation process.
lead_paragraph: A Delta Air Lines jet skidded off a snowy runway at La Guardia Airport and nearly plunged into Flushing Bay last year because its pilot used excessive force to slow the plane as it landed, federal transportation safety officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Vice Media Delays Start of HBO Newscast Until Oct. 10
abstract: “We are just making sure that everything looks as good as we want it to look,” Josh Tyrangiel, who oversees “Vice News Tonight,” said of the delay.
lead_paragraph: Vice Media said on Tuesday that it was delaying the start of its daily HBO half-hour newscast by two weeks. The program, “Vice News Tonight,” will now begin on Oct. 10 instead of Sept. 26, as Vice had announced.

headline: Arsenal Earns a Champions League Draw, but P.S.G. Is the One Moving Forward
abstract: P.S.G. couldn’t hold on to an early lead against a fellow perennial disappointment. But P.S.G., at least, seems to be trying to change its direction.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — As the overblown strains of Handel’s “Zadok the Priest” blasted out over Parc des Princes, and as the players from Paris St.-Germain and Arsenal emerged into the bright lights of the Champions League once more, a vast red banner was unfurled on one side of the stadium.

headline: Black Health Experts Renew Fight Against Menthol Cigarettes
abstract: President Obama’s help was sought against a type of cigarette that is popular among African-American smokers and is heavily marketed to them.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Menthol cigarettes account for about a third of all cigarettes sold in the United States, and they are particularly popular among black smokers — about four out of five report smoking them, according to federal surveys.

headline: Bridgewater Manager Ray Dalio Defends His Firm’s ‘Radical Transparency’
abstract: During a hedge fund conference, the billionaire investor Ray Dalio responded to media scrutiny of the $150 billion firm’s “unusual” workplace culture.
lead_paragraph: The billionaire hedge fund manager Ray Dalio on Tuesday defended the “unusual” culture at his $150 billion firm, Bridgewater Associates.

headline: Details of Syria Pact Widen Rift Between John Kerry and Pentagon
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Defense Secretary Ashton Carter opposed the plan for U.S. and Russian military collaboration against ISIS, which Secretary of State John Kerry supports.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The agreement that Secretary of State John Kerry announced with Russia to reduce the killing in Syria has widened an increasingly public divide between Mr. Kerry and Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter, who has deep reservations about the plan for American and Russian forces to jointly target terrorist groups.

headline: U.S. Wins Gold at Chess Olympiad With Help of Imported Talent
abstract: The five-member American team at the 42nd Chess Olympiad included three players who were recruited from other countries.
lead_paragraph: It has been nearly 80 years since the United States could boast that it had the best chess team in the world, but the group it put together this year — with the help of a wealthy benefactor and a bit of international intrigue — can now make that claim.

headline: Obama Condemns Trump in Full-Throated Pitch for Clinton
abstract: In Philadelphia, Mr. Obama appealed to young and minority voters while criticizing Donald J. Trump and coverage that had turned the race into a “reality show.”
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — President Obama vigorously defended Hillary Clinton on Tuesday as a relentless leader who had been held to unfair standards during an uncommonly wild presidential campaign, pleading with the voters who were the core of his own support to tune out the “reality show” noise of the race and vote for his chosen successor.

headline: Metro-North Getting Bar Cars Again, but Don’t Expect a Seat
abstract: Connecticut announced plans to buy 60 coaches for the New Haven line; pictures showed cars with counters and stability bars, but no place to sit.
lead_paragraph: To the list of famous things that have been discontinued only to be resurrected later — Marvel Comics, the Muppets and Twinkies, to name but three — add bar cars on the Metro-North Railroad.

headline: Cate Blanchett and Chekhov, Together on Broadway
abstract: Theatergoers will have two chances to check out the playwright: productions with Diane Lane and with Ms. Blanchett in her Broadway debut.
lead_paragraph: An old friend writes: “I am far from cheating myself, my dear man, about the true condition of affairs; not only am I bored and dissatisfied, but as a doctor I am cynical enough to be convinced that from this life we can expect only evil — errors, losses, illnesses, weakness, and all kinds of dirty tricks.”

headline: Black Female Playwrights Want You to Face Facts. The Harsh Ones.
abstract: Sarah Jones, Anna Deavere Smith and Lynn Nottage all have new works onstage this fall that grapple with the toughest issues in contemporary culture.
lead_paragraph: It’s not unusual for theater, like many of the arts, to address a pressing social or political issue. But what strikes me as unusual this fall is that most of such work comes from notable black female playwrights: Sarah Jones, Anna Deavere Smith and Lynn Nottage all have new (or new to New York) works that grapple with problems preoccupying contemporary culture.

headline: Allow Me to Introduce What’s His Name

headline: Trial Begins for Maurice Greenberg, Ex-A.I.G. Chief Accused of Fraud

lead_paragraph: The 11-year-old accounting fraud case against the former American International Group chief executive Maurice R. Greenberg finally came to trial on Tuesday in a state courthouse in Lower Manhattan.

lead_paragraph: For months, North Carolina has weathered the umbrage of corporate America and the anger of the federal government over a law that curbed the rights of gay and transgender people.

headline: Prosecution in Potsdam Murder Case Admits a Lapse
abstract: Oral Nicholas Hillary was denied a mistrial over a prosecutor’s failure to disclose that a witness saw a different man in the building where Garrett Phillips was killed.
lead_paragraph: CANTON, N.Y. — It took nearly five years from the time of the savage strangling of a 12-year-old boy for Oral Nicholas Hillary, long the prime suspect, to be brought to trial.

headline: Oregon Refuge Occupiers Were Protesting, Lawyer Says
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Federal Lands', 'Wildlife Sanctuaries and Nature Reserves', 'Public Property']
abstract: The lawyer for Ammon Bundy, one of seven defendants on trial, said the group wanted to draw attention to the government’s mismanagement of public lands.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — The armed demonstrators who took over a federal wildlife refuge in Oregon this year were attempting to reclaim land that they believed was improperly seized by the federal government, a lawyer for one of the group’s leaders told a packed courtroom on Tuesday.

headline: Chelsea Manning Told She Can Have Gender Reassignment Surgery, Lawyer Says
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexuals', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: Ms. Manning, who is in military prison for leaking government files, was told the Army will allow the operation.
lead_paragraph: Chelsea Manning, who announced that she was female the day after being sentenced to prison in 2013 for leaking government files, has been told that the United States military will allow her to proceed with gender reassignment surgery, her lawyer said on Tuesday.

headline: The Failure to Talk Frankly About Poverty
abstract: Neither Hillary Clinton nor Donald Trump has a specific anti-poverty agenda.
lead_paragraph: Poverty in the United States is deeper than in all other wealthy nations. Yet neither Hillary Clinton nor Donald Trump has a specific anti-poverty agenda.

headline: Southern California Gas Reaches $4 Million Settlement Over Natural Gas Leak
abstract: A storage system spewed thousands of tons of methane and other chemicals into the air, forcing the evacuation of more than 8,300 households.
lead_paragraph: A California company that operated a natural gas storage system that leaked last year, spewing thousands of tons of methane and other chemicals into the air and forcing the evacuation of more than 8,300 households, reached a $4 million settlement with state prosecutors, officials announced on Tuesday.

headline: Sexual Abuse Charges Put Shadow on U.S. Gymnastics Federation
abstract: After its success at the Rio de Janeiro Olympics, U.S.A. Gymnastics is under a cloud of accusations involving coaches suspected of abusing athletes.
lead_paragraph: Considering how many medals U.S.A. Gymnastics brought home from the Rio Games — an amazing 12, including Simone Biles’s three individual golds and the women’s team gold — the federation’s post-Olympics glow should be brighter than ever.

headline: What’s ‘Deplorable’ About Presidential Campaigns
abstract: Candidates have become so dependent on the wealthy that America is at risk of forgetting there is any other way to do politics.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to believe now, but there was a time in American politics, not so long ago, when a presidential candidate might hold only a few fund-raisers, when a serving president — Ronald Reagan, for example — might refuse to appear at any fund-raisers at all for his own re-election campaign. That was back before wily political operatives, and then the Supreme Court, opened the floodgates to cash, and candidates began holding fund-raisers by the score.

headline: House Republicans Dread a Possible Election Result: Bipartisanship
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership']
abstract: Fears are rising among some representatives of what President Obama and their party leaders might cook up during a lame-duck session of Congress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A big conspiracy theory in Washington these days, perhaps second only to the one concerning Hillary Clinton’s supposed body double, is the fear among some House Republicans of what President Obama and their party leaders might cook up during a lame-duck session of Congress after Election Day.

headline: Tip Leads to Vanished Arctic Exploration Ship After 168 Years
abstract: Scientists, researchers and the Canadian Navy and Coast Guard searched for the Terror, a British ship that vanished in 1848 while trying to map the Northwest Passage.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — To solve a 168-year-old Arctic mystery, the Canadian government had spared no expense. Officials over the last several years used satellite and underwater imaging and deployed crews from the navy and coast guard along with scientists and researchers to search for the Terror, a British ship that vanished along with 129 crew members while trying to map the Northwest Passage.

headline: Mike Pence Is Rebuffed as He Tries to Rally G.O.P. Leaders Over ‘Deplorables’
abstract: A plea for unity fell short in blunt meetings with House and Senate leaders, who maintained their distance from the Trump campaign.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Gov. Mike Pence came to Capitol Hill on Tuesday on a mission to promote Republican unity, attacking Hillary Clinton for describing many supporters of the G.O.P. ticket as bigoted “deplorables” and urging Republicans to rally behind their nominee, Donald J. Trump.

headline: Brandon Maxwell: Spring 2017
abstract: Having only launched his brand in September 2015, Lady Gaga’s fashion director presents his latest collection.
lead_paragraph: Having only launched his brand in September 2015, Lady Gaga’s fashion director presents his latest collection.

headline: Mohammad Javad Zarif: Let Us Rid the World of Wahhabism
abstract: The Saudis have spent billions exporting this extremist perversion of theology. It must stop.
lead_paragraph: Tehran — Public relations firms with no qualms about taking tainted petrodollars are experiencing a bonanza. Their latest project has been to persuade us that the Nusra Front, Al Qaeda’s affiliate in Syria, is no more. As a Nusra spokesman told CNN, the rebranded rebel group, supposedly separated from its parent terrorist organization, has become “moderate.”

headline: Ethiopian Marathoner Planned His Defiant Gesture
keywords: ['Olympic Games (2016)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Marathon Running', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Feyisa Lilesa, who won a silver medal at the Rio Olympics, said his action was a show of solidarity with his people against a repressive government.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Ethiopian marathoner who won a silver medal at the Rio Olympics and then crossed his arms over his head in an X at the finish line as an act of political defiance, said Tuesday that he planned the action months before the Games in response to the government “killing, imprisoning, repressing its own people.”

headline: Ask Me Anything
abstract: Dan Schoenholz hangs a Wednesday puzzle on us.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — I would bet that the majority of people who don’t solve regularly probably see crossword puzzles as very stodgy, two-dimensional, nonhumorous intellectual ventures. But once you become a regular solver, you learn that this is far from the truth.

headline: Yuh-Line Niou Defeats Sheldon Silver Ally in Primary for His Old Assembly Seat
abstract: In one of several closely watched contests in New York, Ms. Niou won a six-way Democratic race, defeating Alice Cancel, whom Mr. Silver, the disgraced former speaker, had supported.
lead_paragraph: Yuh-Line Niou won a six-way race on Tuesday for the Democratic nomination to inherit the State Assembly seat once held by Sheldon Silver, in a repudiation of the stubborn grip Mr. Silver held on his Lower Manhattan district for four decades — held, that is, until his conviction late last year on federal corruption charges.

headline: Computer Breach Could Have Exposed Trauma Victims to Further Anguish
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Identity Theft', 'Research', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: A hacker (or hackers) broke into servers that held information provided by 22,000 people for 11 mental health studies being done at the New York State Psychiatric Institute.
lead_paragraph: Havoc sneaks in so often, we shrug. Data breaches, for instance. Hackers break into bank computers or Home Depot terminals to steal credit card numbers, dates of birth, addresses, Social Security numbers.

headline: Mets’ Kelly Johnson Remakes His Swing in Daniel Murphy’s Image
abstract: Johnson, in his second tenure with the Mets, is pulling more balls to right and hitting home runs at the highest rate of his career.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Kelly Johnson does not remember the exact date, but sometime in early August, nearly two months into his second tenure with the Mets, he approached the team’s hitting coach, Kevin Long, and his assistant, Pat Roessler, with an idea that he hoped would make him a more consistent power hitter in his 11th season in the majors.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Wednesday, September 14, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “We lifted three and a half million people out of poverty, the largest one-year drop in poverty since 1968. The uninsured rate is the lowest since they began keeping records. The pay gap between men and women shrank to the lowest level on record. Thanks, Obama.”

headline: Stars Off the Bench Help the Yankees Shut Out the Dodgers
abstract: C.C. Sabathia pitched six and a third innings and struck out seven batters, and Jacoby Ellsbury, Didi Gregorius and Gary Sanchez provided all the offense with solo homers.
lead_paragraph: The grind of a long season leaves its mark in many ways, some visible and some unseen. So, with the Yankees nearing mid-September, and with each game precious as they hunt for a playoff berth, Manager Joe Girardi faced a difficult decision.

headline: Mets Blow Lead Against Nationals, but a Hunch Pays Off

Praising a brutal K.G.B. dictator, especially as preferable to a democratically elected U.S. president, whether you like Obama or hate him, is despicable and dangerous.”

headline: How Trump Might Win
abstract: His odds are poor, he probably loses — but he still has a path, and here’s what he needs to walk it.
lead_paragraph: Like a star-crossed baseball team trying to close out a pennant, Hillary Clinton holds an advantage in the race for president that feels real yet not at all reassuring — for her partisans or for Trump fearers worldwide. She just has to hang on seems like the dominant emotion among her backers, and for that matter among her staff, who handled her ground zero meltdown like a front office desperately trying to minimize the seriousness of a star pitcher’s injury. “Just a bruise … O.K., a muscle pull … we just took him out as a precautionary measure … he’ll make his next start … O.K., fine, he’s on the disabled list.”

President Evo Morales of Bolivia responded, as he does each year, with defiance.

headline: Space Travel: A Vision
abstract: For the young man losing his sight, I am an ambassador from a distant land.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — One night, I had a dream (or half-dream) about swinging on my own for the first time. It started out as a kind of interview, as though I were getting help coming up with an idea for a poem. Someone asked me what I was wearing. I said shorts. Then, after thinking a few seconds, I remembered the short-sleeved seersucker shirts we used to wear, my twin brother, Dave, and I. I may have been about 4, about the age of the boy I can hear crying in the street as I write this — all those partials in his voice, all that open-mouthed speech, full of longing, you can’t quite understand.

headline: Looking at White Privilege Under Apartheid
abstract: The South African photographer David Goldblatt revisits white, middle-class life under apartheid in a new edition of his 1982 book, “In Boksburg.”
lead_paragraph: When we imagine South Africa of the 1970s and 1980s, the most indelible images depicted the violent struggle against apartheid. They are epitomized by Sam Nzima’s iconic photograph of Umbiswa Makhubo carrying Hector Pieterson’s limp body during the Soweto Uprising on June 16, 1976, when police opened fire on schoolchildren protesting forced instruction in Afrikaans. The photo sparked international outrage and more protests, helping to galvanize a resistance movement that eventually vanquished apartheid.

Soon enough we picked up momentum and enjoyed a monthlong, unofficial relationship. I did take some things into consideration before I decided to text her. For instance, I made sure that she was not in a relationship; she said she was only casually seeing other people.

headline: Could Ancient Remedies Hold the Answer to the Looming Antibiotics Crisis?
abstract: One researcher thinks the drugs of the future might come from the past: botanical treatments long overlooked by Western medicine.
lead_paragraph: On a warm, clear evening in March, with the sun still hanging above the horizon, Cassandra Quave climbed aboard a jalapeño-green 4-by-4 and started to drive across her father’s ranch in Arcadia, Fla. Surveying the landscape, most people would have seen a homogenous mat of pasture and weeds punctuated by the occasional tree. Quave saw something quite different: a vast botanical tapestry, rich as a Persian rug. On a wire fence, a Smilax vine dangled menacingly pointed leaves, like a necklace of shark’s teeth. Beneath it, tiny wild daisies and mint ornamented the grass with pink tassels and purple cornets. Up above, on the sloping branches of oak trees, whiskery bromeliads, Spanish moss and the gray fronds of resurrection fern tangled in a miniature jungle all their own.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Ear Candling
keywords: ['Ears and Hearing', 'Medicine and Health', 'Alternative and Complementary Medicine']
abstract: It doesn’t actually get the wax out of your ears. But it can still provide a soothing ritual for a circle of friends.
lead_paragraph: Ear candles are widely and emphatically denounced by doctors as quackery. When burned, the little tubes of waxed gauze are supposed to create a vacuum effect just outside your ear, with the pressure differential pulling wax out and up into the tube itself. Sounds scientific enough, but it’s basically impossible to find evidence that they actually work. WebMD includes them on their list of “5 Home Remedy No-Nos,” alongside rubbing whiskey on a teething baby’s gums and at-home colon cleansing. Putting a flaming tube in your ear and lying down for 10 minutes — a lot can go wrong, apparently.

headline: 27 Million Potential Hispanic Votes. But What Will They Really Add Up To?
abstract: For decades, political analysts have heralded the Latino vote as a “sleeping giant” that will solidify Democrats’ hold on power. But in cycle after cycle, turnout remains dismal.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks after Hillary Clinton accepted the Democratic presidential nomination in Philadelphia, beaming through a hail of gigantic balloons, her campaign’s “Latinos con Hillary” program began in five cities in Virginia. One of the kickoff parties took place at Todos Supermarket in Prince William County, in a modest white room where about 40 people gathered around three tables draped in cheap blue cloth to hear a speech by Clinton’s national Latino-vote director, Lorella Praeli. When she was 2, Praeli, now 28, lost one of her legs in a car accident, but with her crutches, she commanded the room more adroitly than any of the speakers who preceded her, moving among the tables as she rallied her troops. Though the party was advertised on Facebook, most of the men and women in attendance were seasoned Democratic politicians, staff members and volunteers.
