headline: ‘If You’re Thinking About Your Underwear, You’re Wearing the Wrong Underwear’
abstract: Kerry O’Brien, the founder of Commando, which is working with dozens of brands during New York Fashion Week, breaks down what lies beneath.
lead_paragraph: During fashion week, hair and makeup help make the outfit, but don’t overlook the underwear. Without the right underpinnings, even the best dress can go so wrong. Little wonder that just as there are go-to beauty experts (Pat McGrath and Orlando Pita, for example), there is a go-to brand for lingerie. Commando, which not coincidentally also dominates the red carpet, is working with more than 30 brands during New York Fashion Week, including Rodarte, Rag & Bone and Zac Posen.

headline: A Steel Watch Inspired by the Skies
abstract: Louis Charles Breguet’s relationship to the dynamics of flight is now evoked in the new Type XXI 3817 chronograph.
lead_paragraph: Rather than assume the mantle of the famed French watch company his family founded in the 18th century, early aviator Louis Charles Breguet decided instead to fly. While the company (now based in Switzerland) was pioneering chronographs for cockpits in the late 1920s, Louis Charles perfected the gyroplane (a helicopter precursor) and developed a reconnaissance aircraft. The watch manufacturer’s relationship to the dynamics of flight is now evoked in the new Type XXI 3817 chronograph, based on a Breguet model worn for decades by the French air force. Its steel case features a retro dove-gray dial with luminous Arabic numerals, and a slew of complications including a fly-back function and a 12-hour counter.

headline: Sportswear That Feels Nostalgic Yet New
abstract: The right mix of athletic wear and crisp basics hits just the right mark.
lead_paragraph: The right mix of athletic wear and crisp basics hits just the right mark.

headline: Conquering TV With ‘Mad Men.’ Now Matthew Weiner Publishes a Novel.
abstract: Mr. Weiner always carries a notebook to record ideas or overheard dialogue. One of them became the seed for a book, “Heather, the Totality.”
lead_paragraph: Last fall, Matthew Weiner was walking on the Upper East Side of Manhattan when he saw a teenage girl having a tense conversation with a companion near a building under construction.

headline: British Lawmakers Condemn 2011 Intervention in Libya
abstract: A parliamentary committee said the former prime minister, David Cameron, “was ultimately responsible for the failure to develop a coherent Libya strategy.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A committee of British lawmakers issued a damning assessment on Wednesday of the 2011 intervention in Libya led by Britain and France, concluding that the military action had lacked a coherent strategy, had been based on poor intelligence and had led to a political collapse that aided the rise of the Islamic State in North Africa.

headline: 1966: A Trip Deep Into Space
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: NASA astronauts streak 850 miles into space in September 1966.
lead_paragraph: CAPE KENNEDY — Astronauts Charles (Pete) Conrad and Richard F. Gordon today [Sept. 14] streaked 850 miles deep into space — nearly twice as high as man has ever travelled before. ‘‘I tell you, you can’t believe it,’’ Comdr. Conrad radioed to earth as the Gemini-11 spacecraft attained the record height over Australia. ‘‘Just out of my window you can see the top of the world, all the way around… we have the whole southern part of the world out of one window.’’ To reach the record altitude, Comdr. Conrad and Lt. Comdr. Gordon fired the 16,000-pound–thrust engine of an Agena target rocket linked to their spacecraft for 25 seconds. As they sped back into the lower orbit, the spacecraft set a new manned speed record of 17,931 miles an hour. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 15, 1966

headline: Colin Powell, in Hacked Emails, Shows Scorn for Trump and Irritation at Clinton
abstract: The disclosures ripped away the diplomatic jargon and political niceties of a former secretary of state with a sober, thoughtful reputation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Former Secretary of State Colin L. Powell has long been one of the high priests of the Washington establishment, staying quiet in this year’s raucous presidential campaign while tending to his reputation as a thoughtful officer and diplomat.

headline: Angelica Garcia: An Unexpected Conspiracy of One
abstract: Ms. Garcia’s debut album, “Medicine for Birds,” is deliciously unfaithful to the roots and country music that inspired it.
lead_paragraph: Angelica Garcia’s songs take unexpected swoops. Sometimes it’s the music, which is steeped in country-rock and blues, with flickers of indie-rock desolation; sometimes it’s her voice, which is sure and conspiratorial, bendy and grounded. Most often, though, it’s her words, which come together in surprising patterns, a blend of old-timey formalism and magical storytelling.

headline: Danny Brown Shows Respect for His Elders With ‘Atrocity Exhibition’
abstract: His fourth album is coming out — with a new label, Warp — and this rapper says having input from people with more knowledge of genres “made this album better.”
lead_paragraph: The rapper Danny Brown is well aware of his reputation as a freak show: a drug-scarfing, cartoon-haired hedonist with an unsettling yelp of a voice.

headline: A $150 Million Stairway to Nowhere on the Far West Side
abstract: Stephen M. Ross, who is developing Hudson Yards, has a nickname for Thomas Heatherwick’s 15-story structure on the plaza: “the social climber.”
lead_paragraph: By the look of the renderings officially unveiled on Wednesday morning, New York’s next significant landmark may be the city’s biggest Rorschach test, too.

headline: Workers Pay More for Health Care as Companies Shift Burden, Survey Finds
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Employee Fringe Benefits', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Although premiums haven’t risen significantly, workers’ deductibles and shares of those premiums are going up, the nonprofit Kaiser Family Foundation said.
lead_paragraph: State health insurance exchanges created under the new health care law are in turmoil. By contrast, the employer market — where the majority of Americans still get their coverage — seems like a bastion of stability.

headline: Baseball’s Grand Old Men, Like the Rangers, Still Seek First Ring
abstract: Only Bartolo Colon has played as many seasons as the Texas Rangers’ Adrian Beltre and Carlos Beltran, 19, without winning a World Series.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The memories stalk Adrian Beltre, haunting and driving him. He has lived for nearly five years with the exquisite agony of that night in St. Louis when the Texas Rangers came so close to winning the World Series.

headline: Rice and Beans, Plum Torte and Other Midweek Winners
abstract: Celebrate mid-week with a Times classic recipe, then go read some science fiction.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Michiko Kakutani on Twitter: A World of ‘Splendid Dishevelment’
abstract: On Twitter: Michiko Kakutani revels in the gems of news and insights she finds amid the heap of “rumors, speculation and disinformation.”
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into The New York Times and how news, feature and opinion pieces come together at the paper. In this article, The Times’s chief book critic, Michiko Kakutani, shares her appreciation for Twitter and its many charms.

headline: Your Next Pair of Shoes Could Come From a 3-D Printer
keywords: ['3-D Printers', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Venture Capital', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Mobile Applications', 'Start-ups', 'Small Business', 'E-Commerce', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Smartphones']
abstract: Fashion start-ups are using technology like smartphones and 3-D printing to make custom clothing more affordable, and Silicon Valley is taking notice.
lead_paragraph: The assembly line at Feetz has 100 humming 3-D printers. Their sole purpose is to make shoes.

headline: Syrian Nurse Explains Protests in Aleppo
abstract: Modar Shekho, a nurse in Aleppo, Syria, took part in a protest against international aid entering the city on Tuesday evening.
lead_paragraph: Modar Shekho, a nurse in Aleppo, Syria, took part in a protest against international aid entering the city on Tuesday evening.

headline: Tom Krell of How to Dress Well, on Caring
abstract: The songs on his new album, “Care,” build dreamlike edifices of electronic and acoustic sounds and grapple with the complexities of love and human frailties.
lead_paragraph: “There’s been a deficit of joy in music,” said Tom Krell, the 32-year-old songwriter who records as How to Dress Well. “It’s often the case that art is able to produce affects of joy, which energize people against the forces of domination, energize people against cynicism and depression.”

headline: To Take Up a Musical Instrument, First Pick Up Your Phone
abstract: Apps can help you learn to play piano, guitar and other instruments through videos, interactive graphics and real-time feedback on your progress.
lead_paragraph: WHEN given the opportunity, some inexperienced musicians can’t resist strumming a few chords on a guitar or plunking out a few bars of “Chopsticks” on a piano. But with the right app, it’s easy to start learning an instrument right on your smartphone.

headline: Real Estate Executive to Take the Helm at Governors Island
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: Michael M. Samuelian, a vice president at Related Companies, will become president of the Trust for Governors Island, which directs development there.
lead_paragraph: With its food festivals and artist-inspired miniature golf, hammocks and bike rentals, Governors Island has become a summertime playground for New Yorkers — a weekend getaway that happens to be within the city limits.

headline: Guggenheim’s Helsinki Outpost Won’t Get Government Funding
abstract: One of Finland’s ruling parties has vetoed using state money to support the project.
lead_paragraph: Plans for a Guggenheim museum in Helsinki have been thrown into doubt, now that one of Finland’s three ruling parties has vetoed government funding for the project.

lead_paragraph: Sapphire Ventures has closed on a $1 billion fund to invest in privately held start-ups, easing fears about a downturn in the venture capital industry.

headline: A New Wave of Miami Cocktail Lounges Refines the Quaffs
keywords: ['Bars and Nightclubs', 'Cocktails and Mixed Drinks', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The quality-before-quantity movement has largely taken root at a series of new Miami Beach hotels that host destination cocktail bars.
lead_paragraph: On a sultry Tuesday night in Miami, plaid-clad and boho-chic hipsters gathered around the pool at Broken Shaker bar, sipping herb-filled cocktails under strings of soft light bulbs. There was nary a bouncer or bikini in sight, replaced by a neighborly mix of artists, professionals and off-season tourists drawn to this denlike bar in a candlelit alcove by the pool.

headline: Obama Pledges to Lift All Sanctions Against Myanmar
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: President Obama, who met on Wednesday with Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, Myanmar’s leader, sought to reward the country for its efforts to establish a more democratic government.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama pledged on Wednesday to lift all remaining sanctions against Myanmar, seeking to reward the country’s recent moves toward democracy after decades of brutal military rule.

headline: Daily Report: Test-Driving (or Not Driving) the Cars of the Future
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs']
abstract: A ride in a self-driving Uber car in Pittsburgh and a spin in Chevy’s new longer-ranger electric Bolt EV show how the auto world is changing fast.
lead_paragraph: The automobile is known as the machine that changed the world. Now the world is changing automobiles — in a big way.

headline: Mansur Gavriel Turned Its Presentation Into a Museum — and Gift Shop
abstract: The brand’s co-founders Rachel Mansur and Floriana Gavriel talk T through the transformation of Cedar Lake.
lead_paragraph: “From the beginning of the brand, we’ve approached our bags as kinds of sculptures,” says Rachel Mansur, the co-founder of the New York City-based accessories brand Mansur Gavriel. Each season, she and Floriana Gavriel put an incredible amount of thought into the set design for their presentations; see last February’s domestic scene. For spring/summer 2017, a collection that includes more bag and shoe silhouettes than before (and three new materials), but a more edited color palette, they sought a minimal background, transforming the performance space Cedar Lake into a museum and coordinating gift shop. Scroll over the images to go inside last night’s presentation.

headline: 1891: Disastrous Floods in Spain
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Floods create a disaster in Spain in September 1891.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Terrible floods have been caused in the South of Spain by the overflow of the Amarguillo River. It is estimated that 1,300 persons have been drowned. The towns of Valencia, Cas’ellon and Almeria are inundated. There is at least 3ft. of water in the streets. It is not likely that there will be any railroad service south of Madrid for a week at least. The Queen Regent has sent her intendant with ten thousand douros, and has given him carte blanche in the matter of expense for the assistance of the sufferers in the Province of Toledo. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 15, 1891

headline: The Daily Bag: Coach 1941
abstract: T plucks the best bags right off the runway.

headline: Re-enacting a Childhood Trauma on Video. For Art.
abstract: Twenty years ago, the artist Antonia Wright fell into a frozen lake, an incident that inspired her new exhibition.
lead_paragraph: When she was 15, Antonia Wright was walking across the frozen surface of a reservoir near Boston with a friend when the ice gave way, and they both plunged into the freezing water.

headline: Five Places to Shop in Florence
abstract: Savvy shoppers have discovered that Florence is full of exceptional vintage finds, from antiques, furniture and clothing to retro treasures.
lead_paragraph: Florence may be known for its current designer offerings — from the likes of Ferragamo, Gucci and Marni — but savvy shoppers have also discovered that the city is full of exceptional vintage finds, from antiques, furniture and clothing to retro treasures. In fact, in the last few years the city has welcomed a number of new secondhand shops that have only added to the richness of an already considerable vintage shopping scene.

headline: Off the Cuff, but on the Record
abstract: Suki Kim thought she was speaking privately when she criticized a fellow author to a Times reporter at a private event. Then she read his story.
lead_paragraph: Suppose you’re at a conference. The panels and keynotes and forums have broken up, and you head off to get a drink with a handful of attendees. Are you on the record?

lead_paragraph: It turns out that Pluto may be responsible for maintaining the highlights on the red head of its biggest moon.

headline: After Years of War, Celebrities Find a Syrian Group to Back

lead_paragraph: The complex and brutal conflict in Syria has defied the best efforts of peace negotiators and humanitarian officials for more than five years, but a new group of luminaries is weighing in on a war that has cost hundreds of thousands of lives: celebrities.

headline: How to View a Richer Year for the Poor and Middle Class
abstract: It was one of the best years of income growth in nearly half a century for the poor and the middle class, but 2015 still couldn’t undo years of decline.
lead_paragraph: The income and poverty report released on Tuesday by the Census Bureau was such a blockbuster that you’d think the bureau had just issued Beyoncé’s next secret album the night before.

headline: Review: ‘Feminist Fight Club’ Takes On Workplace Sexism
abstract: Grounded in academic research, Jessica Bennett’s “Feminist Fight Club” is “Lean In” conceived as an illustrated guide for millennials in the office.
lead_paragraph: The last 20 years has seen a reduction in many of the most blatant forms of workplace discrimination against women. A recent Harvard Business Review article reported, however, that subtle bias is often worse than the more overt variety. The very ambiguity of the behavior heightens stress and diminishes the chances of successfully seeking recourse, legal or otherwise. This could explain, in part, the stubborn persistence of the wage gap and continued underrepresentation of women in top corporate and professional roles — despite decades of women outnumbering and outperforming men through college.

headline: Alicia Keys and the ‘Tyranny of Makeup’
keywords: ['Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Beauty (Concept)', 'Women and Girls', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Music']
abstract: When the pop singer put down her lipstick and eye shadow, she shook up the internet.
lead_paragraph: It was the Friday before Labor Day, and Alicia Keys, the 35-year-old pop star, was on the “Today” show performing for the program’s summer concert series — she’s about to release a new album, and she wrote the theme song for “Queen of Katwe,” out next week. There was a lot to talk about. But instead, Ms. Keys spent most of her time talking about makeup (and not wearing it) with the anchors Tamron Hall, Billy Bush and Al Roker, who were doggedly wiping the pancake off their faces.

headline: Big Bayer-Monsanto Deal Lags in Value
abstract: The price of building a seed-and-fertilizer giant with revenue of $26 billion, but a value of $12 billion, is too high.
lead_paragraph: The German pharmaceutical group Bayer has finally agreed to buy the American seed-maker Monsanto for $66 billion. Shareholders in Bayer do not get the chance to vote on the takeover, but they have already made their views plain. Compared with the wider market, Bayer shares have probably lost $7 billion in value already.

headline: Everything’s Coming Up Daisies for Michael Kors
abstract: An unexpected performance and political statement by Rufus Wainwright cast the collection in a whole new light.
lead_paragraph: Of all the antidotes to Hillary Clinton’s recent stumble (literal and metaphorical) that could have appeared, the Michael Kors show is not the one that immediately leaps to mind.

headline: Free Wi-Fi Kiosks Were to Aid New Yorkers. An Unsavory Side Has Spurred a Retreat.
abstract: The operator is shutting off the internet browsers because they have drawn people who linger for hours, sometimes drinking, using drugs or watching pornography.
lead_paragraph: The Wi-Fi kiosks in New York were designed to replace phone booths and allow users to consult maps, maybe check the weather or charge their phones. But they have also attracted people who linger for hours, sometimes drinking and doing drugs and, at times, boldly watching pornography on the sidewalks.

headline: A.C.C. Pulls League Championships Out of North Carolina
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'College Athletics', 'Discrimination', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Citing an anti-gay-rights law it called “inconsistent” with the conference’s values, the league will relocate neutral site championships.
lead_paragraph: The Atlantic Coast Conference announced Wednesday that it would move neutral-site championships for this academic year, including its football title game in December and its women’s basketball tournament in March, out of North Carolina in reaction to a state law that curbed anti-discrimination protections for lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people.

headline: In a Besieged Town, No Food and No Escape

lead_paragraph: Hala Abdulwahab, 24, is a teacher in Madaya, Syria, near the Lebanese border. Civilians in the town struggle to get food on a daily basis.

abstract: Bells will sound on Sept. 24 to herald the new museum — including one bell from a church founded by slaves and free blacks in 1776 in a ceremony led by the president.
lead_paragraph: Listen for the bells on Sept. 24 when churches in Washington and around the country are scheduled to herald the opening of the National Museum of African American History and Culture in Washington.

headline: A Trip to Matty Bovan’s York Studio
abstract: The designer, who will present his first collection during London Fashion Week, has already worked with Marc Jacobs.
lead_paragraph: The designer, who will present his first collection during London Fashion Week, has already worked with Marc Jacobs.

headline: Inside an Emerging British Designer’s Candy-Colored World
abstract: The 26-year-old Matty Bovan, of York, England, was christened by Marc Jacobs — before he even showed his first London Fashion Week collection.
lead_paragraph: “Come take a look at this — this is a good color because it’s a bit gross,” says the 26-year old British designer Matty Bovan as he pulls a swatch of neon green velour from underneath a sewing machine. “How can it not be a bit revolting?” he continues. “I love taking these taboo fabrics like Aertex or velour that other designers would discredit — I like taking something wrong and making it desirable.”

headline: Jerry Brown’s Disappointing Tampon Tax Decision
abstract: Californians will keep paying sales tax on tampons, thanks to the governor’s veto.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Gov. Jerry Brown of California unwisely vetoed a bill that would have exempted tampons, pads and other menstrual products from the state’s 7.5 percent sales tax. The measure passed the state Legislature unanimously in August. But Governor Brown vetoed it along with six other tax bills, arguing that “tax breaks are the same as new spending” and should be considered during budget deliberations. The seven bills would have cut state revenue by around $300 million over the next two years, he said.

lead_paragraph: Tuesday night’s festivities included cocktails at the Pierre Hotel for Ms. Burch’s new collection, and a party for Interview magazine.

headline: Model Beauty Secrets, From a New York Fashion Week Newcomer
abstract: Backstage at Michael Kors, Mayowa Nicholas caught up with T to discuss her tricks for radiant skin, favorite hair products and more.
lead_paragraph: Backstage at Michael Kors’ spring/summer 2017 show, the mix of models represented exactly what the designer had in mind: “I really wanted diversity as far as the look of the girls, and diversity as far as body types,” he said. And in between supernovas from Kendall Jenner to Carolyn Murphy, stood the striking 5’ 11” Mayowa Nicholas, a newcomer who only began modeling two years ago but has already made quite a mark. Since winning an Elite modeling competition in her native Nigeria in 2014, Nicholas has walked for a number of top-tier European fashion houses including Christian Dior, Prada, Miu Miu, Hermès and Loewe. (After closing Loewe, Nicholas posted on Instagram: “Dreams do come true.”) Last fall, Nicholas became the first Nigerian model to star in a Dolce & Gabbana ad campaign — a milestone moment not only for the Lagos-born beauty, but the industry as a whole. T caught up with Nicholas to talk about her debut at New York Fashion Week this season, her beauty secrets and why Kors is a true fashion king.

headline: Autopilot Cited in Death of Chinese Tesla Driver
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']

lead_paragraph: Tesla Motors came under renewed questioning about the safety of its Autopilot technology after news emerged on Wednesday of a fatal crash in China that may have occurred while the automated driver-assist system was operating.

headline: ‘Human Glitter.’ The Beckerman Twins Are Fashion Week Stars
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week']

lead_paragraph: Sam and Cailli Beckerman go through every waking moment as if they have just won the big prize on the fun wheel. They radiate optimism to an almost absurd degree. They dress bravely and outrageously.

headline: Denzel Washington, Ethan Hawke and Antoine Fuqua on ‘The Magnificent Seven’
abstract: Mr. Fuqua has remade the 1960 western. Here, he talks about the film with Mr. Washington and Mr. Hawke.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — At the heart of “The Magnificent Seven,” John Sturges’s classic 1960 western, is a group of flawed men (including Yul Brynner, Steve McQueen, Charles Bronson and James Coburn) who have never worked as a team, but who come together to defeat a nefarious bandit (Eli Wallach). That dynamic, adapted from Akira Kurosawa’s “Seven Samurai,” endures in the director Antoine Fuqua’s update of “The Magnificent Seven,” in which Denzel Washington, Ethan Hawke, Chris Pratt and others are the mismatched gunslingers; Peter Sarsgaard is the ruthless industrialist they are set against.

headline: Scottish Nurse Who Had Ebola Is Cleared of Misconduct
abstract: The nurse, Pauline Cafferkey, contracted Ebola in Sierra Leone in 2014 and had been accused of concealing her high temperature from health officials.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A Scottish nurse who contracted Ebola in Sierra Leone in 2014 and had been accused of concealing her high temperature from health officials after her return to Britain was cleared of professional misconduct charges at an administrative hearing on Wednesday.

headline: Sales of Hillary Clinton’s New Book Are Off to a Slow Start
abstract: “Stronger Together,” Mrs. Clinton’s blueprint for where she wants to take the country, sold less than 3,000 copies in its first week — compared with 85,000 of her 2014 memoir.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton’s newest book, “Stronger Together,” which provides a policy blueprint for where she hopes to take the country if she is elected president, sold just 2,912 copies in its first week on sale, according to Nielsen BookScan.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Luxe Silk Bra Tops
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Lingerie and Underwear', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: Victoria Beckham, Alexander Wang and Phillip Lim make the case for no shirt, no problem.
lead_paragraph: While some designers this season took the concept of the classic pinstriped shirt and turned it on its head — others eschewed shirts altogether. Alexander Wang sent a lace-trimmed bra down the runway, poking out from under a tuxedo jacket, Victoria Beckham showed a crushed-silk version with matching trousers — and Phillip Lim paired a silk bra with a Western-inspired embroidered jacket.

headline: Gabriela Hearst, Now a Horsewoman of a Different Color
abstract: With her spring collection, the designer tries on sex appeal.
lead_paragraph: Gabriela Hearst is a natural ambassador for wool. She grew up, as has been lavishly documented in the press, on a ranch in Uruguay with thousands of sheep, though she has since relocated to an expensive ZIP code in Manhattan. She requires little prodding to celebrate wool’s versatility and its strength.

headline: ‘Lula,’ Brazil’s Ex-President, Is Charged With Corruption
abstract: Prosecutors say that Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva and his wife illegally benefited from about $1.1 million in work at a beachfront apartment paid for by a company seeking public contracts.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Federal prosecutors in Brazil filed corruption charges Wednesday against Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, the former president who has wielded influence across Latin America for decades, portraying him as the mastermind of a sprawling graft scheme intended to maintain his party’s grip on the presidency.

headline: How Long Is an Actress Onscreen? A New Tool Finds the Answer Faster.
abstract: Software developed for the Geena Davis Institute on Gender in Media could analyze a 90-minute film in 15 minutes, an engineer said.
lead_paragraph: The effort to catalog the inequity in onscreen roles for women and minorities has a new weapon. The Geena Davis Institute on Gender in Media, at Mount Saint Mary’s University, with financial backing from Google.org, the company’s philanthropic division, will announce on Wednesday a tool that employs video- and audio-recognition technology, along with algorithms, to identify gender, speaking time and additional details about characters presented in films, television shows and other media.

headline: Rufus Wainwright Gets Happy at Michael Kors
abstract: A stumble by Bella Hadid not did faze Mr. Wainwright, who performed Judy Garland’s “Get Happy” and other songs.
lead_paragraph: Fashion shows are not always uplifting affairs. Yet there was Rufus Wainwright at the Michael Kors show Wednesday morning, singing Judy Garland’s “Get Happy” with a six-piece band as models marched out in white twin sets and floral print dresses.

headline: The Modern Love Podcast: Kristin Chenoweth Reads ‘Revenge of the Friend’
abstract: On this week’s Modern Love podcast, the “Wicked” actress reads the story of a spinning instructor exploring her more sadistic side.
lead_paragraph: In this episode of Modern Love: The Podcast, the actress Kristin Chenoweth (“Wicked,” “Glee”) reads the essay “Revenge of the Friend,” about a spinning instructor whose usually pleasant Saturday-morning class is upset by a couple of new cyclists.

headline: Boss Women: Spring 2017
abstract: Designer Jason Wu shows his spring 2017 women’s collection.
lead_paragraph: Designer Jason Wu shows his spring 2017 women’s collection.

headline: See How Popular Your Flickr Photos Are
abstract: Users who pay for Flickr Pro accounts get more perks than free account holders, including statistics on the audience viewing their pictures.
lead_paragraph: Q. Is there a way to see a chart of how many people have looked at my Flickr photos?

headline: Muslim Teenager Proposes Emoji of Woman Wearing a Head Scarf
keywords: ['Emojis and Emoticons', 'Muslim Veiling', 'Women and Girls', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: A 15-year-old high school student in Berlin is proposing an emoji with a head scarf, or hijab, to represent the millions of Muslim women who wear one.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The choice of princess, bride or dancer did not really allow Rayouf Alhumedhi to express herself in a chat room she was creating. As a Muslim teenager in Germany who wears a head scarf, she was disappointed by the standard emoji options on her smartphone keyboard.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump Give More Details on Their Health
abstract: Mrs. Clinton elaborated on her pneumonia diagnosis and treatment, and Mr. Trump acknowledged that he was overweight and taking medication to lower cholesterol.
lead_paragraph: With less than eight weeks until Election Day and pressure mounting for the candidates to give details about their health and medical histories, Donald J. Trump acknowledged on Wednesday that he was overweight and taking a cholesterol-fighting drug, and Hillary Clinton elaborated on the circumstances that led to her contracting pneumonia and the medicine she was taking to recover.

headline: U.N. Chief Says North Korea Has Spawned Unprecedented Tension
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'International Relations', 'United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Tests']
abstract: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon urged the Security Council to take “urgent actions” in a news conference before his last annual General Assembly session as the United Nations leader.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Secretary General Ban Ki-moon warned on Wednesday that North Korea’s repeated tests of nuclear bombs and ballistic missiles had created unprecedented tension in the region.

headline: Considering Cremation? What You Need to Know
abstract: Though cremation has grown in popularity, substantial numbers of funeral homes don’t tell consumers of the availability and cost of a basic cremation.
lead_paragraph: Cremation is becoming more popular than burial, but getting clear information about options and prices can be a challenge, a new report finds.

headline: Prostate Cancer Study Details Value of Treatments
abstract: A 10-year study of more than 1,500 men with early prostate cancer found no difference in death rates between men who had surgery or radiation and those who monitored the disease.
lead_paragraph: A new study offers important information to men who are facing difficult decisions about how to treat prostate cancer in its early stages, or whether to treat it at all.

headline: Fox Co-Presidents Sign Multiyear Contracts
abstract: After a sexual harassment scandal and the departure of Roger Ailes at Fox News, the elevations of Bill Shine and Jack Abernethy are meant to promote calm.
lead_paragraph: Fox News already doubled down on its leadership team last month when it announced that Roger Ailes’s major deputies were being elevated into top positions at the network.

headline: Home to High-Security Lab and Source of Rumors, Plum Island Faces Uncertain Future
keywords: ['Livestock Diseases', 'Laboratories and Scientific Equipment', 'Research', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Islands', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Land Use Policies', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: Journalists were given a glimpse of the federal Plum Island Animal Disease Center off Long Island, which will be closed within the next decade. Officials are marketing the island to developers.
lead_paragraph: PLUM ISLAND, N.Y. — There have been comparisons to the H.G. Wells novel, “The Island of Dr. Moreau,” a nod from Hannibal Lecter in “The Silence of the Lambs,” and a murder mystery called “Plum Island,” by Nelson DeMille, in 1997. When the carcass of an unidentified animal was found on a Long Island beach a few years ago, it became popularly known as the Montauk Monster, and local residents said it had come from — where else? — Plum Island.

headline: Shop the Newest See-Now, Buy-Now Collections
abstract: Michael Kors, Thakoon, Tom Ford and other labels will be sending clothes racing directly off the runway into stores.
lead_paragraph: Shop the see-now/buy-now collections just shown at New York Fashion Week. You’ll find items like an oversize cashmere Love intarsia pullover ($995) at the new Michael Kors serialized pop-up shop titled the Kors Edit, where September’s theme is “Ready-to-Wear, Ready to Go.” At 384 Bleecker Street.

headline: Review: ‘Blood at the Root,’ a Tale of Racial Cleansing Close to Home
abstract: Patrick Phillips’s first nonfiction book is about a Georgia county that banished all its black citizens in 1912 and was still 99.95 percent white in 1997.
lead_paragraph: Early one morning in September 1912, an 18-year-old white girl named Mae Crow was discovered in the Georgia woods, badly beaten and barely alive. It took only a day for the Forsyth County sheriff to arrest three young black male suspects. Two were hanged by the state within two months; the other was hanged by a mob within 48 hours.

headline: The Exciting New Directions of a Few Top Designers
abstract: Three creative forces are developing surprising products with unexpected partners.
lead_paragraph: Three creative forces are developing surprising products with unexpected partners.

headline: Review: A Zany Renée Zellweger and Mystery Daddy in ‘Bridget Jones’s Baby’
abstract: The latest film in this series revolves around the pregnancy of Ms. Zellweger’s character and the two dreamboats most likely to be the father.
lead_paragraph: Who could dislike Bridget Jones, the zany screwball heroine whose latest and probably last screen incarnation, in “Bridget Jones’s Baby,” finds the character back where she started: alone and single?

headline: Review: Usher’s ‘Hard II Love’ Uses Regret as a Selling Point
abstract: This R&B singer’s latest album includes his usual suave delivery and appearances by Rubén Blades and others.
lead_paragraph: No one converts an apology into a come-on more suavely than Usher, who releases his eighth solo studio album, “Hard II Love,” this week. It’s a stratagem he perfected as far back as 2004 with “Confessions,” which became his best-selling album. Some sincere contrition, a request for mercy, an appeal to a longtime bond, a reminder of physical chemistry and voilá — he’s sweet-talked his way to another chance.

headline: That Cute Whale You Clicked On? It’s Doomed
keywords: ['ANIMALS', 'Photography', 'Global Warming', 'Social Media', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Endangered and Extinct Species']
abstract: Adorable animal photos on Instagram are the new way to spread the dire message of climate change.
lead_paragraph: I was scrolling through Instagram when I saw it: a white fuzz ball of a baby seal, snuggling in a snowdrift. I stared dopily into its clear black eyes, squealed at the screen and tapped the cartoon heart beneath the photo. You better believe I liked it.

headline: $100 Million Awarded in Contest to Rethink U.S. High Schools
abstract: The 10 winners, which include the Brooklyn Laboratory Charter High School, will each get $10 million from the XQ Institute. It is backed by Laurene Powell Jobs, the widow of Steven P. Jobs.
lead_paragraph: An organization announced on Wednesday that it had chosen the winners of $10 million grants in a competition to rethink the American high school.

headline: MoMA Will Make Thousands of Exhibition Images Available Online
abstract: After years of planning and digitizing, the museum is putting almost 33,000 exhibition photographs online, along with hundreds of catalogs and more.
lead_paragraph: The Museum of Modern Art, which has defined Modernism more powerfully than perhaps any other institution, can often seem monolithic in the mind’s eye, essentially unchanged since its doors opened in 1929: a procession of solemn white-box galleries, an ice palace of formalism, the Kremlin (as the artist Martha Rosler once called it) of 20th-century art.

headline: Congress Considers Plan to Curb Ticket ‘Bots’
abstract: Lawmakers, anxious about the role of automated ticket-buying software in driving up prices, is considering legislation to criminalize its use.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Bill Nelson sounded exasperated. “I did not get to go see ‘Hamilton,’” this Florida Democrat told the musical’s lead producer on Tuesday. “The reason I didn’t go: I did not want to pay $800 a ticket.”

headline: Trump Talks About His Health on ‘Dr. Oz’
abstract: Donald J. Trump taped an episode of “The Dr. Oz Show” on Wednesday and handed over a one-page summary of his recent physical examination.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump taped an episode of “The Dr. Oz Show” on Wednesday and handed over a one-page summary of his recent physical examination.

headline: ‘Hillsong’ Casts a Secular Lens on an Evangelical Band
abstract: Michael John Warren, a director of MTV documentaries, has made a concert film about Hillsong United, a band backed by a Pentecostal megachurch.
lead_paragraph: Michael John Warren, the director of MTV documentaries about Drake and Nicki Minaj, perked up a few years ago when he heard about a big music film that was kicking around Hollywood.

headline: U.S. Presidential Race, Colin Powell, Carla Hayden: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Review: ‘Blossom,’ a Puppet’s Tale of Alzheimer’s
abstract: Spencer Lott’s play shines in its wordless moments as it follows the decline of a 76-year-old widower with Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: With his tufted white eyebrows and kindly old face, James Blossom is instantly endearing — even more so in his patterned sweater vest and jaunty bow tie. But when he first appears at the start of Spencer Lott’s puppet play, “Blossom,” at Dixon Place, James is outfitted for underwater adventure.

headline: Off the Runway: Day 7
abstract: Scenes from New York Fashion Week on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from New York Fashion Week on Wednesday.

headline: محمدجواد ظریف: بیایید جهان را از وهابیت خلاص کنیم
abstract: سعودی ها میلیاردها دلار صرف صدور این انحراف افراطی ازدین کرده اند. این باید متوقف شود.
lead_paragraph: سعودی ها میلیاردها دلار صرف صدور این انحراف افراطی ازدین کرده اند. این باید متوقف شود.

headline: Off the Runway: Day 7
abstract: Scenes from New York Fashion Week on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Moments from the shows of Naeem Khan, Bibhu Mohapatra and Delpozo.

headline: ‘All Syrians Are Tired of This Absurd War’: Voices From the Cease-Fire
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The truce held without many notable violations in its first two days. How did it change the daily lives of people around the country?
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In rebel-held areas of Syria, Day 2 of a shaky cease-fire offered a rare chance to go outside. For some, that meant enjoying the simple pleasure of playing on a swing. For others, it meant protesting.

headline: Jack Hofsiss, Stage Director of ‘The Elephant Man,’ Dies at 65
abstract: After becoming the youngest director to win a Tony, at 28, he went on to direct films and other plays, even after being paralyzed in an accident.
lead_paragraph: Jack Hofsiss, who became the youngest director to win a Tony Award when, at 28, he was honored for his work on “The Elephant Man” in 1979, and who resumed his career after being paralyzed in a diving accident, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 65.

headline: New Librarian of Congress Offers a History Lesson in Her Own Right
abstract: Carla D. Hayden, sworn in to oversee the library’s 162 million items, is the first African-American and the first woman to hold the position.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On the night in April 2015 that Baltimore went up in flames, Carla D. Hayden, the city’s chief librarian, was under pressure to board up a neighborhood library branch and wait out the violence triggered by the death of Freddie Gray after being injured in police custody.

headline: Four Actresses Everyone Will Be Talking About This Fall
abstract: Actresses Ruth Negga, Sasha Lane, Kim Tae-Ri and Auli’i Cravalho give movie performances worth a look this season.
lead_paragraph: These four actresses, featured in films scheduled for release this fall, are newcomers to film or new to American audiences. They won’t be unfamiliar names for long.

headline: Wells Fargo Subpoenaed in Sham Account Case
abstract: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan and San Francisco are investigating how bank employees secretly opened accounts without customers’ consent.
lead_paragraph: Wells Fargo has received subpoenas from three different United States attorneys’ offices in the last week, escalating an investigation into how thousands of bank employees came to secretly issue more than a million sham accounts without customers’ consent.

headline: Marchesa: Spring 2017
abstract: Georgina Chapman and Keren Craig present their latest looks.
lead_paragraph: Georgina Chapman and Keren Craig present their latest looks.

headline: Clinton Foundation Initiative to Become Independent if Hillary Wins
abstract: A plan to spin off the Clinton Health Access Initiative from the foundation is the latest effort to alleviate concerns about potential conflicts of interest.
lead_paragraph: The largest arm of the Bill, Hillary & Chelsea Clinton Foundation will spin off into an independent organization if Hillary Clinton is elected president, the charity said Wednesday in the latest effort by the foundation and the campaign to alleviate concerns about potential conflicts of interest.

headline: Jurors Picked for Bridge Scandal Trial as Opinions About Chris Christie Are Aired
abstract: The two days of jury selection underscored how much the case is about the New Jersey governor, even though he is not charged and has repeatedly disassociated himself from the lane-closing scheme.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — The jury of seven women and five men that will decide whether a political scandal involving the closing of approach lanes at the George Washington Bridge rose to the level of a federal crime includes a certified paralegal who lives in the same town as Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey and says she does not like him.

headline: Rights Groups, Riding Film Publicity, Urge Pardon for Edward Snowden
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Whistle-Blowers', 'Movies', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: Three human rights groups asked President Obama to pardon Mr. Snowden, who is played by Joseph Gordon-Levitt in a new Oliver Stone movie.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Three human rights groups on Wednesday urged President Obama to pardon Edward J. Snowden, the former intelligence contractor who leaked secret documents about National Security Agency surveillance in 2013 and is living in Russia as a fugitive from criminal charges.

headline: A Healthy Snack on the M66
abstract: A rider on a crosstown bus watches as another passenger munches on a carrot, a radish and a cucumber.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Union Leader of New Hampshire Endorses Gary Johnson Over Donald Trump
abstract: The newspaper publisher called Mr. Trump a liar, and for the first time in more than 100 years, the paper is not endorsing the Republican nominee for president, choose the Libertarian nominee.
lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump returns to campaign in New Hampshire on Thursday, he will be greeted by a familiar, if unwelcome, sight — a blistering attack on the front page of The Union Leader.

headline: Disney Cuts 250 Jobs in Consumer Products and Digital Unit
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Computer and Video Games']
abstract: The layoffs, while small given Disney’s sheer size, have followed a pattern in recent months as the company tries to move fast to control costs.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Disney cut 5 percent of its consumer products and digital media staff on Wednesday, or about 250 jobs, a spokesman said, the latest in a series of belt-tightening moves by the world’s largest entertainment conglomerate.

headline: You Don’t Know What Arte Povera Is? They Can Change That
abstract: Nancy Olnick and Giorgio Spanu plan to exhibit hundreds of pieces from the avant-garde movement at their building in Cold Spring, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: ROME — If you don’t know much about Arte Povera, the 1960s Italian avant-garde movement whose proponents created minimalist works using humble or organic materials, two New York collectors are hoping to change that.

headline: Myanmar’s Leader Has a Longtime Champion in Mitch McConnell
abstract: Visiting Washington this week, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi will reunite with the Senate majority leader, who has supported her attempts to promote democracy at home for years.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Myanmar’s pro-democracy figure and government leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, makes her way through Washington’s power centers this week, one face is particularly familiar: Senator Mitch McConnell, who has been watching her for decades, usually at great remove.

headline: Myanmar Leader’s Unexpected Supporter
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: Of all the relationships Daw Aung San Suu Kyi has made with American officials, the most longstanding is with Senator Mitch McConnell, the lead sponsor of U.S. sanctions on Myanmar.
lead_paragraph: Of all the relationships Daw Aung San Suu Kyi has made with American officials, the most longstanding is with Senator Mitch McConnell, the lead sponsor of U.S. sanctions on Myanmar.

headline: Julio Gonzalez, Arsonist Who Killed 87 at New York Club in ’90, Dies at 61
abstract: Mr. Gonzalez was sentenced to 87 concurrent terms of 25 years for starting the fire, which prompted the city to renew its scrutiny of safety measures at nightclubs.
lead_paragraph: Julio Gonzalez, a jilted lover whose arson revenge at the unlicensed Happy Land nightclub in the Bronx in 1990 claimed 87 lives, making him the nation’s worst single mass murderer at the time, died on Tuesday at a hospital in Plattsburgh, N.Y., where he had been taken from prison. He was 61.

headline: A Rebounding Economy Remains Fragile for Many
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'States (US)', 'Income']
abstract: Gains that have been strong for people who live in large metropolitan centers have not reached people who live in rural areas, industrial centers and Appalachia.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The eye-popping improvement in economic fortunes last year raises the question: If incomes are up and poverty is down, why is Donald J. Trump’s message of economic decay resonating so broadly?

headline: Obama Prods Netanyahu After Signing of U.S.-Israel Aid Deal
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Palestinians', 'Foreign Aid']
abstract: Mr. Obama stressed the importance of resolving the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, an imperative he said was as vital to Israel’s security as the military aid itself.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Wednesday renewed his call for a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and argued that it was crucial to Israel’s security, using the completion of a new agreement to provide $38 billion in American military aid as an occasion to prod Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on a long-running dispute.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Thursday, September 15, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “I’m just doing small electrical jobs to dog-paddle my way through till Mr. Trump gets elected.”

headline: Arrest Made in Arson at Mosque That Orlando Nightclub Gunman Attended
keywords: ['ARSON', 'Mosques', 'Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Fires and Firefighters']
abstract: A Florida man who espoused anti-Islamic views on social media was charged with setting a fire that damaged a mosque in Fort Pierce, Fla., the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A Florida man who espoused anti-Islamic views on social media was charged with arson on Wednesday in connection with a fire on Sunday that damaged a mosque in Fort Pierce, Fla., the authorities said.

headline: Marines Scrutinize a Culture of Toughness After a Muslim Recruit’s Death
keywords: ['Hazing', 'Muslim Americans', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: In light of the death and other hazing at the Parris Island training center, the Marine Corps is grappling with how to foster a hardening process for recruits while safeguarding them.
lead_paragraph: At Parris Island in South Carolina, the Marine Corps’s oldest and most famous training center, the Third Recruit Training Battalion was called “the Thumping Third” — a nickname it earned through drill instructors’ reputation for dishing out physical abuse.

headline: America’s Mr. Diplomacy
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials']
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry has worked hard for a cease-fire in Syria, but it will be largely up to Russia to make it succeed.
lead_paragraph: Since becoming secretary of state more than three years ago, John Kerry has been a man on a mission — multiple missions, in fact — relentlessly traveling the globe in search of diplomatic solutions to the world’s toughest problems.

headline: Russian Hackers Draw Attention to Drug-Use Exemptions for Athletes
keywords: ['Doping (Sports)', 'Athletics and Sports', 'Olympic Games (2016)', 'Tennis', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers']
abstract: Russian hackers who breached the World Anti-Doping Agency’s databases revealed therapeutic exemptions for 10 more U.S. Olympians, including medal winners at the Rio Games.
lead_paragraph: After Major League Baseball added amphetamines to its list of banned substances in 2007, many players appeared to exploit a loophole. They applied for what is known as a therapeutic use exemption, a waiver to use a prohibited drug for a legitimate medical reason.

headline: Neighbor Recalls Potsdam Killing: A Scream, a Crash, and ‘Then It Was Silent’
abstract: Marissa Hall’s testimony in the trial of Oral Nicholas Hillary, who is accused of murdering 12-year-old Garrett Phillips, prompted the boy’s grandmother to collapse in court.
lead_paragraph: CANTON, N.Y. — The scream was high-pitched, the witness said, almost feminine, and undeniably scared.

headline: Check From Trump Foundation Sent to Committee Supporting the Florida Attorney General
abstract: On Sept. 9, 2013, Donald J. Trump signed a check from his foundation to And Justice for All, a political committee supporting Pam Bondi, the Florida attorney general. The date of the check, which was included in documents released on Tuesday by the New York attorney general, highlights that the contribution appeared to be on its way before Ms. Bondi's office said publicly that it was reviewing complaints about Mr. Trump's for-profit education company, Trump University.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 9, 2013, Donald J. Trump signed a check from his foundation to And Justice for All, a political committee supporting Pam Bondi, the Florida attorney general. The date of the check, which was included in documents released on Tuesday by the New York attorney general, highlights that the contribution appeared to be on its way before Ms. Bondi's office said publicly that it was reviewing complaints about Mr. Trump's for-profit education company, Trump University.

headline: New Records Shed Light on Donald Trump’s $25,000 Gift to Florida Official
abstract: Documents obtained this week by The New York Times, including a copy of Mr. Trump’s check, at least partly undercut a timeline that looked like a quid pro quo.
lead_paragraph: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — It was Aug. 29, 2013, an unremarkable day inside Florida’s whitewashed Capitol, and a typically sweltering one outside among the moss-bearded oaks and sabal palms. Around 3:45 p.m., Jennifer Meale, the communications director for Attorney General Pam Bondi, fielded a seemingly routine call from a financial reporter for The Orlando Sentinel. The attorney general of New York had recently filed a lawsuit against Donald J. Trump alleging fraud in the marketing of Trump University’s real estate and wealth-building seminars. Had Florida ever conducted its own investigation, the reporter asked.

headline: Mets Lose Game but Not Any Ground
abstract: Wilson Ramos’s seventh-inning homer lifted the Nationals over the Mets, who kept their place in the wild-card hunt as the Giants and the Cardinals lost.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The out-of-town results at Nationals Park are displayed on an electronic scoreboard along the wall in right-center field, and from the visitors’ dugout along the third-base line, the Mets had a clear view of what their competitors were doing. So even though they fell to the Washington Nationals, 1-0, on Wednesday afternoon on one pitch from Fernando Salas to Wilson Ramos, the Mets knew exactly where they stood.

headline: ‘Pandemonium’ Ensues After Fight on J Train
abstract: The police say an off-duty officer hit a conductor during an argument, touching off a commotion and then a panic.
lead_paragraph: When Josh Fjelstad boarded the J train in Bushwick, Brooklyn, on Wednesday morning, he thought he might be early for his job in Manhattan.

headline: Yankees Match a Dominant Kershaw, Then Fumble the Game Away
abstract: Kershaw, in his second start off the disabled list, pitched five scoreless innings. But a lack of hits and errors in the ninth eventually capsized the Yankees against the Dodgers.
lead_paragraph: After the torrent of rain had subsided and the ominous clouds had passed by, replaced by the encroaching darkness of the early evening, Clayton Kershaw occupied the mound at Yankee Stadium, undisturbed by nature or precaution. The Yankees and the Los Angeles Dodgers had waited through 48 minutes of a rain delay — their second of the day — and it stood to reason that Kershaw would not still be standing when it dissipated.

headline: Sowing Doubt Is Seen as Prime Danger in Hacking Voting System
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voting and Voters', 'Voting Machines', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Computer Security']
abstract: Disrupting the presidential election would be far easier than changing the outcome by computer hacking, officials say. But disruption may have already begun.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Russian hackers would not be able to change the outcome of the United States presidential election, the nation’s most senior intelligence and law enforcement officials have assured Congress and the White House in recent weeks.

headline: A Twin Threat Rises in Buffalo
abstract: Bills Coach Rex Ryan has brought on his fraternal twin, Rob, as the team’s new assistant head coach for defense.
lead_paragraph: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y — The coaches are fraternal twins. One wears a beard and long gray hair, and the other a fresh haircut and shave.

headline: Parents Renew a Personal Push to Compel CPR Training for Police in New York
abstract: The family of Briana Ojeda, an 11-year-old who died of an asthma attack in 2010, is pressing once again for legislation that would require regular CPR training for officers.
lead_paragraph: In summer 2010, 11-year-old Briana Ojeda had an asthma attack on a playground in the Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn. Unwilling to wait for an ambulance, her mother, Carmen Ojeda, rushed Briana into the family’s car and sped toward Long Island College Hospital.

headline: Florida Gets Help to Deal With Backlog of Zika Tests
abstract: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is sending seven laboratory technicians, and Gov. Rick Scott has requested more help.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Gov. Rick Scott of Florida announced on Wednesday that the state was getting help to speed up the results of Zika tests, a move that should reduce the inordinately long waits — sometimes up to five weeks — experienced by hundreds of pregnant women who took the state-offered tests at no cost.

headline: A Dream Start as Leicester City’s Fairy Tale Arrives in Europe
abstract: Leicester defeated the Belgian champion Club Brugge, 3-0, in its Champions League opener. It is only Leicester’s fourth European competition in 132 years.
lead_paragraph: BRUGES, Belgium — Leicester City’s fans gathered in the shadows of dreaming spires and sang. They thronged the cobbled streets by the thousands. They hung their flags from the gingerbread facades of delicate redbrick buildings, the storybook backdrop to the next chapter of their fairy tale.

headline: Trapped
abstract: The most evil puzzle in the world, courtesy of Ian Livengood. And he looks like such a nice guy.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Ian Livengood, by all accounts, is a very nice person. He’s well-liked in the puzzle community, his wife still allows him to live with her and his dog thinks he’s just swell.

headline: Ralph Lauren: Fall 2016
abstract: The designer shuts down a city block to show a shoppable fall collection.
lead_paragraph: The designer shuts down a city block to show a shoppable fall collection.

headline: Review: ‘Marie and Rosetta’ Ruminates on Gospel, R&B and Life
abstract: This play from the Atlantic Theater Company tells how the singer Sister Rosetta Tharpe and a protégée, Marie Knight, met and established their act in 1940s Mississippi.
lead_paragraph: There’s an upright piano on the stage of the Atlantic Theater Company, where “Marie and Rosetta,” a new play by George Brant, supplemented by some mighty music-making, opened on Wednesday night. But it may take awhile for you to notice, since the more striking aspect of Riccardo Hernández’s set is the array of coffins surrounding that piano, some of them draped with dresses.

headline: ‘Mr. Robot’ Season 2, Episode 11: The Dark Room
abstract: The message of this series is that human connection is being erased by forces beyond our ability to view.
lead_paragraph: Nearly every scene in Wednesday’s “Mr. Robot” consists simply of two characters talking. But these scenes, as with the conversations these characters have, involve two distinct and indispensable sides. There are the pairs doing the talking, yes: a prisoner and a child, an executive and a government official, an F.B.I. agent and her electronic home companion, a prisoner and her captor, a prisoner (now liberated) and her lawyer, and a madman and a dead man, to name a few. But this is no parade of talky two-handers. In addition to the actors and their dialogue, each of these tightly constructed exchanges involves set design, sound design, cinematography and editing so distinctive, so breathlessly bold, they might as well be from different shows.

Every month, millions of Americans are forced to pay high fees to rent cable boxes. The only way this can change is if the Federal Communications Commission votes to require cable companies to make programming accessible through other devices, ones you could own outright. A vote is set for Sept. 29.

headline: A History Lesson, Served as Coconut-Seafood Soup
abstract: Learning to cook hudutu, a specialty of the Garifuna.
lead_paragraph: When Sulma Arzu-Brown’s father traveled from his village in Honduras into the city, people pointed at him, at his black skin. When he spoke his language, people laughed. “They said, ‘Look at that monkey, goo goo gaga,’ ” Arzu-Brown told me. When it was time for her mother to be promoted at her job, she stood out a little too much. “Blanca,” her boss said to her, “I know you’re qualified, but I can’t give the job to you. You have family in the U.S. Go there. You’ll achieve there.”

headline: How Republicans Lost Their Best Shot at the Hispanic Vote
keywords: ['Hispanic-Americans', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Three years ago, the G.O.P.-led House was close to reaching a compromise on immigration — one that might have neutralized the issue for the 2016 election. This is the inside story of what went wrong.
lead_paragraph: In June, not long after Donald Trump attacked an Indiana-born judge because he was “Mexican,” I went to go see Representative Raúl Labrador in the Longworth Office Building on Capitol Hill. Labrador, an Idaho Republican, cuts an unusual profile in Washington. Born in Puerto Rico, he was raised Mormon by a single mother in Las Vegas and now, as he told me, represents “one of the most conservative districts in the United States, one of the whitest districts in the United States.” Labrador came to Congress as part of the Tea Party wave of 2010 and later helped found the Freedom Caucus, the House’s conservative vanguard. He was also a pivotal member of a bipartisan group of eight House members who, in early 2013, came together in hopes of producing comprehensive legislation to fix the nation’s immigration system.

headline: Where Is Europe’s Moral Authority?
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)']
abstract: When Angela Merkel stands up to the populists who fought the Greek bailout and want to keep out refugees, she’s keeping the flame of principle alive.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Democracies may be destined to dislike one another. When people have a decisive voice in government, they are guided by self-interest, and put their short-term concerns before those of neighbors or partners. In an effort to channel this endless ebb and flow of passions, institutions provide a framework of “rights” and “wrongs,” and governments function by persuading the greatest number of voters that they are doing the “right” thing.

headline: Amy Ryan Says ‘Glamorous Parts are Not Interesting’

It costs me a fortune in babysitters.” But when she read Mike Bartlett’s “Love, Love, Love,” which begins performances at the Roundabout Theater Company’s Laura Pels Theater on Thursday, Sept. 22, she succumbed.

headline: Jay Z: ‘The War on Drugs Is an Epic Fail’
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Marijuana', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Mandatory Sentencing', 'Cocaine and Crack Cocaine']
abstract: Why are white men poised to get rich doing the same thing African-Americans have been going to prison for?
lead_paragraph: This short film, narrated by Jay Z (Shawn Carter) and featuring the artwork of Molly Crabapple, is part history lesson about the war on drugs and part vision statement. As Ms. Crabapple’s haunting images flash by, the film takes us from the Nixon administration and the Rockefeller drug laws — the draconian 1973 statutes enacted in New York that exploded the state’s prison population and ushered in a period of similar sentencing schemes for other states — through the extraordinary growth in our nation’s prison population to the emerging aboveground marijuana market of today. We learn how African-Americans can make up around 13 percent of the United States population — yet 31 percent of those arrested for drug law violations, even though they use and sell drugs at the same rate as whites.

abstract: The fashion giant debuted his first see-now/buy-now collection on a city street; Boss Women and Derek Lam took another road.

headline: Has Murder Come to Town? This Heart Tells No Tales
abstract: So far, anyway. The police and coroner have no leads about a heart found in a plastic bag near a gas station last month in Norwalk, Ohio.
lead_paragraph: Homicides are hardly common in Norwalk, Ohio, a community of about 17,000 near Lake Erie known as the Maple City. For years there were none, officials said, and last year the Police Department investigated only one. But all agree they have seen nothing like the latest possible case, which has stumped the authorities for three weeks: the curious matter of the bodiless heart.

headline: A Classical Composer’s London Guide to Contemporary Music
abstract: Ahead of his stateside symphonic debut, and just in time for fashion week, Gabriel Prokofiev shares some of his favorite local haunts.
lead_paragraph: In Hackney, an East London neighborhood comparable to Bushwick in Brooklyn, the classical composer Gabriel Prokofiev finds himself surrounded by (and seeking out) global, underground music — at local pubs, restaurants, shops and, of course, the nighttime warehouses where Prokofiev grew up going to raves in the mid to late ’90s. “But I’m not clubbing as much as I used to because I have to be a bit more present now,” says the 41-year-old, who’s making waves for remixing classical music, with layers of contemporary influences.

headline: 1941: Effort to Oust Nazi Envoy
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Argentina passes a resolution to declare the German Ambassador Edmund von Thermann persona non grata in September 1941.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Argentina’s Chamber of Deputies approved tonight [Sept. 15], by a vote of 79 to 1, a resolution of censure stating that the German Ambassador, Baron Edmund von Thermann, ‘‘has exceeded his functions and abused diplomatic privileges.’’ The committee has contended that Thermann and his staff have helped to direct and finance totalitarian penetration in Argentina. It has urged that Thermann be declared persona non grata, and it sponsored the motion approved today, after cloakroom polls had indicated that the Chamber would refuse to back it up in that contention. — New York Herald Tribune, Sept. 16, 1941

headline: The Accidental Power of Design
abstract: Consider the current public bathroom kerfuffle: Considerations for men and women may seem self-evident now, but are a relic of the Victorian era.
lead_paragraph: Do we know what we’re talking about when we talk about design? Design is both noun and verb, covering work that ranges from the composition of a tattoo to the amelioration of climate change. We design spoons and rooms, houses and cities, power grids and national identities, international treaties and defense systems and, when all else fails, military campaigns. If design refers to that which is planned and brought to fruition by human ingenuity, we’ve reached the point where, as Mark Wigley and Beatriz Colomina, curators of this year’s Istanbul Design Biennial, aptly observe, “the planet itself has been completely encrusted by design as a geological layer.” Even the few undesigned places left exist because we design the borders around them.

headline: Becoming a Salt Lake City Convert
keywords: ['Budget Travel', 'Restaurants', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Natural beauty and religion, sure, but also night life and great Mexican food.
lead_paragraph: My friend Brigham didn’t pronounce himself an expert on Salt Lake City, but he had attended nearby Brigham Young University, and I trusted his opinion. So when he told me about Red Iguana, a casual Mexican place that’s “quite possibly the most famous restaurant in the state,” I went directly from the airport. He wasn’t wrong: There was a crush of people standing on North Temple under a weathered red sign. A host at a podium outside was ruthlessly informing a party of 15 that because their whole party wasn’t present, they could not be seated and no, their table wouldn’t be held. “You’d be better off going around the corner to Red Iguana 2,” the host told me when I approached. I was stunned — there was a copy of their restaurant quite literally around the corner to handle overflow.

headline: 1966: U.S. Troops Killed By Terrorists
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'UNITED STATES', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Two U.S. soldiers from the Inter-American Peacekeeping force are killed by terrorists in Santo Domingo in September 1966.
lead_paragraph: Two U.S. soldiers were shot and killed by terrorists yesterday [Sept. 14] in downtown Santo Domingo, five days before they were due to end their tour of duty here with the Inter-American Peacekeeping force. U.S. military authorities said the fatal shootings would not interfere with plans to pull out by next week the last units of the force. But nonetheless, the incident touched off speculation that the infant government of President Joaquin Balaguer might request that at least some elements of the peace force stay on for a time. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 16, 1966

headline: Review: ‘Snowden,’ Oliver Stone’s Restrained Portrait of a Whistle-Blower
abstract: This is a movie that does not dazzle or enrage in its evocation of recent history, but creates a cloud of discomfiting doubt.
lead_paragraph: Oliver Stone’s “Snowden,” a quiet, crisply drawn portrait of the world’s most celebrated whistle-blower, belongs to a curious subgenre of movies about very recent historical events. Reversing the usual pattern, it could be described as a fictional “making of” feature about “Citizenfour,” Laura Poitras’s Oscar-winning documentary on the former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden. That film seems to me more likely to last — it is deeper journalism and more haunting cinema — but Mr. Stone has made an honorable and absorbing contribution to the imaginative record of our confusing times. He tells a story torn from slightly faded headlines, filling in some details you may have forgotten, and discreetly embellishing the record in the service of drama and suspense.
