headline: Roasted Figs and Chicken for a Sweet (and Savory) New Year
abstract: This easy yet elegant sheet-pan recipe is fitting for a Rosh Hashana celebration.
lead_paragraph: Before an arctic blast killed my fig tree, I ate only the figs plucked in season from my Brooklyn backyard.

headline: What You Should Watch This Week: ‘High Maintenance’ and ‘Fleabag’
abstract: From the Watching team, expert TV and movie recommendations for the next few days.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Watching, The New York Times’s what-to-watch guide. We comb through releases big and small to email readers twice a week with our timely recommendations. You can browse previous guides here, and to receive recommendations straight to your inbox, sign up here. Stay tuned for our coming website.

headline: People Have Been Dyeing Fabric Indigo Blue for 6,000 Years
keywords: ['Textiles', 'Mummies and Mummification', 'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Dyes and Dyestuffs']
abstract: Before there were bluejeans there were blue Egyptian mummy cloths. Before blue mummy cloths? Possibly blue offerings to ancient Andean gods.
lead_paragraph: Indigo and cotton made a fine pair long before bluejeans ever existed.

headline: Parking Concerns Take a Back Seat in Pursuit of Affordable Housing
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Affordable Housing', 'Parking']
abstract: A group of neighbors on the Upper West Side began a campaign called Save Manhattan Valley. From what did they hope to save it? The demolition of three parking garages.
lead_paragraph: So many development battles in major cities around the world fall into easy narratives (villainy versus virtue, for instance) that we tend to imagine them all possessing moral fault lines that are clearly visible: a set of capitalist savages on one side, and on the other, the marginalized agents of a more noble civic mission. That scenario has proved vulnerable to inconsistency. This year, a group of neighbors inhabiting a patch of the Upper West Side just south of Columbia University began a campaign called Save Manhattan Valley.

headline: Tyre King Family Calls For Shooting Investigation
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'BB and Airsoft Guns', 'Firearms']
abstract: A police officer shot and killed a 13-year-old boy, Tyre King, in Columbus, Ohio, on Sept. 16, 2016, after he had apparently brandished a firearm. It was later determined to be a BB gun.
lead_paragraph: A police officer shot and killed a 13-year-old boy, Tyre King, in Columbus, Ohio, on Sept. 16, 2016, after he had apparently brandished a firearm. It was later determined to be a BB gun.

headline: Wells Fargo Warned Workers Against Sham Accounts, but ‘They Needed a Paycheck’
abstract: Former employees say that their managers warned them not to bend the rules, but they felt pressured by the bank’s aggressive sales culture to create fake accounts anyway.
lead_paragraph: The message to the dozens of Wells Fargo workers gathered for a two-day ethics workshop in San Diego in mid-2014 was loud and clear: Do not create fake bank accounts in the name of unsuspecting clients.

abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.

headline: Conflicting Policy From Trump: To Keep, and Remove, Tax Cut
abstract: After publicly backing away from his proposed tax cut for small businesses, Donald J. Trump’s campaign aides told a small-business group that he still supported the plan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A few hours after Donald J. Trump publicly backed away from a $1 trillion tax cut for small businesses, campaign aides on Thursday privately assured a leading small-business group that Mr. Trump in fact remained committed to the proposal — winning the group’s endorsement.

lead_paragraph: The city known for nonstop partying during the shows now has a handful of places to detox just as hard.

headline: Peyton and Eli Manning, Michael J. Fox and Sarah Ferguson at 9/11 Fundraiser

lead_paragraph: Celebrities make trades for Cantor Fitzgerald’s annual Charity Day; an intimate performance and dinner for Lincoln Center trustees.

headline: Donald Trump Clung to ‘Birther’ Lie for Years, and Still Isn’t Apologetic
abstract: It was never true. Any of it. And even as Mr. Trump surrendered to the reality of President Obama’s birthplace, he insisted on conjuring a new falsehood.
lead_paragraph: It was not true in 2011, when Donald J. Trump mischievously began to question President Obama’s birthplace aloud in television interviews. “I’m starting to think that he was not born here,” he said at the time.

headline: In Art This Fall, Women Win in a Landslide
abstract: Female artists will be the focus of many important solo shows, including Mierle Laderman Ukeles, Carmen Herrera, Yayoi Kusama and Pipilotti Rist.
lead_paragraph: (Asterisks indicate the critic’s Top 10 shows this season.)

headline: Museums Embrace the Unfamiliar
abstract: Many exhibitions devoted to artists who are not white or male will define the coming year.
lead_paragraph: The curator’s job sounds relatively simple: just surprise us. Show us something we haven’t seen before, or lately, or in such depth, or with such clarity. Try to avoid the predictable and familiar, the market-approved or academically sanctioned, or what other curators have already done. Try to step outside your museum’s comfort zone or carefully manicured institutional persona with something eccentric, an intuitive leap. After all, there is plenty of art out there.

headline: Eli Manning, Michael J. Fox and Sarah Ferguson at 9/11 Charity
abstract: Last week’s galas included Cantor Fitzgerald’s annual Charity Day; special dinner and song for Lincoln Center trustees.
lead_paragraph: Cantor Fitzgerald, which lost 658 employees in the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, held its annual Charity Day last Monday. A stream of luminaries visited its Midtown offices, including Peyton and Eli Manning, Michael J. Fox and Sarah Ferguson, who joined brokers to complete trading calls, with all revenues donated to the Cantor Fitzgerald Relief Fund and other charities. About $12 million was raised. That night, the Lincoln Center trustees Dan Crown and his wife, Ellen, hosted a performance and dinner in their Park Avenue home. The Broadway star Justin Guarini performed for trustees and donors.

headline: The Speakeasy Underworld of the Dog Bar
keywords: ['Dogs', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Service Dogs and Other Animals']
abstract: Though they are increasingly rare, there are still New York bars where people can (discreetly) drink alongside their four-legged friends.
lead_paragraph: It was a lovely evening for a drink and a dog on the front patio of a Park Slope bar one recent Thursday.

headline: Dilara Findikoglu’s Rebellious Collection
abstract: The Central Saint Martins graduate will present her first official collection during London Fashion Week on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: The Central Saint Martins graduate will present her first official collection during London Fashion Week on Sunday.

headline: A Punky New British Designer (Who Designs With Girl Rock Stars in Mind)
abstract: Dilara Findikoglu stages guerrilla fashion shows, investigates how women’s bodies have been portrayed over time — and wants her clothes to be a commentary on her homeland of Turkey.
lead_paragraph: In just over a year, Dilara Findikoglu has established herself as one of London’s most rebellious designers. While studying at Central Saint Martins, the Istanbul-born metalhead organized a guerrilla fashion show for the students who failed to make the shortlist for the press show. (She staged it, intentionally, at the exit of the official one.)

headline: After a Gas Explosion Destroyed Its Home, a Band Is Helping the East Village Heal
abstract: In a festival on Saturday, Public Access T.V. will play a concert around the corner from where their apartment building stood before a 2015 blast.
lead_paragraph: When a gas explosion destroyed the building they lived in, the four members of the band Public Access T.V. were in Los Angeles, on tour. Actually, because of the three-hour time difference and an appearance that had kept them out late the previous night, they were still asleep.

headline: 10 Things to Do Now in NYC
abstract: A guide to cultural highlights taking place in New York this weekend and over the week ahead. And there's much more where these came from.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural highlights taking place in New York this weekend and over the week ahead. And there's much more where these came from.

headline: Rice, My Mother’s Way
abstract: It was company fare, made with frozen spinach, Parmesan and cooked Uncle Ben’s. A from-scratch version still captures its charms.
lead_paragraph: My mother was a fairly good cook, but she depended on recipes. She kept a little box of them, some scrawled on 3-by-5 index cards, others torn from newspapers.

headline: Art Fall Preview: From East Coast to West Coast. From Concrete to Ethereal.
abstract: A broad sampling of exhibitions and other art-related events arriving nationwide in the next few months.
lead_paragraph: ELLEN CANTOR: ARE YOU READY FOR LOVE? Drawings, paintings, films and videos by Ellen Cantor (1961-2013) helped shape downtown 1990s post-feminism. Three New York galleries — Participant Inc., Maccarone and Foxy Productions — will also show work by Ms. Cantor. Through Nov. 12, 80WSE Gallery, New York University, steinhardt.nyu.edu/80wse.

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
abstract: This week’s properties are on the Upper East Side, in the West Village, and in Park Slope, Brooklyn.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties are on the Upper East Side, the West Village and in Park Slope, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties are on the Upper East Side, the West Village and in Park Slope, Brooklyn.

headline: Paris Art Fairs Strive to Get Back on Track
abstract: Once global showcases demonstrate the challenges facing market.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The art and antiques market has undergone significant changes in the 21st century. Arguably the most dramatic of these is the hegemony of the new, and of the relatively new. Last year, postwar and contemporary art accounted for 46 percent of the world’s $63.8 billion of auction and dealer sales, according to the 2016 Tefaf Art Market Report that was published in March. Modern art generated a further 30 percent of sales, the report said, leaving the material culture of the preceding 5,000 years with less than a quarter of the market.

headline: Virginia Dwan, a Jet Age Medici, Gets Her Due
abstract: Ms. Dwan either represented, collected or sold the work of a cluster of important midcentury artists, almost all of them men.
lead_paragraph: Giving a tour of her art-filled apartment off Central Park, the dealer Virginia Dwan is all diffidence and grace. Dressed in elegant gray-on-gray, she speaks softly of her black-on-black abstraction by Ad Reinhardt, most meditative of Abstract Expressionists. She waxes quietly enthusiastic about a grid of copper floor tiles by the Minimalist Carl André. She shows off a series of clear plastic boxes by Charles Ross, a pioneer of Land Art whose work with prisms, she says, never got him the attention he deserves.

headline: Dance This Season: Tap, Ballet and the Inexplicable
abstract: A glimpse at performances and festivals from September through April.
lead_paragraph: Dates are subject to change.

headline: Annual Cicadas Perform Their Final Mating Calls of the Season in New York
abstract: The loud little creatures are generally camouflaged in green, black and brown, with none of the demonic, bright red highlights of their periodic cousins.
lead_paragraph: Dog-day cicadas mature into vociferous adulthood during the hottest part of summer, when their steady droning builds in a crescendo and dominates muggy late afternoons. Also known as annual cicadas, these are not the periodic cicadas famous for their 13- or 17-year cycles.

headline: Millions of Square Feet, Billions of Dollars: An Arts Universe Expands
abstract: While the years directly following the financial crisis were quiet ones for cultural construction, all that has changed, and not just in this country.
lead_paragraph: If you need proof of the adage “When the economy sneezes, the arts catch a cold,” consider this: Between 1994 and 2008, the United States added or expanded more than 700 cultural projects, valued at $15.5 billion, according to a University of Chicago study. By 2010, after the housing bubble had burst, “We were happy just to be invited to compete,” said Chris McVoy, senior partner in the New York City-based architecture firm of Steven Holl. “There simply wasn’t any arts-related work out there.”

headline: What’s Missing in Dr. Oz’s TV Exam Room
abstract: I watched Trump and the celebrity doctor with my patient, wishing health could really be that simple.
lead_paragraph: One afternoon during my final year of training to be a doctor, I interviewed to work on “The Dr. Oz Show.” I didn’t get to meet Mehmet Oz himself, but I did explore the back room full of products — weight-loss supplements, anti-aging tinctures, brightly colored workout bands. I joined the team for a lunchtime delivery of Pinkberry frozen yogurt with more toppings than I had ever seen. Later that afternoon, I returned to the sights and smells of sickness in the hospital pleasantly full of tart yogurt and chocolate chips and dreams of celebrity.

headline: Syrian Children Enjoy a Rare Day Outside
abstract: Children play in Tishreen Park in Damascus, the Syrian capital, and families take advantage of a partial cease-fire that went into effect on Monday to enjoy time outside.
lead_paragraph: Children play in Tishreen Park in Damascus, the Syrian capital, and families take advantage of a partial cease-fire that went into effect on Monday to enjoy time outside.

headline: Can You Erase the Trauma From a Place Like Sandy Hook?
keywords: ['Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks']
abstract: After the shooting in 2012, Newtown rebuilt its elementary school. The old campus was wiped off the face of the earth — but not completely.
lead_paragraph: Three and half years after the shooting that claimed 20 young students and six teachers at Sandy Hook Elementary, the town leaders of Newtown, Conn., along with a team of architects, led members of the media on a drizzly late-July morning walk around the rebuilt campus. The new Sandy Hook is a gleaming rural retreat — farther in the woods than the old building — an almost Romantic vision of streams and bridges. An uncommon amount of public money and energy has been invested in the new campus, and it shows.

headline: A Bohemian Pedigree (and Free Tapas) in Greenwich Village
abstract: Spain, a cash-only Basque-style restaurant, is considered a holdout from a time when its neighborhood was filled with Spanish businesses.
lead_paragraph: Greenwich Village’s bohemian landscape eroded long ago, but a succinctly named cash-only Spanish restaurant that opened in 1966 on West 13th Street called Spain has stayed the same.

lead_paragraph: Six former New York City correction officers returned to Rikers Island — this time as inmates — after being sentenced on Friday to prison terms of from four and a half years to six and a half years for their roles in the brutal beating of an inmate there in 2012.

headline: Diane James Is Elected to Lead UKIP, a Force Behind the ‘Brexit’ Vote
abstract: The party, which is in disarray and fighting to be relevant after this summer’s referendum, chose a businesswoman and staunch critic of the European Union.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Diane James, a businesswoman and staunch critic of the European Union, on Friday was elected leader of the U.K. Independence Party, a far-right, anti-immigrant party that was a driving force for Britain’s exit from the bloc.

headline: Tile Gains Footing All Over
keywords: ['Brick and Tile', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Floors and Flooring', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Encaustic cement tile, with its striking look and chalky matte texture, is catching on with designers and homeowners.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve been keeping an eye on the ground beneath your feet, you may have noticed an explosion of pattern. It can be seen in public spaces like the Manhattan restaurant L’Amico, designed by Crème; and the Hotel Van Zandt in Austin, Tex., designed by Mark Zeff. And in private spaces, too, like the New York apartment of the actors Naomi Watts and Liev Schreiber, designed by Ashe & Leandro and featured earlier this year in Architectural Digest.

headline: Classical Music to Come: A Finnish Star, Minimalism and Wagner
abstract: A glimpse at this season’s intriguing offerings in classical music and opera in New York City and beyond.
lead_paragraph: Dates are subject to change.

headline: Virtual Reality: From Guitar Gods to Birds of Prey
abstract: The promise of virtual reality is here, with scores of software titles to be released by year’s end. Here’s a look at some of the most intriguing offerings.
lead_paragraph: Video games can create new and seemingly impossible experiences for their players. We travel to imaginary lands, try on new identities or perform feats of strength and grace that surpass the limits of our bodies. As virtual reality becomes a new aspect of the medium this year, it is delivering on its promise for new kinds of experiences and interactions in ways that are tantalizing yet frustrating.

headline: David Hollander on ‘Ray Donovan’ Season 4 and Taking Over as Showrunner
abstract: Mr. Hollander discusses writing a cancer story line and what his goals were when he took over the series last year.
lead_paragraph: Once mostly anonymous, the producers who oversee top television series have sometimes become as well known as the actors who star in them. On occasion, The New York Times will pose questions to notable showrunners.

headline: Sorry, Cubs Fans: You’re Probably Doomed
abstract: Since 1995, only four baseball teams with the best regular-season record went on to win the World Series.
lead_paragraph: The road ahead is most likely a brief climb, then a steep downhill plunge. Having clinched the National League Central, the Chicago Cubs will now continue motoring toward a 100-victory season and the best record in the major leagues. Then, in all probability, they will meet their inevitable doom once again.

lead_paragraph: On Thursday afternoon, Marc Jacobs closed out fashion week with a show that provoked vociferous debate, though not about the seven-inch platforms or glitter doll frocks on the runway — but about the hair.

keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Foreign Investments', 'Computer Chips', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Computers and the Internet']

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — After a customer canceled a large order at the last minute, shares in Aixtron, a German high-tech company, sank fast. Months later, with the stock still reeling, a Chinese investor agreed to buy the company.

lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Art and Science Meld as NASA Announces a New Artist Collaboration
abstract: The artist and photographer Justin Guariglia will work to present the effects of climate change to the public.
lead_paragraph: “We’re not used to computing the scale of a 100,000-year-old piece of ice the size of California that’s going to break off from an ice sheet,” said the artist and photojournalist Justin Guariglia. Last year, he talked his way on board a NASA mission in Greenland and shot pictures of melting glaciers and sea ices through the drop window of the military transport plane flying very low in the troposphere.

headline: Wells Fargo Scandal May Be Sign of a Poisonous Culture
abstract: That senior executives were not held accountable for the reprehensible behavior of bank employees signals a wider cultural cancer on Wall Street.
lead_paragraph: Let me get this straight: Some 5,300 employees and managers at Wells Fargo’s retail banking division knowingly opened millions of unauthorized accounts in the names of their customers, are rightly fired as a result, but the senior executives at the bank responsible for them and their reprehensible behavior are not? What year is this? 1928? 2007? Or is this 2016, eight years after the crucible moments leading up to one of the worst financial crises in our collective lifetimes?

headline: In the Studio With Katie Roberts-Wood
abstract: A visit to the workspace of the young designer, who presents her first official collection during London Fashion Week this weekend.
lead_paragraph: A visit to the workspace of the young designer, who presents her first official collection during London Fashion Week this weekend.

headline: A Romantic British Designer, Inspired by Science
abstract: Katie Roberts-Wood, who studied medicine for 10 years before turning to fashion, draws on organic shapes she finds in nature.
lead_paragraph: Katie Roberts-Wood’s studio is furrowed away in an industrial building in Regent’s Canal in London. As the evening is settling and commuters are cycling home along the water, the designer’s helpers sit outside painting paillettes of leather for her sculptural designs. It is a week before her London Fashion Week debut, and she has already finished her collection and shot the lookbook — not bad, considering all of these pieces are produced by hand here in her atelier.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Backers Thought She Couldn’t Lose. Now, ‘I Can’t Go There.’
abstract: Those who back the Democratic nominee seem overwhelmed by a wave of unease, exacerbated by Mrs. Clinton’s illness and a slow-footed acknowledgment of it.
lead_paragraph: Beside the olive display at Zabar’s, that iconic hub of lox and neurosis on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, Linda Donohue was trying to talk herself down.

headline: What San Francisco Says About America
abstract: After 27 years reporting abroad, I rediscovered a land of sustainable pot, sleek Teslas and easy credit.
lead_paragraph: San Francisco — AFTER more than 27 years abroad, mostly as a foreign correspondent in Asia covering civil unrest and poverty, I wander the streets of this city, my new home, like an enchanted tourist.

headline: Despite His Doubters, Canelo Álvarez Humbly Fights for Mexico

lead_paragraph: GRAPEVINE, Tex. — The mariachi band played with unmistakable pride. Fans screamed, desperately scrambling to get a glimpse of their hero.

headline: Brooklyn Bridge Park’s Long Path to Development
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: Two books, both by interested parties, examine a 1.3-mile restoration along the East River.
lead_paragraph: The redevelopment of the World Trade Center site since 2001 has produced a number of tomes. Lynne B. Sagalyn’s “Power at Ground Zero” is already being hailed as a definitive history and a classic in urban studies. Two new books explore a somewhat less visible site across the East River, focusing on the tortured incubation of Brooklyn Bridge Park, which took even longer to develop but produced a 1.3-mile waterfront gem.

headline: The Florists Fashion Designers Love in New York, London, Milan and Paris
abstract: From Putnam & Putnam in New York to Moulié in Paris, these companies have become staples for houses in each city.
lead_paragraph: They send giant bouquets to special clients, keep fresh-cut stems on hand and have been known to create larger-than-life flower installations for shows and presentations: Fashion designers have long relied heavily on florists. T polled houses in the four fashion capitals to find out which florists they order from — and why.

headline: Life in the Shadows of War
abstract: People go about their day in Waer, the last rebel-held enclave in the central city of Homs, Syria, during the cease-fire between the government and its opposition.
lead_paragraph: People go about their day in Waer, the last rebel-held enclave in the central city of Homs, Syria, during the cease-fire between the government and its opposition.

headline: How Dan White, a Magician, Spends His Sundays
abstract: Mr. White’s two-hour magic spectacle plays Thursdays through Saturdays, and he finds time to practice on Sundays, and to relax with his fiancée.
lead_paragraph: How in the world did Dan White manage to levitate his assistant, dressed in a long white gown and surrounded on three sides by spectators, almost three feet in the air? Audiences may never know, but people continue to flock to “The Magician,” Mr. White’s old-school magic show featuring mind reading, far-from-ordinary card tricks, and other acts, Thursdays through Saturdays at the NoMad Hotel in the Flatiron district. On Sundays, Mr. White, 35, practices parts of his routine, but also uses the time to relax with his fiancée, Susie Bray. They live in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, with their toy poodle, Gracie.

headline: Three Young Photography Stars, Tapped by Gursky
abstract: The celebrated photographer put together a group show of three of his former students’ works, which opens tomorrow at Sprüth Magers Berlin.
lead_paragraph: Andreas Gursky has long been the subject of exhibitions; since the German photographer and Kunstakademie Düsseldorf professor’s first solo outing in the late 1980s, his large-format images have been mounted in the Museum of Modern Art, Paris’s Centre Pompidou, the Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofía in Madrid and the United Arab Emirates’ Sharjah Art Museum, to list a few. But this weekend, Gursky picks up the mantle of curator, with the opening of “Louisa Clement, Anna Vogel, Moritz Wegwerth,” featuring three of his former students, at Sprüth Magers Berlin. While he has organized the end-of-semester presentations (“Akademierundgänge”) at the academy, he has never coordinated a museum or gallery show until now. He says he gladly accepted the “special task,” explaining, “I am not curating artworks of students, but individual artistic personalities who pursue their artistic path with strong commitment.” Here, Clement, Vogel and Wegwerth discuss their practices — and their former teacher.

lead_paragraph: When Hurricane Sandy lashed the New York coastline and drowned neighborhoods like Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, there was some chatter about retreating from the waterfront.

headline: Almost as Much to Watch as to Hear: Mighty Organ Pieces
abstract: Paul Jacobs, chairman of Juilliard’s organ department, performed a program of Liszt, Brahms and Julius Reubke on Wednesday evening in Paul Hall.
lead_paragraph: With all the wonderful and distinctive organs New York has to offer, you might have wished that Paul Jacobs had played his recital on Wednesday evening on something other than the modest Holtkamp instrument in Paul Hall at the Juilliard School. The program, after all, included what Mr. Jacobs, in preliminary remarks, called “two of the mightiest organ works of the 19th century”: Franz Liszt’s Fantasy and Fugue on “Ad nos, ad salutarem undam” and Julius Reubke’s Sonata in C minor.

headline: After 30 Years, Pete Hamill Returns to Brooklyn
abstract: Mr. Hamill’s journey as a writer is leading him from Manhattan back to the borough where he learned his craft.
lead_paragraph: As a native Brooklynite, Pete Hamill figures he is entitled to disagree about the borough with his fellow novelist Thomas Wolfe, who lived there for less than a decade during the 1930s.

headline: Sewage Overflow Again Fouls Tampa Bay After Storm
keywords: ['Sewers and Sewage', 'Water Pollution', 'Water', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)']
abstract: Rainfall from Hurricane Hermine added to the strain already being faced by aging wastewater treatment facilities along Florida’s Gulf Coast.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — When Hurricane Hermine bowled onto Florida’s Gulf Coast this month, officials in this city were confronted with a familiar problem: The hurricane and days of rain before it had overloaded St. Petersburg’s water pipes and treatment tanks so there was no room for the city’s waste.

lead_paragraph: The first presidential debate between Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump this month will exclude two leading third-party nominees — Gary Johnson of the Libertarian Party and the Green Party’s Jill Stein — the Commission on Presidential Debates announced on Friday.

headline: Jean Paul Gaultier’s Fantastical Imagination

lead_paragraph: BERLIN — “Who is in charge of the feathers?” the designer Jean Paul Gaultier shouted on a July day as about 20 people scurried around him in the costume workshop at the Friedrichstadt-Palast theater.

headline: The Difference Between Rationality and Intelligence
abstract: One is raw cognitive horsepower. The other is the propensity for reflective thought.
lead_paragraph: ARE you intelligent — or rational? The question may sound redundant, but in recent years researchers have demonstrated just how distinct those two cognitive attributes actually are.

headline: The Playlist: Kim Gordon Vents and the White Stripes Unleash an Outtake

You can listen to this playlist on Spotify here. Like this format? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com.

abstract: A trove of documents reveal Republican politicians drawing on fears of election fraud to prevent voters — usually Democratic — from casting ballots.
lead_paragraph: As one prominent and much beloved Republican once said — actually, repeatedly said — “There you go again.”

headline: Watch a 101-Year-Old Painter Argue Against Talking About Art
abstract: In an exclusive clip from the new Netflix documentary “The 100 Years Show,” the artist Carmen Herrera makes a case for staying quiet.
lead_paragraph: Last year, T ran a very popular story rounding up a number of female artists who have continued to create — and in some cases, have only just begun to receive critical attention — late in life, well into their 70s, 80s and 90s. The oldest among them, the Cuban-American minimalist painter Carmen Herrera, turned 101 in May, and if anything, her star has only risen since our story was published. She had a show in May inaugurating the new New York outpost of Lisson Gallery; and today, the Whitney opens a solo show focusing on her work from 1948 to 1978. It’s auspicious timing for the release, on Netflix, of a new documentary about the artist by the award-winning filmmaker Alison Klayman (known most recently for “Ai Weiwei: Never Sorry”), an exclusive clip from which premieres above. In it, Herrera makes the case for artists not talking too much about their work: “You cannot talk about art; you have to art about art,” she says, smiling (and lightly pounding a desk for emphasis).

headline: Review: ‘Crackskull Row,’ an Irish Gothic With Masher, Basher and Rasher
abstract: Honor Molloy explores rage, dissolution, sexual perversity and family history with a bleak and penetrating acuity in this play at Origin’s 1st Irish Festival.
lead_paragraph: You might expect the 2016 edition of Origin’s 1st Irish Festival to kick off with an upbeat paean to Ireland. Instead we have Honor Molloy’s grotesque but richly satisfying drama “Crackskull Row,” at the Theater Workshop.

lead_paragraph: The Queen of England has two birthdays each year: one actual, one official. The composer Steve Reich — American new-music royalty, if such a thing were constitutional — turns 80 next month, but celebrations have been so ubiquitous that they sometimes seem to blur into one big parade.

abstract: Mr. Bratton was among the most influential figures in American policing for more than four decades, leading departments in Los Angeles, Boston and New York.

Bratton marked his final day as New York City police commissioner on Friday by strolling through a receiving line of hundreds of officers, a joyful smile on his face as he exited Police Headquarters to applause and the wail of bagpipes, which all but drowned out a small number of protesters.

headline: Subway Singer Gets Her Big Break

lead_paragraph: Alice Tan Ridley, the mother of the Oscar-nominated actress Gabourey Sidibe, has been singing in the subway system for 30 years. She will soon perform at the Highline Ballroom in Chelsea, in connection with the release of her debut album.

headline: After Years Underground, a Subway Singer Gets the Spotlight
abstract: Alice Tan Ridley, who has sung in New York’s subway system for decades and is the mother of the actress Gabourey Sidibe, is about to release her debut album.
lead_paragraph: Alice Tan Ridley sat before the mirror in her Harlem apartment. She brushed on gold eye shadow, took an auburn wig off a mannequin’s head and put it on. “I really, really don’t know what I’m doing,” she said, laughing. “I never used to wear makeup at all. And I never wore wigs. I just braided my hair in teeny braids that would hang when I’d get wet.”

headline: Prince Memorial Concert to Feature Stevie Wonder and Others
abstract: Christina Aguilera, Chaka Khan and John Mayer will anchor the Official Prince Tribute, at the Xcel Energy Center in St. Paul.
lead_paragraph: In late July, three months after Prince died of an accidental overdose of the opioid painkiller fentanyl, the musician’s sister, Tyka Nelson, announced that a public memorial concert would be held at the U.S. Bank Stadium in Minneapolis on Oct. 13. Less than a month before that date, the performers for the show have finally been announced, but the place has shifted — to the considerably smaller Xcel Energy Center in St. Paul.

headline: European Leaders Debate Proposals for Closer Military Ties
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'International Relations']
abstract: Amid high levels of anti-European Union sentiment across the Continent, European nations are considering greater coordination among their armed forces.
lead_paragraph: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia — At a moment when many voters across the Continent want national governments to reclaim power from Brussels, the leaders of 27 European Union countries debated proposals Friday that would move in the other direction by creating a joint European military headquarters and increase cooperation among their armed forces.

headline: How the Marc Jacobs Fashion Show Came Together
abstract: T trailed the Marc Jacobs show adviser Katie Grand during the 48 hours leading up to the runway in New York.
lead_paragraph: T trailed the Marc Jacobs show adviser Katie Grand during the 48 hours leading up to the runway in New York.

headline: 48 Hours Before the Marc Jacobs Show, With Katie Grand
abstract: All that happened leading up to the New York Fashion Week runway.
lead_paragraph: “We are really late,” said Katie Grand, the stylist and adviser behind Marc Jacobs’s biannual women’s wear shows. “Everyone says that every season, but this is especially, especially late.” To underline the point, it was a little more than 48 hours before Jacobs’s spring/summer 2017 runway, yet very little of the collection was hanging on the rails of Jacobs’s Spring Street studio. Jacobs himself was on his knees on the floor, chopping into a printed chiffon dress. A few boxes held towering platform boots in a fistful of gummy bear colors. There wasn’t much else around.

headline: Canada Today: Searchers Find a Shipwreck, and Conservatives Seek a Leader
keywords: ['Exploration and Explorers', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Shopping and Retail']

lead_paragraph: We’re trying something new: Canada Today, a weekly roundup for Canadian readers and anyone else interested in the True North. Tell us what you think and what you’d like to see, at CanadaToday@nytimes.com. And please subscribe to the email newsletter version, which is coming soon.

headline: Arctic Summer Sea Ice – Going Down, Down, Down
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Ice', 'Ice Age', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Summer (Season)']
abstract: New studies reinforce that the summer retreats in Arctic sea ice of late are far greater than any since least 1850, but the path to an open Arctic Ocean remains murky.
lead_paragraph: The vast, scrabbly sheath of sea ice drifting on the Arctic Ocean ended its annual summer retreat this week, and the result was sobering. This year tied with 2007 as having the second smallest ice extent ever recorded, the National Snow and Ice Data Center announced yesterday.

headline: U.S. Presidential Race, Syria, William Bratton: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Donald Trump Scorns TV Networks. For Once, They Return the Favor.
abstract: After Mr. Trump’s campaign barred an ABC News producer from a tour of his new hotel, news executives refused to cover it, uniting in an unusual act of defiance.
lead_paragraph: Simmering tension between Donald J. Trump and the television networks that cover him entered an extraordinary new phase on Friday, as a consortium of news executives refused to participate in a media session with Mr. Trump after his aides barred a producer from attending.

headline: How Do I Get Out of Here?
abstract: Giving directions out of Manhattan to a driver who really wants to leave.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Bill to Shield International Art Loans Gains in Senate
abstract: The legislation, which opponents contend protects stolen works while they’re being exhibited in the United States, will head to the full Senate for a vote.
lead_paragraph: Legislation to safeguard international art loans will be taken up by the full Senate after years of criticism and complaints that the bill amounts to protection for plundered works.

headline: Who’s Too Young for an App? Musical.ly Tests the Limits
keywords: ['Youth', 'Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Mobile Applications', "Children's Online Privacy Protection Act", 'Privacy', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Children and Childhood', 'Consumer Protection']
abstract: The video-sharing app Musical.ly seems to be popular with children well under the age of 13, which leads to questions over how to monitor young people on the web.
lead_paragraph: In the folklore of the start-up world, few figures loom larger than the teenager. Teenagers see the future, set trends and spend money, or compel parents to spend it for them. Their behavior has become an obsession for entrepreneurs.

headline: Time Traveling at the Toronto Film Festival
abstract: The festival doesn’t have the red-carpet muscle of Cannes, but is instead largely defined by volume and seasonal timing. Here’s a look at some of the highlights.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — In his terrific new documentary, “Into the Inferno,” Werner Herzog leads you to the edge of the red-hot abyss, using airborne cameras, philosophical asides and his boundless interest in the depths of human mystery. Written, directed and narrated by Mr. Herzog, the movie takes you to volcanoes across the globe — from Iceland to Ethiopia and North Korea — in a voyage into wonders and terrors. During this expedition, you discover that North Korean lore asserts that the nation’s founder, Kim Il Sung, led the fight for independence at the foot of Mt. Paektu, using a log cabin with the optics of an Abraham Lincoln shrine and the sacredness of a Bethlehem manger.

headline: Rags, Tea and Advice as Syrians Fret Over Cease-Fire
abstract: As the Muslim holiday of Eid al-Adha wound down, Syrians squeezed in precious time with family and friends as the sound of explosions signaled a truce may be fraying.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The weeklong vacation for the Muslim holiday of Eid al-Adha is nearing an end, and the partial cease-fire that began on Monday night is showing signs of fraying.

headline: Poll Finds Most Voters Embrace Milestone for Women, if Not Hillary Clinton
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Women and Girls', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: The survey found that women think that more progress has been made toward ending sexism than racism in society, but they perceive that men still hold advantages.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 8, American voters for the first time in history will see a woman’s name on the ballot as a major party’s nominee for president. A broad majority of voters — men and women — say they are happy this milestone has been reached, but fully half of them say they would have preferred that that first woman not be Hillary Clinton, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: How the New York Times/CBS News Poll Was Conducted
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Women and Girls', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The survey of 1,770 adults from Sept. 9 through 13 used random sampling methods to ensure proper representation in terms of region, sex, race and other factors.
lead_paragraph: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from Sept. 9 through 13 with 1,770 adults throughout the United States. Of those, 865 were women and 905 were men.

headline: Donald Trump’s Cynical Play for Women’s Votes
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Family Leaves', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Law and Legislation', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Mr. Trump’s recent comments on maternity leave and birth control should sway no one.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has spent the last week attempting to erase his huge deficits among female voters.

lead_paragraph: The poll looked closely at women’s political views and broader outlook on American life, as well as how the wider society views the role of women.

headline: Actually, Income in Rural America Is Growing, Too
keywords: ['Census', 'Rural Areas', 'Income', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Economy']
abstract: A widely reported fact from the new Census Bureau turns out, on closer inspection, to be wrong.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, when the Census Bureau released one of the country’s most important reports on income and poverty, dozens of facts were revealed. We found out that real middle-class incomes in America grew a phenomenal 5.2 percent, and that the poverty rate fell by the largest percentage in nearly 50 years.

headline: The Top 10 Moments From New York Fashion Week
abstract: Kanye West's three-hour show, direct-to-consumer fashion — and so much more.
lead_paragraph: Kanye West's three-hour show, direct-to-consumer fashion — and so much more.

headline: Judge Clears 7 Chimps for Departure. They’re Off to England.
keywords: ['Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Monkeys and Apes', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Zoos']
abstract: A federal judge dismissed a lawsuit against the federal Fish and Wildlife Service, which approved the export, but harshly criticized the agency.
lead_paragraph: For almost two years, the Yerkes National Primate Research Center at Emory University has been working to send seven chimpanzees to a zoo in England, prompting the outrage of several animal welfare and conservation groups because the zoo is unaccredited and there are American sanctuaries ready to accept the chimps.

headline: I Wrote That? Playwrights Look Back at Their Teenage Work
abstract: Neil LaBute, Lynn Nottage and other stage notables take a peek at their early plays (often written in their teens). They weren’t all brilliant.
lead_paragraph: Neil LaBute, Lynn Nottage and other stage notables take a peek at their early plays (often written in their teens). They weren’t all brilliant.

headline: A Two-Mile Beer Pipeline Carries Belgium’s Lifeblood to Be Bottled
abstract: One of Belgium’s oldest breweries, in the narrow streets of medieval Bruges, solved a transportation problem and avoided a move from the city center.
lead_paragraph: Beneath the gilded spires and medieval cobblestone streets of Bruges, the lifeblood of Belgium now flows at more than 1,000 gallons an hour.

headline: Jason Pierre-Paul May Miss Giants’ Home Opener
abstract: The defensive end has a sore shoulder and was listed as questionable for the game against the New Orleans Saints.
lead_paragraph: Although Giants defensive end Jason Pierre-Paul said earlier in the week that his sore shoulder would not keep him out of the team’s home opener Sunday against the New Orleans Saints, Coach Ben McAdoo sounded less confident on Friday about Pierre-Paul’s availability.

headline: Donald Trump Says Hillary Clinton’s Bodyguards Should Disarm to ‘See What Happens to Her’
abstract: The Republican nominee again raised the possibility of violence against his opponent, saying of her Secret Service agents, “Take their guns away.”
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Donald J. Trump once again raised the specter of violence against Hillary Clinton, suggesting Friday that the Secret Service agents who guard her voluntarily disarm to “see what happens to her” without their protection.

headline: Who Is ‘Evil,’ and Who Is the Victim?
keywords: ['Philosophy', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'September 11 (2001)']
abstract: There are victims and there are perpetrators, but it can be dangerous to think only in these terms.
lead_paragraph: This is the eighth in a series of dialogues with philosophers and critical theorists on the question of violence. This conversation is with Simona Forti, a professor of political philosophy at the University of Eastern Piedmont in Italy, and a visiting professor at the New School for Social Research in New York. Her most recent book is “New Demons: Rethinking Power and Evil Today.”

headline: Nigeria Describes 3 Failed Negotiations With Boko Haram on Kidnapped Girls
abstract: More than 200 schoolgirls were kidnapped by the terrorist group in July 2015, and three times government negotiations have failed.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Two and a half years after more than 200 girls were kidnapped from a school in northeastern Nigeria, the government on Friday described for the first time the failed efforts to negotiate for their release.

headline: Federal Charges for Chicago Officer in Shooting Caught on Video
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Officer Marco Proano has been indicted in the 2013 shooting of two black teenagers, who survived.
lead_paragraph: A Chicago police officer is facing federal criminal charges for shooting two black teenagers in 2013, when he fired into a stolen car that was moving away from him in an incident that was recorded on video.

headline: Edward Albee, Trenchant Playwright Who Laid Bare Modern Life, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Albee, the Pulitzer-winning playwright of “Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?” and “Three Tall Women,” among other dramas, charted the contentiousness of intimacy and the gap between self-delusion and truth in contemporary life.
lead_paragraph: Edward Albee, widely considered the foremost American playwright of his generation, whose psychologically astute and piercing dramas explored the contentiousness of intimacy, the gap between self-delusion and truth and the roiling desperation beneath the facade of contemporary life, died on Friday at his home in Montauk, N.Y. He was 88.

headline: Governor’s Views Don’t Help as Maine’s Population Dwindles
keywords: ['Population', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Minorities', 'Discrimination', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: The oldest state, where deaths exceed births, Maine is losing people; some say it must welcome foreign-born workers to help rebuild.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Me. — Leopold Ndayisabye, a Rwandan immigrant who works as a caseworker, has watched refugees, asylum seekers and other immigrants move to this city, fill health care jobs, send their children to school and line up to buy goods in the local stores.

headline: On a Friday Out, Chelsea Gets the Check and Liverpool Gets the Points
abstract: As Chelsea’s Antonio Conte continues to fashion his expensive parts into a working unit, Jurgen Klopp has Liverpool humming.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As early as April — a few days, at most, after Antonio Conte had agreed to take over as Chelsea’s manager this summer — word was starting to echo around Europe that Conte believed he would urgently require a central defender upon his arrival in England.

headline: The Shady History of Big Sugar
keywords: ['Sugar', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Research', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Protectionism (Trade)']
abstract: Manipulating nutrition research was just one of many sneaky tactics.
lead_paragraph: Charlottesville, Va. — On Monday, an article in JAMA Internal Medicine reported that in the 1960s, the sugar industry paid Harvard scientists to publish a study blaming fat and cholesterol for coronary heart disease while largely exculpating sugar. This study, published in the prestigious New England Journal of Medicine in 1967, helped set the agenda for decades of public health policy designed to steer Americans into low-fat foods, which increased carbohydrate consumption and exacerbated our obesity epidemic.

headline: U.N. Meeting a Farewell for Obama, and a Dress Rehearsal for Clinton
abstract: Mr. Obama’s last General Assembly as president is a return to the diplomatic stage for his preferred successor, who will meet with world leaders she already knows.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will use his final appearance at the United Nations General Assembly next week to extol the benefits of his brand of multilateral diplomacy, even as the gathering will lay bare places where that diplomacy has fallen short.

headline: Michelle Obama Makes Ardent Case for Hillary Clinton
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voting and Voters', 'United States Politics and Government', 'First Ladies (US)']
abstract: Mrs. Obama made a rare appearance on the campaign trail on Friday to plead with young voters to support Hillary Clinton and extend President Obama’s legacy.
lead_paragraph: FAIRFAX, Va. — Michelle Obama on Friday issued a cutting critique of Donald J. Trump as an unserious and dangerously unprepared candidate for president, making a rare appearance on the campaign trail to plead with young voters to support Hillary Clinton and extend her husband’s legacy.

headline: As Shelter Population Surges, Housing for Disabled Comes Up Short
keywords: ['Disabilities', 'Homeless Persons', 'AMERICANS WITH DISABILITIES ACT', 'Group Homes and Supportive Housing']
abstract: Advocates have been fighting for years for accommodations for people with disabilities, and the shortcomings have become more pressing.
lead_paragraph: Alison Phillips’s feet dragged beneath her as she used forearm crutches to make her way down a ramp, leaving the Brooklyn homeless shelter where she and her 3-year-old daughter live.

headline: Judge Rejects Justice Department Ruling on Music Licensing
keywords: ['Royalties', 'Music', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: Hailed by the music industry as a major victory, the judge’s decision says the Justice Department misinterpreted a regulatory document that governs the performing-rights agencies BMI and Ascap.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Friday rejected a recent Justice Department ruling on music licensing in a move that was immediately hailed by the music industry as a major victory.

headline: Donald Trump’s Latest Birther Lie
abstract: In his spiral through unreality, the Republican candidate trades one myth for another.
lead_paragraph: The midday bulletin arrived as another bizarre moment in the absurdist presidential campaign of Donald Trump: News Alert: Trump admits Obama was born in the United States.

headline: Trump Makes His Birther Lie Worse
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Birth Certificates', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Lying']
abstract: The most awful retraction in American history includes still another lie.
lead_paragraph: Wow. Donald Trump says President Obama was born here. What a concession. No wonder he’s trending up in the polls.

headline: Violence Flares With 4 Attacks on Israelis in Jerusalem and West Bank
abstract: Four Arabs who tried to attack Israelis were shot and killed, shattering a relative lull and renewing fears of a wider conflict.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A wave of violence that had subsided in recent months flared up again on Friday as four attacks in Jerusalem and the West Bank within 24 hours underscored the edgy mood between Israelis and Palestinians.

headline: South Sudan Rejects Report on Leaders’ Wealth
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The government has denounced a report that accuses the leaders on both sides of the country’s civil war of stoking violence to amass illegal wealth.
lead_paragraph: The government of South Sudan on Friday denounced what it called a groundless report that accuses the president and other figures engaged in the country’s civil war of fomenting violence in order to amass illegal wealth.

headline: A Russian-Iranian Axis
abstract: Moscow’s use of an Iranian air base to bomb Syria is a sign of a broad new threat to Mideast stability.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — THE partial cease-fire in Syria’s civil war is welcome news. But it must not be allowed to obscure a dangerous new development — the emergence from the war of a Russian-Iranian military axis that could upset hopes for stability in the Middle East, and for containing Russia’s global ambitions, into the future.

headline: For the Ages
abstract: Andrew J. Reis makes us work to the finish.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — So does everyone agree that puzzles keep the mind young? Accepting that an “old” mind goes brittle and slow, develops holes in one’s memory, settles into its ruts of ruminative repetition... and so on. I ask this (rhetorically, I hope) because I fell off the game wagon this summer for various reasons and I’m finding it a challenge to get my focus back, like exercising out-of-shape muscles.

headline: The Last Word: Edward Albee
abstract: Edward Albee was one of America's most important and influential playwrights. In this never-before-seen Last Word interview, he discusses his life and work.
lead_paragraph: Edward Albee was one of America's most important and influential playwrights. In this never-before-seen Last Word interview, he discusses his life and work.

headline: The Contest Over Israel Aid
keywords: ['Foreign Aid', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Arms Trade', 'Editorials']
abstract: It is worth asking whether the ever-increasing levels of United States aid to Israel make sense.
lead_paragraph: Even before the ink was dry on the new 10-year, $38 billion defense agreement between Israel and the United States, Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina threw down the gauntlet and promised to fight the Obama administration over key elements of the deal, including its size. Mr. Graham wants Congress to approve billions more.

headline: Viral Sex Tapes and a Suicide Prompt Outrage in Italy
keywords: ['Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Privacy', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Sex']
abstract: A woman found dead this week had fought in court for a year to have videos of her having sex removed from websites.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The suicide of an Italian woman who fought a long court battle to get videos of her having sex removed from the web has rekindled a national debate on the perils of social media and the internet.

headline: Red Sox’ David Ortiz, Thorn in Yankees’ Side for a Bit Longer, Digs Into Them Again
abstract: Boston’s Ortiz, who has always managed to get crucial hits against the Yankees at critical junctures, had an R.B.I. and scored a run in the Red Sox’ victory.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — David Ortiz stood outside the Red Sox’ clubhouse before Friday night’s game wearing a pair of red, white and blue shorts adorned with stars and stripes and a T-shirt depicting the Citgo sign outside Fenway Park with the word “Strong” written underneath.

headline: Mets and Colon Prevail in a Shutout Win Over the Twins
abstract: Despite a few lapses, the Mets easily beat the Twins, 3-0, at Citi Field.
lead_paragraph: Mets Manager Terry Collins told his players after the conclusion of their previous series against the Washington Nationals that there was no time to relax despite the cushy schedule awaiting them over the final two weeks of the season.

headline: A Formula to Make Bail More Fair
abstract: A new system may reduce unnecessary jail time for low-income defendants.
lead_paragraph: Judges in San Francisco’s courts long used a fixed schedule based on the criminal charge as a starting point for setting bail. Too often, this system left defendants who posed little risk to the community sitting in jail because they couldn’t afford bail.

headline: From Women, Skepticism About Marriage and a Hunger for Workplace Equality
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Discrimination', "Women's Rights", 'Marriages', 'Workplace Environment', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Income Inequality', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Some of the women who took part in a New York Times/CBS News poll were called to talk further about the challenges they face today.
lead_paragraph: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll took a reading on the attitudes of American women on a range of topics, from politics to opportunities in the workplace to their overall level of satisfaction in life. We called back a number of them to talk further and also consulted some experts about the challenges facing women today. Here are some of their voices.

headline: A Staten Island Mosque Mixes Prayer and Patriotism
keywords: ['Muslim Americans', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Constitution (US)', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: In an example of what might be called the Khizr Khan effect, leaders of the Masjid Un-Noor mosque gave out small copies of the Constitution on Friday to remind congregants of their rights as Americans.
lead_paragraph: The man stood at the podium in the cramped Masjid Un-Noor mosque on Staten Island as hundreds of Muslims sat barefoot on the carpet before him, facing east, just before the start of Friday prayers. In his outstretched right hand, he held up a tiny American flag and a pocket-size copy of the Constitution.

headline: Joseph B. Keller, Mathematician With Whimsical Curiosity, Dies at 93
abstract: The Stanford professor delved into practical and often playful enigmas, developing equations to explain, for instance, why a jogger’s ponytail swings from side to side.
lead_paragraph: Joseph B. Keller, an honored mathematician who figured out what makes a jogger’s ponytail swing from side to side, why teapots dribble, how earthworms (but not snakes) can wriggle even on glass and, in his spare time, whether underwater nuclear tests could set off tsunamis, died on Sept. 7 at his home in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 93.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, September 17, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “We got the idea from looking at other life provisions that run through pipes. Water pipes, electricity pipes, cable distribution, etc. So why wouldn’t that be possible for beer?”

headline: Del Potro Beats Murray in Davis Cup Match
abstract: Argentina took a 2-0 lead over Britain, the defending champion.
lead_paragraph: Argentina took a 2-0 lead over Britain, the defending champion, in a Davis Cup semifinal in Glasgow on Friday as Juan Martín del Potro defeated Andy Murray in five sets (and more than five hours) and Guido Pella beat Kyle Edmund in four. At 5 hours 7 minutes, the Murray match was the longest of both players’ careers.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘The Revenant’ and ‘The Beatles: Eight Days a Week’

lead_paragraph: “The Revenant,” starring Leonardo DiCaprio in his Oscar-winning role, comes to cable. Ron Howard tries to seduce millennials into loving the Beatles. And revisit “The Ranch” before the second half of Season 1 arrives.

headline: A Lie Too Far?
abstract: The press seems to find its voice. But is it too late?
lead_paragraph: I suspect Donald Trump is feeling a bit sandbagged right now, or will be when he wakes up. All along he has treated the news media with contempt, and been rewarded with obsequious deference — his lies sugar-coated, described as “disputed” or “stretching the truth,” while every aspect of his opponent’s life is described as “raising questions” and “casting shadows”, despite lack of evidence that she did anything wrong.

headline: ‘Her Condescending Dismissal .... Is What Is Deplorable’
abstract: Our top 10 comments of the week: Readers discuss Hillary Clinton’s “deplorables” comment, Russian hackers, and whether it is ever O.K. to assume someone is pregnant.
lead_paragraph: Here are top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

headline: A Sour Surprise for Public Pensions: Two Sets of Books
abstract: The plight of a tiny local retirement fund in California shows how some public pension plans are far less funded than their official numbers suggest.
lead_paragraph: When one of the tiniest pension funds imaginable — for Citrus Pest Control District No. 2, serving just six people in California — decided last year to convert itself to a 401(k) plan, it seemed like a no-brainer.

headline: For Fall, Seven Notable New Hotels
abstract: High-profile hotels are scheduled to open this fall in Tel Aviv, the Maldives, New York, Barcelona, and Vientiane, Laos.
lead_paragraph: It’s a new season with new hotel openings. Although fall usually sees a glut of splashy properties making their debut, that’s not the story line this year, according to the hotel specialist Bobby Zur, who owns Travel Artistry, a consultancy in Franklin Lakes, N.J. “It’s not uncommon for hotels to delay their openings, but the holdups are especially pronounced this fall for a number of reasons including the U.S. elections, European volatility and concerns over Zika,” he said.

headline: The Eternal Struggle of the Empty Nester
abstract: For many whose children leave for college, landing on the proper spot of the Umbilical Cord/Cold Arctic Gale continuum can be tricky.
lead_paragraph: The etiquette of the empty nest can bedevil even the most sophisticated parent. Take, for instance, the actress Alfre Woodard. Ms. Woodard said that when her younger child (her son, Duncan) went to college in 2012, her depression caught her in a bind.

headline: Cynthia Erivo Takes on a New Role: Fashion Diva
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Theater', 'Tony Awards (Theater Awards)']
abstract: Ms. Erivo, who won a Tony Award this year for her performance in “The Color Purple,” is lending her star wattage to fashion’s front row.
lead_paragraph: Cynthia Erivo took a long, level look at her reflection in the V.I.P. room at the Tory Burch shop on Madison Avenue last week. She was trying on, and casting off, a succession of frocks before eventually settling on the ensemble she would wear to Ms. Burch’s spring show on Tuesday.

headline: Want to Find Fulfillment at Last? Think Like a Designer
abstract: Two Silicon Valley veterans have been helping Stanford students navigate the future through their popular courses. Now they want to help you.
lead_paragraph: STANFORD, CALIF. — Take out your flow journals. We’re going to talk about flow moments.

headline: Elizabeth Warren and Tracee Ellis Ross on the Road to Activism
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Television']
abstract: The senator and the actress reflect on the coming election, family dynamics and road maps for social change.
lead_paragraph: Tracee Ellis Ross may be working 14 hours a day in Los Angeles on her hit TV show, “black-ish.” “But when Elizabeth Warren says she’ll have dinner with you,” Ms. Ross said, walking into a suite at the Hay-Adams Hotel in Washington, “you get on a plane. I have a million questions for her.”

headline: Abu Sayyaf Militants Release Norwegian Hostage in Philippines
abstract: The police said the Norwegian man, Kjartan Sekkingstad, whose fellow Canadian hostages were both beheaded this year, had been freed by the group for a ransom.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — The Abu Sayyaf militant group freed a Norwegian hostage in the southern Philippines on Saturday, the police said, almost a year after he was seized along with two Canadians who were later beheaded.

headline: A Little Variety
abstract: A place to discuss the A Little Variety suite of puzzles.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLES — This week’s puzzles include:

headline: JZ Holden and Jules Feiffer: Humor and Truth Spark Outrage, Then a Union
abstract: JZ Holden, a freelance writer, and Jules Feiffer, the cartoonist, author and playwright, are to be married Sept. 18 in Amagansett, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: J Z Holden and Jules Feiffer are to be married on Sept. 18 at the home of Judith Hudson, a friend of the couple in Amagansett, N.Y. Mary Faith Westervelt, a town justice for Shelter Island, N.Y., is to officiate at a ceremony that will combine Jewish and Buddhist traditions and will be led by Monte Farber, a friend of the bride who is also a Universal Life minister.

headline: Vanessa Dube and Gary Le: Surviving a First Date at a Burlesque Show
abstract: A quirky New Year’s resolution and an unusual first outing didn’t ruin a date set up via Match.com.
lead_paragraph: Vanessa Jeanne Dube, a daughter of Jeanne Marie Forte Dube of New York and Gregory R. Dube of Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J., was married Sept. 17 to Gary Dat Le, a son of Tammy D. Le and Scott C. Le of Seattle. Frances Kissling, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at 620 Loft and Garden, an event space at Rockefeller Center in New York.

headline: His Grip Still Secure, Bashar al-Assad Smiles as Syria Burns
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Though Mr. Assad’s standing has been diminished, he is able to present himself as the leader his nation needs to get through a war for which he denies any responsibility.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — On the day after his 51st birthday, Bashar al-Assad, the president of Syria, took a victory lap through the dusty streets of a destroyed and empty rebel town that his forces had starved into submission.

headline: Farhad’s and Paul’s Week in Tech: Apple’s China Conundrum and Samsung’s Recall Conundrum
abstract: Increasingly, what matters for Apple is what people in China think of its products. As for self-driving cars, expect more failures before big success.
lead_paragraph: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Mike is off this week, so Paul Mozur, the Times’s Asia technology correspondent, stepped in.

headline: Readers’ Stories About Race and Education
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Principals (School)', 'Discrimination', 'Children and Childhood', 'Racial Profiling', 'Minorities']
