lead_paragraph: Our Race/Related reporting project asked for your stories about race and education. Here are excerpts of what a handful of parents, teachers and students of pre-k – 12 had to say about how race and diversity are being discussed in schools and at home.

headline: Shared Driveway Parking Problems
abstract: Not all of us are good at sharing, particularly when it comes to coveted Brooklyn parking spots.
lead_paragraph: Q. We have a rent-to-own agreement with our landlord on an attached house in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, with two parking spots and a shared driveway. But our neighbors use the driveway for parking and not as a means of egress. (Their garage is packed with stuff.) And their three adult children block the driveway so we can’t access our parking spots — and sometimes cannot even walk along the driveway. The time for friendly reconciliation has passed, as this has festered since 2009. What are our options? Should the landlord step in?

headline: Egypt Freezes Assets of Several Human Rights Advocates
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Assets, Frozen']
abstract: As part of a criminal investigation, a court froze the assets of five prominent activists and three nongovernmental organizations that document state abuses.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — An Egyptian court dealt a heavy blow to the country’s human rights activists on Saturday by freezing the assets of five prominent human rights defenders and three nongovernmental organizations.

headline: Anya Hindmarch’s Curated Works for Sotheby’s
abstract: The fashion designer talks T through the upcoming auction, which will take place just two days after her London Fashion Week show.
lead_paragraph: The fashion designer talks T through the upcoming auction, which will take place just two days after her London Fashion Week show.

headline: For One Designer, an Art Auction to Chase a Fashion Show
abstract: In London, Anya Hindmarch has curated contemporary works for an upcoming sale at Sotheby’s.
lead_paragraph: “Art has always been a big part of my life. It’s something that I’ve constantly engaged with and loved — starting with Fiorucci graphics,” says Anya Hindmarch, the sparkly, one-woman powerhouse behind her eponymous British clothing and accessories line. Ahead of her runway bonanza in London this Sunday, the designer has collaborated with the art auction house Sotheby’s to curate a one-off sale of contemporary works, each handpicked by Hindmarch, and spanning from the postwar period to the present day. “I could easily lose myself to the art world,” admits the Royal Academy Trustee, who applies her trademark playfulness to the role of curator, even decorating the exhibition space of the historic auction house with speech-bubble emojis. “Working on this project has been like a little bit of me-time in the run-up to the show.” On view now at Sotheby’s on New Bond Street, there are sculptural Wolfgang Tillmans, tiny textural Gerhard Richters — and one rare and riotous hot pink Keith Haring that’s currently the top lot. The refreshing common denominator? Fun! For an insight into Hindmarch’s selection, click through the slideshow below.

headline: Trump, Grand Wizard of Birtherism
abstract: Once again, the Republican candidate has lied, and has compounded his lie by blaming the controversy on Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: So, on Friday the Grand Wizard of Birtherism against President Obama admitted that birtherism was bunk, not by apologizing for his prominent role in the racist campaign — no, that would have been too right — but by suggesting that he deserved credit for dousing the flames he’d fanned.

headline: A Chicago Shooting Survivor, but in Need of a Miracle
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Life-Sustaining Support Systems, Withdrawal Of']
abstract: Sixty-four people were shot in the city over Memorial Day weekend; 6 died. The 58 survivors, including Precious Land, were mostly left to languish in anonymity.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — In a spacious room on the fourth floor of a rehabilitation hospital, Stacey Turner talked to her only daughter, Precious Land, as if she could understand every word. She styled Ms. Land’s hair, massaged her hands and set out to paint her fingernails. The only sound was the whirring of a ventilator.

headline: Gunman Kills One and Wounds Five, Including 2 Officers, in Philadelphia
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police', 'Attacks on Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The shootings began Friday night with an ambush on a city police sergeant in her squad car. The gunman was fatally shot by the police.
lead_paragraph: A gunman killed one person and wounded five others in a rampage on Friday night in Philadelphia that began when he ambushed a police sergeant in her squad car.

headline: Spin Class Full? Feel the Burn From Your Living Room
keywords: ['Exercise', 'Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: A new crop of boutique workout companies are using interactive apps to bring their cycling, yoga and fitness classes to customers around the globe.
lead_paragraph: On a recent weekday morning, Alex Toussaint, a cycling instructor at Peloton, welcomed people to his ’90s hip-hop spin class — 50 who were right in front of him, and more than 200 riders who had tuned in from around the country. Peloton’s sleek space may look like one of many boutique cycling studios around Manhattan, but it also functions as a film studio, broadcasting to thousands of riders who watch classes from tablets mounted to their Peloton bikes.

headline: Variety: The Acrostic
abstract: Try it, you’ll like it, this acrostic from Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Leslie Savan’s “The Sponsored Life: Ads, T.V. and American Culture” is a 90s look at the pervasive influence of advertising. I had never heard of this author or book, but fortunately I was able to fill in just enough clues to slowly cobble together the grid. One of my first certain solves, incidentally, was LUFTHANSA based on the advertising line “Nonstop you”; so I guess I’m among the crowd in thrall of the catchy hook.

headline: Fashion Week Photo Diary: Ryan Lo and Ashley Williams
abstract: Scenes from the spring/summer 2017 collections which were presented in London on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the spring/summer 2017 collections which were presented in London on Friday.

headline: Padres’ A. J. Preller Gets a Slap on the Wrist for His Deception
abstract: Preller, San Diego’s general manager, hid medical records from other teams in trade talks but on Thursday was suspended for only 30 days for that serious ethical breach.
lead_paragraph: The deception of A. J. Preller, the San Diego Padres’ general manager, who hid medical records from other teams in trade talks, is almost as disturbing as baseball’s response to it. Preller was suspended 30 days without pay on Thursday, an inadequate response to a serious ethical breach.

headline: Disarming the ‘Food Pushers’ to Help People Lose Weight
abstract: A Weight Watchers coach offers members strategies for controlling snacking, eating out, staying active and, of course, dealing with unhelpful naysayers.
lead_paragraph: Angela Dunn, 33, is a personal coach and receptionist for Weight Watchers International in College Station, Tex.

headline: At New York Fashion Week, a Reflection on American Style
abstract: The Row, Proenza Schouler and Ralph Lauren each offered decidedly unique definitions of homegrown design.
lead_paragraph: What is “American” fashion? I don’t mean fashion made in America — that much is obvious (though considering most high fashion in America is manufactured in Italy, that’s an interesting point for discussion too). But ideologically, what does it constitute? What makes a collection, or a designer, especially “American?” To a set of jet-lagged eyes, that seemed to be the question that occupied New York designers in their spring/summer 2017 collections.

headline: The Standoff Between Big Oil and Big Corn
keywords: ['Ethanol', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists']
abstract: The policy debate over the decade-old federal Renewable Fuel Standard is largely a battle between two giant competing industries: ethanol and petroleum.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, lawmakers in Washington tried to address a trifecta of thorny challenges with one simple fix that has turned out to be anything but easy to assess.

headline: England’s Forgotten Muslim History
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Ottoman Empire']
abstract: Isolated from Europe, Elizabeth I turned to the Islamic world.
lead_paragraph: London — Britain is divided as never before. The country has turned its back on Europe, and its female ruler has her sights set on trade with the East. As much as this sounds like Britain today, it also describes the country in the 16th century, during the golden age of its most famous monarch, Queen Elizabeth I.

headline: For Independent League Team, a New Stadium, Indictments and a Title Run
keywords: ['Baseball', 'Minor Leagues', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Stadiums and Arenas', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: The Rockland Boulders, in New York’s Hudson Valley, played for a championship at a field whose construction led to federal fraud and conspiracy charges against two men.
lead_paragraph: RAMAPO, N.Y. — Before the Rockland Boulders’ season began, their home field was at the center of federal indictments for securities fraud brought by Preet Bharara, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York.

headline: Swamps, Marijuana, Moonshine: 2 Prison Escapees’ 3 Weeks on the Run in New York
abstract: Maybe breaking out of prison was the easy part. After that, Richard W. Matt and David Sweat fought cold, hunger, and eventually each other before one was caught and one was killed.
lead_paragraph: When the two men plunged into the unforgiving wilderness of the Adirondacks, they had scant experience and supplies better suited to boys running away from home than to convicted killers fleeing a maximum-security prison: pepperoni sticks, toilet paper, a cache of black pepper, an electric shaver and 40 granola bars, all packed in a cloth guitar case.

headline: Paralympic Athletes’ Least Favorite Word: Inspiration
abstract: “It’s not a word that we like to hear,” says the American swimmer Jessica Long. Just call them athletes.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — They hear the word on commercials advertising the Paralympic Games. They see it on promotional material. It surfaces in encounters on the street, in the grocery store, and during interviews.

headline: J.W.Anderson: Spring 2017
abstract: The designer, who is also the creative director of Loewe, presents his latest collection.
lead_paragraph: The designer, who is also the creative director of Loewe, presents his latest collection.

headline: Baseball’s Stirrups: Always in Season, if Not in Fashion
abstract: Stirrups have long been ingrained in the fabric of baseball. A few players wear them to honor tradition while others see them as an act of rebellion.
lead_paragraph: Cleveland Indians shortstop Francisco Lindor absorbed a wealth of baseball knowledge from his father, Miguel. In Puerto Rico, the elder Lindor would hit balls down a hill to refine his son’s fielding instincts, the theory being he would not miss many if he knew he would then have to chase after them.

headline: Device Explodes Near Route of Charity Race in Jersey Shore
abstract: An improvised device exploded in a garbage receptacle near the course of a marine charity race in Seaside Park, N.J. There were no injuries.
lead_paragraph: An improvised device exploded in a garbage receptacle near the course of a charity race that was about to begin in a small town on the Jersey Shore on Saturday, law enforcement officials said.

headline: Safety First, Even if Will Power Finishes Second
abstract: An incorrect concussion diagnosis in March may have cost Power the IndyCar championship. But he has no regrets, calling the extra precautions appropriate.
lead_paragraph: A concussion, or perhaps the absence of one, may help decide the IndyCar title this weekend at Sonoma Raceway in California.

headline: A Trump Empire Built on Inside Connections and $885 Million in Tax Breaks
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Mr. Trump has relied on the government and taxpayers to benefit the 15 buildings at the core of his Manhattan real estate developments.
lead_paragraph: The way Donald J. Trump tells it, his first solo project as a real estate developer, the conversion of a faded railroad hotel on 42nd Street into the sleek, 30-story Grand Hyatt, was a triumph from the very beginning.

headline: In Missouri Senate Race, Challenger Makes His Point With a Blindfold and Rifle
abstract: A campaign ad shows Jason Kander, a veteran and a Democratic candidate for Senate in Missouri, explaining his support for background checks using a blindfold and an assault rifle.
lead_paragraph: One of the most striking campaign ads for the general election has nothing to do with the presidential race and is aimed at only one state. It is from Jason Kander, a Democratic candidate for Senate in Missouri, a veteran who explains his support for firearms background checks using a blindfold and an assault rifle.

headline: In Evolving N.F.L., Giants Show How Getting Younger Is Looking Wiser
abstract: Three rookies — receiver Sterling Shepard, cornerback Eli Apple and free safety Darian Thompson — are already playing important roles for the Giants.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Rookies come into the N.F.L. swelling with pride and promise, but many have ended up neither seen nor heard.

headline: Tim Kaine
abstract: The Democratic vice-presidential candidate on the diplomacy of St. Francis, jamming out with his harmonica, and camping cuisine.
lead_paragraph: TIM KAINE is a United States senator from Virginia and the Democratic nominee for vice president.

headline: Hillary Clinton Struggles to Gain Traction in Florida, Despite Spending
abstract: Recent polls show Mrs. Clinton is not earning the same support of Hispanics, young people or white voters as President Obama did in 2012, which offers Donald J. Trump an opening.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Hillary Clinton has vastly outspent Donald J. Trump on TV ads in Florida. Her 57 campaign offices dwarf Mr. Trump’s afterthought of a ground game. And Mr. Trump is deeply unpopular among Hispanics, who account for nearly one in five Florida voters.

headline: Mike Pence
abstract: The Republican vice-presidential candidate on the populism of Andrew Jackson, Indiana’s own John Mellencamp, and the Zen of horseback riding.
lead_paragraph: MIKE PENCE is the governor of Indiana and the Republican nominee for vice president.

headline: Would You Hide a Jew From the Nazis?
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Movies', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: We should remember heroes of the 1930s and ’40s this week as world leaders meet to discuss today’s global refugee crisis.
lead_paragraph: WHEN representatives from the United States and other countries gathered in Evian, France, in 1938 to discuss the Jewish refugee crisis caused by the Nazis, they exuded sympathy for Jews — and excuses about why they couldn’t admit them. Unto the breach stepped a 33-year-old woman from Massachusetts named Martha Sharp.

headline: Emilia Wickstead: Spring 2017
abstract: The designer shows her spring 2017 looks, sure to be noticed by her repeat customer, the Duchess of Cambridge.
lead_paragraph: The designer shows her spring 2017 looks, sure to be noticed by her repeat customer, the Duchess of Cambridge.

headline: Hate Crime in the United States
abstract: A 20-state study by the Center for the Study of Hate & Extremism, California State University, San Bernardino.
lead_paragraph: A 20-state study by the Center for the Study of Hate & Extremism, California State University, San Bernardino.

headline: ‘He Changed the World’: Artists Mourn Edward Albee
abstract: Theater lovers shared remembrances on social media of the playwright and his work.
lead_paragraph: Edward Albee, the playwright whose Broadway debut — “Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?” — remains one of the best-known American plays, was mourned by the people who knew him best: those in the world of theater.

headline: Rich School, Poor School
abstract: Readers discuss a Connecticut judge’s sweeping indictment of inequities in the state’s education system.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss a Connecticut judge’s sweeping indictment of the inequities in education.

headline: America’s Wildlife Body Count
abstract: We kill millions of “pest” animals each year, without the science to justify it.
lead_paragraph: Until recently, I had never had any dealings with Wildlife Services, a century-old agency of the United States Department of Agriculture with a reputation for strong-arm tactics and secrecy. It is beloved by many farmers and ranchers and hated in equal measure by conservationists, for the same basic reason: It routinely kills predators and an astounding assortment of other animals — 3.2 million of them last year — because ranchers and farmers regard them as pests.

headline: Because Punk Still Rocks
abstract: Four decades after the Sex Pistols, there’s a new crowd in the mosh pit.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Forty years after its noisy arrival, punk rock has hit middle age. CBGB, the seminal New York punk club on the Bowery, has been closed for a decade, but there is a CBGB-themed restaurant at the Newark airport. In my hometown, Boston, the 148-room Hotel Commonwealth, which occupies the former site of the storied punk venue the Rathskeller (always known as “The Rat”), offers a punk-themed luxury suite — for about $500 a night.

headline: California’s Nifty Idea on Immigrant Health Care
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Medicare', 'Editorials', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Helping immigrants gain access to health insurance is both sound fiscal policy and good public health policy.
lead_paragraph: The Affordable Care Act has helped 20 million people gain health insurance, but it explicitly excludes one group: undocumented immigrants. Now, lawmakers in California want to help change that by letting all immigrants purchase policies on the state’s insurance marketplace without federal subsidies. This is a good idea that the Obama administration should support.

headline: Dilution of Doctrine
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Marriages']
abstract: Pope Francis’s divorce maneuvers show how Catholicism might shift on same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: LAST weekend Tim Kaine, the Democratic vice-presidential nominee and a churchgoing Catholic, briefly escaped obscurity by telling an audience of L.G.B.T. activists that he expects his church to eventually bless and celebrate same-sex marriages.

headline: Why Do Anything? A Meditation on Procrastination
abstract: The procrastinator is both contemplator and man of action, which is the worst thing to be.
lead_paragraph: Have you heard the story of the architect from Shiraz who designed the world’s most beautiful mosque? No one had ever conjured up such a design. It was breathtakingly daring yet well-proportioned, divinely sophisticated, yet radiating a distinctly human warmth. Those who saw the plans were awe-struck.

headline: Put Globalization to Work for Democracies
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Protectionism (Trade)', 'North American Free Trade Agreement', 'Customs (Tariff)', 'Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)']
abstract: We need to rescue globalization not just from its populist critics but also from its cheerleaders.
lead_paragraph: A Chinese student once described his country’s globalization strategy to me. China, he said, opened a window to the world economy, but placed a screen on it. The country got the fresh air it needed — nearly 700 million people have been lifted from extreme poverty since the early 1980s — but kept mosquitoes out.

headline: Will This Be a Four-Party Election?
abstract: Sometimes third parties invigorate the major parties with new ideas. Sometimes they bring them crashing down.
lead_paragraph: Third parties don’t fit cleanly into the simple political narrative most of us have in our heads of red versus blue, and two parties battling it out, Super Bowl-style. Yet for much of our history, outsiders have pushed their way onto the playing field, disrupting the narrative of the Big Game.

headline: Bashing the Hero in the Wells Fargo Case
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Editorials', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: A robust consumer protection bureau is needed to protect the public from unfair, deceptive and abusive practices.
lead_paragraph: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has rightly emerged as the hero in the story this month about fraudulent practices at Wells Fargo. The bureau was the lead agency in the investigation of the bank, where some 5,300 employees (now fired) illegally opened millions of unauthorized bank and credit card accounts in customers’ names in order to meet aggressive sales targets.

headline: The Fight Working Moms Won
keywords: ['Work-Life Balance', 'Family Leaves', 'Parenting', 'Women and Girls', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Trump’s paid leave plan is flawed, leaves out fathers — and represents real progress.
lead_paragraph: Working mothers, take note: You have won the culture war. Now you are making advances in the policy battle. This presidential race has become, at least in part, a debate over how best to help you balance work and home, not whether you should be working at all.

headline: The Afghan War Quagmire
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials', 'Series', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The next commander in chief will face no good options in Afghanistan. But we need a plan that is better than the current policy.
lead_paragraph: Eight years ago, President Obama pledged to wind down the war in Iraq and redouble efforts to defeat the Taliban in Afghanistan. “As president, I will make the fight against Al Qaeda and the Taliban the top priority that it should be,” he said during a campaign speech. “This is a war that we have to win.”

headline: Why College Rankings Are a Joke
abstract: Lists like U.S. News & World Report’s are too blunt and too blind to certain gems.
lead_paragraph: Shortly before the newest U.S. News & World Report college rankings came out last week, I got a fresh glimpse of how ridiculous they can be — and of why panicked high school seniors and their status-conscious parents should not spend the next months obsessing over them.

headline: An Al Qaeda Martyr’s Enduring Pitch
keywords: ['Muslim Americans', 'Terrorism', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Somali-Americans', 'San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Five years after his death, Anwar al-Awlaki’s warning to Western Muslims continues to resonate.
lead_paragraph: Hiding out from American drones in Yemen’s badlands in March 2010, Al Qaeda’s most persuasive English-language recruiter donned a camo jacket and addressed American and European Muslims.

headline: My Teenage Obsession With ‘How Things Work’
keywords: ['Schizophrenia', 'Families and Family Life', 'Books and Literature', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Growing up with a schizophrenic mother, I yearned to make sense of the world.
lead_paragraph: Tampa, Fla. — My mother, a paranoid schizophrenic, was kind, shy and very strange, darting from our house to the car, carrying her purse in a cardboard box, always. Any activity that required interacting with fellow humans was, for her, anathema. As an adolescent I knew one thing for certain: I didn’t want to turn out like my mother.

headline: It’s a Wrap: Covering the Toronto Film Festival
abstract: Traffic on the way to a star-studded gala? This culture reporter grabs his sports jacket and hops on a bicycle.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares insights into how we work at The New York Times. In this piece, Mekado Murphy, a Times culture editor, says he still often feels like “the shabby, backpack-toting guest” at glitzy events like the Toronto International Film Festival: “I might be scarfing down a granola bar on the way to a hotel-room interview and find myself sharing an elevator with Michael Fassbender.”

headline: The Strip
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: Germans and Austrians Protest E.U. Trade Talks With U.S. and Canada
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP)']
abstract: Opposition to proposed deals, and to perceived lower consumer standards, has united a coalition of churches, trade unions, intellectuals and left-wing parties.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Hundreds of thousands of people rallied across Germany and Austria on Saturday to urge their governments not to sign new agreements being negotiated for European Union trade deals with the United States and Canada.

headline: Hate Crimes Against American Muslims Most Since Post-9/11 Era
abstract: Some scholars believe that the violence is driven not only by the string of terrorist attacks, but also by the political vitriol from candidates like Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hate crimes against American Muslims have soared to their highest levels since the aftermath of the Sept. 11, 2001 attacks, according to data compiled by researchers, an increase apparently fueled by terrorist attacks in the United States and abroad and by divisive language on the campaign trail.

headline: Caliphate in Peril, More ISIS Fighters May Take Mayhem to Europe
abstract: The American-led coalition is closing in strongholds in Iraq and Syria. But some Western officials expect consequences to that success for years to come.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the Islamic State loses territory in Iraq and Syria, American and other Western officials say they are bracing for large numbers of battle-tested terrorist fighters to flee the conflict in desperation or by design and prepare attacks after returning home.

headline: A Mosquito Killer, Unwelcome to Many
abstract: The insecticide naled is sprayed to fight disease-carrying mosquitoes like the ones that spread the Zika virus. But many people fear the cure is worse than the disease.
lead_paragraph: A controversial pesticide, naled, was sprayed over Miami this month in an effort to eradicate Aedes aegypti, the mosquitoes spreading the Zika virus in southern Florida. The spraying has prompted protests from environmentalists and residents worried about naled’s toxicity. Here are some facts about the pesticide.

headline: Outcry Erupts Over Miami Beach’s Pesticide Spraying to Curb Zika
abstract: Residents and environmental protesters are coalescing around the issue of early morning naled spraying and raising concerns about its safety and efficacy.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI BEACH — As Miami Beach works to blunt the spread of Zika — a virus that is taking a toll on tourism here — the city is wrestling with a separate predicament: a fast-growing outcry over the aerial spraying of naled, the pesticide used to kill adult mosquitoes.

headline: Occupy Wall Street: Where Are They Now?
abstract: Though some protesters have returned to their former lives, all say they have been transformed.
lead_paragraph: Though some protesters have returned to their former lives, all say they have been transformed.

headline: Southeast Asia Replaces Africa as the World’s Hotbed of Piracy
abstract: Militants from Abu Sayyaf and other criminal groups have stepped up kidnappings and thefts in the seas around Indonesia and the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Sembara Oktafian was in the engine room of a tugboat chugging toward the Philippines when something didn’t sound right.

headline: Simone Rocha: Spring 2017
abstract: Ms. Rocha, who debuted at London Fashion Week in 2010, shows the latest in her subversive, romantic style.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Rocha, who debuted at London Fashion Week in 2010, shows the latest in her subversive, romantic style.

headline: The Insomnia Machine
abstract: When medicine fails, where can the sleepless turn?
lead_paragraph: In 1914, The Lancet reported on a clergyman who was found dead in a pool; he had left behind this suicide note: “Another sleepless night, no real sleep for weeks. Oh, my poor brain, I cannot bear the lengthy, dark hours of the night.”

headline: At Simone Rocha, Youthful and ‘Careless’ Plaited Ponytails
abstract: The work of the photographer Jackie Nickerson inspired a utilitarian beauty look at the designer’s spring/summer 2017 show.
lead_paragraph: The work of the Boston-born photographer Jackie Nickerson, whose powerful portraits document agricultural workers across southern Africa, was the cerebral starting point for the look both front and backstage at Simone Rocha for spring 2017. “It’s really important to Simone to have a complete look where everything works together,” explained the hairstylist (and longtime friend of the designer) James Pecis, backstage. “This hair has a practical and utilitarian feel. It’s a little more pulled back than what we’ve done in the past — because there’s so much going on in the collection.” To create a look that would work out-of-doors, Pecis pulled the models’ hair back into two plaited ponytails, using Maximista Thickening Spray to give it the “sweaty” feel that Rocha requested.

headline: Edward Albee, a Playwright Intent on Naming, and Goading, the Beast Within
abstract: Throughout his work, Mr. Albee insisted that our most primitive instincts keep asserting themselves in even the most civilized settings.
lead_paragraph: Edward Albee never expected or even wanted you to like his plays. “Like” is too pale and friendly a word for the red-blooded emotions he hoped to elicit. Rage and bewilderment, fear and loathing and that grand old Aristotelian couple, pity and terror: These were all welcome and entirely appropriate responses to have in the theater of Mr. Albee, one of the genuinely great dramatists of the last century, who died on Friday at 88.

headline: Gareth Pugh: Spring 2017
abstract: The designer, known for his provocative looks, shows his latest collection.
lead_paragraph: The designer, known for his provocative looks, shows his latest collection.

headline: Don Buchla, Inventor, Composer and Electronic Music Maverick, Dies at 79
abstract: The instruments Mr. Buchla built represented what became known as the West Coast philosophy of electronic music: more experimental and less commercial.
lead_paragraph: Don Buchla, a pioneer and maverick of electronic music who had a lifelong fascination with the ways that humans, technology and sounds interact, died on Wednesday at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 79.

headline: Mets’ Win Offsets Bad News on Jacob deGrom, Expected to Miss Rest of Season
abstract: Before a 3-2 win over the Twins in 12 innings, the Mets revealed that deGrom had pain in his right elbow and needed surgery to remove built-up scar tissue.
lead_paragraph: The Mets’ season, a tale that has included as many strange turns as a Stanley Kubrick film, revealed another twist Saturday.

headline: Turkey’s Islamic Fashion Revolution
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Muslim Veiling', 'Models (Professional)', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: As Europe grapples with the burkini, Islamic dress in Turkey has become a symbol of religious freedom, and the nation has fostered fashion houses, magazines and bloggers.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The models, tall and lithe and strutting down the runway to the beat of Moroccan-themed house music, are from Russia and Eastern Europe. They could be displaying the latest designer styles in Paris or New York, but instead they are here, in Istanbul, wearing high heels, flowing tunics and colorful head scarves.

headline: Another Painful Loss for Yankees, With Castro and Ellsbury Injured
abstract: A wild pitch sent the Yankees to their sixth defeat in seven games. Starlin Castro, their leading home run hitter, strained his hamstring, and Jacoby Ellsbury hurt his knee.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — No player who has been with the Yankees since the start of the season has played in fewer games than Austin Romine, their third-string catcher since early August.

headline: Kremlin Says It Wants a Spotless Election, but Locally It Is Marred
abstract: The campaign in Togliatti, long a bastion of opposition to the dominant United Russia Party, illustrates the gap between the promise of fair elections on Sunday and the reality.
lead_paragraph: TOGLIATTI, Russia — The retiree out walking her Scottie in the rain last week in Togliatti, home of the infamous Lada automobile, was delighted to encounter an opposition candidate distributing pamphlets that called on President Vladimir V. Putin to step down.

headline: Howard E. Butt Jr., Grocery Empire Heir Who Spread a Gospel, Dies at 89
abstract: Mr. Butt left the day-to-day operation of a business to focus on Christian outreach, philanthropy and a message of marrying spiritual and professional lives.
lead_paragraph: Howard E. Butt Jr., a billionaire heir apparent to his family’s Texas supermarket empire, who gave up the business to spread a Christian message about the dignity of work and its nexus with faith and built a nationwide following, died on Sept. 11 at his home in San Antonio. He was 89.

headline: Film Shines Light on South Korean Spy Agency’s Fabrication of Enemies
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Political Prisoners', 'Movies']
abstract: A new documentary shows how scores of people were arrested and accused of spying for the North, only to be exonerated years later.

headline: Donald Trump’s Anything-Goes Campaign Sets an Alarming Political Precedent

abstract: The past week’s routine falsehoods, unfounded claims and inflammatory language offered a vivid illustration of how little regard Mr. Trump has for the long-held expectations of America’s leaders.

headline: Duane Graveline, Doctor Who Was Forced Out as an Astronaut, Dies at 85
abstract: Dr. Graveline resigned after two months because he was getting divorced and NASA was worried about its image; his later career as a doctor was marred by scandal.
lead_paragraph: In 1965, Duane E. Graveline, a doctor who did pioneering research in space medicine, was awarded one of the most coveted jobs the government can bestow: astronaut. But he resigned less than two months later without ever being fitted for a spacesuit, let alone riding a rocket into space.

headline: Iranian Cyclist Dies After Crashing at the Paralympics
abstract: Bahman Golbarnezhad, 48, went into cardiac arrest while he was being taken to a hospital.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — An Iranian cyclist died Saturday after an accident in a men’s road race at the Paralympics in Rio de Janeiro. The cyclist, Bahman Golbarnezhad, crashed on a mountainous section of the course known as the Grumari loop, the International Paralympic Committee said.

headline: Berlin Election Deals Angela Merkel’s Party Another Blow

abstract: Ms. Merkel’s Christian Democratic Union won about 18 percent of the vote in a state election, not enough to allow it to remain the junior partner in a coalition with the Social Democrats.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel’s party suffered the latest in a string of defeats in German state elections on Sunday, when her Christian Democratic Union was ousted from power in Berlin after its worst showing in the capital since World War II, according to preliminary results.

headline: 1941: Britain Gets American Aid
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Britain receives food aid from America in September 1941.
lead_paragraph: AT A BRITISH PORT — Cargoes of lease-lend goods, and other materials ordered from America in cash-and-carry days, are pouring into England at an average rate of 850.000 tons a week and are being handled promptly, a visit to this large port revealed today [Sept. 18].

headline: Manhattan Bombs Provide Trove of Clues; F.B.I. Questions 5 People
abstract: The people were taken to an F.B.I. office in Manhattan, and an official said they may have been heading to the airport. Tensions in the region increased when the authorities said pipe bombs were found in Elizabeth, N.J.
lead_paragraph: A bomb that injured 29 people on Saturday in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan, and another that failed to detonate, were filled with shrapnel and made with pressure cookers, flip phones and Christmas lights to set off a powerful explosive compound, law enforcement officials said on Sunday.

headline: F.B.I. Treats Minnesota Mall Stabbing Attack as ‘Potential Act of Terrorism’
abstract: The Islamic State claimed responsibility for an attack in which nine people were injured before the knife-wielding man was shot by an off-duty police officer.
lead_paragraph: A report by a news agency linked to the Islamic State claimed on Sunday that a “soldier of the Islamic State” was behind a stabbing attack on Saturday night at a Minnesota shopping mall, an episode that the F.B.I. said it was investigating as a “potential act of terrorism.” Nine people were injured in the attack before an off-duty police officer fatally shot the knife-wielding man, the authorities in St. Cloud said.

headline: A Weekend Whirlwind: Simone Rocha’s Nostalgia and Henry Holland’s Cheeky Tees
abstract: Gareth Pugh debuted both opera costumes and a spring collection, while models like Gigi Hadid and Winnie Harlow filled the front rows.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Fashion may be an industry based on change, but in the wake of Britain’s vote to leave the European Union and the rise of the see-now, buy-now collections, few in the industry said they could recall a London season that felt more in a state of transition. Some familiar faces also stayed away from the opening weekend, doubtless taking a breather before the show marathon moves onto Milan and then to Paris.

abstract: The authorities believe a homemade bomb caused the explosion in the Chelsea neighborhood about 8:30 p.m. Saturday, injuring 29. A second device was later found four blocks away.
lead_paragraph: The authorities believe a homemade bomb caused the explosion in the Chelsea neighborhood about 8:30 p.m. Saturday, injuring 29. A second device was later found four blocks away.

headline: Contests in New Hampshire May Alter Political Map
abstract: Donald J. Trump has advantages in the state, but in the last six presidential races, the once reliably Republican state has voted Democratic five times.
lead_paragraph: New Hampshire is in the bottom quarter of states in terms of its electoral and popular votes in the United States presidential race. But no other place has more competitive races with national implications.

headline: A Routine Night, Until an Explosion Lifted Her Off Her Feet
abstract: Helena Ayeh was carrying a bag with wine bottles through the gate of her apartment building on West 23rd Street in Chelsea when she was thrown through the air by the blast.
lead_paragraph: In the shadow of Bellevue Hospital Center, cast by a luminescent moon early Sunday, the only hint of the chaos that had erupted on the other side of Manhattan hours earlier was a trim woman in gray sweatpants and a royal-blue button-down shirt who limped out onto First Avenue.

headline: N.F.L.: Here’s What We Learned in Week 2
abstract: The Patriots, the Steelers and the Giants survived sloppy Week 2 battles. Here’s what happened around the league.
lead_paragraph: ■ Optimism is easy to come by in the offseason, but maintaining it in the regular season for even two games can be far more difficult. Just ask the Jaguars (0-2), the Raiders (1-1, with 69 points allowed through two games) and the Buccaneers (1-1 after being crushed 40-7 by the Cardinals).

headline: At Topshop Unique, an ’80s Supermodel Curl
abstract: For spring/summer 2017, the hairstylist Duffy wound models’ hair around chopstick-thin curling irons — but had a trick to avoid “instant noodle hair.”
lead_paragraph: The ravishing beauty of 1980s supermodels was the powerful starting point for the saturated Rapunzel curls backstage at Topshop Unique for spring/summer 2017. “We were going to go quite extreme with a ponytail,” explained the hairstylist Duffy. “But it felt too young, so we’ve gone for a more mature style.” Overloading the hair with L’Oreal Professional’s PHI to create a matte finish, Duffy blasted it with the dryer (no brushing required), pulling it into a topknot tied together with “any old elastic,” before piling on lashings of Volume Life Mousse. After allowing the hair to set, he carefully twisted and twirled small sections around a curling iron with the dimensions of a chopstick. The real power move was to stop short of what Duffy termed “instant noodle hair,” by literally clapping the curls between the palms of the hands to break them up, for a more modern, lived-in look. Once complete, the elastic was snipped out and the hair swept over either to the left or the right of models’ heads, in what amounted to a hair homage to a young Cindy Crawford.

headline: Peter Pilotto: Spring 2017
abstract: Peter Pilotto and Christopher De Vos show their spring designs.
lead_paragraph: Peter Pilotto and Christopher De Vos show their spring designs.

headline: An Explosion in Manhattan
abstract: A blast ripped through Chelsea around 8:30 p.m. on Saturday, injuring 29 people.
lead_paragraph: A blast ripped through Chelsea around 8:30 p.m. on Saturday, injuring 29 people.

headline: 1966: New Met Opera Opens
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: The new Metropolitan Opera House opens at the Lincoln Center in New York in September 1966.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — The new Metropolitan Opera House opened in a blaze of glory Friday night, [Sept. 18] settling a dispute with its orchestra and thrilling one of its most glittering audiences ever gathered in New York. Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson headed personalities at the Lincoln Center first night — which had threatened to be the last for some time. But as the curtain was about to rise for the last act of “Antony and Cleopatra,” Met general manager Rudolf Bing took the stage of the $47 million Opera House to announce that a strike by the musicians was over.

headline: Obama, Keen to Push Israeli-Palestinian Peace, Will Meet With Netanyahu
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'International Relations', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Aides said he was expected to review his diplomatic achievements at his last visit to the United Nations, and he might press Israel’s leader to move toward reconciliation.
lead_paragraph: President Obama arrived in New York City on Sunday evening for three days that will mix election-year politics with a farewell to the world stage at the United Nations. But the visit comes against a suddenly tense backdrop, after a powerful explosion rocked a Manhattan street and a man claiming fealty to the Islamic State stabbed several people in a Minnesota shopping mall.

headline: Straightforward Answers to Basic Questions About Syria’s War
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Terrorism', 'Alawite Muslims', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Tracking the toll is not difficult, but understanding how and why the conflict evolved is far more complicated – and important.
lead_paragraph: You could be forgiven, after five years of Syria’s war dominating front pages, for feeling lost.

abstract: Johnny Coca presents his second collection for the house.
lead_paragraph: Johnny Coca presents his second collection for the house.

headline: Ultra Runner Karl Meltzer Sets Appalachian Trail Record, Fueled by Beer and Candy
abstract: He covered the 2,190 miles in less than 46 days, shaving about 10 hours off the previous mark.
lead_paragraph: At a time when “endurance running” no longer means mere marathons — and even 100-mile races are attracting the masses — Karl Meltzer, a former ski-resort bartender, has proved he can suffer longer and faster than almost anyone else.

headline: Fashion Week Photo Diary: JW Anderson, Simone Rocha and Molly Goddard
abstract: Scenes from the spring/summer 2017 collections which were presented in London on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the spring/summer 2017 collections which were presented in London on Saturday.

headline: Improving the U.N.
The United Nations Explained: Its Purpose, Power and Problems
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Humanitarian Aid']
abstract: As representatives of the body’s 193 member countries gather for the annual session of the General Assembly, a look at how the institution has attempted to live up to its founders’ ambitions.
lead_paragraph: Almost everybody has heard of the United Nations. But how many people know what it actually does? Or how it works? Or why, as world leaders gather to kick off the 71st session of the United Nations General Assembly, the institution has struggled to live up to the promise of its founders: making the world a better, more peaceful place?

headline: ‘La La Land’ Wins Top Prize at Toronto International Film Festival
abstract: Damien Chazelle’s work received the audience award for best feature; the audience prize for best documentary went to Raoul Peck’s “I Am Not Your Negro.”
lead_paragraph: Adding to its early status as an Oscar front-runner, the moody musical “La La Land,” directed by Damien Chazelle and starring Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling, on Sunday received the Toronto International Film Festival’s top prize, the audience award for best feature film.

headline: ‘Blair Witch’ and ‘Bridget Jones’ Sequels Lag; ‘Sully’ Again No. 1
abstract: “Snowden,” also opening this weekend, arrived with a thud, as “Sully” continues to soar, with a two-week total of $70.5 million.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Add two more sequels to the flop heap.

headline: After Blast, New Yorkers Examine Themselves for Psychological Shrapnel
abstract: A walk around Manhattan in the wake of the Saturday night explosion revealed residents conducting their own interior investigations.
lead_paragraph: As detectives scoured every inch of the bomb scene in Chelsea on Sunday, New Yorkers were conducting their own investigations. But theirs were turned inward, as they felt around for the psychological shrapnel that an explosion on a busy city street is designed to release, as damaging in its way as the kind that tears into flesh.

headline: Temperley London: Spring 2017
abstract: One of the Duchess of Cambridge’s go-to designers, Alice Temperley shows her latest looks.
lead_paragraph: One of the Duchess of Cambridge’s go-to designers, Alice Temperley shows her latest looks.

headline: Lil Buck and Jon Boogz, Wearing Paint as They Tell a Tale
abstract: Movement artists are rendered into two-dimensional beings by Alexa Meade as they send a message about social justice in the video “Color of Reality.”
lead_paragraph: It might seem all too obvious. Two young black men sit on a sofa watching the awful news of recent events — police shootings, the Orlando massacre — before venturing outside, where they are ignored, shunned and eventually shot. But in the lushly hypnotic video “Color of Reality,” a quick tale told through movement and visual art, these men are dancers and their message is not just about social justice. It’s also about their art.

headline: Philharmonic Shines in Live Unison With Films as It Kicks Off 175th Season
abstract: “Manhattan” and “West Side Story” were perfect choices for a season in which the orchestra’s New York identity is being celebrated.
lead_paragraph: Of all the projects Alan Gilbert has introduced as music director of the New York Philharmonic, the series that screens classic films synced to the live playing of the scores may be the most popular. There is something magical about having the great Philharmonic serve as, in effect, a live studio orchestra for beloved films. Still, to ready these movies for screenings in concert requires considerable technical tinkering, and the results can be imperfect.

headline: Review: In ‘Kevin Can Wait,’ a Certain Domestic Déja Vu
abstract: This new CBS sitcom about a man’s attempt to retire to domestic life with his not-very-interesting family is long on predictability.
lead_paragraph: Either Kevin waited too long, or he didn’t wait long enough.

headline: Jacoby Brissett Gets Job Done for Patriots After Jimmy Garoppolo Injury
abstract: Garoppolo was rolling when he was knocked to the turf on his throwing shoulder. Brissett did just enough to help the Patriots hold on to beat the Dolphins.
lead_paragraph: The clicking sound heard throughout the Northeast on Sunday, was fans of the New England Patriots frantically searching the internet for anything they could find on Jacoby Brissett, a rookie quarterback unexpectedly forced into action after a shoulder injury knocked Jimmy Garoppolo out of the game.

headline: Review: ‘Welcome Home,’ a 1970s Flashback on Governors Island
abstract: This dance and photography work by Colleen Thomas conveys a sense of what her family’s life was like on the island four decades ago.
lead_paragraph: Technically, it wasn’t her childhood home. But in the case of Colleen Thomas’s new site-specific work, “Welcome Home,” inspired by her years growing up on Governors Island — her father was a photographer for the Coast Guard — it was close enough. She wanted to set the piece in her family’s former residence, where she lived from age 6 to 12, but it suffered severe water damage during Hurricane Sandy. She compromised with another home nearby.

headline: Review: Setting a Squadron of Joyless Worker Drones to Music
abstract: The Holy Body Tattoo’s piece “monumental,” staged at the Next Wave Festival in Brooklyn, holds up a mirror to capitalism and finds discontent.
lead_paragraph: Early in “monumental,” a choreographic denunciation of corporate culture by the Canadian troupe the Holy Body Tattoo, a bit of life advice is projected upstage.

headline: Giants Beat Saints With a Field Goal That Ends a Lackluster Game
abstract: Josh Brown’s 23-yard chip shot as time expired put the Giants at 2-0 for the first time since 2009.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants’ receivers had dropped multiple potential touchdown passes. The team had lost three fumbles, and the offense had not scored a touchdown. Penalties had mired certain drives while sacks had stalled others.

headline: What Happened at the 2016 Emmy Awards
abstract: “Game of Thrones” and “Veep” repeated as best drama and comedy at the 68th Primetime Emmy Awards. Catch up on all the awards and everything that happened at the ceremony.

headline: Review: ‘Three Days of Terror’ Relives the Charlie Hebdo Attacks
abstract: Directed by Dan Reed, this HBO documentary reconstructs the murderous assaults in Paris in early 2015.
lead_paragraph: The British television director Dan Reed has a grisly specialty: documentary reconstructions of major terrorist attacks. He’s made “Terror in Mumbai,” “Terror at the Mall” (about the 2013 attack at a shopping mall in Nairobi, Kenya) and now “Three Days of Terror: The Charlie Hebdo Attacks,” all shown on HBO. They’re elegant, understated chapters in a dreadful volume.

headline: Review: In ‘What Did You Expect?,’ a Potluck of Election-Year Anxiety
abstract: Richard Nelson portrays life in a political season as a bewildering mirage for an extended family that finds itself in reduced circumstances.
lead_paragraph: The Gabriels are as worried as you are. As one of them says, with a matter-of-factness that suggests long and weary acquaintance with a troublesome state of being, “People are scared. Everyone I know is scared.”

headline: Introducing the New York Times Upshot/Siena College Poll
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']

lead_paragraph: On Monday, The Upshot and Siena College will release their first  survey of likely voters in Florida.

headline: Who’s the New Guy Pitching for the Mets? Doesn’t Matter. They Keep Winning.

headline: Reason and Vigilance After the Blast
abstract: The quick response to Saturday night’s explosion in Manhattan reflects the vigilance and public calm that are needed in today’s dangerous world.
lead_paragraph: A blast on a warm Saturday night in Manhattan sent people running through the streets. More than two dozen were hurt. New York City, accustomed to living with the echo and shadow of terrorism, handled the shock with composure.

headline: Review: In ‘The Good Place,’ Kristen Bell Is Dead and Crabby
abstract: Ms. Bell plays a new arrival to a heaven-like domain who should actually be somewhere a bit warmer in this new NBC sitcom.
lead_paragraph: Michael Schur is not the first writer to create a comedy about the afterlife. Dante Alighieri, for one, beat him by about 700 years. But Dante’s “The Divine Comedy” had the advantage of drawing on theology widely accepted by his audience and not having to deal with network notes. (“Beatrice: Relatable enough?”)

headline: Paul Smith: Spring 2017

lead_paragraph: The designer shows his spring 2017 collection.

headline: Anthrax Is Still Here and Still Rocking
abstract: This metal band, which formed in the 1980s, brought its big sound to the intimate St. Vitus club in Brooklyn to raise money for Gilda’s Club.
lead_paragraph: Just before 4 o’clock on Friday afternoon, the bassist Frank Bello and the guitarist Scott Ian, both three-decade-plus veterans of the band Anthrax, arrived at the tiny Greenpoint, Brooklyn club Saint Vitus and took in the scene: Their tour crew was still working out how to fit a festival-size setup onto a stage barely big enough for Charlie Benante’s nine-drum, 16-cymbal kit. Nearly a quarter of the floor was cluttered with crates and guitars, and the top half of an Anthrax banner was draped over the entire back wall.

headline: Review: In ‘The Wonder,’ the Morality of Letting a Child Fast
abstract: This novel by Emma Donoghue, author of the best-seller “Room,” follows a nurse sent to confirm that an 11-year-old has survived on water for four months.
lead_paragraph: Two men sit across from each other in a Northern Ireland prison, locked in an argument so intense it feels like hand-to-hand combat. One is the Irish Republican Army prisoner Bobby Sands, who is preparing to starve himself to death. The other is Father Moran, a Catholic priest, who is trying to talk him out of it.

lead_paragraph: Patrons at a St. Cloud, Minn., mall were forced to stay inside until the police completed a security sweep and checked IDs. Nine people were injured before a knife-wielding man was shot by an off-duty police officer.

keywords: ['Restaurants', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Shortages', 'Labor and Jobs']

headline: Holocaust Survivors’ Needs Grow, and Aid Is Slow to Catch Up
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Reparations', 'Elderly', 'Home Health Care', 'Jews and Judaism', 'ANTI-SEMITISM']
abstract: Aging and often infirm and isolated, the remaining survivors require more help even as traditional sources of funding are starting to taper off.
lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — Agnes Galgoczi, 84, can no longer make it to the toilet on her own. It sits in the kitchen of her apartment in Budapest, just three feet from the bed, where she sings to herself to fight loneliness. Several blocks away, Vera Varga, 78, slides decades-old movies into her videocassette player. The images remind her of the outside world.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Sept. 19

headline: Artificial Intelligence Software Is Booming. But Why Now?
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Artificial Intelligence', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing']
abstract: As G.E., Oracle, Salesforce.com and others push their A.I. products, it remains unclear whether potential customers understand how they will profit.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — This is the year artificial intelligence came into its own for mainstream businesses, at least as a marketing feature.

headline: 2 Former Albuquerque Officers on Trial in Killing of Homeless Man
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Homeless Persons', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: The two former officers face charges of second-degree murder after shooting the homeless man, James Boyd, four hours into a standoff in 2014.
lead_paragraph: ALBUQUERQUE — The 911 call to the Albuquerque police on March 16, 2014, sounded routine: A man had been illegally camping in the foothills of the Sandia Mountains, just 100 yards from the caller’s backyard. Could an officer come by and take him away? But the man refused to comply.

headline: Why the Fed Is About to Raise Interest Rates
abstract: Federal Reserve officials have delayed raising rates this year as they wrestle with three critical questions. But they may soon be about to act.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials have delayed raising rates this year as they wrestle with three critical questions. But they may soon be about to act.

headline: James Stacy, Actor Who Kept Working After a Disabling Crash, Dies at 79
abstract: Mr. Stacy played specialized roles after losing an arm and a leg when his motorcycle was struck by a drunken driver.
lead_paragraph: James Stacy, who played a gunslinging drifter on the television western “Lancer” and, after losing an arm and a leg in a 1973 motorcycle accident, turned in memorable performances in specialized roles, died on Sept. 9 in Ventura, Calif. He was 79.

headline: Following Its Country Music, Nashville May Loosen Up on Marijuana
abstract: This city, which residents often refer to as the Buckle of the Bible Belt, may be on the cusp of decriminalizing marijuana.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Willie Nelson’s famous habit of smoking marijuana is not seen as a badge of outlaw courage here anymore, so much as the frivolous foible of an eccentric uncle. A popular FM station disgorging the Boomer rock hits of yesteryear calls itself Hippie Radio 94.5; one of its sponsors is a smoke shop that incessantly hawks glass pipes and detox kits. Even mainstream country acts mention smoking marijuana now and again among the litany of acceptable American pastimes.

headline: After Quake, an Italian Crisis Unit Races to Rescue a Region’s Heritage
keywords: ['Earthquakes', 'Salvage', 'Archives and Records', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Art', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)']
abstract: With thousands of relics and books at risk in the rubble, a crisis unit is working tirelessly to retrieve and preserve them.
lead_paragraph: AMATRICE, Italy — The rescuers worked tirelessly under a scorching sun. Wearing white masks to fight off the dust, they formed a human chain, passing from hand to hand all they could salvage from the gravelly destruction of the earthquake that struck this region in August. They had to work quickly, fearing the precariousness of an adjacent building splintered by wide fissures.

abstract: A look at the shows, actors and production teams who won at the 68th Primetime Emmy Awards.
lead_paragraph: [ Our full report on the 2016 Emmy Awards | red carpet looks | our critic’s review of the show ]

abstract: Chicago’s defense is likely to have its hands full with Carson Wentz, Philadelphia’s rookie quarterback.
lead_paragraph: 8:30 p.m. Eastern, ESPN Line: Bears by 1 ½

headline: Adblock Plus, Created to Protect Users From Ads, Instead Opens the Door
abstract: With its new platform, an automated online service, the company will allow more websites to place ads in front of users.
lead_paragraph: Adblock Plus, an ad blocker now used on more than 100 million devices, started out as an almost utopian idea a decade ago. Wladimir Palant, a 20-something developer who was annoyed with intrusive ads online, created it as an open-source project and quickly built it up with the help of volunteers who also wanted to make the internet faster, less cluttered and safer from malware.

headline: Chauffeur Service for a Second-String QB
abstract: The starter goes down, and a backup is liberated from his usual long subway ride.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Obama to Push Refugee Aid at U.N., but Critics Say Effort Is Overdue
abstract: Even those who praise Mr. Obama’s planned meeting on the refugee crisis wonder why the United States waited so long to mount a global response and why it has taken in so few Syrians.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — President Obama is planning to use his last appearance before the United Nations General Assembly this week to corral world leaders to uplift the lives of refugees crossing borders in droves. But critics say the United States faces a credibility test of its own.

headline: How a U.S. Airstrike Missed ISIS, but Damaged U.S. Policy in Syria
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The accidental killing of Syrian soldiers again exposed the White House’s struggles to put together a coherent strategy in a multisided civil war.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States’ accidental bombing of Syrian troops over the weekend has put it on the defensive, undercutting American efforts to reduce violence in the civil war and open paths for humanitarian relief.

headline: The Silver Lining in Pinstripes: Gary Sanchez
abstract: As their playoff hopes dim, the Yankees can find a bit of hope for the future in their phenom behind the plate.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — In recent weeks at Yankee Stadium, sprouting up through the thicket of pinstriped No. 2 jerseys and other remnants of the Derek Jeter era, there have been signs that Yankees fans are wrapping themselves in something other than nostalgia.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Avoids Terrorism Label in Manhattan Explosion
abstract: The mayor struck a tone of deliberation, but some saw his description of the attack as conflating the real-world definition of terrorism.
lead_paragraph: It was on the minds of New Yorkers, who immediately drew comparisons to Sept. 11, 2001. It could be felt in the police response, which included teams of heavily armed officers stationed at key targets and the Joint Terrorism Task Force of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Police Department.

headline: Obama Asks for Reality Check as ‘Frivolous’ Issues Dominate Election
abstract: President Obama has limited opportunities in his last months in office to shift focus from the raucous presidential campaign to his signature issues.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The sun was shining, thousands of supporters were chanting his name, and President Obama was basking again in the electricity of a campaign rally. But for a moment last week, he could not hide his exasperation at the circuslike atmosphere of this year’s presidential race.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Monday, September 19, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “This is one of the nightmare scenarios. We really were very lucky that there were no fatalities.”

headline: Larry King, the Russian Media and a Partisan Landscape
abstract: The presence of the cable talk show hosts Larry King and Ed Schultz on the United States feed of Russia Today, the satellite media organization funded by the Russian government, has raised eyebrows.
lead_paragraph: Last week, I caught Larry King on his post-CNN media perch, the RT America television network. His guest, the actress and activist Kamala Lopez, was powerfully emotional as she called for the ratification of the Equal Rights Amendment.

headline: Pro-Putin Parties Show Strength in Russian Parliament Elections
abstract: Early results showed the governing party, United Russia, with 46 percent of the vote in an election marked by low turnout in large cities.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Kremlin’s United Russia party and its three main allies maintained their lock on Parliament in national elections on Sunday, according to early results, with particularly low turnout in the largest cities.

headline: How Police Found Second Bomb, and a ‘Total Containment Vessel’ Hauled It Away
abstract: The authorities used a “total containment vessel” to haul the device to the Bronx before passing it along to the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
lead_paragraph: After the explosion on West 23rd Street on Saturday night, the police did what they typically do when they suspect a bomb has gone off. They spread out and began looking for unexploded bombs — what those on the New York Police Department’s bomb squad call “secondaries.” Officers began searching block by block, going as far south as 14th Street and as far north as 34th Street.

headline: A Doctor’s Assessment of Whether Donald Trump’s Health Is ‘Excellent’
abstract: Mr. Trump has pledged to release a full medical report, but has yet to do so. Here is an assessment of what he has released so far, and what remains unknown.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In releasing a far more sober account of Donald J. Trump’s health on Thursday, his physician provided details to support his view that the Republican nominee for president is overweight but otherwise “is in excellent physical health.”

headline: Michel C. Bergerac, Who Made Over Revlon, Dies at 84
abstract: The French-born deal maker expanded Revlon beyond cosmetics, transforming it into a major player in health care before a hostile takeover by Ronald O. Perelman.
lead_paragraph: Michel C. Bergerac, a French-born deal maker who ran the cosmetics giant Revlon for roughly a decade, diversifying its holdings before losing a battle for control of the company in 1985, died on Sept. 11 in Manhattan. He was 84.

headline: Rams Return to Los Angeles With Fanfare, and a Win
abstract: Many of the fans tailgating on Sunday wore throwback jerseys of bygone Rams.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The parking-lot pageant before the first regular-season home game of the nouveau Los Angeles Rams conveyed a mishmash of messages.

headline: How Healthy Is Hillary Clinton? Doctors Weigh In
abstract: The disclosure that Mrs. Clinton had pneumonia has put candidates’ health under scrutiny. Here is an assessment of the medical history Mrs. Clinton has made public.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The disclosure last week that Hillary Clinton was being treated for pneumonia thrust the health of both of the major parties’ presidential candidates and their running mates to the center of the campaign, and led to the release of more detailed medical histories from the two candidates seeking what is widely regarded as the world’s most demanding job.

headline: The Chaos of the Manhattan Explosion, Captured by Cameras
keywords: ['Chelsea, Manhattan Bombing (2016)', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Videos, some recorded on cellphones and security cameras, show the terror of Saturday’s blast in Manhattan, and the return of calm by the next morning.
lead_paragraph: It was a mild Saturday evening, with throngs of people in parks, on the streets and in restaurants in Manhattan. And then a bomb blast jolted a street in Chelsea with enough force to lift a Dumpster into the air, shattering windows and injuring 29 people. The violence was accentuated by the uncertainty: What had happened, and why, and who had carried it out?

headline: A Neighborhood Is Shaken
abstract: Windows were smashed, glass doors broken and trains stuck. The day after an explosion injured 29, causing mayhem in Chelsea, residents of the Manhattan neighborhood recounted the blast.
lead_paragraph: Windows were smashed, glass doors broken and trains stuck. The day after an explosion injured 29, causing mayhem in Chelsea, residents of the Manhattan neighborhood recounted the blast.

lead_paragraph: With Democratic leaders increasingly worried about a lack of passion for Hillary Clinton among young black voters, President Obama is rolling out a new and more personal campaign message: “It’s about me.”

headline: Chelsea Bomb Rattles Nerves at Selis Manor, a Building for the Blind
abstract: Saturday night’s explosion in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan occurred just outside a building that is home to many residents who are blind or visually impaired.
lead_paragraph: Roselyn Olivares was standing in her kitchen when she heard the explosion. A living room window cracked. Glass shattered in the bedroom. Ms. Olivares, who is blind, called out to her partner, asking her to peer outside their living room window, which overlooks West 23rd Street in Chelsea.

headline: With No Flag, Team Europe’s Players Rally Around Themselves at World Cup of Hockey

lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Its roster and its uniforms are a patchwork. It is the only team at the World Cup of Hockey with no national anthem played before its games.

headline: Housing Bias and the Roots of Segregation
keywords: ['Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination', 'Affordable Housing', 'Poverty', 'Vouchers', 'Segregation and Desegregation', 'Minorities']
abstract: Breaking entrenched patterns of racial separation has been a decades-long challenge for the government. The Obama administration is pursuing a plan that relies on ZIP codes.
lead_paragraph: Should your ZIP code determine your future? Not according to American ideals of social mobility. American realities, however, tell a different story: Where people grow up goes a long way toward shaping how well they will be educated, how stable their families will be, how high their dreams can soar.

headline: Vote as if It Matters
abstract: Will minor parties do major damage?
lead_paragraph: Does it make sense to vote for Gary Johnson, the Libertarian candidate for president? Sure, as long as you believe two things. First, you have to believe that it makes no difference at all whether Hillary Clinton or Donald Trump moves into the White House — because one of them will. Second, you have to believe that America will be better off in the long run if we eliminate environmental regulation, abolish the income tax, do away with public schools, and dismantle Social Security and Medicare — which is what the Libertarian platform calls for.

headline: It’s Not Too Late to Fix Fox News
abstract: The conservative network has been a double-edged sword for Republicans: It boosts candidates but then boxes them in with its narrow views.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in its 20-year history, Fox News is stumbling. Roger Ailes, its founder and guiding force, has been driven out by embarrassing revelations of repeated sexual harassment. The newsroom is sharply divided, some long-term contributors are leaving, and the channel’s parent company has started the expensive process of settling with Mr. Ailes’s accusers.

headline: The TV Cure
abstract: How our anxious, depressed small-screen heroes can help us all feel better.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles — This is how TV used to show mental illness: Men imbued with magical crime-solving or disease-curing powers that hindered their personal lives. Criminals who were “psychotic” and therefore could not be understood, only feared. Girls with eating disorders that appeared in one episode of a sitcom and then were cured after a heart-to-heart. Soap operas that reveled in the split personality — not actually a real disorder — as a plot point.

It is one of the first co-working spaces in New York built from the ground up, rather than having been renovated from another use.

headline: The Age of Distrust

abstract: Democracies are undermined by the growing belief the system is rigged in favor of elites.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — I have a profound respect for the intelligence of the voter. Winston Churchill is often quoted as saying that the best argument against democracy is a five-minute conversation with the average voter, but more important is what he actually said in the House of Commons on Oct. 31, 1944: “At the bottom of all the tributes paid to democracy is the little man, walking into the little booth, with a little pencil, making a little cross on a little bit of paper — no amount of rhetoric or voluminous discussion can possibly palliate the overwhelming importance of that point.”

headline: 1916: Tanks Deployed at the Somme
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Tanks are deployed on the Somme front in September 1916.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The mystery of the new heavy armored automobiles, or ‘‘Tanks,’’ which have played such a splendid part in the latest British drive on the Somme front, is partly elucidated in war despatches from the front, although even now the public is lost in conjecture as to the exact appearance and the construction of the new engine of war. ‘‘The Tank may be roughly described as a dry-land submarine,’’ says ‘‘one who has seen them’’ in an interview with the ‘‘Star.’’ ‘‘The headroom inside the great tortoise is naturally limited, and the crew is selected for its lack of inches.’’ — The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 20, 1916

lead_paragraph: The architect Zaha Hadid, who died unexpectedly in March, was known for her flamboyant and very personal fashion sense. While her architectural practice become famous for large-scale, soaring structures, like the opera house in Guangzhou, China, or the Maxxi museum in Rome, it has embraced fashion, jewelry design and household items with a similar fervor and spirit of innovation. “In terms of form, all our projects — architecture, fashion and furniture — interest me equally,” Ms. Hadid said in a 2015 interview.

headline: Blazes in Southeast Asia May Have Led to Deaths of Over 100,000, Study Says

A vast majority of the cases were in Indonesia, where fires were deliberately set to clear land for agriculture.

headline: After Shimon Peres, Israel Will No Longer Be Young
abstract: Following the former president’s stroke, the country is in danger of losing the last of its founding generation.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — In a little more than a year and a half, Israel will celebrate its 70th birthday. A few weeks after that, Shimon Peres — our country’s former president, prime minister, foreign minister, defense minister, finance minister and so much more — will turn 95. We hope and pray.

headline: In English Lake District, Tradition and Conservation Clash
abstract: The fate of a farm illustrates the struggle to balance farming, environmental renewal and rapid tourism growth in one of the country’s most scenic regions.
lead_paragraph: THRELKELD, England — It was to have been a grand gesture, a deal that would transfer a mountain in the fabled English Lake District from the landed gentry to those who roam its heights, reversing a centuries-old pattern of ownership by the upper-crust few.

headline: Carmen Busquets, Fashion E-Commerce’s Fairy Godmother

lead_paragraph: LONDON — Carmen Busquets, the Venezuelan businesswoman and founding investor in Net-a-Porter who is often referred to as the fairy godmother of fashion e-commerce, sat in her palatial rooftop suite at Claridge’s hotel on a muggy Monday morning discussing the power of reinvention.

lead_paragraph: Soon after the detainee population at Guantánamo Bay dropped to 61 last month, Republicans in the House went into a panic. Representative Jackie Walorski of Indiana figured it was time to halt any and all new transfers.
