headline: Modi Retains Broad Support in India Despite Criticism, Poll Finds
abstract: The Pew Research Center found that 81 percent of Indians had a favorable view of Mr. Modi, despite stalled economic reforms and social tensions.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — More than two years into his tenure, Prime Minister Narendra Modi continues to have broad support in India, despite criticism over stalled economic reforms and religious and caste tensions in the country, according to a new report by the Pew Research Center.

headline: 1941: No More Antipasto for Italians
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Italian restaurants are banned from serving antipasto in September 1941.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The people of Italy were notified today that they will have to tighten their belts more to win the war. Restaurants were informed of five new restrictions, beginning on Monday, and on the same day a prohibition on the sale of confectionery will go into effect. The five-point program forbids the serving of antipasto or double portions of any dishes. No soups made with eggs may be served, which bans the popular ‘‘zuppa pavese,’’ made by poaching an egg or two in meat broth. No butter, olive oil or other fats may be served separately from the dishes of which they may be an element. — New York Herald Tribune, Sept. 20, 1941

headline: Aid Convoy Is Hit in Syria as Cease-Fire Falters and Bombings Resume
abstract: The convoy attack and resumed bombings were the strongest signs yet of the unraveling of an agreement between Russia and the United States aimed at restarting peace talks to end the conflict in Syria.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A humanitarian aid convoy was attacked in Syria on Monday after the Syrian military declared that a seven-day partial cease-fire was over and immediately began intensive bombardments in rebel-held areas of Aleppo, the divided city that has come to symbolize the ravages of the war.

headline: Erdem’s Costume Drama
abstract: Inspired by the discovery of a 17th century gown in a shipwreck, the designer created his own version of history.
lead_paragraph: “That was a weird time and this is a weird time” — thus spake Erdem Moralioglu backstage before his spring 2017 show. The “that” he referred to being the mid-17th century, the midst of the English Civil War between the Cavaliers and the Roundheads, Charles I and Oliver Cromwell, monarchists and parliamentarians, and the “this” being the current time, where you can take your pick of civil wars.

headline: Could It Be Sepsis? C.D.C. Wants More People to Ask
abstract: Sepsis is a leading cause of death, but many people don’t know about it. The Centers for Disease Control wants to make sepsis a household word.
lead_paragraph: The baby seemed fine when Dr. Thomas R. Frieden left for work that July morning in New York more than 20 years ago. But when he returned home several hours later, his son was pale and blazing hot, limp in his wife’s arms.

headline: Higher Heels, Greater Risks?
abstract: No formal scientific studies have linked the wearing of high-heeled shoes with deep-vein thrombosis, but that doesn’t mean they’re good for you.
lead_paragraph: Q. Will someone who wears high-heeled shoes be more likely to suffer deep-vein thrombosis, and perhaps a lethal pulmonary embolism, than a person who wears flats?

headline: News Quiz test for Launch
abstract: A test to see if Balloteer works with Scoop.
lead_paragraph: Have you been following the news? Take our quiz to see what you know and to learn more.

headline: Graffitist in Residence? It’s the Latest Hotel Amenity
abstract: As hotels aim to distinguish themselves in the Airbnb era, many see artist-in-residence programs as a way to add allure.
lead_paragraph: Businesses typically try to keep graffiti off their walls, and remove it when it does sneak on.

headline: Megan Rapinoe’s Protest Leads to Division on and Off the Pitch
abstract: When Rapinoe knelt again Sunday night before a United States friendly against the Netherlands, fans, teammates and TV personalities were quick to weigh in.
lead_paragraph: Hours after the United States Soccer Federation announced that the popular midfielder Megan Rapinoe would not be punished for kneeling during the national anthem at a women’s national team game, she did it again.

headline: Just Cook!
abstract: Recipes for the hardest day of the week.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Daily Report: How Tech Is Sapping the Silicon Valley Food Scene
abstract: Some California cities are fed up with cash-flush tech enterprises and want them to go away. Now that ripple effect has reached the area’s once-bustling restaurant industry.
lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley has disrupted many industries worldwide in the last few decades, but what is less talked about is how much it has also disrupted itself.

headline: France Fears Becoming Too ‘Anglo-Saxon’ in Its Treatment of Minorities
abstract: The French worry that they’re slipping into the American and British model, which they perceive as keeping ethnicities apart, instead of forming a single identity.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — France is frightened about many things these days, terrorism above all. But there is another fear — raised recently by prominent politicians on the right and on the left — of slipping into an acceptance of what is often called an Anglo-Saxon multicultural model, in which ethnic communities live separately, even autonomously.

headline: Bill Murray, Brooklyn Bartender
abstract: As a favor to his son, the restaurant owner Homer Murray, the film star and folk hero serves up shots — and drinks them, too.
lead_paragraph: Many restaurants host an evening for friends and family before a formal opening as a dress rehearsal for the real thing. Such was the case on Sept. 16 at the Brooklyn bistro 21 Greenpoint, formerly known as River Styx. It was reopening, under the same owners, with a new menu and a new look.

headline: Brother Helped to the Finish Before Collapsing in Dramatic Triathlon
abstract: Alistair Brownlee gave up a chance to win and instead aided his dehydrated brother Jonny in a dramatic World Triathlon Series finish.
lead_paragraph: An elite triathlon race in Mexico ended dramatically Sunday with one brother helping another across the finish line.

lead_paragraph: Ahmad Khan Rahami, 28, was taken into custody on Monday, in connection with bombings in Manhattan and New Jersey on Saturday. He was wounded in a gunfight with the police.

headline: Two Cookbooks Offer Fresh Approaches for Rosh Hashana
abstract: “The Gefilte Manifesto” and “Le Marais” go well beyond the usual brisket or roast chicken.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes all it takes is one recipe to justify a new cookbook. The chicken soup in “The Gefilte Manifesto” uses chicken parts that you brown before making the soup, something I have never done. But it works, enhancing depth and color in the broth. The whole point of the book, by the founders of the Gefilteria, the inventive online Jewish food company and caterer, is reworking traditional kosher Ashkenazi cooking and preparing dishes from scratch, with recipes like an inspired kimchi-stuffed cabbage. There’s even a recipe for kosher kimchi. But the so-called apple strudel, while easy and tasty, is a deep-dish pie, not a strudel at all. Another new approach to your Rosh Hashana dinner (the observance starts the evening of Oct. 2) may come from the kosher New York steakhouse Le Marais. Consider recipes for duck cassoulet, coq au vin, slow-roasted lamb shoulder or veal braciole from this new book instead of the usual brisket or roast chicken. The chef, Mark Hennessey, explains various steak cuts and how he adapts French recipes so they conform to the kashrut: “The Gefilte Manifesto: New Recipes for Old World Jewish Foods,” by Jeffrey Yoskowitz and Liz Alpern (Flatiron Books, $35), and “Le Marais: A Rare Steakhouse … Well Done,” by Mark Hennessey and Jose Meirelles (Gefen Publishing, $29.95).

headline: Soup Dumplings With an Expert’s Touch
abstract: A former math professor runs the kitchen at Drunken Dumpling in the East Village.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to xiao long bao, better known as soup dumplings, few practitioners of the craft have the expertise of Qihui Guan, a diminutive, grandmotherly chef who put in plenty of time at Joe’s Shanghai in Chinatown. Now this former math professor is running the tiny kitchen of this new East Village dumpling house for her son, Yuan Lee, with three other cooks. It’s a constant traffic jam as they turn out baskets of handmade dumplings for the restaurant’s 26 seats and fill takeout orders. The soup dumplings include a pillow-size monster served with a straw for sucking the broth. Pot stickers, notable for their delicate wrappers, have fillings like chicken with cashews, beef with cilantro and mixed organic vegetables that rely on local farms for ingredients, making this yet another farm-to-table Chinese restaurant: Drunken Dumpling, 137 First Avenue (Ninth Street), 212-982-8882, drunkendumplingny.com.

headline: Brazil’s New President, Michel Temer, Defends Impeachment of Dilma Rousseff
abstract: Mr. Temer told the United Nations General Assembly that the proceeding showed “absolute respect for the constitutional order,” but he declined to address corruption scandals.
lead_paragraph: In his first speech before the United Nations General Assembly, Brazil’s new president, Michel Temer, defended on Tuesday the contentious impeachment proceedings that ousted his predecessor, Dilma Rousseff, and placed him in power.

headline: Eight Very Nice Looking Tea Pots
abstract: With angular lines and unexpected finishes, there is nothing old-fashioned about these vessels.
lead_paragraph: With angular lines and unexpected finishes, there is nothing old-fashioned about these vessels.

headline: E.U., Accused of Bias Against U.S. Companies, Opens Tax Inquiry Into French Utility
abstract: European officials announced the investigation as the region’s antitrust chief visited the United States for meetings with American officials.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European Union regulators stand accused of unfairly targeting American companies in a series of inquiries. So with the region’s antitrust chief visiting the United States this week, the bloc’s officials said on Monday that they were investigating whether a French company signed a sweetheart tax deal with Luxembourg.

headline: Discussing Kosher Barbecue and Other Jewish-Southern Foods
abstract: A panel on the topic, and some sample dishes, at the Museum of Jewish Heritage.
lead_paragraph: A panel discussion of Jewish foods as they have been adapted to Southern tastes, especially by African-American cooks with dishes like sweet potato rugelach and collards with schmaltz, will be held Sunday at the Museum of Jewish Heritage. The group of food writers and historians, moderated by the author Jayne Cohen, will also talk about Memphis kosher barbecue and Israeli cooking in New Orleans. There will be a sampling of some dishes: “Gefilte Gumbo,” Sunday at 2 p.m., $15 for members, $20 for others, Museum of Jewish Heritage, 36 Battery Place, mjhnyc.org.

headline: Cellphone Alerts Used in New York to Search for Bombing Suspect
keywords: ['Chelsea, Manhattan Bombing (2016)', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Text Messaging', 'Terrorism', 'Wireless Communications', 'Cellular Telephones']
abstract: It is believed to be the first such deployment of the nation’s Wireless Emergency Alerts system: An electronic wanted poster was sent out for Ahmad Khan Rahami, who was wanted in the weekend attack.
lead_paragraph: Across New York City, cellphones blared on Monday morning with the dissonant but familiar tone of an emergency alert, typically used for weather-related advisories or abducted children. But this was different.

headline: François Hollande, France’s President, Urges Action on Climate and Syria
abstract: Addressing the United Nations General Assembly, he called on the gathered countries to put the Paris climate deal into action and to end Syria’s bloody war.
lead_paragraph: President François Hollande of France on Tuesday urged world powers to address the challenges of climate change and to end Syria’s bloody civil war.

headline: After Bombings, Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump Clash Over Terrorism
abstract: Mrs. Clinton stressed her national security credentials and measured her words, and Mr. Trump sounded a note of furious alarm about Saturday’s attacks in New York and New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A suspect in a bombing was still at large Monday morning, his motives and intentions unknown — but Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump were already racing to seize the political upper hand.

headline: The World’s Greatest Detective
abstract: Celebrate the recent birthday of Agatha Christie, the English crime novelist, with a series of three murder mysteries by Po-Shen Loh.
lead_paragraph: This week’s challenge was suggested by Po-Shen Loh, professor of mathematics at Carnegie Mellon University. After a summer of travel around the world speaking about math, Po is back at Carnegie Mellon, working with 200+ students in a unique class focused on creative problem-solving. This week he brings that creative impulse to Numberplay to acknowledge the recent birthday of Agatha Christie, the English crime novelist born on Sept. 15, 1890.

headline: JetBlue Makes Biofuels Deal to Curtail Greenhouse Gases
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Bioenergy and Biofuels', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Global Warming', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The 10-year deal is one of the biggest such agreements yet, as airlines try to reduce their reliance on petroleum-based aviation fuels.
lead_paragraph: JetBlue, seeking to get ahead of looming restrictions on airliners’ greenhouse gas pollution, has agreed to buy more than 330 million gallons of renewable fuel over 10 years, the company said on Monday.

headline: Europe Evaluates Russian Elections
abstract: The parliamentary elections in Russia were beset by legal restrictions on basic rights, said the special coordinator for the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe.
lead_paragraph: The parliamentary elections in Russia were beset by legal restrictions on basic rights, said the special coordinator for the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe.

headline: Bagels Get a Schmear, Salmon and a Stand for Serving
abstract: Eli’s Market offers a dozen mini-bagels in a way that makes holiday entertaining easier.
lead_paragraph: There’s always a place for bagels with smoked salmon and cream cheese during the High Holy Days. Eli Zabar sells stacks of filled mini-bagels on a stand that makes serving them easy: A dozen mini-bagels with smoked salmon and cream cheese, and the stand, $120 from Eli’s Market, 1411 Third Avenue (80th Street), 212-717-8100 extension 9, for pickup or delivery in Manhattan.

headline: Guatemalan Cotton for the Kitchen, and the Benefit of Others
abstract: Napkins, tablecloths are other wares go on sale Tuesday to benefit communities and fight poverty.
lead_paragraph: Creamy natural cotton, with soft blue denim stripes and patterns, has been turned into a line of table and kitchen goods, including place mats, generous napkins, table runners, coasters, towels, potholders, oven mitts and aprons. All go on sale Tuesday online and in October at West Elm and Whole Foods stores. They’re made in Guatemala from recycled denim, and benefit communities there. Also, $1 from the sale of each item will be donated to Whole Foods Market’s Whole Planet Foundation to help alleviate poverty worldwide: The New Denim Project, table linens and kitchen goods, $14 to $39 from westelm.com, starting Tuesday; starting in October at West Elm and Whole Foods stores.

headline: The Changing Clock of Australia’s Little Penguins
abstract: City lights and climate change are among the factors affecting the smallest penguin species. Somehow these popular birds are managing, with a few changes in schedule.
lead_paragraph: ST. KILDA, Australia — On any given night, as the sun sets at the bottom of the world, dozens to hundreds of people gather along the pier at St. Kilda Beach, just off the coast of Melbourne, Australia. Their black silhouettes punctuate the sherbet sky. But they’re not there for the sunset. They’re there for the penguins.

headline: Theresa May Makes Her Debut as the Voice of Britain
abstract: In her first foreign policy speech as prime minister, Mrs. May reassured the United Nations that Britain remained a responsible international player.
lead_paragraph: Theresa May, Britain’s new prime minister, in her first speech before the United Nations General Assembly on Tuesday, vowed that Britain would remain an important and responsible international player despite its vote to leave the European Union.

headline: After a Long Wait, Mah-Ze-Dahr Bakery Gets a Shop
abstract: In the West Village, lush tarts, cookies and cakes from a former investment banker.
lead_paragraph: Umber Ahmad was an investment banker whose specialty was the global expansion of food brands. Tom Colicchio was a client, and they talked food. After Ms. Ahmad treated him to samples of her cakes and cookies she grew up baking with members of her Pakistani family in northern Michigan, he encouraged her to go into the business. Since founding Mah-Ze-Dahr Bakery in 2013, she has been baking in a commercial kitchen with Shelly Barbera, her executive pastry chef and partner, and selling her finely wrought pastries online to consumers as well as to wholesale clients like Jet Blue. And finally, a long year later than expected, she has a spacious West Village shop, opening Thursday, that’s done in pearl gray with a tufted banquette and marble displays for her lush tarts, cookies, cream puffs, bars, cakes, brioche doughnuts and other sweet and savory items. There’s a back room with a communal table that she plans to use for classes, and a big kitchen downstairs. The name of the company is based on the Urdu word mazedar, meaning “the essence”: Mah-Ze-Dahr Bakery, 28 Greenwich Avenue (10th Street), 212-498-9810, mahzedahrbakery.com.

headline: Friends Say Minnesota Attacker Was ‘Normal American Kid’
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Terrorism', 'Shopping Centers and Malls', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: “I can’t see anyone more assimilated than that guy,” a family friend said of the young Somali man who stabbed 10 people in an attack claimed by ISIS.
lead_paragraph: ST. CLOUD, Minn. — The man who the police say stabbed 10 people at a mall here on Saturday seemed like a model of assimilation, not a violent jihadist, people who knew him and his family said. The son of Somali refugees, he lived in the United States most of his life, did well in school, played sports, worked as a security guard and took classes at a local college.

headline: Another Slip for the Libertarian Nominee, Gary Johnson: ‘Nobody Got Hurt’

lead_paragraph: Gary Johnson, the Libertarian Party presidential candidate, who has struggled in recent weeks to recover from a gaffe in which he was unable to identify Aleppo, in war-torn Syria, appeared to fumble once more on Sunday when he said no one had been injured in two violent events in New York City and Minnesota over the weekend.

headline: Review: In ‘Empathitrax,’ the Side Effects of Knowing Too Much
abstract: This Ana Nogueira play centers on a pill that allows a couple to know each other’s deepest feelings. Complications ensue.
lead_paragraph: Wouldn’t it be great to know what people really think about you? Then again, maybe not. Ana Nogueira’s new play, “Empathitrax,” considers a fearsome weapon — a little pill that acts as a sort of truth serum, allowing you to reach out, touch someone and instantly feel what they feel.

abstract: Unlike many companies that signal the existence of an inquiry and its impending settlement, the bank did nothing to condition the market to what was going to come.
lead_paragraph: Wells Fargo is facing a perfect storm of bad publicity and demands for changing its corporate culture after employees opened millions of fake customer accounts to hit their sales targets. The Justice Department has begun a preliminary inquiry into the bank’s conduct while its chief executive, John Stumpf, will be grilled this week by the Senate Banking Committee, including Senator Elizabeth Warren — the scourge of the big banks.

headline: What You Should Watch Now That Fall TV Has Arrived
abstract: From the Watching team, expert TV and movie recommendations for the next few days.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Watching, The New York Times’s what-to-watch guide. We comb through releases big and small to email readers twice a week with our timely recommendations. You can browse previous guides here, and to receive recommendations straight to your inbox, sign up here. Stay tuned for our coming website.

headline: Effortless Hair? It’s Complicated.
abstract: For a certain kind of woman, the most enigmatic expression of effortless style takes place atop the head.
lead_paragraph: Maybe there’s someone in your life with hair like this, hair like a secret: piled or pinned up in a Gordian tangle, or refuting the laws of gravity in a hazy, floating pouf. It’s not a pixie or a mullet or a bowl cut, not a bob or a lob or a Kwan cut or a Klute cut or a Farrah or a Rachel or anything with something so pedestrian as a name. This is a signature look, off-trend, timeless — arranged rather than “done.” Whether it’s a moptop tousled like the artist and writer Leanne Shapton’s or tresses long and pinned back like the artist Taryn Simon’s or the writer Rivka Galchen’s, the effect is romantic, and just-so messy. Songstress Corinne Bailey Rae sometimes wears her curls stacked up on one side. Illustrator-author Juman Malouf architects a half-beehive into a soft crown. The hair seems to be hiding something. It is like a very elegant nest.

headline: Stubborn Grudges Yield Little. Time to Change Your Investing.
abstract: By continuing to invest in the things that hurt you, you only cause yourself more hurt.
lead_paragraph: Over the last few weeks, I have been humbled by the hundreds of emails I received in response to “The Cost of Holding On,” my essay encouraging people to let go of grudges, slights, and yes, underperforming investments.

headline: Abbott’s Sale of Eye Surgery Unit Should Ease Its Merger Woes
abstract: Wrapping up deals with Alere and St. Jude has troubled Abbott Laboratories; a cash infusion will come at a welcome time.
lead_paragraph: Abbott Laboratories may have eased the flow of its merger pipeline. The $62 billion health firm is selling its eye surgery unit to Johnson & Johnson for $4.3 billion. With two looming acquisitions worth over $30 billion — and the purchase of Alere, in particular, not going smoothly — it is a sensible way for Abbott to gain some breathing room.

keywords: ['Speeches and Statements', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'United States International Relations', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: In the last General Assembly address of his presidency, Mr. Obama was focused as much on the American presidential election as on his legacy.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — It was President Obama’s last appearance on the marble dais of the United Nations General Assembly hall, and his farewell speech on Tuesday revealed a man whose eye was fixed as much on the next seven weeks of the American political campaign as on his place in history.

headline: Flaws in Fingerprint Records Allowed Hundreds to Become U.S. Citizens
abstract: The Department of Homeland Security says about 900 people who were to be deported were able to get U.S. citizenship under different names because of gaps in fingerprint databases.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Department of Homeland Security granted citizenship to hundreds of people who had previously been ordered deported or removed under different names because of flaws in keeping fingerprint records, according to a report released Monday.

headline: ‘Shake. Stir. Sip.’ Takes the Math Out of Mixing Cocktails
keywords: ['Cocktails and Mixed Drinks', 'Books and Literature', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES']
abstract: A new collection of recipes calls for equal measures of each ingredient.
lead_paragraph: A funny thing happened on the way to the cocktail-book boom. Or not so funny: It became very hard to make a cocktail at home.

headline: Rome Mayor’s Troubled First 3 Months Raise Doubts on Her Five Star Movement
abstract: Virginia Raggi, elected as the city’s first female mayor in a shining moment for the anti-establishment movement, appears to be floundering.
lead_paragraph: ROME — When Virginia Raggi, Rome’s first female mayor, was elected in June, she represented the anti-establishment Five Star Movement’s highest aspiration — to show Italy how nonprofessional politicians could turn things around.

headline: A Facebook First for New York Philharmonic: Streaming Its 175th Anniversary Opener
abstract: The orchestra’s opening night, which includes Dvorak’s Symphony No. 9, will also kick off an initiative to get the whole city on the same note.
lead_paragraph: The New York Philharmonic will open its 175th anniversary season on Wednesday a little differently than its forebears in 1842: For the first time it will stream the concert on Facebook Live.

headline: Arts Import From New York to Lead ICA London
abstract: Stefan Kalmar, who will become ICA’s director in November, will succeed Gregor Muir, who is joining the Tate.
lead_paragraph: The Institute of Contemporary Arts in London, a leading contemporary arts exhibition space on the Mall, has a new director from New York’s alternative arts scene.

headline: Real Risks in Big Banks’ ‘Merchant Banking’ Activities
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Glass-Steagall Act (1933)']
abstract: Limits on the equity ownership of commercial companies by banks reflects a longstanding principle of separating banking from commerce.
lead_paragraph: In a recent Deal Professor column, Steven Davidoff Solomon gives the Federal Reserve a symbolic “F” for failing to justify its recommendation that Congress repeal existing statutory provisions allowing big Wall Street banks to run in-house private equity funds.

headline: For a U.S. Role in Afghan Peace
abstract: A former senior adviser to the State Department writes that “full support by the United States will be needed for any agreement that may emerge.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Tim Tebow, Wearing No. 15, Participates in First Mets Workout
abstract: Tebow, the former N.F.L. quarterback who signed a minor league deal with the Mets this month, reported to Port St. Lucie, Fla., on Monday.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — A helicopter circled overhead. Below, about 400 fans and more than 70 members of the news media gathered at the Mets’ year-round training complex. They were all there — on the ground, in the air — to watch Tim Tebow play catch.

headline: Me and Prof. Edward Albee
abstract: A meditation on family and legacy from my teacher and friend, Edward Albee.
lead_paragraph: We were sitting in his loft in TriBeCa, Edward Albee and I, talking about families. Edward and his partner, the artist Jonathan Thomas, had never had children (“It never occurred to us, never for a second”). They did raise Irish wolfhounds, though. I once asked Edward how many Irish wolfhounds could fit in a king-size bed with two grown men in it, and without hesitation, he provided the answer: seven.

headline: What We Are Hearing About Clinton and Trump
abstract: The type of information that gets through varies significantly depending on which candidate we’re talking about.
lead_paragraph: This election season, most Americans are paying attention to the presidential candidates on a daily basis. That’s good news, but what Americans report reading and hearing about Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton has to make us wonder about the value of the hyper-prolonged, exhausting modern-day campaign process.

headline: Justin Trudeau’s Message to U.N.: ‘We’re Canada and We’re Here to Help’
abstract: In his first address to the General Assembly, Mr. Trudeau pledged to work with other countries on migrants, the environment and economic disparity.
lead_paragraph: As Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada made his first address to the United Nations General Assembly on Tuesday, he spoke before not only an enthusiastic audience, but one whose agenda largely mirrored his own.

headline: Ahmad Rahami: Fixture in Family’s Business and, Lately, a ‘Completely Different Person’
abstract: In recent years, some friends of Mr. Rahami, the suspect in the Manhattan and New Jersey bombings, noticed a marked change in his personality and religious devotion.
lead_paragraph: He presided behind the counter of a storefront New Jersey fried chicken restaurant, making his home with his family in an apartment above it. To some of his friends, Ahmad Khan Rahami was known as Mad, an abridgment of his name rather than a suggestion of his manner, and they liked that he gave them free food when they were short on money.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Twilight of Democracy?
abstract: A reader asks: What does it say about our political system if someone as bigoted and untrustworthy as Donald Trump is elected? Other readers are invited to reply.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Emmys 2016: Ratings Hit a New Low
abstract: Only 11.3 million viewers watched the show on ABC, fewer than the 11.9 million who watched last year.
lead_paragraph: The Emmys once again hit a new low in viewership Sunday night, with 11.3 million people tuning into the ceremony on ABC, according to Nielsen.

headline: Vladimir Putin Tightens Grip on Russia’s Parliament With Election Rout
abstract: Nearly complete results showed the president’s ruling United Russia party gaining an absolute majority of seats after elections with record low voter turnout.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin leveraged his popularity to assert even greater control over Russia’s already malleable Parliament in national elections, with nearly complete results released on Monday showing the ruling United Russia party gaining an absolute majority of seats.

headline: Fashion Week Photo Diary: Mary Katrantzou, Topshop Unique and Mulberry
abstract: Scenes from the spring/summer 2017 collections that were presented in London on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the spring/summer 2017 collections that were presented in London on Sunday.

headline: Word + Quiz: pore
abstract: The word pore has appeared in 62 New York Times articles in the past year.

headline: Review: ‘This Is Us’ Is Skillful, Shameless Tear-Jerking
abstract: Dan Fogelman’s new NBC dramedy, which centers on four characters with the same birthday, will leave no button on your psychic control panel unmashed.
lead_paragraph: Watching “This Is Us” is like getting beaten up with a pillow soaked in tears.

headline: Review: Michael Weatherly, Recast as a Jury-Puppeteer on ‘Bull’
abstract: Mr. Weatherly left one of TV’s most successful shows, “N.C.I.S.,” for top billing on this new CBS series, but the first episode does not bode well.
lead_paragraph: To take the lead role in “Bull,” a drama that begins Tuesday on CBS, Michael Weatherly left “N.C.I.S.,” which after more than 300 episodes is still among television’s most popular shows. I’m going to go out on a limb here and predict that “Bull” is not going to enjoy that kind of longevity.

headline: “No Ordinary Love: Martino Gamper With Friends”
abstract: For a new group show at Seeds gallery in West London, the designer invited 13 friends to craft one-of-a-kind ceramics.
lead_paragraph: For a new group show at Seeds gallery in West London, the designer invited 13 friends to craft one-of-a-kind ceramics.

headline: When 13 Celebrated Designers (and Friends) Come Together to Make Ceramics
abstract: Martino Gamper recruited 13 creative comrades, including Max Lamb and Bethan Laura Wood, to create objects for a new show in London.
lead_paragraph: With its pristine rows of untouched Victorian villas, Launceston Place is one of the most picturesque corners of the West London district of Kensington. It’s also home to the enterprising art and design upstart Seeds, which is dotted with reminders of the building’s former incarnations as a butcher shop and cheese factory: The intimate gallery and selling space, which opened in January, has meat hooks suspended from the ceiling and ornate ceramic tiling on the walls. “I didn’t want to make it a blank white box,” explains the founder Nathalie Assi, pointing to an antiquated wrought-iron stove where cheese was once made in the redbrick basement kitchen. “We really wanted to preserve its previous life.”

headline: Common Blood-Pressure Drug May Work on Malaria, Too
abstract: Giving malaria victims a common blood-pressure drug along with regular treatment may save help lives, a mouse study suggests.
lead_paragraph: Giving malaria victims a common blood-pressure drug along with regular treatment may save lives by preventing lethal brain hemorrhages, scientists reported on Monday.

headline: Times Insider Photo Challenge: Caption This!
abstract: We asked readers — without any context — to caption a photo that ran in The New York Times. Here’s how they responded.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares insights into how we work at The New York Times. Occasionally we have some fun.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers react to articles in Science Times.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Predict Zika’s Spread? It’s Hard Enough to Count the Cases
abstract: Many cases are likely to go unreported; few cause symptoms, and hundreds of women in Florida are waiting weeks just to get test results.
lead_paragraph: How far will the Zika outbreak spread, and for how long?

headline: Review: Becoming Kazuo Ohno, a Bold Copycat Tribute to a Butoh Master
abstract: The performer Takao Kawaguchi reproduced, gesture for gesture, expression for expression, several Ohno dance-theater performances in a show at Japan Society.
lead_paragraph: As audience members arrived at Japan Society on Friday night, the performer Takao Kawaguchi was already in motion, sliding down banisters, wrestling with a garden hose and otherwise making mischief in the theater lobby. Looking on from one wall was a portrait of his muse: Kazuo Ohno, the great Butoh dancer and a founder of that postwar Japanese dance-theater form, who died in 2010 at 103.

headline: Tim Tebow Takes a Swing at Baseball
abstract: Tebow, the former Heisman Trophy Award winner and N.F.L. quarterback, was in Florida on Monday for his first day of practice for the Mets’ Florida Instructional League team.
lead_paragraph: Tebow, the former Heisman Trophy Award winner and N.F.L. quarterback, was in Florida on Monday for his first day of practice for the Mets’ Florida Instructional League team.

headline: Donald Trump Charity Failed to Heed States’ Rules With Veterans Event
abstract: Some 40 states require registration by charities raising money within their borders. But Mr. Trump’s foundation does not show up in most of those registries.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump boycotted a televised debate in January, instead holding a high-profile charity event for veterans in Iowa that helped raise millions of dollars from donors around the country.

headline: Review: With a Tribute to an Esteemed Organist, Simon Rattle Settles Into New York
abstract: Mr. Rattle, who will be a commanding presence in the city this season, started things off by conducting the St. Thomas Choir and the Orchestra of St. Luke’s.
lead_paragraph: The English conductor Simon Rattle will cut a monumental profile in New York this fall. He opens the Metropolitan Opera’s season with Wagner’s “Tristan und Isolde” (Monday through Oct. 17), leads the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall (Oct. 10), accompanies the tenor Mark Padmore with Ensemble Connect in Hans Zender’s orchestration of Schubert’s “Winterreise” at Zankel Hall (Oct. 16) and conducts the Berlin Philharmonic at Carnegie (Nov. 9 and 10).

headline: Do You Like Your Friends?
abstract: How many of your friends would you call true friends? Do you think the feelings are mutual?
lead_paragraph: Do you actually like your friends?

headline: Hawaiian Crows Join Tool-Users Club
abstract: The animals know how to use tools, and some even manufacture their own.
lead_paragraph: The Hawaiian crow has just been inducted into an exclusive club: animals that know how to use tools.

headline: Shopping for Sneakers
abstract: A look at Buscemi, Concepts NYC and Aglit Italy.
lead_paragraph: A look at Buscemi, Concepts NYC and Aglit Italy.

headline: Review: A Happy Ending in LoftOpera’s ‘Così Fan Tutte,’ With an Edge
abstract: The production ends on a real note: Mozart’s characters learn all there is to know about the people they love, and they reconcile anyway.
lead_paragraph: Cruel love games among the upper crust. Relationships nurtured by shared deceptions. Illusions shattered like cold water tossed in your face. Mozart’s “Così Fan Tutte” is the only opera I know that could do double duty as an Edward Albee play, and LoftOpera’s production of that work on Saturday, the day after Albee’s death, was an unexpectedly proper memorial.

headline: Review: ‘Bathing in Moonlight’ Tests a Priest and Boundaries
abstract: In this Nilo Cruz play, Father Monroe grapples with the intimate feelings he shares with a woman whose family attends his church.
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, N.J. — A Roman Catholic priest faces what might be called a crisis of humanity, rather than a crisis of faith, in “Bathing in Moonlight,” the gauzy new play from Nilo Cruz, which is having its premiere here at the McCarter Theater Center, where Mr. Cruz’s Pulitzer Prize-winning “Anna in the Tropics” was also presented before moving to Broadway.

headline: Memories Distilled by 2 Radically Different Poets
abstract: Two new collections, W.S. Merwin’s elegiac “Garden Time” and Adam Fitzgerald’s pop-inflected “George Washington,” have essential things to say about what we remember and why.
lead_paragraph: W. S. Merwin and Adam Fitzgerald are such dramatically different poets that reading their latest books in tandem can induce a feeling of vertigo. Imagine a playlist that squeezed together the music of Nick Drake and Lady Gaga, or think of a loaf of wild-yeast sourdough bread all rainbow-spangled with Pop Rocks. But both books have essential things to say about the movements of memory and loss — about what our minds try to hold on to, and why.

headline: Sophie Turner, Emilia Clarke and Kerry Washington Party After the Emmys
abstract: With a clutch of golden statues, HBO hosts a lavish party for the winners (and losers).
lead_paragraph: With a clutch of golden statues, HBO hosts a lavish party for the winners (and losers).

headline: Burberry’s Painterly Beauty Look — Inspired by Literature
abstract: The makeup artist Wendy Rowe created “beautiful, statuesque skin,” a nod to Virginia Woolf’s “Orlando,” for the brand’s new collection.
lead_paragraph: Virginia Woolf’s 1928 historical fantasy “Orlando” — which tells the tale of a young Elizabethan nobleman — gave rise to what the makeup artist Wendy Rowe called “beautiful statuesque skin” backstage at Burberry today. The collection was renamed September 2016 (as opposed to spring/summer 2017), because everything, including the makeup used for the look, is shoppable straight after the show. The matte finish of the skin mirrored the many antique statues that filled Burberry’s labyrinth “Maker’s House” venue on the edges of London’s Soho.

headline: Sophie Turner, Emilia Clarke and Kerry Washington Party After the Emmys
abstract: With a clutch of golden statues, HBO hosts lavish party for winners (and losers) after the Emmy Awards.
lead_paragraph: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — If parties reflect the host’s self-esteem, HBO displayed no shortage of confidence.

headline: Deaths, Fraud Allegations and an Inquiry Into a Long Island V.A. Hospital
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Hospitals', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: A series of troubling failings have called into question the care being provided to thousands by the Northport Veterans Affairs Medical Center.
lead_paragraph: Along the winding drive through the 300-acre compound of Long Island’s only veterans’ medical center, banners line the road stating the presumed values of the institution: integrity, commitment, advocacy, respect and excellence.

headline: What Rembrandt Did as a Teenager: 4 of His ‘Sense’ Works Are Reunited
abstract: The Ashmolean Museum in Oxford, England, is displaying this Dutch Master’s early allegorical depictions of sight, hearing, smell and touch together for the first time.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — For the first time, the four paintings still known to exist from Rembrandt’s series depicting the five senses are being displayed together. The works, completed when he was still in his teens, are presented in the exhibition “Sensation: Rembrandt’s First Paintings,” on view at the Ashmolean Museum in Oxford, England, until Nov. 27.

headline: Paris’s New Concept Shop for Men
abstract: Mayaro features made-in-France goods from innovative craftsmen, including one former Hermès saddlemaker, and will soon host small weekly dinners.
lead_paragraph: Four years since the Made in France movement first emerged, the sentiment around preserving homegrown craftsmanship has reached a fever pitch. But until today, no shop has truly limited its offering to a collection of goods that reflects this wave. Mayaro’s abiding mission is precisely that — to showcase the artisans and crafters behind luxury products that demonstrate a distinctly French savoir-faire — and the focus is predominantly on items for men.

headline: The Trump Campaign: ‘Birther’ Lie, Bodyguards and Tax Breaks
abstract: Readers react to Mr. Trump’s reversal on the “birther” issue, his idea of disarming Hillary Clinton’s bodyguards to “see what happens,” and more.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: F.D.A. Approves Muscular Dystrophy Drug That Patients Lobbied For
abstract: The decision went against the recommendation of independent experts, and the agency is requiring an additional trial to confirm effectiveness.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration approved the first drug to treat patients with the most common childhood form of muscular dystrophy, a vivid example of the growing power that patients and their advocates wield over the federal government’s evaluation of drugs.

headline: Bibi Ferreira, Brazil’s Grande Dame of the Stage, Can’t Stop Singing Even at 94
abstract: This week at Symphony Space, Ms. Ferreira will perform her latest one-woman show, “Bibi Times Four,” including salutes to Frank Sinatra and Édith Piaf.
lead_paragraph: Bibi Ferreira speaks in the cultivated, theatrical voice of an English dowager, the result of British schooling as a child. It’s not the sound one would expect to come out of the mouth of an actress, singer and director whom Brazilians have called their greatest living woman of the stage. But in performance, Ms. Ferreira is a chameleon known for her probing, psychologically layered portrayals and the sweeping grandeur of her singing, not to mention her energy. Having worked nonstop since the age of 3, she has earned a rest, but even at 94, the ambition rages on.

headline: Investigating the Blasts in New York and New Jersey
abstract: Readers urge vigilance and caution against tarnishing all Muslims when a small number are guilty of terrorist acts.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Laser Scans Unveil a Network of Ancient Cities in Cambodia
keywords: ['ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)']
abstract: Beyond the famed Angkor Wat temple, a technology known as lidar is allowing archaeologists to map and find the ancient Khmer empire’s intricate urban landscape.
lead_paragraph: SIEM REAP, CAMBODIA — For decades, archaeologists here kept their eyes on the ground as they tramped through thick jungle, rice paddies and buffalo grazing fields, emerald green and soft with mud during the monsoon season.

headline: Marcia Clark Finally Has a Moment to Savor at the Emmys
abstract: “The People v. O.J. Simpson” had its Emmy Awards after-party very close to the courthouse where the trial took place.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — From the stars to the producers to the executives, no one involved with “The People v. O.J. Simpson: American Crime Story” seemed to realize the significance of where they were celebrating their triumphant Emmy night after the awards ceremony Sunday.

headline: The ‘Mad Professor’ Who Makes Sure the Tutus Swirl
abstract: Marc Happel, director of City Ballet’s costume department, is a behind-the-scenes player who receives little credit but is essential to making the show go on.
lead_paragraph: On one side of the fitting room at New York City Ballet’s costume shop, the clothing designer Narciso Rodriguez was studying the neckline of a pink-and-black dress on the ballerina Indiana Woodward.

headline: Colombia’s Leader Says Peace Deal Rests on People’s Ability to Forgive
abstract: President Juan Manuel Santos cited challenges still to come ahead of a referendum on a deal that would end Latin America’s last major guerrilla conflict.
lead_paragraph: A half-century of civil war has deeply injured the psyche of Colombians, the country’s president said on Monday, weeks before a nationwide referendum on a peace deal that would end Latin America’s last major guerrilla conflict.

headline: Burberry: Spring 2017
abstract: Christopher Bailey presents see-now/buy-now collections for both men and women.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Bailey presents see-now/buy-now collections for both men and women.

headline: In Statement to Senate, Wells Fargo Chief Is ‘Deeply Sorry’
abstract: John G. Stumpf, chief of Wells Fargo, is expected to apologize to a Senate panel on Tuesday for sham accounts set up at the bank.
lead_paragraph: The chief executive of Wells Fargo, John G. Stumpf, will say in testimony Tuesday morning that he is “deeply sorry” for selling customers unauthorized bank accounts and credit cards and that he takes “full responsibility” for the unethical activity, according to a copy of the remarks prepared for a Senate Banking Committee hearing.

headline: John Stumpf’s Prepared Testimony to Senate
abstract: In prepared testimony to be delivered before a Senate Committee on Tuesday, John Stumpf, chief executive of Wells Fargo, strikes a decidedly contrite tone on the scandal over fake accounts created by employees at the bank.
lead_paragraph: In prepared testimony to be delivered before a Senate Committee on Tuesday, John Stumpf, chief executive of Wells Fargo, strikes a decidedly contrite tone on the scandal over fake accounts created by employees at the bank.

headline: Kinshasa, Congo, Is Locked Down as Protests Erupt Against Joseph Kabila
abstract: Many Congolese fear that President Joseph Kabila is trying to wiggle out of term limits and hold onto power indefinitely.
lead_paragraph: KINSHASA, Democratic Republic of Congo — Busted glass. Smoldering fires. Torched cars. Empty streets. Hundreds of police officers clumped on the corners, glancing up at the smoke uncurling in the sky.
