headline: Eisenhower Family Drops Objections to Memorial
abstract: Changes have been made to the design, helping to put the stalled project back on track for a 2019 dedication at the base of Capitol Hill, honoring the former president and general.
lead_paragraph: The long-stalled, $150 million memorial to Dwight D. Eisenhower was given new impetus on Monday after Eisenhower family members lifted their objection to the Frank Gehry design, the Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial Commission announced.

headline: Questions for: ‘Ahmad Khan Rahami Is Arrested in Manhattan and New Jersey Bombings’
abstract: How did President Obama, Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump respond to the events?
lead_paragraph: Article: “Ahmad Khan Rahami Is Arrested in Manhattan and New Jersey Bombings”

headline: Mapping Site Shows Shift in Mayor de Blasio’s Fund-Raising
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s fund-raising this year has seen shifts toward smaller contributions from many parts of New York City — a sharp contrast to the way he raised money last year.
lead_paragraph: In politics, geography is money. Political candidates in New York typically trek to Manhattan’s wealthiest neighborhoods to rake in big contributions, often neglecting more far-flung parts of the city.

headline: Three Rolls for a Nickel
abstract: Remembering a neighbor who waited patiently at her Brooklyn window for the bread truck, three times a day.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Self-Driving Cars Gain Powerful Ally: The Government
keywords: ['Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: New federal guidelines make it clear that, while the government will provide oversight, it wants to encourage the development of autonomous vehicles.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal auto safety regulators on Monday made it official: They are betting the nation’s highways will be safer with more cars driven by machines and not people.

headline: Why So Many Business Leaders Are Tiptoeing Around Donald Trump
abstract: LinkedIn’s co-founder has taken to publicly denouncing the candidate, but many executives are offering only whispered critiques, fearing retaliation.
lead_paragraph: In conversations over the last several months with chief executives and other business leaders, the discussion invariably turns to the presidential election. And with few exceptions, at some point, most of the executives say something critical, even derogatory, about Donald Trump — but it is quickly followed by, “I could never say that on the record.”

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Tuesday, September 20, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “It’s like he was a completely different person. He got serious and completely closed off.”

headline: Wells Fargo’s John Stumpf Has His Wall St. Comeuppance
abstract: The head of the bank that came out of the financial crisis relatively unscathed now faces the Senate Banking Committee a over a far-reaching oversight scandal.
lead_paragraph: Long before he ran Wells Fargo, one of the nation’s largest banks, John Stumpf grew up on a dairy and poultry farm, one of 11 children. He started his career as a community banker in Minnesota and married the local banker’s daughter.

headline: One Year Later, a Tip About a Border Crossing Pays Off
abstract: How New York Times reporting may have made the Middle East just a little bit safer.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights from The New York Times. In this piece, Ben Hubbard, a Times Middle East correspondent, and Karam Shoumali, a news assistant, reveal the promising outcome of a story they first reported in May 2015.

headline: Having Won Re-election, a Black Mayor Is Out to Win Every Voter’s Heart
abstract: As Phenix City’s first African-American mayor, Eddie Lowe has sought to mollify white residents fearful of reduced political clout.
lead_paragraph: PHENIX CITY, Ala. — Eddie Lowe, this city’s first-ever black mayor, could feel the white anxiety here.

headline: Dorothy Cann Hamilton, Founder of French Culinary Institute, Dies in Crash at 67
abstract: Ms. Hamilton, a big influence on New York chefs, was driving in Nova Scotia, where she had a home.
lead_paragraph: Dorothy Cann Hamilton, a food aficionado who started a vocational course that evolved into one of the world’s leading culinary schools, died on Friday on Cape Breton Island in Nova Scotia. She was 67.

headline: Mets Reliever Addison Reed Finds Dominance in the Heart of the Plate
abstract: Whether splitting the strike zone or painting the edges of the plate, Reed has relied on his command in posting a 1.76 E.R.A. and 83 strikeouts in 71⅔ innings this season.
lead_paragraph: On June 3, the Mets called on Addison Reed to protect a two-run lead in the eighth inning against the Miami Marlins. He allowed a single to Christian Yelich but struck out three formidable hitters: Martin Prado, Marcell Ozuna and Giancarlo Stanton.

headline: Trial of Ex-Officers Opens With 2 Views of Fatal Albuquerque Shooting
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Homeless Persons']
abstract: A prosecutor said the officers could have backed away from a confrontation with a homeless man, but the defense said they were just doing their jobs.
lead_paragraph: ALBUQUERQUE — Lawyers in the trial of two former police officers charged in the fatal 2014 shooting of a homeless man on Monday painted starkly different views of how the encounter unfolded. A special prosecutor said the officers could have backed away from a confrontation. Defense lawyers said the officers were simply doing their jobs.

headline: After Bombing on Jersey Shore, Residents Try to Make Sense of Chaos
abstract: No one was injured when a bomb went off Saturday morning in the quiet community of Seaside Park, N.J., but an idyll has been interrupted.
lead_paragraph: SEASIDE PARK, N.J. — It was a deserted Monday at the end of the summer season; a determined rain and the news were keeping people inside, watching their flat-screen televisions. Live on Fox and CNN, local and federal authorities were announcing the arrest  of Ahmad Khan Rahami, a 28-year-old of Afghan descent from Elizabeth, N.J., who is suspected of planting bombs in New Jersey and New York.

headline: Obama, at the U.N., Cites Iraq Gains and Urges Steady Nerves at Home
abstract: The president visited the United Nations General Assembly against the backdrop of a stabbing attack in Minnesota and a weekend bombing in New York.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — President Obama came face to face on Monday with the conundrum of his war against the Islamic State: Even as he claimed gains in retaking territory from the militants in Iraq, he had to steady nerves after a stabbing rampage inspired by them in the United States.

headline: Private Coaches Proliferate in Hockey’s Elite Ranks
abstract: Skills consultants are trusted by N.H.L. players, but their strategies may end up being at odds with the wishes of team coaches.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Adam Oates was an unemployed N.H.L. coach in the spring of 2015 when he tuned in to watch the N.B.A. finals.

headline: Video Released in Terence Crutcher’s Killing by Tulsa Police
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: The department opened an investigation into an officer’s shooting of Mr. Crutcher, an unarmed black man who appeared to be raising his hands above his head.
lead_paragraph: The Police Department in Tulsa, Okla., released video on Monday of an encounter during which, the authorities said, a white police officer fatally shot an unarmed black man who could be seen raising his hands above his head.

headline: How Pop Culture Wore Out Leonard Cohen’s ‘Hallelujah’
abstract: Mr. Cohen’s hymnlike 1984 song has become shorthand for Big Emotional Moment everywhere from “Shrek” to the Emmys.
lead_paragraph: Leonard Cohen’s ballad “Hallelujah” has become so inescapable that the songwriter once asked for a break from his own track. “I think it’s a good song, but too many people sing it,” he told The Guardian in 2009, agreeing with a critic for The New York Times who asked for a moratorium on “Hallelujah” in movies.

headline: The Success of the Voter Fraud Myth
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Identification Devices', 'Editorials']
abstract: There is essentially no voter fraud in America, but Republicans have spread the myth so persistently that a lot of people now believe it.
lead_paragraph: How does a lie come to be widely taken as the truth?

headline: The 75-Year-Old Arm Wrestler
abstract: Norm Devio is still pulling ahead of competitors who are twice his size and half his age.
lead_paragraph: WEST BRIDGEWATER, Mass. — In a musty, dungeonlike basement here, more than a dozen sweaty men and women descend the steep steps every Thursday night to grunt and groan while they work on their arm-wrestling techniques.

headline: Who Is Ahmad Khan Rahami?
abstract: Ahmad Khan Rahami, 28, was arrested in connection with explosions in New York and New Jersey over the weekend. Neighbors described him as a friendly car enthusiast and were surprised by the arrest.
lead_paragraph: Ahmad Khan Rahami, 28, was arrested in connection with explosions in New York and New Jersey over the weekend. Neighbors described him as a friendly car enthusiast and were surprised by the arrest.

headline: What’s for Dessert?
abstract: Tracy Bennett sets out a buffet for us.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Tracy Bennett is a fabulous crossword puzzle constructor, but I worry about her cooking skills.

headline: Chelsea Residents Grapple With a Close Call in Their Neighborhood
abstract: The uncertainty that followed on Saturday night has persisted days later, as many questions about the motives and location have remained unanswered.
lead_paragraph: When the barricades were removed, the law enforcement officers had cleared out and the news cameras had mostly dispersed, life on West 27th Street in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan appeared to return to normal. But on Monday morning, nearly 36 hours after an explosive device was discovered across the street from her home, Lisa Bergofin was still shaking, thinking about what could have been.

headline: Noah Syndergaard Stumbles en Route to a Potential Wild-Card Start
abstract: After a powerful display in the first, a rested Syndergaard regressed, giving up five runs before being pulled after three and two-thirds innings.
lead_paragraph: When the Mets debated how to align their starting rotation this week, they weighed short-term goals against long-term planning. It is a careful balance to strike because, although the Mets have a clear path to a playoff berth, none has yet been secured.

headline: News Quiz | Sept. 13-19, 2016
abstract: Have you been following the news? Take our quiz to see what you know and to learn more.
lead_paragraph: Have you been following the news? Take our quiz to see what you know and to learn more.

headline: D. Keith Mano, Novelist Who Tackled Christianity, Sex and More, Dies at 74
abstract: Mr. Mano wrote a stack of books, a National Review column and numerous articles in Playboy, Esquire and other magazines.
lead_paragraph: D. Keith Mano, whose teeming, rollicking novels explored the problems and passions of Christianity in the modern world, to remarkable effect in the capacious, Rabelaisian black comedy “Take Five,” died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 74.

headline: Corrections: September 20, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Tuesday, September 20, 2016.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday: ‘This Is Us’ and ‘Bull’
abstract: Mandy Moore, Milo Ventimiglia and Sterling K. Brown star in “This Is Us,” about people born on the same day. And Michael Weatherly has a leading role post-“NCIS” in “Bull.”
lead_paragraph: Mandy Moore, Milo Ventimiglia and Sterling K. Brown star in “This Is Us,” about a group of interconnected people born on the same day. After leaving “NCIS,” Michael Weatherly has landed a leading role as a trial consultant in “Bull.” And if you haven’t watched the Emmy-winning “The People v. O. J. Simpson: American Crime Story,” now is the time.

headline: Elder Bush Plans to Vote for Hillary Clinton, a Kennedy Says
abstract: Robert F. Kennedy’s eldest daughter, Kathleen Kennedy Townsend, said the 41st president plans to vote Democratic in the presidential election.
lead_paragraph: Kathleen Kennedy Townsend, the eldest child of Robert F. Kennedy, said in a Facebook post on Monday that the elder President George Bush told her that he planned to vote for Hillary Clinton. The former president, however, is not talking.

headline: London Fashion Week, Day 5: Marques’Almeida and NewGen
abstract: There’s just time for a last couple of shows — then it’s up stakes and move on to Milan.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After a busy four days, London Fashion Week comes to a close on Tuesday, with just a few shows on the calendar before the fashion tribe heads to Heathrow for flights to Milan (perhaps making a detour to Bradley Smith, Terminal 5’s first blow dry bar, which officially opened Sept. 15 and promises that you will be on your way, stylishly coiffed, in 15 minutes).

headline: G.M. and Union Avoid Strike by Canadian Workers
abstract: The action focused on two car production lines in Ontario, but it was a battleground for an entire country struggling to revive its manufacturing base.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — General Motors and a union narrowly averted a strike by Canadian workers on Tuesday with a deal that could serve as a model for preserving the country’s dwindling auto jobs.

headline: Regular M.R.I. Is Safe During Pregnancy
abstract: Having an M.R.I. during pregnancy is safe for both fetus and offspring, but the risks may change when a contrast agent is used.
lead_paragraph: Having an M.R.I. during pregnancy presents no danger to the fetus or the offspring, researchers have found, but the risks appear to change when a contrast agent is used.

headline: Burberry Turns the Page
abstract: It may have been the brand’s first shop-now collection for both men and women, but the designer Christopher Bailey didn’t just go for the quick sale.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The first show in the next stage of Burberry’s life as a brand took place on Monday in the former environs of a once-famous bookstore at the top of Charing Cross Road, just past the theater where “Harry Potter and the Cursed Child” was playing to standing-room only crowds.

headline: Bringing @EverydayAfrica to the Printed Page
abstract: The founders of the Everyday Africa Instagram Feed are hoping to publish a book that will educate people on the reality of life in Africa’s many nations.
lead_paragraph: The founders of the Everyday Africa Instagram Feed are hoping to publish a book that will educate people on the reality of life in Africa’s many nations.

headline: How Bad Off Is Oil-Rich Venezuela? It’s Buying U.S. Oil
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Oil accounts for half the government’s revenues, but profits have evaporated amid a drop in global prices, forcing Venezuela to seek help from a nemesis: the United States.
lead_paragraph: EL FURRIAL, Venezuela — One oil rig was idle for weeks because a single piece of equipment was missing. Another was attacked by armed gangs who made off with all they could carry. Many oil workers say they are paid so little that they barely eat and have to keep watch over one another in case they faint while high up on the rigs.

headline: Bringing @EverydayAfrica to the Printed Page
abstract: The founders of the Everyday Africa Instagram Feed are hoping to publish a book that will educate people on the reality of life in Africa’s many nations.
lead_paragraph: When one thinks of Africa — and it is always Africa, never a specific country — what comes to mind are wartime scenes of starving children, kids toting machine guns and diseases like AIDS and Ebola devastating the continent. If you doubt this, check the “Daily Show” segment called “Spot the Africa,” where the former and current hosts Jon Stewart and Trevor Noah discuss the stereotypes that dominate coverage. It seems an insurmountable task to see a more nuanced view of the continent’s many nations.

headline: SUNY’s Wise Move on Admissions
abstract: Doing away with the stigmatizing application question for disciplinary infractions will bring more students into higher education.
lead_paragraph: Colleges that ask about criminal convictions on their applications frighten away untold numbers of students who could succeed academically and who present no risk to campus safety. Fortunately, the trustees of the 64-campus State University of New York did the right thing last week when they voted to remove the felony question from admissions applications. Colleges elsewhere in the country would do well to follow this example.

headline: Dignity and Sadness in the Working Class
keywords: ['Factories and Manufacturing', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Suburbs']
abstract: One man’s journey through postindustrial America.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago I met a guy in Kentucky who’d lived through every trend of deindustrializing America.

headline: Modern Housing With Village Virtues
keywords: ['Cohousing Communities', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Families and Family Life', 'Sociology']
abstract: With cohousing, communities are designed and organized for families to depend on one another.
lead_paragraph: Working families in the United States have many struggles today: expensive child care, not enough time to cook healthy meals, disconnection from nature, a sense of social isolation — what the sociologist Robert Putnam famously called “bowling alone” — and more. Older Americans, a booming population, often end up segregated generationally and in dire need of care and companionship.

headline: Our Immigrants, Our Strength
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Identification Devices', 'Mayors']
abstract: Ignore the xenophobia. Newcomers make New York, Paris and London healthier and more vibrant.
lead_paragraph: World leaders are gathering in New York this week for the United Nations General Assembly, and at the top of their agenda sits a refugee crisis that has reached a level of urgency not seen since World War II. The United Nations Summit for Refugees and Migrants and President Obama’s Leaders’ Summit on Refugees represent a watershed moment that is putting a global spotlight on the need for an effective response to a growing humanitarian crisis.

headline: The Bernie Bump
abstract: He didn’t win the nomination. Can he help get other people elected?
lead_paragraph: NEW PALTZ, N.Y. — This crunchy college town, between the Hudson River and the Catskill Mountains, feels like an ideal place for a Woodstock attendee to retire. Amble down Main Street, and you’ll see a yoga studio, a gluten-free bakery and a clothing store called the Groovy Blueberry. “I’m already against the NEXT war,” a passing bumper sticker reads.

headline: How to Raise Trillions for Green Investments
keywords: ['Sustainable Living', 'Finances', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Governments must create the conditions to encourage private investment in clean technologies and sustainable development.
lead_paragraph: SAVING our planet from the worst effects of climate change won’t be cheap. A new report from the United Nations says that the world will need to mobilize $90 trillion in public and private capital over the next 15 years.

headline: Reversion to the Angry
abstract: Terrorism as the new normal, Hydra-headed conspiracy theories and the tightening race between Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Arthur Brooks: Hi, Gail. Another week slouching toward Gomorrah — I mean, heading toward the election. But at the top of today’s basket of deplorables, before politics, is the sad fact that terrorism is back in the news. This time, it was bombs in New York and New Jersey and a knife attack in Minnesota. Thank God no one was killed by the attackers, but this seems to be becoming the new normal.

headline: The Cost of Corporate-Funded Research
abstract: Does industry's role in science need to be reduced to curb its influence?

headline: A Brand-New Learning Network
abstract: Say goodbye to the blog, our home since 2009 — and say hello to Learning Network 3.0.
lead_paragraph: Good morning!

headline: Once a Voice of Young China, Han Han Stakes Out a Different Path
abstract: After the publication of a new collection of essays, Han Han, at one time China’s most popular blogger, explains why he’s maintaining a lower profile online.
lead_paragraph: Once celebrated as the voice of China’s rebellious youth and the country’s most-read blogger, Han Han, who turns 34 on Friday, has shifted more of his energies in recent years into his career as a racecar driver, filmmaking and family life. Since 2013, he has rarely updated his blog, preferring short messages on his Weibo account, and often addressing personal issues rather than the scathing social and political criticism that made his early reputation. He writes movie scripts, song lyrics and, in 2014, he directed his first movie, the road trip comedy “The Continent.” He is working on two more films, adapted from his own novels.

headline: Did F.D.R. Know He Was Dying? Did Anyone?
abstract: Joseph Lelyveld’s “His Final Battle” explores the challenges of Franklin Roosevelt’s final months in office, including his declining health.
lead_paragraph: HIS FINAL BATTLE The Last Months of Franklin RooseveltBy Joseph LelyveldIllustrated. 399 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $30.

headline: What We Can Learn From Women Who Break the Rules
abstract: In “Trainwreck,” Sady Doyle writes about the women “we love to hate, mock and fear.”
lead_paragraph: TRAINWRECKThe Women We Love to Hate, Mock, and Fear . . . and WhyBy Sady Doyle297 pp. Melville House. $25.99.

headline: A Site to Help Get Wedding Bells Ringing and Ringing and Ringing
abstract: A British entrepreneur saw a business opportunity in matching up married men who want to add wives, and single women who’d be happy sharing a spouse.
lead_paragraph: Add this twist to the panoply of websites that promise to fill the holes in your love life: Sites that are aimed at married men who want to add wives, and single women who’d be happy sharing a spouse.

headline: Donald Trump, the Unsinkable Candidate
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Debates (Political)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'News and News Media', 'Philanthropy', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Muslim Americans']
abstract: Many of Mr. Trump’s remarks would have seriously damaged other candidates, but he has remained popular in spite of accusations of racism and graft.
lead_paragraph: This American presidential election is a dizzying wonder: a torrent of outrages, gaffes and prime-time dramas, where one story blurs into the next, most of it driven by the Republican contender, Donald J. Trump.

headline: Donald Trump Stands by Chris Christie Despite Revelations in Bridge Closing Trial
abstract: In a typical election, having prosecutors declare that a top adviser to a candidate was aware of a plot like the 2013 George Washington Bridge closing would have enormous ramifications.
lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump campaigned in South Carolina in December, in a crowded and tightening Republican primary, he made a pointed declaration about one of his opponents, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey.

headline: Racial Segregation in New York Schools Starts With Pre-K, Report Finds
abstract: In the first year of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s expansion, prekindergarten classrooms tended to be more racially homogeneous than even the city’s public kindergartens.
lead_paragraph: From elementary through high school, New York City children tend to go to school with others similar to themselves, in one of the country’s most racially segregated systems.

headline: 15 Years Into Afghan War, Americans Would Rather Not Talk About It
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Cautious presidential candidates and a weary public are part of a bipartisan silence over the war, which is still costing American lives and hundreds of billions of dollars.
lead_paragraph: The United States will soon mark 15 full years of war in Afghanistan, but you wouldn’t know it from the political discourse.

headline: Resolution of Jacob Wetterling Case Also Closes Chapter for a Reporter
keywords: ['Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Sex Crimes', 'Missing Persons', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: People in St. Joseph, Minn., and a journalist who followed the case, come to grips with the painful ending to a boy’s disappearance in 1989.
lead_paragraph: ST. JOSEPH, Minn. — White ribbons flutter along a grade school’s fence here in memory of Jacob E. Wetterling, whose remains were found this month nearly 27 years after he was abducted on a country road. A fresh vase of flowers sits at the spot on the road, silent but for crickets and the whoosh of wind through rows of corn, where Jacob was grabbed so many years ago. And though it is the middle of the day, at the house where Jacob lived, the porch light still is on, just as it has been over a matter of decades — here and at homes across Minnesota — to guide him home.

headline: Ahmad Khan Rahami, U.S. Elections, Tulsa: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Morning Agenda: Wells Fargo’s Comeuppance, Tiptoeing Around Trump, Self-Driving Cars
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: John Stumpf goes before the Senate Banking Committee on the lender’s unauthorized accounts scandal.
lead_paragraph: Remember the days when a congressional grilling was pretty much a rite of passage for bank chief executives?

headline: At Value-Focused Hotels, the Free Breakfast Gets Bigger
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Local Food']
abstract: Brands like Best Western and Holiday Inn Express are expanding free breakfasts with more buffet offerings that include local products and healthy options.
lead_paragraph: At some affordably priced hotels in the United States, a free breakfast is increasingly a perk of a stay.

headline: When Should Children Take Part in Medical Decisions?
abstract: New guidelines for pediatricians suggest that even a child as young as 7 can express an informed agreement with proposed medical treatment.
lead_paragraph: Pediatricians sometimes find ourselves holding small children down and treating them against their will. When cleaning the wax out of a toddler’s ear, for example, to see if there’s an infection, we don’t ask the child’s opinion.

headline: The Season of the Skulls
keywords: ['Kangaroos', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Science and Technology', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: A family road trip across the belly of Australia brought many wonders. But for an 11-year-old girl, kangaroo skulls offered a great promise of wealth.
lead_paragraph: When I was 11 and my sister 6, my parents pulled us out of our new Australian school for a six-week-long research trip across the belly of the continent. A year earlier, we had moved from the United States to Canberra, where my dad was doing post-doctorate work in geochemistry at the Australian National University, and now we were setting out to explore this vast new country.

headline: New York Today: Bail Is Set for a Suspect
abstract: Tuesday: A manhunt ends, the evolution of scarecrows, and favored food vendors.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 11:38 a.m.

headline: Harvesting Grapes in France, With Champagne as Reward
abstract: Taking part in the timeless tradition of the vendange is a way to tax the body and free the mind, cheaply.
lead_paragraph: As a wine lover with an active imagination, I’d always pictured the French wine harvest as a cross between “Sideways” and “I Love Lucy,” a sun-drenched bacchanal featuring boozy lunches en plein air, rosy-cheeked peasants crushing fruit with their bare feet, and a bit of insouciant grape picking.

headline: Japan’s Negative Interest Rates Explained
abstract: Why the country’s policy makers are reviewing an unconventional part of their effort to shake the Japanese economy out of its doldrums.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan’s central bank is reviewing its economic policies, asking why they have failed to kick-start growth, as intended. Its much-anticipated report is due on Wednesday. One target is negative interest rates — an unconventional tactic adopted in Japan and Europe that turns the usual rules of borrowing and lending upside down.

headline: Trump Campaign Vows to Fund Florida Push, Official Says, but Cash Is in Limbo
abstract: A promised $1.9 million would be used for an “intensive door knocking and phone call program for the last 40 days,” said Susan Wiles, the Florida state director.
lead_paragraph: The campaign of Donald J. Trump, whose grass-roots organizing in Florida is far behind that of conventional presidential nominees, promised $1.9 million for a ground game in the state but has yet to come through with the money, less than five weeks before early voting begins.

headline: Senate Is Set to Vote on Zika and Government Funding
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Zika Virus', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Sticking points remain, but the chamber is expected to vote to advance a bill to finance the overall government and to pay for efforts to combat the virus.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After an unexpected delay, the Senate is scheduled to vote on Tuesday to advance a bill to keep the government’s lights on and to help fund the fight against Zika, while paving the way for Planned Parenthood’s partner in Puerto Rico to have access to some of the roughly $1.1 billion in planned federal money in its efforts against the virus.

headline: U.N. Suspends Convoys to Syria After Attack on Aid Trucks
abstract: A top official at the organization said the airstrike would amount to a war crime if found to have targeted humanitarian workers.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United Nations suspended all aid convoys in Syria on Tuesday, the day after a deadly airstrike on trucks loaded with crucial supplies of food and medicine. The airstrike came after the Syrian military had declared an end to a seven-day partial cease-fire.

headline: Thai Court Finds British Labor Activist Guilty of Defamation
keywords: ['Foreign Workers', 'Minimum Wage', 'Libel and Slander', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Andy Hall was sentenced to three years in prison in connection with his work on a report that accused a Thai company of violating its workers’ rights.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A Thai court on Tuesday found a British labor activist guilty of defamation and computer crimes, a verdict that some experts and rights advocates predicted would harm efforts to protect migrant workers in Southeast Asia.

headline: California Today: Clearing the Air, Without Fossil Fuels
abstract: Tuesday: Cutting out fossil fuels in Los Angeles, the sapping of the Silicon Valley food scene, and San Francisco’s friendly bicycling.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: A National Park’s Plea: Enjoy the Animals; Don’t Act Like One
keywords: ['National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Rocky Mountain National Park has experienced a surge in visitors — and etiquette challenges. The park has asked people not to use the park as a restroom.
lead_paragraph: Does a bear poop in the woods? Of course it does, and so, apparently, do a whole lot of humans.

headline: When to Call a Lie a Lie
abstract: The word has become so freighted in political warfare that its mere appearance on news pages, however accurate, feels partisan. But sometimes it is the right word.
lead_paragraph: Suppose that Donald Trump stops insisting President Obama was born outside the United States, and then saddles Hillary Clinton with starting the rumor in the first place. Is that stretching the truth? An unfounded assertion? An error? A falsehood?

headline: How a Russian Fascist Is Meddling in America’s Election
abstract: The antidemocratic ideas of Ivan Ilyin are guiding the Kremlin’s interference in U.S. presidential politics.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — The president of Russia, Vladimir V. Putin, once described the collapse of the Soviet Union as a “geopolitical catastrophe.” But the political thinker who today has the most influence on Mr. Putin’s Russia is not Vladimir Lenin, the founder of the Communist system, but rather Ivan Ilyin, a prophet of Russian fascism.

headline: 1916: Antiwar Riots in Germany
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Riots anti-World War I occur in Hamburg, Germany, in September 1916.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Despatches from The Hague and Amsterdam announce that grave disorders have again occurred at Chemnitz and Hamburg. The population of Chemnitz, having learned that a large number of the local workingmen had been killed in the Somme, gathered in the streets on Saturday afternoon. The manifestants remained deaf to the orders to disperse and were charged by the cavalry. Revolvers were fired, five Hussars being killed and fourteen wounded. A general fight ensued, and detachments of infantry had to be brought up. Altogether about 40 persons were killed, and 300 who were carrying revolvers were arrested. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Sept. 21, 1916

headline: What Hugo Chávez Tells Us About Donald Trump
abstract: For both figures, TV, performance and reality shows are at the center of their idea of politics and government.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Long before becoming president, when he was a soldier, Hugo Chávez organized cultural activities, most notably beauty pageants. On a stage, microphone in hand, Mr. Chávez served as host, pumping up the audience and announcing the winner. The showman in him already struggled to emerge from under the uniform. Mr. Chávez said he imitated the proceedings he had seen on television in these improvised contests. This is how he learned to play to an audience.

headline: London Fashion Week Partygoers Tear Up Dance Floor (and Tear Down a Wall)
abstract: Love magazine recreated 1989 Berlin, complete with border guards, at Loulou’s, a members-only club in Mayfair.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “Where is your passport? I want your documentation now,” demanded a thickset uniformed soldier with a heavy German accent, sitting on a velvet pouf in a shadowy subterranean nightclub. On the left, a pack of scowling punks in leathers leaned against a graffitied concrete wall. To the right, hordes of beautiful women in glitter and shoulder pads lounged, sipping cups of Champagne.

headline: China Announces Inquiry Into Company Trading With North Korea
abstract: The conglomerate deals in materials that researchers in South Korea and the United States say can be used in the production of nuclear weapons.
lead_paragraph: The police in northeastern China have announced a criminal investigation into a Chinese conglomerate that does extensive trade with North Korea, which researchers in South Korea and the United States say included materials that can be used in the production of nuclear weapons.

headline: Greeks Appeal for Aid After Fire Damages Refugee Camp
keywords: ['Humanitarian Aid', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: The blaze, which started inside the main Moria camp of Lesbos, destroyed 50 homes and dozens of tents, driving about 4,400 migrants into nearby fields, aid workers said.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Thousands of people were left homeless after a fire tore through a refugee camp Monday night on the Aegean island of Lesbos, and the Greek authorities appealed on Tuesday to the European Union for more support in managing the migration crisis.

headline: Eight Beautiful Bucket Bags
abstract: Sturdy silhouettes in soft leather, suede and python.
lead_paragraph: Sturdy silhouettes in soft leather, suede and python.

abstract: The classic men’s style, once a straightforward emblem of corporate power, is now a witty tribute to tailoring.

lead_paragraph: Todd A. Combs, a protégé of the billionaire investor Warren Buffett, has been named a new board member at JPMorgan Chase.

headline: When Kim Gordon Met Michael Smith
abstract: A raw noise-rock pioneer and a fancy interior designer meet somewhere in the middle.

abstract: One organization called the legal process for handling misconduct allegations a “facade” intended to try to stave off a war crimes investigation.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israeli and Palestinian rights organizations have challenged the credibility of Israel’s inquiries into possible military misconduct during the 2014 war in Gaza, with one group describing the internal legal process as a “facade” intended to try to stave off a war crimes investigation by the International Criminal Court.

headline: Chappatte on New York, After the Chelsea Blast
abstract: Trying to return to normal life.
lead_paragraph: Trying to return to normal life.

headline: 5 Cuban Volleyball Players Convicted of Rape in Finland
abstract: The athletes, who were given prison terms, had traveled to the country for a tournament in July.
lead_paragraph: A Finnish court convicted on Tuesday five players from Cuba’s national volleyball team of raping a woman while they were in Finland for a Volleyball World League tournament in July, before the Summer Olympics in Rio de Janeiro, according to news reports.

headline: On Istiklal, Istanbul’s Champs-Élysées, Symbols of a City’s Malaise
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: There seems to be no end to Turkey’s troubles, from a coup attempt to spillover from the war in Syria. All of that is felt these days on Istiklal Avenue.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Istiklal Avenue is Istanbul’s Champs-Élysées, or its Times Square, far from loved by the city’s sophisticates but a place everyone goes to, if only to get to somewhere better.

headline: Airstrikes Hit Aid Trucks in Aleppo as Cease-Fire Ends
abstract: Just after the Syrian military declared the end of a cease-fire in September, aerial attacks destroyed a convoy carrying supplies and aid to neighborhoods of Aleppo, a rescue worker reported.
lead_paragraph: Just after the Syrian military declared the end of a cease-fire in September, aerial attacks destroyed a convoy carrying supplies and aid to neighborhoods of Aleppo, a rescue worker reported.

headline: 1916: Lincoln’s Log Cabin Now Nation’s Property
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: President Wilson inaugurates a memorial for Abraham Lincoln in Hodgensville, Kentucky, in September 1916.
lead_paragraph: HODGENSVILLE, Ky. — Standing before the marble memorial building which now houses the log cabin birthplace of Abraham Lincoln, President Wilson to-day, on behalf of the United States, accepted the Lincoln homestead, purchased by popular subscription through the Lincoln Farm Association. Forty thousand persons assembled for the ceremonies.

headline: Fashioning a Post-‘Brexit’ World
abstract: Collections by Jonathan Anderson, Simone Rocha, Christopher Kane and others reflected the uncertainty about how Britain, and its designers, now move forward.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Uncertainty and insecurity, rents in the social fabric — such atmospheric currents have a creeping, potent influence on the creative mind.

abstract: Marta Marques and Paulo Almeida, who are experimenting with sending ads as personalized emails to fans, show their spring collection.
lead_paragraph: Marta Marques and Paulo Almeida, who are experimenting with sending ads as personalized emails to fans, show their spring collection.

headline: 1966: King Leads Pupils in March
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Martin Luther King leads pupils during a civil rights demonstration in Grenada, Mississippi, in September 1966.
lead_paragraph: GRENADA — The Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. today [Sept. 20] led nearly 200 Negro children to schools where integration last week set off a mob frenzy by whites. Dr. King told a gathering of Negro pupils and parents at the Bellflower Baptist Church before leading them on the demonstration that he could not agree with the black power slogan of ‘‘Burn baby, burn’’ that came out of the 1965 riots in Watts. ‘‘I am forced to disagree with that slogan,’’ Dr. King said. ‘‘I say, ‘Learn, baby, learn’ and ‘Build, baby, build.’’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 21, 1966

headline: Sheldon Adelson Focuses on Congressional Races, Despite Donald Trump’s Pleas
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Campaign Finance', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'Political Action Committees']
abstract: Mr. Adelson, the Las Vegas casino magnate, donated $40 million to Republicans in House and Senate races, with only $5 million going to Mr. Trump’s campaign.
lead_paragraph: The Las Vegas billionaire Sheldon G. Adelson and his wife are giving more than $40 million to groups backing Republican congressional candidates, according to campaign filings and interviews with Republican strategists, disregarding repeated entreaties for support from allies of Donald J. Trump and dealing a major setback to Mr. Trump’s efforts to rally the deepest-pocketed Republican givers.

headline: We Gave Four Good Pollsters the Same Raw Data. They Had Four Different Results.

headline: Approve or Reject: Can You Moderate Five New York Times Comments?

lead_paragraph: We’re partnering with Google to change the way we review the 11,000 comments posted each day to nytimes.com — and this is what we’re up against.

headline: An English Soccer Club Turns Fantasy Sports Into Reality
abstract: United London F.C., which plays in the 12th tier of England’s soccer pyramid, has no manager, instead letting its fans set the team’s lineup each week.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, the sideline of a United London F.C. home game features exactly what one would expect from an amateur-level soccer match on a rented field in England’s capital. Water bottles. A collection of balls. Substitutes warming up. A crowd that United London’s chairman, Mark North, describes as “one man and his dog.”

headline: Erdogan, at United Nations, Defends Turkey’s Move Into Syria
abstract: Turkey’s president said the army had helped bring peace to the Syrian-Turkey border region and urged the General Assembly to find a political solution to the war.
lead_paragraph: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey defended his decision to send ground troops into Syria on Tuesday, saying that his military’s incursion had helped establish “peace, balance and stability in a region taken over by hopelessness.”

headline: U.S. Officials Say Russia Probably Attacked U.N. Humanitarian Convoy
abstract: United Nations officials were dumbfounded by the airstrike, which occurred after the Syrian military declared that a partial cease-fire was over.
lead_paragraph: Russia was probably responsible for the deadly bombing of a United Nations humanitarian aid convoy in Syria, American officials said Tuesday, further shredding what remained of a severely weakened agreement between the United States and Russia aimed at halting the war.

headline: Retracing a Suspect’s Journey: From a Bomb Site to a Quiet Doorway
abstract: Investigators say Ahmad Khan Rahami, accused of the Manhattan and New Jersey bombings, may have gone on foot to the bar where he was captured — a trek winding through homes and an industrial corridor.
lead_paragraph: ELIZABETH, N.J. — A few minutes after 7 o’clock, the evening sky over the train station, which was just the color of Tang, has settled to a deep purple. The rain that fell during the day on Monday has relented, finally. But the air is still sticky. Very, very sticky.

headline: Liev Schreiber, the Reluctant Rake
abstract: Starring in the revival of “Les Liaisons Dangereuses,” Mr. Schreiber doesn’t see himself as a womanizer: It’s “an awkward, uncomfortable mismatch.”
lead_paragraph: On a recent evening, Liev Schreiber wandered through several rooms of 18th-century French portraiture in the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The museum had closed an hour before, allowing Mr. Schreiber private communion with the heaving bosoms and coy smiles, the swathes of silk and froths of lace. He wasn’t impressed. He dismissed a Fragonard painting of a woman reading a love letter as “chocolate box.”

headline: Ousted Critic of Rodrigo Duterte Decries ‘New McCarthyism’ in Philippines
abstract: Leila de Lima said that she was the victim of a campaign to end her inquiry into the president’s possible role in extrajudicial killings.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — For one outspoken critic of President Rodrigo Duterte’s deadly antidrug campaign in the Philippines, the denouement came quickly.

headline: A Very Old Castle, Full of Contemporary Art
abstract: Paintings and sculptures by Gerald Laing populate the 16th-century castle he left New York to buy and restore in the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: Paintings and sculptures by Gerald Laing populate the 16th-century castle he left New York to buy and restore in the 1970s.

headline: Inside a Pop Artist’s Castle — and His Inspiration — in the Scottish Highlands
abstract: In the ’70s, Gerald Laing left the Bowery for a remote, derelict castle he restored with his wife. Today, it’s dotted with the work he made there.
lead_paragraph: Wearying of the social whirl and turmoil of New York life in the late 1960s, the artist Gerald Laing did the unthinkable: He abandoned his successful studio practice in the city for a derelict castle in northeast Scotland. “Staying still and doing the same thing over and over would have been safe,” says the artist’s son Farquhar Ogilvie-Laing, who was born in 1970, while renovation work on the castle was underway. “It was considered absolute professional suicide for my father to move to the north of Scotland from New York when he was doing well. The Highlands in the 1970s were very remote.”

headline: Ahmad Khan Rahami Was Inspired by Bin Laden, Charges Say
abstract: One day after Mr. Rahami, the suspect in the Manhattan and New Jersey bombings, was taken into custody, investigators on Tuesday were learning more about what might have motivated the attack.
lead_paragraph: The man who the authorities say set off powerful bombs in Manhattan and on the Jersey Shore over the weekend planned the attacks for months, conducted a dry run just days before unleashing his assault and took inspiration from “Brother Osama bin Laden” and other international terrorists, according to a criminal complaint filed in federal court on Tuesday.

It’s even more complicated in the case of Günter Seeger, whose confidence is the source of both his success in the kitchen and his occasional capacity for sabotaging himself in the dining room.

As the priest chanted sutras, Yutaka Kai closed his eyes and prayed for his wife, who died last year of complications from a knee replacement.

lead_paragraph: The governors of New York and New Jersey have staked out such starkly different positions on the minimum wage that their discord could result in uneven pay scales for thousands of workers at the airports that serve New York City.

headline: Is Lying Trump’s Strategy?
abstract: Mike Murphy and Paul Begala try to understand how Donald Trump could utter such a demonstrably deceptive statement about his role in the birther movement.
lead_paragraph: The deception was so brazen, so demonstrably disprovable, that it felt like a milestone in campaign history: After relentlessly promoting the lie that Barack Obama was born outside the United States, Donald J. Trump looked into the cameras and declared that he had instead debunked that insidious myth.

headline: Megu and Its Japanese Menu Return to New York
abstract: Other restaurant openings include the John Lamb and Harold’s Meat & Three.
lead_paragraph: MEGU New York once again has a branch of this lavish Japanese-style global restaurant chain, which closed its two Manhattan locations two years ago. The group is now owned by Jon Bakhshi, who also owns Beautique restaurant, a celebrity magnet, on West 58th Street. The sumptuous new Megu has replaced Cherry in the basement of the Dream Downtown hotel. A dramatic mirrored staircase leads to a lounge, a sushi bar and a vast dining room. Some of the décor, like a room decorated with antique kimonos, may be familiar to those who recall the original Megu in TriBeCa. Nothing is modest here, and that also goes for the menu, by the chef Frances Tariga-Weshnak, a native of the Philippines, who is serving spice-crusted duck, edamame lollipops with tahini sauce and Maine lobster with ginger emulsion. There’s an extensive selection of sushi. (Opens Thursday): 355 West 16th Street, 212-885-9400, meguworldwide.com.

Where are they going?

He’s not normal.” Mike Weisser is an N.R.A. lifetime member and the owner of a gun shop in western Massachusetts; here is his response to that column.

All right, not that many moods, then. At his quietest, he appears to be struggling to hold back another choleric eruption.

headline: The Many Sad Fates of Mr. Toledano
abstract: Phillip Toledano was terrified of growing old. So he decided to do it as many times as possible.
lead_paragraph: Afraid of dying? Don’t be. Over a period of three years, I stood by my friend’s side while he became homeless and obese, got disfiguring plastic surgery, had a stroke, became an alcoholic, and got busted for insider trading. Then I watched him die — seven different ways. And, truthfully, it may have been the best thing that’s ever happened to us.

lead_paragraph: On the list of nominees for the Pro Football Hall of Fame released last week, one name stands out: Darren Sharper. Should Sharper be elected, he is unlikely to turn up at the induction ceremony next summer. He is serving 20 years in prison for drugging and raping women.

headline: How Tesla and Apple Could Be Good for Each Other
abstract: Tesla is innovating in self-driving cars, solar energy and fast people-movers, but has a cash-flow problem. Apple is seen as lagging in ideas, but is flush with dormant money.
lead_paragraph: Great partnerships are often forged when each party enjoys a surplus of something the other needs, and there’s little conflict in their ambitions. By that logic, two of Silicon Valley’s best-known firms, Apple and Tesla Motors, really need each other right now. An investment in Tesla by Apple in return for some of the carmaker’s innovation dust might be just the ticket.

headline: Brand to Know: Basics That Champion an Eco-Friendly Agenda
abstract: The designers Bobby Bonaparte and Max Kingery of Olderbrother are making “slow clothing” from natural dyes and unexpected textiles.
lead_paragraph: To prepare their newest goods, the designers Bobby Bonaparte and Max Kingery bought turmeric in bulk — 15 pounds, to be precise; their Los Angeles workshop continuously smelled of simmering curry in the weeks before they headed into production. They were perfecting the marigold hue that features prominently in the spring/summer 2017 collection for their brand, Olderbrother. “Turmeric is a known natural dye, but making it stable, so that a garment can see sunlight or go in the washing machine, takes a while,” Kingery says. He likens the process to cooking (although not all their ingredients are edible), another inexact science. For example, they created a black indigo because Kingery made a mathematical error. “We really stumbled into that one,” he says.
