lead_paragraph: In Rajasthan, India, with the brand’s co-founders, Hopie and Lily Stockman.

headline: Review: ‘Lethal Weapon’ and ‘MacGyver,’ 2 ’80s Reboots, 1 With Chemistry
abstract: Fox’s “Lethal Weapon” TV series may develop some intrigue with Damon Wayans and Clayne Crawford; and CBS’s “MacGyver,” with Lucas Till, is to debut.
lead_paragraph: It’s chemistry versus cleverness in this week’s battle of the 1980s reboots. And the winner is — well, neither of them is mandatory viewing, but if you have to watch one, go with chemistry.

headline: A Trip to India With the Sisters Behind a Cult-Favorite Textile Label
abstract: Twice a year, when the “mangoes are really good,” Lily and Hopie Stockman of Block Shop return to Rajasthan to oversee production of scarves, quilts and rugs.
lead_paragraph: Twice a year for a month at a time, when the tourists melt away in the heat and the “mangoes are really good,” the sisters Lily and Hopie Stockman return to Rajasthan, India, where they have been traveling for the last five years to oversee the production of their textiles line, Block Shop. Beloved for its wood-printed scarves — which are conveyed along the international style route by such retailers as Playmountain in Tokyo and the Hammer Museum shop in Los Angeles — the label recently grew to include topstitched quilts and flat rugs known as dhurries that reflect, as Hopie explains, the subcontinent’s “mashed-up” confluence of overland influences: including “pre-partition” cotton weaving techniques, the dusky desert palette and the visual principles of jaali, stacked geometric forms found in Mughal and Islamic architecture.

headline: John Jasperse Hopes ‘Remains’ Lasts After the Dancing Stops
abstract: This choreographer’s new work, part of the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is his latest effort to leave audiences with feelings that linger.
lead_paragraph: It’s one thing, on an intellectual level, to grasp how ephemeral dance is. Coming to grips with it emotionally is something else. There’s plenty of excitement in fleetingness, but that can also lead to heartbreak. No, dance may not leave any tangible remains, but the choreographer John Jasperse sees another possibility.

headline: Review: In ‘Speechless,’ Balancing Family Needs With Special Needs
abstract: This new ABC comedy, in which a boy’s cerebral palsy prompts a move to a new school district, stands out for its portrayal of a family with normal human flaws.
lead_paragraph: JJ DiMeo (Micah Fowler) is no angel. He’s sarcastic; he’s a little devious; he can be rude. In other words, he’s a teenager. The first time we see him, he flips somebody off, though we have to have it explained to us, because his version of the middle finger is a flat, extended hand.

headline: Shawn Mendes, Pop Idol, Is Not Banking on a Gimmick
abstract: This Canadian star, who originally took off on Vine and is now ensconced as a teenage heartthrob, is releasing his second LP, “Illuminate,” on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Shawn Mendes got his first guitar at the age of 14, a major-label record deal at 15 and his first No. 1 album — last year’s “Handwritten” — at 16, thanks largely to the democratizing power of the internet.

headline: Review: A ‘Hamlet’ That Wants to Get Closer
abstract: The Public Theater’s Mobile Unit took on the challenge of presenting this play in a nontheatrical space in Harlem; now the cast will continue it in a theatrical one.
lead_paragraph: Sitting in the front row at the Public Theater’s touring production of “Hamlet” on Friday evening, the woman had been a little restless. Now, with the title character perched a few feet away, weighing the pros and cons of being and not being, her head was down, as if she were looking at the floor.

headline: Donald Trump Used Over $250,000 From Charity for Business Disputes, Report Says
abstract: The payments from the Donald J. Trump Foundation helped settle unpaid fines at his Mar-a-Lago Club and a lawsuit at a Trump golf course, The Washington Post said.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump, already under scrutiny for how he uses his foundation, directed more than a quarter of a million dollars from the charity to settle legal disputes stemming from his personal businesses, according to a report on Tuesday in The Washington Post.

headline: Bruce Springsteen’s Memoir: Riding Shotgun With the Boss
abstract: This big, loose, rangy and intensely satisfying autobiography is like one of Mr. Springsteen’s shows — ecstatic, exhausting, part séance and part keg party.
lead_paragraph: Long dark highways and thin white lines; fire roads and Interstates; the skeleton frames of burned-out Chevrolets; barefoot girls sitting on the hoods of Dodges; pink Cadillacs; last-chance power drives; men who go out for a ride and never come back.

headline: Syria, U.S. Presidential Race, Tulsa: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: It’s Not Like Hollywood: Why U.S. Airstrikes Go Awry
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Military Aircraft']
abstract: Military officers and experts say that almost all mistaken American strikes over the years have come down to two main reasons: faulty intelligence and battlefield confusion.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If there is a single link between the wars fought by the United States in the Middle East and Afghanistan, it is the long list of errant airstrikes carried out by American warplanes. Weddings, funerals, hospitals and friendly forces have been mistakenly attacked, with each strike prompting fresh outrage.

headline: Federal Charges Against Ahmad Rahami
abstract: In a complaint filed in federal court in Lower Manhattan, Ahmad Khan Rahami was charged with several crimes, including the use of weapons of mass destruction and bombing a place of public use, in the weekend bombings in New York and New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: In a complaint filed in federal court in Lower Manhattan, Ahmad Khan Rahami was charged with several crimes, including the use of weapons of mass destruction and bombing a place of public use, in the weekend bombings in New York and New Jersey.

headline: The 15-Point Federal Checklist for Self-Driving Cars
keywords: ['Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Federal regulators urge automakers to prove that their semiautonomous and driverless vehicles meet specific safety expectations.
lead_paragraph: Federal regulators announced their first safety checklist ever for semiautonomous and driverless cars this week. In the guidelines, the United States Department of Transportation urged automakers and tech companies to prove that their semiautonomous and autonomous vehicles could meet a 15-point list of safety expectations before the autos hit the road.

headline: Public Companies See Gold in California
abstract: California, a state with just 12 percent of the nation’s population, accounts for a fifth of all public companies on the major United States markets.
lead_paragraph: California is the capital of American business. One out of five companies on the New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq stock market hail from that state, according to my recent assessment of relevant data.

headline: Burundi Killings Could Ignite Wider African Crisis, U.N. Report Warns
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Torture', 'International Relations']
abstract: Investigators said the government was responsible for the “vast majority” of abuses and urged international action to contain the country’s violence.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — “I could be your child; I beg you, save me,” the 16-year-old pleaded to police officers in Burundi. Seconds later, an officer put two bullets in his head.

headline: Varvara Lepchenko Is Cleared in Meldonium Inquiry
abstract: Lepchenko, an American ranked 79th, was declared by the International Tennis Federation to bear “no fault or negligence” for her doping rule violation.
lead_paragraph: Months after reports of a doping violation first surfaced, the American tennis player Varvara Lepchenko was declared to bear “no fault or negligence” for her infringement by the International Tennis Federation on Tuesday after having tested positive for meldonium in January at a WTA tournament in Brisbane, Australia.

headline: Allister Sparks, South African Journalist Who Challenged Apartheid, Dies at 83
abstract: As the editor of The Rand Daily Mail, Mr. Sparks exposed a covert government propaganda campaign that led South Africa’s president to resign.
lead_paragraph: Allister Sparks, a prominent South African journalist who challenged apartheid and exposed a covert propaganda campaign by his government, leading to the president’s downfall, died on Monday in Johannesburg. He was 83.

headline: I Work at the Guggenheim
abstract: A poem from the vantage point of a guard at one of New York City’s best-known museums.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: S.E.C. Is Latest to Look Into Exxon Mobil’s Workings
abstract: At issue is how the company values its oil reserves in light of potential climate change regulations, and environmentalists applauded the scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The Securities and Exchange Commission has requested information from Exxon Mobil on the company’s longstanding policy of not writing down the value of oil reserves, as other energy companies have done in the recent past, Exxon Mobil confirmed on Tuesday.

headline: Mets Hope Steven Matz Can Make Imminent Return to Rotation
abstract: Matz, a left-hander who has not pitched in a game since Aug. 14 because of a shoulder injury, is being evaluated for a potential return to the mound by Friday.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — As the improvising Mets continue to piece together a pitching rotation for the final 10 days of the season, their hope of adding Steven Matz to the mix is becoming a little more realistic.

headline: California Voters Face Choice: End Death Penalty, or Speed It Up
abstract: Two ballot proposals, Proposition 62 and Proposition 66, accept that the state’s death penalty, which costs an estimated $150 million a year, is broken.
lead_paragraph: HUNTINGTON BEACH, Calif. — Beth Webb remembers talking with friends at her sister’s Christmas party several years ago, wondering aloud if she would support the death penalty if someone she knew were murdered. Then, in 2011, her sister, Laura Webb Elody, was killed along with seven other people  as she worked at a hair salon in nearby Seal Beach.

headline: Looming Transition Ignites Deadly Clashes in Congo
abstract: At least 25 people from opposing sides of a political divide have been killed in a burst of violence in Kinshasa in the past two days.
lead_paragraph: KINSHASA, Democratic Republic of Congo — The bodies were still smoking Tuesday morning, hours after the sun had risen and the killers had driven off.

headline: Minnesota Knife Attacker Had Only Infrequent, Minor Brushes With Police
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police', 'Terrorism', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Law enforcement officials were still investigating Dahir Adan’s motive in the attack at a St. Cloud mall, even as much remained unknown about him.
lead_paragraph: ST. CLOUD, Minn. — Nearly eight years before Dahir Adan was shot dead by an off-duty police officer and accused of stabbing 10 people at a mall, the police stormed into his family’s apartment here to break up a fight between two of his brothers.

headline: When Life’s a Crazy Mess, Try Going Onstage
abstract: Brian Quijada and Sonya Kelly are performing in plays they have written that illustrate the hoops people go through when they join another culture.
lead_paragraph: Last year, the actor and writer Brian Quijada proposed to his girlfriend. Diamond ring. Bended knee. White sand beach. The whole Instagram-worthy shebang.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Wednesday, September 21, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “Just when we think it cannot get any worse, the bar of depravity sinks lower.”

headline: G.M. Job Shift From Mexico Tests a Trump Premise
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Automobiles', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: Far from a reversal of globalization, a General Motors deal bringing auto jobs back to Canada from Mexico underscores the primacy of markets.
lead_paragraph: In the realm of international trade, it is a truism seemingly as consistent as gravity: Jobs and investment flow from north to south, while manufactured goods travel the other way around. Factories in the United States and Canada shutter as work shifts to Mexico and Central America, where human hands do it more cheaply.

headline: In Backing Autonomous Cars, U.S. Tells Automakers to Figure It Out
keywords: ['Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Roads and Traffic']
abstract: Federal guidelines stress safety but give automakers, one of the country’s most regulated industries, plenty of room to innovate.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration’s approach to hands-free driving is remarkably hands-off.

headline: ‘Lula,’ Brazil’s Ex-President, Will Be Tried on Corruption Charges
abstract: A judge accepted corruption charges against Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, setting the stage for a trial of one of the region’s most influential politicians.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO — The judge overseeing the investigation into the colossal scandal around Brazil’s national oil company accepted corruption charges on Tuesday against the nation’s former president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, setting the stage for a trial of one of Latin America’s most influential political figures.

headline: Man Killed by Tulsa Police Posed No Threat, His Family Says
abstract: The family of Terence Crutcher said his hands were in the air when he was shot by a Tulsa, Okla., police officer last week.
lead_paragraph: The family of Terence Crutcher, an unarmed black man whose fatal confrontation with the Tulsa, Okla., police was recorded on video, said Tuesday that Mr. Crutcher had posed no threat and that his hands were in the air when he was shot.

headline: Behind Mr. Putin’s Easy Victory
abstract: Russia appears to have returned full circle to a pseudo-parliament whose only function is to give a semblance of legitimacy to an authoritarian ruler.
lead_paragraph: In Russia’s parliamentary election on Sunday, Vladimir Putin’s party won three-quarters of the seats outright in the State Duma, the lower house of the Russian Parliament, and the rest indirectly, through parties loyal to him. It apparently did so without many voting irregularities, and despite a sluggish economy, sanctions imposed by the West and unrest in some quarters over the government’s crackdown on civil liberties. What gives?

headline: Rose Pak, a Brash Force for San Francisco’s Chinatown, Dies at 68
abstract: Although she never held office, Ms. Pak helped turn her city’s Asian-American population into a substantial political power through outspoken style.
lead_paragraph: Rose Pak, the brash, combative community organizer in San Francisco who never held political office but who transformed her city’s Asian-American population into a substantial political power, died on Sunday at her home there in Chinatown. She was 68.

headline: Pakistan Grows a Baseball Team From Its Home Soil
abstract: A Pakistani team is in Brooklyn for the World Baseball Classic qualifiers, and in contrast with its competitors, none of its players were born or raised in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Straight off a bone-wearying 24-hour journey, the Pakistani national baseball team went about its inaugural workout in the United States on Tuesday before the Coney Island backdrop of Nathan’s Famous restaurant and the Cyclone roller coaster. The Pakistanis were at MCU Park in Brooklyn for the qualifiers of the World Baseball Classic, which begin Thursday, and they were hoping to find their equilibrium on unfamiliar ground.

headline: Canada Agrees to Talks on Extradition Treaty With China
keywords: ['Extradition', 'Treaties', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'International Relations']
abstract: An announcement nearly coinciding with the deportation of a Canadian missionary held in China on spy charges raises criticism by human rights advocates.
lead_paragraph: Canada has agreed to negotiate a bilateral extradition treaty with China, breaking with a longstanding opposition over concerns about China’s lack of due process and other human rights violations, according to a joint communiqué quietly posted on the website of the Canadian prime minister’s office.

headline: Bombing Case Points to Gaps in Trump’s and Clinton’s Antiterrorism Plans
abstract: There is nothing in the two candidates’ plans that would have had much chance of stopping Ahmad Khan Rahami from planting bombs in New York and New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There is nothing in Donald J. Trump’s or Hillary Clinton’s antiterrorism plans that would have had much chance of stopping the bombings in New York and New Jersey that Ahmad Khan Rahami is accused of carrying out.

headline: Chicago Is Planning to Add Hundreds of Police Officers
abstract: Reeling from the rising toll of gun violence, the city is expected to announce plans to hire perhaps more than 500 new officers.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — This city, reeling from a rising toll of gun violence, may soon hire hundreds of additional police officers — more than 500 of them.

headline: Under New Playoff Format, Liberty Have No Room for Error
abstract: The Liberty had the best record in the East, but as the third seed in a system that eliminates the importance of conferences, they face a single-elimination playoff game.
lead_paragraph: At 21-13, the Liberty finished with the best record in the Eastern Conference for the second straight season, which this year is a feat as valuable as Monopoly money.

headline: In Appeal to Voters, Muslim Brotherhood in Jordan Soft-Pedals Religion
abstract: Forgoing the more radical language of Islamists in other parts of the region, the Brotherhood emphasized bread-and-butter concerns for Tuesday’s election.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — At the headquarters of the Muslim Brotherhood, Ali Abu al-Sukkar’s telephone would not stop ringing Tuesday. It was Election Day, the first time the Islamist organization had taken part after nearly a decade of boycotts, and Mr. Sukkar found himself in demand.

headline: Spring Into Action
abstract: Matthew Sewell gets us going.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — When we met Matthew Sewell not long ago, he was making his New York Times crossword debut with a charming theme about fantasy sports.

headline: Video Caps State’s Case in Trial Over Potsdam Boy’s Killing
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: The video showed the car of the suspect, Oral Nicholas Hillary, in proximity to the boy, 12-year-old Garrett Phillips, minutes before the 2011 attack.
lead_paragraph: CANTON, N.Y. — Banking their hopes on an array of circumstantial evidence, prosecutors in the murder trial of an upstate boy rested their case on Tuesday after showing a video of the suspect’s car in proximity to the boy as he was heading home, minutes before the fatal attack.

headline: Ahmad Khan Rahami’s YouTube Account Listed Jihad Videos, Complaint Says
abstract: Two of the 96 videos listed under his favorites were related to jihad, while the others included romantic ballads and do-it-yourself videos.
lead_paragraph: The man who the police say planted bombs in New York and New Jersey had a YouTube account that listed his favorite videos, two of which related to jihad, according to a criminal complaint filed in Federal District Court in New York on Tuesday.

headline: Donald Trump Jr.’s Skittles Tweet Fits a Pattern
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Fringe Groups and Movements']
abstract: When Mr. Trump, a close adviser to his father, likened Syrian refugees to deadly Skittles, it was not the first time he had been accused of poor taste.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump Jr. — a close political adviser to his father, Donald J. Trump, the Republican nominee for president — posted on Twitter on Monday night an image of a white bowl full of rainbow-colored Skittles. The image came with this text: “If I had a bowl of skittles and I told you just three would kill you. Would you take a handful? That’s our Syrian refugee problem.”

headline: Gary Sanchez’s Homer Gives Yankees a Win They Desperately Need
abstract: Sanchez crushed a breaking ball over the middle of the plate, fueling a comeback against the Rays that ended a five-game skid and gave some life to the Yankees’ faint playoff hopes.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — The Tampa Bay pitching coach Jim Hickey bounced out of the dugout in the seventh inning on Tuesday and hustled to the mound to have a quick word with reliever Brad Boxberger.

headline: After Explosion, Chelsea’s 23rd Street Slowly Comes Back to Life
abstract: As store owners cleaned up damage from Saturday’s bombing and residents tried to return to their daily rhythms, a sense of normalcy remained missing.
lead_paragraph: Steps away from the site where a Dumpster was blasted into the air, the owner of King David Gallery on West 23rd Street took his first look at the shattered glass covering his windowless store in Manhattan on Tuesday morning.

headline: Mets Lose Second Straight to Braves as Jay Bruce’s Struggles Continue
abstract: Bruce, an All-Star with the Reds who has hit .176 in 40 games since joining the Mets late in the season, was pulled for a pinch-hitter during a rally that fell short.
lead_paragraph: In perhaps the biggest moment of Tuesday’s 5-4 loss to the Atlanta Braves, Jay Bruce was not on the field or at the plate for the Mets. Yet most of the questions posed to Manager Terry Collins after the game centered on Bruce, the slumping right fielder who was brought to New York on the Aug. 1 trading deadline to spark a playoff push.

headline: Protests Erupt in Charlotte After Police Kill a Black Man
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Demonstrators faced off with riot officers overnight after the police shot and killed Keith L. Scott while trying to serve an arrest warrant on someone else.
lead_paragraph: About 16 police officers in Charlotte, N.C., were injured when a standoff between law enforcement and demonstrators turned ugly overnight after an officer fatally shot a black man on Tuesday afternoon.

headline: Miami’s Refurbished Stadium Will Be Decked Out in Street Art
abstract: A dozen artists have contributed work to the Hard Rock Stadium, the Dolphins’ newly renovated home.
lead_paragraph: A dozen giant street-art murals, some up to 150 feet wide, by 12 artists, will be on view at the Hard Rock Stadium in Miami Gardens, Fla., when the venue opens to the public for the first regular home game of the Miami Dolphins’ season on Sunday.

headline: Allo’s Tryout: 5 Days With Google’s Annoying Office Intern
abstract: Google’s new chat app promises to stand out from a crowded field by bringing artificial intelligence into conversations. But it turns out to be frustrating and unhelpful.
lead_paragraph: You may now have more messaging apps than you have close friends.

headline: Corrections: September 21, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Wednesday, September 21, 2016.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Milan Fashion Week, Day 1: Will Gucci Be the Blockbuster Show of the Season?
abstract: The Milan shows start with Gucci. Then, expect the usual flamboyance from Fausto Puglisi, Roberto Cavalli and Philipp Plein.
lead_paragraph: Milan Fashion Week has arrived — and with it a whirlwind of shows, presentations, parties and prosecco pit stops. The next seven days will be intense, but we will be on hand to tell you what to look for on the hamster wheel that is the Italian women’s wear show circuit.

headline: I.P.O. for Postal Savings Bank of China Gets Help From Beijing
abstract: The $7.4 billion share offering by the lender, the biggest in two years, shines a light on the way Chinese firms ensure successful deals despite investor doubts.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China’s biggest banks are struggling with a slowing economy, rising bad debts and shrinking profits.

headline: Federal Complaint Traces Ahmad Khan Rahami’s Steps Before Bombings
abstract: The complaint roughly laid out the method the authorities believe that Mr. Rahami used to compile the materials for bombs and then place them in New Jersey and New York.
lead_paragraph: Federal authorities in Manhattan and New Jersey charged Ahmad Khan Rahami with several crimes late Tuesday, including the use of weapons of mass destruction and bombing a place of public use. A federal complaint roughly laid out the method the authorities believe Mr. Rahami used to compile the materials for bombs and then place them in New Jersey and New York.

headline: Curtis Hanson, Director of Wicked Noir ‘L.A. Confidential,’ Dies at 71
abstract: The director’s 1997 adaptation of a tough James Ellroy novel earned him an Academy Award, and introduced American moviegoers to Russell Crowe.
lead_paragraph: Curtis Hanson, the film director whose adaptation of the James Ellroy noir novel “L.A. Confidential” won him an Academy Award, died on Tuesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 71.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday: ‘Speechless’ and ‘Designated Survivor’
abstract: Minnie Driver plays a mother fighting to make things better for her son, who has cerebral palsy, in “Speechless.” And Kiefer Sutherland suddenly finds himself president of the United States in “Designated Survivor.”
lead_paragraph: A mother fights for a better life for her son, who has cerebral palsy, in “Speechless,” starring Minnie Driver and Micah Fowler. Clayne Crawford and Damon Wayans play unlikely perfect partners in “Lethal Weapon.” And Kiefer Sutherland suddenly finds himself president of the United States in “Designated Survivor.”

headline: Word + Quiz: simile
abstract: The word “simile” has appeared in 13 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: The word “simile” has appeared in 13 New York Times articles in the past year, including on Jan. 3 in the book review of James Hamilton’s “A Strange Business”:

headline: Under the Brooklyn Bridge, the New Photoville
abstract: This year is the fifth anniversary of Photoville, one of the country’s premier photo festivals, where an impressive range of images is exhibited inside shipping containers-turned-gallery spaces.
lead_paragraph: This year is the fifth anniversary of Photoville, one of the country’s premier photo festivals, where an impressive range of images is exhibited inside shipping containers-turned-gallery spaces.

headline: Bank of Japan Raises Target Despite Limited Progress
abstract: The increase, which comes despite the central bank failing to meet an earlier target, could add to the debate over the bank’s credibility.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Despite sagging public confidence in its ability to encourage growth, Japan’s central bank on Wednesday raised a key economic target and said it would continue to pump money into the economy until it succeeded.

headline: Under the Brooklyn Bridge, the New Photoville
abstract: This year is the fifth anniversary of Photoville, one of the country’s premier photo festivals, where an impressive range of images is exhibited inside shipping containers-turned-gallery spaces.
lead_paragraph: Photoville, the unorthodox New York photography festival where images are presented in shipping containers, began in 2011 with a simple premise: to bring high-quality photography to the broadest audience possible.

headline: How Companies Like Apple Dodge Taxes and Their Own Investors
keywords: ['Tax Shelters', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: With countries cracking down on elaborate tax schemes, companies need to be more forthright with their own investors.
lead_paragraph: As an investor, one who has been entrusted with helping to safeguard other people’s money over many years, I value the high degree of disclosure required from American public companies. Corporations and the world in which they operate change every day, so investors need to know the risks their money faces.

headline: Two Ex-Spies and Donald Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'International Relations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: An old K.G.B. hand, Vladimir Putin, would be happy to see his admirer elected, but a former C.I.A. director, Robert Gates, sees Trump as unfit.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to assessing the presidential race, I prefer to listen to the spies. They tend to be brutally unsentimental, see through the nonsense and cut to the cold, hard bottom line. And right now, two of the world’s foremost former spymasters are sending uncoded messages about what it will mean for America and the Western alliance if Donald Trump is elected president.

headline: Clinton’s Samantha Bee Problem
abstract: Why an ascendant cultural liberalism is a problem for the Democrats.
lead_paragraph: When the histories of the Trump era are written from exile in Justin Trudeau’s Canada, they will record that it was none other than Jimmy Fallon who brought down the republic.

headline: Mr. Trump’s Stupid Excuses on Taxes
abstract: Mr. Trump claims to be a financial wizard. If that’s true, why doesn’t he prove it by releasing his tax returns?
lead_paragraph: All major party nominees for president going back nearly 40 years have released their tax returns except Donald Trump. That leads to a simple question: What is he hiding?

headline: Hillary Clinton: My Plan for Helping America’s Poor
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Economy', 'Poverty', 'Children and Childhood', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Affordable Housing']
abstract: Good jobs, affordable housing and a focus on communities in need.
lead_paragraph: The true measure of any society is how we take care of our children. With all of our country’s resources, no child should ever have to grow up in poverty. Yet every single night, all across America, kids go to sleep hungry or without a place to call home.

headline: North Carolina Pays a Price for Bigotry
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Law and Legislation', 'Relocation of Business', 'State Legislatures', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Editorials']
abstract: It’s not too late for Gov. Pat McCrory to come to his senses and repeal the discriminatory law that has cost the state jobs and millions of dollars.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Pat McCrory of North Carolina has some nerve. Alarmed by the rising financial fallout from the discriminatory law he and Republican lawmakers hastily passed in March to bar transgender people from using restrooms that match their gender identity, the governor seemed desperate for an off-ramp last week.

headline: Longing for the Male Gaze
abstract: Having cerebral palsy means I don’t get sexually harassed by men. But it’s no fun being invisible.
lead_paragraph: When I was in my early 30s, I practiced yoga at a studio in my neighborhood in Brooklyn. On most days, I walked there with two friends — one who was in her 20s and one about my age — but occasionally we each got to class on our own. There was a construction site across the street as part of the growing onslaught of gentrification in the neighborhood. My friends would often complain about being harassed and catcalled by the construction workers — even more so when they wore their yoga clothes. I passed the site day after day without incident.

headline: Flavors of Home
abstract: What foods remind you of where you come from? Why? What do they make you think of?

headline: Questions for: ‘Japan’s Newest Technology Innovation: Priest Delivery’
abstract: Why do people in Japan want and need a service like this?
lead_paragraph: Article: “Japan’s Newest Technology Innovation: Priest Delivery”

headline: Should Parents Bribe Their Children?
abstract: Are bribes an effective way to get children to do what parents want them to do? Or are bribes counterproductive?
lead_paragraph: Sometimes children don’t naturally do what their parents want them to do. They play video games instead of reading books. They don’t clean up their toys after they’re finished playing. They make too much noise or don’t eat their vegetables. As they get older, they might not do their homework, study for tests or clean their room. What’s a thoughtful parent to do?

headline: Remainders of the Day
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Writing and Writers', 'Libraries and Librarians']
abstract: Not only would no one buy my book, but libraries in various countries were disposing of them because people wouldn’t take them for free.
lead_paragraph: I assumed the humiliations had ended. They began even before my book was published, when network morning shows that regularly had me on now refused my pleas for some airtime to promote it. Once the book came out in 2012, it only got worse. I read at bookstores with audiences smaller than those you might find randomly browsing on any given day, and had an Amazon ranking higher than the number of books I thought existed in the world.

headline: What in the World? 10 Questions on Global Quirks
abstract: If you’ve been a “What in the World” reader, we hope we’ve surprised you, made you smile and maybe even taught you something about another culture. To celebrate the posting of our 100th article, we offer this quiz, where you can test your new knowledge of quirky facts from around the globe.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve been a “What in the World” reader, we hope we’ve surprised you, made you smile and maybe even taught you something about another culture. To celebrate the posting of our 100th article, we offer this quiz, where you can test your new knowledge of quirky facts from around the globe.

headline: Obama Administration Considers Arming Syrian Kurds Against ISIS
keywords: ['Kurds', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The major policy shift could speed up the offensive against the Islamic State but also sharply escalate tensions between Turkey and the United States.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is weighing a military plan to directly arm Syrian Kurdish fighters combating the Islamic State, a major policy shift that could speed up the offensive against the terrorist group but also sharply escalate tensions between Turkey and the United States.

headline: Chemical Accidents in China Have Killed Nearly 200 This Year, Report Finds
keywords: ['Accidents and Safety', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations']
abstract: The Greenpeace report suggested that regulation of the industry remained lax, a year after a disaster in the city of Tianjin prompted calls for more oversight.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 200 people have died in accidents related to the production, storage and transportation of chemicals in China this year, according to a report by Greenpeace released on Wednesday.

headline: How to Be Mindful While Brushing Your Teeth
abstract: Turn a twice-daily chore into a moment of reflection.
lead_paragraph: “Everyone should be brushing their teeth twice a day, bookending the day,” says Dr. Fern White, a dentist in Australia who practices mindful dentistry. “If you do so mindfully, you can also be ‘brushing your brain.’”

headline: The Deflategate Scientists Unlock Their Lab
abstract: The researchers whose work led to Tom Brady’s suspension have never spoken publicly. Now they’re eager to say they were right, no matter what Patriots fans believe.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — It was over 100 degrees in the scrubby sprawl on the city’s northern frontier earlier this month, but inside the 40-foot-long thermal chamber, it was 48 degrees — same as it was for the playoff game on that January night in Foxborough, Mass. The floor was covered in green artificial turf, like a football field.

headline: For the Debaters: What Shall We Do About the Tech Careening Our Way?
keywords: ['Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Trucks and Trucking', 'Debates (Political)', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Autonomous vehicles are symbolic of numerous technology advances, each requiring a close look at benefits and risks, and leadership to navigate them.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a question I’m hoping comes up at Monday’s presidential debate: Secretary Clinton and Mr. Trump, what would you do about self-driving trucks?

headline: Who Hates Free Trade Treaties? Surprisingly, Not Voters
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Support for trade agreements in general, and the pending Pacific pact in particular, stands in notable contrast to the toxicity of trade this election season.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Few issues in this campaign cycle seem as toxic as trade: Both major-party presidential candidates oppose President Obama’s 12-nation Trans-Pacific Partnership, and congressional leaders, having refused all year to vote on the trade accord until after the election, say they will not do so even then — potentially killing the largest regional trade pact in history.

headline: Mistaken for Pregnant? Readers Respond
abstract: Over a thousand people wrote in about their mostly mortifying experiences.
lead_paragraph: Have you ever been mistaken for being pregnant? Or have you wrongly assumed someone else was pregnant?

abstract: American corporate might is increasingly concentrated in just four states, reflecting a shift toward the technology and biotechnology industries.
lead_paragraph: The income gap doesn’t just apply to people — it applies to states, as well.

headline: Vasectomy Not Tied to Prostate Cancer Risk
abstract: A large new study found that having a vasectomy did not increase the risk of prostate cancer, a concern that earlier studies had raised.
lead_paragraph: A large new study has found no connection between vasectomy and prostate cancer.

headline: Hillary Clinton Outlines Vision of More Job Opportunities for People With Disabilities
abstract: In Florida, Mrs. Clinton called for a more “inclusive economy” for a group of Americans who are too often “overlooked and undervalued.”
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Of all the attacks that Hillary Clinton and her fellow Democrats have tried against Donald J. Trump since he captured the Republican presidential nomination, one has stood out for its emotional force and persuasive power: No one, it seems, can abide Mr. Trump’s mockery last year of a reporter’s physical disability.

headline: In Crete, Henry Miller Found His Muse Amid the Ruins
abstract: Crete was the high point of the author’s nine-month romp through Greece, and the inspiration for his exuberant travelogue “The Colossus of Maroussi.”
lead_paragraph: Traveling from Athens to Crete in 1939, Henry Miller, the author of bawdy novels, many of them banned in America, flew in an airplane for the first time — an experience he described in “The Colossus of Maroussi,” his exuberant travelogue of a nine-month journey through Greece.

headline: Dostoyevsky vs. Tolstoy: One Family’s Competitive Vacation in Russia
abstract: Which makes for a better literary trip: Tolstoy’s Moscow or Dostoyevsky’s St. Petersburg? A family investigates.
lead_paragraph: Some readers gravitate toward Tolstoy, others toward Dostoyevsky. It is fun to assign camps to your friends and even more fun to argue in favor of your own inclination. The choice takes on a special resonance in Russia, however, where the arts are a central part of the national identity.

headline: ‘South Park’: After Two Decades, It’s Still by the Seat of Their Pants
abstract: While the show’s staff has grown exponentially, the Comedy Central series remains fundamentally the work of its creators, Trey Parker and Matt Stone.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Every day at South Park Studios is different, but Trey Parker said this particular afternoon, Monday, Sept. 12, was especially memorable.

headline: Air Pollution Is Linked to a Diabetes Marker
abstract: The effect was particularly strong in people who are already considered prediabetic because of abnormally high blood sugar levels.
lead_paragraph: Exposure to air pollution, a new study finds, may increase glucose intolerance, a precursor of diabetes.

headline: Donald Trump Hits Familiar Chords Before First General Election Debate
abstract: With less than a week until the event, Mr. Trump has used his recent rallies to sharpen the nationalist message he has embraced throughout the campaign.
lead_paragraph: With less than a week until the first general election debate, Donald J. Trump has used his recent rallies to sharpen the nationalist message he has embraced throughout the campaign.

headline: Protests in Charlotte
abstract: Police in riot gear responded to protests in Charlotte, N.C., after the shooting death of Keith L. Scott on Tuesday. Kerr Putney, the Charlotte-Mecklenburg police chief, said Mr. Scott had a gun. His family said he was holding a book.
lead_paragraph: Police in riot gear responded to protests in Charlotte, N.C., after the shooting death of Keith L. Scott on Tuesday. Kerr Putney, the Charlotte-Mecklenburg police chief, said Mr. Scott had a gun. His family said he was holding a book.

headline: What Maria Bamford Can’t Travel Without
abstract: Maria Bamford, the star of the Netflix series ‘Lady Dynamite,’ always brings a curling iron when she travels. Why? ‘I like to curl.’
lead_paragraph: Maria Bamford has built a career on turning her experience with bipolar disorder into hilarious, addictive comedy. Her latest project, in which she stars, is “Lady Dynamite,” a Netflix show inspired by her own life. The second season is due in 2017.

headline: Cellphones, Not Banks, May Be Key to Finance in the Developing World
keywords: ['Third World and Developing Countries', 'Microfinance', 'Wireless Communications', 'Cellular Telephones']
abstract: McKinsey finds the vast recent dissemination of mobile technology is poised to substantially increase the economic output of developing nations.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The increasing digitization of finance, and the move away from cash, could add 6 percent to the annual economic output of the world’s developing nations over the next 10 years, according to a new report from the McKinsey consulting firm’s research arm.

headline: How to Counter China’s Global Propaganda Offensive
abstract: Western governments should resist the temptation to emulate China’s methods.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — It has been a difficult year for many Western democracies — and China is rubbing it in. As Donald J. Trump rose in the Republican primaries, the state-run Xinhua news agency gleefully described the United States presidential election as “an entertaining drama that illustrates the malfunction of the self-claimed world standard of democracy.” Another Xinhua article exploited the leak of Democratic Party emails to reassert that “money politics has become an incurable disease of the American electoral system.”

headline: Bank of Japan Tries the Long View
abstract: The central bank’s shift in strategy may bolster bank earnings and improve returns for insurers and pension funds.
lead_paragraph: The Bank of Japan’s latest policy overhaul buys it some time and friends. The world’s most aggressive central bank concluded a review of its huge stimulus program on Thursday by switching focus to targeting longer-term interest rates.

headline: Italian Brands Expect Some ‘Brexit’ Benefits

headline: Five New York Prison Guards Charged in ’13 Beating of Inmate
keywords: ['Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Assaults', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: The corrections officers, who worked in Fishkill, were accused of severely injuring Kevin Moore, tearing out his dreadlocks and lying about the encounter.
lead_paragraph: On the night three years ago when Kevin Moore’s dreadlocks were ripped out and his ribs and facial bones were broken, a group of New York State corrections officers involved in a confrontation with him said that they were the victims, that Mr. Moore, a 56-year-old inmate, had attacked them.

headline: A Baseball Card Contest Pays Off, 6 Decades After the Fact
abstract: A Texas man found a collection of old baseball cards and entered a 1957 contest sponsored by Bazooka that omitted the year of the deadline. The company delivered.
lead_paragraph: Over the years, Darwin Day, a 70-year-old resident of Grand Prairie, Tex., had given away so many baseball cards from his childhood that he didn’t think he had any left. But one that he found recently paid off when he entered a contest from 1957: He won a new baseball glove.

headline: A Cuff That Dazzles — and Changes as It Moves
abstract: This two-and-a-half-inch-wide bracelet, designed by Tiffany & Co., is either ice cool or fiery red, depending on the angle.
lead_paragraph: In the modern annals of fine jewelry, the rubellite beguiles. Unrelated to the ruby despite its rosy tone and similar name, it is a rare form of tourmaline, a semiprecious crystalline stone, often a blackish-blue shade. Rubellite, however, glows scarlet purple, like a luminescent raspberry. The artisans at Tiffany & Co. have crafted this nearly two-and-a-half-inch-wide cuff with 480 of the baguette-cut gems, 60 carats in all. With alternating lines of diamonds in a bold platinum armature, the bracelet looks entirely different — ice cool or fiery red — depending on the angle.

headline: Charges Against 3 Corrections Officers in Fishkill, N.Y.
abstract: George Santiago, Carson Morris and Kathy Scott were charged with conspiracy and fraud in connection with the beating of Kevin Moore on Nov. 12, 2013, at Downstate Correctional Facility in Fishkill, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: George Santiago, Carson Morris and Kathy Scott were charged with conspiracy and fraud in connection with the beating of Kevin Moore on Nov. 12, 2013, at Downstate Correctional Facility in Fishkill, N.Y.

headline: In a Parched Corner of Xinjiang, Ancient Water Tunnels Are Running Dry
abstract: The karez channels that bring water from the mountains to the farmers of Turpan are under threat, a victim of global warming, oil drillers and industrial-scale agriculture.
lead_paragraph: TURPAN, China — It is an improbable journey that begins on the highest peaks of the Tianshan Mountains, where glacial snowmelt descends across one of the world’s most arid landscapes to reach the lush oasis communities of this ancient Silk Road outpost.

headline: 1966: Paris Plans Somali Plebiscite
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: France announces a plebiscite for Somaliland to determine if the colony wants its independence in September 1966.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — France will hold a plebiscite before next July 1 in strife-torn Somaliland to determine whether the colony wants independence, it was announced today. But, Gen. Pierre Billotte, minister for overseas territories, warned that an independence vote would mean that France will wash its hands of its last African colony and cut off most aid to it. Information Minister Yvon Bourges said after a cabinet meeting presided over by President Charles de Gaulle that a bill authorizing the referendum would be introduced in parliament. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 22, 1966

abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Marshal Pétain rebuked the attacks by Frenchmen on German soldiers in September 1941.
lead_paragraph: VICHY — Marshal Henri Pétain, in an appeal fraught with deep emotion, besought the population in occupied France tonight to cease molesting the Nazis. The ultimate sufferers from such action, he warned, would be ‘‘innocent Frenchmen.’’

headline: Russia Denies Any Role in Deadly Convoy Attack in Syria

lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia sought to distance itself on Wednesday from American accusations that it was responsible for the fiery destruction of a humanitarian convoy in Syria, with the foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, also seeking to absolve Syria of responsibility for the attack.

headline: The Blessed, Cursed Life of Bon Iver
abstract: The 35-year-old musician Justin Vernon asks himself many questions over the course of his new record, “22, a Million,” which was influenced by numbers.
lead_paragraph: “What is left when unhungry?,” Justin Vernon sings midway through “22, a Million,” his third album as Bon Iver. It’s one of many questions this 35-year-old songwriter and multi-instrumentalist asks of himself in the course of the album. And it’s answered, in some ways, by the songs themselves on Bon Iver’s most diverse, noisiest, shortest, knottiest and most experimental album so far.

headline: Gucci’s Sequined, Studded, Spangled Saga

headline: Whitestone: Suburban Feel on the Waterfront

lead_paragraph: Although it is bounded by the heavily trafficked Bronx-Whitestone and Throgs Neck Bridges, the Whitestone section of Queens is surprisingly quiet. It’s a sleepy waterfront neighborhood of tree-lined streets, manicured lawns and salty breezes off the East River.

Law enforcement authorities fired tear gas in a desperate bid to restore order.

lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Secretary of State John Kerry on Wednesday called for an immediate grounding of all military aircraft in what he described as “key areas” of Syria — including where aid is delivered — as a last-ditch effort to save an agreement with Russia to reduce violence and ultimately halt a war that shows no sign of slowing.

headline: Flagged Two Times in 2014, Ahmad Rahami Passed Scrutiny

headline: How to Get Gucci’s Dreamlike Beauty Look
abstract: The makeup artist Yadim‘s minimal concept complemented the fantasy of the show.
lead_paragraph: For Gucci’s spring/summer runway show, the designer Alessandro Michele created a rapturous fantasy world, where walls shimmered with mirrored tiles that distorted light in all directions. The collection itself featured full-length gowns in materials like stiff taffeta or pleated, soft lamé, which made it look like the models were floating down the runway.

lead_paragraph: When a company starts up, a retirement plan is usually the last item on the laundry list.

lead_paragraph: Nearly half a century ago, archaeologists found a charred ancient scroll in the ark of a synagogue on the western shore of the Dead Sea.

headline: A 17th-Century Portrait Will Be the Earliest Painting by a Woman at the Tate
abstract: “Portrait of an Unknown Lady” was made between 1650 and 1655 by Joan Carlile, one of the first women known to be a professional painter in England.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A rare portrait by Joan Carlile, one of the first women known to be a professional painter in England, will become the earliest work by a female artist to enter the Tate collection here. The acquisition of “Portrait of an Unknown Lady” (circa 1650-1655), one of only 10 paintings by the artist known to be in existence, was announced at the Tate’s annual news conference on Wednesday, when Alex Farquharson, the director of Tate Britain, affirmed the Tate’s commitment to showing more work by female artists.

headline: After Bombing, a Crucial Test for Mayor de Blasio, and a Calm Response
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio has had his share of stumbles and political sideshows, but he has won praise for his handling of the bombing on Saturday in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio strode along West 23rd Street on Tuesday, amid a phalanx of suits and uniforms, past the buildings and shops with windows shattered by a terrorist’s bomb in Manhattan.

headline: Former ITT Technical Students Can Get Counseling at New Website
abstract: The site was announced by the Department of Education, which wants to expand support to students left in the lurch when the school closed.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of students affected by the abrupt closing of ITT Technical Institute campuses can seek free academic and financial counseling through an online tool introduced this week by two nonprofit groups and the federal government.

headline: The Lies of Big Sugar
abstract: A reader writes that the federal government should sue to recoup its losses.

headline: Nicolás Maduro, Venezuela’s Leader, Opts Not to Deliver U.N. Speech
abstract: Mr. Maduro did not offer a reason, but his government often cancels engagements and meetings without explanation. The foreign minister will fill in.
lead_paragraph: Flush with oil money and political bravado, Hugo Chávez of Venezuela used his United Nations platform a decade ago to call George W. Bush the devil.

headline: Benjamin Netanyahu: Speaking to an Audience Outside the Hall
abstract: Israel’s prime minister is determined to head off any new effort to try to dictate terms of a settlement of the longstanding conflict with the Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: For Benjamin Netanyahu, the brash prime minister of Israel, there are few audiences more skeptical than the world leaders he will face at the United Nations General Assembly on Thursday. But if his international peers are not all that fond of him, it is fair to say the feeling is mutual.

headline: Iran’s President Accuses U.S. of ‘Lack of Compliance’ on Nuclear Deal
abstract: President Hassan Rouhani, speaking at the United Nations, warned that American credibility would suffer if the United States undercut the accord with “illegal actions.”
lead_paragraph: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran accused the United States on Thursday of not complying with the landmark nuclear agreement that took effect in January, and said American credibility would suffer if the accord were not honored.

headline: Mahmoud Abbas: Out to Push Palestinian Cause Back to Top of Agenda
abstract: As president of the Palestinian Authority, he is not a head of state, a point he is likely to make in an appeal to the United Nations to help make him one.
lead_paragraph: When Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Palestinian Authority, attends sessions of the United Nations General Assembly, he enjoys many of the trappings of a head of state. He is invited to address other world leaders. Last year, the Palestinian flag was even raised over the United Nations for the first time.

headline: The Three-Decade Wild Ride of Supermodel Naomi Campbell Isn’t Slowing Down
abstract: Ms. Campbell is still at the top of her game, and an omnipresent figure on the global party circuit.
lead_paragraph: Here she was at Madison Square Garden introducing Rihanna in late August at the Video Music Awards. There she was the next weekend at the Venice Film Festival for the premiere of “Franca: Chaos and Creation,” a documentary about Italian Vogue’s longtime editor, Franca Sozzani.

headline: Jonathan Anderson’s Things
abstract: Jonathan Anderson, the creative director of Loewe and his namesake fashion line, curates his most personal possessions.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Anderson, the creative director of Loewe and his namesake fashion line, curates his most personal possessions.

headline: How to Use Google to Plan Your Trip
abstract: Google Maps revolutionized how you get from point A to point B. Google Trips aims to to do the same for how you vacation.
lead_paragraph: Google Maps revolutionized how you get from point A to point B. Google Trips aims to to do the same for how you vacation.

headline: Marc Jacobs and the Appropriateness of Appropriation
abstract: The cultural “borrowing” that informed Marc Jacobs’ show isn’t new. But the media’s — and consumers’ — reaction to it are decidedly of the moment.
lead_paragraph: Despite the fashion calendar shifting continents and an entire fashion week unfolding in the interim (London’s five-day schedule ended yesterday evening), attention is still being drawn back to New York; namely, to Marc Jacobs. Last Thursday afternoon, Jacobs unveiled his spring/summer 2017 show, to generally positive critical reviews — and a social media brouhaha. The focus was the models’ hair, braided into multicolored dreadlocks inspired by the transgender filmmaker Lana Wachowski and sourced online. The designer was subsequently accused of cultural appropriation, of lifting influences from black culture and showing them on a cast of predominantly white models. Jacobs was rapidly tried and sentenced by a public jury; a fusillade of comments rained down on Instagram and Twitter. Jacobs responded, first by “justifying” his actions and then, after that engendered further criticism, apologizing for the justification, and for any offense caused. The story had already leapt from the fashion pages: Time ran a piece, as did many other general-interest publications.

headline: A Brief History of Designers Appropriating Culture
abstract: Marc Jacobs came under fire on social media last week for the dreadlocked beauty look in his spring/summer show. But he’s hardly the first designer to “borrow” from other cultures.
lead_paragraph: Marc Jacobs came under fire on social media last week for the dreadlocked beauty look in his spring/summer show. But he’s hardly the first designer to “borrow” from other cultures.

headline: Fall’s Voluminous (but Quiet) Silhouettes
abstract: Textured knits, loose shirts and roomy skirts that welcome the calmer side of the season.
lead_paragraph: Textured knits, loose shirts and roomy skirts that welcome the calmer side of the season.

headline: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
abstract: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this article, Diaa Hadid, a correspondent in The Times’s Jerusalem bureau, shares what delighted her (pilgrims eating ice cream, helicopter rides over holy sites) and disturbed her (ever-failing WiFi, official answers to tough questions) about her first trip to Mecca.

headline: David Adjaye on Designing a Museum That Speaks a Different Language
abstract: The designer of the Museum of African American History and Culture discusses the project, its structure, setbacks and symbolism.
lead_paragraph: The first really fine major public building of the century to rise in the nation’s capital, the National Museum of African American History and Culture, opening on Saturday, fills the last prime plot of land along the National Mall in Washington and, with it, a gaping hole in the American story. Its three-tier bronzed aluminum skin, burnished and intricate, rising as if from out of the earth, contrasts with the white marble, concrete and glass palaces telling other chapters in that story.

abstract: The designer holds a theatrics-filled presentation at the Derby Theater in lieu of a traditional runway show.
lead_paragraph: The designer holds a theatrics-filled presentation at the Derby Theater in lieu of a traditional runway show.

headline: Feud Over a Holiday Threatens Fragile Peace in Bosnia
abstract: A move by Bosnian Serbs to defy the country’s constitutional court in a disagreement over a Serbian holiday could be a pretext for an independence declaration, some observers fear.
lead_paragraph: Bosnia and Herzegovina, the poor and chronically divided Balkan country, is facing a new threat of disintegration.

headline: Smaller Stars Will Get a Chance to Shine at Latin Grammys
abstract: With many of Latin music’s major artists on the sidelines, the field will be wide open at the awards show on Nov. 17.
lead_paragraph: It’s a wide-open field at the Latin Grammys this year as many of the award show’s most reliable winners — Juanes, Shakira, Calle 13, Alejandro Sanz, Juan Luis Guerra — are without eligible major albums.

headline: Even Balanchine’s Arithmetic Contains Drama
abstract: The Times’s dance critic adds, multiplies and divides up this choreographer’s “Divertimento No. 15,” at New York City Ballet this season.
lead_paragraph: Five lead women, three lead men: this odd formula — as seen in this photograph — is the nucleus of George Balanchine’s “Divertimento No. 15” (1956), a classic set to Mozart that returns to the New York City Ballet repertory on Thursday after more than five years. Three men to partner five women! This also gives a clue to one aspect of how Balanchine prepared a work: arithmetic as drama.

headline: The Modern Love Podcast: 2016 Emmys Edition
keywords: ['Podcasts', 'ADULTERY', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Marriages', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Miscarriages', 'Emmy Awards']
abstract: Hear the Emmy-winning actors Sarah Paulson, Tony Hale and Sterling K. Brown read three essays on adoption, rejection and miscarriage.
lead_paragraph: In this episode of Modern Love: The Podcast, we’ve reprised readings from three actors who brought home Emmys on Sunday: Sarah Paulson (“The People v. O.J. Simpson: American Crime Story”), Tony Hale (“Veep”) and Sterling K. Brown (“The People v. O.J. Simpson: American Crime Story”).

headline: MoMA Looks at Migrants and Efforts to Help Them
abstract: “Insecurities: Tracing Displacement and Shelter” at the museum considers how designers are responding to the plight of those on the move.
lead_paragraph: Worldwide, some 65 million people have been forced out of places they knew as home by drone attacks and ground warfare, by arson and engineered starvation, and by psychological violence in countless forms. Where can these wanderers rest? That’s the question asked by the exhibition “Insecurities: Tracing Displacement and Shelter” at the Museum of Modern Art (Oct. 1 to Jan. 22).

headline: Review: Melissa Errico Laughs, but Can’t Let Go, at 54 Below
abstract: “Funny, I’m a Woman With Children” at Feinstein’s/54 Below was full of Ms. Errico’s humor, though she was unable to fully let go in some numbers.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Errico is lucky she has a sense of humor: Without it, the frenetic life she described in her amusing show “Funny, I’m a Woman With Children” at Feinstein’s/54 Below on Tuesday evening would be an exhausting roller-coaster ride. But as she put it in a declamatory rendition of the show’s opening number, James Taylor’s “Secret o’ Life,” the key is “enjoying the passage of time.”

headline: A Mysterious Boom Rattles New Yorkers
abstract: The Police Department blamed military F-22s. But Norad said the jets in place for the United Nations General Assembly did not produce a sonic boom.
lead_paragraph: Already on edge days after two bombings in New York and New Jersey, residents were startled on Wednesday afternoon by an earthshaking boom that thundered across several neighborhoods in Queens and on Long Island.

headline: Hoping to Work in China? If You’re a Class C Foreigner, It May Be Tough
abstract: A government plan to sort foreigners into classes of A, B and C — with the last tier for unskilled or service workers — has many wondering how they’ll fit in.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — If you’ve ever wondered what class of person you are, move to China and find out.

abstract: The illustrator Damien Florébert Cuypers draws the models, designers, buyers, bloggers — and looks — at the spring/summer 2017 collections.
lead_paragraph: The illustrator Damien Florébert Cuypers draws the models, designers, buyers, bloggers — and looks — at the spring/summer 2017 collections.

headline: ‘Marvel’s Luke Cage’ Sweeps From Barbershop to Neighborhood Battle
abstract: A superhero tries to lie low in Harlem, but he is soon forced into a showdown in this Netflix show with a hip-hop and R&B soundtrack.
lead_paragraph: I wasn’t alone in not being able to look away from Mike Colter in “Marvel’s Jessica Jones” on Netflix. As Luke Cage, the source of Jessica’s bittersweet longing, Mr. Colter played his superhero brooding and tender, shackled by the memory of his dead wife and enraged when he discovered the truth of her demise. Just because he had unbreakable skin didn’t mean that his heart couldn’t split in two.

headline: Mark Zuckerberg and Priscilla Chan Pledge $3 Billion to Fighting Disease
abstract: The Facebook co-founder and his wife announced an effort to prevent, cure or at least manage all diseases by the end of this century.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, and his wife, Dr. Priscilla Chan, last year said they would give 99 percent of their Facebook shares to charitable causes. Now they are putting a large chunk of that money to work.

headline: See Now, Buy Now: Burberry, Fresh From London Fashion Week, Now at Barneys

lead_paragraph: The French breakdancer Anne Nguyen combines years of dance-battle experience with an avid interest in geometry — fields not as unrelated as they may sound — in her works for par Terre Dance Company, the Paris-based troupe she founded in 2005.

headline: In Cranes’ Shadow, Los Angeles Strains to See a Future With Less Sprawl
keywords: ['Building (Construction)', 'Land Use Policies', 'Referendums', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Affordable Housing']
abstract: An economic resurgence has prompted a debate about height and neighborhood character, and, most of all, what the city should look like a generation from now.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The powerful economic resurgence that has swept Southern California is on display almost everywhere here, visible in the construction cranes towering on the skyline and the gush of applications to build luxury hotels, shopping centers, high-rise condominiums and acres of apartment complexes from Santa Monica to downtown Los Angeles.
