lead_paragraph: These are the 11 plaintiffs — and their words.

headline: The Roots Picnic Expands to New York City, Featuring D’Angelo
abstract: This event from Philadelphia heads to Bryant Park, with guests also including Wu-Tang Clan, Nile Rodgers and David Byrne.
lead_paragraph: It’s about time the Roots Picnic expanded from the band’s hometown, Philadelphia, to New York City, where the Roots have their daily gig on “The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon.”

headline: Maternal Mortality Rate in U.S. Rises, Defying Global Trend, Study Finds
abstract: Global death rates related to pregnancies fell by more than a third from 2000 to 2015. But the United States has gone against the grain, new data show.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One of the biggest worldwide public health triumphs in recent years has been maternal mortality. Global death rates fell by more than a third from 2000 to 2015. The United States, however, is one of the few countries in the world that have gone against the grain, new data show. Its maternal mortality rate has risen despite improvements in health care and an overwhelming global trend in the other direction.

headline: Can Bots Fight Bullying?
abstract: Tech companies are experimenting with tools that use artificial intelligence to spot online harassment.
lead_paragraph: If a teenager gets bullied on social media, it’s usually up to her to report the incident. But one day, an automated tool might spot the harassment, ask her if she needs help, tell a moderator to step in on her behalf or notify her parents.

headline: Review: City Ballet’s Gala Evening of Misses ... and a Lot of Skin
abstract: Our chief dance critic on the company’s “Ballet and Fashion” event, which included four premieres and questionable choices about dancers’ attire.
lead_paragraph: At Tuesday’s “Ballet and Fashion” gala, given by New York City Ballet, the best-dressed people onstage were the four who had choreographed the evening’s world premieres (Annabelle Lopez Ochoa, Lauren Lovette, Justin Peck, Peter Walker), and the solo guest cellist (Sara Sant’Ambrogio) who accompanied one of them. The whole gala, a trivial event, had a back-to-front quality of misplaced priorities and unresolved ideas. None of the ballets were important. Three of them actually suffered from their unflattering designs.

headline: Street Style: London
abstract: Some looks from the streets as fashion month moves on to its next phase.
lead_paragraph: Some looks from the streets as fashion month moves on to its next phase.

headline: The Top 10 Moments from London Fashion Week
abstract: See-Now, Buy-Now at Burberry, Donatella Versace in chainmail — and Crocs on the runway.
lead_paragraph: See-Now, Buy-Now at Burberry, Donatella Versace in chainmail — and Crocs on the runway.

headline: Street Style: London
abstract: Some looks from the streets as fashion month moves on to its next phase.
lead_paragraph: Fashion month has moved on to Milan, but the street style from London lives on in photos.

headline: Review: ‘Notorious’ Offers Nice Cheekbones, but Not Much Else
abstract: This ABC drama about a cable-news producer and a celebrity lawyer starts Thursday. It doesn’t have the zing of Shonda Rhimes’s shows on the same night.
lead_paragraph: “Notorious” is technically a television drama about the symbiotic relationship between a cable-news producer and a celebrity lawyer. But it’s really a show about cheekbones. When Piper Perabo and Daniel Sunjata face off onscreen, you may duck involuntarily, afraid of being cut by a dangerously sharp zygomatic arch.

headline: Review: ‘Pitch,’ a Gender Changeup, but With Clichés Intact
abstract: Kylie Bunbury stars in this baseball drama as a female pitcher who gets called up to the major leagues. It starts on Fox on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: By default, the new Fox series “Pitch” is not your usual baseball drama. Beyond “A League of Their Own” and “The Bad News Bears,” there aren’t a lot of stories featuring women or girls actually playing the game, let alone a woman who gets called up to the major leagues.

headline: Arson at Belgian Forensic Lab May Set Back Terrorism Cases
abstract: A fire that destroyed evidence at the country’s main forensic lab has shaken the criminal justice system and raised concerns about security at sites like nuclear plants.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The whole operation took less than 10 minutes. Three people drove a van up to Belgium’s main forensic storehouse at 2 a.m., cut through a perimeter fence, smashed the ground-floor windows, and placed bottles of accelerant inside.

headline: Review: ‘Easy’ Stars the Young and the Muddled, Connecting in Chicago
abstract: “Easy,” available Thursday on Netflix, consists of eight half-hour episodes that are free-standing stories, a few of them very loosely connected.
lead_paragraph: Among the axioms of the television renaissance is that the medium is becoming more cinematic, with single-story seasons that are essentially six- or 10-hour films. But one of the most movielike new shows of the fall doesn’t fit that description.

headline: Charlotte, U.S. Presidential Race, Syria: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Review: A Rough Cut of ‘The Thief and the Cobbler’ Makes It to MoMA
abstract: A dream project by the animator Richard Williams, this film, still in an incomplete state, screens through Tuesday at the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: “The Thief and the Cobbler” is to animated movies what “The Magnificent Ambersons” is to live-action ones: a staggering masterpiece that can never be seen in its ideal form. “Ambersons,” directed by Orson Welles, was completed but then mutilated by its studio, its original version lost; “Cobbler,” a dream project the animator Richard Williams had been working on since the 1960s, was wrested from him by financiers in 1993, incomplete by about 15 minutes.

headline: Forget Twitter. I’d Rather Binge Theater.
abstract: Our critic Charles Isherwood prizes epic theater. Here’s his take on two inspired long-form works coming to an end in New York at roughly the same time.
lead_paragraph: It’s often said that we live in an era that prizes speed and brevity above all else. There’s long been fast food, but now there’s fast fashion, too. Why take the time to phone someone when an email will take less of your time? Why send an email when a text message would be quicker?

headline: Review: In ‘Hero of the Empire,’ a Young Churchill Earns His Spurs
abstract: Candice Millard’s account of Winston Churchill’s exploits during the Boer War in 1899 vividly recounts an entitled youth who wins headlines for his brashness and bravery.
lead_paragraph: Candice Millard’s third book, “Hero of the Empire: The Boer War, a Daring Escape and the Making of Winston Churchill,” would make a fine movie, though Richard Attenborough did, in a sense, get there first. In 1972, he made “Young Winston,” drawn from Churchill’s own account of his early life, and it includes the same material Ms. Millard recounts so thrillingly: the future prime minister’s brash heroics in the South African Republic in 1899, which culminated in a prison break and nine days on the lam.

headline: Review: It’s a Wild, but Peaceful, World for the Former Cat Stevens
abstract: The singer, who is now named Yusaf Islam, performed in his show, “A Cat’s Attic,” at the Beacon Theater.
lead_paragraph: Nostalgia, invocations of peace and love, and diplomatic positioning were all part of “A Cat’s Attic,” a gentle retrospective concert by Yusuf, the former Cat Stevens. Two shows at the Beacon Theater were his first full New York concerts since 1976, the year before he converted to Islam, changed his full name to Yusuf Islam and spent nearly three decades away from secular music.

headline: Anthem and Cigna Accuse Each Other of Breaching Merger Deal
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The federal government argued that the fraught relationship between the companies ran counter to their defense in the case.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department, which is suing Anthem and Cigna to block their $48 billion deal, revealed on Wednesday in court documents that the two health insurers have been accusing each other of breaching their merger agreement.

headline: Review: Hamilton Leithauser and Rostam Evoke Dreams and Ghosts
abstract: On the moody “I Had a Dream That You Were Mine,” Mr. Leithauser and Rostam shamble through styles and approaches without fretting over how all the pieces will fit.
lead_paragraph: Hamilton Leithauser has one of the most tactile voices in rock: a coarse yet viscous instrument, like wet concrete. So it’s striking that he keeps returning to the intangible, the realm of phantasm and reverie, on “I Had a Dream That You Were Mine,” his persuasively moody new collaboration with the producer and multi-instrumentalist known as Rostam.

headline: Avery Amereau Is a Rarity in Music: A Contralto
abstract: This singer, 25, a rising star in a narrow field, will sing at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday and make her Metropolitan Opera debut in November.
lead_paragraph: Contraltos, the female singers with the lowest vocal range, have always been scarce and seem especially rare today. The days of Kathleen Ferrier and Marian Anderson are long past. Edith Wiens, a stellar soprano and a renowned teacher, calls the contralto voice — or, informally, alto — a freak of nature, a product of “that inch in the throat.”

headline: Suzanne Farrell Ballet Plans to Close After 2017-18 Season
abstract: The company was led by Ms. Farrell, an important muse of the choreographer George Balanchine when she danced for him at New York City Ballet.
lead_paragraph: The Suzanne Farrell Ballet, a company known for keeping the legacy and choreography of George Balanchine alive at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, plans to close after the 2017-18 season, officials said Wednesday.

headline: A Murder Case Nags at a Reporter’s Mind, Before and After It Goes to Trial
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: His March front-page whodunit of a feature story ended in a cliffhanger — for readers and for our reporter himself.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this article, Jesse McKinley, The Times’s Albany bureau chief, shares how difficult it’s been — “particularly for a father, like me, of an 11-year-old boy” — to leave the Garrett Phillips murder case behind, for months, while juggling other stories.

headline: Shell Fired by ISIS at U.S. and Iraqi Troops May Have Contained Chemical Agent
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Kurds', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare']
abstract: Officials say an unexploded round from an attack by the Islamic State on a military outpost in northern Iraq initially tested positive for a mustard agent.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Fighters with the Islamic State fired a shell onto a military base in northern Iraq, home to American and Iraqi troops, that may have contained a chemical agent, military officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Chicago to Hire Many More Police, but Effect on Crime Is Debated
keywords: ['Police', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: With more than 500 murders in Chicago already this year and more than 3,000 people shot, the proposed increase was being lauded by many.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — An ambitious, costly plan to expand this city’s police force by almost 1,000 officers to stem a surge in murders and shootings has opened a new question here: Do more police officers always mean an end to rising violence?

headline: If You See Something, Say Something — and New Yorkers Have, in Droves
abstract: Since a bomb exploded in Chelsea, the police have responded to more than 800 reports of suspicious packages in New York City, far more than usual.
lead_paragraph: The scene that unfolded at a McDonald’s in Times Square on Wednesday has played out more than 800 times across New York City in the days since a bomb rattled Chelsea. Police officers rushed into the fast-food restaurant, evacuated customers and their half-eaten breakfasts and shut down a busy thoroughfare.

headline: Immigrants Aren’t Taking Americans’ Jobs, New Study Finds
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Foreign Workers', 'United States Economy', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Researchers found that, over the long term, immigration had no negative effects on the wages and jobs of native-born workers.
lead_paragraph: Do immigrants take jobs from Americans and lower their wages by working for less?

headline: Kashmir Crisis Poses Major Test for India’s Leader, Narendra Modi
abstract: A recent incursion by militants that left 18 Indian soldiers dead has created a new challenge for India’s prime minister in dealing with Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Escalating tension over the contested Kashmir region is presenting a challenge to Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India, who needs regional peace to reach his principal goal of economic revival there. But Indian citizens have been clamoring for a response to what they say is a provocation by Pakistan.

headline: Barcelona’s Season Takes a Turn in the Span of a Minute
abstract: Barcelona was cruising through the season until suddenly Lionel Messi was injured and Atlético Madrid scored in a disappointing 1-1 draw.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — Perhaps a minute elapsed between Lionel Messi’s trudging off the field as he dejectedly clutched his left thigh and Ángel Correa’s joyously clenching his fist as he celebrated the goal that gave Atlético Madrid a point at Barcelona. Those 60 seconds may prove the most significant of the entire Spanish league season.

headline: A Wall of Pigeons in a Biker’s Path
abstract: After an unexpected obstacle sends a cyclist to the ground, a dialogue ensues about the proper place to toss out bird seed.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Texas Threatens to Pull Out of Refugee Resettlement Program
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Federal Aid (US)']
abstract: The state is demanding to limit the number of refugees it accepts and receive additional security assurances, though a withdrawal from the program may not have much effect.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Texas escalated its fight with the Obama administration over refugee resettlements on Wednesday, threatening to pull out of the federal resettlement program if the state’s plan to limit the number of refugees it accepts and to receive additional security assurances is not approved.

headline: In Wells Fargo’s Bogus Accounts, Echoes of Foreclosure Abuses
abstract: The bank’s practice of opening fake accounts and charging customers fees to do so has parallels with its mistreatment of some borrowers after the financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: John Stumpf, the chairman and chief executive of Wells Fargo, won a dubious achievement award from one of his interrogators during Tuesday’s scorching hearings on Capitol Hill. The bank’s yearslong practice of opening bogus accounts for customers and charging fees to do so, said Senator Jon Tester, Democrat of Montana, had united the Senate Banking Committee on a major topic for the first time in a decade. “And not in a good way,” he added.

headline: World Leaders Agree at U.N. on Steps to Curb Rising Drug Resistance
abstract: The leaders began the first global effort to stop the spread of dangerous superbugs that are fast becoming immune to many of the most critical medicines.
lead_paragraph: World leaders agreed Wednesday on steps to curb the rapid rise of drug resistance, the first global effort to stop the spread of dangerous superbugs that are fast becoming immune to many of the most critical medicines.

headline: Las mujeres de Atenco
abstract:
Hace más de diez años, cuando era gobernador del Estado de México, Enrique Peña Nieto ordenó un operativo para reprimir a manifestantes en San Salvador de Atenco que derivó en brutales abusos sexuales a decenas de mujeres. Las víctimas llevaron su caso a la Comisión Interamericana de Derechos Humanos, que ahora ha solicitado una investigación sobre toda la cadena de mando involucrada con los hechos.

Este es el testimonio de 11 de las víctimas.
lead_paragraph:
Hace más de diez años, cuando era gobernador del Estado de México, Enrique Peña Nieto ordenó un operativo para reprimir a manifestantes en San Salvador de Atenco que derivó en brutales abusos sexuales a decenas de mujeres. Las víctimas llevaron su caso a la Comisión Interamericana de Derechos Humanos, que ahora ha solicitado una investigación sobre toda la cadena de mando involucrada con los hechos.

Este es el testimonio de 11 de las víctimas.

headline: Port Authority Chief Testifies Christie Ally Pressured Him to Reclose Lanes to Bridge
abstract: Patrick J. Foye, the executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, said that Gov. Chris Christie’s top appointee at the agency came to his office more than once to ask that the lanes be closed.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — On the morning that Patrick J. Foye ordered the reversal of the mysterious lane closings near the George Washington Bridge in September 2013, Bill Baroni appeared in his office, visibly on edge.

headline: I.R.S. Chief Calls Efforts to Oust Him ‘Improper’
abstract: John A. Koskinen warned that an attempt by House Republicans to impeach him would discourage people from government service.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, John A. Koskinen, expressed regret Wednesday for management mistakes but called an attempt by House Republicans to impeach him “improper,” warning that such threats would discourage people from government service.

headline: U.S. Allows Boeing and Airbus to Sell Planes to Iran
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The green light will allow Iran, a country desperately in need of hundreds of new aircraft, to begin replacing its aging fleet.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — The United States on Wednesday removed a final hurdle for Western aircraft manufacturers to sell planes to Iran, a country desperately in need of hundreds of new aircraft.

headline: Mayor Suggests London Could Eventually Host M.L.B. Games
abstract: Mayor Sadiq Khan said on Wednesday that the Mets’ owners and Major League Baseball officials were interested in playing in London, perhaps as soon as 2018.
lead_paragraph: Major League Baseball has hosted regular-season games in Mexico, Japan and, most recently, in Australia in 2014. Commissioner Rob Manfred has said he was interested in expanding baseball overseas.

headline: After Much Rancor, Obama and Netanyahu Meet, Probably for Last Time
abstract: For all the bitterness that has characterized their relationship, the leaders of the United States and Israel were able to end things on a harmonious note, at least publicly.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — For seven years, they slogged through the sour rituals of a broken relationship: the strained meetings; the angry phone calls; the bitter recriminations; the slights, real and perceived.

headline: Defendant’s Daughter Testifies in Potsdam Murder Trial
abstract: Shanna-Kay Hillary is the central alibi witness for her father, Oral Nicholas Hillary, who is accused of killing Garrett Phillips, the 12-year-old son of Mr. Hillary’s former girlfriend, Tandy Cyrus.
lead_paragraph: CANTON, N.Y. — The most intense clash on the final day of testimony in the trial of an upstate man accused of strangling a small boy was between a veteran Syracuse-area prosecutor — with dozens of murder convictions to his name — and a 19-year-old woman who barely spoke above a whisper.

headline: Why First Aid Is Often Lacking in the Moments After a Police Shooting
keywords: ['First Aid', 'Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: A police research group suggests that departments install requirements for officers to render first aid, even to people they may have just shot.
lead_paragraph: After the police in Tulsa, Okla., released video footage of an officer fatally shooting an unarmed man, and then standing back rather than tending to the man’s wounds, many people had the same reaction as a local activist, Marq Lewis, who voiced outrage that “they let him lay there two-plus minutes, bleeding.”

headline: Cuomo Called for ‘Reboot’ of School Standards. Officials Propose Tweaks Instead.
abstract: After more than 130 parents and teachers reviewed the standards, education officials proposed mostly minor changes for the state’s version of the Common Core.
lead_paragraph: More interactive lessons for the youngest students. Reading more fiction. Delaying teaching the order of operations in math until the fourth grade. Those are some of the changes New York State public schools may see in their classrooms, under revised standards proposed on Wednesday by education officials.

headline: Dead Shot Mary, Pistol-Packing Trailblazer, Returns in One-Policewoman Show
keywords: ['Theater', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: A new play relives the career of Mary Shanley, a pioneering policewoman and detective who once made headlines for her gun-toting arrests.
lead_paragraph: Armed with her trusty .32-caliber revolver and a bottle of Irish whiskey, Dead Shot Mary is back in town.

headline: The EpiPen Outrage Continues
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Epinephrine (Drug)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Generic Brands and Products', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Medicare', 'Editorials']
abstract: It’s time for Congress to stop letting pharmaceutical companies get away with price gouging on lifesaving drugs.
lead_paragraph: A congressional hearing on Wednesday about the outlandish price increases of the EpiPen followed a pattern that has become all too familiar in recent years. A drug price soars for no reason; lawmakers call a hearing to scold a pharmaceutical executive; the executive pleads innocence and provides as little information as possible. The drama plays out with no effect on the price.

headline: Paris Climate Deal Passes Milestone as 20 More Nations Sign On
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change']
abstract: The moves essentially ensure that the agreement will go into force by the end of the year, but the specifics of each country’s plans to curb climate change are voluntary.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — More than 20 world leaders tendered legal documents on Wednesday, formally binding their governments to the Paris climate accord at a General Assembly ceremony here and all but ensuring that the agreement will go into force by the end of the year.

headline: Fight Between Saudis and 9/11 Families Escalates in Washington
keywords: ['September 11 (2001)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama is facing pressure from each side of legislation allowing families to sue Saudi Arabia. He has said he will veto the bill.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On Monday, a constellation of lobbyists for Saudi Arabia, which has spent more than $5 million this past year to buy influence in Washington, called a crisis meeting to try to stop legislation allowing the families of victims of the Sept. 11 attacks to sue the Saudi government for any role in the plot.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Thursday, September 22, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “In about 18 minutes, everyone will stop what they’re doing and wash their hands.”

headline: Liberals See Hillary Clinton’s Focus on Big Donors as Bafflingly Dated
abstract: The lack of an online donor network is forcing Mrs. Clinton to continue with an aggressive calendar of fund-raisers with rich donors — events that can limit her time in swing states.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 2012, B. Rowe Winecoff, a retired social worker from Newton, Iowa, contributed $120 to President Obama’s re-election campaign. But he has yet to give any money to Hillary Clinton in this election. “This year just seems dirtier than ever,” said Mr. Winecoff, a Democrat, explaining why he has not contributed to the candidate he intends to vote for.

headline: Clashes in Charlotte After Shots Fired
abstract: A 26-year-old man, Justin Carr, was fatally wounded on Wednesday night during protests in Charlotte, N.C., over the police killing of Keith L. Scott.
lead_paragraph: A 26-year-old man, Justin Carr, was fatally wounded on Wednesday night during protests in Charlotte, N.C., over the police killing of Keith L. Scott.

headline: Cocktails in Berlin
abstract: Jeffrey Wechsler counts on us to join him in Europe.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — I’ve always said that if there are two things that go together particularly well, it’s puns and European travel. [You have, in fact, never said that. — Ed.] [You don’t believe me? Check out this sketch from Monty Python. — D. A.]

headline: ‘Empire’ Season 3 Premiere: The Fall
abstract: “Empire” once again delivers the combination of personality, politics, pulp and pop that took it to the top.
lead_paragraph: “Empire” wasn’t built in a day — it was built one jaw-dropping, Twitter-ready moment at a time. Fox’s blockbuster drama about the Shakespearean dynamics between a family of performers, producers and businesspeople at the pinnacle of a hip-hop record label is, or was, simply very good at being a ritzy prime-time soap opera. It moved its many story lines along at breakneck speed, careening through multiple shocks and twists each episode with little of the plot-prolonging wheel-spinning endemic to the genre. For an instructive comparison, viewers should watch not just any entertaining daytime soap, but even a relatively sharp and setting-specific nighttime serial like “Gossip Girl”; the ruthless efficiency of “Empire” is unparalleled. And from corpses in cars to main characters behind bars, it always knew how to end an hour, a stretch of episodes or an entire season on a strong note.

headline: Why Didn’t the F.B.I. Stop the New York Bombing?
abstract: The bureau has been criticized for failing to prevent a series of recent attacks, but there are limitations on what it can investigate without justification.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. is the government agency in charge of investigating terrorism. But the bureau has been criticized for failing to thwart a series of terrorist attacks in recent years in Boston; Orlando, Fla.; Garland, Tex.; and now New York. In each of those cases, the person suspected of carrying out the attack had been investigated previously by the F.B.I. The latest case involved Ahmad Khan Rahami, 28, who was charged with setting off bombs in New York and New Jersey.

headline: Georgia Won’t Force Fugitive, 71, Back From Connecticut to Finish His Term
abstract: Officials in the state where Robert Stackowitz fled from prison nearly 50 years ago have agreed to grant him a medical reprieve, sparing him from going back to serve the rest of his sentence.
lead_paragraph: A Connecticut man who escaped from a Georgia prison nearly 50 years ago and then settled into a quiet life in his home state will be allowed to remain there, the authorities in Georgia have decided.

headline: New Tool Shows New York Neighborhoods at Risk of Rent Hikes
keywords: ['Affordable Housing', 'Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Maps', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Housing groups unveiled an interactive map that looks at real estate trends to identify areas where tenants may need more city protections.
lead_paragraph: A building sells for twice as much as the average price in the neighborhood. For another building, multiple work permits are being sought from the city for renovations.

headline: Fire at Power Plant Leaves Puerto Rico in the Dark
abstract: The power failure disrupted service to 1.5 million utility customers, created massive traffic jams, and prompted the early closings of businesses
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Puerto Rico tumbled into darkness on Wednesday after a fire knocked a power plant offline, disrupting service to 1.5 million utility customers, creating huge traffic jams, and prompting the early closings of businesses and a return to candles and open windows for residents.

headline: Deborah S. Jin Dies at 47; Physicist Studied Matter in Extreme Cold
abstract: A MacArthur fellow and the second-youngest woman ever elected to the National Academy of Sciences.
lead_paragraph: Deborah S. Jin, a much-honored physicist who created and explored matter that exists only at a sliver of a degree above absolute zero — or minus 459.67 degrees Fahrenheit — died on Sept. 15 in Boulder, Colo. She was 47.

headline: Curtis Hanson: A Filmmaker of Sunshine and Noir
abstract: The director of “L.A. Confidential” used genre cinema to develop his art and craft, then made films that fit their moment.
lead_paragraph: Curtis Hanson and Los Angeles were made for each other. He grew up in that city, learned from it and, in his 1997 noir “L.A. Confidential,” gave it one of its greatest films. Mr. Hanson, who died Tuesday at 71, hadn’t directed a feature since “Chasing Mavericks,” a 2012 drama about California surfers. Mr. Hanson left “Mavericks” before finishing it (Michael Apted took over for him), apparently because of health issues. It’s a sunny distraction if now also a rueful finale to a career that for about a decade starting in the mid-1990s, enlivened movie screens with grace, range and peerless turns from the likes of Russell Crowe, Kim Basinger and Michael Douglas.

headline: Victor Scheinman, Assembly Line Robot Inventor, Dies at 73
abstract: The Scheinman Stanford Arm, developed in 1969, was adapted by manufacturers to become the leading robot in assembling and spot-welding products.
lead_paragraph: Victor Scheinman, who overcame his boyhood nightmares about a science-fiction movie humanoid to build the first successful electrically powered, computer-controlled industrial robot, died on Tuesday in Petrolia, Calif. He was 73.

headline: Unanswered Questions Fuel Doubts Among Friends of Minnesota Mall Attacker
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Police']
abstract: The suspect, Dahir Adan, was described as “a respectful, nice guy” who behaved normally in recent encounters.
lead_paragraph: ST. CLOUD, Minn. — Frustration is growing among members of the Somali community here who are eager for official information about a stabbing attack at a mall Saturday that left 10 people injured and the suspect, Dahir Adan, shot dead by an off-duty policeman. The episode is being investigated as a potential terrorist attack by the F.B.I.

headline: Violent Protest in Charlotte
abstract: Protests of a fatal shooting by the police in Charlotte, N.C., took a violent turn Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: Protests of a fatal shooting by the police in Charlotte, N.C., took a violent turn Wednesday night.

headline: Entire Indiana Fever Team Kneels During Anthem Before Playoff Game
keywords: ['Basketball', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Football', 'Playoff Games']
abstract: The gesture came in the wake of police shootings in Tulsa and Charlotte, and many other professional athletes have joined either side of the protest movement.
lead_paragraph: The latest round of athlete protests during the playing of the national anthem came Wednesday against the backdrop of recent fatal shootings of black men by the police in Tulsa, Okla., and Charlotte, N.C.

headline: ‘I’ve Never Seen Anything Like It’: Gary Sanchez Blasts 2 More Homers
abstract: Sanchez drove in five runs, homering for a fourth straight game, as the Yankees kept their slim playoff hopes alive with their second straight win over the Rays.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Brian McCann rapped out four hits, something he had not done in more than two years. Masahiro Tanaka gave up four home runs in an inning, something he had never done in a game since joining the Yankees.

headline: ‘Designated Survivor’ Series Premiere: Glasses Off
abstract: Kiefer Sutherland’s Tom Kirkman seems a warm, resolute presence, if not yet a hero, in a chaotic year.
lead_paragraph: At the Emmy Awards ceremony this week, while accepting her Emmy for best actress, “Veep” star Julia Louis-Dreyfus offered an apology for the toxic political climate that pervades Washington. “Our show started out as a political satire, but it now feels like a sobering documentary.”

headline: ‘Mr. Robot’ Season 2 Finale: Fade to Black
abstract: The second season of “Mr. Robot” didn’t so much end as slip into darkness.
lead_paragraph: Ending a season of unremitting bleakness with an unambiguous, unhappy ending would have been harsh of “Mr. Robot,” but understandable. Ending it on a note of near-total uncertainty, with virtually none of its major story lines resolved for either good or ill, is somehow even crueler.

headline: Ender Inciarte Seals Braves’ Sweep of Mets With a Game-Ending Catch
abstract: Amid a tight wild-card race, the Mets squandered a three-run lead and lost their third straight to the lowly Atlanta Braves.
lead_paragraph: Yoenis Cespedes swung hard, and the ball sliced through the September night, the Mets’ playoff hopes riding on every play at this critical time of the season. He jogged out of the batter’s box, and the crowd at Citi Field roared, thinking, like Cespedes and the entire Mets dugout, that he had clobbered a three-run home to erase a night of missed opportunities and mistakes.

headline: Auston Matthews, N.H.L.’s Top Pick, Draws Attention at World Cup of Hockey
abstract: Matthews, scheduled to begin his rookie season with the Toronto Maple Leafs in October, is one of the stars of the squad of Canadian and American players competing as Team North America.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Auston Matthews got a glimpse of the kind of reception he is likely to receive from Toronto fans when his rookie N.H.L. season begins next month.

headline: MacArthur Foundation’s 23 ‘Genius’ Grant Winners for 2016
abstract: These fellowships, awarded annually for exceptional “originality, insight and potential,” come with a no-strings-attached award of $625,000, distributed over five years.
lead_paragraph: The MacArthur fellowships, awarded annually by the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation for exceptional “originality, insight and potential,” come with a no-strings-attached award of $625,000, distributed over five years. These are the 2016 fellows.

keywords: ['Grants (Corporate and Foundation)', 'Books and Literature', 'Art', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Scholarships and Fellowships', 'Culture (Arts)']

lead_paragraph: Getting a phone call from an unidentified number in Chicago in late summer is a fantasy many artists, scientists and other creative people have entertained. But that doesn’t mean it seems real when it actually happens.

headline: Chinese Court Sentences Ai Weiwei’s Lawyer to 12 Years for Fraud
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Legal Profession', 'Censorship']
abstract: Xia Lin, a Beijing rights lawyer, called the case part of China’s campaign to silence lawyers who have challenged arbitrary state power.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A Beijing lawyer whose clients included the artist Ai Weiwei joined the swelling population of Chinese rights advocates in prison on Thursday, when a court sentenced him to 12 years after convicting him on fraud charges.

headline: Milan Fashion Week, Day 2: It Will Be Frenzied
abstract: Some of the biggest names on the Milan calendar — Prada, Fendi, Pucci — will show their collections on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, Milan. Proceedings kick off early on Thursday, even if you partied until the wee hours with Fergie after her set at Philipp Plein last night (as we did). There are no excuses not to be on time, people. It’s only Day 2, and as we’ve said, fashion month is a marathon, not a sprint.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘Pitch’ and ‘Brangelina’ in ‘By the Sea’
abstract: Kylie Bunbury stars as the first woman to pitch in the big leagues in “Pitch,” made with help from Major League Baseball. And ponder marriage as you watch “By the Sea.”
lead_paragraph: Kylie Bunbury stars as the first woman to pitch in the big leagues in “Pitch,” made with the involvement of Major League Baseball. Piper Perabo and Daniel Sunjata spar in the cable-news arena in “Notorious.” And ponder the demise of “Brangelina” with “By the Sea.”

headline: In the Studio: Fendi
abstract: Silvia Fendi, Creative Director of Accessories and Men’s,  takes us inside the extraordinary palazzo that Fendi calls home.
lead_paragraph: Silvia Fendi, Creative Director of Accessories and Men’s,  takes us inside the extraordinary palazzo that Fendi calls home.

headline: In the Studio With Silvia Fendi
abstract: The Fendi creative director of accessories and men’s wear talks about her obsession with order and her first job at the company (phone operator!).
lead_paragraph: ROME — In Episode 2 of this season’s In the Studio series, which takes you into a designer’s private working space, Silvia Fendi, the creative director of accessories and men’s wear for the company that bears her name, talks about her obsession with order, her first job at the company (phone operator!) and her family’s special request to the president. This interview has been condensed and edited.

headline: Word + Quiz: spendthrift
abstract: The word spendthrift has appeared in 13 New York Times articles in the past year.

abstract: Robin Hammond set out to document Lagos, a teeming metropolis where “intimacy and exclusion, love and hate, laughter and insult regularly rub shoulders” on its streets.
lead_paragraph: Robin Hammond set out to document Lagos, a teeming metropolis where “intimacy and exclusion, love and hate, laughter and insult regularly rub shoulders” on its streets.

headline: Saad Hariri: Iran Must Stop Meddling in Arab Affairs
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Sunni Muslims']
abstract: We Lebanese are all too familiar with the sectarian hatred and terrorism Iran and its allies are capable of inflicting.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 14, 2005, a massive bomb killed the former prime minister of Lebanon, Rafik Hariri, my father, along with 22 other Lebanese. The Special Tribunal for Lebanon at The Hague identified five Hezbollah operatives as suspected collaborators in the murder. If proved, that would mean his assassination was carried out by Iran’s allies in Lebanon, who are financed and controlled by the regime in Tehran.

headline: Foreign Wars and Terrorism
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Series', 'Editorials']
abstract: It’s time for the candidates to give voters the specifics of how they will handle Iraq, Syria and homegrown terrorism.
lead_paragraph: Dealing with extremism abroad and its spillover at home will present an enormously complex challenge for the next president. Over the last five years, conflicts in Syria and Iraq have continued to frustrate the United States diplomatically, sapped military resources and provided a breeding ground for Islamic State radicals, who have spread bloodshed and destruction in the region and the West.

headline: Ready, Aim — Voting
abstract: The hottest political ad of the season shows a candidate assembling an assault rifle blindfolded.
lead_paragraph: The hottest political ad of the season — I am not counting anything involving Triumph the Insult Comic Dog — is probably for the Missouri Senate, in which the Democratic candidate talks about … gun background checks.

headline: The Folly of the Protest Vote
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Voting and Voters', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Either Clinton or Trump will be the next president of the United States. Not Jill Stein. Not Gary Johnson.
lead_paragraph: Last week, after I delivered a speech at the impressive campus of Morgan State University, a historically black college in northeast Baltimore, a woman approached the mike during the question-and-answer period to raise an issue that she and I both found frustrating: What to say to young people, particularly young African-Americans, who have decided either not to vote in the forthcoming presidential election or to cast a protest vote for a third-party candidate who will most assuredly lose?

headline: The Best News You Don’t Know
keywords: ['Poverty', 'News and News Media', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Children and Childhood', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Medicine and Health', 'Illiteracy']
abstract: The world is winning the war on extreme poverty.
lead_paragraph: The world is a mess, with billions of people locked in inescapable cycles of war, famine and poverty, with more children than ever perishing from hunger, disease and violence.

headline: When It Comes to Baskets, We’re All Deplorable
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Discrimination', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: Hillary Clinton is wrong to divide America into good and bad. Everyone has prejudices.
lead_paragraph: It was the awkward comment heard round the world. At a fund-raiser earlier this month, the Democratic presidential nominee, Hillary Clinton, divided the supporters of her Republican opponent Donald J. Trump into two even groups. One consisted of good, if alienated and dispossessed, people. But the other half goes into a “basket of deplorables,” she said. “The racist, sexist, homophobic, xenophobic, Islamophobic — you name it.”

headline: The Divided States of America
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment']
abstract: Rather than being one two-party nation, we are increasingly two one-party nations.
lead_paragraph: Reading the nonstop coverage of what may well be a close presidential election, one might be forgiven for thinking that political competition is alive and well in America.

headline: Artist Zeng Fanzhi on the Evolution of His Work and China’s Art Market
abstract: As a major retrospective opens in Beijing, Mr. Zeng discusses traditional Chinese culture, the marketplace and mixing politics and art.
lead_paragraph: To get a sense of the remarkable growth of the Chinese contemporary art market, look no further than the artist Zeng Fanzhi.

headline: Photographing Lagos, ‘As Much an Experience as a Place’
abstract: Robin Hammond set out to document Lagos, a teeming metropolis where “intimacy and exclusion, love and hate, laughter and insult regularly rub shoulders” on its streets.
lead_paragraph: I have been an outsider most of my life. As an immigrant or photographer in the countries where I have lived and worked, I have not truly belonged. I’ve been a foreigner for so long that I don’t really know anything else. It has become part of who I am.

headline: An 18-Karat Throne
abstract: Our question: Is this art? Why or why not? If you think it is, what do you imagine the artist is trying to say or show?

keywords: ['Robots and Robotics', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: Hit it with a laser, and a polymer strip at the University of Warsaw will start wriggling like a caterpillar, part of a new class of “soft robots.”
lead_paragraph: It’s about half an inch long, a few millimeters wide and no thicker than a human hair, and it usually just sits there like a discarded strip of red cellophane — until a specific shade of green laser light strikes it.

headline: Police Sex Abuse Case Is Bad News for Mexico’s Leader

abstract: An international commission’s call for an investigation into a 2006 crackdown, ordered by Enrique Peña Nieto when he was governor, is a new blow to his presidency.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — International human rights officials are demanding an investigation into the brutal sexual assaults of 11 Mexican women during protests a decade ago — an inquiry that would take aim at President Enrique Peña Nieto, who was the governor in charge at the time of the attacks.

abstract: Ryan Tannehill, Christine Michael and Larry Fitzgerald are among the players set up to perform well in Week 3.
lead_paragraph: The Sablich brothers have provided award-winning fantasy football advice for The New York Times since 2010. See their weekly player rankings and visit 5thDownFantasy.com for more fantasy analysis. You can also ask them questions through their Twitter account, @5thdownfantasy.

keywords: ['Robots and Robotics', 'Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: The University of Warsaw developed a robot caterpillar that uses an external laser to move. Other “soft robots” can be propelled by electromagnetic fields or light.
lead_paragraph: The University of Warsaw developed a robot caterpillar that uses an external laser to move. Other “soft robots” can be propelled by electromagnetic fields or light.

headline: Why Does Celebrity Gossip Interest Us So Much?
abstract: Why do we care so much about the lives of celebrities in general, and this couple in particular? What role does celebrity gossip play in our culture?
lead_paragraph: When did you hear the “Brangelina” news? How did you react? Why do you think the public reaction was so intense that the hashtag #Brangelina quickly became the top trending item on Twitter?

headline: Review: Denzel Washington Rides High in ‘The Magnificent Seven’
abstract: Ethan Hawke, Chris Pratt and Vincent D’Onofrio help round out the cast of this western remake, as outlaws who band together to protect a terrorized town.
lead_paragraph: Denzel Washington looks just right high in the saddle, which makes sense given that he’s become our John Wayne — our point-and-shoot savior. It’s a funny business being a hero these days, and Mr. Washington has the résumé to prove it, with characters — a corrupt cop, a drug kingpin — that would have been unthinkable for Wayne, who saved the day when the lines between right and wrong were more rigidly defined. Those lines have blurred, of course, and good guys went sort of bad and sometimes very bad, partly because we like it like that. (It feels so good.)

headline: Will Women Play Major League Baseball? (And Not Just on TV)
abstract: The new Fox show “Pitch” imagines a time when women can play Major League Baseball. Is it possible?
lead_paragraph: The new Fox drama “Pitch,” about the first female pitcher in Major League Baseball, proclaims that it is “a true story on the verge of happening.”

headline: Foreign Reporters in China Face More Restrictions Now, Report Says
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: A survey by PEN America shows growing difficulties in getting news out of the country as its economic importance and geopolitical power grow.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China has tightened restrictions on foreign journalists since Xi Jinping became the country’s leader four years ago, complicating efforts to parse Beijing’s thinking at a time when its slowing economy and growing global ambitions are making it increasingly important to the world.

lead_paragraph: The world of health care is filled with acrimony and accusations at the moment.

headline: Flyhalf Assembly Line Is Key to New Zealand’s Rugby Success
abstract: Year after year, the All Blacks have had an embarrassment of riches at the position that is most crucial to the game’s attack.
lead_paragraph: WELLINGTON, New Zealand — Grant Fox, Andrew Mehrtens, Dan Carter: for 30 years, the New Zealand All Blacks have produced an endless stream of world-class flyhalves who have steered the team to success.

headline: 5 Ways to Make College Tours Fun Instead of Grueling
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Fall is here, and so is college tour season. Turn it into a vacation!
lead_paragraph: At Amherst College in Amherst, Mass., my family, including our son, prospective applicant Seth, enjoyed the natural history museum and spied on swim team practice. At Colby College in Waterville, Me., we appreciated the colonial architecture and the modern art collection. At the University of Chicago, we loved the Hogwarts-like reading room and the pierogi truck.

headline: Five Places to Go in Prague
abstract: Prague’s Vrsovice district has become something of a cultural melting pot with a breezy bohemian vibe, attracting an international crowd.
lead_paragraph: Once defined by its rundown Communist-style housing blocks, uneven sidewalks and graffiti-laced storefronts, Prague’s Vrsovice district has transformed into one of the capital’s “it” neighborhoods. Over the last decade, stylish cafes, craft beer pubs and boutique retailers have moved in, tucked among its colorful rowhouses. With its popular biannual street festivals and vibrant night life, this former blue-collar neighborhood has now become something of a cultural melting pot with a breezy bohemian vibe, attracting an international crowd.

headline: Sarah Jessica Parker, Leaving Carrie Behind With HBO’s ‘Divorce’
abstract: Ms. Parker makes clear that “Divorce,” her first HBO series since “Sex and the City,” “is not Carrie in the suburbs.”
lead_paragraph: Sarah Jessica Parker was waiting for a menu at a restaurant in Hastings-on-Hudson, a Westchester County suburb of New York, when a 50-something man in a polo shirt and shorts showed up at her table. “I’m out of your face right after this little note I made for you — check it out,” he said. He handed her a small folded piece of paper and waited as Ms. Parker read it. “Aw,” she said, and smiled. “Thank you! Thank you, Michael!”

headline: Clinton and Trump Tied in North Carolina Poll, With Sharp Educational Divides
abstract: Perhaps no battleground state is as polarized along demographic lines as this one.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps no battleground state is as polarized along demographic lines as this one.

headline: Lang Lang Is Named New York’s First ‘Cultural Tourism Ambassador’
abstract: With the pianist’s help, the city hopes to entice Chinese visitors to explore parts of the city outside Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — New York City, already a top international tourist destination, has a message for visitors from China: There’s more to see than the Empire State Building and Times Square.

headline: The Voyages Issue: Remarkable Journeys With Six Photographers
abstract: Photo essays from around the world by Andrea Frazzetta, Joachim Ladefoged, David Maurice Smith, Kirsten Luce, Sebastián Liste and Raymond Meeks.
lead_paragraph: Photo essays from around the world by Andrea Frazzetta, Joachim Ladefoged, David Maurice Smith, Kirsten Luce, Sebastián Liste and Raymond Meeks.

headline: What We See When We Look at Travel Photography
abstract: On the visual — and psychological — contradictions of pictures from the road.
lead_paragraph: There is a vast gulf between how people tend to think of “tourism,” an agreeable pursuit for themselves and a great benefit to their local economy, and how people tend to think of other tourists, as interlopers, beholden to oafish appetites for packaged experience. Those of us who travel professionally, with a view to record for those at home our encounters on the road, try to bridge that perceptual divide. This can be uncomfortable. Tourists in bad faith, we are paid to elevate our naïve consumption (of city, museum, vista, ruin, breakfast) to the level of a vocation. The internal anxiety that this contradiction inspires in us often gets displaced, in an amusing way, onto others on the same circuit. Professional travelers like nothing better than the opportunity to point out the crumminess of other professional travelers.

headline: ‘Identity Is a Hoax, People!’
abstract: RuPaul joins for a discussion of the Emmys on this week’s episode of Still Processing.
lead_paragraph: This week, we discuss Sunday’s prime-time Emmy Awards broadcast, which Jenna barely wanted to watch.

headline: 1966: Peace Move Would End Assault
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: The United States offer to stop bombing North Vietnam if Hanoi takes similar action towards the U.S. forces, during the Vietnam War in September 1966.
lead_paragraph: United Nations — The United States offered today [Sept. 22] to stop bombing North Vietnam and begin pulling out its troops if Hanoi would take corresponding action to de-escalate the fighting. U.S. Ambassador Arthur J. Goldberg, making a major policy declaration, told the 118-member General Assembly that the United States was willing to undertake first steps provided North Vietnam showed through public or private response it was ready to reciprocate. The United States, Mr. Goldberg said, does not seek to make South Vietnam a permanent U.S. ally. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 23, 1966

headline: Nina Stemme on a Love and Loss in ‘Tristan und Isolde’
abstract: The soprano is playing Isolde in this Wagner opera at the Met. Here, she discusses a passing moment in the first act.
lead_paragraph: Nina Stemme’s favorite page from the score of Wagner’s “Tristan und Isolde” is a surprising one: not Isolde’s closing “Liebestod” or the great love scene, but a passing moment in the first act. Isolde, eyeing Tristan but addressing herself and her maid, Brangäne, laments that Tristan is destined for her but has been taken from her. She reveals her love for him by tracing the yearning theme that dominates the opera but resolves that such love must end in death. Hers are a “Todgeweihtes Haupt” and a “Todgeweihtes Herz” — a head and heart fated for the grave. Here are edited excerpts from a conversation with Ms. Stemme about the sequence.

headline: Spending Bill Seems Likely to Take Up Ted Cruz’s Fight Over Internet Directory
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: His effort to halt the government’s plan to transfer oversight of the internet’s master directory of website addresses seems set to find purchase in a congressional measure.
lead_paragraph: A plan to help revive the Export-Import Bank seems to be headed for the legislative cutting-room floor. A Republican dream of weakening pesticide regulations has been scotched. But the short-term spending bill that Congress is set to pass next week, one that both parties tried to use to promote various policies, will most likely include a provision championed by Senator Ted Cruz, Republican of Texas, a frequent troublemaker on all matters fiscal.

headline: Nina Stemme Takes On Her Biggest Met Opera Assignment Yet
abstract: Ms. Stemme, the Swedish dramatic soprano, is singing Isolde, perhaps her greatest role, in a new production of “Tristan und Isolde.”
lead_paragraph: For a certain kind of New Yorker, whose Manhattan-centrism comes with the expectation that the Big Apple should naturally be a magnet for the best of everything, the long absences of Nina Stemme, the great Swedish dramatic soprano, were somewhat puzzling.

headline: Apple Opens the iMessage Door, and the Ephemera Rushes In
abstract: Several new features have turned this intimate chat experience into more of a social network.
lead_paragraph: Apple built an empire on hermetically sealed systems with sleek, minimalist designs. Nowhere was its strategy more evident than in iMessage, the company’s instant messaging system that offered a free, elegant chatting solution exclusive to Apple devices. Until last week, that is, when Apple updated its software, cracked open iMessage and allowed the ephemera of the outside internet to seep in.

headline: Ex-Cuomo Aides Charged in Federal Corruption Inquiry
abstract: The charges are the culmination of a long-running investigation into the Cuomo administration’s attempts to lure jobs and businesses to upstate New York’s limping economy.
lead_paragraph: Federal corruption charges were announced on Thursday against two former close aides to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, a senior state official and six other people, in a blow to the governor’s innermost circle and a repudiation of the way his prized upstate economic development programs were managed.

headline: ‘Botched’ Repair to China’s Great Wall Provokes Outrage
abstract: An effort to preserve a stretch of the Great Wall in northeast China has been criticized for erasing distinctive features.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Great Wall of China. A stirring symbol of national pride whose overlapping sections span thousands of miles. A crumbling, melancholy monument to China’s imperial grandeur, so imposing that it inspired the stubborn myth that it is visible from the moon.

headline: The Curious Confidence of Charlatans and Cranks
abstract: Knowing what just wasn’t so.
lead_paragraph: Brad DeLong tells us about a letter being circulated by economists for Trump — although, as he notes, they don’t dare say that, and describe themselves only as critics of Clinton. Several things are notable about the letter, including the absence of many usually reliable Republican hired guns economists. But they do have a Nobelist, Eugene Fama, at the top. And the substance of the letter — government bad! taxes and regulation bad! free markets rool like Reagan! — is pretty standard.

headline: In Pinter’s ‘No Man’s Land,’ Actor-Knights Wield Their Words
abstract: Ian McKellen and Patrick Stewart star in a new London production of the play at Wyndham’s Theater.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “No Man’s Land” has attracted no shortage of legendary talent since Harold Pinter’s ceaselessly tantalizing and cryptic play premiered in 1975, starting with those era-defining actor-knights, John Gielgud and Ralph Richardson. As two of the signature stage voices of all time, their every utterance signaled the play’squalities as a chamber poem.

headline: Afghanistan Signs Draft Peace Deal With Faction Led by Gulbuddin Hekmatyar
abstract: The faction, Hezb-i-Islami, agreed to cease hostilities in exchange for government recognition and support for removing sanctions against its leader.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Afghan government signed a draft peace deal on Thursday with a small insurgent faction led by a warlord who has been designated a “global terrorist” by the United States.

headline: Body Image Issues? Lisa Lampanelli Knows the Feeling
abstract: The insult comic has channeled anxieties about food and body insecurities into her first play, “Stuffed.”
lead_paragraph: Lisa Lampanelli didn’t become an insult comic by herself. A heckler helped.

headline: U.S. to Step Up Deportations of Haitians Amid Surge at Border
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Deportation', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The Obama administration said it would fully resume deportations of those without visas, a policy shift that surprised migrant advocates.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The Obama administration, responding to an extraordinary wave of Haitian migrants seeking to enter the United States, said on Thursday that it would fully resume deportations of undocumented Haitian immigrants.

headline: Cirque du Soleil Brings Steampunk to Randalls Island
abstract: “Kurios: Cabinet of Curiosities” will play under a big top in a pop-up space.
lead_paragraph: Cirque du Soleil has its geographical bases pretty much covered, from “Paramour,” currently on Broadway, to the many productions in Las Vegas and on tour. But the best way to experience the circus is under a big top, which makes “Kurios: Cabinet of Curiosities,” to be presented in a pop-up space on Randalls Island, especially exciting. And it arrives in New York with exuberant reviews in its wake: “It is not to be missed on any account,” Chris Jones wrote in The Chicago Tribune.

headline: This Conductor Is on the Rise, and She’s Coming to New York
abstract: Mirga Grazinyte-Tyla will lead the ensemble in a program featuring Beethoven and Berlioz.
lead_paragraph: Mirga Grazinyte-Tyla, 30, is already one of the world’s fastest-rising conductors. Closely affiliated with the Los Angeles Philharmonic, a canny judge of young talent, she has just become the music director of the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra in England, a position that jump-started the careers of Simon Rattle and Andris Nelsons.

headline: California Today: The Debate Over Indian Mascots and Imagery
abstract: Thursday: Native American team nicknames in schools, the future of Los Angeles, and a look at the death penalty propositions.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Jeremy Corbyn and the Problem With ‘Electability’
abstract: If Labour members re-elect a left-wing firebrand as their leader, they’ll undo years of rightward drift in their party.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Jeremy Corbyn’s tenure since last September as leader of the Labour Party has been bumpy, to say the least: The party now has the worst poll ratings in its history. Labour’s parliamentary members have complained that Mr. Corbyn cannot manage them. And his tenure has been troubled by poor decisions — he chose, for example, to go to a Cuba solidarity event on the same day that Theresa May, the new prime minister, announced the formation of her cabinet, leaving the opposition with no public response. Mr. Corbyn was widely considered a lackluster campaigner in the effort to persuade British voters that their country should remain in the European Union.

headline: End U.S. Support for the Thugs of Honduras
abstract: Instead of continuing aid for security forces that have a dire human rights record, America should back calls for an independent investigation.
lead_paragraph: Santa Cruz, Calif. — Around midnight on March 2, the indigenous peoples’ rights and environmental activist Berta Cáceres was shot dead by gunmen who entered her residence in La Esperanza, Honduras. A longtime campaigner against illegal logging operations, Ms. Cáceres had been repeatedly threatened because of her opposition to the Agua Zarca hydroelectric project, one of the largest of its kind in Central America.

headline: Come Check Out Our House, Metropolitan Opera Says
abstract: The Met will welcome visitors to the front of the opera house for free self-guided tours on weekdays, from 10 a.m.-2 p.m., starting Oct. 4.
lead_paragraph: As opera companies around the world try to remove the barriers that can inhibit newcomers, the Metropolitan Opera is experimenting with a literal approach. The Met plans to throw open its gates and welcome visitors to the front of the opera house for free on weekdays beginning next month, the company announced Thursday.

headline: The Artists and Their Alley, in Postwar France
abstract: From Brancusi to Ernst to Klein, the greatest painters and sculptors of the time once lived and worked together, sharing beds, a single toilet and their creative brilliance.
lead_paragraph: There’s a back street in Montparnasse, the entrance to a hospital morgue, where weeds grow in sidewalk cracks and beer cans rust on the pavement. The only discernible sign of life is a corner cafe, but even that feels more like the backdrop of a Cartier-Bresson photograph than a place to purchase actual coffee. On a clammy afternoon in August, the owner sits outside alone, smoking.

headline: Charges Against Joseph Percoco and Others
abstract: Mr. Percoco, who had served as Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s executive deputy secretary, is accused of soliciting and taking more than $315,000 in bribes. In addition, corruption charges were announced against another former aide, a senior state official and six other people.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Percoco, who had served as Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s executive deputy secretary, is accused of soliciting and taking more than $315,000 in bribes. In addition, corruption charges were announced against another former aide, a senior state official and six other people.

abstract: Mr. Howe, a former aide to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, is accused of arranging bribes for another aide.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Howe, a former aide to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, is accused of arranging bribes for another aide.

headline: Boko Haram Rages in Nigeria, but the World’s Eyes Are Elsewhere
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Terrorism', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Malnutrition', 'Music']
abstract: The militant group, which has pledged allegiance to the Islamic State, has continued its bloody campaign, creating a growing humanitarian crisis.
lead_paragraph: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria — The crisis spawned by Boko Haram has drawn hundreds of thousands of people to a relatively little-known city in Nigeria that has finally become safe enough for them to wait out an end to the awful, deadly war.

headline: Slovenia’s (Burgeoning) Fairy Tale of a City
abstract: Where to eat, sleep and shop in Ljubljana, the country’s majestic capital.
lead_paragraph: Visiting Ljubljana, Slovenia’s 1,000-year-old capital, feels like stepping into an ancient fable. Despite decades under communist rule, there’s magic to the intimate city: It’s the sort of place where you can stroll past jelly-bean-colored Baroque churches, over a bridge flanked by dragons — Ljubljana’s mascot — onto winding cobblestone lanes filled with local farmers selling peonies the size of lap dogs and creaky inns serving bear meat.

headline: The Peculiar Pleasure of Ornately Embellished Accessories
abstract: Visually arresting shoes and bags are the perfect antidote to minimalist fashion.
lead_paragraph: Visually arresting shoes and bags are the perfect antidote to minimalist fashion.

headline: Want to Change Banking Culture? Stop Talking About Cross-Selling
abstract: When it comes to culture, words matter. Any time a financial institution talks about “products” that can be cross-sold to customers, trouble isn’t far behind, says a wealth management executive.
lead_paragraph: Bankers love the phrase “cross-sell.” I don’t.

headline: Restoring a Run-Down Convent in Tuscany
abstract: A mother-daughter duo brought back to life a centuries-old house in the countryside.
lead_paragraph: For 60 years, a 16th-century Franciscan convent designed by the Florentine architect Antonio da Sangallo the Younger, a creator of both the Palazzo Farnese and the Villa Madama in Rome, had existed in a state of abandoned decrepitude. Situated on the edge of the town of Pitigliano, in southern Tuscany, with vegetation engulfing its cloisters, the house had no electricity, almost no running water and no windows. It was exactly what the mother-and-daughter duo Holly Lueders and Venetia Sacret Young had been looking for: “the perfect ruin.”

headline: Fendi: Spring 2017
abstract: After showing a 90th-anniversary couture collection at he Trevi Fountain in Rome, Karl Lagerfeld presents his spring show.
lead_paragraph: After showing a 90th-anniversary couture collection at he Trevi Fountain in Rome, Karl Lagerfeld presents his spring show.

headline: Poland’s Most Optimistic, Backward-Looking Artist
abstract: Faded utopias have served as the greatest inspiration for Paulina Olowska — painting, living and believing in a forgotten past.
lead_paragraph: For the Polish artist Paulina Olowska, Warsaw in the 2000s was a city of ghosts. Walking through neighborhoods, she would notice skeletal and darkened neon signs for shops that no longer existed, the legacy of a centrally planned “neonization of Warsaw.” She would pass shuttered storefronts with elaborate papier-mâché dioramas, a decorative tradition left over from a time when shops had little to display in their windows. She saw an expired idealism in the library for the blind across the street from her apartment; in the Modernist buildings, constructed with a ­utopian society in mind and yet unlivable; in the defunct socialist monuments.

headline: Professed Hit Man Tempers Claims of Rodrigo Duterte’s Role in Philippine Killings
keywords: ['Vigilantes', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Under questioning, Edgar Matobato said he did not hear the president order an execution but saw him give orders to a death squad commander.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — A professed hit man who implicated President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines in extrajudicial killings backed off some of his earlier assertions of the president’s involvement under tough questioning from a Senate committee on Thursday.

lead_paragraph: Inside the creative rodeo of the RTH shop owner and purveyor of eclectic finds René Tadeo Holguin.

headline: How Restricting Food Stamp Choices Can Fight Obesity
abstract: A study shows the potential benefits, but if the past is any guide, what’s effective will nonetheless be politically unpalatable.
lead_paragraph: Often, when people discuss the obesity crisis in the United States, and another failed effort to help people change their eating habits, it’s as if there’s nothing we can do.

abstract: A slide show of some of our favorite “What’s Going On in This Picture?” posts, culled from four years of images.
lead_paragraph: Update, Oct. 4, 2020: We have published a sequel to this post with 40 more intriguing photographs.

headline: 1891: Rebellion Threatens China
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: The rebellion spreads in the Ichang, Yangstee and Wuchang regions of China, worrying foreigners, in September 1891.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — The situation daily grows more serious. Mob rule prevails at Ichang, and is the prelude of other disorders. The Valley of the Yangtsee is in rebellion.

headline: Who Is Jacoby Brissett? Maybe the Patriots’ Starting Quarterback
abstract: With Tom Brady suspended and Jimmy Garoppolo hurt, the Patriots may start a rookie third-stringer against the Texans on Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: The Patriots are 2-0, and all the concerns about Tom Brady’s four-game suspension to start the season seemed unfounded when his backup, Jimmy Garoppolo, played well.

headline: Climate Change Threatens World’s Coffee Supply, Report Says
abstract: A new analysis of environmental research has coffee companies and drinkers worried about the future of the product.
lead_paragraph: A report examining the many ways climate change threatens coffee and coffee farmers has alarmed people who are now imagining what it would be like getting through the day without their caffeine fix.

headline: ‘Great British Bake Off’ Loses Mary Berry, a Star Host
abstract: Ms. Berry, an 81-year-old celebrity chef and author, is the third presenter to leave the show, which is moving from the BBC to a rival network.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “The Great British Bake Off,” the hit series that pits pastry makers against one another in polite competition, is losing one of its greatest draws: Mary Berry, an 81-year-old celebrity chef whose understated expressions of delight and disdain have attracted something of a cult following.

headline: U.N. Criticizes Congo for Response to Deadly Unrest
abstract: The high commissioner for human rights blamed the government for using excessive force during political demonstrations and riots that may have killed over 50 people.
lead_paragraph: KINSHASA, Democratic Republic of Congo — The United Nations high commissioner for human rights blamed the government of the Democratic Republic of Congo on Thursday for using excessive force during political demonstrations and riots this week that might have killed more than 50 people.

headline: After ‘Brexit,’ E.U. Revives Idea of Its Own Joint Military Command
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The notion of a European military headquarters outside of NATO is back, and the United States now seems quietly supportive of the idea.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In late April 2003, just after the rapid fall of Baghdad, four of the founding countries of what is now the European Union met to announce the formation of a European operational military command headquarters just down the road from NATO.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It has taken nearly eight years, but it appears President Obama is about to finally suffer the stinging indignity of a veto override.

headline: In a Switch for Paris Show, Automakers Turn From Diesel

headline: Video Review: With Many Options, Ford Explorer Rides High

lead_paragraph: IT can be argued that the Ford Explorer ignited America’s love affair with sport utility vehicles when it arrived in 1990, riding on the compact Ranger pickup platform.

headline: Expecto Patronum! Patronus Test Keeps ‘Harry Potter’ Marketing Alive
keywords: ['Harry Potter (Fictional Character)', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The quiz, produced with 3D animation and written by Ms. Rowling herself, quickly excited the online fandom.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a question that separates a real “Harry Potter” fan from the rest of the muggles who think this is all just a bunch of wizarding gibberish: Is your Patronus a Siberian cat, a heron or a basset hound?

headline: Inside MoMA PS1’s Back to School Bash
abstract: All of PS1’s galleries, which are temporarily empty, will become classrooms for the night. The dress code? “Come as you were”: jock, prep or nerd.
lead_paragraph: Ryan McNamara likes to think his No. 1 talent is as a casting director. He may be confident in his vision for new performance pieces, but he said he often invites his “weird” friends to add something he can’t.

headline: Rebelling Against Insta-Everything at Fendi and Roberto Cavalli
abstract: In Milan, the emphasis is on the clothes but also on the hands that made them, and the time it took.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — There’s a balmy wind of minor rebellion sweeping along the catwalks of Milan, making unlikely allies of normally opposing aesthetics, and drawing a line in the sand. The insta-fashion that so defined the start of the season in New York (the way, arguably, insta-everything so defines modern life) is finding little purchase here.

headline: Secrets to Lasting Relationships From High School Sweethearts
abstract: Growing up, and growing older, with their partners. Couples reveal how their love matured.
lead_paragraph: Growing up, and growing older, with their partners. Couples reveal how their love matured.

headline: Living With Schizophrenia: My Father’s Perfect Family
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Schizophrenia', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Brokenness has a way of cementing bonds among a family.
lead_paragraph: My father said on numerous occasions when I was growing up that he would see other families that had problems like divorce and drug use, and he would thank God that his family was so perfect.

headline: Put Your iPhone Photos on the Map
abstract: If your iPhone did not automatically tag your photos with a geographic location when you took them, you can add the information manually.
