lead_paragraph: Massimo Giorgetti shows his third collection for the house.

headline: Chris Christie Protected Culprit in Bridge Lane Closings, Agency Head Testifies
abstract: The executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, Patrick J. Foye, said on Thursday that he was prevented from questioning an ally of the governor.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — The acknowledged culprit behind the closing of traffic lanes leading to the George Washington Bridge in September 2013 was “protected by Chris Christie,” the executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey agreed during court testimony on Thursday.

headline: Keith Scott’s Family Sees Videos of His Killing, and Says the Public Should, Too
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Charlotte’s police chief stood by his decision not to release the recordings. As people resumed protests Thursday night, the city’s mayor ordered a curfew.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — The grieving relatives of a man who was killed by the police here watched videos on Thursday of the fatal shooting, a wrenching experience that they said revealed no hint of aggression in him and left the family members convinced that the videos should be made public. But the city’s police chief, who had arranged for the private viewing, held fast to his decision not to release the recordings.

headline: Amid New Airstrikes in Syria, an Aid Convoy Arrives
abstract: A procession of trucks carrying supplies for 40,000 people arrived in a Damascus suburb on Thursday, but bombing continued in the rebel-held areas of Aleppo.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations resumed aid convoys to besieged communities in Syria on Thursday for the first time since a deadly attack on trucks loaded with supplies on Monday.

headline: Baseball Is Having a Power Surge, but Nobody Knows Why
abstract: Explanations for the sudden rise in home runs include doping and a shift in strategy.
lead_paragraph: If you looked through the annual home run leaderboards, the 2000 season would not stick out as particularly noteworthy. Sammy Sosa led Major League Baseball with a relatively modest 50 homers after consecutive seasons in which he and Mark McGwire each hit more than 60. A year later, Barry Bonds surpassed both of them by hitting 73.

headline: Stress May Counteract Effects of a Healthful Diet
keywords: ['Anxiety and Stress', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Food', 'Oils and Fats']
abstract: After a stress-filled day, the body responded differently to a diet low in saturated fats.
lead_paragraph: Stress may counteract the beneficial effects of a healthful diet, a study in Molecular Psychiatry suggests.

headline: Daily Report: Bay Area Claims Transport Center of the World Title
abstract: Start-ups and big companies are experimenting with driverless cars, electric vehicles, ride-sharing, drones, robot sailboats and even flying autos.
lead_paragraph: For several years now, the San Francisco Bay Area has increasingly become the transportation hub of the world, with start-ups and big companies experimenting with driverless cars, electric vehicles, ride-sharing, drones and even flying autos.

headline: Tong Sam Gyup Goo Yi
abstract: Korean barbecue pork reigns supreme at this tiny restaurant in Flushing, Queens.
lead_paragraph: Korean barbecue pork reigns supreme at this tiny restaurant in Flushing, Queens.

headline: The Thrill of the Tabletop Grill at Tong Sam Gyup Goo Yi
abstract: A standout destination for Korean pork dishes in the “kimchi belt” of Flushing, Queens.
lead_paragraph: The crowd is of one mind at Tong Sam Gyup Goo Yi: From every table rises a gleaming black cast-iron dome with a tapered handle, like the lid of a giant pot, and on every dome lie stripes of pork belly, more white than red, flesh nearly overrun by fat.

headline: Risky Business: Hollywood Bets Big on ‘Deepwater Horizon’
abstract: The documentary-style film isn’t the kind of project that usually commands a nine-figure budget, but the 2010 oil rig disaster had elements straight out of a movie.
lead_paragraph: In Hollywood, films like “Deepwater Horizon” are not supposed to exist.

headline: Before I Say ‘I Do,’ Let’s Just Go Over Every Possible Scenario One More Time
abstract: Why not really be yourself on your wedding day?
lead_paragraph: Alex, the first night we met, I knew you were the one. When you asked me to move in, I didn’t hesitate. When you proposed, I said “yes” right away.

headline: Can the F.B.I. Do More to Investigate Suspected Extremists?
abstract: The New York City bombing is the latest attack that has been tied to someone whose suspected extremism  led to federal inquiries.

headline: Violence Ripples Through Congo

lead_paragraph: Uncertainty over the next presidential election has spurred deadly clashes in the Democratic Republic of Congo’s capital, Kinshasa, over the last week.

headline: Panthers Review Game Security After Violent Protests in Charlotte
keywords: ['Football', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The N.F.L. said it would continue “to monitor events as we prepare for Sunday’s home game.” The Panthers host the Vikings on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: The Carolina Panthers are reviewing security for Sunday afternoon’s home game against the Minnesota Vikings in the wake of violent protests in Charlotte, N.C., over the killing of a black man by a police officer.

headline: ‘In-Betweeners’ Are Part of a Rich Recruiting Pool for Jihadists
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Youth', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Chelsea, Manhattan Bombing (2016)']
abstract: Terrorism experts say Islamist groups target the particular anxieties of Western Muslims from immigrant backgrounds — young adults whose identities have not yet solidified.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — They were young men caught between cultures, sons of immigrant families, feeling lost or rejected — and angry about American-led wars. Online they encountered the silver-tongued recruiters of Al Qaeda and the Islamic State, who said their first loyalty should be not to their nation but to Islam. Then they plotted sensational violence.

headline: ‘Keep an Eye on Him,’ Ahmad Khan Rahami’s Father Says He Told F.B.I.
abstract: In interviews, Mohammad Rahami said he warned agents about his son’s interest in terrorist organizations and his admiration of a leading Qaeda propagandist.
lead_paragraph: The father of the man accused of carrying out bombings last weekend in New York and New Jersey said that, two years ago, he warned federal agents explicitly about his son’s interest in terrorist organizations like Al Qaeda and his fascination with jihadist music, poetry and videos.

headline: ‘Fees Must Fall’: Anatomy of the Student Protests in South Africa
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: Protests by university students flared up after a government proposal that university fees could increase as much as 8 percent next year.
lead_paragraph: University students protested in South Africa for at least a second day this week over plans to increase fees at the country’s colleges in 2017. The protests, which erupted in September, have turned violent as students have clashed with the police.

headline: Review: In ‘Queen of Katwe,’ a Pawn Finds Her Crown Through Chess
abstract: In this stirring underdog story directed by Mira Nair, Madina Nalwanga plays a young Ugandan with a gift for chess, supported by Lupita Nyong’o as her mother.
lead_paragraph: “Irresistible” is one of those adjectives that critics should handle with utmost care. No matter how universally charming or winning a movie or a performance might seem to be, there is always a chance that somebody, somewhere, will be able to resist it. For all I know that may be the case with “Queen of Katwe,” but if there is anyone out there capable of remaining unmoved by this true-life triumph-of-the-underdog sports story, I don’t think I want to meet that person.

headline: A Deadpan Hillary Clinton Visits ‘Between Two Ferns’
abstract: The comic Zach Galifianakis asked if she would be excited to be “the first girl president” and whether she would move to Canada if she lost to Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton, a candidate who has gone to great lengths to showcase the playful side of her personality, apparently wanted to prove that she can take not only a joke but a full interview of nonstop lampooning when she appeared on the mock celebrity interview show “Between Two Ferns.”

headline: With Boeing Deal, Americans Are Coming to Iran
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Boeing technicians, trainers and managers will be the first United States citizens to take up residence in Iran since 1980, when all 140,000 Americans there were forced to leave.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Long before the first newly purchased Boeing airliner lands at Imam Khomeini International Airport, Iran and the United States will have had to come to terms with a new reality: American citizens will once again be taking up residence in Tehran, the first to do so since the Islamic Revolution and subsequent hostage crisis in 1979 and 1980.

keywords: ['Chelsea, Manhattan Bombing (2016)', 'Terrorism', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Officials spoke with relief that no one died in the Chelsea bombing, but those injured suffered grievous wounds — to their bodies, and their psyches.
lead_paragraph: One man’s front teeth were knocked out. Another blacked out when his car was hit by the force of the blast. And one woman had to have ball bearings tweezed from her flesh, metal fragments removed from her ear and wood shards extracted from her neck.

headline: Apple Kicks the Tires at McLaren
abstract: A tech company and a maker of high-tech cars might seem like a good fit, but it’s hard to see how McLaren can take Apple’s vehicular ambitions far.

headline: Yahoo Says Hackers Stole Data on 500 Million Users in 2014
abstract: The company said user information was stolen by what it believed was a “state-sponsored actor,” without naming the country.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Yahoo announced on Thursday that the account information of at least 500 million users was stolen by hackers two years ago, in the biggest known intrusion of one company’s computer network.

headline: Eleven Artists Share Their Most Memorable Art-School Stories
abstract: In honor of MoMA PS1’s one-night-only reversion to its original function this weekend, T gathered coming-of-age reminiscences.
lead_paragraph: New York’s beloved kunsthalle in Long Island City, MoMA PS1, was a pioneering alternative art space when its founder Alanna Heiss converted a decommissioned public school into a full-time contemporary art center in 1971. This Friday evening, for the first time since then, school bells will ring to call PS1 to session in its original, pre-museum incarnation, in a festive subversion of T.G.I.F.

headline: When a Fashionable Photographer Shoots Her Own Relatives
abstract: Bea De Giacomo bonds with her family by photographing them in staged situations, for her ongoing series “La Casa Rosa.”
lead_paragraph: Bea De Giacomo bonds with her family by photographing them in staged situations, for her ongoing series “La Casa Rosa.”

keywords: ['International Relations', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change']
abstract: China has for decades chipped away at Taiwan’s global standing, but now the island is pushing back with behind-the-scenes diplomacy and soft power.
lead_paragraph: From her 12th-floor corner office overlooking the thrum of Manhattan’s East 42nd Street, Joanne Ou, a Taiwanese diplomat, can catch a glimpse of the motorcades ferrying foreign leaders to the United Nations General Assembly meeting a few blocks to the east.

headline: Don’t Waste Money on Premium Gas if Your Car Is Made for Regular
abstract: A new AAA report states that except in certain cases, premium offers no benefit and is a waste of money. However, brand-name fuels can still help.
lead_paragraph: With the typical new passenger vehicle costing more than $33,000, American drivers understandably want to do everything they can to preserve their investments.

headline: Photoville: Bigger, and Covering the Waterfront
abstract: Almost everything is bigger. Even the beer garden.
lead_paragraph: ALMOST everything is bigger at this year’s edition of Photoville, the annual Brooklyn photography festival that runs through Sunday in Dumbo. Even the beer garden.

keywords: ['Marriages', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: As the number of marriages in China declines, more and more young people are raising questions that upend traditional Chinese notions of love and family.
lead_paragraph: China has marriage on its mind — but perhaps not commitment.

headline: How I Got the Shot: A Discreetly Passed Note About the Location of a Terror Suspect
abstract: While other photographers were positioned to capture a swearing-in, Sam Hodgson had his eye out for something else.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares insights into how we work at The New York Times. In this installment of “How I Got the Shot,” Sam Hodgson, a freelance photographer, reveals that a Times push alert on his phone enabled him to be in the right spot at the right time.

abstract: Plus: Puglisi and MaxMara’s spring 2017 collections.
lead_paragraph: Plus: Puglisi and MaxMara’s spring 2017 collections.

headline: In the Wild, Goldfish Turn From Pet to Pest
abstract: Your pet goldfish may seem tiny and harmless. But in the wild, they can take down entire ecosystems.
lead_paragraph: Two decades ago, someone dropped a handful of unwanted pet goldfish into a creek in southwestern Australia. Those goldfish grew, swam downstream, mucked up waters wherever they went and spawned like mad. Before long, they took over the whole river.

headline: A Real-Life Black Beauty Is Cashing In on His Looks
abstract: Frederik the Great, a horse with a flowing mane and a legion of fans, is making appearances at a New York City horse show this weekend.
lead_paragraph: Fifteen hundred tons of synthetic dirt now sit in the middle of Wollman Rink in Central Park, hauled in a few days ago to transform the ice skating area into a parade ground for some of the world’s most prized horses. The Rolex Central Park Horse Show is meant to bring horses back to a city and a park with bridle paths that were once frequently used for riding. Champion ponies and renowned Olympic steeds will spend part of this week there in what are expected to be fierce competitions.

headline: JPMorgan May Face New Scrutiny in China Hiring Case
abstract: The bank’s top regulators are seeking to impose their own penalties in the China hiring case, according to people briefed on the investigations.
lead_paragraph: For the last three years, JPMorgan Chase’s hiring practices in China were at the center of a federal bribery investigation.

headline: Netanyahu and Abbas at U.N. General Assembly
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and the Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, continued to make their cases for peace at the United Nations on Thursday
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and the Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, continued to make their cases for peace at the United Nations on Thursday

headline: Review: Dance That Playfully Brings Art History to Life
abstract: John Jasperse’s “Remains,” currently at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, suggests a rummaging through collective memory.
lead_paragraph: It begins with a body, a woman lying curled and motionless onstage, possibly asleep. There’s a suggestion of story in the sparkly dress she wears. When she stirs, she moves languorously, and when, still reclining, she strikes an over-the-shoulder pose, you think of the odalisques of art history.

headline: ‘An American Tragedy’: Charlotte, Tulsa ...
abstract: Readers discuss the proliferation of guns, nonlethal ways to deal with suspects and giving first aid after police shootings.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How Pucci’s New Designer Reinterprets Vintage Pieces
abstract: For his spring/summer 2017 collection, Massimo Giorgetti drew inspiration from among the 18,000 garments in the house’s archives.
lead_paragraph: When Emilio Pucci — marquis of Barsento, Olympic skier, aviator and politician — whipped up his first stretch ski suits in 1947 and launched his own fashion label in 1951, he couldn’t have dreamed that, nearly 80 years later, his brand of kaleidoscope-print luxury wear would carry on his name.

headline: As Flagship Returns, South Street Museum Aims to Right Its Course
abstract: Damaged by Hurricane Sandy and dogged by financial problems, Manhattan museum is making a fresh start as the newly restored Wavertree sails back into port.
lead_paragraph: JONATHAN BOULWARE, executive director of the South Street Seaport Museum in Lower Manhattan, was talking about restoration, revitalization and return — the restoration, revitalization and return of a 131-year-old sailing ship. But he could just as easily have been talking about the museum itself.

headline: Review: In ‘The Undertaking,’ Considering the End With Some Laughter
abstract: The thought-provoking new show from the Civilians is a collage of testimonials drawn from people with a particular point of view on, or relationship with, mortality.
lead_paragraph: What’s your greatest fear? If you’re a normal, neurotic New Yorker, it’s probably the big inevitable: death.

headline: Review: ‘Storks,’ an Uneasy Return to Delivering Babies
abstract: A new animated film, aimed at young children, has an infant that needs a home and a bird on a mission.
lead_paragraph: Birds have been fine — memorable, even — as secondary characters in animated fare. Zazu in “The Lion King.” Scuttle in “The Little Mermaid.” But giving a bird or birds top billing is another matter, as demonstrated by “Storks.” This film, directed by Nicholas Stoller and Doug Sweetland, is a harmless enough way to occupy a youngster for an hour and a half. It’s just not especially rich in extraordinary characters or moments.

headline: How to Get the Bright, Matte Lips From the Runways
abstract: This season, makeup artists have painted pouts with shades from powder blue to traffic-cone orange.
lead_paragraph: This season, makeup artists have painted lips with bright, matte shades ranging from powder blue to traffic-cone orange. Here’s how they did it.

headline: Manslaughter Charge for Tulsa Officer Who Killed Black Driver
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: According to court documents, the officer was overcome with fear that the man was going to kill her.
lead_paragraph: TULSA, Okla. — The white police officer who fatally shot an unarmed black driver here last week as he stood outside his vehicle overreacted during a confrontation captured on video and was charged on Thursday with first-degree manslaughter, the authorities said.

headline: How to Get Prada’s Simple, Classic Beauty Look
keywords: ['Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Hair', 'Milan Fashion Week']
abstract: Makeup and hair at the spring/summer show was minimal — and reminiscent of the house’s past.
lead_paragraph: The Prada spring/summer 2017 collection was full of delicate, feminine pieces with off-kilter men’s wear touches — in other words, classic Prada. To accompany the clothing, the makeup artist Pat McGrath created a stripped down, natural look for the models’ faces — perfecting the skin with a little foundation, grooming the eyebrows, adding a touch of cream blush and mascara and, to finish, highlighting cheeks and eyes with nude Skin Fetish from her recently launched line, Pat McGrath Labs. “Mrs. Prada spoke about going back to the codes of Prada, and a nod to the past,” McGrath said backstage before the show, “So I kept things very simple and easy.”

headline: Review: In ‘The Dressmaker,’ a Femme Fatale Wants Vengeance
abstract: Tilly Dunnage (Kate Winslet) returns to the dusty Australian hometown where she was bullied by a rich kid and blamed for his death.
lead_paragraph: “I’m back, you bastards.”

headline: Yahoo Says It Was Hacked. Here’s How to Protect Yourself.
abstract: Simple tips to follow if you think your personal information online has been exposed to hackers.
lead_paragraph: Simple tips to follow if you think your personal information online has been exposed to hackers.

headline: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
abstract: Art in review, from critics for The Times.
lead_paragraph: Marcus Garvey Park, Morningside Park, St. Nicholas Park and Jackie Robinson Park Through July 25

headline: Review: In ‘Seed: The Untold Story,’ It’s Farmers Versus Big Business
abstract: This documentary raises alarm about declining crop diversity, genetically altered seeds and the ownership of nature.
lead_paragraph: “Seed: The Untold Story” is one of those documentaries that get you riled up about a situation but leave you feeling that nothing significant can be done about it.

headline: A Peek at House Members Before Recess, in Three Snippets
abstract: Members are trying to keep busy while the Senate brokers a spending deal to keep the lights on in the federal government and shut them off in the Capitol.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — These are the final days of this pre-election Congress, the last chance to make an impression for Americans to carry to the voting booth. Nowhere is this clearer than in the House, where members are trying to keep busy while the Senate brokers a spending deal to simultaneously keep the lights on in the federal government and shut them off in the halls of Congress as everyone heads home to campaign.

headline: Review: It’s Jane Jacobs’s World We Live In
abstract: Robert Kanigel’s flawed book is the largest and most comprehensive biography of a heroic figure of intellectual life in the second half of the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: Jane Jacobs (1916-2006) was a heroic figure of intellectual life in the second half of the 20th century, and she is nearly always instructive and cheering to read about.

headline: Review: A Safe Start to Alan Gilbert’s Final Season With the Philharmonic
abstract: The season-opening gala concert included the New York premiere of John Corigliano’s “STOMP” and an animated performance by the pianist Aaron Diehl.
lead_paragraph: Alan Gilbert began his tenure as music director of the New York Philharmonic in September  2009 by turning the traditional season-opening gala concert into a strong statement of artistic purpose. Conductors at orchestras everywhere are under institutional pressure to make these gala programs, which also function as fund-raisers for patrons, light and festive. Mr. Gilbert’s inaugural challenged this notion.

headline: Review: In ‘The Ruins of Lifta,’ a Dispute Amid the Rubble
abstract: This documentary by Menachem Daum and Oren Rudavsky focuses on the fate of an old Arab village on the outskirts of Jerusalem.
lead_paragraph: Among the hills on the western outskirts of Jerusalem stands an abandoned group of stone buildings, the remains of Lifta, an Arab village whose residents were driven out in 1948, during what Israelis know as the War of Independence and what Palestinians call the Nakba (Catastrophe). Plans to demolish the homes and build a new development have drawn opposition from an Israeli-Palestinian coalition seeking to preserve the site.

headline: Good, Bad and Mad: Times Opinion Columnist Andrew Rosenthal on the News
abstract: Times Opinion columnist Andrew Rosenthal on the Chelsea bombing, racial profiling, Lewis Black, and Times Op-Docs. Susan Lehman is host.
lead_paragraph: Times Opinion columnist Andrew Rosenthal on the Chelsea bombing, racial profiling, Lewis Black, and Times Op-Docs. Susan Lehman is host.

headline: The Paintings Are Delicate. The Show’s a Shambles.
abstract: Kai Althoff’s major exhibition at MoMA features more than 200 works folded into a confusing installation of found materials.
lead_paragraph: Some artists may be at odds with their own talents and wish they could be something more than they are. A spectacular example of such a conflicted creative sensibility is “Kai Althoff: and then leave me to the common swifts (und dann überlasst mich den Mauerseglern)” at the Museum of Modern Art, which has more than 200 of Mr. Althoff’s poetically allusive, delicately made paintings, drawings and sculptures folded into an unfortunately messy and confusing installation of found materials.

headline: Review: ‘1000 Rupee Note,’ a Poor Widow’s Blessing and Curse
abstract: In this film, set in the Maharashtra State of India, a villager sets off on a fraught shopping trip after receiving a few 1,000-rupee notes at a political rally.
lead_paragraph: It’s not every day you see a film in Marathi. But Shrihari Sathe’s “1000 Rupee Note,” true to its origins in the Maharashtra State of India, is told in a dialect of that language.

headline: Siblings Who Don’t Play Nice After a Mother’s Death
abstract: Also, a cake-baking nanny and a silent office mate.
lead_paragraph: It has been two years since my mother died, and the Jewish holidays are around the corner again. The problem: They are stressful and not much fun without her. My siblings and I, in our 20s and 30s, do a lot of sniping, and our dad seems mostly checked out. I know that everyone is trying; no one always plays the villain. But too often, family occasions end in hurt feelings. Do you think it’s possible to repair this situation? Or should I just stop going and deal with the fallout?

headline: Good, Bad and Mad: Andrew Rosenthal on the News
keywords: ['Chelsea, Manhattan Bombing (2016)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Times Opinion columnist Andrew Rosenthal on the Chelsea bombing, racial profiling, Lewis Black, and Times Op-Docs.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this podcast, Andrew Rosenthal, a Times Op-Ed columnist, talks about the news — the good, the bad and that which makes him mad.

headline: Call Him an Early Adopter: Thomas Child, a 19th-Century Photographer in China
abstract: His work captured scenes from the Qing dynasty that will be in an exhibition at the Sidney Mishkin Gallery at Baruch College in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Child, a British engineer, traveled to China in 1870 for work but was so entranced by the scenery and culture that he stayed for nearly two decades. He imported cameras to set up a sideline business as a portrait and landscape photographer, and his works were published in magazines and books. He also marketed them to tourists and dignitaries. The accompanying texts were a mix of admiration and condescension for traditions that Westerners of the time considered primitive.

headline: Review: ‘My Blind Brother,’ Who Is Also a Major Pain
abstract: Sibling rivalry arises between an arrogant blind athlete and his helpful underdog brother when they end up in a love triangle with an appealing young woman.
lead_paragraph: In “My Blind Brother,” Robbie (Adam Scott) is a world-class jerk, an athlete who brags about his achievements. He also happens to be blind, and during sporting events is guided by his brother, Bill (Nick Kroll), introduced — exhausted and sweaty — running beside him in a marathon to raise money for blind children.

headline: Moschino: Spring 2017
abstract: Jeremy Scott shows his latest Pop-infused collection.
lead_paragraph: Jeremy Scott shows his latest Pop-infused collection.

headline: Elizabeth Dee Gallery Is Ready to Take On Harlem
abstract: Ms. Dee, who closed her Chelsea gallery in January, has an open house on Saturday in her new two-story space. She discusses trying to carve out a Harlem gallery scene.
lead_paragraph: It’s too soon to declare Chelsea over.

headline: Review: ‘The Jazz Loft According to W. Eugene Smith’
abstract: When Smith, an esteemed photojournalist, moved to the flower district in Manhattan in the 1950s, he started shooting and taping his neighbors for almost a decade.
lead_paragraph: In the last years of the 1950s, the esteemed American photojournalist W. Eugene Smith was at a personal and professional crossroads. Several years spent on a productive but ultimately abortive project (documenting the city of Pittsburgh) forced him to sell his large home in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. His marriage ended. He acquired a Manhattan loft on Avenue of the Americas in the 20s — then known as the flower district — where his immediate neighbors were up-all-night musicians. A different resident might have complained of the noise. But Smith, whose predilection for recording eventually developed into something like a mania, started shooting and taping, and kept at it for almost a decade.

headline: Theater Listings for Sept. 23-29
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.

headline: Donald Trump’s Real Message on Race
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Search and Seizure', 'Discrimination', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: He claims his “movement” is for “everybody,” but his supporters know what he’s really saying.
lead_paragraph: The more Donald Trump presses his supposed effort to appeal to black voters, the more bizarre it gets.

headline: ‘Cosima von Bonin,’ Swimming Against the Tide
abstract: This SculptureCenter show owes as much to “Finding Nemo” as it does to Manet, Whistler and other artists who turned to the sea.
lead_paragraph: This world, Hamlet tells us, is a sea of troubles; love, every pop star will assure you, is as deep as an ocean. For the versatile, sometimes inscrutable German sculptor Cosima von Bonin, too, the sea is a metaphor for our own lives, and she brings to our dry environment visitors from the deep. Hermit crabs and octopuses flounce on furniture, burdened by all too human anxieties. Clams stare out of their shells, their goggle eyes bearing down on you as if they know your secrets.

headline: Review: In ‘I.T.,’ Smart House, Dumb Owner
abstract: This thriller features a computer-controlled home owned by a businessman who isn’t very savvy when it comes to guarding his privacy from wrongdoers.
lead_paragraph: Wishing you had one of those “smart houses,” where there are cameras everyplace, and the plumbing and lighting and appliances are all computer-controlled? The thriller “I.T.” could save you a lot of money. It will make you grateful that you live in an old-fashioned dumb house.

headline: Review: Sagas, Swashbuckling and Scheherazade in ‘1001 Nights’
abstract: Robert Lopez, a songwriter for “Frozen,” and Adam Koplan created this Atlantic for Kids adaptation, an exuberant musical with both actors and puppets.
lead_paragraph: Poor Scheherazade. You couldn’t have blamed her if she’d had trouble keeping her head. “The Arabian Nights” gave her little recourse: Use it or lose it.

headline: Wage Campaign at Port Authority Hits an Impasse
keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'Minimum Wage', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Living Wage', 'AIRPORTS']
abstract: The agency’s commissioners mostly split along state lines when they voted on two proposals for raising the pay scale, frustrating employees’ yearslong push for what they consider a living wage.
lead_paragraph: Angering a vocal crowd of unionized airport workers, the commissioners of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey hit an impasse on Thursday over proposals for raising the agency’s minimum wage.

headline: Charlotte, Yahoo, U.S. Presidential Race: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Wells Fargo Tests Justice Department’s Get-Tough Approach
abstract: Guidelines issued last year by the Justice Department stressed the need to hold individuals accountable for corporate misdeeds.
lead_paragraph: In response to widespread public criticism that the government has been too lenient with executives responsible for corporate crime, Deputy Attorney General Sally Quillian Yates issued tough new guidelines last year for federal prosecutors.

headline: They Found Bombs on a Beer Run. What Gratitude Are They Owed?
abstract: Almost as soon as Ahmad Khan Rahami was taken into custody, an online campaign for two Elizabeth, N.J., men was started as a show of thanks. A backlash developed just as quickly.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday evening, the day after a bomb exploded on West 23rd Street in Manhattan, Lee Parker visited his friend Ivan White at his apartment in Elizabeth, N.J., to borrow some clothes for a job interview the next morning and to watch some football. Mr. Parker had been struggling to find work for the past few years; he was laid off after Hurricane Sandy and had been sleeping on a series of sofas belonging to friends for some time. The interview the following day was for work at a trucking company. Mr. Parker had mentioned to Mr. White that in addition to a new outfit, he wished he had a new backpack.

headline: Review: In ‘Goat,’ Frat Brothers Unleash Their Sadistic Terror
abstract: Nick Jonas and Ben Schnetzer star in this disturbing tale about the urge to belong, no matter what the cost.
lead_paragraph: A credible and dispiriting chronicle of late-adolescent male toxicity, “Goat,” adapted from a 2004 memoir by Brad Land, begins with a senseless assault. The quiet, seemingly sensible Brad (Ben Schnetzer) bails on a college party his older brother, Brett (Nick Jonas), has allowed him to attend, and is waylaid by a couple of local lowlifes. Brad nevertheless resolves to go to Brett’s school, and pledge his frat.

headline: Shove Over. I Want Back on the Grid.
abstract: A visit to a rustic country cabin makes one long for the city’s chaos (and the phone service).
lead_paragraph: The three words that terrify me most are “off the grid,” so it’s a testament to our friendship that I visit my pal Joyce (yeah, same name) in her off-the-grid cabin in the Catskills every summer.

headline: Donald Trump, in Pittsburgh, Pledges to Boost Both Coal and Gas
abstract: But experts said the Republican nominee’s plan won’t work, because natural gas fracking is the surest way to stymie coal production, and vice versa.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump on Thursday traveled to Pittsburgh, a city once synonymous with the rich coal seam that runs beneath it and now the capital of natural gas fracking, to promise the impossible: a boom for both coal and gas.

headline: Jerusalem as a Place of Desire and Death, at the Metropolitan Museum
abstract: The exhibition “Jerusalem 1000-1400: Every People Under Heaven” looks at the past and the present, with 200 works from some 60 international collections.
lead_paragraph: Arrows of desire: Jerusalem has been aiming them at the hearts of pilgrims, tourists and potentates for thousands of years. And the complex sensations the stings can deliver — exhilarating, devastating — is what the Metropolitan Museum of Art captures in “Jerusalem 1000-1400: Every People Under Heaven.”

headline: Review: ‘The Exorcist’ Reboots a Battle Against a Demonic Presence
abstract: Inspired by the memorably scary 1973 movie, a new Fox series starring Geena Davis, Ben Daniels and Alfonso Herrera enlists two contrasting priests.
lead_paragraph: “The Exorcist,” a horror series that begins Friday on Fox, has two demons to fight. Some viewers will be measuring it against what they consider to be one of the scariest movies the genre has ever produced, the 1973 film directed by William Friedkin. Others, schooled on decades’ worth of parodies of that same movie (especially its projectile-vomiting and 360-degree-head-spinning scenes), will be on the lookout for anything in the TV show that might be laughably ineffective or pretentious.

headline: Review: ‘Debate Wars,’ Where Nothing Is Too Frivolous for Argument
abstract: This hilarious show, on Seeso, is almost certainly more fun than anything that will come out of the presidential debates.
lead_paragraph: Whatever happens in Monday night’s presidential debate, it’s unlikely to be anywhere near as entertaining as the goings-on in “Debate Wars,” six episodes of which went up on Thursday on Seeso, the comedy streaming service.

headline: Review: In ‘Closet Monster,’ a Teenager’s Self-Discovery Is Tinged With Danger
abstract: An entrancing coming-of-age story about a young man at odds with his sexuality, and haunted by what he witnessed as a boy.
lead_paragraph: You may find yourself hoping that “Closet Monster” fades to black during one of its few cheerful scenes — that way, the conflicted young man at its center will get a happy ending. This affecting film prompts that kind of concern for its characters. You want them to be safe.

headline: Review: In ‘The Free World,’ Being Free Isn’t All It’s Cracked Up to Be
abstract: Jason Lew’s directorial debut features a man wrongly imprisoned for a crime he didn’t commit who risks everything to help an abused wife.
lead_paragraph: Boyd Holbrook’s performance in “The Free World” is so intense in its compressed fury that you can almost see steam coming out of his ears. An approximate ’80s Mel Gibson look-alike, Mr. Holbrook plays Mo Lundy, a recently released prisoner who served time in the Louisiana State Penitentiary for murders he did not commit.

headline: Review: An Unflinching Portrayal of Impending Mortality in ‘Chronic’
abstract: The first English-language film from Michel Franco, centering on a stoop-shouldered caregiver for terminally ill patients, ends with a blow to your equilibrium.
lead_paragraph: In the quietly devastating “Chronic,” Tim Roth, never more impressive onscreen, plays David, a palliative care worker whose intimacy with death and dying both scares and shames family members who nervously peek in on loved ones they have more or less abandoned. The first English-language film by Michel Franco, the Mexican director of “After Lucia,” a harrowing study of high school bullying, “Chronic” stands back from its characters, which it views with a cold documentarylike detachment.

headline: Review: In ‘The Lovers and the Despot,’ a Harrowing Korean Ordeal
abstract: This documentary looks at how and why a South Korean actress, Choi Eun-hee, and a once successful film director, Shin Sang-ok, landed in North Korea.
lead_paragraph: Every so often a documentary has such a head-shakingly bizarre story that alone makes it worth seeing. If you follow the news, this one may sound familiar: In 1986, a popular South Korean actress, Choi Eun-hee, and her ex-husband, a once-successful film director, Shin Sang-ok, entered the United States Embassy in Vienna and said that years earlier they had been kidnapped by North Korea — where they had been held against their will — and were now seeking asylum. It was stranger than fiction and also true (mostly, maybe).

headline: Review: In ‘The Age of Shadows,’ Plot’s Fine, but Action’s Better
abstract: Kim Jee-woon’s new action movie takes place in Korea in the 1920s, when the country was under Japanese occupation.
lead_paragraph: Like a reader skimming a novel to find the juicy parts, Kim Jee-woon gets through the story dutifully enough in “The Age of Shadows.” But this director is really looking to stage the action sequences, which he prolongs and savors once they arrive.

headline: Review: ‘Audrie & Daisy,’ on Sexual Assault and Technology
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Movies', 'Web-Original Programming']
abstract: Audrey Pott committed suicide. Daisy Coleman spoke out against the legal system. This documentary tells their stories.
lead_paragraph: The Netflix documentary “Audrie & Daisy” is intended to spread awareness of teenage sexual assaults and how technology can amplify their ramifications.

headline: Email Hack Details Movements of Joe Biden, Michelle Obama and Hillary Clinton
abstract: Emails from a Democratic operative posted online reveal not only detailed schedules of officials but also personal information of donors and Secret Service agents.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hackers on Thursday posted hundreds of emails from a young Democratic operative that contained documents detailing the minute-by-minute schedules and precise movements of the vice president, the first lady and Hillary Clinton during recent campaign fund-raisers and official political events.

headline: Review: ‘Chicken People,’ Pampering Royalty That Clucks
abstract: This documentary, directed by Nicole Lucas Haimes, looks at devotees of these fair fowl on the show circuit.
lead_paragraph: They hold grudges. They have best friends. They aren’t big on foreplay, and you can revive them with mouth-to-mouth resuscitation if they choke during a shampoo.

headline: Government Moves to Close a Watchdog of For-Profit Colleges
abstract: The Education Department said a staff report found a body that had overseen failing institutions like Corinthian Colleges and ITT had fallen short.
lead_paragraph: The Education Department on Thursday moved to shut down the nation’s largest accreditor of for-profit colleges, which had stood watch as failing institutions like Corinthian Colleges and ITT Technical Institute teetered on a pileup of fraud investigations.

headline: Gigi Hadid Fights Off a Fashion Week Nuisance
abstract: The model stands up for herself on Twitter following a strange incident in Milan.
lead_paragraph: Oversize black sunglasses perched on her nose, the model Gigi Hadid made her way out of the Max Mara show on Thursday in Milan, pausing to smile for selfies with a few fans. As she moved through the paparazzi gaggle, a bearded man in a wide-brimmed hat and reflective sunglasses wrapped his arms around her waist from behind and lifted her into the air.

headline: Comedy Listings for Sept. 23-29
abstract: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.

headline: Movie Listings for Sept. 23-29
abstract: A guide to movies playing at theaters in the New York City area, as well as select festivals and film series.
lead_paragraph: A guide to movies playing at theaters in the New York City area, as well as select festivals and film series.

headline: Harvard, Searching for Endowment Manager, Reports a Loss
abstract: Harvard’s showing comes after years of poor performance as a series of investment chiefs have come and gone.
lead_paragraph: Harvard is looking for a new manager for its endowment, the largest of any university. And based on results announced on Thursday, there will be plenty of room for improvement.

headline: Why the World Forgot the Israeli-Palestinian Conflict
abstract: In the past, Mahmoud Abbas and Benjamin Netanyahu dominated the United Nations General Assembly, but this year, they were overshadowed by concerns over Syria and ISIS.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — They took the stage, one after the other, two aging actors in a long-running drama that has begun to lose its audience. As the Israeli and Palestinian leaders recited their lines in the grand hall of the United Nations General Assembly on Thursday, many in the orchestra seats recognized the script.

headline: Keith Scott’s Killing by Police Emerges as Issue in Tight North Carolina Race
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voting and Voters', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump seized on the shooting and protests in Charlotte, but it was unclear whether they could sway undecided voters.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — The  protests filling television screens since a police shooting here have added a volatile new element to the presidential race in North Carolina, where the candidates are locked in fierce competition.

headline: Presenting America’s Newest Comedy Team: Mel Brooks and Obama
abstract: Mel Brooks stole the show at a White House ceremony in which President Obama awarded National Medals of Arts and Humanities to an “impressive crew.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Mel Brooks performed a bit of slapstick near the portrait of George Washington. President Obama tried his hand at stand-up comedy beside his lectern. Audra McDonald almost missed her moment on stage.

headline: One Upside of Living in a Walk-Up
abstract: A delayed delivery underscores what can go wrong with elevators.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Classical Music Listings for Sept. 23-29
abstract: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area.

headline: Yankees’ Playoff Hopes Wane With Shutout and Injury to Masahiro Tanaka
abstract: Tanaka, the Yankees’ ace, will miss his next start, an unwelcome blow as Tampa Bay pushed the Yankees further back in the wild-card race.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — When Yankees Manager Joe Girardi, sitting in the dugout before Wednesday’s game, was asked about the surprisingly sturdy health of his starting pitchers this season, he did not wait for the question to be finished.

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for Sept. 23-29
abstract: A selected guide to concerts in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to concerts in the New York City area.

headline: The Wells Fargo Spillover Effect
abstract: The company has agreed on fines, but top managers have not been punished in the opening of millions of unauthorized accounts.
lead_paragraph: At a Senate hearing on Tuesday, John Stumpf, the chairman and chief executive of Wells Fargo, gave the Banking Committee a non-apology for the bank’s pervasive abuse of customers.

headline: Jazz Listings for Sept. 23-29
abstract: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.

headline: Police Videos, Kept Private, Fuel Tensions in Charlotte
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: A police chief’s decision to show dashboard and body camera videos from the killing of Keith L. Scott only to Mr. Scott’s family raised questions about North Carolina’s policies.
lead_paragraph: The release of official videos has become a significant point of contention in the aftermath of the fatal police shooting of a 43-year-old black man on Tuesday in Charlotte, N.C.

headline: Teodoro González de León, Evocative Mexican Architect, Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. González de León, in various settings, reimagined the tenets of Modernism in a Mexican context.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Teodoro González de León, an architect who fused the legacy of Mexico’s pre-Hispanic past with European Modernism to design some of his country’s most distinctive public buildings, died on Sept. 16 in Mexico City. He was 90.

headline: Dance Listings for Sept. 23-29
abstract: A selected guide to dance performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to dance performances in New York City.

headline: Shooting Victim Keith L. Scott Lived Sometimes Troubled but Quiet Life
abstract: Those who knew Mr. Scott, a father of seven, present a different picture from the one presented by the police.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Before Keith L. Scott joined a growing list of black men killed by the police and before his death became the center of violent protests here, he lived a sometimes troubled but relatively quiet life in a close-knit family.

headline: Release the Charlotte Police Video
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Editorials']
abstract: In the face of concern and anger over killings by the police, transparency would be the wisest course, but some cities and states are resisting this.
lead_paragraph: Elected officials who have paid any attention to the killings of civilians by the police that have roiled several cities in recent years should understand that keeping the public in the dark heightens tension and undermines trust in law enforcement.

headline: In San Francisco, a Sinking Skyscraper and a Deepening Dispute
abstract: A public scandal has raised doubts about whether skyscraper development has been properly monitored by building officials and city authorities.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The developers of the luxurious Millennium Tower laid out the risks and potential defects of the 58-story building in minute detail when its apartments went on sale seven years ago.

headline: Mets Scratch Steven Matz as Shoulder Concerns Return
abstract: Matz, who had not pitched since Aug. 14 because of rotator cuff irritation, threw a bullpen session in hopes of starting against the Phillies on Friday, then woke up with familiar symptoms.
lead_paragraph: As soon as a Mets athletic trainer appeared in Manager Terry Collins’s office on Thursday afternoon, Collins shook his head. In a season defined by nicks and bruises up and down the roster, Collins had a hunch the injury news was about Steven Matz.

headline: Nike Tosses Its Golf Clubs. (Shirts to Stay On.)
abstract: Because of unsatisfactory sales, the company will shut down production of golf clubs and balls, but it will continue to produce its popular golf apparel.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — So, who comes to mind when you think of golf and Nike?

headline: Museum & Gallery Listings for Sept. 23-29
abstract: A critical guide to exhibitions and installations in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: A critical guide to exhibitions and installations in the New York area.

headline: Around Town for Sept. 23-29
abstract: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.

headline: Fatal Shooting by Police Shakes Charlotte’s Self-Image
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: After decades in which it willed itself to big-city status, Charlotte, in the last decade, has had to grapple with a host of big-city problems.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE — This has always been a place that has prided itself on order, consensus and a can-do corporate mentality that turned a locale with no real geographic reason to exist into one of the hemisphere’s financial dynamos.

headline: Anthony Weiner Faces New Scrutiny After Report About Girl, 15
abstract: A federal subpoena seeks records pertaining to allegations that Mr. Weiner, an ex-congressman married to a Hillary Clinton aide, traded sexually explicit messages with a teenager.
lead_paragraph: Federal authorities in New York have issued a subpoena for records pertaining to allegations that Anthony D. Weiner exchanged sexually explicit messages with a 15-year-old girl, a person with knowledge of the matter said.

headline: Obama Puts Syria at Arm’s Length as Carnage Drags On
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The president scarcely mentioned the war in a farewell address to the United Nations General Assembly, typical of the approach he has taken on the world stage in recent weeks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Secretary of State John Kerry took the floor at the United Nations on Wednesday to deliver a searing denunciation of the airstrike on an aid convoy headed for the Syrian city of Aleppo President Obama was crosstown, at his Manhattan hotel, preparing for a day of diplomacy that included Africa, Israel and Colombia — but, conspicuously, not Syria.

headline: Donald Trump’s Crime Policies Might Hit Minorities Harder, Experts Say
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Racial Profiling', 'Minorities', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: Civil rights activists and national security veterans fear Mr. Trump’s plan could have the effect of treating minorities with suspicion and singling them out for scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: Branding himself the “law-and-order candidate,” Donald J. Trump has vowed to carry out a crackdown on crime and terrorism that would benefit white Americans and racial minorities alike.

headline: A New York School Where Students Learn to Read by Sculpting Words
abstract: At the Windward School in Manhattan, children with learning disabilities learn to connect words to their meanings through multiple senses, including shaping letters out of clay.
lead_paragraph: Cut into syllables, one of Wednesday’s vocabulary words was displayed on the board in Rachel Schiff’s fourth-grade classroom in Manhattan.

headline: Spare Times for Children Listings for Sept. 23-29
abstract: A select guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: A select guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families.

headline: Physicist in Albany Corruption Case Was a Geek With Big Goals
abstract: Alain E. Kaloyeros rose from a university laboratory to oversee hundreds of millions of dollars in state economic development funds. Beyond money, the rewards he sought seemed mostly to involve power.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — For eight of the nine defendants charged on Thursday in the wide-ranging bribery and bid-rigging scheme surrounding Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s economic development programs in upstate and Western New York, the motive for the alleged crime seemed to be simple, old-fashioned greed.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Friday, September 23, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “I have not overcome it, not even a little. It is something that haunts me, and you don’t survive.”

headline: Muslim Brotherhood’s Political Arm Wins Seats in Jordan’s Parliament
abstract: Most seats in the lower house were retained by pro-monarchy loyalists, election results showed, but Islamists and women made gains.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — Members of the political arm of the opposition Muslim Brotherhood won seats in Jordan’s Parliament in a symbolic comeback, and women increased their numbers in the legislature, according to results of parliamentary elections released on Thursday.

headline: John D. Loudermilk, Who Wrote ‘Tobacco Road’ and ‘Indian Reservation,’ Dies at 82
abstract: The country singer and songwriter wrote dozens of hits in the 1960s and ’70s, performed by artists including Eddie Cochran and Paul Revere and the Raiders.
lead_paragraph: John D. Loudermilk, a country singer and prolific songwriter whose dozens of hits in the 1960s and ’70s included “Tobacco Road” by the Nashville Teens, “Then You Can Tell Me Goodbye” by the Casinos and “Indian Reservation” by Paul Revere and the Raiders, died on Wednesday at his home in Christiana, Tenn. He was 82.

headline: One Making Waves
abstract: Andrew Zhou begins our solving weekend with a crunchy challenge.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — If you’re going to push yourself to do the late-week puzzles, you might want to practice on a puzzle like Andrew Zhou’s, which allows you to succeed while feeling slightly naughty: You may feel challenged by the more obscure entries and tougher clues, but you can find just enough “gettable” entries to keep you going. Today’s puzzle will require you to tough it out for quite a while, but you’re definitely solving with the pros now.

headline: Canada and China Will Enter Trade Talks, Justin Trudeau Says
abstract: The announcement was the latest of Mr. Trudeau’s efforts to develop stronger ties. He said he hoped to double trade with China by 2025.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Canada and China will begin talks that may lead to a free-trade agreement, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said Thursday.

headline: Closing Arguments Are Made in Trial Over Potsdam Boy’s Killing
abstract: The fate of Oral Nicholas Hillary, who is accused of killing Garrett Phillips, the 12-year-old son of Mr. Hillary’s former girlfriend, now rests with Judge Felix J. Catena.
lead_paragraph: CANTON, N.Y. — After nearly five years of living under suspicion, Oral Nicholas Hillary — accused of murder, and steadfastly proclaiming his innocence — is about to have his fate decided by a single man.

headline: Rahm Emanuel Proposes More Police and Mentors to Stop Chicago’s Cascading Violence
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Youth', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Gun Control', 'Gangs']
abstract: Chicago’s soaring rate of murders and shootings this year has captured national attention and become an issue in the presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Faced with intensifying pressure to solve this city’s cascading violence, Mayor Rahm Emanuel on Thursday evening laid out what he described as a comprehensive plan for public safety: more police, more mentors, more jobs.

headline: New Charges for Long Island Foster Father Accused of Abusing Boys
abstract: Cesar Gonzales-Mugaburu, who is charged with sexually abusing five of his adopted sons, pleaded not guilty in Suffolk County court after being accused of abusing another young boy.
lead_paragraph: A longtime foster father, already accused of sexually abusing five of his adopted sons and endangering the welfare of two foster children, was charged on Thursday with abusing another boy in his home on Long Island.

headline: Indictment of Long Island Foster Father
abstract: Cesar Gonzales-Mugaburu, a longtime foster father already accused of sexually abusing five of his adopted sons and endangering the welfare of two foster children, was charged on Thursday with abusing another young boy in his home on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: Cesar Gonzales-Mugaburu, a longtime foster father already accused of sexually abusing five of his adopted sons and endangering the welfare of two foster children, was charged on Thursday with abusing another young boy in his home on Long Island.

headline: Ike Davis, Back in New York, Leads Israel Past Britain in World Baseball Classic Qualifier
abstract: Israel, composed largely of Jewish American minor leaguers and former major leaguers, got considerable support from a partisan crowd at Coney Island stadium.
lead_paragraph: Ike Davis spoke Thursday about his affection for New York — the state and the city. He began his professional career with the Brooklyn Cyclones in this Coney Island stadium. Eventually, he would spend minor league seasons in Buffalo and Binghamton, and play in five seasons with the Mets and eight games with the Yankees.

headline: Antiques Dealers Charged in Illegal Sale of Ivory Priced at $4.5 Million
abstract: The Manhattan district attorney, Cyrus R. Vance Jr., expressed outrage that stores in New York continued to profit from ivory sales, even after the Legislature had banned them except in limited cases.
lead_paragraph: One chilly day last November, two well-dressed men walked into the Metropolitan Fine Arts and Antiques store on West 57th Street in Manhattan, looking for Chinese figurines carved from ivory.

headline: Jacoby Brissett Proves More Than Capable in Patriots’ Rout of Texans
abstract: Brissett, the rookie third-string quarterback, avoided major mistakes and added a rushing element to New England’s offense in the win.
lead_paragraph: It did not look much like Tom Brady’s version of the New England Patriots, but when Jacoby Brissett rolled over the right tackle on a bootleg and sprinted for the end zone in the first quarter of Thursday night’s game against the Houston Texans, he made quite a statement about his readiness for the N.F.L.

headline: Asdrubal Cabrera’s 3-Run Homer Pushes Mets Past Phillies in 11 Innings
abstract: In a back-and-forth game, Philadelphia went ahead by two runs in the top of the 11th, but Cabrera’s blast saved the Mets from absorbing their fourth straight loss.
lead_paragraph: The baseball season is arduously long and rewards the emotionally even-keeled, so forgive Asdrubal Cabrera if, in one dramatic moment, it all came pouring out. When he made contact, he instantly knew what had happened. Unlike one the night before, this home run ball was not getting robbed at the fence. It was not going to hook foul as one had earlier on Thursday night.

lead_paragraph: A United States representative from North Carolina said in a television interview on Thursday that protesters in Charlotte “hate white people because white people are successful and they’re not,” and then hours later recanted and apologized.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading by the editors of The New York Times Book Review.
lead_paragraph: I know, the number of big books out each fall is intimidating — even this month, when publishers put off a lot of big fiction until after the election. This week we’ve got the best books related to the election itself (there aren’t many, to be honest). And then we’ve got some smart and entertaining counterprogramming.

headline: ‘The Savory Collection,’ a Mythical Trove of Jazz Recordings, Will Get a Digital Release
abstract: The recordings, from the archives of the sound engineer Bill Savory, will finally be available to the public via the National Jazz Museum and Apple Music.
lead_paragraph: A major jazz discovery will finally be commercially accessible to the public, courtesy of the National Jazz Museum in Harlem and Apple Music, which have partnered to release “The Savory Collection” in digital form. A series of archival recordings from the 1930s and early ’40s, from radio broadcasts taped by the pioneering sound engineer Bill Savory, it’s a revelatory body of music that had been cloaked in myth and obscurity for many years.

lead_paragraph: There are few legal fights more lopsided than landlords suing to evict their lower-income tenants.

headline: The Lying Game
abstract: In covering the presidential debates, and the campaign, the press needs to stand up for the truth amid Donald Trump’s fairy tales.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what we can be fairly sure will happen in Monday’s presidential debate: Donald Trump will lie repeatedly and grotesquely, on a variety of subjects. Meanwhile, Hillary Clinton might say a couple of untrue things. Or she might not.

headline: Will the Left Survive the Millennials?
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Books and Literature', 'Youth', 'Censorship', 'Millennial Generation', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Liberals used to defend the free speech of nonconformists. No longer.
lead_paragraph: Midway through my opening address for the Brisbane Writers Festival earlier this month, Yassmin Abdel-Magied, a Sudanese-born Australian engineer and 25-year-old memoirist, walked out. Her indignant comments about the event might have sunk into obscurity, along with my speech, had they not been republished by The Guardian. Twenty minutes in, this audience member apparently turned to her mother: “ ‘Mama, I can’t sit here,’ I said, the corners of my mouth dragging downwards. ‘I cannot legitimize this.’ ” She continued: “The faces around me blurred. As my heels thudded against the grey plastic of the flooring, harmonizing with the beat of the adrenaline pumping through my veins, my mind was blank save for one question. ‘How is this happening?’ ”

headline: Audiobooks Turn More Readers Into Listeners as E-Books Slip
abstract: Publishers saw their revenue dip early this year compared with 2015, in part because they lacked a runaway hit and the sales of e-books fell sharply.
lead_paragraph: Sales of paperback books are up. Independent bookstores are thriving again. The threat of a digital apocalypse has subsided, as e-book sales have tumbled.

headline: Brendan Cox: Carrying On Jo’s Work Against Hate
keywords: ['Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: My wife, a British member of Parliament, was murdered in June amid a swirl of xenophobia. I’m dedicated to turning that horror to good.
lead_paragraph: All our lives, Jo and I had been optimists. Almost by instinct, we both believed that the world was getting better and that it would continue to do so.

abstract: The company had been sold for $2.6 billion in 2014 by a group of Nordic banks to a consortium that included Advent International and Bain Capital.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Nets, a Danish payments processor, said on Friday that it was valued at 30 billion Danish kroner, or about $4.5 billion, in its initial public stock offering in Copenhagen.

headline: How to Find the Right Cruise for You
abstract: For getting the most out of a cruise, decide if you want a lot of amenities (large ship) or a boutique-hotel atmosphere (smaller).
lead_paragraph: Whether your idea of a vacation is to sleep until noon and while away afternoons sipping margaritas by a pool or wake up early for a nonstop day of sightseeing, there is a cruise for you — one that fits your budget, too. “Cruises today cater to every kind of traveler,” said Judy Perl, a cruise specialist and the founder of the New York City travel consultancy Judy Perl Worldwide Travel. Gone are the days, she said, when a cruise vacation was only about midnight buffets and spending a half-day at a port before moving on to the next one. Here, she shares her top tips for finding a trip to suit your travel style.

headline: When a Couch Is More Than a Couch
abstract: For a young mother with terminal cancer, questions about her own mortality merge with decisions about upholstery and cushion width.
lead_paragraph: Were I healthy enough these days, I would be sipping a glass of free wine and running my hands over an exquisite accent pillow in an impossibly hip showroom called something like Space or Lust, while a sales assistant speaks to me of the virtues of aniline versus semi-aniline leather.

headline: Moments of Giants Glory: What Alzheimer’s Couldn’t Steal
abstract: For a reporter and his mother, this decade, in which San Francisco has won three World Series titles, has been a long goodbye.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Every now and again, when I’m feeling a little down, I go to Baseball-Reference.com and look up the San Francisco Giants’ box score from July 29, 2012. It’s an odd choice for a Giants fan. The Los Angeles Dodgers won, 4-0, completing a weekend sweep in which they outscored the Giants by 19-3 and tied them for the lead in the National League West.

headline: Why Bomb Suspect’s Travels Didn’t Set Off More Scrutiny
abstract: Ahmad Khan Rahami, who is charged in a two-state bombing spree, was flagged for extra screening when he returned from traveling abroad, but his travels did not raise any immediate alarm.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — To an amateur eye, Ahmad Khan Rahami’s travel history might appear to be a red flag: He had traveled to Pakistan, the home of Al Qaeda, four times between 2005 and 2014. The last time he stayed for a year.

headline: Australia Is Not as Down Under as Everyone Thinks It Is

lead_paragraph: It was the worst — and, in one critical way, the best — news that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo could have received.

headline: Mr. Ryan, Your Views on Donald Trump? Next Question, Please
abstract: Speaker Paul D. Ryan, who once frequently criticized the Republican presidential nominee over his incendiary remarks, has gone notably mum.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House speaker, Paul D. Ryan, has expressed no particular opinion on the stop-and-frisk police tactics advocated this week by Donald J. Trump. He does not have any certain thoughts about Mr. Trump’s repeated praise of Vladimir V. Putin. He sort of suggested that Mr. Trump should release his tax returns, but what he really meant, it seems, is that candidates in general should do so. Then again, he said that he would “defer” to Mr. Trump on the decision.

lead_paragraph: The first time I climbed out of the subway stop at Broadway and 157th Street in Washington Heights, I thought I had stepped back in time — and wound up in Paris.

headline: Buffalo Museum, Ready to Expand, Raises Money at Breakneck Pace

headline: On St. Croix, a Restaurant Twists Caribbean Classics
abstract: Balter, which has a polished charm, artfully adapts comfort food from its native island.
lead_paragraph: Kallaloo, a mass of greens and okra, pork and crab, slow-simmered into a deep, darkly flavorful stew, is a dish usually best found at granny’s house — if you’re lucky enough to have a West Indian granny. Or you could head to Balter, in St. Croix’s historic Christiansted, where the homespun dish takes on a gloss with foraged leaves of sea purslane and house-pickled peppers adding pops of color and crunch against a luxuriously soft background. The result is the sort of artful twisting of Caribbean comfort food that characterizes this elegant restaurant, which opened in April.

headline: How to Plan an Active Vacation
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Hikes and Hiking', 'Walking', 'Bicycles and Bicycling']
abstract: When planning an active vacation, find trips that match your fitness level — and consider those that offer more than one type of sport.
lead_paragraph: Forget the standard hangout by the beach or sightseeing through a city vacation. Hiking, walking and biking are less common ways to explore a destination, according to Susan Sparks, a travel adviser at Points of Interest Travel in Aspen, Colo., who specializes in customized active trips. “When you take an active trip, you’re out in nature and get a perspective on a place that most travelers don’t. Plus, you’re moving a lot and burn plenty of calories to balance out all the eating and drinking that are typical on vacations,” she said.

headline: How I Found Ways to Work Out as a New Mom of Twins
abstract: A tennis court became a playpen to contain my boys while I frantically ran laps in a race against their impatience.
lead_paragraph: Up until a week before I gave birth to my twin boys, I swam every day. My belly ballooned between the halves of my sports bikini, and the swimmers in the other lanes must have feared that they were going to witness a water birth. I felt weightless and free. The scent of chlorine was bracing yet purifying, and the air bubbles trailed behind me like comets.

headline: Victoria and Albert Exhibition Opens a ’60s Treasure Chest

lead_paragraph: LONDON — It was only when he saw a report about it on the BBC evening news on April 29, 1967, that John Lennon remembered having promised to attend the “14-Hour Technicolour Dream,” an all-night benefit at Alexandra Palace in north London for the International Times, an underground newspaper recently raided by the police.

headline: Chinese City Urges Comrades to Do Their Part and Reproduce
abstract: The appeal by Yichang officials, coming so soon after the end of the national one-child policy, was met with howls of amazement and resentment on social media.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — For 36 years the Chinese state nearly turned out the lights on childbearing, ordering most families to have just one child and to focus instead on economic growth. An authoritative public letter to Communist Party members from the central government in September 1980 detailed the one-child policy.

headline: 1941: Signs of Vichy Collaboration
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Collaboration between France’s Vichy government and Germany’s Nazi regime are evident in September 1941.
lead_paragraph: VICHY — Signs of a renewal of political activity, probably along the lines of Franco-German collaboration, were evident in Vichy today, after the summer lull. Marshal Henri Pétain is back in the provisional capital after a visit to the Alpine province of Savoy, and Jacques Benoist-Mechin, Under Secretary of State, is on his way here from Paris. Benoist-Mechin, one of the most ardent collaborationists, has his office in Paris, where he is in fact, if not titularly, the most important representative of the Pétain government. His return to Vichy follows discussions with Otto Abetz, the German Ambassador at Paris. Informed quarters here say they expect no important developments in Franco-German relations soon, but it is cautiously admitted that Benoist-Mechin’s visit here signifies a ‘‘resumption of contacts’’ with the Nazis. — New York Herald Tribune, Sept. 24, 1941

headline: The Bangladeshi Traffic Jam That Never Ends
keywords: ['Roads and Traffic', 'Pedicabs and Rickshaws', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: A visit to the city of Dhaka, where there are two types of traffic: really bad and really, really bad.
lead_paragraph: Of all the dysfunctions that plague the world’s megacities, none may be more pernicious than bad (really, really bad) traffic. Sitting still in Dhaka, where bad design takes on epic proportions.

headline: Forget Trump’s Wall: For Mexico, the Election Is About Nafta
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'North American Free Trade Agreement', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Automobiles', 'Agriculture and Farming']
abstract: With both candidates bashing free trade, how their anger translates into policy is the big question south of the border.
lead_paragraph: TOLUCA, Mexico — In this industrial city near the Mexican capital, workers gather outside the gates of a sprawling Chrysler plant for a late shift assembling Dodge Journey S.U.V.s. It’s a sought-after job, with autoworkers in Mexico earning an average of about $5 an hour, compared with the nation’s minimum wage of less than $4 for the whole day. Yet it is a fifth of what autoworkers make in Detroit, and that has helped Mexico become a global powerhouse in car production. The finished products can be seen in the parking lot: thousands of shiny new S.U.V.s, black, white, silver, red, waiting to be shipped around the planet, particularly to the United States, where Americans bought 100,000 Journeys last year.

headline: ‘Love in the Afternoon,’ a Tale of Male Restlessness, Back Onscreen
abstract: Eric Rohmer’s 1972 film, the final one in his cycle “Six Moral Tales,” runs through Thursday.
lead_paragraph: “I feel marriage closes me in, cloisters me, and I want to escape,” muses Frédéric, the protagonist of Eric Rohmer’s 1972 film “Love in the Afternoon,” which runs until Thursday, Sept. 29, at the Walter Reade Theater.

headline: A Very Moon Juice Cookbook
abstract: Amanda Chantal Bacon, who founded the L.A.-based wellness brand, is releasing recipes, and life tips, in print.
lead_paragraph: Amanda Chantal Bacon, the founder of the L.A.-based wellness brand Moon Juice, owns countless cookbooks but can’t remember ever having followed a recipe, preferring to page through them for inspiration, often in bed. To that end, she sees her own first book, out next month, as more guide than manual, for anyone who wants to rethink their entire food philosophy­ — though it does contain recipes, 75 of them, for things like green-juice-and-kelp gazpacho, almond milk kefir and chia sesame dough.

headline: ‘Frozen’ Musical Zeros In on Michael Grandage as Director
abstract: Disney is expected to hire Michael Grandage to direct the musical version of its hit film “Frozen.”
lead_paragraph: Disney is expected to name Michael Grandage to direct its coming “Frozen” musical as the company seeks to keep the high-stakes project on track after firing the previous director.

headline: Trump’s Ghostwriter Explains How to Beat Him in a Debate
abstract: The author who wrote “The Art of the Deal” for Donald Trump explains what advice he’s giving Hillary Clinton for Monday’s debate.
lead_paragraph: When Tony Schwartz was writing Donald J. Trump’s first book, “The Art of the Deal,” in the late 1980s, he was startled by his client’s short attention span. During their first interview, Mr. Trump endured just a few minutes of Mr. Schwartz’s questions before leaping up from his chair and declaring the entire exercise a waste of his time.

headline: Why Isn’t There a Landlord Blacklist?
keywords: ['Landlords', 'Blacklisting', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate Brokers']
abstract: Rentlogic is attempting to grade landlords and buildings on an A to F scale. Some are pushing back.
lead_paragraph: Renting an apartment in New York City is an exercise in financial exhibitionism. By the time you are offered a lease, your future landlord knows your salary, savings and credit history, down to that unpaid Verizon bill from four years ago. If a past rental dispute ended up in housing court, good luck getting the new apartment, because he probably knows about that, too.

headline: Designing a Custom-Made Creative Family
abstract: In Milan, the designer Arthur Arbesser and his associates work and play together; perhaps it’s a template for a future fashion world.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — The Milanese midcentury Luigi Caccia Dominioni building, nestled in a quiet residential neighborhood that is traditionally home to the Milano Bene, the wealthy, conservative members of society, may bear little physical resemblance to Andy Warhol’s silver-painted Manhattan loft that came to be known as the Factory.

headline: Going Live From Charlotte
abstract: Richard Wright Jr., 29, of Charlotte, N.C., participated in a third night of protests in the city on Thursday, after a police shooting of a black man ignited demonstrations. “I really felt in my heart I wanted to be about something,” Mr. Wright said.
lead_paragraph: Richard Wright Jr., 29, of Charlotte, N.C., participated in a third night of protests in the city on Thursday, after a police shooting of a black man ignited demonstrations. “I really felt in my heart I wanted to be about something,” Mr. Wright said.
