abstract: In many states, this is the last week to register before the November presidential election. Here’s a state-by-state list of deadlines.
lead_paragraph: Election Day is Nov. 8, but most states require voters to register well before then. Deadlines in the remaining states are rapidly approaching.

headline: ‘Miss Peregrine’ and Tim Burton: The Making of a Film Fable
abstract: For “Miss Peregrine’s Home for Peculiar Children,” based on a novel by Ransom Riggs, Mr. Burton sketched characters and more to create a new world.
lead_paragraph: Ransom Riggs’s novel “Miss Peregrine’s Home for Peculiar Children,” with its haunting photos, quirky outsiders and feel for the macabre, reads a bit like a Tim Burton movie. And, fittingly, it has now become one.

headline: An Expert on Chinese Medicine, but No New Age Healer
keywords: ['Alternative and Complementary Medicine', 'Translation and Interpreters', 'Books and Literature', 'ACUPUNCTURE']
abstract: Paul U. Unschuld has done more to promote Chinese medicine than perhaps any other Westerner, but he sees it more as a clue to the culture than as an exotic cure.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — One day in 1971, the doorbell rang at Paul U. Unschuld’s apartment in Munich. He opened the door to find a young man, who laconically said in English: “Hi, I am James Quinn, C.I.A. Tell me about the military usage of acupuncture.”

headline: A Garden Sanctuary of Medieval Magic
keywords: ['Gardens and Gardening', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Palaces and Castles', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: The landscape designers Isabel and Julian Bannerman have transformed their coastal English home with acres of demonstrative and dramatic flowers.
lead_paragraph: In September 2011, something rather special awaited anyone leafing through the real-estate advertisements in Country Life, the British magazine that has been the best resource for those seeking classic English properties for more than a century. A gorgeous Cotswolds rectory? A grand Yorkshire pile? You can find all manner of manors within its oversize pages.

headline: Beijing’s Disturbing Turn Against Personal Freedoms

lead_paragraph: HUANGSHAN, China — In February 2015, a group of about 15 people met at a restaurant in the Chaoyang District of Beijing. This past August, four of the attendees were convicted by the Tianjin Second Intermediate People’s Court of “subversion of state power,” and details from their conversation were used as evidence against them.

headline: It Lives. Birtherism Is Diminished but Far From Dead.

lead_paragraph: America’s most prominent birther has finally disavowed the myth he helped to create. Will Donald J. Trump’s concession affect the public’s belief about whether President Obama was born in the United States?

headline: The Story Behind This Week’s Best Sellers
abstract: “The Hidden Life of Trees,” No. 5 on the hardcover nonfiction list, describes the way trees protect their young, communicate and develop communities.
lead_paragraph: Timber: “I speak for the trees,” the Lorax proclaimed. But maybe trees can speak for themselves, if we’d just shut up and listen. That’s the premise of a book by the German forest ranger Peter Wohlleben, “The Hidden Life of Trees,” that debuts at No. 5 on the hardcover nonfiction list and explains — in strikingly anthropomorphic terms — how trees protect their young, communicate through underground networks and develop sophisticated social communities, among other things. “When trees are really thirsty, they begin to scream,” Wohlleben writes. “If you’re out in the forest, you won’t be able to hear them, because this all takes place at ultrasonic levels.” Published last year in Germany, the book has already been a big best seller there, prompting a New York Times profile of the author last winter. (My favorite quote came not from Wohlleben — who once clarified to a German newspaper that “I don’t hug trees and I don’t talk to them” — but from a German literary critic eager to dismiss the idea that forestry was a particularly German obsession: “Yes, there’s ‘Hansel and Gretel,’ and, sure, if your marriage fails, you go for a long hike in the woods. But I don’t think Germans love their forest more than Swedes or Norwegians or Finns.”) Now that Wohlleben’s book has been translated into English, by Jane Billinghurst, other media outlets are also taking notice. “The thing that surprised me most is how social trees are,” Wohlleben told The Guardian recently. “I stumbled over an old stump one day and saw that it was still living although it was 400 or 500 years old, without any green leaf. Every living being needs nutrition. The only explanation was that it was supported by the neighbor trees via the roots with a sugar solution. . . . Trees are very interested in keeping every member of this community alive.”

headline: The Truth Is Out There
abstract: The notion that life, including intelligent life, exists beyond Earth seems more persuasive than ever. Four new books take a look at the search, and the searchers.
lead_paragraph: In October of 1995, two Swiss astronomers announced a major discovery: They had detected, about 50 light-years from Earth, a planet orbiting a sun-like star. Scientists had long imagined there were such planets outside our solar system, but never before had one been confirmed. This extrasolar planet, or “exoplanet,” appeared to be a Jupiter-like ball of gas and liquid with a blistering atmospheric temperature of 1,700 degrees Fahrenheit. In the two decades since, astronomers have detected more than 3,000 exoplanets. No one has yet found a replica of Earth, although Proxima b, an Earth-size planet in a temperate orbit a mere 4.2 light-years away, whose discovery was announced last month, sounds as if it could be a decent place to live.

headline: 1966: War Threat in Europe
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: A Russian minister emphases the possibility of a war in Europe during the Vietnam war in September 1966.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko pulled a surprise in his speech today [Sept. 23] to the General Assembly by placing more emphasis on the potential for war in Europe than on the actual conflict in Vietnam. Mr. Gromyko did castigate the United States for its ‘‘barbaric bombing’’ of North Vietnam and for ‘‘military interference in the affairs of Cambodia and Laos.’’

headline: How Jean Grae, an Actress and Musician, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: For Ms. Grae, Sundays are about watching TV, cooking brunch, going to thrift and vintage stores, and meeting up with friends.
lead_paragraph: Jean Grae, born Tsidi Ibrahim, made a name for herself as an underground M.C. alongside friends and fellow hip-hop artists like Talib Kweli in the 1990s. She later produced and starred in the comedic online series “Life With Jeannie.” On Oct. 2, she will host the Golden Probes, a satirical ceremony that will pay tribute to “outstanding achievements in the fields of sexism and anti-abortion extremism.” The show will also feature the comedians Sarah Silverman and Abbi Jacobson and Ilana Glazer from the TV series “Broad City.” Ms. Grae, 39, lives in Bushwick, Brooklyn, with Quelle Chris, a musician and producer. The two recently broke up, and Mr. Chris is looking for a new apartment.

headline: Review: In ‘Dead Shot Mary,’ a Pioneering New York Cop Walks the Beat
abstract: Mary Shanley, the subject of this play by Robert K. Benson, was one of the first women to become a New York City police detective.
lead_paragraph: One thing you had to say for Mary Shanley: She knew how to stop a pickpocket dead in his tracks. Ms. Shanley, the subject of “Dead Shot Mary,” was one of the first women to become a New York City police detective. Her story lives on in Depression-era newspaper headlines like “Policewoman Seizes Two Men Without Aid” (1936) and “Woman Detective Draws Pistol in Fifth Avenue” (1938). And now in this one-hour one-act, by Robert K. Benson, at Shetler Studios.

headline: A Lost Art on Broadway: Sneaking In for Act 2
abstract: Slipping in with crowds during intermission, known as second-acting, was once a rite of passage for students and starving actors. But theaters no longer turn a blind eye to the practice.
lead_paragraph: During a visit to the city a few years ago, Linda Nenno, a former New Yorker now living in Austin, Tex., found herself standing in Times Square, gazing toward the Palace Theater, where a preview of “West Side Story” had just broken for intermission.

headline: T’s New Design & Luxury Issue: Editor’s Letter
abstract: For this issue, we decided to take a closer look at the meaning of design and why we make certain choices.
lead_paragraph: Design is so pervasive, argues Michael Rock in his Sign of the Times essay, that it often appears as fact rather than the result of subjective decision-making. After a period of time, an idea that originally evolved from mores, habits or customs becomes so codified and ingrained that it takes on the air of inevitability. For this issue, we decided to take a closer look at the meaning of design and why we make certain choices, from the wild natural beauty of Isabel and Julian Bannerman’s garden to the fine attention to detail in the rising designer Billy Cotton’s interiors. We considered the psychological effects of design, from the standpoint of a mad collector, the young fashion designer Jonathan Anderson, to what happens when it all goes terribly wrong. Of course, we also celebrate the vast range of the designed world: teapots, interesting hairdos, clever companies, artists’ communities, fabric, paint and rugs, jewels, clothing, even plumbing. Added up, these stories are a call to see design more clearly, to appreciate what is all around us, but also to realize the delicacy of ingenuity — that none of it had to be quite this way, and yet it is. And, to recognize that if something isn’t working, we can try to design its change.

abstract: Mr. Gottlieb has been the editorial midwife to works by writers like Toni Morrison, Joseph Heller and Robert Caro. In his new memoir, he writes about the editing life.

headline: Sufi Sect of Islam Draws ‘Spiritual Vagabonds’ in New York
abstract: Americans joining the mystical branch of the religion see their faith as peaceful and worry about rising anti-Muslim sentiments.
lead_paragraph: On a leafy block of West 72nd Street, a Muslim Sufi order meets each Thursday evening, squeezing into Abdul Latif’s three-bedroom apartment. You don’t have to know Mr. Latif, born John Healy, to attend. Raised in the Yorkville neighborhood on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, he greeted his guests in Arabic with a thick New York accent, inviting them to sit on the floor.

headline: Clinton Plays It Frosty Between the Ferns
abstract: Her appearance with Zack Galifianakis showed her as bemused and withering. Will she show that side on Monday night’s debate?
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, Hillary Clinton arguably had one of her most effective public appearances in months, and it happened on the website Funny or Die. Clinton appeared as a guest on “Between Two Ferns” with Zach Galifianakis, a semi-aggressive, extremely rumpled comedian and sort-of talk show host who makes David Letterman look painfully earnest by comparison. The show has a glaringly low-rent aesthetic, like something made in an office park, circa 1981, by a bunch of interns with time on their hands. That sensibility — self-mocking, on-the-fly and D.I.Y. — is very 2016.

headline: Why Industrial Farms Are Good for the Environment
abstract: Technology has helped make them more sustainable than at any time in history.
lead_paragraph: Stillwater, Okla. — There is much to like about small, local farms and their influence on what we eat. But if we are to sustainably deal with problems presented by population growth and climate change, we need to look to the farmers who grow a majority of the country’s food and fiber.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Printed Sweater Vests, Fit for Grandpa
abstract: Gucci, Prada and Michael Kors have all revived the classic, bookish look in a variety of patterns for spring/summer 2017.
lead_paragraph: The bookish, grandfatherly sweater vest has been reimagined for the spring/summer 2017 runway, in a variety of prints and patterns. Alessandro Michele kicked off Milan Fashion Week on Wednesday with a mushroom-printed sweater vest, paired with a polka-dot dress on Gucci’s runway. Yesterday at Prada, Miuccia Prada clashed a plaid sweater vest with a geometric, floral button-up and a bright yellow skirt. And last week in New York, Michael Kors showcased a version with a blue flowered pattern, matched at both smaller and larger scales in the rest of the look.

lead_paragraph: PARIS — Jérôme Kerviel, the rogue trader who nearly brought down the French bank Société Générale more than eight years ago, has had his fine reduced on appeal: By 99.98 percent, in fact.

headline: Geena Davis Talks About ‘The Exorcist’ and Women Onscreen
abstract: Ms. Davis is playing Angela Rance, a Chicago hotel manager, wife and mother, in Fox’s retooling of the 1973 horror classic.
lead_paragraph: By her own admission, Geena Davis is not the norm when it comes to gender disparity onscreen. “I’ve been really lucky to play a lot of important roles in movies, and I got to be really cool things,” she said, ticking off a list that includes a baseball phenomenon (“A League of Their Own”), a pirate captain (“Cutthroat Island”) and, perhaps the coolest of them all, a housewife on the lam in “Thelma and Louise.”

keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Blacks', 'Black People']

headline: On the Hudson, a ‘River Rat’ to the Rescue

lead_paragraph: When US Airways Flight 1549 landed in the Hudson River on Jan. 15, 2009, with 155 people aboard, Scott Koen happened to be on a 46-foot work boat he had bought on eBay for $15,000 “just for kicking around.”

headline: Claudia Chesson-Williams

headline: Take Extra Steps to Keep Your Personal Information Secure
abstract: Some websites may seem less important to protect than others, but even the most mundane accounts may reveal information about you.
lead_paragraph: Q. How important is it to have a strong password, change a password and/or use two-step verification on websites that require a login? I certainly understand how critical it is to maintain security on websites that contain my personal and financial information such as medicare.gov or banks, but what about other websites or cloud data where I do not care about the information that is stored there?

lead_paragraph: A cab ride allowed Bria Skonberg, a jazz musician and Matthew Papper, artistic director of Manhattan’s Town Hall, to get to know one another.

headline: Drawn to a Jazzwoman and Her Trumpet’s Clarion Call
abstract: A fateful ride around and around Manhattan brings a jazz musician and a musical impresario ever closer.
lead_paragraph: On their first official date, Bria Skonberg, the jazz trumpeter and vocalist, and Matthew Papper, who would later become the artistic director of Town Hall, circumnavigated Manhattan in a yellow cab. More than twice.

headline: If I Were President … of My Club, My Class, My College, My Country
abstract: Share your concerns, and hopes, for the future.
lead_paragraph: Students, send us — in words, drawings or pictures — what you would do if you were in charge. We want to know your concerns, and hopes, for the future. Would you make college free? Ban drinking? Build a safe space, or a wall around campus? Why, and what would that look like? Written entries should be no more than 150 words. Provide the name of your school, class and a photo credit. Please email your submissions to edlife@nytimes.com. Selections are being posted here.

headline: Some Things T Editors Are Really Into Right Now
abstract: A by-no-means exhaustive list of items we like.
lead_paragraph: The designer and DwellStudio founder Christiane Lemieux’s new book is chock-full of inspiring interiors — and mini-guides to understanding the most fundamental elements of a great room. From the history of wallpaper to the evolution of a frame, “The Finer Things” breaks down furniture, textiles and details — and how to incorporate them — to show how good design is truly the sum of its parts. It’s probably a perfect housewarming gift, if such a thing exists. $60, amazon.com. — ALAINNA LEXIE BEDDIE

headline: Federal-Style Brooklyn Heights House for $7 Million
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']

lead_paragraph: One of the oldest homes in Brooklyn Heights, a Federal-style, wood-frame house that dates to the early 19th century, with a two-bedroom backhouse, is about to go on the market for the first time in nearly 60 years.

headline: In California, Grenache Packs More Than Power
abstract: Though these wines are known for their assertive blockbuster style, subtler expressions of them can be compelling.
lead_paragraph: The grenache grape is almost stealthy in its ubiquity. It is grown and made into wine pretty much all over the world, often known by its French name, grenache, but sometimes by the Spanish garnacha.

headline: ‘Transparent’ Season 3 Premiere: The Prophet Elizah
abstract: The pileup of prejudices in the premiere’s final scene bodes well for how the show will handle its newfound interest in intersectionality.
lead_paragraph: After seven decades on Earth, Maura Pfefferman finally has everything she ever wanted. In an early scene from the Season 3 premiere, she lists her blessings: a loving girlfriend (Anjelica Huston is back as Vicki), supportive kids, meaningful volunteer work at an L.G.B.T. hotline. It goes without saying that she left the trappings of Mort behind some time ago to live as Maura.

headline: ‘All of the World Has Failed’ Aleppo
abstract: Civilians in Aleppo try to cope after the Syrian government and Russian forces launched a new offensive on opposition-held areas on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Civilians in Aleppo try to cope after the Syrian government and Russian forces launched a new offensive on opposition-held areas on Friday.

headline: José Mourinho’s United, and His Methods, Go Under the Microscope
abstract: A coach’s reputation for infallibility is sustained only by a steady diet of victories. But lately, they haven’t come.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — A coffee table dominated the center of José Mourinho’s office at Chelsea’s training complex during his second, tempestuous tenure at the West London club. It looked custom-built: framed under the glass were the front pages of three Italian newspapers, each one celebrating a different trophy Mourinho had won during his glorious final season at Inter Milan.

headline: This Movie Was Nearly Lost. Now They’re Fighting to Save It.
abstract: A negative of “Cane River” (1982), which resurfaced two years ago, has connected a disparate group of people across the country.
lead_paragraph: When it debuted in 1982, “Cane River” was already a rarity: a drama by an independent black filmmaker, financed by wealthy black patrons and dealing with race issues untouched by mainstream cinema. Richard Pryor had even tried to take it to Hollywood.

lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — After North Korea conducted its fifth and most powerful nuclear test this month, South Korea’s president, Park Geun-hye, met with her country’s opposition leaders to discuss how to react. The outcome was not surprising.

abstract: That’s the median hourly wage for the workers, mostly minority women, caring for older adults. Not surprisingly, the annual turnover rate is 40 percent to 60 percent.

headline: He Thought Times Square Was Dead, Before It Showed Him Life
abstract: One summer in the early 1980s, Jan Staller went to Times Square to photograph signs of ruin. Instead, the city revealed its life to him.
lead_paragraph: Jan Staller has an eye for urban ruin, and one summer in the early 1980s, it brought him to Times Square. Mr. Staller, 64, is best known for his images of New York’s desolate landscapes. In Times Square, he was drawn to what he thought were dead zones: a subterranean shoe-repair shop squeezed into a subway station and a coin-operated fortune teller perched by the subway stairs. “They were so grimy and old, so redolent of another time, the first 50 years of the 20th century,” he said.

headline: How to Get Versace’s Fresh, Sporty Beauty Look
keywords: ['Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'Beauty (Concept)']
abstract: For Donatella Versace’s runway in Milan, the makeup artist Pat McGrath imparted a natural glow.
lead_paragraph: This season, rather than show an overtly sexy collection akin to the Versace designs of yore, Donatella Versace said that her mission was to elevate sportswear to luxury levels — so women could look good while feeling comfortable and powerful. To that end, she asked the makeup artist Pat McGrath to create a look that emphasized a natural glow. Which she did, with just a bit of cream blush and mascara, and her namesake line’s Skin Fetish highlighter. McGrath also groomed the models’ eyebrows and, finally, added a touch of silver pigment to the inside corner of the eyes — “a little futuristic but at the same time pretty,” she said. “The look is sporty, but not sporty as in sweaty and undone and disheveled … it’s more of a refined sport look.”

headline: Doors of Manhattan
abstract: Even though they stand between us and the chaos of the city, the borough’s distinctive doors are easy to overlook.

headline: If the 18th Hole Isn’t Made for TV, Make It the 9th
abstract: The PGA Tour has flipped the front and back nines at East Lake Golf Club for the Tour Championship, while the last five holes of each nine at Hazeltine will be swapped for the Ryder Cup.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Imagine if, just this year, the horses at the Kentucky Derby made right turns instead of lefts around the track at Churchill Downs. Or if the New York City Marathon ended at the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge instead of starting there. Or, for the baseball playoffs, the Boston Red Sox moved Fenway Park’s iconic Green Monster outfield wall from left field to right.

headline: Ted Cruz Announces Support for Donald Trump
abstract: Two months after refusing to endorse Mr. Trump at the G.O.P. convention, the senator said he had decided to vote for the nominee after “searching my own conscience.”
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz said on Friday that he would vote for Donald J. Trump for president, two months after Mr. Cruz pointedly declined to endorse his former rival in a speech at the Republican National Convention.

headline: Diego Della Valle of Tod’s on Design, Politics — and Tattoos
abstract: The president and C.E.O. of the Tod’s Group reflects on the current climate of the fashion industry.
lead_paragraph: Diego Della Valle is the 62-year-old billionaire who not only manages but is instantly identifiable with the brands he owns. Unlike his closest peers, François-Henri Pinault of Kering, or Bernard Arnault of LVMH, Della Valle has an unexpected, dandyish flair: He habitually sports upturned shirt collars and a wide-spread scarf in place of a tie, and employs not one but two tailors (Lattini for his sport jackets, Caraceni for his suits) though I’ve most often seen him combine his Caraceni jackets with Levis. His gray hair is swept back from his high forehead, his horn-rimmed spectacles seem well-considered. He is a man who likes fashion, wears it, buys some — and sells lots.

headline: Harvard Needs a Steady Endowment Manager
abstract: Over the last few months, Harvard’s endowment has fallen short of its own goals, and that of its rival, Yale.
lead_paragraph: Harvard University is struggling with postgraduate life. Its giant endowment lost 2 percent in the year to June, falling short of its own yardsticks and the 3.4 percent gain generated by David Swensen at its rival, Yale. More than a decade after the departure of its architect, Jack Meyer, the Harvard Management Company is finding it hard to get past being the sort-of hedge fund it once was.

headline: Coffee Grounds May Filter Out Heavy Metals in Water
abstract: Chemists in Italy offer up a solution for all that smelly espresso and coffee waste.
lead_paragraph: Inside an old gas tank, pink and white mold grows atop crispy cakes of spent espresso.

headline: Ed Temple, Track Coach Who Produced Olympians and National Titles, Dies at 89
abstract: Temple, who coached at Tennessee State University from 1950 to 1993, mentored female runners who won 23 Olympic medals and 34 national titles.
lead_paragraph: Ed Temple, who coached Wilma Rudolph, Wyomia Tyus and 38 other Olympians in his 43 seasons as the most celebrated women’s track and field coach in the United States, died on Thursday. He was 89.

headline: Amor Towles, a Gentleman in Gramercy Park
abstract: The author of ‘Rules of Civility’ and ‘A Gentleman in Moscow,’ lives in a gracious townhouse near Gramercy Park.
lead_paragraph: Amor Towles lives with his family in an elegant Victorian townhouse near Gramercy Park, a circumstance his fans would, no doubt, find eminently fitting. After all, Mr. Towles’s 2011 debut novel, “Rules of Civility,” takes place amid the haunts of cafe and Nescafé society in 1930s Manhattan. With its beautifully restored staircase and moldings, its marble fireplaces and French doors, its adroit mix of antique and Art Deco furniture, Mr. Towles’s home could have been one of the soignée settings for his best-selling book.

headline: Obama Vetoes 9/11 Bill, but Congressional Override Is Expected

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama vetoed legislation on Friday that would allow families of victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks to sue the government of Saudi Arabia for any role in the plot, setting up an extraordinary confrontation with a Congress that unanimously backed the bill and has vowed to uphold it.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s ‘Angry’ Face
abstract: Why women look mad when men look serious.
lead_paragraph: When Hillary Clinton participated in a televised forum on national security and military issues this month, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, Reince Priebus, tweeted that she was “angry and defensive the entire time — no smile and uncomfortable.” Mrs. Clinton, evidently undaunted by Mr. Priebus’s opinion on when she should and shouldn’t smile, tweeted back, “Actually, that’s just what taking the office of president seriously looks like.”

headline: Arctic Climate Change Revealed in a Luxury Cruise and Haunting Wreck
abstract: The transformation of the Arctic is revealed in the discovery of a long-lost ship, a cruise liner’s Arctic passage and a probe of ancient records.

keywords: ['Pop and Rock Music', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Sex Crimes', 'Music']
abstract: Onstage in Brooklyn, the singer tested whether the singer or the song is the object of fans’ affections.
lead_paragraph: Pop songs in the modern era are the products of collaboration — singers, writers, producers, engineers and many more all have a part to play. That arrangement engenders a perennial pop-star anxiety: Is it the songs that have fans, or the singer? And can the singer go it alone detached from the ecosystem that laid the foundation for her success?

headline: Can Tesla’s Autopilot Be Trusted? Not Always
keywords: ['Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Automobiles']
abstract: A reporter tests the company’s old self-driving software and its updated one, finding an exhilarating system that he still needed to override for self-preservation.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Driving a Tesla Model S with Autopilot technology can be frightening and exhilarating.

headline: Charlotte, Syria, Ted Cruz: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Danzig on Getting the Band (the Misfits) Back Together. Briefly.
abstract: Glenn Danzig, the Misfits’ co-founder, who had not fronted it since 1983, discussed the short reunion that ended by headlining Riot Fest in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday night, Glenn Danzig fronted the Misfits — the band in which he sang lead for six years in his 20s but hadn’t joined onstage since 1983 — for the headlining slot of Chicago’s Riot Fest. The second and, he said, final performance of a two-show reunion run, the set was a comprehensive, ecstatic summary of his time with the group, which is credited with developing and popularizing horror punk.

headline: Review: Betty Buckley Digs Deep for the Autumn in Her Soul
abstract: In her stunning new show at Joe’s Pub, Ms. Buckley gave everything she sang the shape and depth of a personal confession.
lead_paragraph: “September! November!” To hear Betty Buckley cry out the names of the remaining months as the year wanes in “September Song” at Joe’s Pub on Thursday evening was to hear a great dramatic singer dig out the underlying anguish in a standard that is typically treated as a slice of senior nostalgia. Yes, the days may be dwindling down, but there is consolation. The words, “These few precious days I’ll spend with you” give you an image of grandma and grandpa snuggling under a comforter by the hearth, not of a dazed oldster struggling with Alzheimer’s. Without overstating things, Ms. Buckley found alarm and impending grief in the song.

headline: The Other 13 Women Testifying Against Cosby ... if the Court Lets Them
abstract: Bill Cosby’s fate may rest on whether a judge in his sexual assault trial lets jurors hear from a group of women with details that prosecutors say echo his accuser’s.
lead_paragraph: Some knew him for only a day. Others built friendships over months, even years, and introduced him to their mothers, an aunt, even a 9-year-old son, they say.

headline: Review: In ‘A Taste of Honey,’ She’s Having the Baby. How Quaint.
abstract: Shelagh Delaney’s play, once a hit in the West End and on Broadway, is revived by Pearl Theater Company.
lead_paragraph: Shelagh Delaney was still a teenager when she sent her first script off to a London theater in 1958, enclosing a note that fairly bristled with a bold defensiveness.

headline: Review: ‘Hit the Body Alarm’ Finds Satan in a Jumpsuit
abstract: The play, by Winsome Browne and Brad Rouse, also samples a bit of Milton as it tells its tales.
lead_paragraph: Satan, cast down from heaven, tries to make the best of his new home. “Better to reign in hell, than serve in heaven,” he says. Hell promises freedom, safety, power. Besides, do the denizens of paradise get to wear cool asymmetrical jumpsuits?

headline: Adventures on the China Golf Tour
abstract: The sport proved to be a wonderful window to view modern China and its contradictions.
lead_paragraph: It was a foggy day in Chongqing, a metropolis in southwest China, and the driving range was almost empty. Out beyond the 250-yard marker, a cluster of new high-rise apartment buildings was barely visible, blurred by the haze into a mountainous shadow that made this decidedly urban setting feel unusually secluded.

headline: Why We Are Protesting in Charlotte
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: Don’t listen to the fear-mongers. Our peaceful movement seeks justice, not division.
lead_paragraph: Charlotte, N.C. — Since a police officer shot and killed Keith Lamont Scott in Charlotte, N.C., on Tuesday afternoon, the ensuing protests have dominated national news. Provocateurs who attacked police officers and looted stores made headlines. Gov. Pat McCrory declared a state of emergency, and the National Guard joined police officers in riot gear, making the Queen City look like a war zone.

headline: Karl Dietrich Bracher, German Historian of Nazi Era, Dies at 94
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: Professor Bracher, who was born in 1922, refused to absolve his own generation of complicity in the horrors of Nazism.
lead_paragraph: Karl Dietrich Bracher, a World War II veteran of the German army who argued as a historian that the German people had to take responsibility for the rise of Nazism because of their embrace of Hitler and his racist agenda, died on Monday in Bonn. He was 94.

headline: Ruling Means Most of Hillary Clinton’s Emails Will Come Out After Election
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'E-Mail', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: In announcing a new timetable, a federal judge acknowledged the burden on State Department lawyers in reviewing thousands of messages.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Friday ordered the State Department to finish preparing roughly 1,000 pages of Hillary Clinton’s emails for release by Nov. 4, a more protracted timetable that means the bulk of Mrs. Clinton’s emails that were uncovered by the Federal Bureau of Investigation will not be released until after the election.

headline: For Taiwan, Google Images of Disputed Island Are Too Clear
abstract: Taiwan made an unusual request to blur pictures of what appear to be new military installations on an island in the South China Sea claimed by four countries.
lead_paragraph: Satellite photos by Google can be a fun way to see your house — or your neighbor’s — from high above.

headline: Knicks Face Questions About Derrick Rose’s Trial as Training Camp Approaches
abstract: The Knicks will open their preseason schedule on Oct. 4, the same day Rose is scheduled to be in court for a civil suit accusing him of rape.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Phil Jackson appeared at a preseason news conference on Friday afternoon to discuss the Knicks’ revamped roster before training camp next week. He quickly found himself fending off questions about a potential civil trial involving rape allegations against Derrick Rose, one of his key off-season acquisitions.

keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Deportation', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Visas', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: After a trek through Latin America many migrants thought they were just days from entering the United States, but a shift in American policy has left them stranded.

keywords: ['Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Computer Security', 'E-Mail', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing']
abstract: By perusing personal accounts of people with even the thinnest thread of a connection to power, hackers can find their way to high-level government officials.

headline: Bridge Case Culprit Says Christie and Ex-Aides Used Port Authority as ‘Goody Bag’
abstract: David Wildstein, who has confessed to coming up with the George Washington Bridge lane-closing scheme, said the Christie administration used the agency to spread money, jobs and gifts.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — The admitted mastermind of the mysterious George Washington Bridge lane closings broke a three-year silence on Friday, testifying in federal court here that everything he did in his job was at the direction and for the benefit of Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey.

headline: Henry Louis Gates Jr.: Restoring Black History
abstract: Some intellectuals once believed that blacks lacked humanity because they had no written history. The new museum demolishes that idea.
lead_paragraph: With the ringing of a bell and a speech from President Obama, the National Museum of African American History and Culture in Washington is to officially open its extraordinary collection to the public on Saturday. But the museum can claim another, equally important achievement: helping resolve the protracted debate about the contributions of black people to American history and, indeed, about whether they had a history worth preserving at all. Those questions were at the heart of the nation’s original debate about whether, and how, black lives matter.

headline: Mets’ Win Comes With a Big Loss, as Noah Syndergaard Has Strep Throat
abstract: In another marathon game, the Mets thumped the Phillies, but the loss of Syndergaard to illness was a blow to their chase for a wild-card berth.
lead_paragraph: As the Mets near the final week of the regular season chasing a playoff spot, they have come to resemble a triage unit housing a baseball team. Every day seems to bring a new injury and a new conundrum. Their September roster, bloated to 39 players, is not carrying unnecessary baggage but much-needed pieces to paper over new holes and to leverage in crucial moments.

headline: Health Care Deserves More Attention on the Campaign Trail
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Editorials', 'Series']
abstract: Why hasn’t the growing burden of medical expenses gotten more attention from the presidential candidates?
lead_paragraph: The reaction to opening a medical bill these days is often shock and confusion — for the insured and the uninsured. Prices and deductibles keep rising, policies are drowning in fine print, and doctors are jumping on and off networks. So why hasn’t the growing burden of health care gotten more attention in the presidential campaign?

headline: Donald Trump the Philanthropist Is Known for His Reluctance
abstract: His depiction as a generous benefactor has come into question recently amid a series of reports raising doubts about his pledges and his foundation.

headline: Dustin Johnson Moves a Step Closer to FedEx Cup Title

lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The bee sting hurt. Of course it did. But as Kevin Chappell shook his left hand in pain as he walked off the tee on the 11th hole at East Lake Golf Club Friday, he did his best to be pragmatic.

headline: The Feckless F.E.C., Rebuked
abstract: A federal judge’s ruling is further evidence that the F.E.C. is paralyzed and should be replaced by a new agency.
lead_paragraph: In an era of unbridled campaign spending, the Federal Election Commission has consistently and shamefully ducked its responsibilities. It has made it possible for tax-exempt “social welfare” organizations to operate as partisan attack machines. And it has dismissed complaints and failed to police this rise of “dark money” from hidden donors that is pouring into elections.

headline: Donald Trump’s Shiny New Washington Hotel
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Political Advertising', 'Editorials', 'Editorial Observer']
abstract: If Mr. Trump’s new hotel is any indication, he should be worried about the campaign’s effect on the marketability of his brand.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Donald Trump labeled Mexican immigrants “rapists” in announcing his candidacy in June of last year, he lost contracts with Nascar, Macy’s, NBC Universal, Univision, even Serta mattresses. Not surprisingly, his three eldest children — Ivanka, Donald Jr. and Eric — began worrying about whether the marketability of the Trump brand could survive the campaign undamaged.

But at a time when 65 million people have been displaced by violence, and 20 million of them are classified as refugees — more than half of them children — it is not enough.

headline: A Humane Voice for a Cruel Regime
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'News and News Media', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: Dissenters aren’t jailed for their opinions? Iran’s top diplomat must know he’s lying about that.
lead_paragraph: Seven years ago, I heard the name of a prominent Iranian diplomat, Mohammad Javad Zarif, at least 118 times. That was how many days I spent imprisoned in Iran for doing my job as a journalist — and how many days I was beaten by an intelligence officer in the hard-line Revolutionary Guards. He demanded that I falsely confess to being a C.I.A. agent and invent false stories that Mr. Zarif had connections to Western intelligence agencies. Rather than cooperate, I somehow withstood the daily torture.

abstract: China’s breakneck growth fueled an iron ore boom in Western Australia. Now, Chinese investors are fleeing a cooling economy by investing in Australian homes.

His store failed — he had chosen the wrong street, he says — and he lost almost all his savings. By then, the fashion world had found fresher faces.

headline: Aging and My Beauty Dilemma
abstract: Being ideologically opposed to intervening in such a natural process as aging can’t always prevent a woman from calling herself a “two-faced hypocrite.”
lead_paragraph: When I was 21, I underwent breast reduction surgery, reducing my embarrassingly large chest to something that could at least fit inside a cardigan. Although there was some medical rationale for the procedure, the overwhelming reason was that I was sick and tired of every man on the planet being unable to look above my neck. Their fault, I know, not mine, and symptomatic of the baggage, both physical and psychological, women are forced to carry around with them. But once my own baggage was surgically removed, I felt amazing — lighter, prettier, healthier. Was this an indulgent move on my part? Maybe. Have I regretted it over the last 30 years? Not for a single moment. I had a problem, or at least what felt an awful lot like a problem, and I made it go away.

headline: A Sex Offender in the Building
abstract: What can shareholders do when an undesirable neighbor moves into a co-op building?
lead_paragraph: Q. A young woman moved into our co-op in Long Beach, N.Y., two years ago. At her board interview, she said she lived alone. But afterward, a man quietly moved in. Recently, police posted notifications around the building alerting tenants that a sex offender — the man who moved in with this woman — lives in the area. She has a premier apartment overlooking the pool where children swim. What can we do to get this man off our premises? Can we force the deceitful shareholder to sell?

headline: Hillary Clinton for President
abstract: Our endorsement is rooted in respect for her intellect, experience and courage.
lead_paragraph: In any normal election year, we’d compare the two presidential candidates side by side on the issues. But this is not a normal election year. A comparison like that would be an empty exercise in a race where one candidate — our choice, Hillary Clinton — has a record of service and a raft of pragmatic ideas, and the other, Donald Trump, discloses nothing concrete about himself or his plans while promising the moon and offering the stars on layaway. (We will explain in a subsequent editorial why we believe Mr. Trump to be the worst nominee put forward by a major party in modern American history.)

lead_paragraph: The uniquely uncivil presidential campaign is about to produce one of the biggest civic gatherings in decades: For 90 minutes on Monday night, a polarized nation will pause to watch the first head-to-head encounter between Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump.

headline: Variety Puzzle: Puns and Anagrams
abstract: Mel Taub returns with a punny, mixed-up puzzle.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Puns and Anagrams puzzles, a known gateway drug to cryptic crosswords, are probably the most self-explanatory of all the Variety puzzles, and if you’ve never tried one, I highly recommend them.

headline: Young Rural Women in India Chase Big-City Dreams
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Families and Family Life', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Rural Areas', 'Textiles']
abstract: Experiments like one in Bangalore, luring migrants to fill factory jobs, collide with an old way of life that keeps women and girls in seclusion until an arranged marriage.
lead_paragraph: BANGALORE, India — The factory floor is going full throttle when the new girls walk in. Everywhere is the thrumming of sewing machines, the hum of fans, the faint burning smell of steam irons. On narrow tables that run between the machines, half-assembled Marks & Spencer miniskirts are thrust forward by fistfuls. The tailors, absorbed in the task of finishing 100 pieces per hour, for once turn their heads to look.

headline: How to Get Jil Sander’s Pared-Back ’80s Beauty Look
abstract: The makeup artist Lisa Eldridge and the hairstylist Sam McKnight took cues from the decade but made them more minimal.
lead_paragraph: At Jil Sander, the designer Rodolfo Paglialunga used ’80s power dressing as a starting point for his spring/summer collection: he took men’s suiting and big shoulders and modernized them in soft, floaty materials.

headline: Can Hillary Clinton Keep You Safe?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Gender', 'Women and Girls', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Discrimination', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Voters no longer believe men are stronger than women on national security.
lead_paragraph: When you’re scared, do you feel safer with Mommy or with Daddy?

headline: A Week of Whoppers From Donald Trump
abstract: Mr. Trump has unleashed a blizzard of falsehoods, exaggerations and outright lies in the general election. Here's our analysis of 31 untruths from Sept. 15-21.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Trump has unleashed a blizzard of falsehoods, exaggerations and outright lies in the general election. Here's our analysis of 31 untruths from Sept. 15-21.

headline: Man, 20, in Custody After Fatal Shooting of 5 People at Mall Outside Seattle
abstract: The police said they suspected Arcan Cetin of Oak Harbor, Wash., in the killing of four women and a man at the Cascade Mall in Burlington, north of Seattle.
lead_paragraph: A 20-year-old man was taken into custody on Saturday night in connection with a shooting that killed five people on Friday at a mall north of Seattle, the authorities said.

headline: Journey From Class Clown to Suspect in Chelsea Bombing
abstract: Ahmad Rahami’s life seemed stuck. Then he found jihad on the internet and fell under the sway of a radical cleric in Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: If there was one child Mohammad Rahami had to worry about bringing shame upon the family, it was Ahmad. In the fifth grade, his teacher complained to Mr. Rahami that Ahmad acted like a king in class. In junior high, he broke a friend’s nose. Even worse was high school — after Mr. Rahami arranged for Ahmad to marry a good Afghan girl from Kabul, Ahmad dated a Dominican girl, getting her pregnant in his senior year.

headline: Donald Trump’s ‘Movement’ Ad: Positive Message, Subtle Dig
abstract: A fast-paced commercial includes shots of a gleaming Trump hotel in Chicago, a soldier returning home, a lemonade stand — and a 1992 image of the Clintons.
lead_paragraph: Cheering crowds and Trump-branded skyscrapers mark a new ad from Donald J. Trump’s campaign, titled “Movement,” its first commercial of the general election that is uplifting in tone.

headline: Chinese Jews of Ancient Lineage Huddle Under Pressure
abstract: A campaign against unapproved religion and foreign influence has turned to a small group of Jews with ancestors who settled in Kaifeng more than 1,000 years ago.
lead_paragraph: KAIFENG, China — The rooms where ruddy-faced Chinese men and women once assembled to pray in Hebrew and Mandarin are silent. Signs and exhibits that celebrated centuries of Jewish life have disappeared. An ancient well, believed to be the last visible remnant of a long-demolished synagogue, was recently buried under concrete and a pile of earth.

headline: With Wayne Rooney Benched, Manchester United Looks Sharp Once Again
abstract: In what may foretell a new stage of the career of Rooney, United’s captain, the team rolled past Leicester City, 4-1, without him in the starting lineup.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — On the back of two straight Premier League defeats, Manchester United named a team to face Leicester City that did not contain its captain, Wayne Rooney. By halftime, with Rooney watching from the substitutes’ bench at Old Trafford, United had a four-goal lead, José Mourinho’s side exhibiting precisely the kind of zip and poise it had recently so sorely lacked.

headline: What I Learned From a Stroke at 26: Make Time to Untangle
keywords: ['Stroke', 'Careers and Professions', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Start-ups', 'Work-Life Balance']
abstract: After a stroke at work, an employee at a venture-backed start-up learns to adjust his professional priorities and take a break from the daily sprint.
lead_paragraph: As an idealistic, knowledge-hungry college graduate and aspiring writer, I had grown tired of hopping from one office gig to the next. It was 2000 and technology was in full bloom. I wanted to cash in on the digital gold rush. Like many of my friends in Austin, Tex., I figured, why not join the internet economy?

headline: Rarity of Tulsa Shooting: Female Officers Are Almost Never Involved
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Women and Girls', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: Police officers kill about 1,000 people each year, according to data collected by the federal government. Only a handful of those shootings are by female officers.
lead_paragraph: Betty Jo Shelby drew her gun and warned the man to stop walking. But Terence Crutcher continued moving toward his S.U.V., which he had left in the middle of the road, the driver’s side door open and the engine running. He was mumbling to himself, but his hands were raised in the air.

headline: You Have 540 Days to Request a Refund, Starting 541 Days Ago
abstract: When buyers stiffed by a bankrupt wine store asked American Express for a refund, the company declined, citing a 540-day window with an uncertain start time.
lead_paragraph: Longtime readers may remember the strange and colorful tale of Premier Cru, a wine store in Berkeley, Calif., that stiffed hundreds of customers who had ordered “prearrival” cases of high-end vino. The Haggler had never heard of prearrival wine either, but he learned that it is a way to pay for it well in advance to secure good prices on coveted vintages.

headline: The Curative Power of Water, Waders and a Fly Rod
abstract: A lifelong fly fisherman who finds tranquillity when he wades into a stream shares his elixir with visitors to a wilderness resort lodge in Colorado.
lead_paragraph: Scott Tarrant, 46, is manager of fly-fishing at the Broadmoor, a resort and hotel in Colorado Springs.

headline: Beyond the Stats, Asdrubal Cabrera Is a Met Admired
abstract: While battling the effects of an aching knee, Cabrera has hit .364 with nine home runs and 22 R.B.I. since returning from the disabled list on Aug. 19.
lead_paragraph: The toll inflicted by Asdrubal Cabrera’s balky left knee has manifested itself in several ways. And last Tuesday, in a game at Citi Field against the Atlanta Braves, Cabrera could not hide it.

headline: Donald Trump’s Hotel Chain to Pay Penalty Over Data Breaches
abstract: The conclusion of the data case comes as cyberthreats have taken an outsize role in Mr. Trump’s presidential campaign against Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s hotel chain agreed to pay a $50,000 penalty and revamp its data security policies after a couple of breaches exposed 70,000 credit card numbers and other personal information of its customers.

headline: The Strip
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: In Syrian War, Russia Has Yet to Fulfill Superpower Ambitions
abstract: Vladimir V. Putin has won Moscow a seat at any table where Syria’s future is debated. But his drive for renewed recognition as a superpower remains unfulfilled.
lead_paragraph: If you held up two maps of Syria — one from last September, when Russian forces first intervened in the chaotic civil war there, and one today — you would see that the battle lines look quite similar.

headline: The Stakes in the Election
abstract: Readers discuss what a President Trump would mean for America’s future.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss what a President Trump would mean for America’s future.

headline: Taking the Stealth Out of Editing
abstract: Changing stories online is fine, as long as The Times owns up to it. Otherwise, readers assume the worst.
lead_paragraph: IN the history of do-overs at The New York Times, there is one example that may seem of no large consequence but nonetheless infuriated readers. It involved an obituary about a rocket scientist named Yvonne Brill. In its first incarnation, the obit referred to 88-year-old Brill in the first paragraph as a woman who “made a mean beef stroganoff, followed her husband around from job to job and took eight years off to raise three children.” In secondary fashion, it mentioned that Brill was a pioneering scientist who invented a propulsion system that kept communications satellites in orbit.

headline: The Trouble With Tylenol and Pregnancy
abstract: The drug appears to increase the risk of asthma or developmental problems in children.
lead_paragraph: If you’re a pregnant woman and have a backache or headache, or a fever, your options for over-the-counter treatment basically boil down to one medication: the pain reliever acetaminophen, better known as Tylenol. Doctors advise against using nonsteroidal anti-inflammatories, like ibuprofen and aspirin, during late pregnancy because they can compromise fetal circulation and have other adverse consequences.

headline: The Sweet Relief of Splenda in My Purse
abstract: As a kid with diabetes, I learned to find substitutes for what I loved.
lead_paragraph: I feel a special kind of relief when I walk into a fancy coffee shop and see Splenda alongside the simple syrup and almond milk. Nowadays it’s trendy to eat all-natural, organic, clean. We’re told it’s healthy and morally superior, even. But all I want in my iced coffee is the contents of those little yellow packets, or the blue ones, or pink.

headline: Am I Introverted, or Just Rude?
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Parties (Social)', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: I said no to parties, ducked out of school events, and excused it as “self-care.”
lead_paragraph: A good friend and colleague, a real extrovert, sent me a link to a shirt recently that she knew I’d appreciate. “Sorry I’m late,” the T-shirt reads. “I didn’t want to be here.”

headline: Who Gets to Write What?
abstract: An Asian man can write a lynching scene if it’s good enough. So could Lionel Shriver.
lead_paragraph: When I was in graduate school, I remember a fellow writer bringing to a workshop a lynching scene. The writer was not black. He was, in fact, a Chinese-American man named Bill Cheng, who would go on to write a novel of the blues called “Southern Cross the Dog.”

headline: The Political Magic of C.S. Lewis
keywords: ['Christians and Christianity', 'Politics and Government', 'Books and Literature', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: We aren’t doing a very good job of living faithfully in a broken world. The genius behind Narnia can help us look upward rather than inward.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I was on Christmas break from college in 1980, I wrote a letter to the editor of my hometown newspaper, The Tri-City Herald. It was published soon after I began to embrace Christianity, a gradual rather than a dramatic process that didn’t come all that easily.

headline: The Debate Mismatch
abstract: In Clinton vs. Trump, expect the expected.
lead_paragraph: PUNDITRY, like most human occupations, depends on pattern recognition. Certain things happen regularly; other things rarely; others never. Probabilities emerge, assumptions are formed, scenarios are considered and ruled out.

headline: How to Cover a Charlatan Like Trump
abstract: As the presidential debates near, what’s the media’s job?
lead_paragraph: WITH presidential debates approaching, we in journalism are locked in a fierce dispute: How should we report on a duplicitous demagogue?

headline: My Debate Nightmare? A Duller Donald Trump
abstract: A dignified performance could really help him. So I’m rooting for ranting.
lead_paragraph: There are predictions that Monday night’s presidential debate will “shatter records,” as one recent headline put it, drawing a Super Bowl-size audience of more than 100 million viewers.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Final Exam
abstract: How she should handle the asymmetric challenge posed by her unorthodox opponent.
lead_paragraph: EARLY in 2007, Barack Obama met Hillary Clinton at a candidates forum on health care in Las Vegas in one of their first encounters on a debate-like stage, in what would become one of the longest nominating battles in presidential campaign history.

headline: Where to Go From the Anger in Charlotte
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: I served as a police chief for 17 years and have never seen such a challenging environment.
lead_paragraph: Charlotte, N.C. — On Wednesday, I spent the day here teaching a workshop for senior police leaders from around the country — deputies and sheriffs who are one step away from taking control of police departments of their own. That night, I went back to the Omni Charlotte Hotel. From my window, I could see lines of police officers assembled, and I could see protesters throwing various objects. I watched the officers release tear gas into the crowd.

headline: Where Ice Once Crushed Ships, Open Water Beckons
abstract: Two voyages to the Northwest Passage, separated by nearly two centuries, underscore the big changes underway in the Arctic as the planet warms.
lead_paragraph: This month, as the luxury cruise ship Crystal Serenity completed its pioneering transit of the Northwest Passage, a Canadian expedition announced the discovery of the Terror, a British ship that vanished along the same general Arctic route some 170 years ago.

headline: Jets’ Matt Forte Is Showing His Game Hasn’t Aged
abstract: Forte, 30, in his first season with the Jets after a prolific career with the Bears, is continuing to produce.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Matt Forte hoped to be among the few N.F.L. players who closed their careers where they had opened them. Drafted by the Chicago Bears in the second round in 2008, he amassed a league-leading 12,718 yards from scrimmage over eight seasons — 8,602 rushing, 4,116 receiving — and established himself as the second-most-prolific running back in franchise history, after Walter Payton.

headline: Obama Says African-American Museum Will Tell of ‘Suffering and Delight’
abstract: Mr. Obama, dedicating the museum on Saturday, said that the story of black Americans is the story of the nation’s essential greatness.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, dedicating the National Museum of African American History and Culture on Saturday, said it would tell an American story, one of “suffering and delight, one of fear, but also of hope, of wandering in the wilderness, and then seeing, out on the horizon, a glimmer of the Promised Land.”

headline: On the Trail: Week of Sept. 17
abstract: Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump responded to the New York and New Jersey bombings, prepped for Monday’s debate and campaigned across the country.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump responded to the New York and New Jersey bombings, prepped for Monday’s debate and campaigned across the country.

headline: ‘From Paradise to Hell’: How an Aid Convoy in Syria Was Blown Apart
keywords: ['Humanitarian Aid', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Interviews with aid workers, rescuers and residents, along with video and photographic evidence, point to a coordinated attack by Russian or Syrian aircraft, probably both.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The familiar hum of a drone lingered overhead as Omar Barakat, the local chief of the Red Crescent, watched workers unload lifesaving cargo at a warehouse in the rebel-held town of Urum al-Kubra, Syria.

headline: Once a Hockey Lode, Quebec Now Yields Few Top Prospects
abstract: The Canadian province reorganized its youth hockey program after fewer and fewer players were selected near the top of the N.H.L. draft.
lead_paragraph: When the two-day Quebec Hockey Summit took place in Montreal in 2011, it touched on issues including head injuries and ways to improve the game.

headline: 2008 Crisis Deepened the Ties Between Clintons and Goldman Sachs
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: One of the country’s most powerful financial firms and one of its most famous political families have a long-running and mutually beneficial relationship.
lead_paragraph: A blue-ribbon commission had just excoriated Goldman Sachs and other Wall Street banks for fueling the financial crisis. Prosecutors were investigating whether Goldman had misled investors. The company was a whipping boy for politicians looking to lay blame for the crash.

headline: In Red Sox’ Magical Season, Rick Porcello Has Been the Hidden Ace
abstract: Porcello rediscovered his sinking two-seam fastball before delivering a breakout season.
lead_paragraph: Rick Porcello would rather play down the magnitude of his comeback this season. If he is proud of his quick ascent from a losing pitcher to the majors’ top winner, it is not for his resilience.

headline: Jack Garman, Whose Judgment Call Saved Moon Landing, Dies at 72
abstract: Mr. Garman was at a back-room console on July 20, 1969, when Neil Armstrong told mission control of a possible computer systems overload. “As long as it doesn’t reoccur, it’s fine,” Mr. Garman said.
lead_paragraph: On July 20, 1969, moments after mission control in Houston had given the Apollo 11 lunar module, Eagle, the O.K. to begin its descent to the moon, a yellow warning light flashed on the cockpit instrument panel.

headline: $5 Trillion and Rising
abstract: Readers comment on “This Man Oversees $5 Trillion” (Sept. 18).
lead_paragraph: “This Man Oversees $5 Trillion,” by Landon Thomas Jr. (Sept. 18) looked at Laurence D. Fink and the asset management firm he founded and heads, BlackRock. BlackRock has grown to control $5 trillion in assets by emphasizing rules-based, data-driven investments through vehicles like exchange-traded funds.

headline: Bobby Breen, a Child Star Who Hit a High Note in the 1930s, Dies at 87
abstract: Mr. Breen arrived on the scene as an 8-year-old boy with an angelic face, and was described as “the most alarming vocal phenomenon of the day.”
lead_paragraph: In the 1930s, with the United States paralyzed by the Depression, a small army of child stars lifted the nation’s spirits, offering innocence, hope and oodles of sentiment. Shirley Temple led the pack of adorables, but in 1936, a small but powerful rival appeared on the scene: an 8-year-old boy with an angelic face and a celestial voice, first raised heavenward in the film “Let’s Sing Again.”

headline: Odell Beckham, Josh Norman and an Antidote to On-Field Antagonism
abstract: Beckham, a Giants receiver, was barred for one game last season after sparring with Norman, who became a division rival by signing with the Redskins.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Victor Cruz knows it is not unusual for veteran defenders to try to rile young receivers with choice words during games.

headline: IndyCar’s Newest Champion, Simon Pagenaud, Had Fast Assimilation to America
abstract: Despite watching Formula One while growing up in France, Pagenaud is comfortable living in North Carolina while driving for Roger Penske.
lead_paragraph: Even after he started racing cars, Simon Pagenaud was known as the son of the grocer in Montmorillon, France, about 220 miles southwest of Paris. His father, Christian, also the son of a grocer, would make it big there, eventually running a hypermarket franchise for E.Leclerc.

headline: Snapchat, Known for Ephemera, Proves Its Staying Power With Videos
keywords: ['Online Advertising', 'Mobile Applications', 'Web-Original Programming', 'Television', 'Social Media', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Wearable Computing', 'Sunglasses']
abstract: With a growing slate of highly edited video content, the app is catching advertisers’ attention and competing with television for viewers.
lead_paragraph: The Summer Olympics was something of a coming-out party for Snapchat, the mobile storytelling and messaging app.

headline: Yielding to Pressure, Charlotte Releases Videos of Keith Scott Shooting
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: City officials released dashboard and body camera recordings in the fatal police shooting after they were pressed by politicians, community leaders and protesters.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Under mounting pressure from politicians, community leaders and boisterous protesters who have brought this city’s main business district to a near standstill, the Charlotte police chief on Saturday released body and dashboard camera videos of the fatal police shooting of Keith Lamont Scott, a black resident here.

headline: Syrian Forces Tighten Siege of Rebel-Held Areas in Aleppo
abstract: The capture of a refugee camp north of the city showed that a Syrian and Russian bombing campaign was bolstering the position of pro-government troops.
lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — As wave and after wave of bombs fell on areas of eastern Aleppo in Syria, ground forces loyal to the Syrian government seized a rebel-held neighborhood on Saturday, intensifying the siege against the rebels and the many civilians who live among them.

headline: Prospect of Philippine Thaw Slows China’s Plans in South China Sea
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Bases and Installations', 'Building (Construction)']
abstract: For Beijing, befriending the Philippines’ new president, Rodrigo Duterte, trumps building a military base 150 miles from the country’s coast.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s next big target for construction of an artificial island in the South China Sea has long been assumed to be a cluster of rocks poking above sapphire waters near the Philippines.

headline: Adding On
abstract: A Jim Holland and Jeff Chen collaboration.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Many solvers skip reading bylines and the Sunday puzzle titles and such, but I think that’s a mistake. You might not need the assistance they provide, but when you do, those pieces of information can really help a person out.

headline: Gennifer Flowers at Debate? Just Making a Point, Says Team Trump
abstract: Taunted by a Hillary Clinton ally, Donald J. Trump threatened to invite Ms. Flowers, who had a sexual relationship with Bill Clinton.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s campaign moved on Sunday to squelch reports — set off by the candidate himself — that Gennifer Flowers, the woman whose claims of an affair with Bill Clinton imperiled his 1992 presidential campaign, would be Mr. Trump’s guest on Monday at his first debate with Hillary Clinton.

headline: The First Gore-Bush Debate
abstract: In a pivotal moment during the 2000 presidential campaign, a series of missteps by Al Gore at the first of three debates with George W. Bush was said to have damaged the vice president's chances of winning the presidency.
lead_paragraph: In a pivotal moment during the 2000 presidential campaign, a series of missteps by Al Gore at the first of three debates with George W. Bush was said to have damaged the vice president's chances of winning the presidency.

headline: Jose Bautista’s Homer Leaves Yankees in First Three-Shutout Skid Since 1975
abstract: The Yankees have not scored since a ninth-inning homer against the Rays on Wednesday, a stretch of 27 innings.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — There was no preening. There was no signature bat flip. But as soon as Jose Bautista connected with Tyler Clippard’s right-down-Spadina-Avenue fastball, there was no doubt.

headline: Liberty and Mercury Players Join Anthem Protest Before Playoff Game
keywords: ['National Anthems', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Playoff Games']
abstract: At Madison Square Garden, some players on the Liberty and the Phoenix Mercury joined the movement ignited by the San Francisco 49ers’ Colin Kaepernick.
lead_paragraph: Liberty guard Brittany Boyd arrived at Madison Square Garden on Saturday for the first W.N.B.A. playoff game of her career wearing a No. 7 San Francisco 49ers jersey to support Colin Kaepernick, the quarterback whose decision not to stand for the national anthem has made him a lightning rod in discussions about race, violence and policing.

headline: Bill Nunn, Who Played Radio Raheem in ‘Do the Right Thing,’ Dies at 63
abstract: Mr. Nunn starred in several movies by the director Spike Lee, but he made his greatest mark in the 1989 role as Radio Raheem.
lead_paragraph: Bill Nunn, a versatile actor best known for playing the role of Radio Raheem, the boombox-toting neighborhood philosopher killed by police officers in Spike Lee’s 1989 film “Do the Right Thing,” died on Saturday in Pittsburgh. He was 63.

headline: Dustin Johnson Shares Lead, but FedEx Cup Title Is in Reach
abstract: After Johnson made three straight birdies to go up by three shots in the third round of the Tour Championship, Kevin Chappell caught up with him.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Midway through his postround news conference Saturday, Dustin Johnson peered out at the room as a journalist questioned him about his trainer, Joey Diovisalvi, a fitness coach who is known for highlighting biomechanics. The journalist asked if Diovisalvi often used science in communication with Johnson, and Johnson cocked his head.

headline: In a Roundabout Way, a Maine Town’s Future May Turn on a Traffic Issue
abstract: Boothbay will vote on a measure to add a traffic roundabout to a main road, which some see as the beginning of the end for “a cozy, treasured spot.”
lead_paragraph: BOOTHBAY, Maine — The craggy coast of Maine, dotted with lobster shacks, tidal inlets and fishing villages, has long been a popular summertime destination.

headline: Home Teams Are Israeli, but Turf Is in West Bank
abstract: Palestinians are asking soccer’s governing body, FIFA, to bar clubs run by Jewish settlers from using fields in occupied territory.
lead_paragraph: MAALE ADUMIM, West Bank — The latest battleground in the age-old struggle between Israelis and Palestinians is a remote patch of green artificial turf surrounded by barren desert hills in a place where dust gathers in the mouth before the afternoon sun begins to set.

headline: A Poised Diana Taurasi Helps the Mercury Oust the Liberty
abstract: Taurasi scored a game-high 30 points, including a huge 3-pointer to end a string of Liberty comebacks, to end the Liberty’s playoff season after one game.
lead_paragraph: With a minute and a half remaining and one team’s season destined to end in Saturday night’s W.N.B.A. playoff game between the Liberty and Phoenix Mercury, Diana Taurasi, one of the W.N.B.A.’s most reliable playoff performers, decided she had seen enough.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Sunday, September 25, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “I will go to Bangalore. If I come back, then you can get me married. If I don’t come back, you can’t get me married.”

headline: Stanley Dural Jr., Founder of Buckwheat Zydeco, Dies at 68
abstract: Founded in 1979, Buckwheat Zydeco mixed Louisiana Creole traditions with R&B and rock to become one of the world’s great party bands.
lead_paragraph: Stanley Dural Jr., better known as Buckwheat, the accordionist whose band carried zydeco music from the Louisiana bayous to a worldwide audience, died on Saturday in Lafayette, La., where he was born. He was 68.

headline: Rui Cheng, Scott Huang
abstract: The couple met at Princeton and were married in the university chapel.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Rui Cheng, the daughter of Shiying Wang and Dr. Wanli Cheng of Wilmington, N.C., was married Sept. 24 to Scott Huang, the son of Joanne Huang and Chih Hsueh Huang of Great Neck, N.Y. Nicholas J. Mora, a college friend of the couple, became a minister of the American Marriage Ministries to preside; he officiated at the Princeton University Chapel in Princeton, N.J.

headline: Logan McClellan, Robert Eshleman
abstract: The couple, who met at the University of Virginia, were married at the Bryant Park Grill in New York.
lead_paragraph: Logan Michael McClellan, the son of Julia A. McClellan and Michael L. McClellan of Chesapeake, Va., was married Sept. 24 to Charles Robert Eshleman, the son of Elizabeth A. Boh and Charles L. Eshleman III, both of New Orleans, and the stepson of Helen F. Eshleman. Shane L. Regier, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at the Bryant Park Grill in New York.

headline: Amy Goldstein, Jonathan Farber
abstract: The couple met at Hamilton College, from which they both graduated, he cum laude.
lead_paragraph: Amy Lauren Goldstein, the daughter of Ellen Keats and Irv J. Goldstein of Greenwich, Conn., was married Sept. 24 to Jonathan David Farber, a son of Deborah G. Farber and Judge Sidney T. Farber of Penfield, N.Y. Rabbi Vicki Axe officiated at the Belle Haven Club in Greenwich.

headline: Francesca Antonacci, Frank Del Vecchio Jr.
abstract: The bride is a copywriter for Gucci. The groom is a police officer in New York.
lead_paragraph: Francesca Rosa Antonacci, a daughter of Rosa Antonacci and Francesco Antonacci of Brooklyn, was married Sept. 23 to Frank William Del Vecchio Jr., the son of Frank Del Vecchio of Tampa, Fla., and the late Esther Del Vecchio. The Rev. Louis Olivieri, who was ordained by the One Spirit Interfaith Seminary, officiated at the Royalton Mansion in Roslyn Heights, N.Y.

headline: Karen Sklaire, Mark Watson
abstract: The couple were married at the Brant Point Lighthouse on Nantucket.
lead_paragraph: Karen Sarah Sklaire and Mark Thomas Watson were married Sept. 24 at the Brant Point Lighthouse on Nantucket in Massachusetts. Mitchell H. Cohan, a friend of the bride’s family, who received a one-day solemnization certificate from Massachusetts, led a ceremony that incorporated Jewish traditions.

headline: Hannah Wirfel, George Jones IV
abstract: The couple, who both graduated from Trinity College, are wed.
lead_paragraph: Hannah Elisabeth Wirfel, a daughter of June A. Eichbaum and Kenneth I. Wirfel of Westport, Conn., is to be married Sept. 25 to George Davenport Jones IV, a son of Mary-Elisabeth Jones and Mr. Jones III of Concord, Mass. Rabbi Devon Lerner is to officiate with the assistance of the Rev. William Eddy, an Episcopal priest, at the Wianno Club in Osterville, Mass.

headline: Christina Kim, Mark Wagner
abstract: The couple met at Stanford, where both study neuroscience.
lead_paragraph: Christina Kay Kim, the daughter of Susan K. Kim and Young K. Kim of Huntsville, Ala., is to be married Sept. 25 to Mark Jason Wagner, a son of Robin M. Wagner and Eric M. Wagner of Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Deborah Roth, an interfaith minister, is to officiate at the Liberty House Restaurant in Jersey City.

headline: Mets Rally From 10-0 Deficit but Fall Just Short of Record Comeback
abstract: A comeback victory would have been the biggest in franchise history.

headline: Jewish and Chinese: Explaining a Shared Identity
abstract: Moshe Bernstein, a researcher based in Western Australia, discusses the revival of an ancient Jewish community facing a government clampdown.
lead_paragraph: The ancient Jewish community of Kaifeng, in central China, was experiencing a cultural and religious revival until a recent government clampdown, which has brought a ban on collective worship and forced out foreign Jewish groups. Moshe Yehuda Bernstein is a researcher based in Perth, Western Australia, who has studied this revival and written a coming book, “Globalization, Translation and Transmission: Sino-Judaic Cultural Identity in Kaifeng, China.” In an interview, Mr. Bernstein explained the background to the recent revival and official restrictions.

One extended a team’s national championship aspirations, the other effectively ended the long tenure of one of college football’s most lovable, frustrating and just plain noticeable coaches.

headline: China Hunts for Scientific Glory, and Aliens, With New Telescope
abstract: The telescope, which officially began operating on Sunday in a majestic but poor part of Guizhou Province, embodies China’s ambitions as a scientific power.
lead_paragraph: PINGTANG COUNTY, China — When hundreds of engineers and builders began clambering up a jagged hill in southwestern China to assemble a giant telescope in a deep, bowl-shaped basin, poor villagers sometimes crept over the sheer slopes to glimpse the country’s latest technological wonder.

headline: World-Class Photojournalism, at Home in the South Bronx
abstract: When the Bronx Documentary Center opened five years ago, Manhattan-centric curators scoffed. Not anymore. From Eugene Richards to emerging talents, the B.D.C. has created a diverse and dedicated community of photographers.
lead_paragraph: When Eugene Richards opens his next exhibit, it will not be at a Chelsea gallery or a major Midtown museum. It will be at a location that he much prefers: the Bronx Documentary Center.

headline: Writer Charged With Insulting Islam Is Killed as Extremism Boils Over in Jordan
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Cartoons and Cartoonists']
abstract: Nahed Hattar, who was recently arrested after sharing a cartoon on Facebook that offended some Muslims, was killed outside a court in Amman.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — Some of the most extreme elements in Jordan made clear in recent weeks that Nahed Hattar should pay for a provocative cartoon he posted online depicting a bearded man in bed with two women ordering God to bring him cashews and wine.
