headline: Marlins Pitcher Jose Fernandez Is Killed in a Boating Accident
abstract: A Coast Guard crew found the overturned boat and three bodies around 3:30 a.m. Fernandez, Miami’s ace, was 24.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Major League Baseball lost one of its best pitchers this weekend when a boat carrying Jose Fernandez of the Miami Marlins struck a pile of rocks and capsized, killing him and two other men aboard.

headline: How to Get Marni’s Clean, Glowy Beauty
abstract: The makeup artist Tom Pecheux gave models a purified look — except for layers of shimmer on their faces.
lead_paragraph: At Marni, Consuelo Castiglioni put forth a new spring/summer collection full of floaty accordion pleat dresses, and looks in single, all-over colors. Tom Pecheux, the makeup artist who has been collaborating with Castiglioni since she launched the brand in 1994, avoided distracting from the colorful clothes by creating a clean, purified beauty look, illuminated by layers of highlights. He eschewed foundation, mascara and lipstick, and added only coats of shimmer on the face.

headline: Jane Pauley to Become Anchor of CBS Show ‘Sunday Morning’
abstract: For Ms. Pauley, who catapulted to fame as an anchor of the “Today” show 40 years ago, the move represents an unexpected late-career comeback.
lead_paragraph: The veteran television personality Jane Pauley will replace Charles Osgood as the anchor of the highly rated CBS show “Sunday Morning.” Mr. Osgood, who is retiring, announced the news on his last show on Sunday.

headline: Activist in South Korea Dies of Injuries From Police Water Cannon
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The activist, Baek Nam-gi, who had been expelled from school twice for protests against the dictator Park Chung-hee, was injured while opposing Mr. Park’s daughter, President Park Geun-hye.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — An activist farmer who was expelled from school twice for protesting the rule of the military dictator Park Chung-hee of South Korea died on Sunday as a result of injuries he sustained while opposing Mr. Park’s daughter, President Park Geun-hye.

headline: N.F.L.: Here’s What We Learned in Week 3
abstract: Behind young arms, the Broncos, Eagles and Cowboys are rolling. Here’s what happened in Week 3 of the N.F.L. season.
lead_paragraph: In the N.F.L. these days, young quarterbacks are all the rage. There once was a time when a team would have to wait two or three years for a young quarterback to develop, but not anymore. The Eagles, with 23-year old Carson Wentz at quarterback, are 3-0. The Broncos, behind 23-year old Trevor Siemian, are also 3-0. And the Cowboys, riding red-hot 23-year old Dak Prescott, are 2-1.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Cook big tonight and sensible the rest of the week.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s a good day for a project dinner, something ambitious but not crazily so, the sort of meal to put a capstone on the weekend, mark it a success. I’ll give you sensible recipes for weeknight fare, as always. But for this evening’s meal, it’d be great if you could plan big and then execute. You’ll deliver incredible delight to whomever you serve.

headline: 1941: Turkey Cool To Nazis
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Hitler’s Nazi Germany makes unsuccessful offers to Turkey in September 1941.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Strong representations reportedly transmitted to Turkey by Fuehrer Adolf Hitler in an effort to make that country either withdraw from the Anglo-Turkish agreement or else enter the war actively on the side of the Axis apparently are meeting with little success, informed British sources said tonight [Sept. 25]. Turkey, admittedly in a precarious position, has shown no inclination to accept any of the recent German offers. One London authority on international affairs said: ‘‘The Anglo-Turkish pact [the tripartite agreement by Great Britain, France and Turkey about six months after the start of the war] has made Germany proceed most cautiously in her relations with Turkey.’’

headline: Everyone Knows Peter, Paul and Mary. But What About Bob?
abstract: Robert De Cormier was the recording secretary for the folk act, in charge of arranging music and mediating disputes. He will be celebrated at Symphony Space.
lead_paragraph: The world is full of who-knew jobs, jobs you did not know were jobs until you found out that somebody did them. Who knew that Peter, Paul and Mary had a “recording secretary”?

headline: Foreign Policy Questions to Ask Clinton and Trump at the Debate
abstract: So far in the American presidential election, discussion of foreign policy has seemed to chiefly involve insults and clichés.
lead_paragraph: The United States is still fighting a war in Afghanistan and has troops in Iraq, the Iranian nuclear deal remains controversial, the Islamic State is weakened but continues to be threatening, North Korea is launching missiles, Russia flouts international norms, and China has expansionary designs.

headline: Three’s a Trend: That ’70s Suit
abstract: At Gucci, Roberto Cavalli and Giamba, designers offered new takes on the decade’s dressing.
lead_paragraph: Three’s a trend — or “Three’s Company”? The ’70s are alive and well in Milan this season, with a handful of designers showing new takes on the leisure suit. At Gucci, Alessandro Michele debuted grommet-embellished denim bell bottoms with a slim jacket with wide lapels; at Roberto Cavalli, Peter Dundas went hippie-by-way-of-Marrakech with patchwork jeans paired with a striped blazer and layered scarves and enamel jewelry. Finally at Giamba, prints clashed as floral funnel pants came mixed with a cropped jacket and a contrasting tie blouse.

headline: You Need an Armed Guard to Plant These Seeds
abstract: A farm in upstate New York is growing the state’s first legal crop of industrial hemp in 80 years, but getting the plants into the ground was not easy.
lead_paragraph: EATON, N.Y. — For the first time in 80 years, a farm in New York State is legally growing cannabis. But no one could get high from these plants.

headline: Syria and Russia Appear Ready to Scorch Aleppo
abstract: The Syrians and Russians appear to be mobilizing to apply a kill-all-who-resist strategy to their most ambitious target yet.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Make life intolerable and death likely. Open an escape route, or offer a deal to those who leave or surrender. Let people trickle out. Kill whoever stays. Repeat until a deserted cityscape is yours.

headline: A Moment of Truth for Presidential Debate Moderators
abstract: News outlets and fact-checking sites can separate truth from fable after a debate, but it falls to the moderator to interject in the moment when a candidate lies.
lead_paragraph: If this hasn’t been the worst year ever for truth in politics, I can’t think of what was. Nor can anyone tell me.

headline: Why Donald Trump Should Not Be President
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Discrimination', 'Taxation', 'United States International Relations', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Editorials']
abstract: Donald Trump is a man who dwells in bigotry, bluster and false promises.
lead_paragraph: When Donald Trump began his improbable run for president 15 months ago, he offered his wealth and television celebrity as credentials, then slyly added a twist of fearmongering about Mexican “rapists” flooding across the Southern border.

headline: Review: Paris Opera Ballet Kicks Off New Season With Futuristic Choreography
abstract: During the season-opening gala on Saturday, the audience leapt to their feet, applauding wildly at the end of “The Seasons’ Canon.”
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Tropical flowers dripped off the gilded balconies and balustrades of the Palais Garnier. Huge parrots presided over the brightly hued display, and a tiger prowled through the plant-filled basin of a fountain. French pop stars and actors posed for photographs; women in couture on needle-sharp heels negotiated the crowds. (The parrots and tiger were stuffed. The women were real.)

headline: ‘The Magnificent Seven’ Dominates Weekend North American Box Office
abstract: Antoine Fuqua’s ethnically diverse remake of the John Sturges classic includes heavy-hitting stars like Denzel Washington and Chris Pratt.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — An honest-to-goodness western, “The Magnificent Seven,” arrived to a solid $35 million in domestic ticket sales over the weekend, proving that studios can make hay from worn genres and remakes if they are conceived in a totally new way.

headline: Books by Melanie Finn, Alexandra Kleeman, Robert Seethaler and Margot Livesey
abstract: One novel follows a grieving woman in Africa and Switzerland; another offers alienation in experimental tales; a third covers a life; and a fourth dissects a marriage.

headline: Taking On ‘Tristan,’ a Role That Demands Much of a Tenor
abstract: The Metropolitan Opera’s season will open with “Tristan und Isolde,” starring Stuart Skelton, who waited for just the right moment to embark on the role.
lead_paragraph: A few months after the premiere performances of Wagner’s “Tristan und Isolde,” the first Tristan, Ludwig Schnorr von Carolsfeld, fell ill. As he died, he reportedly began to sing fragments of his character’s prolonged death scene. Wagner, struck with guilt, wrote: “My Tristan! My beloved! I drove you to the abyss.”

headline: Review: ‘The Choice 2016’ Lets the Chips Fall Where They May on Clinton and Trump
abstract: This PBS documentary gives the candidates equal time while managing to avoid the journalistic pitfall sometimes labeled “false equivalency.”
lead_paragraph: Each presidential election since 1988, PBS’s “Frontline” has produced “The Choice,” an in-depth bio-documentary on the two major-party nominees — governors, senators, vice presidents, incumbents. (The 1992 edition did not include the businessman and independent candidate Ross Perot.)

headline: Yankees’ Bullpen Falters as Blue Jays Rally for Win in the Ninth
abstract: The Yankees, who had been shut out for three straight games, finally scored, but Dellin Betances and Tyler Clippard, their two top relievers, failed to protect the lead.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Once upon a time, the Yankees had a bullpen that was so indomitable that it sent fear into opposing dugouts, shortened games, and spawned T-shirt sales and pithy nicknames.

headline: A Play Timed to Trump’s Candidacy Asks What If
abstract: Mirroring similar theatrical efforts, Berkeley Rep stages an adaptation of a Sinclair Lewis novel about a vain nominee inveighing against a religious minority.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — A vain politician runs for the presidency, short on specifics but long on bluster, inveighing against a religious minority and promising to make America prosperous again.

headline: Review: ‘Breaking the Waves’ Lends Musical Heft to a von Trier Tale
abstract: Opera Philadelphia staged the premiere of this Missy Mazzoli work, adapted from a 1996 film about a woman whose marriage changes after an accident.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — If opera is the art of emotional extremity, few subjects are as operatic as “Breaking the Waves,” the 1996 Lars von Trier film that has been adapted by the composer Missy Mazzoli and the librettist Royce Vavrek. Its doomed protagonist endures trials at least the equal of Tosca’s or Madama Butterfly’s.

headline: Pronoun Privilege
abstract: At some colleges students introduce themselves by name, followed by a string of preferred pronouns. But the ritual is discomfiting.
lead_paragraph: My fall classes started recently, and I had to face the pronoun question. It’s simple for me: My appearance matches my preferred pronoun, so I don’t worry about anyone misstating it. But some of my students are transgender or gender nonconforming, and they want to announce how others should refer to them. Or do they?

headline: ‘Desperate’ Redskins Take Risks and Beat Giants
abstract: Eli Manning threw two fourth-quarter interceptions, and the Giants’ defense faltered, squandering a chance to bury their rivals deeper in the N.F.C. East standings.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Odell Beckham Jr.’s bushy platinum curls posed a stark contrast to the deep red scratch still glimmering above the corner of his right eye socket Sunday evening, as he stood in the Giants’ locker room minutes after a hard-fought defeat.

headline: Mets Crush the Phillies. Now the Hard Part.
abstract: After the team’s most lopsided win of the year, its tattered pitching staff enters the final week of the regular season with a playoff berth in the balance.
lead_paragraph: The Mets clobbered the also-ran Philadelphia Phillies, 17-0, in their most lopsided shutout victory in franchise history on Sunday. In their final home game of the season, the Mets took advantage of relentless hitting, the stellar pitching of the rookie Robert Gsellman and head-scratching mistakes by the Phillies.

headline: ‘Shut Up Already!’
abstract: Timothy Polin would like to unburden himself.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — If you can’t afford psychotherapy, I highly recommend giving crossword-puzzle constructing a try. It’s fun, it’s a creative outlet and, best of all, you don’t have to worry about whether your therapist is in-network.

I switched to Geico and got more,” the first man says.

Instead, we grudgingly eased ourselves into a seat by the door.

headline: Stories From the Black Panthers’ Unfinished Revolution
abstract: A half-century after the founding of the Black Panthers, rank-and-file members of the revolutionary black nationalist group reflect on their experiences.
lead_paragraph: In “The Black Panthers: Portraits From an Unfinished Revolution,” the photographer Bryan Shih and the historian Yohuru R. Williams tell the rarely heard stories of the rank-and-file members of the organization through portraits, interviews and scholarly essays. Fifty years after the Black Panthers’ founding, in October 1966, the volume, published by Nation Books, goes beyond charismatic leaders like Huey P. Newton, Bobby Seale and Eldridge Cleaver and allows the group’s members to reflect on their personal experiences. Below are portraits by Mr. Shih, along with short biographies as they appear in the book and audio excerpts of the testimonies.

headline: Review: Jennifer Monson, the Spellbinding Shape-Shifter

lead_paragraph: “A lot of live things mixing.” That’s what the choreographer and extraordinary improviser Jennifer Monson promised and delivered at Danspace Project on Friday night. The audience was clustered in corners of St. Mark’s Church in the East Village, and Ms. Monson was explaining to one group the prompts and ideas that she and her colleagues would be playing with, improvisationally, during a performance called “in tow.” She spoke very quietly. I thought I heard the phrases “anonymity without being hidden” and “productive unproductivity.”

headline: To Save Mosul, Arm the Sunnis
abstract: Liberating Iraq’s second largest city from the Islamic State will require more than air power and Shiite militias.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Iraq’s prime minister, Haider al-Abadi, has said that by the end of the year Mosul, Iraq’s second largest city, will be liberated from the Islamic State’s control. As of this month, Mr. Abadi, a Shiite, has had two years to rebuild the Iraqi Army with the support of an international coalition. Unfortunately, the institution remains incapable of liberating Mosul on its own, forcing Mr. Abadi to rely on Shiite militias — many of which serve as Iran’s proxies in Iraq — to conduct the war.

headline: 1941: Poles Ready to Fight Nazis
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'RUSSIA', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: The Polish army is ready to fight Nazis in Russia, according to Josef H. Retinger, the Polish Charge d’Affaires at Moscow in September 1941.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Three Polish divisions, comprising about 45,000 men, are ready to go into battle against Germany on the Russian front ‘‘within a fortnight’’ after supplies of arms and equipment for them now en route to Great Britain and America arrive in Russia, it was said today [Sept. 26]. About 80 percent of the men have had army training and 50 percent have seen combat service, according to Josef H. Retinger, Polish Charge d’Affaires at Moscow, who has just reached London. — New York Herald Tribune, Sept. 27, 1941

headline: 1966: Humphrey Doubts Kennedy
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: U.S. Vice-President Hubert H. Humphrey doubts President Kennedy’s political maturity in September 1966.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Vice-President Hubert H. Humphrey twisted a raw nerve within the Democratic hierarchy today [Sept. 26] asserting that Sen. Robert F. Kennedy displays less political maturity than President Johnson. ‘‘I don’t think Sen. Kennedy is out to get President Johnson — as such,’’ Mr. Humphrey said. Then he added: ‘‘I think he has a different point of view on some matters. I think President Johnson’s point of view is a little more mature, a little more responsible and a little bit more in the public interest.’’ Before arriving to speak on behalf of Democratic candidates in the November election, Mr. Humphrey always had attempted to submerge any friction with the Kennedy camp. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 27, 1966

headline: Red Tie and No Kiss? What Bettors Expect in the Clinton-Trump Debate
abstract: The event is inspiring all manner of side wagers: a 40 percent chance that Donald Trump will say “Crooked Hillary,” for instance.
lead_paragraph: Where there’s a spectacle, there are bettors, and Monday night’s first presidential debate is inspiring all manner of wagers.

headline: Star of British Soap Opera Is Fired Over Anti-India Twitter Posts
abstract: Marc Anwar, an actor on “Coronation Street,” condemned India and Indian citizens on Twitter; the police are investigating the activity as a hate crime.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Marc Anwar, an actor on “Coronation Street,” one of Britain’s most popular soap operas, has been fired for posting a series of Tweets condemning India and Indian citizens in incendiary language.

headline: Irene Neuwirth on the Significance of a Childhood Painting
abstract: When she was young, the jewelry designer developed an infatuation with color, painting, art and animals — which hasn’t diminished over the years.
lead_paragraph: In this series for T, the writer and author of “Worn Stories,” Emily Spivack, interviews creative types about their most prized possessions.

headline: Unrelenting Assault on Aleppo Is Called Worst Yet in Syria’s Civil War
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: Residents and rescuers described the bombardment as among the worst yet in the five-year war.
lead_paragraph: Undeterred and infuriated by Western accusations of war crimes and barbarity in the aerial assault on Aleppo, the Syrian government and its ally Russia intensively bombed the city in northern Syria on Monday for the fourth consecutive day. Residents and rescuers there described the bombardment as among the worst yet in the five-year war.

headline: Fashion Review: Milan Spring 2017 Collections
abstract: Looks from Dolce & Gabbana, Salvatore Ferragamo, Arthur Arbesser and Missoni.
lead_paragraph: Looks from Dolce & Gabbana, Salvatore Ferragamo, Arthur Arbesser and Missoni.

headline: For Rosetta, a Landing and an Ending on a Comet
abstract: The spacecraft is to end its 12-year pursuit of Comet 67P/Churyumov–Gerasimenko on Friday. Here is what the European Space Agency mission found out.
lead_paragraph: For two years, the Rosetta spacecraft has been playing around with a comet shaped like a rubber ducky.

headline: Can Maastricht Take Manhattan?
abstract: The European Fine Art Fair, Tefaf, hopes its American debut at the Park Avenue Armory helps offset the fair’s shrinking audience in Europe.
lead_paragraph: For six days beginning on Oct. 21, visitors to the crenelated, fortresslike Park Avenue Armory will find its 19th-century interior transformed into a light, modern setting. Translucent scrims will obscure the dark-wood lobby and second-floor period rooms, which will open to the public for the first time since their recent restoration. Muted colors will turn the Drill Room into airy galleries.

headline: The What-Ifs: 11 Debate Possibilities That Should Worry the Campaigns
abstract: For a face-off between such contrasting candidates, anything that happens after the introductions is a guess. Check out some possible situations.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton will be there. Donald J. Trump, too. Pleasantries will probably be exchanged. And after that, the road map for the first presidential debate is anyone’s guess. What are some of the most consequential “what-ifs” ahead of Monday night’s showdown — the possibilities that make the campaigns sweat? Or should:

headline: Gennifer Flowers, Donald Trump and the Making of the Sex-Scandal Culture
abstract: How Bill Clinton’s affairs, and the Republican nominee’s, shaped the media’s obsession.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday, Donald Trump once again used his Twitter feed to kick up a news microcycle when he tweeted that if Mark Cuban, a prominent Hillary Clinton supporter and occasional Trump nemesis, was going to attend the debate, “perhaps I will put Gennifer Flowers right alongside of him!” Trump’s campaign was quick to clarify that he was just making a point, but by merely mentioning the idea, Trump managed to reopen a chapter of ancient Clinton history that has played a mercifully small role in an otherwise sordid election cycle.

headline: Fashion Week Photo Diary: Dolce & Gabbana, Marni, Missoni and Arthur Arbesser
abstract: Scenes from the spring/summer 2017 collections that were presented in Milan on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the spring/summer 2017 collections that were presented in Milan on Sunday.

headline: For Debate Organizer, a New Priority: Crowd Control
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Debates (Political)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Spectators at the general election debates have long been seen but not heard, but that tradition seemed threatened by a campaign full of gamesmanship.
lead_paragraph: Debate audiences sometimes seemed to lose all inhibitions this year. They hooted like wrestling fans in March throughout a Republican primary debate in Detroit. They booed and stomped at a Democratic forum the next month in Brooklyn.

headline: What You Should Watch This Week: ‘Younger’ and ‘Magic Mike XXL’
abstract: From the Watching team, expert TV and movie recommendations for the next few days.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Watching, The New York Times’s what-to-watch guide. We comb through releases big and small to email readers twice a week with our timely recommendations. You can browse previous guides here, and to receive recommendations straight to your inbox, sign up here. Stay tuned for our coming website.

headline: A Powerful Legacy
abstract: David Ortiz, who plans to retire after this season, was not unfailingly clutch for the Boston Red Sox, but when they have won, Ortiz has carried them.
lead_paragraph: David Ortiz, who plans to retire after this season, was not unfailingly clutch for the Boston Red Sox, but when they have won, Ortiz has carried them.

headline: David Ortiz Is Ready to Trot Away
abstract: The slugger who helped lift the cloud over the Red Sox is still crushing homers at age 40. But his remarkable season is a definitive goodbye.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 1, 1986, at the old Arlington Stadium in Texas, Dave Kingman hit his 35th home run of the season for the Oakland Athletics. About 7,000 fans were there to see it. Kingman finished the season hitting .210 and never played in the majors again.

headline: S.E.C. Takes Different Strategy in Insider Trading Case
abstract: The agency claims that the hedge fund manager Leon Cooperman breached a duty of trust by trading on confidential information.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission’s latest insider trading case, against the prominent hedge fund manager Leon G. Cooperman, will test whether the old proverb “where there’s smoke, there’s fire” is enough to prove a violation.

headline: The Best Way to Teach Reading
abstract: A former teacher writes that she can attest to the superiority of phonics over whole language.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Drake Returns to No. 1 and Releases ‘Please Forgive Me’ Video
abstract: The rapper’s “Views” notched a 13th week at the top of the Billboard 200 as he released a 23-minute video on Apple Music.
lead_paragraph: Remember Drake? He dominated the music charts for most of the summer, and now, just has he has released a new long-form video via Apple Music, he is back at No. 1.

headline: Together, in Med School
abstract: A psychiatrist writes about a successful student-run note-taking system shared by all.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Seeking Accountability for Wells Fargo Sham Accounts
abstract: Readers are shocked by the lack of bank oversight and cynical about how the discovery of the fraud will play out.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: An Artist’s New Look — at the Hairdresser, and on Show
abstract: Sol Calero brings T to Gloria’s Unisex Salon, a source of inspiration and reminder of home, for a haircut.
lead_paragraph: “Coming here reminds me of home,” says the Venezuelan artist Sol Calero as she relaxes into her chair. It’s days before the opening of her sophomore show at Laura Bartlett Gallery in London, and Calero is at Gloria’s Unisex Salon, a local’s haunt that’s situated under the railway arches in Elephant and Castle. “I realized I needed a change,” she says, showing off her Rapunzel length jet-black hair. “It has got so long that cycling around Berlin, where I live, has become kind of dangerous.” It’s not the first time the artist has visited Gloria Dominguez’s salon. After spotting an advertisement for the hairdresser in a copy of the local Latin News (Dominguez hails from Ecuador), Calero enlisted her help for her debut display at Laura Bartlett — a reconstructed Latin beauty salon, where visitors could get their hair and nails done.

headline: Meet Quetsche, a New Brand Inspired by Fantasy
abstract: A look at the line’s fall/winter 2016 collection.
lead_paragraph: A look at the line’s fall/winter 2016 collection.

headline: Brand to Know: A Line of Deconstructed Unisex Pieces, Inspired by Fantasy
abstract: Li Yang of the brand Quetsche, who has worked previously for Dior and Maison Martin Margiela, finds inspiration in cartoons.
lead_paragraph: Li Yang had no interest in being a fashion designer when he was growing up in the industrial city of Changchun, China. He liked science best at school — and though he would play after class in his mother’s clothing factory, where she manufactured mass-market apparel, he read Japanese manga, never fashion magazines. The feminine figures he sketched resembled Hayao Miyazaki’s Princess Nausicaä, heroine of the post-apocalyptic tale “Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind” — not the typical elongated croquis of fashion illustrations.

headline: Pfizer Remains Whole, but the Option to Split Could Return
abstract: Wall Street has given Pfizer the benefit of the doubt, but investors do not universally love the decision not to break up.
lead_paragraph: Pfizer has finally admitted that there is no rabbit in its breakup hat.

headline: With Statue’s Removal, Lenin Is Momentarily Toppled on the Lower East Side
abstract: An 18-foot statue of Vladimir Lenin was taken down from the roof of a building on Houston Street, but is expected to be reinstalled just down the block.
lead_paragraph: The copper statue of Vladimir Lenin stood above the Lower East Side cityscape for more than 20 years, facing southwest with one arm perpetually raised as if in mid-oration. Visible from neighboring buildings and the sidewalk below, the statue topped a 13-story luxury apartment building on Houston Street and presented an unusual juxtaposition: the founder of Soviet Communism perched atop a decidedly capitalist enterprise.

headline: College Education in Prison
abstract: The president of John Jay College of Criminal Justice writes that we should “restore college education to our prisons.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Chris Bosh’s Desire to Play Leaves Heat at an Ethical Crossroads
abstract: Bosh’s last two seasons have been cut short by blood clots, and Miami has indicated it doesn’t want him to step on the court this season, or perhaps ever again.
lead_paragraph: Chris Bosh, one of the top players in the N.B.A., has never caused trouble for his team, on or off the court. He has won two N.B.A. titles and been selected for the All-Star Game 11 times. The Miami Heat, however, do not want him to step on the court for them this season, or perhaps ever again.

headline: The Box Office Power of Denzel Washington
abstract: With the successful opening weekend for “The Magnificent Seven,” here is a look back at the box office for five other recent Denzel Washington movies.
lead_paragraph: With the successful opening weekend for “The Magnificent Seven,” here is a look back at the box office for five other recent Denzel Washington movies.

headline: Playing for His Country Brought Out Arnold Palmer’s Best
abstract: His Ryder Cup record in six appearances as a player was 22-8-2.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Few golfers were more enthusiastic about the Ryder Cup than Arnold Palmer. His seven appearances for the United States in the biennial event, including six as a player, were a continuation of a patriot’s act that began when Palmer dropped out of Wake Forest during his senior year and served three years in the Coast Guard.

headline: بعد مرور عام، تلميح إلى تهريب عبر الحدود تؤتي ثمارها

headline: Organic Milk Will Wait and Wait for You
keywords: ['Milk', 'Organic Foods and Products', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning']
abstract: A different, hotter pasteurization process helps explain why organic milk has a longer shelf life than the other stuff.
lead_paragraph: Q. Why does organic milk have a longer shelf life, as signified by later expiration dates, than regular milk?

headline: Some Good News on Ovarian Cancer
abstract: The death rate from the disease declined in the United States by 16 percent from 2002 to 2012, among the largest reductions in the world.
lead_paragraph: The death rate from ovarian cancer declined in the United States by 16 percent from 2002 to 2012, among the largest reductions in the world.

abstract: Readers react to articles in Science Times.

headline: Williams Companies, Under Pressure, Continues Board Overhaul
abstract: The company appointed two more independent directors and will select another two by November, prompting an activist investor to call off a proxy fight.
lead_paragraph: In just three months, the Williams Companies’ board has experienced more conflict than many companies do in a lifetime. On Monday, the public discord was put to rest, at least for now.

headline: Bones Unearthed in Finger Lakes Backyard Are Those of Long-Dead Inmates
abstract: A homeowner working in his backyard in July made the gruesome discovery: human remains buried more than a century ago by the local state prison.
lead_paragraph: AUBURN, N.Y. — Like a lot of new homeowners, Eric Johnson II had ambitious plans when he moved into his tidy beige house this summer. He envisioned a swing set in back for his 2-year-old son, and a detached garage.

headline: How The New York Times Will Fact-Check the Debate
abstract: With clashes over falsehoods dominating the prelude to the first presidential debate, we have assembled a team of at least 18 fact-checkers to help cover it.
lead_paragraph: With clashes over truth, lies and exaggerations dominating the prelude to the first presidential debate, The New York Times has assembled a team of at least 18 fact-checkers for Monday night, drawing on the expertise of some of our most seasoned reporters. (Here’s our live analysis and video of the debate, highlights and fact checks.)

headline: السعوديون والتطرف: مشعلو النار ومخمدوها
abstract: يعتبر النقاد أن ما تصدره المملكة العربية السعودية من نهج الإسلام المتشدد يساهم في تصاعد الإرهاب، ولكن امتداد نفوذ المملكة يعتمد بشكل كبير على المعطيات المحلية.
lead_paragraph: يعتبر النقاد أن ما تصدره المملكة العربية السعودية من نهج الإسلام المتشدد يساهم في تصاعد الإرهاب، ولكن امتداد نفوذ المملكة يعتمد بشكل كبير على المعطيات المحلية.

headline: ‘A Steel-Nerved Master’: How We Introduced Arnold Palmer in 1958
abstract: After winning The Masters, Palmer was featured in a “Man in the News” column in The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Arnold Palmer won the first of his seven major championships at the Masters in 1958. Here is an excerpt from Man in the News column in The New York Times on April 7, 1958.

headline: Witness Details Origins of Bridge Plot and Links Scheme to Christie Aides
abstract: David Wildstein, the mastermind behind the lane closings, testified that Gov. Chris Christie’s former campaign manager knew about the plan and that it was meant as political retribution.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — David Wildstein was in the operations center of the George Washington Bridge one morning in March 2011 for a discussion about the number of toll collectors when he noticed there were three lanes leading to the bridge cordoned off where traffic was moving faster than the others.

headline: Times Editor Dean Baquet on the Future of The New York Times
abstract: Dean Baquet, executive editor of The New York Times, talks with the media columnist Jim Rutenberg about “a way of telling stories that is unimaginably different.”
lead_paragraph: Dean Baquet, executive editor of The New York Times, talks with the media columnist Jim Rutenberg about “a way of telling stories that is unimaginably different.”

headline: What It’s Like to Fight Online Hate
keywords: ['ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Bullies', 'Censorship', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Cyberharassment', 'Discrimination', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Social Media', 'Threats and Threatening Messages']
abstract: When the Anti-Defamation League hired Brittan Heller to work with tech companies against harassment, she was deluged with online attacks.
lead_paragraph: Brittan Heller has a hard job. The Anti-Defamation League’s first director of technology and society, she’ll be working with tech companies to combat online harassment. The magnitude of her task became clear as soon as the A.D.L. announced her hire earlier this month, when she was deluged with anti-Semitic and sexist attacks. In a recent interview, Ms. Heller talked about what companies can do to stop online abuse and how her personal experiences have informed her, and offered advice for others dealing with harassment online.

headline: Researchers Make Progress Toward Identifying C.T.E. in the Living
abstract: One group of researchers revealed a step toward identifying in the brain a biomarker linked to the disease; another found elevated levels of tau proteins in blood samples.
lead_paragraph: One of the frustrations of researchers who study chronic traumatic encephalopathy, the degenerative brain disease linked to repeated head hits, is that it can be detected only in autopsies, and not in the living.

headline: Iran Releases Homa Hoodfar, a Canadian-Iranian Professor Held Since June
abstract: Iran never said why it was holding the professor, but her release coincided with an announcement that Canada and Iran would discuss reopening embassies.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — A Canadian-Iranian professor who was arrested by Iranian intelligence officers in June was released on Monday, the government news agency IRNA reported.

headline: New Sarah Ruhl Play to Premiere at Lincoln Center
abstract: The playwright also will receive this year’s Steinberg Distinguished Playwright Award.
lead_paragraph: Add one prominent production and one lucrative prize to the tally for Sarah Ruhl. The playwright is the recipient of this year’s Steinberg Distinguished Playwright Award, and her latest work, “How to Transcend a Happy Marriage,” will make its debut at Lincoln Center Theater in March.

headline: Alton Brown, Showman of Food TV, Pulls Back the Curtain
abstract: As he releases a new cookbook, “EveryDayCook: This Time It’s Personal,” the very private host reflects on a difficult time in his life.
lead_paragraph: MARIETTA, Ga. — The afternoon sun had melted most of the ice in the Mason jar that held Alton Brown’s sangria. At 54 and recently divorced, the king of the food-science geeks and master of ceremonies to the first Food Network generation rocked gently on a backyard swing and pondered the big questions.

headline: Dean Baquet: The Golden Age of Journalism Is Now!
abstract: Dean Baquet, executive editor of The New York Times, talks with the media columnist Jim Rutenberg about “a way of telling stories that is unimaginably different.”
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into news, features and opinion at The New York Times.

headline: What We’re Seeing in the First Presidential Debate
abstract: How Donald Trump vs. Hillary Clinton looks to Times Opinion writers — before, during and after.
lead_paragraph: How Donald Trump vs. Hillary Clinton looks to Times Opinion writers — before, during and after.

headline: After Setbacks, a Baritone Works His Way Back to the Met Opera
abstract: Simon Keenlyside, the British singer, discussed vocal damage and other recent challenges ahead of his turn in Mozart’s “Don Giovanni.”
lead_paragraph: The first crisis to silence Simon Keenlyside — the British baritone whose refined musicality and edge-of-your-seat theatricality have made him a favorite in both recital halls and opera houses — hit nearly two years ago in the most high-profile of settings.

headline: Twitter’s Steep Premium: The Cost of Employee Stock Grants
keywords: ['Stock Options and Purchase Plans', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Twitter has relied on stock-based compensation more than its peers in Silicon Valley, and that has unavoidable implications for potential buyers.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Buying Twitter would be a challenge for a number of reasons. Among the lesser-explored ones: The struggling social network pays out so much stock to its employees.

headline: For Tenants Facing Eviction, New York May Guarantee a Lawyer
keywords: ['Legal Aid for the Poor (Civil)', 'Evictions', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Affordable Housing']
abstract: A bill backed by a majority on the City Council would aid low-income residents who are outmatched in Housing Court.
lead_paragraph: Outside Housing Court in the Bronx, the line invariably winds down the block, snaking past the vendors at tables hawking cellphone plans and by a man selling moving boxes.

headline: Sharon Olds, Laureate of Sexuality, Scrutinizes the Body in ‘Odes’
abstract: This Pulitzer Prize-winning poet’s latest collection continues to push boundaries, and includes some of the best and most ingenious poems of her career.
lead_paragraph: Sharon Olds feels bad about her neck. In her new book there is a poem called “Ode to Wattles,” and it is about what you suspect it’s about: the poet’s “face hanging down from the bottom of my face,” the “slackness of the drapery.”

headline: Tardigrades Have the Right Stuff to Resist Radiation
abstract: Japanese researchers have found a protein in tardigrade cells that confers an ability to tolerate doses of radiation that would kill most other animals.
lead_paragraph: Tardigrades, eight-legged microscopic animals that resemble obese caterpillars, can survive temperatures close to absolute zero and live after being baked at 300 degrees.

headline: Ringing Up a New Species of Crab
abstract: A previously unknown category of freshwater crab was found in a pet shop in a subtropical province of China and is being called Yuebeipotamon.
lead_paragraph: A previously unknown freshwater crab has been discovered in plain sight: on sale at a pet shop in China.

headline: Geysers May Erupt on Europa, Jupiter’s Moon
abstract: There is new evidence that plumes of water erupt through the icy surface of Jupiter’s moon Europa.
lead_paragraph: The Hubble Space Telescope has found further evidence that plumes of water erupt through the icy surface of Jupiter’s moon Europa. If the geysers do exist, they may provide NASA with opportunities to study the moon’s subsurface ocean during flyby missions.

headline: Ants Pick Morphine Over Sugar
abstract: This is the first nonmammal to display drug-seeking behavior, researchers said.
lead_paragraph: Ants, like people and rats, can become addicted to morphine.

headline: First Clinton and Trump Debate: Analysis
abstract: The Times analyzed the first presidential debate between Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump in real time.
lead_paragraph: The Times analyzed the first presidential debate between Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump in real time.

abstract: Mr. Rosenthal, a columnist at The Times, will host a panel about the delicate balance, at a time of frequent killing sprees.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Times Insider Events — live programming for Times Insiders and their guests.

headline: Pride and Pain on Opening Day at a Museum of African-American History
abstract: On Sunday, the opening hours stretched from 7 a.m. to midnight. The building was packed throughout, but the mood was largely jubilant.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — They arrived here by the thousands in rented buses and on foot, in wheelchairs and strollers, with church groups and college friends.

headline: Presidential Debate, Houston, Syria: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

abstract: What you need to know about the presidential debate, the continuing George Washington Bridge drama and a collision in the Lincoln Tunnel.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:08 p.m.

headline: Brooklyn Officer Charged With Murder and Manslaughter in Off-Duty Shooting
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Wayne Isaacs, who shot another driver after a road-rage episode in July, is the first police officer to be prosecuted by the New York attorney general.
lead_paragraph: A New York City police officer was charged on Monday with second-degree murder, accused of fatally shooting a man during an off-duty confrontation on July 4 in Brooklyn, the officer’s lawyer said.

headline: How Italian Designers Used the Past as Inspiration
abstract: Milan Fashion Week saw a handful of labels — including Prada, Gucci and Versace — referencing different eras as a way of nodding to the future.
lead_paragraph: The evening after her spring/summer 2017 show, at the cinema in the heart of the multimillion dollar Milanese art foundation bearing her surname, Miuccia Prada premiered a film to a small audience. It was directed by David O. Russell, and veered between the simultaneous stories of three women, all obviously wearing Prada. Snippets of it had also played on giant screens throughout the Prada fashion show, specially calibrated to coordinate with the show’s soundtrack, of “MacArthur Park” and Diana Ross’s “Reflections.” The film, which will be released on Prada’s website in October, is called “Past Forward.”

headline: No Debate: Trump Picks a Perfect Transition Man for the E.P.A.
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Environment', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: A longtime defender of fossil fuels and critic of regulations limiting greenhouse gases appears to be Trump’s pick to handle the transition at the Environmental Protection Agency should he prevail.
lead_paragraph: Late this afternoon, I sent an email query to Myron Ebell, the longtime director of energy and environmental policy at the Competitive Enterprise Institute, to check on reports that he’d been tapped by Donald J. Trump’s campaign to run the evisceration transition team for the Environmental Protection Agency should Trump prevail in November. Robin Bravender at E&E’s Climate Wire appeared to lead the pack this morning. (Read more about Trump’s environmental game plan in a detailed E&E feature by Kevin Bogardus.)

headline: Man Charged With Murder in Shooting of 5 at Mall in Washington State
abstract: No motive was disclosed as Arcan Cetin was formally charged in the killings at the Cascade Mall, north of Seattle.
lead_paragraph: MOUNT VERNON, Wash. — Arcan Cetin, the man accused of shooting five people to death in a rampage at a shopping mall last week, was charged on Monday with five counts of first-degree murder.

headline: Wells Fargo Workers Claim Retaliation for Playing by the Rules
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: In two lawsuits seeking class-action status, workers say they were fired or demoted for acting ethically and falling short of unrealistic sales goals.
lead_paragraph: At least 5,300 Wells Fargo employees have been fired for ethics violations like setting up illicit accounts without customers’ knowledge to meet sales targets. Now there’s another group of aggrieved Wells Fargo workers: people who say they were fired or demoted for staying honest and falling short of sales goals they say were unrealistic.

headline: Suit Accuses Alabama of Bias in Law That Bars Some Felons From Voting
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Ex-Convicts', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Discrimination', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: Language citing ‘moral turpitude’ is seen as vague and as being applied arbitrarily to disenfranchise black and poor people.
lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — Constance Todd, 70 years old and a diligent voter in elections local and national, did not know what to make of the letter she got from the local registrar this month.

headline: Colombia Signs Peace Agreement With FARC After 5 Decades of War
abstract: The ceremony brought an end to a war that has killed as many as 220,000 people and displaced more than five million.
lead_paragraph: In a Caribbean resort city, far from the jungles where guerrilla battles once raged, the Colombian government and the country’s largest rebel group signed a peace agreement on Monday evening.

headline: Giants’ Shane Vereen May Miss Rest of Season With a Torn Triceps
abstract: Coach Ben McAdoo said he wasn’t sure when the injury occurred but said Vereen may have been playing with it “for a significant amount of time.”
lead_paragraph: The Giants announced Monday that running back Shane Vereen would have surgery to repair a torn triceps muscle, most likely ending his season and dealing a significant blow to the team’s rushing attack.

headline: After a Debacle, the Jets Already Face a Potential Turning Point
abstract: Quarterback Ryan Fitzpatrick had the worst game of his career, and the team’s red-zone offense, among the best last year, is now among the worst.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — By any objective measure, Ryan Fitzpatrick quarterbacked the worst game of his 12-year career Sunday. He threw six interceptions in a 24-3 loss at Kansas City, the most in the N.F.L. since 2007, and compiled an 18.2 passer rating, his lowest ever in a game he started.

headline: Perry Closes Flagship Fund as Clients Flee After Losses
abstract: “The industry and market headwinds against us have been strong, and the timing for success in our positions too unpredictable,” Richard C. Perry said.
lead_paragraph: Richard C. Perry, once one of the hedge fund industry’s most successful investors, is shuttering his flagship fund as clients leave after steep losses.

headline: Trump’s a Businessman. Where’s His Business Backing?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Campaign Finance', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Despite pushing proposals that sound like a corporate chieftain’s dream, the Republican nominee isn’t getting much love from his peers.
lead_paragraph: Should it come as a surprise that not one chief executive among the Fortune 100 has donated money to Donald Trump’s campaign?

headline: Talking Parades With the Police
abstract: Recalling a first Halloween in New York, and an unexpected chat with three friendly officers.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Pierre Huyghe Wins Nasher Sculpture Prize
abstract: The $100,000 Nasher Prize went to this French artist whose work challenges “the very limits of artmaking.”
lead_paragraph: The French artist Pierre Huyghe, who has stretched the concept of sculpture’s stability in recent years by making work with decidedly unstable elements like bees, spiders, horseshoe crabs and artificial snowstorms, has won the Nasher Prize, an award created by the Nasher Sculpture Center in Dallas to draw attention to the work of the most influential contemporary sculptors.

headline: U.S. Accuses Tech Firm Palantir of Bias Against Asian Engineers
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Asian-Americans', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Government Contracts and Procurement', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Palantir Technologies, which helped the government find Osama bin Laden, could lose its federal contracts in a discrimination suit.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The United States Department of Labor sued Palantir Technologies, a prominent data analytics start-up, claiming systemic discrimination against Asian job applicants. The move again raises questions about diversity in Silicon Valley.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Name Misspelled on Debate Ticket
abstract: Hillary Clinton’s first name was misspelled on commemorative tickets given to the audience at the first debate.
lead_paragraph: Months of preparation went into the first presidential debate, which will be watched by millions of people, but members of the audience arrived on Monday night to find at least one major detail that went awry: the spelling of Hillary Clinton’s name.

headline: Emotion Takes Center Stage After Tragic Loss of Jose Fernandez
abstract: Fernandez, a Miami Marlins pitcher who died in a boating accident with two others, represented the best to his teammates, his city and his Cuban compatriots.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — It did not win a pennant. It did not heal the aching heart of a sport and a community. And the one thing everyone wants — for Jose Fernandez to come bounding into Marlins Park and resume his life of joy — will never happen.

headline: Man Convicted in Kidnapping and Murder of Brooklyn Landlord
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Kidnapping and Hostages']
abstract: Kendel Felix was found guilty in the death of Menachem Stark, whose charred remains were found in a trash bin on Long Island, in 2014.
lead_paragraph: A 29-year-old man was convicted of kidnapping and murder on Monday for his role in the killing of a Brooklyn landlord during a botched robbery two years ago.

headline: To Kneel or Not in the N.B.A.? For Some Stars, Team Consensus Is Key
keywords: ['Basketball', 'National Anthems', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: The league’s rule book requires players, coaches and trainers “to stand and line up in a dignified posture” during the national anthem.
lead_paragraph: With the first exhibition games of the N.B.A. season less than a week away, the players find themselves in deep preparation for what had been the least taxing part of the game: the playing of the national anthem.

headline: Golf Great Arnold Palmer Was Also a Pioneering Pitchman
abstract: Mr. Palmer hawked nearly 50 products over a half-century and created the template for the modern entrepreneurial athlete.
lead_paragraph: In a grainy black-and-white 1968 television commercial, Arnold Palmer steers a Mercury Monterey up to a golf course, nodding approvingly at the coupe’s smooth handling. A few years later, Mr. Palmer was driving up to another course, this time in color, in a flashy Cadillac El Dorado.

headline: Dee Gordon Hits His First Home Run of the Year in Tribute to Jose Fernandez
abstract: Gordon took one pitch in Fernandez’s right-handed stance, then hit his first homer of the season.
lead_paragraph: In a moving and surreal tribute to Jose Fernandez on Monday night, the Miami Marlins’ Dee Gordon took the first pitch in the bottom of the first inning against the Mets batting right-handed, imitating Fernandez’s stance, then switched to his natural left-handed stance.

headline: Derrick Rose Case Is Subject of Los Angeles Police Investigation
abstract: The Police Department confirmed it was conducting its own inquiry into a rape accusation against Rose that is the subject of a civil suit. At the Knicks’ preseason media day, Rose said he would be proved innocent.
lead_paragraph: For the Knicks and many other N.B.A. teams, Monday was media day, an annual ritual that serves as the start of training camp. But in his 10-minute session with reporters, Derrick Rose was not asked much about the coming season.

headline: Kerr Putney, Charlotte Chief, Had Cause in His Life to Distrust Police
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Caught between defending his officers and regaining the trust of many who claim he has reacted badly to the fatal police shooting of a black man.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Kerr Putney, who 15 months ago was sworn in as Charlotte’s second black police chief, has spoken openly of his own lingering, lifelong distrust of the police.

headline: American Express Can Stop Merchants From Steering Clients to Other Cards
keywords: ['Credit Cards', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']
abstract: A federal appeals court reversed a 2015 ruling that a provision in American Express’s contracts with merchants violated federal antitrust law.
lead_paragraph: American Express will be able to prevent businesses from pushing customers toward competing credit cards after all.

headline: Our Fact Checks of the First Debate
abstract: Our team of reporters fact-checked Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump on the economy, trade and other issues.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump kept fact-checkers busy throughout their first debate on Monday night as they sparred over their policies and records on the economy, national security, the environment and their personal pasts. In keeping with how he has run his campaign, Mr. Trump stretched the facts more often than Mrs. Clinton did; a couple of times, Mrs. Clinton literally called out for fact-checkers from the stage. (Here’s how we analyzed it live, and  the highlights.)

headline: My Take on the Presidential Debate
abstract: Live tweeting the smackdown between Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump dueled tonight in the presidential debate, and here’s my play-by-play commentary. And no, this isn’t a column or even a formal blog post; it’s simply an assortment of my tweets during the debate. Think of it as journalism on the fly — and here goes!

headline: Recuperating
abstract: Robert Cirillo isn’t feeling well.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Robert Cirillo’s word ladder in today’s crossword puzzle is just like any other kind of ladder you might find at a hardware store, as long as you don’t mind that several of the rungs between the top and the bottom are missing and that there’s a ZIPLINE in the middle. But other than that, they are pretty much the same.

headline: Let’s Play ‘Underground Railroad Game’: A Lacerating Comedy on Race
abstract: This shocking play from the Philadelphia-based Lightning Rod Special troupe is about finding ways to speak to one another about an unspeakable American institution.
lead_paragraph: Our “safe word” for today is “Sojourner.”

headline: Review: ‘Nat Turner in Jerusalem,’ an Avatar of Divine Vengeance
abstract: Nathan Alan Davis’s contemplative and largely inert play depicts the famous leader of a slave uprising as a biblical martyr and prophet.
lead_paragraph: Though he is to be hanged in the morning, before a crowd that wants nothing more than to see him die, the title character of “Nat Turner in Jerusalem” lights up the night with a luminous, faith-filled serenity. He regrets that his single, west-looking prison window will not allow him to see the next daybreak, but, as he says, “Where I am going, the sunrises are infinite.”

headline: Ahmad Khan Rahami’s Father and Wife Retain A.C.L.U. to Defend Him
abstract: A dispute continues over what jurisdiction should provide a lawyer for Mr. Rahami, who faces federal charges in both New York and New Jersey for two bombings.
lead_paragraph: The question of legal representation for Ahmad Khan Rahami, the man accused of carrying out recent bombings in Manhattan and on the Jersey Shore, took a new turn on Monday when the American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey said that it had been retained by his father and his wife to defend him on federal charges, at least until he was given a federal public defender or other lawyer.

headline: CUNY Application Fee to Be Waived for Low-Income Students
abstract: The initiative, which applies to New York City public school students, is part of an effort by the city to encourage more young people to go to college.
lead_paragraph: New York City public school students from low-income families will no longer have to pay a fee to apply to the City University of New York, the city announced on Monday, part of an effort to encourage more young people to go to college.

headline: Jean Shepard, a Female Country Voice With Muscle and Ambition, Dies at 82
abstract: Ms. Shepard, also an expert yodeler, joined the Grand Ole Opry in 1955.
lead_paragraph: Jean Shepard, a mainstay of the Grand Ole Opry whose feisty honky-tonk songs of the 1950s and ’60s paved the way for the brash, assertive style of singers like Loretta Lynn, died on Sunday in Gallatin, Tenn. She was 82.

headline: Trump and Clinton in First Debate
abstract: Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton clashed on taxes, crime and race during their presidential debate on Monday at Hofstra University in Hempstead, N.Y. The Times reporter Michael D. Shear weighs in on the night of pointed attacks.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton clashed on taxes, crime and race during their presidential debate on Monday at Hofstra University in Hempstead, N.Y. The Times reporter Michael D. Shear weighs in on the night of pointed attacks.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump Press Pointed Attacks in Debate
abstract: In the first general-election debate, Mr. Trump criticized Mrs. Clinton on trade and her email practices, and she called him unfit to be commander in chief.
lead_paragraph: In a relentlessly antagonistic debate, Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton clashed over trade, the Iraq war, his refusal to release his tax returns and her use of a private email server, with Mr. Trump frequently showing impatience and political inexperience as Mrs. Clinton pushed him to defend his past denigration of women and President Obama.

headline: Decline in Oil Prices Lands on Government Workers as Saudi Arabia Cuts Paychecks
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Government Employees', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: The reductions affect a wide range of government employees, from ministers, whose pay was cut by 20 percent, to civil servants, whose overtime pay and vacation time will face new limits.
lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — Saudi Arabia on Monday announced sudden, drastic cuts to salaries and perks for government employees as part of the kingdom’s struggle to slash spending at a time of low oil prices.

headline: Lester Holt, Given a Choice Assignment, Opted for Restraint
abstract: Mr. Holt often held back during the debate, allowing the two candidates to bicker, but he did reject Donald J. Trump’s claim that he opposed the Iraq war.
lead_paragraph: Call him the minimalist moderator.

headline: International Cricket’s Biggest Test Is Security
abstract: England will play a series in Bangladesh next month without some of its leading players because of safety concerns.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When England’s cricket team plays a one-day international match in Bangladesh on Oct. 7, it will do so without its captain, Eoin Morgan, who recently opted out of the tour, citing security concerns. Alex Hales, another leading English player, made the same decision, and the team’s largest fan group has said that it, too, will follow an official government security warning and skip the tour.

headline: Yankees Rally Past Blue Jays by Putting Up a Fight. Two of Them, Actually.
abstract: Bench-clearing incidents in the top and bottom of the second inning resulted in four ejections, and the Yankees took the lead in the ninth with two home runs.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — As the losses have piled up for the Yankees, drawing them closer to elimination, Manager Joe Girardi has praised his players for continuing to fight.

headline: An Ugly Campaign, Condensed Into One Debate
abstract: The word “debate” loses its meaning when one candidate is serious and the other is a vacuous bully.
lead_paragraph: “Debate” is an iffy word for an exercise in which candidates are prompted by moderators to dole out their stump speeches bit by bit under hot lights while a clock counts the seconds and every quip and jab and stumble is used to keep score and proclaim a “winner.”

headline: Clinton Could Have Corrected Trump, but He Blared ‘Wrong!’
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Debates (Political)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The first presidential debate was a lot like the presidential race itself: largely devoid of a way for voters to know who was sticking to the facts.
lead_paragraph: It did not come from the moderator, Lester Holt of NBC, or from Hillary Clinton. Often the closest thing to fact-checking to occur during Monday’s presidential debate was the low, blaring honk of Donald J. Trump’s voice: “Wrong!”

headline: For a Night, the Mets’ Focus Shifts From Competition to Empathy
abstract: In the heat of a playoff race, the Mets understood the added importance of their role in facing the Miami Marlins a day after the death of the star pitcher Jose Fernandez.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — No matter how hard the Mets tried on Monday night, the emotions that overtook Marlins Park were so raw and profound that even they struggled. Jose Fernandez was not their teammate, but he was a young, vibrant and talented pitcher whom the Mets admired from afar and who sparked their own competitive fire.

headline: How Hillary Clinton Went From Hesitant to Scorching
abstract: Mrs. Clinton, with some help from the moderator, Lester Holt, found her footing during the second half and attacked Mr. Trump on his treatment of women.
lead_paragraph: It started with a mystifying missed opportunity on race. It ended with a piercing attack on gender.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Tuesday, September 27, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “You get up. You boil water in the microwave to take your sink bath. You sometimes want to save that water to use it to flush it in the toilet. It is what it is. You’ve got to learn to live this way until God gives us rain.”

headline: Prediction Markets Score the Debate a Rout: Clinton Over Trump
abstract: Hillary Clinton’s odds of winning the election rose from around 63 percent in the minutes before the debate started to 69 percent by the end.
lead_paragraph: According to the people who put money on the line in the political prediction markets, Hillary Clinton clearly won the first debate.

headline: Paris Fashion Week, Day 1: Enter the Newbies
abstract: What used to be a barely there first day of shows has become a showcase for the new guard.
lead_paragraph: No offense to Milan or London (though some will surely be taken), but the fashion world waits and waits for Paris Fashion Week. And now, after days of costolette and aperitivi in Milan, it has arrived. The traveling class began arriving yesterday (some, to judge by Instagram, after sneaking in a day off in Como or Cap d’Antibes) and continues today. But the shows won’t wait. What used to be a barely there day of shows has grown into a showcase for the new guard. Here’s what to look for today.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday: Issa Rae in ‘Insecure,’ ‘The Lobster’ and ‘Drunk History’
abstract: Check out the pilot of “Insecure,” the series from Issa Rae of “Awkward Black Girl” fame, or tuck into ‘The Lobster.’ And the Emmy-nominated “Drunk History” begins a fourth season.
lead_paragraph: Check out the pilot of “Insecure,” the series from Issa Rae of “Awkward Black Girl” fame, before the official premiere. Get more info on the presidential candidates from “Frontline.” And the Emmy-nominated “Drunk History” begins a fourth season of revisionist tales.

abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Tuesday, September 27, 2016.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Drew Brees’s Interception-Free Streak Ends as Falcons Keep Saints Winless
abstract: Atlanta defeated New Orleans, 45-32, behind three rushing touchdowns by Tevin Coleman.
lead_paragraph: Matt Ryan threw two touchdown passes, Tevin Coleman ran for three and linebacker Deion Jones returned an interception 90 yards to power the Atlanta Falcons to a 45-32 victory over the host New Orleans Saints on Monday night.

lead_paragraph: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y. — As Monday night’s presidential debate neared its end, Donald J. Trump alluded to an attack line against Hillary Clinton that he was refraining from using.

abstract: Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump faced off Monday night at Hofstra University in Hempstead, N.Y.
