lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump said on Monday that he’ll release his tax returns as soon as his opponent Hillary Clinton “releases her 33,000 emails that have been deleted.”

headline: Debate Takeaways: Hillary Clinton Digs In and Prevails
abstract: The Democratic candidate appeared to gain strength as the debate progressed, ultimately beating back Donald Trump in the late exchanges.
lead_paragraph: Some debates seem to transform the fundamentals of a political campaign. The first clash between Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump was not one of those events.

headline: Clinton Wary of Trump and Nuclear Arms
abstract: Hillary Clinton said on Monday that Donald J. Trump’s “cavalier attitude about nuclear weapons is so deeply troubling.”
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton said on Monday that Donald J. Trump’s “cavalier attitude about nuclear weapons is so deeply troubling.”

headline: Word + Quiz: residue
abstract: The word residue has appeared in 103 New York Times articles in the past year.

headline: Commentators Give Hillary Clinton Edge in Debate
abstract: Mrs. Clinton drew praise on social media for her grasp of policy and her preparedness for her first debate with Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: In the first showdown between Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump, the presidential candidates exchanged blows on trade and foreign policy, called each other racist and inept, and could not resist letting out stray smirks or occasional sniffles.

headline: Daily Report: Twitter Attracts a Wide Range of Suitors
abstract: A possible takeover shows that just what Twitter is still is very much in the eye of the beholder.
lead_paragraph: Twitter has some 300 million regular monthly users — and possibly as many views about the company’s long-term purpose and value.

headline: Holt’s Moderation Gets Mixed Reviews
abstract: Lester Holt, moderator of the first presidential debate of the election, drew gripes from both sides, but seemed to avoid the kind of harsh criticism given to Matt Lauer, who moderated a town hall weeks earlier.
lead_paragraph: Lester Holt, moderator of the first presidential debate of the election, drew gripes from both sides, but seemed to avoid the kind of harsh criticism given to Matt Lauer, who moderated a town hall weeks earlier.

headline: ‘A Lyricist With a Camera’ on New York’s Streets
abstract: When Louis Faurer highlighted the liveliness and sorrow of Manhattan, he rarely looked at the skyline. To him, the city’s essence was in the details he found on its teeming streets.
lead_paragraph: When Louis Faurer highlighted the liveliness and sorrow of Manhattan, he rarely looked at the skyline. To him, the city’s essence was in the details he found on its teeming streets.

headline: By the Numbers: Butting In, and Going On, Trump Dominates
abstract: The Republican nominee interrupted Hillary Clinton 29 times in Monday night’s event.
lead_paragraph: The first presidential debate on Monday drew all the hype of a Super Bowl or Academy Awards ceremony — and perhaps an audience to match. It may take days or weeks to measure the impact of the first confrontation between Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump, but a few hard numbers already tell the story of their clash. Here is a box score:

headline: Police Officers Need to Get Better at CPR
abstract: When they shoot, they must be prepared for the aftermath.
lead_paragraph: The first time I tried to intubate a patient who had stopped breathing, my supervisor snatched the tube from me at the last minute. “What are you going to do after you place the tube?” she asked. Her intuition was right: I was completely unprepared for the next step. It was an important reminder that no matter how dire the situation, it is inappropriate to act unless you’re ready for what comes next.

headline: Bringing Prison Guards to Justice
keywords: ['Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Editorials', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Assaults', 'District Attorneys']
abstract: Elected officials and local prosecutors need to do their part in ridding New York’s prison system of wanton brutality.
lead_paragraph: New York State prison guards sometimes get away with barbaric acts of brutality because their union shields even the worst of them from prosecution — and because district attorneys in communities dominated by prisons are hesitant to bring difficult, politically unpopular cases.

headline: Beyond the Summer’s Burkini Debate
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Muslim Veiling', 'Bathing Suits and Swimwear']
abstract: Cultural diversity and creativity are embraced by a Paris suburb.
lead_paragraph: PANTIN, France — Where I live in Pantin, a banlieue, or suburb, northeast of Paris, the brouhaha this summer in France over the burkini — body-covering swimwear whose name is an amalgam of burqa and bikini — seems very much at odds with the positive and inclusive changes occurring here.

headline: The Age of Reaction
abstract: How reactionaries supplanted conservatives on the right.
lead_paragraph: In the normal telling, history is driven by visionaries and revolutionaries. If you studied history in school you probably plowed through book after book about this revolution or that one — the American Revolution or the French, the industrial revolution or the information one. In the normal telling of the past, events are driven by revolutionaries, and the few reactionaries who stand in the way get run over.

headline: Reviving House Calls by Doctors
abstract: Especially when treating the aging, house calls can benefit doctor, patient and the nation’s health care budget.
lead_paragraph: Surah Grumet used to be a family doctor at a clinic in the Bronx. “It always felt like I was trying to catch up,” she said. “I was always falling behind, and it was so stressful. And it was really hard to bring up my two girls, to be there for them, and still be able to practice medicine the way that I wanted to.”

headline: Want to Make Ethical Purchases? Stop Buying Illegal Drugs
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Drug Cartels', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Behind your night of partying is a trail of blood in my home country, Mexico.
lead_paragraph: Many of my friends and classmates here in the United States care about making the world a better place, and they try to make purchases that reflect their values. Some have become vegetarians to save animals or fight climate change. Others buy cruelty-free cosmetics, fair-trade coffee or conflict-free diamonds.

headline: In a Tight Race, Every Party Matters
abstract: Voters considering Gary Johnson or Jill Stein may want to delve deeper into their views.
lead_paragraph: The third-party candidates in the presidential race — Gary Johnson of the Libertarian Party and Jill Stein of the Green Party — aren’t very well known and have virtually no chance of winning. Their support comes chiefly from young voters aged 18 to 39, according to new polls, and their appeal seems to be mainly that they’re not Hillary Clinton or Donald Trump. Some of these voters may just want to register their disdain of Washington in general.

headline: Fact-Checking the First Presidential Debate
abstract: Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton squared off over the Islamic State militant group, jobs and climate change.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton squared off over the Islamic State militant group, jobs and climate change.

headline: U.S. Says Chinese Executive Helped North Korea Dodge Sanctions
abstract: An indictment against Ma Xiaohong, her company and three colleagues accuses them of violating American bans and helping Pyongyang develop nuclear arms.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The United States Justice Department has filed criminal charges against a Chinese executive, accusing her, the company she owns and several of her colleagues of violating American sanctions meant to choke off funding to North Korean companies that help Pyongyang develop nuclear weapons.

headline: ‘A Lyricist With a Camera’ on New York’s Streets
abstract: When Louis Faurer highlighted the liveliness and sorrow of Manhattan, he rarely looked at the skyline. To him, the city’s essence was in the details he found on its teeming streets.
lead_paragraph: When Louis Faurer encountered memorable silhouettes and faces on New York’s sidewalks, he highlighted the liveliness and sorrow of metropolitan life. He rarely looked up at the skyline: New York’s essence was on its teeming streets, especially in Times Square, which he prowled at night.

headline: A Hug Seen Around the World
abstract: Why do you think this image became so popular so quickly? What does it say to you?

headline: Trump On Trade
abstract: Loud, confident nonsense.
lead_paragraph: For the most part, at least as of now — mid-morning where I am, even if it’s the middle of the night back in America — the media consensus seems to be that Clinton won. This is a big deal: you know, just know, that they were primed to declare Trump the winner based on Clinton’s snooty insistence on facts, or maybe her “body language”. (Imagine what they would have said if she had engaged in Trump-like grimacing, pouting, and smirking, not to mention sniffling.) But he was so bad and she so good that they couldn’t.

headline: Women Petition U.N. Leader to Seek Korean Peace Treaty
abstract: More than 130 activists from 38 countries urged Ban Ki-moon to pursue a permanent peace treaty to end the Korean War, replacing the 63-year-old armistice.
lead_paragraph: More than 130 female activists from 38 countries pressed the leader of the United Nations on Tuesday to fulfill a goal he declared after assuming the job a decade ago: a permanent peace treaty to end the Korean War.

headline: A Major New Book Takes on the Power Struggle at Ground Zero
abstract: Lynne B. Sagalyn’s “Power at Ground Zero” shows how rebuilding at the site was delayed by the need to placate scores of stakeholders.
lead_paragraph: POWER AT GROUND ZEROPolitics, Money, and the Remaking of Lower ManhattanBy Lynne B. SagalynIllustrated. 901 pp. Oxford University Press. $39.95.

headline: What’s ‘A Prairie Home Companion’ Without Garrison Keillor?
abstract: Chris Thile, a 35-year-old mandolin player, aims to find out.
lead_paragraph: ‘Here they come,” said the security guard, mopping sweat from his brow. He was tall and bald but not imposing, and he worried that the searing heat would lead to too much drinking. It was 3 p.m. on June 11, and the gates to the Ravinia outdoor theater in Highland Park, Ill., had just opened. People streamed in carrying coolers and lawn chairs, checkered blankets and wineglasses, plasticware full of crackers, melons and deviled eggs. They politely competed for swatches of grass in the shade of oak trees mounted with thank you for not smoking signs.

headline: The Conspiracy Theorists’ Election
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'English Language']
abstract: How paranoia moved from the margins of American politics to its center.
lead_paragraph: It’s possible to gaze back almost wistfully on all the moments in recent American politics that seemed, at the time, to constitute Peak Crazy, but look from today’s vantage point like false summits. Consider, for instance, the remarks Barack Obama gave at the 2011 White House Correspondents Dinner, three days after releasing the long-form birth certificate Donald Trump had spent weeks demanding. “Now, I know that he’s taken some flak lately,” Obama said, with Trump in the audience, “but no one is happier, no one is prouder to put this birth-certificate matter to rest than the Donald. And that’s because he can finally get back to focusing on issues that matter — like, did we fake the moon landing? What really happened in Roswell? And where are Biggie and Tupac?”

headline: Stephen King Reviews Emma Donoghue’s Latest Novel
abstract: In 19th-century Ireland, a nurse is hired to watch a girl on a suspicious religious fast in Emma Donoghue’s “The Wonder.”
lead_paragraph: THE WONDERBy Emma Donoghue291 pp. Little, Brown & Company. $27.

headline: Social Media Got You Down? Be More Like Beyoncé
abstract: The pop star provides a model for dealing with the pressure of oversharing.
lead_paragraph: In Gary Shteyngart’s 2010 novel, “Super Sad True Love Story,” characters carry around smart devices called äppäräts, which are something like iPhones on meth. The book is set in the near future. Staten Island is the new Brooklyn, and all the characters use their äppäräts to chat and shop and beam their lives out to the world, nonstop. Äppäräts are also equipped with a program called RateMe Plus, which constantly calculates (and broadcasts, of course) a status ranking based on users’ jobs, financials and online popularity, which is gauged by the quantity and quality of what they share. Live-streaming the most intimate details of your life is the only way to get ahead — job promotions and romantic prospects depend on it.

headline: After Mudslides and Flooding in Iceland, Elves Are Suspects
abstract: Workers clearing a roadway after a series of storms unleashed havoc after unwittingly dumping dirt on a special rock that has its own name in Icelandic folklore.
lead_paragraph: When Siglufjordur, a small mountain town in northern Iceland, was hit by a series of storms last summer, construction workers clearing a roadway soon found themselves dodging mudslides and contending with a flooded river.

headline: Clinton’s Victory Without Breakthrough
abstract: Trump revealed all of his shortcomings in the debate. But does it matter?
lead_paragraph: About midway through their first debate, Hillary Clinton said of Donald Trump: “I think Donald just criticized me for preparing for this debate. And, yes, I did. And you know what else I prepared for? I prepared to be president. And I think that’s a good thing.”

headline: Are the Web Filters at Your School Too Restrictive?
abstract: What websites, blogs and social networks are blocked in your school? How has this affected teaching and learning for you?
lead_paragraph: Five years ago we asked students about the web filters used in their schools, and the question became the single most commented-on Student Opinion question we’ve ever asked.

headline: Facebook Ordered to Stop Collecting Data on WhatsApp Users in Germany

abstract: A Hamburg regulator said on Tuesday that neither the messenger nor its parent company had received individuals’ permission to share digital information.
lead_paragraph: When the messaging service WhatsApp announced last month that it was starting to share some of its users’ online information with Facebook, its parent company, many users expressed anger that their digital privacy could be at risk.

headline: A Debate Victory Doesn’t Ensure a Real Shift in the Race
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Debates (Political)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: A CNN/ORC instant poll found that Hillary Clinton won by a margin of 62 percent to 27 percent.
lead_paragraph: It might have been the most watched political debate in history, and the emerging consensus among pundits and the instant polls is that Hillary Clinton prevailed over Donald J. Trump on Monday night.

headline: In ‘Star Trek Beyond’ or on TV: Half-Vulcan, All Role Model
abstract: Whether played by Leonard Nimoy or Zachary Quinto, Spock has provided inspiration to multiracial fans who identify with his conflicts.
lead_paragraph: BURBANK, Calif. — Is there a more beloved character in all of science fiction than Spock, the half-human, half-Vulcan first officer from “Star Trek”? He’s superstrong — he could easily pummel Captain Kirk, his ranking officer, were the spirit to move him — and a whiz at science. He’s cool to the point of wintry, a master at tamping down his base needs (granted, Vulcans get the urge to mate only once every seven years) and human emotions. He’s skilled at martial arts but rarely fights. He can literally look into your mind.

headline: Fontainebleau: A Forgotten Treasure
abstract: You’ve been to the Louvre, Notre Dame and Versailles. Now it’s time to see Fontainebleau.
lead_paragraph: You’ve visited the Louvre, Notre Dame, Sainte-Chapelle. You’ve been to Versailles and perhaps even made a trip to the chateaus of the Loire Valley. Is there anything else of the same caliber near Paris for those who love the classic ideals of French architecture and decorative arts? The answer is a resounding yes: the Château de Fontainebleau.

abstract: This staging by Mariusz Trelinski may be clunky. But Stuart Skelton and Nina Stemme in the title roles, and Simon Rattle in the pit, are enthralling.
lead_paragraph: The all-consuming, mystifying love story at the core of Wagner’s “Tristan und Isolde” unfolds against a medieval tale of war between Cornwall and Ireland. Many productions employ imagery of sailors, military conquest and retribution but keep the focus on Wagner’s exploration of love, desire and death.

abstract: The decision, by judges at the International Criminal Court in The Hague, was the body’s first prosecution of the destruction of cultural heritage as a war crime.

headline: An Entrepreneurial Spirit Revives Two Manchester Neighborhoods
abstract: In Manchester, the Northern Quarter and its next-door neighbor, Ancoats, are blurring the lines between gentrification and regeneration.
lead_paragraph: Emily Dixon still recalls the horrified reaction of Manchester residents when she told them in the early 2000s that she lived in the Northern Quarter, which had been a dicey industrial pocket in the heart of the city. “They’d say, ‘You live where?!’ ” said the 34-year-old Ms. Dixon, drinking coffee at a wooden table in the housewares/art shop and coffee bar  Fig and Sparrow (figandsparrow.co.uk), which she co-owns. Now an artsy hub of trendy cafes, restaurants, bars and boutiques opened mostly by independent entrepreneurs, the Northern Quarter and its next-door neighbor, Ancoats, are blurring the lines between gentrification and regeneration. Both neighborhoods are seeing revivals as locals have increasingly returned to settle there.

headline: Our Middle-of-the-Night Debate Analysis Roundtable

lead_paragraph: It’s 1:30 a.m. in The New York Times newsroom. Our reporters and Opinion writers have fact-checked, analyzed, highlighted and opined. But The Run-Up refuses to rest until we’ve answered these questions: Who won this titanic clash of personalities, Hillary Clinton or Donald J. Trump? Who is full of regret this morning? And just how loose were these two candidates with the truth?

headline: More Than 9 in 10 People Breathe Bad Air, W.H.O. Study Says
abstract: The analysis by the World Health Organization is another sign that atmospheric pollution is a significant threat to global public health.

headline: Brazilian Politics Smother a Film’s Oscar Ambitions
abstract: A government panel rejected the critically acclaimed “Aquarius,” starring Sonia Braga, as Brazil’s Academy Awards entry, prompting other directors to withdraw their films.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Few movies have touched a nerve in Brazil in recent years like “Aquarius.” Starring Sonia Braga as a marijuana-smoking grandmother who clashes with real estate developers, the film has won prizes in festivals from Amsterdam to Sydney, Australia. Brazilian audiences stand to applaud it in theaters. Many here saw “Aquarius” as a shoo-in to represent the country at the Academy Awards.

headline: At Paris Fashion Week, Who’s Got the Power?
abstract: Fashion’s cycle has turned again, and the balance of influence has shifted, with new names at Dior, Lanvin, YSL and Valentino reshaping more than silhouettes.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — This week marks the ascension of four new designers at four vaunted houses: Anthony Vaccarello at Yves Saint Laurent, Bouchra Jarrar at Lanvin, Maria Grazia Chiuri at Christian Dior and Pierpaolo Piccioli, solo for the first time, at Valentino.

headline: Don’t Defeat ISIS, Yet
abstract: A premature U.S.-backed Iraqi offensive to retake Mosul from the militants risks unleashing deeper sectarian conflict.
lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — A military push to recapture Mosul, Iraq’s second largest city, and the rest of Nineveh Province from the Islamic State is expected soon. Unfortunately, even if the campaign is successful, the liberation of Mosul will not stabilize the country. Nor will conquest resolve the underlying conditions that originally fueled the extremist insurgency.

headline: After a Disappointing Debate, Donald Trump Goes on the Attack

Trump lashed out on Tuesday in the aftermath of a disappointing first debate with Hillary Clinton, scolding the moderator, criticizing a beauty pageant winner for her physique and raising the prospect of an all-out attack on Bill Clinton’s marital infidelities in the final stretch of the campaign.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — E. Anheuser & Company started as a small brewer in St. Louis more than 160 years ago – one of several breweries opened by German immigrants that introduced German-style lager to the United States.

headline: Germany’s Retrograde Record on Gay Rights
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: When it comes to marriage equality, one of Europe’s most progressive countries is far behind the rest.
lead_paragraph: Across Western Europe, marriage equality is fast becoming the norm: From Scandinavia through the Netherlands and Denmark; even the Catholic countries of Ireland, France and Spain. But there’s one glaring exception: Germany. It stands out not only because it is the largest country in Western Europe, but also because on many measures, it is among the most progressive.

lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey was told about the George Washington Bridge lane closings — and that they were done to punish a mayor who had declined to endorse him for re-election — during a Sept. 11 memorial service two days after they began, a former ally who orchestrated the scheme testified in federal court here on Tuesday.

Ingredients make unexpected cameos that often steal the show.

headline: Julie de Libran, Designer of Sonia Rykiel, Shares Her French Beauty Secrets
abstract: The artistic director doesn’t use soap in the morning and matches her makeup to her mood.
lead_paragraph: Julie de Libran, the artistic director for Sonia Rykiel, has a knack for knowing what the cool girls want. Her designs have been quite the hit with the international set, an aesthetic that may have been informed by her transcontinental upbringing. Ms. de Libran, 44, was born in Aix-en-Provence, France, but moved to the United States when she was 8. She now lives in Paris. Below, she shares the beauty products and services she will be relying on before the Rykiel spring 2017 show on Oct. 3.

headline: The Reverse-Gaslighting of Donald Trump
abstract: On Monday night, Hillary Clinton used the Republican candidate’s own tactics against him.
lead_paragraph: When I watch Donald Trump, I sometimes feel like Ingrid Bergman — not European and glamorous, but unnerved, as though I’m being gaslit, as in the famous plot of her old classic movie “Gaslight.” The lights are flickering, but her character’s husband, who is secretly a seriously bad dude, is convincing her that no such thing is occurring. He is trying to get her to question her sense of reality, to think her mind is playing tricks on her — in short, to convince her that she is going slightly crazy, a tactic that can be scarily effective.

headline: Sympathy for the Donald
abstract: What’s a man to do when all is rigged against him?
lead_paragraph: Go ahead and laugh at Donald Trump’s claims that he was foiled by a finicky microphone on Monday night, but I can relate. When I write a bad column, it’s all my keyboard’s fault.

headline: Old Mills Remade in Pawtucket, R.I., With Art as Their Product
abstract: The Rhode Island city is shedding its industrial image as “the bucket,” and has embraced the arts as a tool for redevelopment.
lead_paragraph: PAWTUCKET, R.I. — This city just north of Providence, settled in the 17th century and home to dozens of old mills, is claiming a new identity.

headline: Review: Practical Magic for the Modern Cook
abstract: Several new cookbooks target today’s home kitchens with eclectic recipes and strategies for planning.
lead_paragraph: Here’s one way to spot the modern cook: Look in her refrigerator. Chances are, there’s a little kimchi fizzing in the back and a jar of preserved lemons in the door. Regardless of the food she grew up with, she is acquainted with a wide array of global flavors, from fish sauce and tahini to pomegranate molasses and miso.

headline: Senate’s Vote on Simple Bill to Fund the Government Is Anything But
abstract: Republicans wanted money for Louisiana flood relief, Democrats for the water in Flint, Mich. A vote on a stopgap spending bill then got difficult.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — This was not supposed to be difficult. With the election a little more than a month away and few major issues on the table, the House and Senate were going to pass a straightforward stopgap bill to fund the government through early December and then skedaddle.

headline: Kevin Kline Plans Return to Broadway in ‘Present Laughter’
abstract: Mr. Kline, 68, is expected to take on this new role in a revival of the Noël Coward play by at the St. James Theater next year.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Kline, who won his first Tony Award as a self-regarding actor in “On the Twentieth Century,” will return to Broadway as a self-regarding actor in “Present Laughter.”

headline: Americas Region Declared Free of Endemic Measles
abstract: The last case of measles that did not result from an imported strain was in 2002, global health authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Global health authorities on Tuesday declared the Americas free of endemic measles, the first region to be so certified.

headline: Review: ‘The Red Rooster Cookbook’ Is a Homage to Modern Harlem
abstract: The chef Marcus Samuelsson’s restaurant draws on the neighborhood’s rich array of cultural influences.
lead_paragraph: When the Obamas visited Red Rooster Harlem in 2011 for a fund-raising dinner, the chef Marcus Samuelsson served them braised short ribs, lobster salad and his cornbread with honey butter. And to the crowds who gathered outside to see the nation’s first African-American president, he passed out coffee and doughnuts. He fed the president, and he fed the neighborhood.

headline: Keith Scott Threatened Family, Wife Said in Court Papers
abstract: Rakeyia Scott sought a protective order last year against Mr. Scott, whose death at the hands of the Charlotte, N.C., police has set off protests.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Nearly a year before Keith Lamont Scott was shot to death by the police in an episode that has convulsed this city, his wife applied for a protective order against him that said he owned a gun and had threatened to kill family members with it.

headline: How Two Times Photographers Prepped for a Presidential Showdown
abstract: Photographing Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump at last night’s debate was “90 percent logistics and 10 percent shooting,” said a Times staff photographer.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights on how news, features and opinion pieces come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Damon Winter and Doug Mills, two staff photographers for The Times, describe their experiences photographing Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump at the presidential debate on Monday.

keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York City.
lead_paragraph: $1.325 MILLION

headline: After Fatal Boat Crash, Baseballs Apparently Signed by Jose Fernandez Wash Ashore
keywords: ['Accidents and Safety', 'Boats and Boating', 'Baseball', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The Marlins star pitcher was killed with two friends in a boating accident over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: Hours after Miami Marlins pitcher Jose Fernandez and two friends were killed in a boating accident, a beachgoer approached a lifeguard in Miami Beach with a mysterious object that had washed ashore on Sunday.

headline: Diana Henry Writes Hundreds of Great Recipes a Year. How Does She Do It?
abstract: The popular British food writer works constantly to create her masterly flavor combinations.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — If you want to peer into writers’ souls, the saying goes, you peruse their libraries. But for food writers, you’ll also need to snoop around their larders.

headline: Jacquemus: Spring 2017
abstract: The label’s spring 2017 rtw collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 rtw collection.

headline: We’re Finally Living in an Age When Designers Make Clothes for Normal Women
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Models (Professional)', 'Women and Girls', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: Several shows this season featured models who were not actually models at all.
lead_paragraph: The models weren’t models at all. That was the point. They were artists, athletes, employees — one, an expecting mother. Some had long hair, others sheared short. Many were tall, a handful small; their bodies were lanky or shapely or strong. There have been many women who are not professional models on the runways this season. And fashion designers are turning to them not just as models — but also, muses.

headline: Trump on the Fed’s Motives
abstract: Donald J. Trump accused the Federal Reserve and its chairwoman, Janet L. Yellen, of "doing political things" and says that the stock market will come crashing down if interest rates are raised.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump accused the Federal Reserve and its chairwoman, Janet L. Yellen, of "doing political things" and says that the stock market will come crashing down if interest rates are raised.

headline: Joan of Arc’s Shaky Pedestal: France Battles Over Its Identity at School
abstract: Changes to how history is taught, as well as changes to how French, Latin and Greek are introduced, have set off arguments between the right and the left.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Bikini — and burkini — season is over here, but with the new school year, France’s battle over national identity has erupted on a new front: its history curriculum.

headline: The Spin Room, Trump’s Safe Space
abstract: The Republican candidate returns to the place where he’s always welcome.
lead_paragraph: For all his flagellation of the dishonest, disgusting and corrupt media — including, of course, “the failing New York Times” — Donald Trump rarely seems as comfortable as he does when swaddled in the soft glare of the TV news cameras. This was visibly true Monday night when, eight minutes after exiting the debate stage at Hofstra University, he showed up, as always, in the Spin Room. Within seconds of entering through a side door of the large gymlike hall, he was absorbed into the scrum of boom mikes, stampeding cameramen and shouted questions. He was, finally, home.

headline: Review: ‘Taste of Persia’ Crosses Borders
abstract: Naomi Duguid’s latest cookbook follows a trail through Iran, Georgia, Kurdistan, Azerbaijan and Armenia.
lead_paragraph: A new book from Naomi Duguid is a reason to celebrate, as each promises a fascinating culinary excursion. Her previous books focused on Southeast Asia, and like them, this newest, “Taste of Persia,” opens with a map, which illustrates Ms. Duguid’s wise observation that regional cooking doesn’t respect borders. So the search for Persian cuisine includes stops in Armenia, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Iran and Kurdistan.

headline: Review: Fall for Dance’s Sampler Platter of Extremes
abstract: This festival’s opening night included a premiere by Elizabeth Streb and a charismatic performance by the flamenco dancer Farruquito.
lead_paragraph: As millions of people tuned into the presidential debate on Monday, at least a couple of thousand opted out, flocking to City Center for the opening night of Fall for Dance. Tickets always go fast for this annual dance sampler, where every seat is just $15 (remember when they were $10, though?) and every program promises an assortment of styles rarely seen on one stage.

headline: Wolfgang Puck Makes His First New York Splash, at Cut
abstract: A downtown debut for the Spago chef, soft-serve from a high-end trailer and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: CUT Wolfgang Puck, the Austrian-born chef and restaurateur, is making his New York debut with this restaurant, one of several Cuts in a global portfolio that stretches from his Los Angeles base to airport food kiosks. Though the emphasis is on steaks — U.S.D.A. prime, grass-fed and wagyu — Raymond Weber, the executive chef, ranges well beyond them, with seafood, salads, seasonal vegetable preparations and pasta. Mr. Weber’s wife, Zairah Molina, is the pastry chef; she says that her desserts for the New York branch are more elaborate than they have been elsewhere. The space, by the French designer Jacques Garcia, working with Kimberly Brown and Strata Architects, provides an ebony background for artwork from Mr. Puck’s personal collection. Burgundy upholstery, gold curtains and, in the bar, dramatic slashes of red neon enliven the room: Four Seasons Hotel New York Downtown, 99 Church Street (Barclay Street), 646-880-1995, wolfgangpuck.com.

headline: No Evidence to Support Trump’s Attacks on the Fed
keywords: ['Interest Rates', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Debates (Political)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: An array of experts rejected Donald Trump’s accusations that Janet Yellen, the Fed’s chairwoman, is holding down interest rates for political reasons.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump attacked the Federal Reserve on Monday night before the largest audience he has yet addressed, telling the millions of people watching the first presidential debate that the nation’s central bank is acting as an arm of the Democratic Party at the expense of the economy.

headline: At 84 Million Viewers, Debate Was the Most-Watched Ever
abstract: Nielsen says Monday’s debate between Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton drew 84 million TV viewers, the largest audience since televised debates began in 1960.
lead_paragraph: It was the biggest political clash in American history — by one measure, at least.

headline: Review: ‘Sand Storm’ Follows a Bedouin Mother and Daughter in Quiet Revolts
abstract: In her feature debut, the Israeli filmmaker Elite Zexer directs a story about women constricted by, and pushing back against, cultural traditions.
lead_paragraph: Set in a Bedouin village in southern Israel, “Sand Storm” is framed by two weddings, events that don’t as much bookend this movie as seal it closed. That’s because despite the raucous celebrations, the clapping and trilling cries, neither marriage is especially joyous, at least for the brides. Here, in this rundown desert hamlet, tradition is passed from generation to generation, from mother to daughter. Daughters, in turn, are passed from family to family.

headline: What Donald Trump Got Wrong on Stop-and-Frisk
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Search and Seizure', 'Debates (Political)', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: In his debate with Hillary Clinton, Mr. Trump uttered elaborate fiction about tactics still used by the New York Police Department.
lead_paragraph: Among the senseless beatings inflicted on reality during the presidential debate on Monday night was the discussion of New York City’s stop-and-frisk tactics.

headline: Understanding Balanchine’s ‘Jewels,’ a Perfect Introduction to Ballet
abstract: This pure-dance triptych — “Emeralds,” “Rubies” and “Diamonds,” with vividly difference stage worlds — returns to New York City Ballet this week.
lead_paragraph: Next year, George Balanchine’s pure-dance triptych “Jewels” will have its 50th anniversary. It remains a perfect introduction to ballet: Few full-length story ballets are as satisfying as this storyless one, which returns Wednesday to New York City Ballet, for which it was created.

headline: Review: In ‘Tharlo,’ a Shepherd’s Life Upended by a Trip to the City
abstract: A black-and-white film from the Tibetan director Pema Tseden has a fleeting charm until the narrative takes a grim turn.
lead_paragraph: “Tharlo” begins with its title character, a middle-aged shepherd who has lived practically all of his life atop a Tibetan mountain tending his animals, reciting a speech by Mao Zedong to a local law-enforcement official, who is greatly impressed with the shepherd’s memory. Tharlo, who is nicknamed Ponytail for his long braid, shyly exclaims that he showed prodigious powers of memory in elementary school, where he learned the speech, but had no further opportunities for education.

headline: In ‘Hitler,’ an Ascent From ‘Dunderhead’ to Demagogue
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: A new biography portrays Hitler as a clownish, deceitful narcissist who took control of a powerful nation thanks to slick propaganda and a dysfunctional elite that failed to block his rise.
lead_paragraph: How did Adolf Hitler — described by one eminent magazine editor in 1930 as a “half-insane rascal,” a “pathetic dunderhead,” a “nowhere fool,” a “big mouth” — rise to power in the land of Goethe and Beethoven? What persuaded millions of ordinary Germans to embrace him and his doctrine of hatred? How did this “most unlikely pretender to high state office” achieve absolute power in a once democratic country and set it on a course of monstrous horror?

headline: Review: ‘Mozza at Home’ and ‘Eat in My Kitchen’
abstract: New cookbooks from the chef Nancy Silverton and the blogger Meike Peters offer inviting recipes for entertaining.
lead_paragraph: Conventional wisdom has it that when you’re entertaining, it’s best to focus on the tried and true, not something new that might result in emergency takeout.

headline: Lapo Binazzi’s Radical Italian Design
abstract: Ahead of his first retrospective, the designer and UFO Collective co-founder delves into his archive.
lead_paragraph: Ahead of his first retrospective, the designer and UFO Collective co-founder delves into his archive.

headline: The Artist-Architect Who Revolutionized Italian Design — With Humor
abstract: Lapo Binazzi shares thoughts on his own loopy work: dollar-sign table lamps, satirical discos and more.
lead_paragraph: Lapo Binazzi is a lover of the absurd. UFO, the design collective he co-founded, played an integral role in the rise of Radical Design in Italy, alongside groups like Gruppo 9999 and Superstudio, all of which pushed forward utopian agendas using a practice that wed art, architecture and technology. The supergroups used humor and free association to topple the existing hierarchies of quality as a reaction to Italy’s political and economic strife — often in undeniably fun ways. (For evidence, look no further than UFO’s “Discoteque Bamba Issa,” a shapeshifting discothèque variously dotted with seating inspired by camels’ humps, and décor that satirized Italian infrastructural bureaucracy.)

headline: Suburban Women Find Little to Like in Donald Trump’s Debate Performance
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Debates (Political)', 'Women and Girls', 'Voting and Voters', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Undecided women in Philadelphia’s suburbs, a crucial voting bloc, said Mr. Trump had not only failed to win them over but in many cases had repelled them.
lead_paragraph: WEST CHESTER, Pa. — Donald J. Trump badly needed to make an impression on women like Nancy Groux in Monday’s presidential debate. She is an undecided Republican who hungers for change in Washington and thinks business experience would be an asset in the Oval Office.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Tara Parker-Pope, John Branch and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: The Power of Hillary Clinton’s Throwback Photos
keywords: ['ADULTERY', 'Photography', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Social Media', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Her campaign’s use of old photos sends a message to Donald Trump and his supporters.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton hasn’t always been the most effective campaigner. But her campaign’s use of the candidate’s photographs — especially on Monday night — has been smart and bold.

headline: Review: ‘The Black Crook’ Delivers Theater History and a Potent Brew
abstract: The play, at the Abrons Arts Center, is adapted by Joshua William Gelb from the 1866 New York stage spectacular of the same name.
lead_paragraph: The artisanal beer on offer in the lobby outside “The Black Crook,” at Abrons Arts Center, was an endearing monstrosity: flat, murky brown and smelling strongly of a principal ingredient, molasses. Based on a recipe from the 1840s, it was brewed as a tie-in to the show, which has 19th-century roots. Maybe, the thinking went, the characters would have drunk something similar.

headline: Saint Laurent: Spring 2017
abstract: The label’s spring 2017 rtw collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 rtw collection.

headline: Review: A Rising Conductor Makes Her New York Debut
abstract: Mirga Grazinyte-Tyla deftly led the Juilliard Orchestra in works by Beethoven, Berlioz and Raminta Serksnyte at Alice Tully Hall.
lead_paragraph: On an ordinary night — one lacking the first presidential debate of the year and the opening of the Metropolitan Opera’s season — it would have dominated the attention of the city’s classical music fanciers. As it was, the New York debut of the rapidly rising young conductor Mirga Grazinyte-Tyla, leading the Juilliard Orchestra on Monday evening, remained a subject of intense curiosity, as witness the full house at Alice Tully Hall, heavily laced with music industry professionals.

headline: I Muted Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton During the Debate. I Still Knew the Score.
abstract: The idea was simple: to test the theory that what presidential candidates say during debates is less important than what they look like while they’re saying it.
lead_paragraph: It was a little shimmy of her shoulders — cheeky, insouciant — accompanied by a big, toothy grin. Her opponent smirked.

headline: Caesars Entertainment to Emerge From Chapter 11 Bankruptcy
abstract: Apollo Global Management and TPG Capital, which bought what was known as Harrah’s Entertainment, will give up most of their stake in the company.
lead_paragraph: When Apollo Global Management and TPG Capital bought what was Harrah’s Entertainment for about $31 billion, the two firms took control of the world’s biggest casino operator during a heady time for daring leveraged buyouts.

headline: Stephen Colbert Reboots ‘The Late Show,’ Fixing It on the Fly
abstract: In the battle against Jimmy Fallon and Jimmy Kimmel, Mr. Colbert is taking a hands-on approach that includes more topical humor and live episodes.
lead_paragraph: At 10:45 p.m. on Monday night, in a 14th-floor office above the Ed Sullivan Theater, Stephen Colbert was talking so rapidly that he might as well have been speaking in tongues.

headline: The Exoneree Band Is Free to Rock, and Rightly So
abstract: The band, formed of musicians who were wrongfully convicted of crimes, share their stories and offer hope when they take the stage.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — A few hours before William Michael Dillon and his bandmates took the stage for their headline gig at the House of Blues here last week, this singer and guitarist took a moment to listen to his own grim ballad, “Black Robes and Lawyers.” A self-taught musician, Mr. Dillon wrote the tune in 1985 on strips of prison toilet paper while serving nearly 30 years for a murder he didn’t commit. Sitting now in his lake-view room in a boutique hotel, he softly sang along with the recording, lost in a fog of distance.

headline: Neue Galerie Returns Painting Seized by Nazis and Then Rebuys It in Settlement
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Art']
abstract: The museum reached a restitution settlement for a Karl Schmidt-Rottluff painting with the heirs of a Jewish shoe manufacturer whose family fled Germany.
lead_paragraph: The Neue Galerie of New York has reached a restitution settlement for “Nude,” a 1914 painting by Karl Schmidt-Rottluff, with the heirs of a Jewish shoe manufacturer and art collector whose artworks were taken when his wife and son were forced to flee Germany by the Nazis in the 1930s, the museum announced Tuesday.

headline: The Top 10 Moments From Milan Fashion Week
abstract: The spring/summer 2017 shows featured Lauren Hutton, pajamas — and so much pasta.
lead_paragraph: The spring/summer 2017 shows featured Lauren Hutton, pajamas — and so much pasta.

headline: Elon Musk’s Plan: Get Humans to Mars, and Beyond
abstract: Mr. Musk, the billionaire founder of SpaceX, hopes to make humanity a “multiplanetary species.”
lead_paragraph: GUADALAJARA, Mexico — Elon Musk’s plans to get to Mars start with a really big rocket. He still needs to figure out how to pay for it.

headline: Review: ‘Taste & Technique’ Makes French Cooking Cool
abstract: The first book from the chef Naomi Pomeroy aims to elevate your cooking with bossy but warm instruction.
lead_paragraph: Cheffy cookbooks have gotten a bad name in recent years. Who expects readers to have a Pacojet or xanthan gum on hand?

headline: City to Pay $5.75 Million Over Death of Mentally Ill Inmate at Rikers Island
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Bradley Ballard was found naked and covered in feces and urine after being locked in a cell at the New York City jail complex for six days.
lead_paragraph: New York City has agreed to pay $5.75 million to settle a lawsuit stemming from the 2013 death of a mentally ill inmate who was found naked and covered in urine and feces after being locked in a cell at Rikers Island for six days.

headline: Chinese Tourists Pump Cash Into a Hot Destination: China
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Chinese tourists took four billion domestic trips in 2015, twice as many as in 2010 and many more than the 122 million trips abroad, the government said.
lead_paragraph: SANYA, China — When Stephan Stoss arrived here six years ago, little more than lush foliage lined the roads leading to the 492-room Hilton where he is now general manager.

headline: Tax Returns, Climate Change and the Sniffles: The Fallout From the First Debate
abstract: With the first presidential debate over, the candidates resumed criticizing each other from afar as they returned to the campaign trail.
lead_paragraph: With the first presidential debate in the books, both candidates returned to the campaign trail on Tuesday and intensified their criticism of each other from afar.

headline: Review: Two Books to Master Chinese Cuisines
abstract: Fuchsia Dunlop explores the cuisine of Jiangnan in “Land of Fish and Rice,” and Carolyn Phillips takes a broad approach to Chinese cooking in “All Under Heaven.”
lead_paragraph: Cookbooks turn up every few years with the promise of an everyday mastery of Chinese cuisine. Their mark is fleeting, and cooks happily return to their manila envelopes of takeout menus. This year may be different.

headline: By Taking Back Money, Wells Fargo’s Board Seems to Recall Its Role
keywords: ['Boards of Directors', 'Executive Compensation', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: As John G. Stumpf prepares to face a second round of congressional grilling, the bank’s board said he would forfeit about $41 million in stock awards, forgo his salary during the inquiry and receive no bonus in 2016.
lead_paragraph: As John G. Stumpf, the chief executive of Wells Fargo, prepares to face a congressional tribunal on Thursday for the second time in two weeks, questions are intensifying about the bank’s sham accounts scandal and its lethargic response to it.

headline: Trump? How Could We?
abstract: It would be insanity to put him in the White House.
lead_paragraph: My reaction to the Donald Trump-Hillary Clinton debate can be summarized with one word: “How?”

headline: Review: The Poole’s Cookbook, Reimagining Southern Classics
abstract: Ashley Christensen’s debut book celebrates exquisite ingredients and exacting instruction.
lead_paragraph: Most cookbooks fall into one of two categories: the aspirational and the useful, those that are flipped through on lazy Sundays, then returned to the top shelf, and those that live a dog-eared life on the counter.

headline: Standard Chartered’s U.S. Settlement Is Imperiled by New Claims
abstract: The London-based bank, which has a deferred-prosecution agreement from a 2012 inquiry, reported accusations against a company in which it holds a stake.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Standard Chartered said on Tuesday that it had received accusations of potential wrongdoing by officials at an Indonesian power company in which it is an investor.

headline: Birth of Baby With Three Parents’ DNA Marks Success for Banned Technique
keywords: ['Mitochondria', 'In Vitro Fertilization', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: Reproductive scientists used genetic material from a donor in addition to that of the couple trying to conceive.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, after a fertility procedure at a Mexican clinic, a healthy baby boy was born in New York to a couple from Jordan. It was the first live birth of a child who has been called — to the dismay of scientists who say the term is grossly misleading — a three-parent baby.

headline: Would Donald Trump Ever Use Nuclear Arms First? He Doesn’t Seem Sure
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Debates (Political)', 'United States International Relations', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense']
abstract: On the debate question of whether the United States should ever be the first to use such weapons, he appeared somewhere between contradictory and confused.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Donald J. Trump often says he never wants to signal to the nation’s adversaries what he would do as commander in chief — an embrace of the concept of “strategic ambiguity” that is as old as warfare.

headline: The Best Cookbooks of Fall 2016
abstract: Our reporters and editors review new releases from Alton Brown, Diana Henry and more.
lead_paragraph: Our reporters and editors review new releases from Alton Brown, Diana Henry and more.

headline: Why So Many Children Are Being Killed in Aleppo
abstract: Among the roughly 250,000 people stuck in the insurgent redoubt in northern Syria are 100,000 children, the most vulnerable victims of intensified bombings.
lead_paragraph: They cannot play, sleep or attend school. Increasingly, they cannot eat. Injury or illness could be fatal. Many just huddle with their parents in windowless underground shelters — which offer no protection from the powerful bombs that have turned east Aleppo into a kill zone.

headline: A Voice Cuts Through, and Adds to, the Intrigue of Russia’s Cyberattacks
abstract: A tattooed 26-year-old living near the Mongolian border is the only person publicly identified with Russia’s cyberattacks. And he’s apparently eager to talk.
lead_paragraph: BIYSK, Russia — Living anonymously, down a winding road in the wilderness of western Siberia, not far from the Mongolian border, the only person so far implicated in the flurry of Russian hacking of the Democratic National Committee and other political sites was obviously enjoying the moment.

headline: U.S.-Backed Effort to Fight Afghan Corruption Is a Near-Total Failure, Audit Finds
abstract: An anti-corruption program backed by the United States has had compliance from only one of 83 officials, President Ashraf Ghani.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — An effort to fight corruption by monitoring the financial assets of top Afghan officials, underwritten by the United States, has been a near-total failure, according to American auditors.

headline: Greek Lawmakers Pass Additional Austerity Measures
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Privatization', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: The Greek Parliament agreed to further pension cuts and plans to privatize the country’s power corporation and the water boards of Athens and Thessaloniki.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Greek lawmakers approved a new set of austerity measures Tuesday evening, including further trims in pensions and the transfer of major state assets to a new privatization fund to be overseen by the country’s creditors.

headline: Furor Over Drug Prices Puts Patient Advocacy Groups in Bind
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists']
abstract: Many groups ostensibly on the side of patients find themselves conflicted by the millions they receive from the pharmaceutical industry.
lead_paragraph: Public anger over the cost of drugs has burned hot for a year, coursing through social media, popping up on the presidential campaign, and erupting in a series of congressional hearings, including one last week over the rising price of the allergy treatment EpiPen.

headline: England Manager Sam Allardyce Undone by an Undercover Film
abstract: His employers at the Football Association found that footage shot by journalists from The Daily Telegraph contained conduct “inappropriate of the England manager.”
lead_paragraph: Sam Allardyce had made sure he looked the part. On the day he was presented as manager of England’s national team in July, Allardyce, 61, wore a Three Lions lapel badge, a shirt with his initials monogrammed on the cuffs, and the broadest of grins. This, he said, was his “dream job.”

headline: Conor McGregor Takes Manhattan: ‘The Irish, We Built This Town. Now We’re Coming Back to Claim What’s Ours.’
abstract: In a news conference at the Garden, where he will face Eddie Alvarez in November, McGregor announced: “I run New York, I run this whole city.”
lead_paragraph: With mixed martial arts finally legal in New York State, the Ultimate Fighting Championship had a rare opportunity to make a splash with its Madison Square Garden debut this Nov. 12.

headline: Trump Scores Points on Trade in Debate, but Not So Much on Accuracy
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Debates (Political)', 'North American Free Trade Agreement', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Hillary Clinton did call the Trans-Pacific Partnership a “gold standard,” though it wasn’t Donald Trump who changed her mind.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In his otherwise shaky performance on Monday, Donald J. Trump had his best moments of the first presidential debate on the topic of trade — a defining one for the election — as he threw Hillary Clinton on the defensive over trade pacts past and present.

headline: A.I.G. Ex-Chief Testifies at Trial, 11 Years After Charges
abstract: Maurice R. Greenberg has denied charges that he buffed up the insurer’s financial results with fraudulent transactions in 2000 and 2001.
lead_paragraph: Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of insurance giant American International Group, took the witness stand on Tuesday for the first time in his state civil accounting fraud trial in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

headline: Addicted Parents Get Their Fix, Even With Children Watching
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Pain-Relieving Drugs', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: The opioid epidemic in New England and elsewhere has reached such proportions that addicts are increasingly getting high and passing out with their children in tow.
lead_paragraph: It was a horrific video — a young mother who had overdosed was lying unconscious on the floor of a Family Dollar store in Lawrence, Mass.

headline: Charles L. Schultze, 91, Dies; Advised Presidents on Economic Policy
abstract: Mr. Schultze spent most of his career working on national economic and fiscal policy, as a government economic adviser, university professor and research fellow.
lead_paragraph: Charles L. Schultze, an economist who was President Lyndon B. Johnson’s budget director and President Jimmy Carter’s chief economic adviser, died on Tuesday at his home in Washington. He was 91.

headline: World Bank Picks Jim Yong Kim for Second Term as President
abstract: Mr. Kim was the World Bank’s unanimous choice, and only nominee, continuing a tradition of having an American at the helm.
lead_paragraph: For the more than 70 years since the World Bank was founded as an institution to give loans and grants to developing countries, an American has been at the helm.

headline: Whether Crime Is Up or Down Depends on Data Being Used
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Urban Areas', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: The decline in homicide has been so significant that sudden increases in just a few cities can skew the national picture, criminologists and police officials say.
lead_paragraph: The news from the F.B.I. crime data was alarming: The murder rate rose sharply last year, driven by jumps in several major cities.

headline: David Ortiz Makes His Final Visit to Yankee Stadium
abstract: Ortiz often made himself at home in the Bronx, where he has been a beloved foil.
lead_paragraph: David Ortiz, the burly and ebullient Red Sox designated hitter, stood on the top steps leading out of the visitors’ dugout at Yankee Stadium on Tuesday evening and looked at the upper decks. On the ground, he was nearly encased by people — members of the news media, team officials and fans — all standing on the warning track as the Red Sox took batting practice. At 40, Ortiz is more popular than he has ever been and, somehow, nearly as good.

headline: Concern as Venezuela Refuses to Accept Aid
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'International Relations', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Humanitarian Aid']
abstract: The State Department said that John Kerry’s meeting with President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela was Mr. Kerry’s chance to express concern about “challenges that have affected millions of Venezuelans.”
lead_paragraph: The photo suggested promise. On the sidelines of a peace ceremony in Colombia, President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela and Secretary of State John Kerry met for the kind of brief exchange that, under normal circumstances, might have been the start of a thaw after years of icy relations.

headline: Pepe the Frog Meme Listed as a Hate Symbol
abstract: A cartoon frog tied to anti-Semitism was added to the Anti-Defamation League’s list of hate symbols, which includes the swastika and the Confederate battle flag.
lead_paragraph: A cartoon frog tied to anti-Semitism and racism that has become an unofficial mascot of the alt-right has been added to the Anti-Defamation League’s list of hate symbols, joining the ranks of the swastika and the Confederate battle flag, the group said on Tuesday.

headline: Peter L. Gerety, Oldest Archbishop Who Preached Social Justice, Dies at 104
abstract: Archbishop Gerety, who led the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark, preached for social justice and sought to give voice to women, the laity and lapsed churchgoers.
lead_paragraph: Archbishop Peter L. Gerety, who as a liberal leader of the Roman Catholic Church in America gave voice to the laity, to women and to lapsed churchgoers and preached for social justice, died on Sept. 20 in Totowa, N.J. He was 104, and the world’s oldest Roman Catholic bishop.

headline: Appeals Court Hears Challenge to Obama’s Climate Change Rules
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Global Warming', 'Clean Air Act', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Coal', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Federal judges hear oral arguments in a lawsuit filed by 28 states and hundreds of companies and industry groups opposed to the Clean Power Plan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The nation’s second-most powerful court grappled Tuesday with the intractable and potentially catastrophic problem of climate change, weighing whether constitutional questions surrounding President Obama’s climate change regulations should trump the moral obligations of upholding a plan to curb global warming.

headline: Mets Still Scrambling for One-Game Shot at a Longer Postseason
abstract: After months of having to address one injury after another, the Mets lead the National League wild-card race and retain strong hopes of hosting the wild-card game.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The news was so routine for these Mets that it barely registered. Steven Matz, the fragile rookie who made three starts on last fall’s postseason joy ride, was officially shut down for the season Tuesday because of his sore left shoulder. As long as he is not pitching, the Mets said, Matz will finally get those bone spurs removed from his elbow next week.

headline: Herschell Gordon Lewis, a Pioneer of Gore Cinema, Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Lewis set the bar for low-budget horror in movies like “Blood Feast” that went on to inspire filmmakers like Wes Craven and Quentin Tarantino.
lead_paragraph: Herschell Gordon Lewis, a director who set new standards for gore and violence in the early 1960s with the low-budget films “Blood Feast” and “Two Thousand Maniacs!,” died on Monday at his home in Pompano, Fla. He was 90.

headline: Michael Phelps Is Calmer These Days, on the Golf Course and Off
abstract: Phelps’s second Ryder Cup pro-am hardly resembled his shaky experience at his first, in 2012 — a change that is mirrored in his life more broadly.
lead_paragraph: CHASKA, Minn. — The 28-time Olympic medalist Michael Phelps stepped to the first tee on Tuesday for the Ryder Cup celebrity pro-am with his driver in hand. After Phelps was introduced, he dropped his club, leaned over and executed three full arm swings and slaps, as was his routine when he stood on the starting blocks before a swimming race.

headline: Next Target for IBM’s Watson? Third-Grade Math
abstract: Watson, the IBM computer platform that dominated on “Jeopardy!” and has helped fight cancer, is part of a pilot program that will help teachers build personalized lesson plans.
lead_paragraph: It knew enough about medical diagnoses and literature to beat “Jeopardy!” champions at their game, and has been put to use in cancer wards. Now, an IBM computer platform called Watson is taking on something really tough: teaching third-grade math.

headline: Max Mannheimer, a Keeper of Holocaust Memory, Dies at 96
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Concentration Camps', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Mr. Mannheimer visited hundreds of schools and other institutions, advocating democracy and helping ensure that Germany’s World War II horrors were never repeated.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Max Mannheimer, who survived Theresienstadt, Auschwitz and Dachau and devoted his last decades to admonishing later generations of Germans that while they carried no guilt for the Nazis’ crimes, they bore a responsibility to ensure that they never happen again, died on Sept. 23 in Munich. He was 96.

headline: Obama Nominates First Ambassador to Cuba in Over 50 Years
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The president selected Jeffrey DeLaurentis, who has served since 2014 as the chief of mission for the United States in Havana, to fill the post.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Tuesday nominated the first United States ambassador to Cuba in more than a half-century, defying opponents of his policy of rapprochement with the government of President Raúl Castro in an effort to further cement a new relationship between the countries before he leaves office.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Everywoman Moment
abstract: Monday’s debate was the kind of workplace confrontation that women find all too familiar.
lead_paragraph: The direct confrontation between Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton over Mr. Trump’s treatment of women didn’t come until the final moments of Monday night’s debate. But in many ways, the entire event played out as a big-screen version of what women encounter every day.

headline: Islanders, Preparing for Second Season in Brooklyn, Have Lots of Fresh Faces
abstract: The team, coming off a season in which it won a playoff series, lost Kyle Okposo, Frans Nielsen and Matt Martin, but has a raft of rookie prospects.
lead_paragraph: With their captain, John Tavares, and goaltenders Jaroslav Halak and Thomas Greiss still at the World Cup of Hockey in Toronto, the Islanders are working toward their second year in Brooklyn amid the usual paces of training camp and preseason games.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Wednesday, September 28, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “I come from a long line of Republican family members who will turn over in their graves.”

headline: Where’s the Downside?
abstract: No, your puzzle isn’t broken. Morton Mendelson is back.
lead_paragraph: Before I say anything else, no, your puzzle isn’t broken. There really is only one list of clues, unless you are solving in Across Lite where clue lists cannot be combined.

headline: Shimon Peres, an Enduring Pillar From Israel’s Founding Era, Dies at 93
abstract: Mr. Peres helped build up his country’s military might, then worked as hard to establish peace with Israel’s Arab neighbors.
lead_paragraph: Shimon Peres, one of the last surviving pillars of Israel’s founding generation, who did more than anyone to build up his country’s formidable military might, then worked as hard to establish a lasting peace with Israel’s Arab neighbors, died on Wednesday in a Tel Aviv area hospital. He was 93.

headline: The Life of Shimon Peres
abstract: One of the last of Israel’s founding generation, Mr. Peres was on the public stage during the country’s seven decades.
lead_paragraph: One of the last of Israel’s founding generation, Mr. Peres was on the public stage during the country’s seven decades.

headline: Behind the Scenes With Shimon Peres
abstract: In 2013, the photographer Lynsey Addario accompanied Mr. Peres, then the president of Israel and one of the world’s oldest sitting leaders, for a day just before he turned 90.
lead_paragraph: I was on my way to Afghanistan in 2013 when I received a call from my editor asking me to stop in Jerusalem and photograph Shimon Peres, who was about to celebrate his 90th birthday.

headline: Wells Fargo to Claw Back $41 Million of Chief’s Pay Over Scandal
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Executive Compensation']
abstract: The move against John G. Stumpf is one of the first times since the 2008 financial crisis that a company’s chief executive has been forced to give up pay.
lead_paragraph: Wells Fargo announced on Tuesday that it would claw back compensation valued at $41 million from its embattled chairman and chief executive, John G. Stumpf, as the financial consequences of the scandal over illegally created sham accounts at the bank reached the executive suite.

headline: Shimon Peres’s Reflections on War, Peace and Life
abstract: The former prime minister and president of Israel was a fountain of seemingly effortless bons mots and poetic musings.
lead_paragraph: The former prime minister and president of Israel was a fountain of seemingly effortless bons mots and poetic musings.

abstract: With Derrick Rose around to lessen the burden on Carmelo Anthony, the new-look Knicks are getting to know one another while hoping they won’t be waylaid by injuries.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Jeff Hornacek, the new coach of the Knicks, was surprised Tuesday morning to find that his players had arrived an hour before the scheduled start time of the team’s first training-camp practice.

headline: Joe Browder, a Guardian of the Florida Everglades, Dies at 78
abstract: Mr. Browder put together an eclectic bloc that prevented the construction of a jetport near Everglades National Park that would have been the world’s largest.
lead_paragraph: Joe Browder, a television reporter turned environmentalist who was instrumental in preserving Florida’s Everglades, vast areas nearby and Biscayne Bay, died on Sept. 18 at his home in Fairhaven, Md. He was 78.

abstract: The Yankees ended Boston’s 11-game winning streak and shut down Ortiz at two key moments in the game.
lead_paragraph: David Ortiz ambled up to home plate in the seventh inning Tuesday night at Yankee Stadium in a situation he has often confronted.

lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The death of Shimon Peres prompted an outpouring of emotional tributes from around the world even as Israel woke up Wednesday morning to discover that a figure integral to the history of the state was gone.

keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Alfred Olango, who was walking in traffic and was said to be acting erratically, pointed an object at officers, the police said.
lead_paragraph: Demonstrators gathered outside the Police Department in El Cajon, Calif., on Wednesday morning calling for a federal investigation into the fatal police shooting of a black man a day earlier, the latest in a string of such killings that have provoked protests nationwide.

abstract: Tomasz Gudzowaty thinks nothing of trekking for days across snow and ice or in heat and rain to find scenes that look as if Genesis just happened.
lead_paragraph: Tomasz Gudzowaty thinks nothing of trekking for days across snow and ice or in heat and rain to find scenes that look as if Genesis just happened.

headline: The World Wakes Up to the Danger of Superbugs
abstract: The United Nations was right to ring the alarm about a growing danger that requires a global response.
lead_paragraph: Tuberculosis. Malaria. Syphilis. Gonorrhea. The microbes that cause these diseases are increasingly resistant, and sometimes even impervious, to antibiotics that worked in the past. Last week, amid other pressing business, 193 nations at the United Nations General Assembly signed a declaration summoning each of them to a war against a powerful and resourceful enemy: superbugs that have learned to evade science’s last remaining defenses.

headline: Gary Johnson: Take a Deep Breath, Voters. There Is a Third Way.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Libertarianism (US Politics)', 'Debates (Political)', 'Illegal Immigration', 'National Debt (US)', 'Mandatory Sentencing', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The Libertarian candidate for president believes that Americans aren’t nearly as polarized as Trump and Clinton might think.
lead_paragraph: The America I know wasn’t on the television screen on Monday night. My America is about the freedom to make choices, pursue your dreams and use your skills as entrepreneurs. It is about having more choices than just red versus blue.

headline: The Risks of Suing the Saudis for 9/11
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'September 11 (2001)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Terrorism', 'Editorials', 'Vetoes (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: While the aim of a bill is compassionate, it could expose the American government, citizens and corporations to lawsuits abroad.
lead_paragraph: The Senate and the House are expected to vote this week on whether to override President Obama’s veto of a bill that would allow families of the victims of the Sept. 11 attacks to sue Saudi Arabia for any role it had in the terrorist operations. The lawmakers should let the veto stand.

headline: Has Pope Francis Failed?
abstract: His mass appeal is undeniable. But Catholics are not coming back to the church.
lead_paragraph: When Pope Francis ascended to the chair of St. Peter in March 2013, the world looked on in wonder. Here at last was a pope in line with the times, a man who preferred spontaneous gestures to ritual forms. Francis paid his own hotel bill and eschewed the red shoes. Rather than move into the grand papal apartments, he settled in the cozy guesthouse for visitors to the Vatican. He also set a new nondogmatic tone with statements like “Who am I to judge?”

headline: Explaining the U.S. Presidential Election to China: It’s Not Really Like ‘House of Cards’
abstract: A founder of the podcast “Xuanmei,” or “U.S. Election,” says the Chinese are more interested in the American election than ever but don’t always understand it.
lead_paragraph: As Election Day approaches in the United States, the Chinese are paying closer attention to the selection of the next president.

headline: The Deaf Body in Public Space
abstract: To communicate in sign language, I often have to break the norms placed on our bodies.
lead_paragraph: “It’s rude to point,” my friend told me from across the elementary-school cafeteria table. I grasped her words as I read them off her lips. She stared at my index finger, which I held raised in midair, gesturing toward a mutual classmate. “My mom said so.”

headline: VAT of Deplorables
abstract: Trump picks terrible advisers, too.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been writing about Donald Trump’s claim that Mexico’s value-added tax is an unfair trade policy, which is just really bad economics. Here’s Joel Slemrod explaining that a VAT has the same effects as a sales tax. Now, nobody thinks that sales taxes are an unfair trade practice. New York has fairly high sales taxes; Delaware has no such tax. Does anyone think that this gives New York an unfair advantage in interstate competition?

headline: Should the U.S. Give Up Oversight of Internet Addresses?
abstract: A planned move to transfer control of domain names is vigorously opposed by Senator Ted Cruz and others.

abstract: Clashes over costs and fears that security measures would chase away customers hobbled Yahoo’s efforts, leading to the 2014 breach of 500 million users.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Six years ago, Yahoo’s computer systems and customer email accounts were penetrated by Chinese military hackers. Google and a number of other technology companies were also hit.

headline: On the Prowl With a Wildlife Photographer
abstract: Tomasz Gudzowaty thinks nothing of trekking for days across snow and ice or in heat and rain to find scenes that look as if Genesis just happened.
lead_paragraph: For a lot of people, “The First Lesson of Killing,” a photo of two young cheetahs encountering an antelope (Slide 8), is among Tomasz Gudzowaty’s most powerful images, and he gets it.

abstract: Think about the books you have read in school so far. Overall, how well have they represented a range of diverse characters and experiences?
lead_paragraph: This week is Banned Books Week, and the theme this year is “Celebrating Diversity.”

headline: Do I Have to Tell My Family I’m No Longer Religious?
keywords: ['Ethics (Personal)', 'Religion and Belief', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Doctors', 'Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Friendship', 'Marriages', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on visiting your Southern Baptist relatives when you’re no longer a believer, what to do when your E.R. colleague defers treatment of his patients until you arrive and more.
lead_paragraph: I am an African-American woman from a very religious Southern Baptist family. I now live in Europe with my husband, who is an atheist, and my two children. I am spiritual but not religious in any way that my family would recognize. We are teaching our children about all religions, as well as how to be good, compassionate, humble humans.

headline: What Rules Do You Have for Staying Healthy?
abstract: Is the five-second rule something you’ve invoked? Does the article change your mind in any way?
lead_paragraph: We all have ways we try to stay healthy, whether we learned them from our parents or picked them up on our own. Perhaps we always wash our hands before we eat — or take vitamins every morning, or never go outside in the cold with wet hair.

lead_paragraph: THE IRAN WARSSpy Games, Bank Battles, and the Secret Deals That Reshaped the Middle EastBy Jay Solomon336 pp. Random House. $28.
