lead_paragraph: David Schiff, a former portfolio manager at Perella Weinberg Partners, and Andrew Dym, previously a partner at the same firm, have started their own investment shop, Innovatus Capital Partners.

headline: American Apartheid: A Georgia County Drove Out All Its Black Citizens in 1912
abstract: Patrick Phillips’s “Blood at the Root” tells the story of how Forsyth County drove out its black residents and stayed white-only for 80 years.
lead_paragraph: BLOOD AT THE ROOTA Racial Cleansing in AmericaBy Patrick PhillipsIllustrated. 302 pp. W.W. Norton & Company. $26.95.

headline: Baltimore vs. Marilyn Mosby
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: In the midst of a national crisis of police violence, Baltimore’s state’s attorney gambled that prosecuting six officers for the death of Freddie Gray would help heal her city. She lost much more than just the case.
lead_paragraph: A little before 7 the other night, the prosecutor Marilyn Mosby stopped by my house in Baltimore for dinner. She was coming straight from work in one of her customary gray pantsuits, and because I was already nursing a beer, she took off her jacket with a sigh and poured herself a glass of white wine. Then we stepped onto the back deck to throw a few burgers on the grill. This being a September evening, you might imagine the yard in raking light and breezy autumnal aspect, but it was actually pretty swampy, the oppressive tonnage of summer humidity not yet given way to season’s end, so as soon as the burgers looked about done, we ferried them inside and settled at the island in my kitchen to eat. After a few minutes, Mosby’s husband, Nick, who sits on the City Council, knocked on my front door, let himself in and wandered through the house to join us. He took a seat two chairs down from Marilyn, leaving an empty one between them.

headline: Beyond Baseball, Vin Scully Leaves Behind an Archive of Oddities
abstract: The body of work of the longtime voice of the Dodgers, including his hosting of a game show and reading of a grocery list, reflects a time when no job seemed too small.
lead_paragraph: In 2005, a pizza-size recording disc was discovered in the archives of WFUV, the Fordham University radio station. With no equipment old enough to play it, the disc had to be transferred to a CD or a cassette tape to yield what lay within its old grooves.

headline: Ana Navarro Wants Republicans to Stand Up to Trump
abstract: The Republican strategist on how being an anti-Trumper has affected her personal life, what it will take to rebuild the party and more.
lead_paragraph: You and the other anti-Trump Republicans have been embraced by a lot of liberals because of the gusto with which you’ve gone after Trump. Does that feel a little strange for you? It’s very mercurial. The liberals love you until you say something critical about Hillary Clinton. People have a complete inability to see the flaws in their candidates. God forbid you criticize the blurred lines between the Clinton philanthropy business and political worlds.

headline: Elvis Costello’s New York Soul
abstract: He grew up in England, but this veteran troubadour has a long history with the five boroughs. Now he’s back.
lead_paragraph: Elvis Costello first saw Manhattan when he was 23. This was late 1977. He and his band, the Attractions, were coming down from New Haven on their first tour of the United States when the skyscrapers came into view.

headline: New Debate Strategy for Donald Trump: Practice, Practice, Practice
abstract: Advisers plan to more rigorously prepare him for his next debate with Hillary Clinton, but whether he is open to meticulous preparation is a major concern.
lead_paragraph: Campaign advisers to Donald J. Trump, concerned that his focus and objectives had dissolved during the first presidential debate on Monday, plan to more rigorously prepare him for his next face-off with Hillary Clinton. They intend to drill the Republican nominee on crucial answers, facts and counterattacks, and coach him on ways to whack Mrs. Clinton on issues even if he is not asked about them.

headline: Cold Cases: Crime and Punishment in Antarctica
abstract: How are crimes handled where there are no permanent courts, prisons or police forces? Under the Antarctic Treaty, countries police their own.
lead_paragraph: An unsolved death. Assault with a deadly weapon. Lots of alcohol-fueled misbehavior. It’s quite a rap sheet for a continent where almost nobody lives.

headline: Living in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y.
abstract: The village’s setting on the Hudson, its diversity and its access to the city are draws for many residents.
lead_paragraph: The village’s setting on the Hudson, its diversity and its access to the city are draws for many residents.

abstract: The village’s setting on the Hudson, its cultural diversity and its access to the city are draws for many residents.
lead_paragraph: Sleepy Hollow has become a big deal at Halloween. Street signs promoting holiday events in the village — which was immortalized in Washington Irving’s short story “The Legend of Sleepy Hollow” — and in neighboring towns start popping up right after Labor Day.

headline: A Woman Dies After Childbirth, and Her Husband Asks Why
abstract: Amy Lam, who prematurely gave birth in her bathroom, bled to death after a series of surgical procedures at Harlem Hospital Center. Now her family has accused the hospital of malpractice and negligence.
lead_paragraph: After Amy Lam prematurely went into labor and gave birth to their baby at home, her husband, Gilbert Kwok, thought the worst was over. Once emergency responders had arrived and loaded Ms. Lam, 34, into an ambulance, the couple took photos with the newborn and called family members, smiling and elated that — despite the unexpected circumstances — their son had arrived.

abstract: A provocative new study finds that some of the benefits of exercise for brain health may evaporate if we take to the couch, even just for a week or so.
lead_paragraph: Before you skip another workout, you might think about your brain. A provocative new study finds that some of the benefits of exercise for brain health may evaporate if we take to the couch and stop being active, even just for a week or so.

headline: An Atlas of a Billion Stars
keywords: ['Stars and Galaxies', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Milky Way Galaxy', 'Telescopes and Observatories']
abstract: The European Space Agency’s Gaia space telescope has been scanning the cosmos in order to create the largest and most accurate 3-D map of our galaxy.
lead_paragraph: This map, the first of its kind, shows a billion stars shining in the Milky Way. It’s the work of the European Space Agency’s Gaia space telescope, which has been scanning the cosmos in order to create the largest and most accurate 3-D map of our galaxy.

headline: How to Be Mindful With Facebook
abstract: Take a moment before you log on to your phone or computer to evaluate your intentions.
lead_paragraph: “You can bring mindful awareness to all contexts, including being online.” — Bill Duane, a Google executive and meditation teacher who oversees the company’s well-being and performance learning programs.

headline: A Family Returns to Montana ‘Ruts’ and a Million-Dollar View
abstract: Bigfork, Mont., has seen big change but the family ties, the vistas and the colorful stones of Flathead Lake remain a draw for the Frugal Family.
lead_paragraph: We drove out a zigzagging peninsula to Finley Point Unit, a state park with a boat launch, a small public marina and a row of campsites along the lakeshore. The beach was nothing but water-weathered rock. But the rounded stones of Flathead Lake, Mont., aren’t mere pebbles. Beneath the crisp, transparent water, their straight-from-the-1970s hues — dusty mauve, adobe and pale avocado — are magnified, becoming deep purples, oranges and greens. They are so spectacular that when I left, a week later, I brought with me a Ziploc bag-size collection that I have since arranged in a glass jar — submerged in unworthy urban tap water — and placed in my kitchen window. The multicolored mosaic is an unmarked memorial to my grandmother Frances Evans, who was raised among the yellow pine, lowland fir, red cedar and cherry orchard banks of the Flathead.

headline: Questions to Consider if Your Trump-Clinton Vote Doesn’t Really Count
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Third-Party Politics (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The distortions of the Electoral College make voting a mere formality for many. We asked a scholar to explore gray areas on maximizing your vote.
lead_paragraph: If you live in California, the value of your vote this November will be much smaller than a neighbor’s a few miles away in Nevada. The same contrast exists along many other state borders, like those of Vermont and New Hampshire.

headline: Dutch Inquiry Links Russia to 298 Deaths in Explosion of Jetliner Over Ukraine
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 17', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems']
abstract: A Dutch-led investigation concluded that Russian-backed separatists in eastern Ukraine asked for and received a surface-to-air missile that was used to shoot down the plane in 2014.
lead_paragraph: A Dutch-led investigation has concluded that the powerful surface-to-air missile system used to shoot down a Malaysia Airlines plane over Ukraine two years ago, killing all 298 on board, was trucked in from Russia at the request of Russian-backed separatists and returned to Russia the same night.

headline: Shimon Peres, the Realist Dreamer
abstract: Israel needs leaders like him who believed the country would find security in peace.
lead_paragraph: Tel Aviv — There are very few people in the world whose lives align so effortlessly with the birth and being of their homeland. Shimon Peres, who has died at age 93, left an indelible mark on Israel — fighting for its independence, its security, and then, for its peace. It is difficult to imagine Israel’s past without him; it will be even harder to imagine its future.

keywords: ['E-Learning', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Tuition', 'Tests and Examinations']
abstract: A Georgia Tech computer science program at drastically reduced prices could change the way we think about the problem of college costs.
lead_paragraph: The master’s degree business is booming. College graduates looking for a leg up in the job market are flocking to one- and two-year programs that promise entry to lucrative careers. Top colleges are more than willing to provide them — for a price. Tuition for a 30-credit master’s in computer science from the University of Southern California runs $57,000. Syracuse, Johns Hopkins and Carnegie Mellon charge over $43,000 for the same degree.

headline: A Chinese Scholar on the Changing World of the Yugur Nomads
abstract: A traditions of the nomadic herders are fading as the government restricts grazing on the grasslands and promotes the move to more permanent homes.
lead_paragraph: There are fewer than 15,000 Yugurs in China, making the ethnic group one of the smallest of the 56 officially recognized by the government. For centuries they were nomads, moving among pastures at the foot of the snowcapped Qilian Mountains in Gansu Province. Some spoke a language related to Mongolian, while others spoke a Turkic one. They practiced shamanism and Tibetan Buddhism.

headline: Modern Life Presents Nomads of China’s Highlands With a ‘Tragic Choice’
abstract: The Yugurs are struggling to maintain the language and culture that distinguish them as a people, the products of centuries of swirling Asian history.

headline: The Taxi Driver’s Last Ride
abstract: When Mohammad Azam picked up a passenger near the Iran-Pakistan border, did he have any idea he was a target for a U.S. drone strike?
lead_paragraph: When Mohammad Azam started his shift on May 21, it was just another sunny morning in Taftan, a small desert town in Pakistan’s Balochistan Province. Like taxi drivers around the world, he planned to spend this day waiting for customers, and navigating through traffic when he could find a fare. He had no idea it would be his last day alive.

headline: Dior and TV: A ‘New Look’ All Around

lead_paragraph: PARIS — For Dior, it is a revolution: a woman leading its creative side for the first time in the house’s 69-year history. On Friday, Maria Grazia Chiuri will unveil her first collection for the house to an audience (and clients) on the edge of their seats with anticipation. So it is fortuitous that this turning point coincides with the release of a glossy, eight-part television drama calculated to remind us how it all began.

headline: Oral Nicholas Hillary Acquitted in Potsdam Boy’s Killing
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Blacks', 'Black People']

headline: Metropolitan Museum of Art Lays Off 34 Employees
abstract: The number, which amounts to 1.5 percent of its 2,200-member work force, is lower than anticipated and comes as the Met faces a ballooning deficit.
lead_paragraph: As part of an effort to cut its deficit by $30 million, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has laid off 34 employees, the museum announced on Wednesday. The number is fewer than the Met originally anticipated, and makes up 1.5 percent of its more than 2,200-member work force.

headline: In a Paris Retail Space, a Door to Japan
abstract: A new boutique, stocked with imports from tea to kimonos, is a venture of the country’s largest department store group.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The newest Japanese ambassador to Paris sits in the shadow of the Eiffel Tower, preparing for a debut. On Tuesday morning, a man with a tape measure was making sure each tea set displayed on a center table was positioned just so. The kimonos and patchwork denim shirts had been hung. On Saturday, the Japan Store at the Maison de la Culture du Japon à Paris, in the 15th Arrondissement, is to open its doors.

headline: 1966: Klansman Acquitted of Murder

lead_paragraph: HAYNEVILLE — A jury of eight Negroes and four white men last night [Sept. 27] acquitted a Ku Klux Klansman of first-degree murder in the slaying of white civil rights worker Mrs. Viola Liuzzo.

headline: Like Father, Like Son. Like the Cubs? No Way!
abstract: What a Cubs World Series title would mean to a family of lifelong White Sox fans.
lead_paragraph: When I was a kid, I had a recurring nightmare. I would imagine stepping into the batter’s box for my first major league at-bat, my name announced over the loudspeaker, followed by a roar from the crowd. The dream was spoiled, though, when I looked down at my jersey and saw “Cubs” printed in bright red letters.

lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — World leaders made plans to converge on Israel to pay tribute to Shimon Peres, the Nobel Prize-winning former prime minister who died on Wednesday, focusing renewed attention on his quest for peace in a fractured land that fell well short of his dreams.

headline: More Fun on Your Wrist With New Apps for the Apple Watch
abstract: Among the offerings, apps in which you can speak to your watch to update to-do lists or get a quick assist on deciphering a foreign language.
lead_paragraph: APPLE this month released a faster, smarter Apple Watch and also sped up its first-generation smartwatch with a faster chip. The speed increase will help watch apps run more smoothly, and plenty of great software is available to take the improved watches for a test drive.

headline: A High-Stakes Bet: Turning Google Assistant Into a ‘Star Trek’ Computer
keywords: ['Artificial Intelligence', 'Innovation', 'Mobile Applications', 'Search Engines', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Voice Recognition Systems']
abstract: Google is threatened by the decline of web search, so it’s making a bold bet on what comes next: an all-knowing digital helper.
lead_paragraph: Google is one of the most valuable companies in the world, but its future, like that of all tech giants, is clouded by a looming threat. The search company makes virtually all of its money from ads placed on the World Wide Web. But what happens to the cash machine if web search eventually becomes outmoded?

headline: Regulators to Review London Stock Exchange-Deutsche Börse Merger

lead_paragraph: LONDON — European regulators said on Wednesday that they had opened an “in-depth” investigation into the planned merger of the London Stock Exchange Group and Deutsche Börse over its potential impact on competition in financial markets.

headline: The Jacquemus Girl; Courrèges, Slim and Short
abstract: Simon Porte Jacquemus drew on his youth as inspiration, while at Courrèges, Sébastien Meyer and Arnaud Vaillant showed their first full collection.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — “It’s a French one, eh?” said Simon Porte Jacquemus, accepting French cheek kisses and French congratulations backstage after his Jacquemus show. The tent had been pitched in the heart of the Tuileries garden, but the scene was set in the south of France, his home turf. His models wore giant straw hats and, leg-of-mutton sleeves, and came down the runway to the schmaltzy orchestral theme from “Jean de Florette,” the Gérard Depardieu period piece from the 1980s — French cheese at its ripest.

headline: The Plot to Put Conceptual Art on ‘Melrose Place.’ Yes, Really.
abstract: A team of artists, led by Mel Chin, supplied art and props for the show’s sets, with coded messages. Those works are on display in a new exhibition.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, the conceptual artist Mel Chin cold-called the offices of “Melrose Place,” Aaron Spelling’s wildly popular prime-time soap opera, with a proposition. What if a task force of artists supplied free artworks and props for the show’s apartment-complex set, with coded cultural messages on pressing topics like reproductive rights, American foreign policy, alcoholism and sexual politics?

headline: Flying While Muslim: A Civil Rights Advocate on Travel Right Now
keywords: ['Muslim Americans', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Airport Security']
abstract: Roula Allouch of the Council on American-Islamic Relations says that treatment of Muslim passengers on recent flights has been “very troubling.”
lead_paragraph: Roula Allouch, 36, is a Cincinnati lawyer and the chairwoman of the national board of directors of the Council on American-Islamic Relations, one of the nation’s largest civil rights and advocacy groups for the American Muslim community. Raised in Kentucky, she is a member of the American Bar Association’s Rule of Law Initiative for the Middle East and North Africa. Ms. Allouch’s parents emigrated to the United States from Syria in the 1970s. Following are edited excerpts from a conversation with Ms. Allouch.

headline: In Laos, a Haven for Tubing Offers More Peace, Less Partying
abstract: Vang Vieng in Laos once was known for its wild party scene. Now, the draws are river tubing and caves — though you can still dance on a table top.
lead_paragraph: I never imagined I’d experience the sensation of floating in the sky while on a river, but in Vang Vieng in central Laos, I did. Arching my back on an inner tube while lifting my feet out of the silky Nam Song, the air still and the day quiet, I looked up into a cloudless sky and felt as if I were hovering in midair, completely weightless.

headline: President and Michelle Obama Lash Out at Donald Trump
abstract: In appearances on the radio and in Pennsylvania, they criticized the Republican nominee and urged supporters to vote for Hillary Clinton, not a third-party candidate.

headline: Congress Votes to Override Obama Veto on 9/11 Victims Bill
keywords: ['September 11 (2001)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Vetoes (US)', 'Terrorism', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Both chambers overwhelmingly voted on Wednesday for a bill that would let Americans sue Saudi Arabia in the attacks — the first veto override of the Obama presidency.

headline: The Anatomy of an Airstrike
abstract: An airstrike in east Aleppo, Syria, destroyed a building where four families lived. Here’s how rescuers responded minute by minute in an area where basic services have been devastated by years of war.
lead_paragraph: An airstrike in east Aleppo, Syria, destroyed a building where four families lived. Here’s how rescuers responded minute by minute in an area where basic services have been devastated by years of war.

headline: James Blake and Majid Jordan: Soul Through a Digital Lens
abstract: Mr. Blake and the duo Majid Jordan play shows in New York, offering their 21st-century takes on soul.
lead_paragraph: There’s real breathing room in the music of James Blake and Majid Jordan, two acts that refract soul music through a digital lens, approaching their songs with reserve and crispness and using moist emotion as a point of contrast. Majid Jordan, a Toronto duo signed to Drake’s OVO Sound label, builds a thick sheen atop disco and funk skeletons on its self-titled debut album. And Mr. Blake’s latest, “The Colour in Anything” (Republic), is familiarly meditative and aching; he’s an austere singer who finds swing in minimal electronic compositions.

headline: A Venezuelan Orchestra of Fortitude Opens Carnegie Hall Season
abstract: Gustavo Dudamel and the Simón Bolívar Symphony offer three challenging programs, from an orchestra whose country in crisis.
lead_paragraph: Venezuela is a country in crisis, with drastic food shortages, public protests and government crackdowns. Given this backdrop, that the Simón Bolívar Symphony Orchestra of Venezuela is making it to New York to open the Carnegie Hall season shows fortitude.

headline: A Shen Wei Premiere at the Brooklyn Academy of Music
abstract: This choreographer and visual artist offers his version of “Neither,” a collaboration between the composer Morton Feldman and Samuel Beckett.
lead_paragraph: Watching the work of the choreographer and visual artist Shen Wei is like peeking into an ant farm, in which dancers elegantly and efficiently construct a private world, seemingly unaware of being observed. These worlds are always distinctive, defined by Mr. Shen’s signature swooshing style of movement, best explained as physical calligraphy.

headline: O Death: Posthumous Portraits at the Folk Art Museum
abstract: “Securing the Shadow” focuses on an obsession with death in 19th-century America.
lead_paragraph: “It seemed like a resurrection,” said Sidney George Fisher, a well-to-do Philadelphian in 1858, upon seeing a miniature portrait of his recently deceased sister-in-law painted from a daguerreotype, a posthumous icon made as such imagery began to flourish in a society preoccupied with mourning.

headline: At 77, He Gets to Woo Mary-Louise Parker
abstract: By happy accident, the veteran actor Denis Arndt makes his Broadway debut in Simon Stephens’s “Heisenberg.”
lead_paragraph: On a recent late-summer morning, the actor Denis Arndt sat down to a pint of Guinness and a plate of bivalves in the oyster bar at Grand Central Terminal. The beer was cool, the oysters plump, and Mr. Arndt had even put on a tie, a swirling print designed by Jerry Garcia. Normally he dresses up only for “openings and bat mitzvahs,” he said. But he was determined to make an occasion of this snack. And why not?

headline: ‘Holiday Inn’ Arrives, and so Does an Early ‘White Christmas’
abstract: Roundabout presents a stage adaptation of the 1942 movie starring Bing Crosby. The film is best known for Irving Berlin’s “White Christmas.”
lead_paragraph: The Roundabout Theater Company enters the seasonal-treats sweepstakes with “Holiday Inn,” a stage adaptation of the 1942 movie starring Bing Crosby as an entertainer who decides to call it quits, buy a farm and turn the place into a novelty act: a venue open only on holidays.

headline: ‘Heaven’s Gate’ Comes to BAMcinématek
abstract: Michael Cimino’s costly, 216-minute western about class conflict in Wyoming, based on the Johnson County War, helped sink the studio behind it.
lead_paragraph: Michael Cimino’s costly, 216-minute western “Heaven’s Gate” (1980) — coming to BAMcinématek on Sunday, Oct. 2, as part of “Desperate Hours: The Films of Michael Cimino” — helped sink United Artists, the studio behind it. But Mr. Cimino (who died in July) had made his masterpiece, with granular attention to period detail that at times evokes the Italian director Luchino Visconti at his most lavish. The brilliant cinematographer Vilmos Zsigmond is at his atmospheric apex, with a cast including Isabelle Huppert, Christopher Walken (from Mr. Cimino’s “The Deer Hunter”), Jeff Bridges (from his “Thunderbolt and Lightfoot”) and Kris Kristofferson as the archetypal taciturn lawman.

headline: ‘The Siege of Jadotville’ on Netflix Rediscovers a Faded Footnote
abstract: This film revisits the trials and tribulations of an Irish force in Central Africa in 1961.
lead_paragraph: The Congo crisis, as it was generally known, is a historical footnote to many people now, but “The Siege of Jadotville,” a Netflix film that becomes available Friday, Oct. 7, makes a gripping drama out of one particular moment in the yearslong struggle for control in Central Africa. Jamie Dornan (“Fifty Shades of Grey”) plays the commandant leading a small Irish force of United Nations peacekeepers that was besieged in 1961 in the Democratic Republic of Congo by several thousand local troops from Katanga Province, which was seeking to secede. “By the fourth day, the Irish were down to their last biscuit,” The New York Times reported at the time. “They had gone for four days without sleep and two days without water.” Early in the film, before the Irish force deploys, someone asks the commandant if he thinks his men will see any action. “Who knows?” he responds. “I don’t think anyone’s clear what’s going on out there.” Those words prove to be quite accurate.

headline: Wells Fargo C.E.O.’s Prepared House Testimony
abstract: John Stumpf is scheduled to testify on September 29 to a House panel on the scandal over the bank illegally creating sham accounts.
lead_paragraph: John Stumpf is scheduled to testify on September 29 to a House panel on the scandal over the bank illegally creating sham accounts.

headline: Maine’s ‘Clean’ Medical Marijuana: ‘Organic’ in Disguise
keywords: ['Marijuana', 'Medical Marijuana', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Organic Foods and Products']
abstract: As growers and enterprises see more competition, a new labeling program may help them stay competitive. Just don’t call it “organic.”
lead_paragraph: FARMINGTON, Me. — In a suite one flight above the bustling main street of Farmington, a university town in the foothills of western Maine, LoveGrown Caregiver Services is a marijuana lover’s delight.

headline: The Best Sellers: Filed Under Sports
abstract: The best-selling sports books in August 2016, according to the New York Times best-seller list.
lead_paragraph: The best-selling sports books in August 2016, according to the New York Times best-seller list.

headline: ‘I Won’t Be Silent’: Serena Williams on the Fear of Driving While Black
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: The tennis champion shared a story on her public page of allowing her nephew to drive, and having misgivings after spotting a police officer on the side of the road.
lead_paragraph: It may seem mundane: having a relative drive you around to do errands.

headline: How to Get Dries Van Noten’s ‘Shadowed Eye’ Look
abstract: The makeup artist Peter Philips explains the simple trick behind the subtle brown band that graced models’ faces.
lead_paragraph: At Dries Van Noten’s spring/summer 2017 show, several models wore veils. The shadows they created over the models’ faces, specifically across the eyes and the bridge of the nose, became an inspirational reference point for an entire uniform makeup look. “It’s got a little bit of a ‘Blade Runner’ effect, but it’s an actual shadow,” explained the makeup artist Peter Philips.

headline: Daily Report: Latest Hack Shows Yahoo’s Weak Security History
abstract: The internet’s fun place had one of history’s biggest hacks, one of a series of security problems at Yahoo in recent years.
lead_paragraph: For Yahoo, loving customers used to be so much easier.

headline: How Those Wireless Emergency Alerts Find You
abstract: Officials can push out emergency alerts for weather conditions and even warnings about wanted individuals, but not everybody gets the same messages.
lead_paragraph: Q. When I get an emergency alert on my phone for a certain area, how does the system know I’m in that location? Do these messages count against my monthly limit?

headline: Bulgarian Shakes Up Race for U.N. Leader
abstract: The addition of a second Bulgarian candidate, Kristalina Georgieva, could alter the calculus between the West and Russia over who replaces Ban Ki-moon as secretary general.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The contest to be the next leader of the United Nations turned more complicated on Wednesday when a Bulgarian diplomat long rumored to aspire to the position formally entered the race.

headline: Keep Tradition in Olde England
abstract: A reader says a “perfect synergy” in the Lake District over millenniums should not be disrupted.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Loma Fire Spreads in California
abstract: The blaze has spread to more than 2,000 acres, threatening hundreds of homes and forcing residents to evacuate. Officials are investigating the cause.
lead_paragraph: The blaze has spread to more than 2,000 acres, threatening hundreds of homes and forcing residents to evacuate. Officials are investigating the cause.

headline: Chinese vs. Western Medicine
abstract: A Harvard Sinologist writes that Mao “mixed praise for Chinese medicine with hardheaded preference for Western medical science on his own body.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Och-Ziff African Unit Expected to Plead Guilty to Bribery
keywords: ['Hedge Funds', 'Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (1977)', 'Bribery and Kickbacks']
abstract: Daniel Och, founder of the $39 billion hedge fund, is also expected to be named in an S.E.C. complaint and enter an agreement over inaccurate record-keeping, according to people briefed on the matter.
lead_paragraph: OZ Africa Management, a unit of the hedge fund giant Och-Ziff Capital Management, is expected to enter a guilty plea to bribery charges on Thursday, according to two people briefed on the matter.

headline: Tim Tebow Homers in First At-Bat (and Finishes 1 for 6)
abstract: Tebow, the football player turned Mets minor leaguer, hit a home run on Wednesday afternoon on the first pitch he faced in the Florida Instructional League.
lead_paragraph: Tim Tebow stepped to the plate Wednesday for his first at-bat as a professional baseball player and took a swing at the first pitch he saw. Naturally, he hit a home run.

headline: Elizabeth LeCompte of the Wooster Group Wins the Gish Prize
abstract: Under her direction, the Wooster Group has created what the prize announcement called “startlingly innovative, collagelike works.”
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth LeCompte, the director of the experimental theater company the Wooster Group, has been awarded the Dorothy and Lillian Gish Prize, which is given annually to an artist who pushes the boundaries of an art form and contributes to social change.

headline: Azuma Makoto’s “Iced Flowers” at Dries Van Noten
abstract: The Japanese artist brought his sculptures to Paris Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: The Japanese artist brought his sculptures to Paris Fashion Week.

headline: The Story Behind the Magical, Ice-Encased Flowers at Dries Van Noten
abstract: The designer collaborated with the artist Azuma Makoto on the sculptures that flanked his runway show — the talk of Paris today.
lead_paragraph: The backdrops for Dries Van Noten’s women’s wear shows are, oftentimes, art unto themselves; for example, his models for spring/summer 2015 swanned atop a custom-made, patchy green carpet by the Argentine talent Alexandra Kehayoglou. To present his latest collection today in Paris, the designer partnered with the Japanese flower artist Azuma Makoto, sending a series of floral-print garments down a runway flanked by Azuma’s sculptures.

headline: Rochas: Spring 2017
abstract: The label’s spring 2017 collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 collection.

headline: A Dozen Looks That Make Us Want to Wear More Color
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Leather and Leather Goods', 'Handbags and Purses', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: A city known for dressing in black has really brightened up.
lead_paragraph: A city known for dressing in black has really brightened up.

headline: Text to Text | ‘The Glass Castle’ and ‘Life on the Streets’
abstract: In this Text to Text, we ask students to reflect on the ways individual stories might shape or change conventional beliefs about homelessness.
lead_paragraph: Browse all our Text to Text lesson plans.

headline: In Caesars Bankruptcy Fight, Private Equity Owners Fold
abstract: Efforts by Apollo Global Management and TPG Capital to salvage their $30 billion buyout of Caesars Entertainment largely failed after creditors fought back.
lead_paragraph: Caesars may be defeated, but borrowers reign supreme.

headline: Is a Third-Party Vote a Wasted Vote?
abstract: Readers disagree. One chastises “holier-than-thou lefties” with a “Downton Abbey” quote. Another says, “It’s never unprincipled to vote one’s conscience.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Peres: 93 Years Young
abstract: Peres believed in applied hope, and he had no respect for the pessimists.
lead_paragraph: When I heard the news that Shimon Peres, the last of Israel’s greatest generation of founding leaders, had died I found myself ruminating about what was so special about this man whom I had had the pleasure of knowing for almost 35 years. It took me a second to articulate it. Peres was almost unique among the Arab and Israeli leaders I’ve covered as a reporter in the Middle East in two crucial respects: He could stand in the other guy’s shoes, and he was determined to let the future bury the past and not let the past bury the future.

headline: The Proposal Was Awkward (but the Answer Was Yes)
abstract: After an imperfect proposal, there can still be a happily ever after.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Fox of New Castle, Pa., had it all planned. He would propose to his girlfriend, Heather Terwilliger of Fredonia, N.Y., Tuesday night during their first visit to Yankee Stadium as the Yankees played the Boston Red Sox.

headline: In Decades-Old Slides, Drops of Blood and Hints of Malaria’s Path
abstract: DNA studies help reveal that some malaria strains closely followed the migrations of people: from India to Europe and then from Europe to the Americas.
lead_paragraph: In 1925, the Spanish government hired a doctor named Ildefonso Canicio to head up a malaria research center in the Ebro Delta, where the disease was endemic. Dr. Canicio worked with patients from the surrounding rice fields for several decades, until he contracted malaria himself. He died of unrelated causes in 1961, the year malaria was eradicated from Spain.

headline: Donald Verrilli, Former Solicitor General, to Join Law Firm
abstract: Mr. Verrilli, who argued 37 cases before the Supreme Court for the Obama administration, will open a Washington office for Munger, Tolles & Olson.
lead_paragraph: Former Solicitor General Donald B. Verrilli Jr., who defended the Obama administration’s positions in major legal issues including the Affordable Care Act and marriage equality before the Supreme Court, is joining the law firm Munger, Tolles & Olson. He will open a Washington office for the firm, which is based in Los Angeles.

headline: What’s in Your Herbal Pills? Firm Promises DNA Testing for Proof
keywords: ['Dietary Supplements and Herbal Remedies', 'Product Tests', 'Labeling and Labels (Product)', 'Consumer Protection']
abstract: One of the national’s largest supplement makers will conduct advanced DNA testing to ensure its products contain the ingredients listed on the label.
lead_paragraph: NBTY, one of the nation’s largest makers of popular supplements like ginkgo biloba and ginseng, has agreed to conduct advanced genetic testing to help ensure that its herbal products actually contain the ingredients promised on the label.

headline: What Do Anna Wintour and Bob Dylan Have in Common? This Secret Garden
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Families and Family Life', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Music']
abstract: A hidden oasis in Greenwich Village that many famous New Yorkers have called home.
lead_paragraph: In 2008, the photographer and film director Francesco Carrozzini bought a townhouse in Greenwich Village for $6.8 million. Ostensibly, he got a four-story brick home built in 1844 with low ceilings and small, dark rooms. But luxury real estate is never about the basics.

headline: 2 Men Who Found Unexploded Bomb in Chelsea Are Identified
abstract: Residents of Egypt, who have since returned there, came upon a travel bag containing the explosives, a law enforcement official said.
lead_paragraph: Investigators have identified the two men who found a travel bag containing an unexploded bomb on a Manhattan street this month, a few blocks from where a bomb exploded, two law enforcement officials said.

headline: A Set Designer Captures His Journey Around the World
abstract: Over more than two decades, Happy Massee traveled to many cities for his work — and documented his adventures in Polaroids.
lead_paragraph: Over more than two decades, Happy Massee traveled to many cities for his work — and documented his adventures in Polaroids.

headline: Twenty-Five Years as a Set Designer, Captured in Polaroids
abstract: Happy Massee, who has worked with Madonna and Michael Jordan, chronicles his life behind the scenes.
lead_paragraph: “I was just very lucky I snuck in there,” says Happy Massee of the Polaroid on the cover of his new book, “Diary of a Set Designer.” The image features Madonna sitting in a cloak of light — a stroke of magic for the infamously finicky film — wearing a satiny bra, her legs wrapped in a black skirt and tights. It’s from the set of her 1994 music video “Take a Bow,” on which Massee worked. (The video is now in the Museum of Modern Art’s permanent video collection.)

headline: California Suspends Ties With Wells Fargo
abstract: The state will drop several relationships with the bank, which is enmeshed in a scandal over the creation of millions of unauthorized accounts.
lead_paragraph: Citing Wells Fargo’s “venal abuse of its customers,” the California treasurer took the unusual step on Wednesday of suspending many of its ties with the San Francisco bank as it continues to reel from the scandal over the creation of as many as two million unauthorized bank and credit card accounts.

headline: Carolina Boy, 14, Held After Father Is Killed and 3 Are Shot at School
keywords: ['School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: A teenager killed his father before going to a nearby elementary school and wounding a teacher and two students, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Update: Jesse Dewitt Osborne was sentenced on Nov. 14, 2019, to life without parole.

headline: Soho Rep Abruptly Closes Its Theater, Seeking New Space
abstract: Three rental productions, including one that was to open Thursday, will have to be relocated or canceled.
lead_paragraph: Soho Rep, a small Off Broadway theater that has nurtured plays with impact well beyond its size, is closing the TriBeCa space in which it has been performing for 25 years.

headline: U.S. to Send 600 More Troops to Iraq to Help Retake Mosul From ISIS
abstract: The deployment, to aid Iraqis in the looming battle to take back Mosul from the Islamic State, will bring the number of American troops in Iraq to 5,000.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama has authorized sending an additional 600 American troops to Iraq to assist Iraqi forces in the looming battle to take back the city of Mosul from the Islamic State, United States officials said on Wednesday.

headline: A Look at Alessandro Michele’s Sets for Gucci
abstract: Since becoming creative director of the iconic house, he has crafted a careful world within the show environment each season.
lead_paragraph: Since becoming creative director of the iconic house, he has crafted a careful world within the show environment each season.

headline: Inside the Elaborate World of Gucci’s Shows
abstract: In his tenure at the house, Alessandro Michele has become known for creating intricate sets, much like the director of a film.
lead_paragraph: “I have the soul of a director,” says the designer Alessandro Michele, a couple of days after his spring/summer 2017 Gucci show. He’s speaking over the phone from Rome, which is fitting, given that Rome is the home of la Cinecittà, the hub of Italian cinema. Michele isn’t hankering after a feature film production like his predecessor Tom Ford. (The former Gucci creative director’s second movie, “Nocturnal Animals,” is out this November.) Rather, he’s talking about the scenography of his tenure at Gucci, which has scrolled through multiple iterations over the past 18 months, like sequels in an ever-unfolding cinematic franchise.

headline: Donald Trump, Sean Hannity and a Still-Elusive Tape
abstract: What exactly did the Republican candidate say about the Iraq war in 2003?
lead_paragraph: Near the end of Monday’s presidential debate between Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton, Trump stood by his oft-contested claim that he opposed invading Iraq in 2003, despite a tape-recorded interview with Howard Stern in 2002 to the contrary. This time, however, he suggested a new source to back up his assertion. “I had numerous conversations with Sean Hannity at Fox,” he told the audience. “He and I used to have arguments about the war. I said it’s a terrible, stupid thing; it’s going to destabilize the Middle East. And that’s exactly what it’s done.” He added: “Nobody wants to call him. Nobody calls Sean Hannity.”

headline: Tennessee Williams and Eugene O’Neill Side by Side, Under the Sun
abstract: This year’s Provincetown Tennessee Williams Theater Festival featured works by Williams and Eugene O’Neill, including a searing “Desire Under the Elms.”
lead_paragraph: PROVINCETOWN, Mass. — Loneliness, the condition into which we are born, and from which we spend much of our lives trying to escape — whether through love and sex, or alcohol or drugs or even, yes, art — is a theme that resounds throughout the works of Eugene O’Neill and Tennessee Williams, two of America’s greatest playwrights, if not the two greatest.

headline: 4.1 Miles
keywords: ['Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Drownings', 'Boats and Boating', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Rescues', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: A coast guard captain on a small Greek island is suddenly charged with saving thousands of refugees from drowning at sea.
lead_paragraph: A coast guard captain on a small Greek island is suddenly charged with saving thousands of refugees from drowning at sea.

headline: 4.1 Miles
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Rescues', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: In this short documentary, nominated for an Academy award, a coast guard captain on a Greek island is charged with saving thousands of refugees.
lead_paragraph: Note: This documentary short film won a 2016 Peabody Award and was nominated for a 2017 Academy Award.

headline: Vineyard Vines, Now at Grand Central. Consider a Pit Stop.
abstract: Charlotte Tilbury works magic at Bloomingdale’s, the MoMA Design Store reopens with new products, and more.
lead_paragraph: Make your Metro-North commute more enjoyable with a pit stop on Thursday, from 5 to 7 p.m., at the recently opened Vineyard Vines store. You’ll find drinks and custom Grand Central coozies, and the founders, Shep and Ian Murray, will be signing the label’s signature whimsical whale-print bow ties ($55 to $65). At Grand Central Terminal, 89 East 42nd Street.

headline: Yankees Praise Their Hitting Coach, but Not Their Hitting
abstract: The team’s general manager stood by the job done by Alan Cockrell, saying the players were to blame for a subpar offensive year.
lead_paragraph: When Mark Teixeira paused to admire his ninth-inning, game-tying home run Monday night, which he then punctuated with an ostentatious flip of the bat, it was a cause for celebration of an infrequent type — for him and the Yankees — when leaving the batter’s box this season.

headline: After the Clinton-Trump Debate: Other Voices
abstract: Readers offer quick takes on Hillary Clinton’s shimmy, Donald Trump’s tax returns, marital infidelity, man vs. woman debates and more.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What Stumpf Is Telling Congress About the Wells Fargo Scandal
abstract: The responses that John G. Stumpf, Wells Fargo’s chief executive, gave last week before a Senate committee notably veered off script from his prepared remarks. See how.
lead_paragraph: The responses that John G. Stumpf, Wells Fargo’s chief executive, gave last week before a Senate committee notably veered off script from his prepared remarks. See how.

headline: In Battle for Soul of Britain’s Labour Party, a Leftist Group Is Winning
abstract: Jeremy Corbyn’s strengthened hold on the Labour Party is due in large part to the success of Momentum, a group intent on bringing true socialism to Britain.
lead_paragraph: LIVERPOOL, England — Jackie Walker, a prominent left-wing activist, was in full flow. “We’re part of the biggest political moment in the last 50 years!” she cried. “The seeds we are sowing, who knows what fruit they will bring?”

headline: 7 Party Hot Spots Opening in New York This Fall
abstract: Night life takes a multiplex approach, with places that feature daytime cafes, cocktail lounges, music halls, restaurants and even Skee-Ball.
lead_paragraph: Leaf through vintage records from Sly and the Family Stone while sipping coffee. Pair duck confit with a mezcal cocktail. Sprawl on a kidney-shaped banquette with a personal mixologist. Maybe catch a rugby match.

headline: CBS and Viacom, Long Split, Will Be Told to Consider Reuniting
abstract: Sumner Redstone’s holding company, which controls the two media giants, is said to be sending letters instructing the companies to consider a merger.
lead_paragraph: A month after a bitter fight over Viacom’s leadership was settled, the company may find itself pressed to reunite with its corporate sibling, CBS.

headline: In Martino, Atlanta United Hires a Pedigree With an Eye on the Future
abstract: Gerardo Martino, who most recently coached Barcelona and Argentina, was hired to get M.L.S.’s new expansion team, Atlanta United, off the ground.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Gerardo Martino looked relaxed Wednesday morning, an hour before his unveiling as the first coach of Atlanta United, the Major League Soccer expansion team scheduled to begin play in March. Dressed in a tailored black suit, a European collar on his white shirt, he smiled readily as he discussed tactics, players and plans. The only sign that he was about to stand in front of a room of reporters was a cheat sheet on a table nearby bearing a few words of greeting in English — a language that Martino, an Argentine, has yet to learn.

headline: Russia’s Brutal Bombing of Aleppo May Be Calculated, and It May Be Working
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Many analysts say Russia and the Syrian government could be massacring civilians as part of a strategy with aims beyond just one city.
lead_paragraph: The effects of Russia’s bombing campaign in the Syrian city of Aleppo — destroying hospitals and schools, choking off basic supplies, and killing aid workers and hundreds of civilians over just days — raise a question: What could possibly motivate such brutality?

headline: The Modern Love Podcast: Kathryn Hahn Reads ‘The Wedding Toast I’ll Never Give’
abstract: On this week’s Modern Love podcast, the “Transparent” actress tells the story of how a missed flight leads a woman to weigh the pros and cons of marriage.
lead_paragraph: In this episode of Modern Love: The Podcast, the actress Kathryn Hahn (“Bad Moms,” “Transparent”) reads the essay “The Wedding Toast I’ll Never Give,” about lessons learned — but seldom shared — from 11 years of marriage.

headline: Review: ‘NY Quadrille’ Opens With a Barefoot Delight
abstract: In a program by Pam Tanowitz Dance, performers on the reconfigured stage of the Joyce Theater put on a suspenseful, lively show.
lead_paragraph: For the two weeks of “NY Quadrille,” the Joyce Theater has been reconfigured. The stage is a raised rectangle (almost a square) in the center of the space. Half the audience is on the far side. Dancers are seen to wait and even dance in the wide margins of space on either side of the stage.

headline: Review: A Singer’s Strong Return in a Drab ‘Don Giovanni’
abstract: The baritone Simon Keenlyside, recovered from injuries, is back at the Met Opera in a sleepy staging of Mozart’s dark comedy.
lead_paragraph: First the good news. The acclaimed English baritone Simon Keenlyside made a much-anticipated return to the Metropolitan Opera on Tuesday evening, after health-related cancellations in recent years.

headline: Income, Not Driving Record, May Determine Auto Insurance Cost
keywords: ['Automobile Insurance and Liability', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Income']
abstract: A consumer group found that some high-income motorists with bad driving records pay less for insurance than lower-income consumers with clean records.
lead_paragraph: Some motorists with high incomes but bad driving records may pay less for car insurance than lower-income consumers with pristine records, a new analysis has found.

headline: Why Do We Lock Up Survivors of Sex Trafficking?
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Foster Care', 'Human Trafficking', 'Law and Legislation', 'Prostitution', 'Sex Crimes', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Young victims are often prosecuted for prostitution.
lead_paragraph: Eighteen-year-old Macy [1] has an infectious smile despite everything. Like many of her college freshman classmates, she works part-time and has several roommates. Unlike those classmates, the shared house she lives in is a safe home for survivors of human trafficking.

headline: Hillary Clinton Struggles to Win Back Young Voters From Third Parties
abstract: More than a third of voters ages 18 to 29 say they will vote for a third-party candidate, and when asked to choose a major-party nominee, 10 percent said they would not vote.
lead_paragraph: With just six weeks to go until Election Day, younger voters are shunning the two major political parties on a scale not seen since Ross Perot’s third-party bid for the presidency in 1992, a striking swing in public opinion that is slicing into Hillary Clinton’s thin margin for error.

headline: Protecting Humans and Jobs From Robots Is 5 Tech Giants’ Goal
keywords: ['Artificial Intelligence', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Partnership on AI unites Amazon, Facebook, Google, IBM and Microsoft to ease public fears of machines that are learning to think for themselves.
lead_paragraph: Five major technology companies said Wednesday that they had created an organization to set the ground rules for protecting humans — and their jobs — in the face of rapid advances in artificial intelligence.

headline: Review: Laura Benanti Shows Range With Songs and Stories
abstract: In her show at Café Carlyle, a self-assured and humorous Ms. Benanti displayed a powerful voice as she took on songs from her idols.
lead_paragraph: Supreme command, a thrilling voice and a wild sense of humor combined to make Laura Benanti’s opening-night show, “Tales From Soprano Isle” at Café Carlyle, on Tuesday evening a sensation. If some of the stories she told of her adventures in show business described disabling stage fright and technical mishaps during performances, Ms. Benanti exhibited a fearless self-assurance as she blithely sailed through a program that ran from Rodgers and Hammerstein to Tori Amos. On top of that, Ms. Benanti is pregnant with her first child, a girl, by Patrick Brown, whom she married last November.

headline: Court Overturns New Hampshire Ban on Selfies (and Snapchat) in Voting Booths
keywords: ['Photography', 'Social Media', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Instant Messaging', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: The social media company and journalism groups argued against the claim that the pictures intimidate voters.
lead_paragraph: New Hampshire voters seeking to express themselves in the voting booth with a so-called ballot selfie will be able to snap freely after a federal appeals court ruled that a ban against the practice infringed on free speech.

headline: For Some Newspapers, Endorsing Clinton Means Losing Subscribers
abstract: The Arizona Republic on Tuesday joined several other publications that had broken long traditions of backing Republicans for president.
lead_paragraph: The subscription cancellations were coming every 10 minutes. Angry readers have been calling in droves. One caller issued a death threat.

headline: Review: With ‘22, a Million,’ Bon Iver Beats a Retreat to Even Quieter Reinvention
abstract: The new album is what happens when a performer who craved interiority has to re-entrench after finding a spotlight he couldn’t shake.
lead_paragraph: The eccentric in retreat isn’t a new character in pop — the motivations can be technological, aesthetic, psychological or simply circumstantial — but it has specific meaning in 2016. The relentlessness of modern internet conversation has led to an implicit threat: Be everywhere, or don’t be at all.

headline: YouTube Hires Music Executive as a Liaison to the Industry
abstract: Lyor Cohen, who got his start in hip-hop, said he would encourage the music world to embrace new technologies to promote music and talent.
lead_paragraph: For the last year, the music industry has been waging a bitter war against YouTube, accusing the popular video site of paying too little in royalties. The conflict has often seemed tribal, with record companies and stars on one side, and Silicon Valley on the other.

headline: Alec Baldwin Joins ‘S.N.L.’ as Donald Trump
abstract: The actor, a frequent host of the comedy program, will appear on the premiere Saturday, with Kate McKinnon as Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: “Saturday Night Live” has found its Donald Trump, and it’s a performer who is plenty familiar with the show.

lead_paragraph: For the word porn alone, nature writing can be its own giddy reward. Consider the names of shorebirds, which Michael McCarthy deploys to voluptuous effect in “The Moth Snowstorm: Nature and Joy.” Dunlins. Great knots. Curlews. Nordmann’s greenshanks. Bar-tailed godwits.

headline: Israel Without Shimon Peres? In Many Ways, His Dream Faded Long Ago
abstract: Despite his own late-in-life attempts at unity among Israelis, perhaps it is only natural that his legacy is viewed through a prism of old divides.

headline: Romeo Castellucci, the Provocative Italian Stage Director
abstract: Despite his international fame, Mr. Castellucci has never had his work seen in New York City until now, at the Crossing the Line Festival.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers get to see a lot of Shakespeare, but it’s usually not as out there as “Julius Caesar. Spared Parts.” Directed by Romeo Castellucci, this 45-minute performance boils down the play to three main scenes, and even they are almost unrecognizable. Mark Antony’s funeral speech, for instance, is delivered in a barely decipherable rasp by an actor, Dalmazio Masini, who has had a tracheotomy.

headline: Agnes Nixon, Who Infused Her Soap Operas With Social Relevance, Dies at 93

lead_paragraph: Agnes Nixon, a celebrated creator and writer of television soap operas, who introduced uterine cancer, venereal diseases, child abuse, AIDS and other societal terrors into the weekday fantasy worlds of millions of daytime viewers, died on Wednesday in Rosemont, Pa. She was 93.

headline: Israel’s Philosopher-Politician
abstract: Shimon Peres remained optimistic about Israel’s role in the world.
lead_paragraph: Shimon Peres, who died in Tel Aviv on Wednesday at age 93, was a man of contradictions. Admired in much of the world for his eloquence, wisdom and dedication to peacemaking, within Israel he lacked the popularity and charisma of other leaders of his generation, military heroes like Yitzhak Rabin or Ariel Sharon in whose shadow he spent much of his long public service.

This may be due in part to the competing theatrics here and elsewhere these days — the criminal conviction of the House speaker, the possible impeachment of an allegedly philandering governor, not to mention the national political spectacle.

headline: Leader of Spain’s Socialist Party Survives Ouster Attempt
abstract: The future of the main opposition party’s leader, Pedro Sánchez, still hangs in the balance, after top party officials said they would resign in protest.

headline: Review: ‘Giselle,’ a Winning Gamble for English National Ballet
abstract: Akram Khan’s beautiful new production blends an earthy physicality with balletic grace and an inventive score, although the storytelling doesn’t measure up.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — Akram Khan’s eagerly awaited new “Giselle” for English National Ballet was a courageous, expensive gamble for the company’s director, Tamara Rojo. It was also a creative leap and a risk for Mr. Khan, who had never created a full-length work for a ballet company, and whose distinctive fusion of contemporary dance and Indian kathak did not seem especially suited to a classical ensemble. To add to the high stakes, Mr. Khan decided to commission a score rather than use the ballet’s traditional music by Adolphe Adam, then parted ways with his composer, Ben Frost, a month before the premiere, replacing him with Vincenzo Lamagna.

And still others are here to test us via the crossword puzzle, most likely to make sure we have not fallen asleep facedown into our bowl of Cocoa Puffs.

headline: ‘Empire’ Season 3, Episode 2: Stay WOKE
abstract: "Empire” earns a ton of good will whenever the Lyon boys get together.
lead_paragraph: The pop, the pulp and the politics of “Empire” are often so explosive they might be expected to send the show flying in a million different directions. Episodes like this week’s, however, go a long way toward explaining why that’s never happened: Quiet scenes involving the three Lyon sons, like the scotch-fueled exchange that appears near the end of the hour, frequently serve as the invisible thread that holds the whole thing together.

headline: Review: ‘All the Ways to Say I Love You,’ a Lesson in Guilt
abstract: Judith Light performs this Neil LaBute monologue about a schoolteacher racked with regret over an inadvisable decision.
lead_paragraph: When a subway rumbles under the Lucille Lortel Theater these days, audiences assembled there for Neil LaBute’s “All the Ways to Say I Love You” may assume that it’s just Judith Light’s thundering pulse. Portraying a schoolteacher with a secret (or rather, A Secret) in a self-flagellating monologue that could have been written only by Mr. LaBute, she gives palpable force to a buried guilt that keeps clawing its way to the light, like some prematurely entombed figure out of Edgar Allan Poe.

headline: Colin Kaepernick Says Presidential Candidates Were Trying to ‘Debate Who’s Less Racist’

headline: ‘The Girl on the Train’ Takes the Fast Track From Book to Screen
abstract: When Paula Hawkins’s novel became a meteoric best seller, its movie team suddenly had to catch up.
lead_paragraph: Back in March 2014, when Jared LeBoff, a producer at Marc Platt Productions, first read the thriller “The Girl on the Train,” it wasn’t yet a sensation, one that to date has sold more than six million copies in the United States alone. Sent to him in digital form by an agent of an unknown author, Paula  Hawkins, it was a yet-to-be-published novel with three untrustworthy female narrators — one of them an unhappy, alcoholic divorcée named Rachel Watson who believes she has witnessed something key to a woman’s disappearance.

headline: Chicken Tetrazzini, the Casserole Even Snobs Love
abstract: Time and home cooking have stripped away many of the dish’s Continental flourishes. That might be for the better.
lead_paragraph: In the early years of the 20th century, when the Italian opera star Luisa Tetrazzini was singing to adoring crowds in San Francisco and New York, some enterprising chef got the idea of making an insanely rich pasta dish and naming it for her. Chicken tetrazzini was spaghetti, heavy cream, chicken, mushrooms and Parmesan, served with two classic French sauces, chicken velouté and hollandaise, on top. This was fancy food, if hardly Italian, and within just a few years you could find tetrazzini in the dining rooms of the nation’s swankier hotels. In the 1930s, the actor Vincent Price used to eat it at Sardi’s in Manhattan, where he was a thrice-weekly regular during a run of “Victoria Regina” at the Broadhurst Theater across the street. He liked tetrazzini so much that he included a recipe for it in “A Treasury of Great Recipes,” the cookbook he wrote with his wife, Mary, in 1965.

headline: Medicinal Herb or Myth? Indian Official Proposes Hunt for Sanjivani of Lore
abstract: A state official wants to spend nearly $4 million in search of the plant, which is said to grow in the Himalayas and which a Hindu epic claims has the power to revive the dying.
lead_paragraph: Sanjivani is the stuff of myth: an herb that glows in the dark and has the power to revive the dying, wrenching them back from the fog of unconsciousness. In the Ramayana, a sacred Hindu epic, the herb is used to resuscitate both the god-hero Rama and his younger brother Lakshmana.

headline: The 4 Traits That Put Kids at Risk for Addiction
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Children and Childhood', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Addiction (Psychology)', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder']
abstract: Early trials show that personality testing can identify 90 percent of the highest risk children, targeting risky traits before they cause problems.
lead_paragraph: Drug education is the only part of the middle school curriculum I remember — perhaps because it backfired so spectacularly. Before reaching today’s legal drinking age, I was shooting cocaine and heroin.

headline: The Health Care ‘Public Option’ Is Back. Can It Help Obamacare?
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'States (US)']
abstract: A closer look at one increasingly popular, but not well-defined, idea to address the markets shortcomings of the health law.
lead_paragraph: On the campaign trail and in the halls of policy wonks, the health care term of the moment is “the public option.” The idea is to create a government-run health care plan that would be an alternative to the private insurance plans offered under the Affordable Care Act, or provide a fallback in markets where insurers have been pulling out. In an article in The New England Journal of Medicine published on Wednesday, Hillary Clinton reiterated her support for such a measure. Margot Sanger-Katz and Reed Abelson, two New York Times reporters who have been covering Obamacare, discuss the public option and the questions it raises.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: The Nakagin Capsule Tower
abstract: Architectural failure can be beautiful, like the intrusion of another world into our own.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, heartbroken and restless, I ran away from my problems to visit a friend in Tokyo. The city is famously full of diversions for rootless Westerners; any neurosis or perversion might be catered to in the warrens between its skyscrapers. But there was only one thing I really wanted to see: the Nakagin Capsule Tower, a grand architectural oddity designed by Kisho Kurokawa, a founding genius behind Japanese Metabolism, an innovative movement united around the desire to create buildings whose forms mirrored and were responsive to those of living organisms. The Metabolists were part of the postwar boom in bizarre, expressive architectural concepts, but unlike so many of their contemporaries, the Metabolists actually managed to get some of their projects built.

headline: How Donald Trump Set Off a Civil War Within the Right-Wing Media
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Since the candidate clinched the nomination, the green room has become a chilly place.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, one of the most important events on a prospective Republican presidential candidate’s calendar was the RedState Gathering, a summer convention for conservative activists from across the nation. Its host was Erick Erickson, a round-faced, redheaded former election lawyer and city councilman in Macon, Ga., who began blogging in 2004 on a site called RedState.com.

headline: A Dog-Friendly Co-op in Sunset Park, Brooklyn
abstract: Michael Beattie and Marissa Tarallo went in “wide-eyed” thinking their search would be a one-month process.
lead_paragraph: Michael Beattie and Marissa Tarallo, traffic engineers who met at work, rented a one-bedroom on the garden level of a brownstone in Park Slope, Brooklyn. The rent was $2,100 a month. The place was dark and noisy. “It served its purpose, but we were ready to move on,” Mr. Beattie said.

headline: Cubs’ Theo Epstein Is Making Lightning Strike Twice
abstract: Epstein helped the Boston Red Sox end an 86-year World Series title drought. Expectations are high he can duplicate the feat with the playoff-bound Chicago Cubs.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Five years ago, Theo Epstein took a job that even his friends called career suicide.

headline: 36 Hours in Richmond, Virginia
abstract: A new African-American museum, appealing parks and distinctive dining spots are among the lures of this riverside city.
lead_paragraph: A new African-American museum, appealing parks and distinctive dining spots are among the lures of this riverside city.

headline: When ‘Yelling Commands’ Is the Wrong Police Response
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Abuse of the Disabled', 'Disabilities', 'Intellectual Disabilities']
abstract: More officers are being taught to de-escalate tensions, particularly when facing people with diminished mental capacity, but experts say there is a long way to go.
lead_paragraph: The story out of El Cajon, Calif., a San Diego suburb, had an eerie familiarity: The police respond to a person exhibiting some kind of disturbing behavior, but the subject — perhaps lost in his own, altered world — does not comply with the usual commands, does not heed the standard warnings, acts in a way that seems to invite danger, and ends up dead.

headline: Rihanna’s Fenty Line Debuts in Paris and Receives a Pop Star Welcome
abstract: Fashion — and fans — paid court to the pop star and the look she described as Marie Antoinette “if she was going to the gym.”
lead_paragraph: PARIS — On an upper floor of the Hôtel Salomon de Rothschild, the 19th-century manse formerly occupied by the banking Rothschilds, a line of sweating models fiddled with the rings in their lips and the septums of their perfect noses, and waited to have their lip gloss reapplied. They chatted among themselves, fanning one another with torn bits of cardboard in the close, sticky corridor and examining their nails, which had been sharpened to talons and encrusted with miniature gems. They received compliments with the languorous equanimity of court ladies, which for a night they were.

headline: Is Your Online World Just a ‘Filter Bubble’ of People With the Same Opinions?
abstract: How diverse are the sources in your social media feed, and why does it matter?
lead_paragraph: Where and how do you get your news? How much comes via a social media feed? How diverse is that feed in terms of demographic details like the ages, races, religions, geographical locations, interests and political affiliations of the people you follow?

headline: India Claims ‘Surgical Strikes’ Across Line of Control in Kashmir
abstract: Pakistan played down the early morning operation, which it said killed two of its soldiers and wounded nine, calling it a propaganda exercise by Delhi.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — India announced on Thursday that it had carried out early morning “surgical strikes” on terrorist camps in Pakistani-controlled Kashmir, a step that risks escalating the conflict between the two nuclear powers.

headline: Torn Over Donald Trump and Cut Off by Culture Wars, Evangelicals Despair
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Series', 'Evangelical Movement', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'ABORTION']
abstract: In small-town Iowa, conservative Christians say they feel abandoned, with no true champion in the presidential race and a country that they believe has turned its back.
lead_paragraph: GRIMES, Iowa — Betty and Dick Odgaard used to own the tiny church next door to their home. They had built it over 13 years into an art gallery, bistro, flower shop and framing service. They even rented out the chapel, with its bright stained glass windows, for social events.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s College Plan Appeals to the Left, but Educators Have Doubts
abstract: While the idea of free tuition has been championed as an antidote to soaring costs and student debt, many in higher education fear unintended consequences.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton announced her new higher education plan this summer with a burst of fanfare, promising to invest $500 billion to eliminate tuition for millions of students at public colleges and universities across the country. The move was an expansion of an earlier, less ambitious proposal, and was seen as a conciliatory gesture to her left-leaning primary opponent, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, and his supporters ahead of the Democratic Party’s convention.

headline: U.S. Election, El Cajon, Yahoo: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Peres and the Passing of Hope
abstract: Shimon Peres thought about history. Netanyahu thinks about the next election.
lead_paragraph: With the death of Shimon Peres and the passing of the last of the giants of Israel’s foundation a void fills the soul — in part because the peace of which he dreamed has proved elusive, in part because the search for Israeli-Palestinian compromise has reached a low point of repetitive sterility, but above all because statesmanship has now given way among the leaders of Israel to barren tactical maneuver.

headline: New York Today: Artists-in-Residence
abstract: Thursday: Finding inspiration in unusual places, honoring a fallen firefighter, and Vaclav Havel Day.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:20 a.m.

headline: A 7-Night, $250 Cruise? Yes, and You Might Also Do Some Good
keywords: ['Cruises', 'Budget Travel', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Volunteers and Community Service']
abstract: Taking the Fathom “social impact” cruise, in which travelers do volunteer work in exchange for low rates to the Dominican Republic.
lead_paragraph: I had been on only one cruise in my life: a hulking 4,252-person Royal Caribbean vessel that featured an ice-skating rink, a mini-golf course, a casino and a Johnny Rockets. It felt as if a small city had been ripped from its foundation, airlifted and placed on the water. David Foster Wallace’s famous essay on the perils of being pampered at sea rang true: Between the all-you-can-eat food, bad drinks and being compelled to participate in “Y.M.C.A.” more times than I care to admit, I was ready to never set foot on a cruise ship again.

headline: Five Places to Shop in Singapore
abstract: Throughout Singapore, local designers are setting up shops and increasingly giving this global financial center a reputation as a design hub.
lead_paragraph: A homegrown design scene is emerging in Singapore, which last year celebrated 50 years as an independent state. A smattering of 19th-century buildings from its days as a British colony conjure up images of steamy afternoons of Singapore Sling cocktails and card games at the Raffles Hotel, which its owners named after Stamford Raffles, founder of modern Singapore. But get a taste of Singapore’s cultural mélange by delving into vibrant enclaves like Little India, Chinatown and Arab Town. Look even further and you’ll find local designers setting up shops across the island city-state, increasingly giving this global financial center a reputation as a design hub.

headline: Is ‘Westworld’ HBO’s Next Big Hit?
abstract: HBO faces pressure with this new show to revive its drama slate as “Game of Thrones,” another high-concept epic with lots of violence, enters its twilight.
lead_paragraph: On the morning they finished shooting the pilot for “Westworld,” the married showrunners Jonathan Nolan and Lisa Joy commandeered a golf cart and went for a drive around Sweetwater, the Old West town they built for the show on Gene Autry’s former ranch studio in Santa Clarita, Calif.

headline: Morning Agenda: CBS and Viacom, Rules on Arbitration, Deutsche Bank Gloom
keywords: ['Television', 'ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION', 'Elder Care', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: CBS and Viacom have had very different fortunes since they split, but could it be time for them to get back together?
lead_paragraph: Could it be time for CBS and Viacom to get back together again?

headline: Deborah de Robertis: Shocking for a Purpose
abstract: The renegade performance artist discusses the heady ideas behind her bold acts.
lead_paragraph: In 2014, the renegade performance artist Deborah de Robertis shocked audiences at the Musée d’Orsay by exposing her genitals in front of Gustave Courbet’s “The Origin of the World.” In January, she was arrested after staging a similar re-enactment of Manet’s “Olympia,” also at the Orsay. This month, she invited herself into two major Paris exhibitions. At the Musée Guimet, she recast herself as the model in an iconic photograph by Nobuyoshi Araki, dressing as a geisha and gorging on a watermelon placed between her legs. Then, at the Musée des Arts Décoratifs, she was arrested after crashing an exhibition devoted to “Barbie,” appearing in a plastic costume that reimagined the classic doll as a symbol of 21st-century feminism, with articulated nipples, pubic hair, a nose ring and Go-Pro camera strapped to her head. While some dismiss these unsanctioned appearances as shameless provocations, the Luxembourg-born Ms. De Robertis, 32, sees her work in the tradition of guerrilla performance artists like Valie Export and Andrea Fraser. In the following edited interview, she discusses the heady ideas behind her bold acts, and the very diverse reactions they elicit — from ferocious criticism to rapturous applause.

headline: Donald Trump Leans Into Rough News Cycle
abstract: On the topic of Alicia Machado, he has dug in on the notion that he did nothing wrong — and that a Miss Universe should not gain weight in the first place.
lead_paragraph: When presented with the opportunity to move past a difficult news cycle, Donald J. Trump has struggled to do so throughout the campaign.

headline: Review: In ‘Deepwater Horizon,’ Oil, Fire and Greed
abstract: Peter Berg’s film dramatizes a familiar story and stands as a work of popular narrative for an age of corporate impunity.
lead_paragraph: “Deepwater Horizon” is a swift and suspenseful action movie, full of noise, peril, muck and fire. It’s also a true-crime story, the highly detailed procedural chronicle of how, on April 20, 2010, 11 people were killed and a vast marine ecosystem was despoiled because of negligence and greed. Like “The Big Short,” this film, directed by Peter Berg, dramatizes a broadly familiar story and stands as a work of popular narrative for an age of corporate impunity. The anger and grief you feel leaving the theater constitute a kind of catharsis, a modest symbolic compensation for the failure of justice in the real world.

headline: Review: Youthful Recklessness Finds Adventure on the Road in ‘American Honey’
abstract: Andrea Arnold’s new feature (her first set in the United States), with a cast mostly of newcomers, follows a band of aimless youths around the country.
lead_paragraph: On the shelf of essential cultural products whose names begin with the word “American,” Andrea Arnold’s new film (her fourth feature and the first set in the United States) might find a spot between Grant Wood’s “Gothic” and Green Day’s “Idiot.” This is not solely a matter of alphabetical order. “American Honey,” which takes its title from a song by Lady Antebellum, is a roaming, rambling road picture propelled by sex, hip-hop and close-ups of insects. It probes the murk and terror beneath the surface of contemporary life, and illuminates the vital role of ignorance, poor judgment and wishful thinking in our national character.

headline: Chengguan, Widely Despised Officers in China, Find Refuge and a Kind Ear
abstract: In recognition of the pressures they face, a center opened in Nanjing that offers the urban management officers counseling and other support services.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — They may be the most reviled public servants in China. A Chinese Academy of Social Sciences report on the popularity of government officials two years ago ranked the chengguan, or urban management officers, dead last. Unarmed but charged with enforcing order on city streets, they have been scorned as bullies who brutalize beggars, smash unlicensed fruit vendors’ carts, kill unregistered pets and assist in the forced demolition of people’s homes. Scuffles are common, sometimes ending in injury or even death.

lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Russia escalated its anti-American invective Thursday in the deadlocked diplomacy over the Syrian war, dismissing a threat by Secretary of State John Kerry to halt talks and accusing his spokesman of abetting global terrorism — including against Russian military personnel in Syria.

headline: Fall Weather Means Good Deals at Upscale European Hotels
abstract: Destinations like the Amalfi Coast and the South of France are inviting just about any time of year — and considerably less expensive starting in October.
lead_paragraph: The South of France, the Amalfi Coast of Italy and Spain’s Costa del Sol are just a few of the seaside European destinations known as the summertime haunts of well-heeled travelers. From June through September, prices for a night’s stay in a hotel are sky high, and jockeying for reservations at popular restaurants is something of a full-time sport.
