keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Electoral College']
abstract: Models are basically compilations of different sources of information like polls, but underlying assumptions influence the outcome greatly.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton currently has a 71 percent chance of winning the presidency, according to The Upshot’s forecasting model. This is down from 90 percent last month, but higher than some other models we’re tracking, which put the odds between 58 percent and 85 percent.

headline: Hoboken Train Crash Kills 1 and Injures Over 100

lead_paragraph: HOBOKEN, N.J. — A careening commuter train plowed through the barrier at the end of the tracks and crashed into a wall at a terminal here during the morning rush on Thursday, killing one person, injuring more than 100 others and unleashing chaos as part of the station’s roof came tumbling down in a jumble of metal.

headline: A Free-Speech Fatality
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Censorship', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: The Jordanian government claims it’s fighting radicalization but at the same time offers concessions to radicals. And the result is deadly.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — In January 2015, King Abdullah and Queen Rania of Jordan marched in Paris with other world leaders to pay tribute to the murdered cartoonists of Charlie Hebdo and to stand up for freedom of expression. Less than two years later, when Nahed Hattar, a 56-year-old Jordanian writer from a Christian family, shared a cartoon on his Facebook page that some perceived to be mocking God, the Jordanian government swiftly ordered his arrest and charged him with “insulting religious belief and sentiment.”

headline: Antoine Fuqua Narrates a Scene From ‘The Magnificent Seven’
abstract: The director discusses an action sequence from the film.
lead_paragraph: One particular gunfight in the new “Magnificent Seven” is a doozy. The crew from the title has gotten together to save a town from bandits and, in this scene, unite to fight for the first time. Guns blaze, arrows pierce, knives fly — and the bodies pile up.

headline: 1916: Sultan of Egypt Keeps Faith in Britain
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Sultan Hussein Kamel expresses his faith in the British protectorate of Egypt in 1916.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In an interview with a correspondent of the Associated Press, the Sultan of Egypt dealt at considerable length with the British protectorate over his country. He said, according to a Reuter despatch from New York: “I believe that under the protection of Great Britain, the greatest of liberal Powers, the future of Egypt is assured. … Had it not been for my faith in the British Government, and my belief that there would be a gradual increase in the rights granted us in the matter of self-rule, I should never have undertaken the task. From a personal standpoint I had nothing to gain. I was happy as a prince, following my agricultural and philanthropic pursuits, with no weight of government upon my shoulders.”

In the weeks since, he has been watching baseball on television at home in Miami and shepherding his daughters, ages 8 and 11, to school and other places.

abstract: During the forum Monday night, she adopted a lexicon that has been embraced by a new generation of young black activists and liberal whites.

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the spring/summer 2017 collections that were presented in Paris on Wednesday.

headline: A.C.C. Moves Football Championship Game to Orlando
abstract: The game, typically played in Charlotte, was pulled from North Carolina earlier this month in response to a controversial state law.
lead_paragraph: The Atlantic Coast Conference’s football championship game, typically played in Charlotte, N.C., but pulled from the state earlier this month in response to a controversial North Carolina law, will be staged at Camping World Stadium in Orlando, Fla., in December, the conference announced Thursday.

headline: Train Crashes Into Hoboken Station
abstract: A New Jersey Transit train crashed at a station during the Thursday morning rush, killing at least one person and injuring dozens.
lead_paragraph: A New Jersey Transit train crashed at a station during the Thursday morning rush, killing at least one person and injuring dozens.

headline: So Was Rihanna’s Show Any Good? And More Pressing Questions from Paris Fashion Week
abstract: How do you reconcile the desire to preserve the past with the need to accept the present? From Dries Van Noten to Chloé, some answers were designed.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Twenty-three blocks of ice, each almost five feet tall, enclosed perfectly preserved gardens of flowers at the peak of their color and bloom on the second floor of a long, cavernous warehouse space at a grungy edge of the Eighth Arrondissement of Paris, just beyond the railway tracks of the Gare St.-Lazare, like a three-dimensional gallery of Dutch flower paintings. Then the melting — and the Dries Van Noten show — began. Everyone watching knew that all that frozen beauty would inevitably end in puddles in the floor. Disney came to mind. Also Robert Frost.

headline: Swizz Beatz’s Music Studio Is Basically an Art Gallery
abstract: The hip-hop artist and music producer started his art collection at the age of 18 with a photograph by Ansel Adams.
lead_paragraph: On a recent late-summer evening, a gleaming black Mercedes Maybach pulled up on West 15th Street outside of Kola House, a newly opened restaurant, and lingered quietly by the curb.

headline: Sophie and Frederik Bille Brahe’s Jewelry-Inspired Feast
abstract: For her Paris Fashion Week dinner tonight, the jewelry designer recruited her younger brother to create a menu based on her designs.
lead_paragraph: For her Paris Fashion Week dinner tonight, the jewelry designer recruited her younger brother to create a menu based on her designs.

headline: In Paris, a Dinner Where Food and Jewelry Commingle
abstract: The Danish jewelry designer Sophie Bille Brahe and her brother, chef Frederik Bille Brahe, have collaborated on an outside-the-box meal.
lead_paragraph: “Scandinavian bling” is how the Danish jewelry designer Sophie Bille Brahe jokingly describes her new spring/summer 2017 collection, which will be presented in Paris tonight.

headline: Creepy Clown Hoaxes Lead to 12 Arrests in Multiple States
abstract: The police crack down on pranksters taking advantage of hysteria that was fueled by social media and news reports.
lead_paragraph: The reports to the police had one thing in common with the circus act involving an improbable number of clowns emerging from a small car.

headline: 1941: Van Gogh Painting Acquired
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: The Museum of Modern Art in New York acquires the painting “Starry Night” by Vincent Van Gogh through the Lillie P. Bliss bequest in September 1941.
lead_paragraph: The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, announced yesterday the acquisition of a painting by Vincent Van Gogh, called “Starry Night.” The work, an oil painting measuring about 29 by 35 inches, was acquired by the museum through the Lillie P. Bliss bequest. “Starry Night,” the announcement said, is the first Van Gogh to be acquired by a New York museum, and one of the most important paintings obtained by the Museum of Modern Art. It was painted in 1889 in St. Rémy in the artist’s late style, and consists of a composition of cypress trees in the foreground with a village and hills in a distance beneath a sky with explosive stars and swirling milky way. The picture is comparatively little known in New York. — New York Herald Tribune, Sept. 30, 1941

headline: How a Merger of Viacom and CBS Might Make Sense
abstract: Strategically, the idea to put the two businesses back together is far from absurd, but the trouble is keeping both sets of shareholders happy.
lead_paragraph: Sumner M. Redstone and his family are contemplating a reunification.

headline: Spectacular Northern Lights Over Iceland
abstract: The northern lights are particularly vivid this week and the Reykjavik City Council ordered street lamps to be turned off in most neighborhoods to improve visibility for watching the dancing lights.
lead_paragraph: The northern lights are particularly vivid this week and the Reykjavik City Council ordered street lamps to be turned off in most neighborhoods to improve visibility for watching the dancing lights.

headline: Joy Luck Palace
abstract: The dim sum, little piggy buns included, draws crowds in Manhattan’s Chinatown.
lead_paragraph: The dim sum, little piggy buns included, draws crowds in Manhattan’s Chinatown.

headline: At Joy Luck Palace, Dim Sum Amid the Chaos
abstract: Crowds seek the little piggy buns along with the classics at this perpetually packed restaurant in Manhattan’s Chinatown.
lead_paragraph: Everyone wants the little piggies, plump white buns with black sesame-seed eyes, orange snouts and slashes of ears that look more like worried brows. At Joy Luck Palace in Manhattan’s Chinatown, they come three to a steamer basket and harbor gooey souls of custard.

headline: Win or Lose, the U.S. Ryder Cup Team Belongs to Phil Mickelson
abstract: Mickelson, a member of eight losing teams, was part of a United States task force that helped implement changes, including a more decentralized system.
lead_paragraph: CHASKA, Minn. — The wind was gusting at more than 30 miles per hour when the United States team showed up at Hazeltine National Golf Club on Monday for its first practices of the Ryder Cup week. Some people might have seen the blustery conditions as symbolic of the difficulties the Americans face in trying to regain their footing in a competition whose outcome in recent years has tilted toward the Europeans.

headline: Take a Picture Quickly in iOS 10
abstract: Among other things, Apple’s latest redesign of its mobile operating system changes the lock screen’s shortcut to the iPhone’s camera app.
lead_paragraph: Q. I just upgraded to iOS 10. Where did the shortcut camera icon in the bottom corner of the iPhone lock screen go? That was useful.

headline: In Bruce Springsteen’s America, Many Turn Toward Donald Trump
abstract: A tour of signature places from Springsteen songs about working-class whites shows enthusiasm for the Republican nominee.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Springsteen is often called the troubadour of white, working-class America, a landscape he explores  in his autobiography released this week. But this election, the Republican presidential nominee, Donald J. Trump, has captured many of those blue-collar voters’ hearts, with his denunciation of trade deals and promises to bring back manufacturing.

headline: Wildlife Management: The View From Washington
abstract: Wildlife Services writes that its “nonlethal actions constituted the majority of management” last year.

headline: Donald Trump and Nuclear Arms
abstract: A reader says Donald Trump seems to be ignorant about the United States’ nuclear policy and arsenal.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Ohio, Long a Bellwether, Is Fading on the Electoral Map
abstract: It is a jarring change for Ohio’s political veterans, who have long relished having their state at the center of the country’s presidential races.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS, Ohio — After decades as one of America’s most reliable political bellwethers, an inevitable presidential battleground that closely mirrored the mood and makeup of the country, Ohio is suddenly fading in importance this year.

headline: After Outcry, Miró Collection to Stay in Portugal
abstract: The art became a national controversy in 2014 when the government announced its sale via Christie’s in London; it goes on display Saturday in Porto.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Portugal’s government has decided to keep a collection of works by the artist Joan Miró, more than two years after the pieces set off  a national debate over whether such cultural patrimony could be sold to help improve the country’s finances.

headline: Fantasy Football: Players to Start in Week 4
abstract: Cam Newton, LeGarrette Blount and Demaryius Thomas are among the players set up to perform well in Week 4.
lead_paragraph: The Sablich brothers have provided award-winning fantasy football advice for The New York Times since 2010. See their weekly player rankings and visit 5thDownFantasy.com for more fantasy analysis. You can also ask them questions through their Twitter account, @5thdownfantasy.

headline: Good, Bad and Mad: Andrew Rosenthal on the News
abstract: Andrew Rosenthal, a Times opinion columnist, on the latest Aleppo bombing, the presidential debate, “Bridget Jones’s Baby” and more. Susan Lehman is host.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Rosenthal, a Times opinion columnist, on the latest Aleppo bombing, the presidential debate, “Bridget Jones’s Baby” and more. Susan Lehman is host.

headline: New York City Starts $5 Million Fund for Women in Film and Theater
abstract: The Mayor’s Office of Media and Entertainment will create the fund, administered over five years, to help with projects “by, for, or about women.”
lead_paragraph: New York is set to become the first city in the country with a major municipal program geared toward helping female filmmakers and theater-makers. The Mayor’s Office of Media and Entertainment is to announce on Thursday a new five-part initiative to promote equality behind and in front of the camera, in film and television, as well as onstage.

headline: Balmain: Spring 2017
abstract: Olivier Rousteing presents his spring looks.
lead_paragraph: Olivier Rousteing presents his spring looks.

headline: Joseph Harmatz, Who Led Jewish Plot to Kill Germans After World War II, Dies at 91
abstract: Harmatz, a survivor of the Vilnius ghetto in Lithuania, was the leader of a group that poisoned 2,200 imprisoned Germans by lacing their bread with arsenic.
lead_paragraph: Imagine a real-life version of “Inglourious Basterds,” Quentin Tarantino’s quixotic movie about Jewish avengers in World War II — but in this case involving a plot by a band of refugees to kill millions of Germans just after the war by poisoning their water supply.

headline: Share Your Experiences as a Female Police Officer
abstract: We’d like to hear from female police officers about how being a woman plays out while in the line of duty.
lead_paragraph: We’d like to hear from female police officers about how being a woman plays out while in the line of duty.

headline: Breaking Bad News to Patients
abstract: Some doctors engage in light conversation with their patients before telling them their cancer has returned, but I have always felt that to be disingenuous, writes Dr. Mikkael Sekeres.
lead_paragraph: I carried the knowledge like a millstone chained around my neck, my back aching from the emotional weight of bad news not yet imparted.

headline: Alexis Mabille: Spring 2017
abstract: The label’s spring 2017 collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 collection.

headline: Daily Report: When Artificial Intelligence Goes to the Dark Side
abstract: Criminals are beginning to take advantage of the kind of smart technology that imitates voices and helps people plot the fastest route home.
lead_paragraph: Computers really are becoming like people: Just because they are smart doesn’t mean they won’t do awful things.

headline: Wine for the Ages, Without Artifice
abstract: Working without preservatives on the dangerous border between art and ruin, Stanko Radikon achieved wines of rare beauty and rocklike stability.
lead_paragraph: Stanislao Radikon died of cancer a few weeks ago, on Sept. 11. He was just 62, and though most casual wine consumers may never have heard of him, his wines epitomized a level of beauty and truth sought by wine lovers every time they open a bottle.

headline: California’s Hotel Bungalow Boom
abstract: Three hotels are reviving the traditional Hollywood hide-out.
lead_paragraph: Historic hotel bungalows have a timeless allure that dates back to the early 20th century, when they were first introduced to accommodate families needing more space and privacy. Today, three California properties are reviving the traditional Hollywood hide-out.

headline: Mahmoud Abbas to Attend Shimon Peres Funeral, but Thaw With Israel Is Unlikely
abstract: The decision by Mahmoud Abbas, president of the Palestinian Authority, to attend the Israeli statesman’s funeral does not portend reconciliation with Israel.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — In death as in life, Shimon Peres will bring together longtime adversaries. But no one expects reconciliation when Israeli and Palestinian leaders both attend his funeral on Friday.

headline: Salesforce Is Said to Question Microsoft-LinkedIn Deal in Europe
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']
abstract: Salesforce, a San Francisco tech company, is said to have questioned whether Microsoft’s takeover of LinkedIn might hinder consumer choice and access to data.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft outmuscled its rival Salesforce.com this year to buy LinkedIn, the professional social network, for $26.2 billion.

headline: Which Debate Clips Got Replayed the Most on CNN, Fox News and MSNBC
abstract: In the 24 hours after the candidates’ first confrontation, the three networks replayed several of the pivotal moments, often highlighting different clips.
lead_paragraph: In the 24 hours after the candidates’ first confrontation, the three networks replayed several of the pivotal moments, often highlighting different clips.

headline: Google Searches for Voter Registration Have Surged in Hispanic Areas
abstract: Google trends data shows an interesting pattern in registration in the last week, and a former beauty queen could have something to do with it.
lead_paragraph: In the real world, demographic change is gradual: Every day, the country becomes a tad more diverse as babies are born, people immigrate, and others die.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Throwback Sportswear
abstract: Versace, Koché and Maison Margiela showed retro looks that recalled the athletic trends of the ’70s and ’90s.
lead_paragraph: Throughout the latter half of fashion month, designers have pulled out retro-inspired sportswear. First, in Milan, variations on old-school tracksuits (like this chevron-striped, half-zip sweater) came down the runway at Versace’s show, which celebrated athleticism. On the first day of Paris, the up-and-coming designer Christelle Kocher showed a ’90s-inspired windbreaker at her Koché show. And at Maison Margiela, John Galliano put his own spin on the trend with a navy and neon-yellow windbreaker paired with a matching skirt, labeled “Tortuga.”

headline: Good, Bad and Mad: Andrew Rosenthal on the News
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Debates (Political)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Bombs and Explosives']

headline: You’ll Find Me in My Hammock, Inside
abstract: The Venezuelans taught me that hammocks are useful indoors as well as outdoors. When it’s cold outside, bring it in.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Saturday afternoon, a bit overtaxed from the morning’s pancake making and the previous evening’s socializing, I flopped into my hammock. To and fro I swayed, as if pushed by a beachy breeze.

lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Ammon and Ryan Bundy, who led an armed occupation to protest federal control of Western lands — much of which was captured on video and streamed online — began their defense in court this week.

headline: Keep the Tax Returns, Trump; Just Give Us a Few Figures
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Income Tax', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mr. Trump’s adjusted gross income and actual federal taxes paid for the past five years are numbers that any taxpayer can understand.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Trump, I have a deal for you.

headline: The Sweet Emotional Life of Bees
abstract: New experiments suggest that bees given treats may experience a positive, or optimistic, state of being.
lead_paragraph: It is hard enough to figure out emotions in humans — but insects?

headline: A New Chapter in Book Prizes: Readers Are the Winners
abstract: Heywood Hill, a bookstore in London, will award a book a month for life to the winner of a contest in honor of its 80th birthday.
lead_paragraph: The rules of the competition are simple. Pick a book that means a great deal to you — more than any other book you’ve read (a caveat: It must have been published for the first time in English within the last 80 years, so no Austen, no Lampedusa, no “Sir Gawain and the Green Knight”). Submit its name to the London bookstore Heywood Hill, which is celebrating its 80th birthday this year, sometime before midnight Oct. 31.

headline: Chaos at Hoboken Station After Train ‘Flew Through the Air’
abstract: Commuters said nothing seemed out of the ordinary as they approached the Hoboken train station. Then they were thrown from their feet and plunged into darkness.
lead_paragraph: HOBOKEN, N.J. — New Jersey Transit train No. 1614 just did not stop.

headline: Eerie Historical Parallels?
abstract: A reader found a review of a book on Hitler alarming because of similarities to today.

headline: What Wells Fargo’s C.E.O. Told Congress
abstract: Nine days ago, the leader of Wells Fargo faced a skeptical Senate committee for more than two hours. Today, he was denounced for more than four hours at a House panel.

lead_paragraph: Download the NYT VR app and allow yourself to be transported to some of California's most spectacular vistas and take a moment to meditate on the tranquil sights and sounds of nature.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading by the editors of The New York Times Book Review.
lead_paragraph: Every week, editors at the Book Review pick our favorites of the books reviewed in the previous issue and call them “Editors’ Choice.” It’s our chance to heap extra praise on books that got stellar reviews and to give books that didn’t get a great review an endorsement of our own. One book that famously got a negative review — “All the Light We Cannot See,” by Anthony Doerr — went on to be an Editors’ Choice, a massive best seller (125 weeks on the hardcover fiction list and counting) and one of our 10 Best Books of 2014.

headline: Canada Stuns Europe in Final Minutes to Sweep World Cup
abstract: Sidney Crosby’s assist propelled Canada to victory in Game 2 of the World Cup of Hockey finals. Crosby led the tournament in scoring and was selected as the most valuable player.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — The problem with being Sidney Crosby is that he can never be ordinary. Others will not let him, and he will not stand for it.

headline: Mary Weber Novak, Top California Vintner, Dies at 84
abstract: Ms. Novak took over Spottswoode, her family’s vineyard, and turned it into a top producer of cabernet sauvignon and sauvignon blanc.
lead_paragraph: Mary Weber Novak, who took over Spottswoode, her family’s Napa Valley vineyard, after her husband’s death and turned it into one of California’s top producers of cabernet sauvignon and sauvignon blanc, died on Sunday in St. Helena, Calif. She was 84.

headline: Grappling With a Teenager’s Accidental Pregnancy
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Parenting', 'Parties (Social)', 'Elections', 'Families and Family Life', 'Marriages']
abstract: Also, when a potluck burdens a guest and staying mum about politics. And more.
lead_paragraph: My 18-year-old daughter will soon give birth, a month after she was to begin college on an academic scholarship. The pregnancy was accidental. The boy, who was in recovery, has relapsed into drug use and is not seeing her. (He is in treatment.) But his parents, whom I have never met, have been very kind to her and want to be active grandparents. We will probably meet them at the hospital. This will be awkward, and I worry that their involvement will bring their unstable son back into our orbit. How should I handle this?

headline: In ‘By the People,’ Designing for the Underserved and Overlooked
abstract: In this exhibition at the Cooper Hewitt, everyday citizens cook up solutions to what ails their own communities.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, while Chattanooga, Tenn., made headlines for revitalizing its downtown, residents, mostly African-Americans, living just a few miles away in the Glass Farms neighborhood, were struggling to cope with years of disinvestment and decline. Storefronts were empty, buildings abandoned. Crime was through the roof.

headline: ‘Transparent’ Season 3: Watched It All? Let’s Talk
abstract: Season 3, if a bit slow in terms of character, was the show’s most stylistically innovative to date. It also tackled some exceptionally weighty themes.
lead_paragraph: Now that we’ve watched the third season of “Transparent” — and sobbed over Shelly’s cabaret rendition of Alanis Morissette’s “Hand in My Pocket” from the finale — it’s time to take stock of yet another season of the Pfeffermans’ ceaseless navel-gazing.

headline: Nineties Supermodels, Paired With Satire
abstract: A new exhibition and book combine Miles Ladin’s starry black-and-white photos of Kate Moss, Naomi Campbell and more with tongue-in-cheek excerpts from Bret Easton Ellis’s “Glamorama.”
lead_paragraph: A new exhibition and book combine Miles Ladin’s starry black-and-white photos of Kate Moss, Naomi Campbell and more with tongue-in-cheek excerpts from Bret Easton Ellis’s “Glamorama.”

headline: Rick Owens: Spring 2017
abstract: Mr. Owens, who recently opened an outpost in New York City, presents his spring looks.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Owens, who recently opened an outpost in New York City, presents his spring looks.

headline: Isabel Marant: Spring 2017
abstract: The label’s spring 2017 collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 collection.

headline: Review: ‘Passage to Mars,’ an Otherworldly Voyage on Earth
abstract: Scientists train for Mars exploration during a long mission in the unyielding cold of the Arctic, testing equipment that may one day be used in space.
lead_paragraph: Take “Ice Road Truckers,” mix it with “The Martian” and blend in a book of verse, and you’ve got something that resembles “Passage to Mars,” a beguiling documentary that’s concerned as much with images as it is with information.

headline: How to Get Home After the Hoboken Train Crash
abstract: With no train, light-rail, bus or ferry service into or out of Hoboken Terminal, here are alternative ways to get home during this evening’s commute.
lead_paragraph: Thursday morning’s fatal train crash at the Hoboken Terminal in New Jersey, a hub used by nearly 60,000 people a day, crippled mass transit in the area and is likely to snarl the evening commute.

headline: Building Zaha Hadid’s Bold Afterlife
abstract: Ms. Hadid’s posthumous architectural career promises to deliver nearly 50 more structures, as many as were created in her lifetime.
lead_paragraph: ANTWERP, BELGIUM — For architects, or at least for Zaha Hadid, there is an afterlife. On Sept. 22, nearly six months after this British architect’s sudden death at 65, one of her boldest buildings, Port House, opened in a ceremony on the newly christened Zaha Hadid Square in Antwerp. Under the soaring prow of a dynamically angled glass-and-steel structure drifting like an airship over a palatial brick firehouse, a chorus and orchestra performed the “Ode to Joy” from Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony.  The score and backdrop amounted to a curtain rising on the second act of Ms. Hadid’s career, as operatic as any since Frank Lloyd Wright’s.

headline: ‘Beethoven’s Wig’ Combines Classical Music With Seussian Whimsy
abstract: Richard Perlmutter created this multimedia show, which adds lyrics and animation to canonical works. He’ll present it Saturday at the N.Y.U. Skirball Center.
lead_paragraph: Instrumental music tends not to charm children, unless an ice cream truck is playing the tune. And a classical piece like Beethoven’s Fifth Symphony? Not a good bet.

headline: Wells Fargo’s Reaction to Scandal Fails to Satisfy Angry Lawmakers
abstract: John Stumpf, the bank’s leader, told lawmakers the sham accounts were an ethical lapse limited to the 5,300 low-level employees, who were fired.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He is forfeiting at least $41 million in pay. He vows that his bank will drop its sales incentive program — blamed for prompting bankers to set up illegal and unauthorized bank and credit card accounts to meet their sales goals — by the end of the week, not in January, as he had previously promised.

headline: The Secrets Behind Sargent’s Intimate Portrait of a Jewish Family
abstract: “John Singer Sargent’s Mrs. Carl Meyer and Her Children,” at the Jewish Museum, reveals the British philanthropists Carl and Adèle Meyer, but one painting is the star.
lead_paragraph: “I have not recovered from the joy of Shortgrove being ours and we enrolled among the ‘landed gentry’ of England,” the British society figure and philanthropist Adèle Meyer wrote to her son, Frank, in 1903.

headline: Review: ‘Never Surrender: The Ed Ramsey Story,’ an Overdue Paean to a War Hero
abstract: A documentary honors Mr. Ramsey, an Army officer in the Philippines when it fell to the Japanese in World War II, and later a wartime underground leader.
lead_paragraph: “Never Surrender: The Ed Ramsey Story” introduces one of the hundreds — if not thousands — of inspiring military heroes from World War II whose valor and courage have rarely gotten wide notice and appropriate appreciation.

headline: Och-Ziff to Pay Over $400 Million in Bribery Settlement
keywords: ['Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Hedge Funds', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Deferred Prosecution Agreements']
abstract: OZ Africa Management, a unit of the hedge fund, pleaded guilty to bribing officials in Libya, Chad, Niger, Guinea and the Democratic Republic of Congo.
lead_paragraph: Africa once represented a lucrative new market for a giant New York hedge fund.

headline: American Airstrike Killed Afghan Civilians, U.N. Says
abstract: An American spokesman said the military was investigating reports of civilian casualties in the strike in the Islamic State stronghold of Achin district, in Nangarhar Province.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The United Nations mission in Afghanistan on Thursday condemned an American airstrike it said had killed at least 15 civilians in eastern Afghanistan, a day after American and Afghan officials said they had targeted a gathering of Islamic State affiliates.

headline: ‘Luke Cage’ Puts Race at the Center of the Story
abstract: The neighborhood is a vivid presence in this new Netflix series, which stars Mike Colter as a literally bulletproof threat to a crime boss.
lead_paragraph: In the connected series of movies and television shows known as the Marvel Cinematic Universe, which occupies an inordinate amount of territory in our popular culture, there’s a quiet corner that belongs to Netflix. The Netflix-Marvel series, focusing on a mostly second-tier group of heroes — so far Daredevil, Jessica Jones and, beginning on Friday, Luke Cage — have been a laboratory in turning comic books into live-action TV without the noisy battles and tag-team group heroics of Marvel mainstays like the Avengers, X-Men and Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.

headline: Harvest Lunch to Celebrate Hudson Valley
abstract: Terrance Brennan will cook at “Celebrate Our Love of the Hudson Valley” ahead of his new restaurant opening.
lead_paragraph: Glasses will be raised next month in the Hudson Valley to toast the harvest, a chef and an anniversary. On Oct. 8, the chef Terrance Brennan will prepare a three-course lunch as part of “Celebrate Our Love of the Hudson Valley,” an event to benefit the FarmOn! Foundation, which supports educational programs and local family farms. The meal will include local cheeses and charcuterie, pumpkin bisque, chicken grilled over wine vines and an array of apple desserts. The wine pairing will feature vintages from Clinton Vineyards, which is hosting the event and celebrating its 40th anniversary.

headline: Chains, Whips and Misery: Studying and Preserving Old ‘Lunatic’ Asylums
keywords: ['Art', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists', 'ANTIQUES', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: Several exhibitions and books, including “Bedlam: The Asylum and Beyond” at the Wellcome Collection in London, document the terrors experienced by patients.
lead_paragraph: Mental hospitals have an unsettling history, which is the subject of many museum exhibitions and books this fall. The scholarship illuminates how for centuries reformers tried to prevent cruel treatment of the mentally ill and worked to develop architecture that would provide comfort while keeping patients away from the public. Historians and preservationists are trying to save the isolated buildings that resulted from these efforts and are poring over sometimes-forgotten archives.

headline: Review: ‘Masterminds,’ a Tale of Grand Larceny and Meager Gray Matter
abstract: This comedy from Jared Hess stars Zach Galifianakis as a real-life felon who tried to steal millions of dollars in 1997.
lead_paragraph: “I blame popular culture,” Zach Galifianakis says at the start of this comedy, the ridiculousness of his Southern accent rivaling that of his very fluffy hairstyle. His character, David Ghantt — a real-life felon who took part in an ostentatious crime in the late 1990s — is rationalizing his own miscreant deeds for the audience of “Masterminds,” a would-be memorable piece of popular culture that applies the TV-sketch-show-surreal-farce approach to a based-on-true-events caper picture.

headline: Review: ‘The Rolling Stones Olé, Olé, Olé!’ Captures Tour Euphoria in Latin America
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Music']
abstract: The documentary follows the Stones to eight countries, including Cuba, recalling when rock truly mattered as a force for change.
lead_paragraph: Early in “The Rolling Stones Olé, Olé, Olé!,” Mick Jagger notes that several Latin American nations in the 1960s and ’70s censored rock music. “The Rolling Stones, being part of this rebellious movement,” he adds, “was anathema to a lot of these regimes.”

headline: A Bold New Landing for Modern Art at the National Gallery
abstract: A show at the museum that traces the arc of Virginia Dwan’s career coincides with the reopening of its East Building and the reinstallation of its modern art holdings.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Supposedly, we live in a great age of collecting, though the greatness is strictly in volume. Art fairs and auction houses keep product coming: painting, sculpture, some photography, stuff you can stick a price tag on. It seems impossible that there were times when unknown artists could make untaggable art and survive.

headline: Slouching Toward Accountability at Wells Fargo
abstract: Clawbacks of executive pay are an important step, but they won’t be enough to deter future wrongdoing.
lead_paragraph: In testimony on Thursday before the House Financial Services committee, John Stumpf, chairman and chief executive of Wells Fargo, largely stuck to the script from a week before, when he appeared before the Senate Banking committee to answer questions about phony customer accounts at the bank. But in one way, he was a changed man: He was less wealthy by tens of millions of dollars.

headline: Julie Mehretu on Her Influences, Auction Pressure and New Paintings
abstract: Gone are the traces of architectural drawings and the slashes of color. Ms. Mehretu called her works at Marian Goodman Gallery show a radical departure.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, the paintings on the walls may not look all that different from what Julie Mehretu has done before. There are the marks, the layering, the allusions to current events.

headline: Review: In ‘Amanda Knox,’ a Murder and Journalism Run Amok
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Movies']
abstract: This documentary about the case of an exchange student killed in Italy focuses less on an accused killer and more on unprincipled journalism and unapologetic sexism.
lead_paragraph: You don’t have to remember the gutter headlines inspired by its namesake to find the true-crime documentary “Amanda Knox” completely riveting. And not because of the lip-smacking speculations surrounding Ms. Knox’s eight-year battle with the Italian legal system after being charged with the 2007 murder of a housemate and fellow exchange student, Meredith Kercher. Rather, the directors, Brian McGinn and Rod Blackhurst, have produced a tightly edited, coherently structured and ultimately moving reassessment that burrows beneath the lurid in search of the illuminating.

headline: Review: ‘Songs of Lear,’ We Hear Cordelia Singing
abstract: Song of the Goat Theater from Poland presents an impressionistic and sung version of “King Lear” at BAM.
lead_paragraph: The “King Lear” evoked in “Songs of Lear” shares so little with Shakespeare’s tragedy that the show’s director, Grzegorz Bral, delivers an explanatory introduction onstage. This is doubly helpful because “Songs of Lear” also shares little with traditional, linear storytelling, and large parts of it are in untranslated Latin and Polish — in other words, it’s hard to tell what’s going on. While you don’t need to know “King Lear” to appreciate the show, it certainly helps.

headline: Video of Fatal Police Shooting of Louisiana Boy, 6, Is Released
abstract: The boy was a passenger in his father’s car when he was killed in 2015, and two deputy marshals will be tried on charges of second-degree murder in a case that raises questions about police tactics.
lead_paragraph: The police video footage of the last moments of 6-year-old Jeremy Mardis’s life shows deputy marshals firing a barrage of bullets at his father’s S.U.V. after a car chase on the dark streets of central Louisiana. It shows his father slumped over the open car window, injured and bleeding.

headline: Dance Listings for Sept. 30-Oct. 6
abstract: A selected guide to dance performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to dance performances in New York City.

headline: Bartolo Colon’s Secret: It’s the Wrist, Not the Waist
abstract: At age 43 and 285 pounds, the Mets pitcher thrives with one pitch by making it move three ways.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The best vantage point from which to truly appreciate how Bartolo Colon pitches is behind home plate. Focus on the ball, as a batter would, even though it temporarily disappears behind Colon’s head as he prepares to throw.

headline: Theater Listings for Sept. 30-Oct. 6
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: ‘She Bested the Bully’: Readers on Gender and the Debate
abstract: Many readers saw their own experiences of sexism reflected as Donald Trump repeatedly interrupted Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: As women watched the presidential debate earlier this week, many saw their own experiences of everyday sexism reflected as Donald Trump repeatedly interrupted Hillary Clinton.

headline: Review: In ‘A Man Called Ove,’ Don’t Let That Scowl Fool You
abstract: Adapted from a best-selling Swedish novel, this film stars Rolf Lassgard as a gruff, unemployed railroad worker who befriends immigrants who are his new neighbors.
lead_paragraph: Sweden’s official entry for a best foreign-language film at the Academy Awards proves that Swedish pictures can be just as sentimental and conventionally heartwarming as Hollywood ones. Granted, few Hollywood films would deign to tell the story of a protagonist’s life through a series of flashbacks brought on by unsuccessful suicide attempts. But still.

headline: New York Tonight: Hoboken Train Crash and Wet Weather
abstract: What you need to know about the New Jersey Transit crash, how to get home and back to work, and the weather.
lead_paragraph: Good evening on this rain-riddled Thursday.

headline: Review: The Animated ‘Long Way North’ Finds a Girl on a Journey
abstract: The movie follows 14-year-old Sacha in the late 1800s as she goes off in search of her lost grandfather.
lead_paragraph: The story isn’t flashy and neither is the animation in “Long Way North,” qualities that give the film a certain low-key charm in an age of fast-moving sagas eye-poppingly served. This tale, which in its theatrical release is being shown in both English- and French-language versions, has a young heroine, but you won’t mistake it for “Frozen.”

headline: Review: ‘Crisis in Six Scenes,’ a Mere Ghost of Woody Allen Past
abstract: Mr. Allen’s first TV show, a six-episode mini-series on Amazon, feels as if he emptied his notebook and strung together a series of comic set pieces.
lead_paragraph: We’re in the midst of a revolution in American television comedy, and one important source for the dark humor and cinematic style of shows like “Louie” and “Transparent” is undoubtedly the films of Woody Allen. It’s especially disappointing, then, that “Crisis in Six Scenes,” Mr. Allen’s first TV show, feels instantly forgettable.

headline: 400-Pound Hacker? Trump Comments Fuel Dialogue on Fat-Shaming
abstract: A remark during the presidential debate has fueled a national conversation in a country where two-thirds of the population is overweight.
lead_paragraph: It was a casual remark tossed off by Donald J. Trump that jolted Johanna Kandel from her seat during the recent presidential debate.

headline: Angered by 9/11 Victims Law, Saudis Rethink U.S. Alliance
keywords: ['September 11 (2001)', 'Terrorism', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Many Saudis see the passage of the Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act, overriding President Obama’s veto, as irreparable damage to a long relationship.
lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — Throughout President Obama’s time in the White House, Saudi Arabia and its allies in the Persian Gulf have watched with dismay as the kingdom’s decades-old alliance with the United States seemed to be slipping.

headline: Off/White: Spring 2017
abstract: Virgil Abloh shows his spring looks.
lead_paragraph: Virgil Abloh shows his spring looks.

headline: Maria Semple’s ‘Today Will Be Different’ Serves Up Screwball With Soul
abstract: Ms. Semple’s follow-up to “Where’d You Go, Bernadette” can be as outrageously funny, but this book cuts closer to the bone with less satire.
lead_paragraph: Maria Semple’s “Where’d You Go, Bernadette” was the kind of instant classic that earns its author a loyal readership in perpetuity. For anyone who needs reminding, it was a novel that skewered all things Seattle; used an epistolary format to riotous advantage; took a huge whack at Microsoft’s corporate culture; made terrific fun of the Mom Wars at an especially ridiculous grade school; and guaranteed that you, the reader, would never look at a blackberry bush in quite the same way.

headline: Review: ‘Harry & Snowman’ Recalls a Man and a Horse of Powerful Haunches
abstract: Ron Davis’s documentary is about Snowman, a white gelding and championship show jumper in his time, and Harry deLeyer, who raised him.
lead_paragraph: The Snowman of Ron Davis’s documentary “Harry & Snowman” is a horse that melts the heart. Purchased in the 1950s for $80 off a truck bound for the slaughterhouse, Snowman became a champion show jumper. And that was only one surprise in the long friendship that began when this scruffy white gelding locked eyes with Harry deLeyer, who raised horses and taught riding at a girls’ school in Long Island.

headline: Microsoft Reorganizes Its Research Efforts Around A.I.
abstract: The company will combine its vaunted research group with the unit focused on products that use artificial intelligence, like Bing and Cortana.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Microsoft said on Thursday that it was reorganizing part of the company to better position itself as one of the significant players in the emerging field of artificial intelligence.

headline: Review: ‘Do Not Resist,’ or When a Police Force Becomes an Army
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Police', 'Movies']
abstract: More details on the scope and scale of the militarization of American police forces would help bolster this documentary.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy to fault the one-sidedness of “Do Not Resist,” Craig Atkinson’s documentary about the militarization of the police in the United States, but that’s missing the point. Sure, plenty of local police officers — a majority, even — have more in common with Andy Taylor (Andy Griffith), the genial television sheriff of the 1960s than they do with a storm trooper. But this unsettling film is about the planting and nurturing of a mind-set, one grounded in hostility and fear.

headline: Review: In ‘Tomorrow’s Parties,’ Visions of the Planet’s Future
abstract: A woman and a man conjure ever-morphing, wildly different ideas in this show from Forced Entertainment, part of the Crossing the Line Festival.
lead_paragraph: It was a deep-sleep snore with a snort at the end. Rising out of the darkened auditorium at Florence Gould Hall on Wednesday night, near the end of “Tomorrow’s Parties” by the British company Forced Entertainment, the sound was too loud to ignore. An infectious case of the giggles rippled through the audience, and kept rippling.

headline: Trade Ban to Protect Pangolins: Enough to Save Them?
abstract: An international agreement now prohibits the commercial sale across international borders of the world’s most trafficked mammals. Enforcement is another matter.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — Representatives from more than 100 countries have agreed to ban worldwide trade in pangolins, which are now threatened with extinction because of illegal trafficking in Asia and Africa.

headline: At the New York Film Festival, a Defense of Human Dignity
abstract: This year’s lineup, in films like “13th,” “I, Daniel Blake” and “Toni Erdmann,” largely focuses on fights for recognition and self-determination.
lead_paragraph: The second most memorable scene in “Toni Erdmann” — which is to say one of the two or three most remarkable moments you will encounter on a movie screen this year — consists of an impromptu amateur performance of “The Greatest Love of All.” I hesitate to say anything about who sings that notorious anthem to self-reliance or under what circumstances, but I will note that one line stands out, capturing with an impossible blend of excruciating irony and disarming sincerity one of the movie’s great themes: “No matter what they take from me, they can’t take away my dignity.”

headline: Qualcomm Is Said to Be in Talks to Buy NXP Semiconductors
abstract: A merger of the two companies would be the latest consolidation in the chip-making industry and could be valued at over $30 billion.
lead_paragraph: Qualcomm is in discussions to buy NXP Semiconductors in what would be another act of consolidation in the chip-making industry, a person briefed on the matter said on Thursday.

headline: Review: ‘Danny Says,’ a Paean to a Rock Gadfly and Tastemaker
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Movies']
abstract: Brendan Toller’s documentary about the music manager and journalist Danny Fields aims to reacquaint viewers with his influence, including the rise of punk.
lead_paragraph: To hear it from the new documentary “Danny Says,” Danny Fields had a hand in the breakup of the Beatles and the discovery of the Ramones. He palled around with the photographer Linda Eastman (a.k.a. Linda McCartney). He tried playing matchmaker for Jim Morrison and Nico, an introduction that resulted in a strange stare-down. He signed MC5 and the Stooges to Elektra in one swoop. He tripped on acid on the floor of Leonard Cohen and Judy Collins’s hotel room.

headline: Review: In ‘Among the Believers,’ a Cleric Holds Sway
abstract: This documentary takes the viewer inside the Islamic schools in Pakistan run by the fiery Abdul Aziz.
lead_paragraph: “Once we train their minds, they’ll never change until they die,” the dean of the Red Mosque madrasa says casually and, for the viewer, chillingly, in “Among the Believers.”

lead_paragraph: A critical guide to exhibitions and installations in the New York area.

abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Deepwater Horizon,” “”American Honey” and “Denial.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Deepwater Horizon,” “”American Honey” and “Denial.”

headline: Donald Trump Proves Perversely Good for The Peso
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Debates (Political)', 'Elections', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'US Dollar (Currency)']
abstract: The currency turns out to be inversely tied to the fortunes of the Republican nominee.
lead_paragraph: Tired of tracking the presidential election through the soporific data analyses of political pundits? Try the Mexican peso instead. The currency turns out to be inversely tied to the fortunes of Donald Trump as he makes a daily punching bag of Mexico in his campaign. Experts who saw the peso reach an all-time low against the dollar just before the presidential debate Monday reported that it rose immediately after the debate, going up 2.3 percent in tandem with opinion polls in which viewers pronounced Mr. Trump the loser.

lead_paragraph: Last week’s top events included opening night of the Metropolitan Opera, Mehregan at Untermyer Park and the New-York Historical Society’s gala.

headline: Review: In ‘Denial,’ Confronting a Holocaust Revisionist in Court
abstract: The libel trial of a historian, brought by a Holocaust denier, is dramatized in this sober and methodical film. But the movie lacks an emotional flash point.
lead_paragraph: No courtroom fireworks detonate in “Denial,” a sober, methodical recounting of a 1996 libel suit brought by David Irving, a discredited British historian, against Deborah E. Lipstadt, author of the 1993 book “Denying the Holocaust: The Growing Assault on Truth and Memory.”

headline: Hoboken, Wells Fargo, F.C.C.: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Review: In ‘Girl Asleep,’ Floating Through a Teenage Fantasia
abstract: Rosemary Myers’s hybrid of film and children’s theater follows Greta, a young wallflower whose social woes turn surreal when she runs into the woods behind her home.
lead_paragraph: How might it feel to be a shy 14-year-old wallflower going to a new school in an Australian suburb in the late 1970s? Rosemary Myers’s charming offbeat fantasia, “Girl Asleep,” offers a giddy approximation. Much of this uncategorizable hybrid of a movie and children’s theater piece is played out on an elaborate stage set.

headline: Comedy Listings for Sept. 30-Oct. 6
abstract: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.

headline: Ex-A.I.G. Chief Parries Inquiries on Offshore Reinsurer in Fraud Trial
abstract: The state contends Capco was a sham used to convert into investment losses $163 million in auto insurance losses, duping investors.
lead_paragraph: Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of American International Group, told the judge presiding over his civil accounting fraud trial on Thursday that the motive for one key transaction was to help certain A.I.G. employees get continuing losses “off their back” in a competitive corporate culture.

headline: Fall Brings Operas, Harvest Festivals and a Bounty of Galas
abstract: Last week’s top events included opening night of the Metropolitan Opera, Mehregan at Untermyer Park and the New-York Historical Society’s gala.
lead_paragraph: In a high point of the fall social calendar, the Metropolitan Opera held its opening night gala Sept. 26, with a production of Wagner’s “Tristan und Isolde.” In Yonkers, the Untermyer Gardens Conservancy celebrated Mehregan, the ancient Persian harvest festival. And the New-York Historical Society honored the filmmakers Ken Burns and Ric Burns at Cipriani 42nd Street.

headline: Drawings? Maybe, but Certainly the Art of Frustration
abstract: The works of Jean Dubuffet at the Morgan Library & Museum are billed as drawings, but defy definition.
lead_paragraph: When you’re hot you’re hot — and Jean Dubuffet is ablaze. “Dubuffet Drawings, 1935–1962,” a hefty and insightful exhibition at the Morgan Library & Museum, is the fourth here in less than two years to examine the Frenchman’s rough, unrefined, war-scarred creations, and his advocacy of art from outside the mainstream. The Museum of Modern Art’s excellent “Soul of the Underground” concentrated on the technical processes Dubuffet used for his disquieting prints and impressions. The American Folk Art Museum last fall presented 200 works from Dubuffet’s own collection of Art Brut — objects made by untrained or nonprofessional artists. Earlier this year, a significant show at Acquavella Galleries on the Upper East Side covered about the same period as this one: from the hardships of World War II to the booming first years of France’s Fifth Republic.

headline: The Ways Clinton or Trump Can Win the Election
abstract: Explore the paths to victory available for the presidential candidates.
lead_paragraph: Explore the paths to victory available for the presidential candidates.

headline: With Glut of Vice Captains at the Ryder Cup, Will Tiger Woods Fetch Lunch?
abstract: As the Ryder Cup expands, so do its rosters, with this year’s vice captain count at 10.
lead_paragraph: CHASKA, Minn. — Golf might be losing market share and the millennials, but the Ryder Cup keeps expanding: more sponsor pavilions, more merchandise, more venues on the European continent (Paris and Rome are next).

headline: World’s Fair, and Queens, in the Meadows Festival Spotlight
abstract: This hip-hop collective, which will be on a bill that includes Kanye West and Chance the Rapper, discusses its roots ahead of this weekend’s event.
lead_paragraph: The Bronx is known as the birthplace of hip-hop and Brooklyn nurtured the indie-rock explosion of the early 2000s, but Queens has also produced enough influential artists to build its own rock ’n’ roll hall of fame: Musicians who grew up there range from Simon and Garfunkel to the Ramones, Nicki Minaj to Nas, Cyndi Lauper to Anthrax. But to find a live audience, they often ventured across the river, to Greenwich Village or the Lower East Side.

headline: How the Balmain Show Came Together
abstract: Olivier Rousteing takes T behind the scenes in the 48 hours before his spring/summer 2017 show.
lead_paragraph: Olivier Rousteing takes T behind the scenes in the 48 hours before his spring/summer 2017 show.

headline: Forty-Eight Hours in Paris With Balmain’s Olivier Rousteing
abstract: In the days before his show, the creative director of the iconic French house held about 60 fittings — and got a visit from the Kardashians.
lead_paragraph: Twenty hours before Balmain’s creative director, Olivier Rousteing, was due to present his spring/summer 2017 collection in Paris, the reality television star Kris Jenner crossed paths with the model Isabeli Fontana in the label’s Parisian atelier. The latter was on her way into a fitting, the former — in a black patent trench, bodyguard in tow — was on her way out.

headline: Movie Listings for Sept. 30-Oct. 6
abstract: A guide to movies playing at theaters in the New York City area, as well as select festivals and film series. A complete list of new releases is at nytimes.com/intheaters.
lead_paragraph: A guide to movies playing at theaters in the New York City area, as well as select festivals and film series. A complete list of new releases is at nytimes.com/intheaters.

headline: Review: In ‘Miss Peregrine’s Home,’ Chasing Grandpa’s Stories Down a Rabbit Hole
abstract: Tim Burton’s adaptation of the novel by Ransom Riggs describes the adventures of an adolescent who travels through time to prove his grandfather right.
lead_paragraph: The movies have long made room for phantasmagoric visionaries, the strange ones, the different ones, who like to peek under rocks (or peel back the skin) to peer at what squirms beneath. Fitting their deliriums into bright, shiny, commercially palatable vehicles can be difficult, as Tim Burton’s career attests. Time and again, Mr. Burton has tried to smooth down his singular art, rather like one of Cinderella’s stepsisters sawing off a bit of her foot to squeeze into a happily-ever-after slipper. Mr. Burton should never hack off his strange bits; they can be glorious.

headline: How Do You Make Turbo Engines More Efficient? Just Add Water
abstract: Water injection technology is well-known, but has not caught on in consumer autos. Bosch is betting that environmental regulations will help it go mainstream.
lead_paragraph: FOR decades, automakers have relied on turbocharging, which uses energy captured from exhaust gases to force additional air into the cylinders, to increase the power and efficiency of some gasoline engines.

headline: Offshore Wind Farms See Promise in Platforms That Float
abstract: Engineers look to floating platforms to enable wind turbines to move into deeper waters farther from the coast.
lead_paragraph: ORONO, Me. — The sun was beating down on the leafy campus of the University of Maine one afternoon last month. But inside a hangarlike laboratory, a miniature hurricane was raging.

headline: Talking Across Divides: 10 Ways to Encourage Civil Classroom Conversation On Difficult Issues
abstract: Ideas for fostering respectful and productive discussions, both online and off.
lead_paragraph: So begins an article from June 2016, which described a problem that has only deepened as the weeks of this unprecedented, vitriolic presidential campaign have gone on.

abstract: A select guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: A select guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families.

headline: Clemson Quarterback Deshaun Watson Stays Cool While Taking the Heat
abstract: How Watson leads the No. 5 Tigers (4-0) will be significant when Clemson meets No. 3 Louisville (4-0) in an Atlantic Coast Conference showdown Saturday.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — In early September, two days after No. 5 Clemson squeezed past Troy in a surprisingly close nonconference game, Tigers quarterback Deshaun Watson apologized for displaying what he described as “negative energy” in the 30-24 victory. A spotlight is always placed on a star player when a team with immense expectations appears to sag, it seems, and when Clemson did not obliterate Troy, Watson offered up himself as a sacrifice.

headline: U.S. Paid Insurers Funds Meant for Treasury, Auditors Say
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Federal auditors ruled that the Obama administration had violated the law by paying insurers more than allowed under the Affordable Care Act in an effort to hold down insurance premiums.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal auditors ruled on Thursday that the Obama administration had violated the law by paying health insurance companies more than allowed under the Affordable Care Act in an effort to hold down insurance premiums.

headline: Progress? Depends on Which Party Is Doing the Talking
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: Averting a government shutdown with two days to go is not ordinarily something to be proud of, but this is Congress, where partisanship is upheld above all else.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — To be fair, Congress averted a government shutdown a full two days before the lights were set to go out. So by contemporary standards, they are making great progress. There will be money to combat the Zika virus — seven months after President Obama asked for it and following a predictable fight over Planned Parenthood — and a promise of money to fix the water systems in Flint, Mich., at some point, probably.

headline: Concern Over Deutsche Bank’s Health Shakes Markets
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Hedge Funds', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The German bank’s shares in the United States tumbled 6.7 percent for the day, after falling as much as 9 percent, in unusually heavy trading.
lead_paragraph: Stock markets were rattled on Thursday after reports emerged that some clients of Deutsche Bank, the struggling German lender, were reducing their exposure.

headline: A Very Fair Exchange
abstract: A woman needing a watchband fixed has just what she needs to persuade the repairman to get to work.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: An $8 Million Arena Sculpture to Usher In Civilization 3.0
abstract: Jeff Koons’s “Coloring Book” sculpture outside the home of the Sacramento Kings is the latest example of the art world becoming a player in the sports world.
lead_paragraph: Art installations have long been a requirement for developers who want to show off their panache and good taste.

headline: C.D.C. Advises Against Travel to Zika-Affected Countries in Southeast Asia
keywords: ['Zika Virus', 'Women and Girls', 'Birth Defects', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: The warning from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention cited 11 countries and was not as urgent as those issued earlier this year regarding Latin America and the Caribbean.
lead_paragraph: Federal health officials on Thursday advised pregnant women to “consider postponing nonessential” travel to 11 countries in Southeast Asia where the Zika virus was circulating.

headline: Leaderless and Underfunded, N.J. Transit Had Troubles Well Before Fatal Crash
abstract: The agency has been operating without an executive director for nearly a year and has not explained how it will close a $45 million gap in its budget.
lead_paragraph: Even before one of its trains crashed in Hoboken Terminal on Thursday morning, killing one woman and injuring more than 100 others, New Jersey Transit was an agency in distress.

headline: Credibility of Chris Christie’s ‘Enforcer’ Challenged During Bridge Scandal Trial
abstract: David Wildstein, a former ally of the New Jersey governor, denied accusations by a defense lawyer that he had embellished his accounts of the George Washington Bridge lane closings.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — A defense lawyer tried to undermine the credibility of the confessed culprit in the George Washington Bridge lane closings in federal court on Thursday, suggesting that he was a serial schemer and braggart who had hoped to take credit for the scheme — but now, as the star witness for the prosecution, could not keep his story straight.

headline: After Acquittal in Boy’s Killing, Potsdam Sighs With Relief and Resignation
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: After the prosecution presented an overwhelmingly circumstantial case, a judge cleared Oral Nicholas Hillary of second-degree murder charges in the death of a 12-year-old boy.
lead_paragraph: POTSDAM, N.Y. — In front of the building at 100 Market Street, where a 12-year-old boy, Garrett Phillips, was murdered nearly five years ago, a small sign, one of hundreds that once dotted the area, had called for “Justice for Garrett.”

headline: In Hacked Audio, Hillary Clinton Rethinks Obama’s Nuclear Upgrade Plan
keywords: ['Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The release of a recording of Mrs. Clinton’s comments at a private fund-raiser raised questions about the scope of attacks on the Democratic National Committee and the Clinton campaign.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hillary Clinton expressed doubts about whether the United States should go forward with a trillion-dollar modernization of its nuclear forces at a fund-raiser in February, questioning an Obama administration plan that she has remained largely silent on in public.

headline: Why New Jersey’s Trains Aren’t Safer
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie and other state leaders have neglected and mismanaged the mass transit system.
lead_paragraph: Why did a New Jersey Transit train crash into Hoboken Terminal on Thursday morning, killing at least one person and injuring more than 100 people?

headline: A Wild-Card Spot, and More, Is Within the Mets’ Reach
abstract: Two more wins would assure the Mets a home game to start the playoffs on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The Mets did not play Thursday, allowing them to savor their situation heading into the final weekend of the regular season, a wild-card spot clearly within their grasp.

headline: I.P.O. Values Cloud Company Nutanix at $2.18 Billion
abstract: So far, it is one of only a handful of venture-backed companies to go public this year with a valuation greater than $1 billion.
lead_paragraph: It was one of the few venture-backed start-ups brave enough to file for an initial public offering last year. But Nutanix, which provides cloud-based data storage for businesses, was faced with about nine months of choppy markets that discouraged many private companies from making their stock debuts.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Friday, September 30, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “It all flipped, so fast. Suddenly, we were in the minority. That was kind of a scary feeling. It makes you wonder where the Christians went.”

headline: Ex-Marine Describes Violent Hazing and the Lies That Covered It Up
keywords: ['Hazing', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A top-notch recruit who was expelled from the Marines said his superiors told trainees to lie about punching, kicking and choking by drill instructors.
lead_paragraph: PUTNAM COUNTY, Fla. — In Marine Corps boot camp, Thomas Weaver learned to endure punches, kicks and choking by drill instructors in the Third Recruit Training Battalion at Parris Island, S.C. When one instructor repeatedly bashed his head against a doorway, he kept quiet and acted as if it were no big deal. But what he eventually could not take was the lying that covered up the abuse.

headline: Red Sox Have Bright Hopes as David Ortiz’s Era Comes to an End
abstract: As the Ortiz era draws to a close, the Red Sox are poised for a long run of success after shrewd acquisitions. The Yankees will try to keep up.
lead_paragraph: David Ortiz was the last of the old lions in this rivalry, the final link to the autumn that changed everything. Alex Rodriguez left with a whimper at Fenway Park last month. Ortiz, still roaring, said goodbye to Yankee Stadium on Thursday.

headline: What Is Russia Up To, and Is It Time to Draw the Line?
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense']
abstract: Russian airstrikes in Syria and cyberattacks have echoed some of the Cold War’s uglier moments. American intelligence officials wonder whether a grander scheme is at work.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Escalating airstrikes in Syria. Sophisticated cyberattacks, apparently intended to influence the American election. New evidence of complicity in shooting down a civilian airliner.

headline: Fire Dept. Chief Killed in Bronx Explosion Is Promoted
abstract: Michael J. Fahy, 44, who was directing operations at a house where a gas leak was reported, was promoted from battalion chief to deputy chief.
lead_paragraph: A 44-year-old battalion chief with the New York City Fire Department who was killed by debris after a house exploded in the Bronx this week has been promoted to deputy chief, the mayor and the fire commissioner said on Thursday.

headline: No Stranger to Marital Strife, Rudy Giuliani Wags a Finger at the Clintons
abstract: The former mayor of New York, whose affairs made the front pages, has publicly criticized Hillary Clinton on her response to her husband’s affair.
lead_paragraph: Most people probably can’t identify any senior advisers to presidential candidates, but one member of Donald J. Trump’s brain trust has been skywriting his name across the national news.

headline: Claims of Saudi Role in 9/11 Appear Headed for Manhattan Court
keywords: ['September 11 (2001)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States International Relations', 'Vetoes (US)']
abstract: Families of Sept. 11 victims are now able to pursue legal claims against the Saudis, and the legal battle could last for years.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Saudi Arabia paid millions of dollars to Washington lobbyists to keep it out of court. They have been unsuccessful. And now it is up to the kingdom’s lawyers to limit the damage.

headline: Caregiver Who Abused 4-Year-Old Boy Pleads Guilty to Murder
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Kryzie King, 29, admitted to torturing and killing Myls Dobson in exchange for a sentence of 22 years to life, slightly less than the maximum.
lead_paragraph: The abuse that 4-year-old Myls Dobson suffered — the beatings, burnings and deprivation — lasted for three weeks and ended with his death in January 2014. The prison term his killer faces will be far longer than the life the little boy had.

headline: David Ortiz Exits Yankee Stadium for Final Time With a Walk, a Painting and a Standing Ovation
abstract: The Yankees held a brief pregame ceremony to honor Ortiz, who did as much as any player to even the once-lopsided rivalry between the Red Sox and the Yankees.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees spent a little over two minutes honoring David Ortiz on Thursday, and Ortiz used two inconsequential plate appearances to say goodbye to Yankee Stadium.

headline: A Tribute Dinner for the Chef Gerry Hayden
abstract: The dinner, part of the New York City Wine and Food Festival, will feature food from Charlie Palmer and Mr. Hayden’s widow, Claudia Fleming.
lead_paragraph: Among the events at this year’s New York City Wine and Food Festival, scheduled for Oct. 13 to 16, is a dinner on Oct. 14 to honor Gerry Hayden, a chef who died last year from complications of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or Lou Gehrig’s disease. Charlie Palmer, with whom Mr. Hayden worked for many years, will be the host and will cook along with Michael Mina, David Burke, Bryan Voltaggio and Mr. Hayden’s widow, Claudia Fleming: 7 p.m. Oct. 14, Charlie Palmer at the Knick, Knickerbocker Hotel, 6 Times Square (42nd Street), $300, nycwff.org.

headline: City Officials Are Questioned Over Changes to Nursing Home’s Deed
abstract: After a several-month delay, a hearing tried to get to the heart of why city officials had lifted limits on a nursing home’s use and let it be sold to a developer.
lead_paragraph: The questions came steadily, for six hours, at a City Council hearing on Thursday that tried to get to the heart of why officials had lifted a deed restriction on a nursing home and let it be sold to a luxury condominium developer.

headline: Rezoning Plan for Manhattan Elementary School Draws Anger From All Sides
abstract: New York City is trying to change school zone lines on the Upper West Side, but after countless meetings addressing the proposals, a consensus has not been reached.
lead_paragraph: One man threatened to marshal 1,000 votes against any elected official who dared to disagree with him. A woman who took an opposing stance was warned about making enemies. Another was so distressed she broke down in tears in front of her 4-year-old.

headline: A Show to Indulge in All Things Chocolate
abstract: The Big Chocolate Show satisfies a sweet tooth in Chelsea.
lead_paragraph: It has been four years since a chocolate show has been an autumn attraction in Manhattan. Wizard Studios of Bushwick, Brooklyn, brings its Big Chocolate Show to Terminal Stores in Chelsea on Oct. 8 and 9, with tasting classes, hourly cooking demonstrations and other events included in the admission. Tickets are sold for half-day segments, from 9 a.m. to 1:30 p.m. and from 2:30 to 7 p.m., and reservations for various classes are available with ticket purchase.

headline: Review: ‘La Bohème,’ in All Its Excessive Glory
abstract: This Franco Zeffirelli production of Puccini’s opera, which made its debut in 1981, returned to the Met with a talented and energetic cast.
lead_paragraph: Franco Zeffirelli’s production of Puccini’s “La Bohème” at the Metropolitan Opera undoubtedly had years added to its life in 2012, when Peter Gelb, the Met’s general manager, scrapped the widely beloved Zeffirelli “Tosca” in favor of a new staging by Luc Bondy. Public and critical uproar was immediate and lasting.

headline: American Fan at Ryder Cup Heckles European Players, Then Out-Putts Them
abstract: David Johnson was invited by the professionals onto the course during a practice round to back up his insults — which he did, earning $100 in the process.
lead_paragraph: The Ryder Cup had not yet started.

headline: Taking the Plunge
abstract: James Mulhern delivers a lively Friday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — It’s Friday and the living is, if not easy, at least theme-free and fairly open in terms of white space.

headline: Review: ‘13TH,’ the Journey From Shackles to Prison Bars
keywords: ['New York Film Festival', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Thirteenth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Slavery (Historical)', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Movies']
abstract: Ms. DuVernay makes a startling and powerful statement about the prison industrial complex and the history of black lives in post-Jim-Crow America.
lead_paragraph: Powerful, infuriating and at times overwhelming, Ava DuVernay’s documentary “13TH” will get your blood boiling and tear ducts leaking. It shakes you up, but it also challenges your ideas about the intersection of race, justice and mass incarceration in the United States, subject matter that could not sound less cinematic. Yet Ms. DuVernay — best known for “Selma,” and a filmmaker whose art has become increasingly inseparable from her activism — has made a movie that’s as timely as the latest Black Lives Matter protest and the approaching presidential election.

headline: Review: ‘The Encounter’ Is a High-Tech Head Trip Through an Amazon Labyrinth
abstract: Simon McBurney’s astonishing one-man show, from the British troupe Complicite, immerses the audience in an aural landscape where time and space collapse.
lead_paragraph: See that scruffy-looking guy up there on the stage, the one messing around with the microphones and the plastic water bottles? It turns out that he’s a world-class head shrinker — and head enlarger, too, an all-purpose mind-bender. He is going to retune, rearrange and reproportion your senses, while taking you places you never expected to visit.

headline: Harvard Hires New Endowment Manager From Columbia
abstract: The appointment of N.P. Narvekar, who has overseen the impressive growth of Columbia’s endowment, follows several years of lagging returns for Harvard’s investments.
lead_paragraph: Harvard has brought in a new manager from Columbia University to run its $36 billion endowment, the largest of any university.

headline: Richard D. Trentlage, 87, Who Wrote ‘The Oscar Mayer Wiener Song,’ Dies
abstract: Mr. Trentlage’s may not be a household name, but generations know his work writing advertising jingles for companies such as Oscar Mayer and McDonald’s.
lead_paragraph: The name Richard D. Trentlage may not roll off the tongues of most Americans, but generations of them, for good or ill, can no doubt sing along with some of the catchiest advertising jingles that he wrote for companies like Oscar Mayer and McDonald’s.

headline: Yankees Eliminated From Postseason Contention Despite Beating Red Sox

lead_paragraph: The last faint ember of hope was snuffed out on an unusual Yankees season Thursday night. Perhaps appropriately considering the upside-down nature of their 2016 campaign, it came during a win.

lead_paragraph: Rosetta, the first spacecraft to orbit a comet, is dead, setting down in a final embrace with its companion of the past two years.

headline: Danny Fields Loved Punk Rock. It Loved Him Back.

abstract: Two new documentaries spotlight this music manager, whose acts included the Stooges and the Ramones.
lead_paragraph: In certain circles, Danny Fields is a mythical figure. He’s a rock ’n’ roll mover, shaker, influencer and scene maker — a Harvard Law School dropout who eventually fell in with Andy Warhol’s Factory crowd and went on to manage the Stooges and the Ramones. And yet, when it came time to watch Brendan Toller’s new documentary, “Danny Says,” about his life, Mr. Fields had to brace himself.

lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — From across the ocean and across the Green Line, they came on Friday to the mountaintop sanctuary of Mount Herzl to bid farewell to Shimon Peres, marking what one called the “end of the era of giants.” But the question of the moment was whether it was a funeral for a man or for his dream.
