Trump Foundation and chairman of the relatively large Trump Organization. Although the foundation is a charitable organization, it appears to have been used for less than charitable purposes.

headline: The Death of Idealism
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Baby Boomers', 'Nineteen Hundred Eighties', 'Nineteen Hundred Sixties']
abstract: It’s sad to see how the promise of the decades when Clinton and Trump established themselves has aged.
lead_paragraph: This presidential election is a contest between the oldest of the baby boomers. Yet Donald Trump, 70, and Hillary Clinton, 68, represent two very different decades in the formation of that generation. Donald Trump became famous as a classic 1980s type, while Hillary Clinton first attained public notice as a classic 1960s type.

headline: Candidate Obama Kept His Promise to Native Americans
abstract: Although some issues are unsettled, the president has done a commendable job of serving the American Indian community.
lead_paragraph: President Obama campaigned hard in 2008 for the votes of American Indians. He vowed that his administration would pay special attention to their grievances about federal mismanagement and the government’s recurring neglect of treaty obligations. “Few have been ignored by Washington for as long as Native Americans — the first Americans,” he told the Crow Nation in Montana, promising a change.

headline: Fat-Shamer in Chief
abstract: With little more than a month to go until the election, Donald Trump finds himself in a very public fight with a beauty queen. Sigh.
lead_paragraph: Apparently, millions of Americans don’t care that a man now within a nose-hair of the presidency may be the most prolific liar in modern political history. Nor do they care about the authoritarian policies he espouses, his truly scary embrace of dictators abroad and crackpots at home, or his monumental ignorance on every subject.

headline: How the Clinton-Trump Race Got Close
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Debates (Political)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Hillary Clinton was hurt by hostile reporting from the mainstream media.
lead_paragraph: Monday’s presidential debate was a blowout, surely the most one-sided confrontation in American political history. Hillary Clinton was knowledgeable, unflappable and — dare we say it? — likable. Donald Trump was ignorant, thin-skinned and boorish.

headline: Why It’s Safe to Scrap America’s ICBMs

abstract: These missiles are expensive and dangerous holdovers from a long-gone era. It’s time to phase them out.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, Russia and the United States have started rebuilding their Cold War nuclear arsenals, putting the world on the threshold of a dangerous new arms race. But we don’t have to repeat the perilous drama of the 20th century. We can maintain our country’s strength and security and still do away with the worst of the Cold War weapons.

headline: How to Walk in High Heels
abstract: Shop in brick-and-mortar stores. Don’t obsess over mechanics.
lead_paragraph: Start with the right shoes. Finding them should be not unlike finding a lover. “Go toward the thing that excites you the most,” says Alexandra Billings, a transgender actress and theater-arts professor at California State University, Long Beach, who plays the role of mentor to Jeffrey Tambor’s character on “Transparent.” Billings does all her shoe shopping in brick-and-mortar stores, never online. “You’ve got to walk around in them, touch them, spend some time,” she says. Feel even the hint of a pinched toe or wobble? Take them off. You cannot be your true self if you’re in pain. Plus, Billings says, “nobody wants to see you fall.”

headline: Lousy Libidos: Why Do Pandas Have So Little Sex?

headline: In Formula One, the First Few Seconds Can Decide a Race

abstract: As investors’ concerns of another crisis are stoked, the arithmetic is less important than fears about the impotence of European authorities.

Yet the biggest source of worry is less about its finances than a vast tangle of unknowns — not least, whether Europe can muster the will to mount a rescue in the event of an emergency.

headline: So Just Who Are These Undecided Voters?

headline: Review: ‘Westworld’ Is a Provocative but Flawed Sci-Fi Shoot-’Em-Up
abstract: Watching this new HBO show can be like playing a virtual reality game, and that’s what the Westworld theme park is; that meta aspect becomes provocative.
lead_paragraph: In HBO’s “Westworld,” Dr. Robert Ford (Anthony Hopkins) runs a theme park where wealthy “guests” live out frontier fantasies among lifelike robot “hosts.” In the fourth episode, a colleague points out to him what viewers will have already noticed: Those fantasies almost uniformly involve murder, rape or torture.

headline: 1891: Boulanger Commits Suicide
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: General Boulanger commits suicide in Brussels in October 1891.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — At noon today [Sept. 30] the rumor spread like wildfire throughout Brussels that General Boulanger had committed suicide. What first appeared like a joke was soon afterwards confirmed. The Herald correspondent can also vouch for the fact that his funds were getting very low, and that his appeals for financial aid to his old friends had of late been quite in vain. This morning, at eleven o’clock, after breakfasting with his nieces, he ordered his carriage and drove to the cemetery.

headline: Posting Political Signs in the Window Is Your Right — Isn’t It?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Political Advertising', 'Signs and Signage', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Cooperatives', 'Condominiums', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Rules in many apartment buildings prevent residents from proclaiming their views.
lead_paragraph: In July, Rebecca and Shirley Solomon, two sisters who have shared a TriBeCa loft for the better part of 40 years, hung a sign in their window for Hillary Clinton. In other election years, they had hung signs for Barack Obama and placards opposing George W. Bush and the Iraq war. But this time, their exercise in political engagement was thwarted.

headline: As America Sleeps, Donald Trump Seethes on Twitter
abstract: In the predawn hours on Friday, the Republican presidential nominee took to Twitter to continue his attacks on both Hillary Clinton and Alicia Machado.
lead_paragraph: The tweets started around 3:20 a.m. on Friday. Inside Trump Tower, a restless figure stirred in the predawn darkness, nursing his grievances and grabbing a device that often lands him in hot water.

headline: Brands to Ad Agencies: Diversify or Else

lead_paragraph: The advertising industry has tried for decades with little success to shed its “Mad Men”-like reputation as a profession dominated by white men. Now, some of the world’s biggest brands are viewing that lack of diversity as a liability.

headline: Over 100 Children Among 338 Killed in Aleppo Attacks This Week, W.H.O. Says
abstract: The World Health Organization said it feared many more would die from lack of treatment at hospitals destroyed or damaged by the government’s airstrikes.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — An array of groups allied with the Syrian government pressed an assault on rebel-held eastern Aleppo on Friday, as the World Health Organization said heavy bombardment of the area by Russia and Syria had killed 338 people in the last week, including more than 100 children.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — Few people could have predicted the first policy on which Britain’s new prime minister would take a stand. It is none of the issues that have dominated British politics in recent months: Brexit, immigration, terrorism. Rather, Theresa May has decided it is to be grammar schools.

lead_paragraph: ANGELINA JOLIE’S decision to file for divorce from Brad Pitt was certainly a blow to many fans of the Hollywood couple. But because the couple has six children, homes around the world, assets in the tens of millions of dollars and hard-to-value royalty income for years to come, their split offers an opportunity to look at how other wealthy couples manage their divorces.

lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Review: ‘Pandaemonium’ Gives Unhappiness a Light Touch
abstract: The show, a hybrid of physical theater and cinema directed by Lars Jan, at New York Live Arts, offers a musical window on a silent couple.
lead_paragraph: Somewhere in the American desert, a man and a woman recline on beach chairs under a drive-in movie screen. Something is not right between them. Soon, she’ll break out divorce papers; he’ll break out the booze. It’s a scene of emptiness and estrangement. But in “Pandaemonium,” a clever hybrid of physical theater and cinema that had its local debut at New York Live Arts on Wednesday, much of the alienation is treated lightly. When the show is working, the unhappiness is enjoyable.

headline: The Case for Shirley Jackson

lead_paragraph: SHIRLEY JACKSONA Rather Haunted LifeBy Ruth FranklinIllustrated. 607 pp. Liveright Publishing. $35.

headline: One English Village’s New Garden Retreat
abstract: Wilderness Reserve, a 5,000-acre estate dotted with an idiosyncratic set of rentable lodgings, introduces its newest place to stay.
lead_paragraph: In an English village, just inland from the rugged Suffolk coast, something close to Arcadia is being created. Under the watch of the revered British landscape artist Kim Wilkie, three historic estates — Heveningham, Sibton Park and Cockfield Hall — are being slowly re-imagined as one luxurious rural retreat. “The idea is to take what have been rather run-down and fractured places, where ownership has been split up, and restore them to what was a very balanced and harmonious whole,” says Wilkie of Wilderness Reserve, a 5,000-acre expanse of pasture, lake and woodland that’s dotted with an idiosyncratic set of rentable lodgings. Now the already up-for-rent Moat Cottage, Cartshed and electricity-free Hex Cottage have been joined by the Walled Garden, a palatial eight-bedroom bolthole wrought from one of Suffolk’s few surviving walled kitchen gardens.

You guys are so smart. This is the eighth book in Bradley’s series about a precocious adolescent chemist-slash-sleuth, and here’s how Booklist describes the story:

headline: A Civil War Classic Endures
abstract: MacKinlay Kantor’s “Andersonville,” an epic novel about the notorious Confederate prisoner of war camp in Georgia, won the Pulitzer Prize in 1956.
lead_paragraph: The cover of the Book Review on Oct. 30, 1955, was split in two. On one side, the historian Henry Steele Commager reviewed MacKinlay Kantor’s “Andersonville,” calling it “the greatest of our Civil War novels.” On the other side, Kantor himself wrote an essay about the more than two decades he spent researching and writing his densely peopled 750-page epic about the notoriously inhumane Confederate prisoner of war camp in Georgia. The book, which won the Pulitzer Prize in 1956, was recently republished in a new edition.

headline: After Van Gogh Recoveries, Remembering Other Tales of Art Lost and Found
abstract: Two missing paintings by the Dutch master were recovered this week, a rare event. Here are a few other stolen works that were retrieved.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Two missing van Gogh paintings were recovered this week in Italy, nearly 14 years after being stolen from an Amsterdam museum. “Only 5 to 10 percent of stolen art ever returns, so it’s very good that they got these back,” Arthur Brand, a Dutch independent art crimes investigator, said. Here is a sampling of other masterworks that have been lost, and improbably found:

headline: The Latest and Best in Crime Fiction
abstract: New books by Karin Fossum, Harlan Coben, Charles Todd and Sharon Bolton.
lead_paragraph: Karin Fossum may be the most unsentimental crime novelist since Ruth Rendell’s alter ego, Barbara Vine. On the very first page of HELL FIRE (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $24), a young mother and her 4-year-old son lie dead of multiple stab wounds in the ramshackle little trailer in the Norwegian woods where they had spent the night. Not far into the story, we’re introduced to a character who, we’ll very soon deduce, is almost certainly the killer. Surprisingly, anticipating the ending doesn’t destroy the suspense; in fact, imagining the horror that awaits actually increases our sense of dread.

headline: Pittsburgh Symphony Musicians Go on Strike
abstract: This weekend’s concerts have been canceled in the latest bout of labor unrest in the orchestra world.
lead_paragraph: A new bout of labor unrest hit the classical music world on Friday when the musicians of the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra went on strike after rejecting a management proposal they said would cut their pay, freeze their pensions and reduce the orchestra’s size.

headline: 1966: Caribbean Hurricane Kills 110
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Hundreds of people die in Haiti and the Dominican Republic after the Hurricane Inez hits the Caribbean in October 1891.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Haiti and the Dominican Republic suffered hundreds of deaths and disastrous destruction from Hurricane Inez, first reports indicated today [Sept. 30]. The killer Hurricane then slashed across eastern Cuba on a course aimed at the Bahamas. A government spokesman for the Dominican Republic late today listed 110 known dead. The casualty toll was expected to grow higher. An air-force spokesman said several small cities in the interior had not been heard from.

headline: Daily Report: Trust Busters Destined to Dig into Data
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Artificial Intelligence', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: European regulators look at Microsoft’s purchase of LinkedIn not for what it is, but for what may be. They are right to.
lead_paragraph: European regulators may be starting to regard antitrust in the tech industry in the light of the famous line about pornography: They can’t define it, but they know it when they see it.

headline: How to Get Dior’s Youthful, Luminous Beauty Look
abstract: It’s easy: just a little primer, foundation and powder, to match a tomboyish collection.
lead_paragraph: For her debut collection as Dior’s new creative director, Maria Grazia Chiuri wanted to make a soft — but powerful — statement with the makeup look this season. “She wanted to do something really young,” said the makeup artist Peter Philips about his first collaboration with the designer. That sensibility translated to glowing, luminous skin, with little interference.

headline: Why Won’t Midcentury Design Die?
abstract: It’s a design trend that has lasted longer than many others. There are good reasons for that, although designers say some clichés should be banished.
lead_paragraph: In 1998, The New York Times noted a new design trend. Cool creative types were tossing aside their thrift store décor in favor of midcentury modern. Out went the funky votive candles and wrought-iron beds, and in came the clean-lined furniture of Arne Jacobsen, Eero Saarinen, Charles and Ray Eames, and Florence Knoll. The look’s adherents were labeled “Generation Wallpaper,” after the magazine.

headline: It’s Auctions vs. Galleries
abstract: Facing a glut, art dealers hold the line even as prices fall at auction.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “Frieze Week,” which begins here on Monday, is a uniquely frantic moment in the art-world calendar. At no other time does such a concentration of high-quality fairs, auctions and dealer shows jostle for the attention — and spending — of the world’s art collectors.

headline: Poor, Transgender and Dressed for Arrest
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Prostitution', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Loitering', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Hispanic-Americans']
abstract: When bourgeois women talk about the policing of female sexuality, they are often speaking in metaphors, but poor women are frequently talking about something literal.
lead_paragraph: Measured in terms of cultural attention, it can seem like a very enlightened time to be living with an unconventional gender identity. The rights of transgender people have been a concern of presidential politics; “Transparent,” the comedy about a middle-aged male political scientist in the process of becoming female, is popular and in its third season; gender-neutral bathrooms are on the rise, and opposition to them puts challengers in the position of seeming benighted and cranky, as though they hankered for a world still dominated by three television networks.

lead_paragraph: New bathrooms don’t come cheap.

headline: Roy Moore, Alabama Chief Justice, Suspended Over Gay Marriage Order
keywords: ['Supreme Courts (State)', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Chief Justice Moore was suspended for the remainder of his term for ordering Alabama’s probate judges to defy federal court orders on same-sex marriage licenses.
lead_paragraph: Nine months after instructing Alabama’s probate judges to defy federal court orders on same-sex marriage, Roy S. Moore, the chief justice of the Alabama Supreme Court, was suspended on Friday for the remainder of his term for violating the state’s canon of judicial ethics.

headline: Ode to Milkweed: Seemingly Everywhere, Yet Overlooked
abstract: The plant, which performs free urban renewal, is considered a wild edible, and can even be used as insulation, deserves more attention.
lead_paragraph: If there is any plant that deserves more attention, it is the common milkweed. The plant can reach an impressive five feet tall — and it often grows in tidy groups, performing cost-free urban renewal as it transforms neglected fields into attractive green refuges.

headline: How to Take Legal Recourse When Dodging Food Delivery Motorbikes Fails
keywords: ['Delivery Services', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: This installment of F.Y.I. explores the rules and regulations governing the use of electric motorbikes in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Q. I’m all for fast food — the faster, the better. But if one of these deliverymen for New York restaurants and groceries on their little electric motorbikes runs me down, what is my legal recourse? They have no license plates or signs indicating the business they are delivering for. Do they have insurance? If one hits me, whom do I sue? The poor working person riding the bike, or the business he or she works for?

headline: The Right to Sue — Restored
keywords: ['ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION', 'Consumer Protection', 'Elder Care', 'Elderly', 'Medicare', 'Nursing Homes', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']

lead_paragraph: We are permitted to heat up the kitchen now that the weather is cooling down. Not that boiling water for pasta will raise the temperature significantly. But there’s a shift of focus and an urge to fill the room with autumn aromas.

headline: Polls Show Debate Performance Gave Hillary Clinton a Lift

lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton’s strong debate performance has lifted her standing in a handful of battleground state polls, an indication that her first face-off against Donald J. Trump halted the surge he was enjoying for much of September.

headline: Embarking on a Two-Year Pop-Up Kitchen, Around the World
abstract: One Star House Party will pop up in cities like Taipei, Seoul, New York and more.
lead_paragraph: “If you do a pop-up restaurant in Hong Kong, and 400 people come to it, you’ll meet enough people to open 20 restaurants in 20 countries,” says the nomadic 25-year old English chef James Sharman, as he huddles over a makeshift bamboo table. He’s in the vacant basement of Beijing’s Opposite House hotel, where his traveling dinner series, One Star House Party, will begin to put that theory to practice over the next two years.

headline: A Choreographer’s Loft, Where ‘There’s History in the Walls’
abstract: Cathy Weis, a choreographer and video artist, lets artists “try things out” in the low-stakes setting of her large SoHo studio.
lead_paragraph: The easiest way to find Cathy Weis’s loft, on Broadway between Prince and Spring Streets, is to use retail as your compass: Locate the signs for Guess and Lucky Brand Jeans. Tucked between those stores — on the same block as Lacoste, Hugo Boss, Uniqlo, Club Monaco and Sephora — is the much less conspicuous door to 537 Broadway.

headline: Supreme Court v. the American Voter
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Minorities', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']

lead_paragraph: This year’s election will be the first in over 50 years without the full protection of the Voting Rights Act.

headline: Who Gets to Vote?
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Law and Legislation', 'States (US)', 'Identification Devices', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Minorities', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: Voter ID laws strike at the rights and dignity of racial minorities and the poor. But there is another, more inclusive way.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, you’ve needed a scorecard to keep track of voting laws in the United States. For nearly a decade, Republican-dominated state legislatures have been churning out strict voter ID laws and other measures likely to reduce access to the ballot box. But the pace of activity quickened after June 2013, when the Supreme Court disabled a vital provision of the Voting Rights Act, the so-called preclearance provision, opening the door to restrictive legislation in the nine states (and parts of six others) that had been covered by the law.

headline: Steve Reich at 80: Still Plugged In, Still Plugging Away
abstract: The composer, whose latest work will have its premiere on Nov. 1 at Carnegie Hall, muses about the trade-offs of technology.
lead_paragraph: Caught between Netflix binges and digital detoxes, Americans can’t decide whether they love or hate technology. Despite being a pioneer of electronic music, the composer Steve Reich has maintained a similar ambivalence throughout his long career. Decades before the Grammy- and Pulitzer-winning heyday that has made him one of this country’s most renowned artists, Mr. Reich struggled with the very technology that first brought him fame.

headline: Review: A Delicious ‘Rosenkavalier’ in Boston

lead_paragraph: BOSTON — In a city regularly starved of quality opera, Andris Nelsons’s habit of conducting Strauss with his Boston Symphony Orchestra can only be welcome. First there was “Salome,” then a smoldering “Elektra” with Christine Goerke last year. And, on Thursday at Symphony Hall here, a delectable “Der Rosenkavalier.”

headline: Shimon Peres: Not Just a Man of Peace
abstract: In Israel, the late president is best known for his contributions to the military, not for the Oslo agreement.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Shimon Peres, who died Wednesday at 93, was laid to rest as an Israeli prince of peace. Leaders from around the world came to Jerusalem to pay their respects to Israel’s eldest statesman, a defense minister, prime minister, president and more, who ended his long life as a symbol of his country’s quest for reconciliation with the Palestinians.

headline: The Sex-Ed Queens of YouTube Don’t Need a Ph.D.
abstract: A young online generation of advisers on sex and relationships is using the internet to get their message out. Their lack of credentials is a plus.
lead_paragraph: The video opens inside a 20-something’s starter apartment: novelty string lights, overstuffed armchair, red accent wall. A young woman with black-framed glasses and a lip stud sits in front of the camera, the shot framed so tightly on her face that it cuts off the top of her head. Press “play,” and she careens into a riddle. “What bleeds every month without dying, produces pleasure and can push out entire human beings?” She raises her hands to the sky. Her eyes flash wildly. “It’s the one! The only!” Her voice rumbles toward the finish. “Vagina!”

headline: A Co-op Overlooking Central Park for $11.75 Million

headline: How Jennifer Vaughan Maanavi, Co-Founder of Physique 57, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Ms. Maanavi’s hectic day includes working for her global fitness company, attending to her children’s soccer games and finding 15 minutes of “quiet time.”
lead_paragraph: As the chief executive and co-founder of the ballet barre studio chain Physique 57 and a mother of three, Jennifer Vaughan Maanavi has a full schedule. A former Morgan Stanley employee, she now oversees nine Physique 57 locations, from Bangkok to New York, in addition to attending her children’s soccer games and ballet classes and fitting in a few date nights with her husband. Ms. Maanavi, 45, lives in an Upper East Side apartment with her husband, Dar Maanavi, 50, who works in trade finance and commodities, and their children, Alec, 12, Halle, 7, and Cameron, 4.

headline: Orioles Deliver a Seventh-Inning Message: This Song Is Their Song
abstract: The regular playing of “This Land Is Your Land” is a subtle reminder from Orioles management that at the intersection of sports and patriotism, one size does not have to fit all.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — In the middle of the seventh inning of the Baltimore Orioles’ game against the Arizona Diamondbacks two Friday nights ago, the public-address announcer asked the crowd at Camden Yards to stand and celebrate America’s diversity. Three singers then stood on the first-base dugout and did a rendition of “This Land Is Your Land,” the famous folk song written by Woody Guthrie.

headline: Women Fill New York City Ballet’s Season With Splendor
abstract: The company’s fall season has been bounteous with repertory by its founder-choreographer, George Balanchine, and features exciting performances.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to tear yourself away from New York City Ballet just now, in particular from its many excellent ballerinas. The company, almost halfway through its four-week fall season, is being characteristically bounteous with repertory by its founder-choreographer, George Balanchine, which in turn is bounteous with ballerina roles. A few of the women cast in Balanchine parts are too tame, too weak, too passive; but all the troupe’s three ranks (principal, soloist, corps) contain women whose vivid individuality excites. Two in particular — Tiler Peck and Sara Mearns — set peak standards of musicality that enrich the entire art, showing the mysterious connection between space and music at its most fascinating.

headline: A Quest to Gather All My Medical Records in 72 Hours
keywords: ['Electronic Health Records', 'Personal Finances', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicine and Health', 'Doctors']
abstract: Most people have seen many doctors over many years, so compiling complete medical records would be a nightmare, experts say. But why not try?
lead_paragraph: When Donald Trump challenged Hillary Clinton to a medical records disclosure throwdown not long ago, my colleague Margot Sanger-Katz wrote an article pointing out that there’s often no such thing as a complete medical dossier on anyone.

lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Harry Belafonte: ‘Movements Don’t Die’
keywords: ['Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Music', 'Celebrities', 'Festivals']
abstract: The singer, actor and civil rights leader reflects on his work ahead of a festival in the Atlanta area that focuses on voting and mass incarceration.
lead_paragraph: During his seven-decade career, Harry Belafonte has been a singer, an actor, a friend to Martin Luther King Jr., a Unicef good-will ambassador, an anti-apartheid activist and more. “I’m at a time of life when I’m examining the entire journey,” he said one recent afternoon at his Manhattan home, lamenting how the dreams of the civil rights movement are far from realized. “When I was 20 and 30, my visions for what the world would be, all things were possible.”

lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 collection.

headline: Translating Shakespeare? 36 Playwrights Taketh the Big Risk
abstract: The Oregon Shakespeare Festival has challenged playwrights to translate Shakespeare into modern English, while hewing to the rule “Do no harm.”
lead_paragraph: Ashland, Ore. — Since 1935, this mountain town has been home to the Oregon Shakespeare Festival, whose guiding spirit is present not just onstage, but also in the names of businesses like Oberon’s Tavern and the All’s Well Herb and Vitamin Shop.

headline: Canada Today: Cruising, Royals, BlackBerrys and Blueberries
abstract: The recent sailing of the 1,700-passenger Crystal Serenity through the Northwest Passage has prompted calls for limiting the size of ships in the Canadian Arctic.
lead_paragraph: We’re trying something new: Canada Today, a weekly roundup for Canadian readers and anyone else interested in the True North. Tell us what you think and what you’d like to see, at CanadaToday@nytimes.com. And, using the link below, please subscribe to the email newsletter version.

headline: At Carnegie Deli in Manhattan, Just 3 Months of Pastramis to Go
abstract: The well-known kosher-style restaurant, more a magnet for tourists than for New Yorkers, is shutting down at the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: Live in New York long enough and you will lose somewhere you love. Good things die here. It’s what keeps the place alive.

headline: New York International Fringe Festival Will Skip 2017
abstract: Organizers of the summer festival, which has been produced for 20 years, say the hiatus will be used to reconsider the festival’s mission.
lead_paragraph: Over the past 20 summers, the New York International Fringe Festival has shepherded 3,680 productions onto downtown stages, 193 of them this August alone. But performance spaces in Greenwich Village and the Lower East Side may be seeking new tenants next year. In a move that officials hastened to say was not a precursor to its demise, the festival — popularly known as FringeNYC — is taking 2017 off.

headline: New Jersey Will Increase Gas Tax 23¢, Ending Long Political Stalemate
keywords: ['Gasoline Tax (US)', 'Railroad Accidents and Safety', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Transit Systems']
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie said an agreement with legislative leaders would also trim the sales tax rate and phase out the estate tax.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie, who has long resisted raising any taxes, has battled with Democratic leaders since early summer over raising New Jersey’s gas tax, reaching an impasse that brought hundreds of highway and transit projects to a standstill that lasted months.

headline: The Mystery of Trump’s Suits, Solved
abstract: Yes, the Republican nominee wears Brioni — as well as suits by the Brooklyn tailor Martin Greenfield.
lead_paragraph: The press took note when Hillary Clinton wore pantsuits from the American label Ralph Lauren at the Democratic National Convention and at the first presidential debate. But the brands favored by her opponent, Donald J. Trump, have slipped under the radar.

headline: What the Alicia Machado Story Reveals About Donald Trump
keywords: ['Beauty Contests', 'Debates (Political)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: When someone criticizes him, he can’t let it go.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton’s introduction of Alicia Machado at the end of the first presidential debate was a stroke of genius. Donald Trump, she noted, had referred to the 1996 Miss Universe winner as “Miss Piggy” and “Miss Housekeeping.” “Donald,” said Mrs. Clinton, “she has a name.”

headline: No Debate That Hillary Clinton’s Polling Numbers Are Improving
abstract: The durability of her post-debate bump is another matter.
lead_paragraph: The post-debate polls are beginning to trickle in, and it already seems clear that Hillary Clinton has received a bump after the first presidential debate.

headline: New York Tonight: Train Crash Updates and Carnegie Deli News
abstract: What you need to know about the investigation into the train crash, and the closing of a beloved city deli.
lead_paragraph: Good evening on this drippy-droopy Friday.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Amazon Creates 3 Games for Twitch Fans
abstract: The releases, which will weave features from the popular streaming video service into the gaming experience, are Amazon’s first games aimed at hard-core players.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Amazon paid about $1 billion two years ago to acquire Twitch, the streaming video service with a fanatical following among gamers. Now the company is using Twitch to start a deeper push into the video game business.

headline: In Deposition, Donald Trump Says Illegal Immigration Led to Nomination
abstract: Mr. Trump made the comments while being questioned as part of his lawsuit against the celebrity chef Geoffrey Zakarian for backing out of a restaurant in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump is often seen at rallies or on reality television or across from a journalist. But on Friday, a Washington judge made public video showing Mr. Trump in a far more subdued setting: the deposition room.

headline: Met Picasso Belonged to Family That Fled Nazis, Suit Says
keywords: ['Wills and Estates', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Art']
abstract: Lawyers for the estate of Paul Leffmann say persecution by the Nazis led him to sell a painting.
lead_paragraph: The estate of a German Jewish businessman sued the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Friday in an effort to claim one of its most valuable Picassos, “The Actor,” asserting in court papers that the museum does not hold good title to the painting because the businessman was forced to sell it at a low price after fleeing the Nazis.

headline: The Remarriage of Edie Windsor, a Gay Marriage Pioneer
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Weddings and Engagements']
abstract: Edie Windsor, the veteran L.G.B.T. activist who emerged as a central figure in the marriage equality movement, has gotten married again.
lead_paragraph: Edie Windsor, the veteran L.G.B.T. activist who emerged as arguably the most famous figure in the marriage equality movement, has gotten married again.

headline: Children Who Get Zika After Birth Tend Not to Fall Seriously Ill, Study Finds
abstract: A study by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention involving teenagers and toddlers was a rare bright spot in the epidemic.
lead_paragraph: Serious complications are rare among children infected with the Zika virus after birth, federal health researchers concluded in a study published on Friday — a rare bright spot in the unfolding story of the epidemic.

headline: Bias Suit Filed on Behalf of Disabled Men in South Carolina Meat Plant
abstract: The lawsuit comes after a Times investigation found that several older men with intellectual disability were living in virtual segregation in a seedy bunkhouse in Newberry, S.C.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, several older men with intellectual disability were found living in virtual segregation in a seedy bunkhouse in South Carolina, across the street from the massive meat-processing plant where they once worked. One man was still working at the plant, disposing of the D.O.A.’s — that is, the poultry that arrived on trucks already dead.

headline: Redstones Await Response From CBS on Merger Request
abstract: A day after the family stated its desire to merge Viacom with CBS, Viacom formed an independent board committee to consider the move.
lead_paragraph: A day after the Redstone family formally called for a reunification of its media empire, meaning a merger of CBS and Viacom, Viacom has unveiled an independent board committee to review the proposal.

headline: Curtis Roosevelt, a White House Charmer as a Child, Dies at 86
abstract: He and his sister were well known to Americans when they lived with their mother and grandparents in the White House in the 1930s.
lead_paragraph: Curtis Roosevelt, who with his sister, Eleanor, charmed Americans in the mid-1930s as Buzzie and Sistie, the towheaded children who lived in the White House with their grandparents Franklin D. and Eleanor Roosevelt, died on Monday at his home in St.-Bonnet-du-Gard, France. He was 86.

headline: 2 Men Who Found Bomb in Chelsea Are Identified as Airline Security Guards
abstract: The men, who found a travel bag containing the bomb last month, serve as unarmed guards on EgyptAir flights, officials at the carrier said.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Two men who found a travel bag containing a bomb on a Manhattan street last month — and then walked off with the bag but left the bomb — were not just employees of EgyptAir but in-flight security officers for the carrier, two officials at the airline said on Friday.

headline: Status of Jets Receiver Eric Decker Is Week to Week
abstract: After sustaining a partially torn rotator cuff in a Week 2 victory over the Buffalo Bills, Decker aggravated the injury the next week against the Kansas City Chiefs.
lead_paragraph: The Jets know that Eric Decker will miss Sunday’s game against the Seattle Seahawks with a partly torn rotator cuff. What they do not know is whether Decker will be able to return the following week at Pittsburgh, or even at some point later this season.

headline: N.H.L. Sees the World Cup of Hockey as a Coup
abstract: N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman said that more editions of the event would follow but that the format might change.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — The N.H.L. viewed the World Cup of Hockey as a marketing and competitive success after a 12-year absence.
